title: U.S., in Gesture to Peking, Drops Jet Sale to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Carter Administration, in anether move to improve ties with China, has scrapped plan to SE11 60 F4 fighterbombers to Taiwan, officials said today.

title: Outlook for Farms and Food Prices
description: CHICAGO, June 30  Terry Francl, a former agricultural economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, now serves in a similar capacity for the Continental Illinois National Bank, an institution that has long kept a close watch on farm conditions. At Continental, his role is to keep abreast both of producers' changing fortunes and of the effects of farm conditions on consumers. In an interview, he discussed both fields and also touched on the business conditions facing farm suppliers.

title: BELL NOT EXPECTED TO SURRENDER FILES
description: WASHINGTON, June 30With Attorney General Griffin B. Bell saving only  that he had anticipated the threat by a Federal judge to hold him in contempt his chief spokesman said this evening that Mr. Bell and his aides did not expect the ruling to make the Attorney General change his position and turn over files on 18 informers used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Judge Threatening A Contempt Action For Bell Over Files
description: A Federal judge c:oe'ared yesterday that Attorney General Gr:ffin B. Bell would automatical:y be in civil contempt of court if he failed to release Government files on 18 informers by Friday.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Cotton futures rose in price yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, possibly because of traders expectations that farmers would plant anywhere from 12.4 million to 12.9 million acres.

title: P.B.A. Aids Family Of Good Samaritz.
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday sent a check for a:most S65,000 to the family of Paul Schumacher, who was stabbed to death last March when he tried to retrieve an elderly woman's purse from a thief in Btooldvn.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Rockthrowing vandals, who have been plaguing a quiet neighborhood in Hazlet with nightly barrages for three weeks, Thursday night hurled pieces of driveway asphalt at the home of a police officer who has been investigating the vandalism.

title: Jackson Hits Grand Slam Gullett Strong
description: With an assist from the American League schedulemaker, who gave them a day off Thursday, the refreshed Yankees rebounded from their wearisome, whirlwind trip to Milwaukee and erupted for a 102 victory over the Detroit Tigers last night.

title: Iowa Drinking Age Raised to 19
description: DES MOINES, June 30 (AP)Citing grim statistics involving 18 year  old drinking drivers, Gov. Robert Ray last flight signed a bill raising Iowa's legal drinking age from 18 to 19. Aiding his decision to sign the bill, Mr. Ray said, were statistics showing that the proportion of 18yearold drinking drivers inyolved in fatal crashes increased during the years the drinking age was lowered.

title: News Summary
description: Measures to restrain the arms race were approved by the United Nations General Assembly, which agreed on replacing the 16yearold Geneva Disarmament Conference with a larger negotiating body. These agreements were contained in a final document. adopted without a vote. Like all Asaembly decisions, the document is not binding on the 149 members. [Page 1, Columns 34].

title: U.S. ORDERS A HALT TOWORK AT SEABROOK
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Construction of the controversial nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., was ordered suspended by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission tonight on a vote of 2 to 1.

title: Shift of Rockies to Jersey Faces Snags
description: The proposed shift of the National Hockey League's Colorado Rockies to New Jersey, after a twoyear stopover at Madison Square Garden, hit several snags yesterday.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  Every day, hundreds of shoppers wander through the New Renovation Department Store in Libreville, Gabon, a mere 10,000 miles from South Korea as the jet flies.

title: 2 Bands Led By Brubecks And Mulligan
description: Gerry Mulligan, who was scheduled to appear at the Newport Jazz Festival this year with a quartet, showed up at Carnegie Hall Thursday night leading a 13piece big band. He introduced it as a present to George Wein, Newport's producer, on the 25th anniversary of the festival, but one could tell by his enthusiasm that he was also giving a present to himself.

title: Franc Soars Amid Talk of Float
description: PARIS, June 30  The French franc surged on European currency markets today after strengthening gradually all week on speculation that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing plans to link it soon to the strong West German mark in a joint float against the weakening American dollar.

title: 9% Loan Cost Highest Since January 1975
description: The prime lending rate was increased yesterday to 9 percent from 8% percent by Citibank, New York's largest bank, and other major commercial banks across the country.

title: Torme Croons With Rich's Band
description: Mel Torme, whose jazz credentials have more validity than those of virtually any other popular entertainer  he is a drummer, pianist and arranger, as well as a singer  rescued a Newport Jazz Festival program at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. Despite the presence of Dizzy Gillespie, Stan Getz and Buddy Rich's orchestra, the concert had been wallowing in a mix of loud, fuzzy sound and arrangements that, buried under the welter of sound, seemed undistinguished and monotonously similar.

title: KeyesArcata Accord
description: The Keyes Fibre Company an. nounced that it had reached an agreement with the Arcata National Corporation on principal terms of the previously announced proposal for the acquisition of Keyes by Arcata. Under terms of the acquisition holders of Keyes shares would be entitled to receive in exchange for each share of common one share of a new series of Arcata convertible preferred stock or $28.50. Keyes has about 3.07 million common shares outstanding and the total value of the transaction is based on the cash offer.

title: Samuel Bierman, an Art Expert And Lawyer Who Aided Met
description: Samuel Bierman, an art expert who for 50 years was an adviser to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, other noted museums and collectors, died of a heart attack Thursday night in Mt. Sinai Hospital, He was 76 years old and lived at 125 East 72d Street.

title: Justice Before the Grand Jury
description: From now on, lawyers in New York State will be allowed to accompany clients who have waived immunity from prosecution into the grand jury room. A law signed by Governor Carey last week makes New York the twelfth state to permit this penetration of the grand jury sanctuary, sometimes the scene of prosecutorial abuse and intimidation of witnesses.

title: Miss Watts in New Rubies Role
description: The year is lust one big season for the New York City Ballet, which is still ushering in debuts at the end of its local engagement before going on immediately to its annual stay at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center next week.

description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S A. (5) Pattern for Living

title: Two Loan Rates Raised
description: In two monetary actions, the Federal Reserve discount rate and the commercial bank prime rate were increased yesterday, each by onequarter point. The discount rate was raised to 7 percent and the prime rate to 9 percent, lifting both to their highest levels since January 1975. The crime rate increase was led by Citibank, and it. quickly became industrywide. Page 23.

title: Sports Today
description: Michigan 400 stockcar race, at Michigan International Auto Speedway. A special performance by Nadia Co maneci of the Rumanian gymnastics team, at Strasbourg, France, will also be shown.

title: Amalgamated: Cautious Bank With Union Label
description: Officials at the Amalgamated Bank of New York like to think of the bank as a place for the person of modest means  a legacy, they say, of their labor union heritage.

title: Paul Winter at the Bottom Line
description: We live in a musical era in which the word fusion is all the rage, with musical styles of every sort happily commingling. In one obvious and honorable way, the Paul Winter Consort, which ended a twonight run. Thursday at the Bottom Line, is a prime example of modernday fusion music. But without wishing to be mean about it, and paying due heed to the palpable pleasure the audience derived from Mr. Winter at Thursday's early show, it should never be fogotten that pablum is a fusion food.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOME TEAM New Yorkers are afforded few opportunities to see samplings of art from the Soviet Union. A major exhibition of 63 paintings and graphics representing art trends in that country has just gone on display at the World Trade Center. This is an offs. cially sent exhibition, created by 40 artists in the Soviet Union and selected for showings here by the U.S.S.R.U.S.A. Society in Moscow.

title: DEFENSE CHALLENGES-FINDINGS ON CURARE
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 30The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Maria E. Jascalevich sought to show today that tests could have been in error in giving a positive indication of curare in the exhumed body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: State Homes for Disabled Studied For Effect on RealEstate Values
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 30New York State has begun a discreet survey of 10 suburban communities, half of them in the metropolitan area, to determine if the establishment of group homes for the mentally retarded has any effect on neighborhood realestate values.

title: 130 Hurt as Truck Explodes Near Wall St.

title: The New York Times/Jack Manning
description: 100 YEARS YOUNG: Julius Kahn kissing his wife, Dela, in New York City yesterday as they celebrated her 100th birthday. Mr. Kahn will join his wife as a centenarian on his birthday on Aug. 16. President Carter, Governor Carey and Mayor Koch sent wellwishes to the couple, who will celebrate their 70th wedding anniversary on Sept. 22. The Kahns were born in Frankfurt, Germany, and came to New York in 1940.

title: City Pays Off Its Last Seasonal Loan
description: New York City repaid $207.8, million to the Federal Government yesterday, its final installment under the seasonalloan program, which expired yesterday, one day after the Senate approved a new program of longterm loan guarantees.

title: Richard Walters, Former Head 01 Diamond International Corp.
description: Richard J. Walters, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Diamond International Corporation, died suddenly Wednesday in his home, at 548 Manhasset Woods Road in Manhasset, L.I He was 48 years old.

title: Duryea Mocks Carey Turnabout
description: Perry B. Duryea, the Republican candidate for Governor, yesterday ridiculed Governor Carey's revised position favoring the trial of certain juvenile defendants in adult courts. Mr. Duryea said that the Republicans in the State Legislature stood ready to enact a tough anticrime nackaee at a moment's notice.

title: Oldtimers in Children's Concert.
description: The children's concert at the Newport Jazz Festival this year was called Jazz for the Young and the Young at Heart. The latter phrase presumably included the two performers who took part in the concert yesterday at New York University's Loeb Center  83yearold Alberta Hunter and 95yearold Eubie Blake.

title: News Summary
description: Measures to restrain the arms race were approved by the United Nations General Assembly, which agreed on replacing the 16yearold Geneva Disarmament Conference with a larger negotiating body. These agreements were contained in a final document adopted without a vote. Like all Assembly decisions, the document is not binding on the 149 members. [Page 1, Columns 5].

description: I think things have improved; I do believe that, said Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis of the midtown oasis called Bryant Park. People are not afraid to go there anymore, he said, crediting Capt. William Guildet sen of the Midtown South police precinct. who says that the park is better than e;er thanks to an increased patrol.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY OA IN MAY, PACED BY FOOD AND HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Consumer Price Index climbed by ninetenths of 1 percent in May as food and housing costs again rose rapidly. The brisk rate of inflation, the White House admitted, was not good news.

title: United Press International
description: A GIFT: West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, accepts shield presented to him in Livingstone, Zambia, by Stephen Sicombe, a province leader. Mr. Schmidt also visited Nigeria on this trip.

title: Holiday Traffic Flows Into and Out of City
description: Lugging tennis rackets, swimsuits and rags bulging with vacation paraphernaia, hundreds of thousands of travelers locked into and out of New York City yesterday to begin a long Fourth of July veekend that promised theater and har??? spectacles in the city and quiet reseats and dazzling beaches out of town.

title: Walter Newman, 82, Former Head Of Virginia Polytechnic Institute
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., June 30 (UPI)Walter S. Newman, who headed the Virg;n a Polytechnic Institute during its transition to a major state university, died yesterday at Montgomery Community Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: DORIC (Horne). Left Bermuda June 29; due $ A M. W. 55th Street.

title: Learning From Crown Heights
description: Summer looked as if it might be long and hot in Brooklyn's Crown Heights, where a large black and Hispanic population coexists uneasily with a community of Hasidic Jews. The recent death of a black businessman, allegedly at police hands, and the beating of a black teenager brought anger to the streets. Now calm seems to be returning. Despite advance fears, a merchants street fair last weekend went off peacefully. And an interracial coalition has offered wise proposal: that citizen anticrime patrols be integrated. Still, it is summer; trouble could erupt in minute, in Crown Heights or elsewhere. New Yorkers would do well to come to grips quickly with the hard issues.

description: WASHINGTON, June 30Construction of the controversial nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., was ordered suspended by the Nuclear Regulatciry Commission tonight on a vote of 2 to 1.

title: About New york
description: Kennedy International Airport was a mess of impedimenta Thursday night, with anxious travelers trapped in hot metal clots of auto traffic. They were jammed and crawling so near yet so far from the jetliners that came and went endlessly and grizzled the sky with plumes of jet exhaust.

title: F.B.I. SAID TO VIOLATE LA ON JURY REPORTS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has turned over confidential grand jury information to various Government agencies in violation of the law and against specific orders of Federal prosecutors, Justice Department officials disclosed yesterday.

title: 4Run Rally In 9th Beats Pirates, 65
description: PITTSBURGH, June 30  A crowd of 31,947 turned out tonight to see the Pirates, the Mets and a fireworks show. But the loudest explosion of the evening occurred at home plate in the last of the ninth inning when Dave Parker of Pittsburgh slammed into John Stearns, the Wets catcher, trying to score the tying run.

title: Merckx's Shadow Pervades Big Race
description: BRUSSELS, June 30 The Tour de France bicycle race began this morning with an Eddy Merckx team riding Eddy Merckx cycles. And in the hundreds of small towns through which the tour will pass, a boy's biography of Merckx in comic strips is still for sale.

title: Bryant Park Is Showing Improvement, but It Still Has Its Ups and Downs
description: I think things have improved; I do believe that, said Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis of the midtown oasis called Bryant Park. People are not afraid to go there anymore, he said, crediting Capt. William Gundersen of the Midtown South police precinct, who says that the park is better than ever thanks to an increased patrol.

title: Syracuse Crew Reaches Quarterfinals at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 30  The crowds peeked out from under their umbrellas as the sun finally broke through today at this year's Henley Royal Regatta, brightening the colors of the boaters and blazers resnlendent in the Stewards Enclosure.

title: A (Mini) Brownstone Revival in South Bronx
description: Aureo and Cookie Cardona jumped at the chance to pay $75,000 for a brownstone that cost only $12,000 eight years before. Skip Butler and his wife, Mary, gladly paid $35,000 for a brownstone that was sold for $25,000 two years ago.

description: NEW ORLEANS, June 30For the first time in bridge history, the United States has won the world women's team championship.

description: Negotiators for New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association resumed bargaining on a new contract last night in an intensified effort to reach a settlement.

title: Tax Revolters, Spare the Waste
description: The United States is the home office of waste and always has been. The country was built on waste. We wasted land, wasted people, wasted resources and wasted fortunes that were built on wasting land, people and resources. Large parts of the country stretching from the South Bronx to Los Angeles shopping centers are now pure wastelands.

title: Prominent East German Dissident Sentenced to 8 Years in Prison
description: EAST BERLIN, June 30 (Reuters)  A prominent East German dissident, Rudolf Bahro, was sentenced today at a previously unannounced trial to eight years in jail for having collected Intelligence and having relayed secrets to the West.

title: Latin America Turning Away Froi4U.S. Military Guidance
description: FORT GULICK, PanamaWith most Latin American governments now able to control their internal security threats, interest in sending their military officers to attend counterinsurgency and other courses at the United States Army's School of the Americas here seems to be waning.

title: Patents
description: THE president of a New York company that monitors by telephone the operation of pacemakers implanted in hundreds of heart patients around the country has invented a new pacemaker that monitors itself.

title: Brezhnev Warns on Blocs in Africa
description: MOSCOW. June 30 (UPI)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has accused the West of taking an unhealthy interest in Africa, and says that the Soviet Union opposes the division of the continent into military blocs.

description: WASHINGTON, June 30  As expected, the Federal Reserve Board today raised its discount rate, the interest rate it charges member banks to borrow money, despite opposition from G. William Miller, its chairman.

description: CHICAGO, June 30 (AP)  Bob Lemon was replaced as manager of the Chicago White Sox today by Larry Dobv.

title: 5 INJURED AT IRT STATION IN ACETYLENE EXPLOSION
description: An acetylene tank exploded yesterday at the West 170th Street station of the IRT subway in the Bronx, injuring five persons, including two New York City Police officers. The blast, at 1:45 A.M., resulted from a fire in a storage locker in the elevated station on the southbound platform. The station is 170th Street and Jerome Avenue on the WoodlawnJerome Avenue line in the borough's High Bridge section.

title: Jets Waive Ebersole
description: John Ebersole, a veteran linebacker who was drafted out of Penn State in 1970, was waived yesterday by the New York Jets and became a free agent.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Eli LillyIreland Deal
description: Eli Lilly & Company expects to start building a pharmaceuticals manufacturing plant in Ireland this summer. The initial phase will cost about $25 million. The first products to be made in the plant will be bulk pharmaceuticals, principally of the oephalosporin family of antibiotics. The plant, which will do business in Ireland under the name of Elanco S.A., will be built on a 107acre site, about 18 miles from Cork, near the town of Kinsale.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dual purpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overthe counter dealertodealer asked prices for the capftal shares of each company with the percentage differences (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: ChrisCraft Increases Its Fox Film Holding
description: ChrisCraft Industries, which has been buying stock in the Twentieth, CenturyFox Film Corporation, said that it had bought 18,900 shares since June 15, raising its position to 735,400 shares, or about 9.5 percent. ChrisCraft said that it had spent $19.7 million for the stock.

title: Talcott Unit Is Sought
description: The Republic New York Corporation said yesterday that it wanted to buy the factoring division of James Talcott Inc., a subsidiary of the financially troubled Talcott National Corporation.

title: U.S. Reporters Get 2Day Delay in Soviet Libel Trial
description: MOSCOW, June 30Two American reporters appeared again today, as ordered, in a Moscow judge's chambers, and submitted statements saying that they had not been given enough time to prepare an adequate defense against charges of libel lodged two days ago.

title: U.N.V Votes Compromise Arms Text
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30The General Assembly, moving toward the end of a special fiveweek session, approved recommendations today for restraining the arms race and agreed on replacing the 16yearold Geneva Disarmament Conference with a larger negotiating body.,

title: United Press international
description: JERUSALEM, June 30Vice President Mondale, jostled by crowds of enthusiastic American tourists and young Israelis shouting antiAmerican slogans, visited the Wailing Wall today as the first act on his fourday tour of the Middle East.

title: Hong Kong Approves Plant by Du Pont
description: The Hong Kong Trade Development Council reported in New York that approval had been given recently by its government to E. I du Pont de Nemours & Company to set up a plant to manufacture its Tovex water gel explosives.

title: PRICES IN NEW YORK WENT UP 0.7% IN MAY
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose seentenths or 1 percent in May, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Archimandrite Gregory Abboud, Dean of St. Nicholas Cathedral, 55
description: The Rt. Rev. Archimandrite Gregory Abboud, Dian of St. Nicholas Cathedral, 355 State Street, Brooklyn, since 1932, died Thursday in Lutheran Medical Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 55 years old.

title: POLICE IMPOSE FINES ON 59 WHO ADMITTED HARLEM BRETAKING
description: New York City's Police Department imposed fines yesterday totaling $175,000 on 59 police officers, detectives and supervisors who admitted they had accepted bribes while assigned as officers to the 28th Precinct in Harlem from 1955 to 1973.

title: Despite Strides, British Feminists Admit That Women Are Still a Class Apart
description: LONDON  A judge recently ruled that a Fleet Street bar called El Vino was simply being chivalrous in prohibiting women from standing at the bar with men. They can drink at tables In the rear without being jostled, he said, so El Vino's rule does not violate the Sex Discrimination Act.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.What good are the snail darter, the little fish that stopped the big dam, and the furbish lousewort, the snapdragon relative that is slowing down Maine's DickevLincoln Dower Droiect?

Rodriguez, the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, said today that regulations governing boarding homes in New Jersey were dangerously superficial and that the commission will make recommendations within two weeks. for expeditious Corrective action.

description: MONTREAL. June 30 (Reuters) The International Air Transport Association met in special session today to revamp its cumbersome ratemaking apparatus and stave off what one member called its worst crisis ever. the iutimemoer association presented nine recommendations draw n up by a fiveman study group that called for sweeping changes in its operations.

title: U.S. Assails Al Fatah and Arafat For Blast in Israel but Not P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON. June 30  The United States condemned the principal Palestinian guerrilla movement and its leader, Yasir Arafat, today for the bombing of a Jerusalem market yesterday but rejected a blanket condemnation of the parent Palestine Liberation Organisation.

title: McCovey's 500th Homer. Clouted in Losing Effort; National League; Dodgers 5, Reds 3 (1st) Dodgers 5, Reds 2 (2d); American League; Orioles 3, Red SOx 2
description: Willie McCovey of the San Francisco Giants broke intoorganized baseball in 1955 with Sandersville of the Georgia State League. He came into the National League in 1959 and has been there most of his major league career.

title: Looking Back With Willard Mullin
description: The news from the third green at the Sawgrass Country Club in Ponte Verde, Fla., is almost as bad as it could be. Willard Mullin reports that back in February some doctors up in Jacksonville put him in a cage, poked sticks through the bars and then told him he had lung cancer. They gave him three months to a year. The only reason the news isn't as bad as it could be is that Willard says he feels fine, except that it takes him three tries to blow out the candles on a 4yearold's birthday cake. In the condominium that overlooks the third green  it's a par3 hole and he watched Jack Nicklaus take a double bogey there he plays bridge, reads, talks, laughs, drinks beer or chablis and makes like Julia Child. A long while ago, he was the salad chef at the semiannual meetings of the Village Green Reading Society, but he has branched out gourmetwise, as they say on Madison Aveenue.

title: Two Loan Rates Raised
description: In two monetary actions, the Federal R'serve discount rate and the commercial bank prime rate were increased yesterday, each by onequarter point. The discount rate was raised to 7 percent and the prime rate to 9 percent, lifting both to their highest levels since January 1975. The prime rate in. crease was led by Citibank, and it quickly became industrywide. Page 23.

title: CitizensSouthern Sets Goal to Acquire 18 Banks
description: The Atlantabased Citizens and Southern National Bank said yesterday that it had set a goal of acquiring 18 small Georgia banks in the next five years.

title: Mexico Won't Sell Gas to U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, June 30 The Mexican Government has decided not to export natural gas to the United States even if the Carter Administration reverses itself and agrees to pay the price demanded by Mexico last year.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: HIGHWAY AS AN ART MEDIUM: A view of the Westside Highway looking north below the World Trade Center. On June 3 a nameless group of NeW Yorkattstsrledbylerome Lipani, declared the highway an American, sculpture. Since then the group has been decorating this stretch of roadway with figures and abstract symbols. According to Mr. Lipani, the group hopes to use the highway for environmental theater and for performing opera.

title: BigTime Marbles On the Boardwalk
description: In an annual event attracting youngsters from all over the Northeast, two Pennsylvanians captured this year's championship in the national Big Blue Marble contest at Wildwood. Dean Feinauer, left, won the boy's division; Diane Bertosh, not shown, won for the girls. They were among 56 boys and girls who began competition on Monday.

title: When One's Son is a Chip Off the Old Block A Cylinder Block  and It Makes Dad Proud
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa.Every man wants his son to be somewhat of a clone, not in features but in footsteps.

title: RHODESIAN ASKS U.S. TO BACK INTERIM PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. June 30Dr. Elliott Gabellah, the black cominister of foreign affairs in the interim government, challenged the Carter Administration today to reverse its policy and support the internal settlement with moderate blacks.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.9% IN MAY, PACED BY FOOD AND HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  The Consumer Price Index climbed by ninetenths of 1 percent in May as food and housing costs again rose rapidly. The brisk rate of inflation, the White House admitted, was not good news.

title: CHARLOTTE STAPLES
description: Charlotte Staples, a language scholar and former chairmar of the Department of Modern Languages at Briarcliff College, where she taught Russian and Spanish, died of cancer Thursday in New York City. She was 53 years old.

title: Saving a Terminal Case
description: If New York's Grand Central Terminal has a new lease on life as a result of the Supreme Court decision in the Penn Central case, so has every historic structure in the country. The grotesque tower atop the terminal that had been proposed by the railroad and its developers and denied by the city may be a building lost for New York but it represents a principle gained for the nation. The outcome of the case that carried the challenge to the terminal's landmark designation and to New York's landmarks law up to the highest court has decisively established the legitimacy of property regulation for its historic, cultural and esthetic value.

title: Malnutritin and Some Deaths by Cancer Are Linked
description: Malnutritin and Some Deaths by Cancer Are Linked

title: U.S., in a Shift, Asks Less Than a Complete Test Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Carter Administration, in a reversal of negotiating policy, has decided that any new agreement with the Soviet Union to ban nuclear testing should still permit very small blasts, officials said today.

title: Okker, Newcombe Score Victories at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, ENGLAND, June 30  The old soldiers would not die at Wimbledon today.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

description: DiFALCO  Hon S Samuel. dear and trusted friend of Gotham Cerebral Palsy Our deep expression of sorrow to Mrs. Samuel DiFalco and family.

description: A man who had been honored at City Hall as a hero and had been given wide attention was found yesterday to be facing charges of having passed bad checks.

title: Restless Ray Brown Is Back on Road
description: Ray Brown, the bassist, had been on the road for 20 years with Dizzy Gillespie, and with Jazz at the Philharmonic and the Oscar Peterson Trio before he settled into studio work and managing other musicians in Los Angeles 12 years ago. But now he is restless and is on the move again. This time his vehicle is the L. A. 4,a group he formed four years ago with Laurindo Almeida, the guitarist, and Bud Shank, the saxophonist. It will make its first appearance in New York tonight at the Newport Jazz Festival when it will share a concert at Carnegie Hall at 8 P.M. with Stan Kenton and his orchestra.

title: Byrne Signs $4.4 Billion Budget After Trimming It by $4 Million
description: TRENTON, June 30Governor Byrne today signed the 197879 fiscal year budget of $4.4 billion, which will spend all but $26 million of a $270 million state surplus.

title: U.N. SESSION ADOPTS COMPROMISE ON ARMS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 The General Assembly, moving toward the end of a special fiveweek session, approved recommendations today for restraining the arms race and agreed on replacing the 16yearold Geneva Disarmament Conference with a larger negotiating body.

title: Frisbees Are Tossed Into the Smithsonian
description: Frisbees Are Tossed Into the Smithsonian

title: RightWing Afghan Group Says It Is Battling New Leftist Regime
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 30 (Reuters)A spokesman for a group opposed to the new leftwing regime in Afghanistan said here today that its supporters were fighting a guerrilla war against Government troops in the country.

title: Homesteaders Find Bargains At a Tax Sale
description: NEWARK, June 30 With Newark's Tax Collector urging on the bidders in a lively auction, the city put 97 pieces of taxdelinquent properties on The auctioneer's block in an effort to return them to the its tax rolls today.

title: 2 in Indian Cabinet and 4 Aides Quit
description: NEW DELHI, June 30 Two Cabinet ministers critical of the delay in prosecuting former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi resigned from India's Government today in response to pressure from Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, and four junior ministers quit in support of the dissidents.

title: 3 Hurt in Subway Derailment
description: A subway train on the L.I. line in Brooklyn derailed yesterday afternoon, injuring three passengers. The Transit Authority descirbed the injuries as minor. A spokesman for the authority said nine cars of the train had left the track, damaging the track and platform. The cause of the derailment was unknown. Service was suspendid between Myrtle and Wycoff streets to Atlatnic Avenue.

title: Notes on People
description: Apparently because they were so angered by cousin Hugh Carter's tellall book about the family, Lillian Carter and her son Billy have thrown their political support to Mr. Carter's opponent. A Georgia State Senator. he is running for reelection against Malcolm (Chicken) Wishard, a peanut farmer in Plains, Ga. Mr. Wishard said that Mrs. Carter and her younger son had not only given him their backing, but he also expects some financial help from them in his campaign to unseat Mr. Carter, who has been in office since 1966. The Carters, mother and son, were upset by unflattering references to them in Mr. Carter's book, Cousin Beedie and Cousin Hot. Their support of his opponent is underhanded, Mr. Carter said. I'm very disappointed in this, with as much as I've done for Jimmy. I know they're real disappointed in the book, but I wanted to tell the truth. Aunt Lillian hasn't spoken to me since the book was published.

title: Judge Threatening A Contempt Action For Bell Over Files
description: A Federal judge declared yesterday that Attorney General Griffin B. Bell would automatically be in civil contempt of court if he failed to release Government files on 18 informers by Friday.

title: COMPANY NEWS Colonial Calls Release By Grand Union False
description: Colonial Stores Inc., in a swift reac: tion to a $114 million takeover bid from the Grand Union Company, assailed Grand Union yesterday for issuing what it called a deliberately false and misleading press release implying prior substantive discussions, which never occurred.

title: Truly, a Capital City
description: WASHINGTONI get these funny cravings for New York. There are times when I have to flee the indecision of bureaucratic Washington to sit at the feet of political experts. I do this in Elaine's. It is there I am permitted all the things I cannot do in Washington: I can smoke without fear of reprisal from Joe Califano and I can be the only one in the crowd to speak with a Southern accent. It is for these reasons I am opposed to President Carter's selling the Eastern shuttle to Saudi Arabia.

title: Jascalevich's Lawyer Challenges Curare Findings, Suggesting a Mixup
description: HACKENSACK, June 30The defense in the murder trial of Dr, Mario E. Jascalevich sought to show today that tests could have been in error in giving a positive indication of curare in the exhumed body of one of Dr. Ja.scalevich's alleged victims.

title: 29YEAROLD NAMED NBC COAST OFFICIAL
description: A 29yearold television executive, Brandon Tartikoff, has been appointed by NBC as vice president of programs on the West Coast, making him one of the youngest persons to achieve that level at the network.

title: Andy Warliors Last Loire Presented by the Squat Theater Troupe
description: There is a moving desolation, a precision of theatrical images and a decided point and delicacy to the absurdist theater offered by the Squat Company,, a Hungarian troupe that settled precariously in New York a year ago.

title: Lekach Wins Saber Final In National Fencing
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., June 30 (AP) Stan Lekach from the New York Athletic Club won the men's saber final at the national fencing championships yesterday as N.Y.A.C. fencers took four of the top six places.

title: Watson and Fezier Tied For Western Open Lead
description: OAK BROOK, lll., June 30 The sec-ond round of the 75th Western open, interrupted three times today by rain and lightning and then slowed by fog, turned out to be one of the longest days on this year's PGA Tour. When officials stopped play at 8:26 P.M., central daylight time, the round still was not complete.

title: It'll Now Be Armco Inc.
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, June 30 (UPI) The Armco Steel Corporation will officially change its name to Armco Inc. tomorrow. The company said that the new name reflected continuing Giversification into enterprises in addition to steel, including oilfield production equipment, commercial insurance, finance leasing and industrial products and services.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I would like to suggest  or scream from the housetop  the idea for a fiveyear plan to put our nation back into shape. The idea is simple: Each year for the next five years the Federal Government should set a limit on the importation of oil and natural gas so that each year we spend one billion dollars less for imported fuel.

title: Blast Brings Chaos to a Bustling Corner
description: The Mister Softee truck was parked at the curb, the kind of innocent van that brings soft ice cream cones to shouting children these hot summer days. All around were people, shoppers, strollers, workers from tne tinancial and government districts, maybe hurrying back to the office or stretching a late lunch hour the day before a long holiday weekend.

description: Questions are based on news reports In The Times in the last week.

title: Carey to Seek Lengthier Confinement for Juveniles
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 30Governor Carey said today he would propose legislation designed to confine juvenile offenders past the age of 21 without trial if it is determined that they constitute a threat to society.

description: LOS ANGELES, June 30 (UPI)Plans by Rockefeller Center Inc. to construct a 40story office building in downtown Los Angeles at a cost of $80 million to $90 million were announced today in a ceremony near the construction site.

description: BWAYNE PEVEY has been counting and recounting the number of classrooms at the Brentwood campus of Suffolk Community College. Each time he counts, the answer comes up the same: 28 classrooms will not accommodate the number of students who want to enroll there in the fall.

description: When in search of tenants to fill a new office building in Kansas City, Mo., the thing to do nowadays is go east.

description: LINCOLN, N.M., June 28For days during that bloodfogged summer a century ago, scores of men on horseback converged on this tiny village from every direction.

title: NEW YONKBS BUDGET APPROVED BY COUNCIL
description: YONKERS, July 1  The City Council early this morning approved a $153 million 197879 budget that took into account a $6 millim loan from the state that would avert layoffs of some 300 em. ployees, and involved raising, as of today, the utility tax from 1 to 3 percent to sass beck the loan.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The American economy completed its 39th consecutive month of expansion in its current cycle in fairly good shape last week, but entered the summer period on a note of high anxiety reminiscent of the fears that prevailed at the halfyear point in 1977 and 1976.

title: Jai Alai Promoters Want a Piece of the Gambling Boom
description: TRENTONThere still won't be any dog tracks, but by next year, if New Jersey voters cooperate, the state may offer almost everything else a gambler could want. Since betting on the horses was legalized nearly 40 years ago, gambling in its various forms has become one of the state's biggest industries, with almost 5 percent of the total personal income of New Jersey's 7.4 million residents wagered during a year's time. Now, after the Legislature's passage of a proposed constitutional amendment last week, voters will be asked in November to add jai alai to the list of betting games people can play.

title: Mark Berkley, Joan Gillmore Marry on L.I.
description: The marriage of Joan West Gillmore, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Frederick H. Gilimore of Oyster Bay, LI., and New York, to Mark Edward Berkley took place yesterday in Oyster Bay. The bridegroom is a son of Clair P. Martin of Ephrata, Pa., and the late Charles H. Berkley. The Rev, Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: A Cool Story for a Hot Summer Day
description: CHAPPAQUA IT WAS really just a coincidence: The right people talking to the right people at the right time. young housewife complained to friend about the long, hot summer days made longer and hotter by three schoolage children constantly asking why they could not go to one of the swimming pools in town. She vowed that, she knew how, she would build a new club herself.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Traditionally, South Jersey had been harder hit by gypsy moths than the northern part of the state. But last year, with an unexpected migration of the insects from Pennsylvania, parts of North Jersey were stripped bare, and the state planned an extensive spraying program to prevent another infestation there this year.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: As a transport route, the Arctic Ocean seems distinctly unpromising; heavy pack ice covers 90 percent of it in winter and 70 percent of it of it all year round. Henry Hudson and many others died searching fruitlessly for a passage through it. Nevertheless, the American explorer Vilhjalmur Stefansson once predicted that the Arctic was destined to become a new Mediterranean, and now it looks as if the Soviet Union may be able to make the prophecy come true.

description: ISLAND PARK

title: An Artist Round When All Was Square
description: KATONAH TODAY, shaped canvases are very much a fixture in modern art. In fact, canvases whose shapes are anything but the standard rectangle have become somewhat commonplace. But when Edward Giobbi began making his shaped canvases nearly 20 years ago, they were patently new to the art world  opening eyes to fresh pictorial possibilities.

title: Teachers Gifts Evoke the Past
description: No one knows when the custom of youngsters bringing gifts to favorite teachers originated, but It must have begun when their pay was scanty and a generous endofterm gift appeased both giver and recipient.

description: When a jazz program starts with Woody Herman's orchestra sounding better than it has in years and goes onmud and upward Irom there, it should be quite an evening.

title: William F. Harrah, 67, Is Dead; Was a Casino Pioneer in Nevada
description: RENO, July 1 (UPI)William F. Harrah, who built a multimilliondollar gambling empire by never forgetting the slot machine players, died yesterday after surgery at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 67 years old.

title: Wide Range Of Musicians In Film Salute
description: The Film Salute to the Newport Jazz Festival, presented Friday night at New York University, ranged from 1933 clip of Louis Armstrong in Copenhagen to some Newport footage from the early 60's. It varied artistically as well, from the greatness of Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Duke Ellington and Count Baste  to some forgettable moments by Buddy Rich and a Newport All Stars group.

title: Thomas Foster Fiance Of Pamela E. Gardner
description: Pamela Elizabeth Gardner and Thomas Tenney Foster plan to be married In Gates Mills, Ohio, on Aug. 26. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Edward Gardner of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. James Hiram Foster Jr., also of Shaker Heights, and the late Mr. Foster.

title: CAMERA
description: There are many photographers and camera enthusiasts who over the years have found it advantageous to shop for items of photographic equipment by mail. While their specific reasons may differ, three of the most popular reasons for mail order shopping are: (1) saving money, (2) the convenience of being able to order what you want by simply going to the nearest mailbox or picking up the telephone, and (3) being able to purchase items that are sometimes not available in local camera shops or similar stores.

title: Headliners
description: Every time pork bellies or soybeans get out of control, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, an independent Government regulatory agency, regulates things and, as a result, more pigs are planted, or something, and food prices remain reasonable. Last week, in a news conference, President Carter called on a member of that commission to resign. Responding to a reporter's question, Mr. Carter said he had decided that David Gartner, confirmed by the Senate last  May after being appointed by Mr. Caner, should resign. The President confirmed more: Mr. Gartner had called the White House and said he declined to resign, and Mr. Carter did not believe he had the authority to fire him. What was Mr. Gartner's sin? Between 1975 and 1977, while working as an aide Senator Hubert Humphrey, he had accepted a gift of $72,000 worth of stock on behalf of his children from the chairman the ArcherDanielsMidland Company, a big grain firm whose business is partly regulated by the commission Mr. Gartner now sits on. He had told the White House this before being appointed, and told the Senate the same. Then, apparently, the White House changed the rules and now, Mr. Gartner said, if he were to resign it would look like an admission wrongdoing. Mr. Gartner has sold the stock, as he promised to do in May, and has declared that he would decline to regulate matter involving ArcherDanielsMidland.

title: Kim Anker Bride of Richard Paddon
description: Kim Louise Anker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace R. Anker of Frankfurt, West Germany, was married yesterday in Bernardsville, NJ., to Richard Locke Paddon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Paddon of Summit, N.J. Canon Charles A. Shreve. assisted by the Rev. H. Scott Kirby, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain.

title: Janet Van Wie Stanley Fiancee of T. J. Hoffmann
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Justin Armstrong Stanley of Winnetka, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Van Wie Stanley, to Thomas J. Hoffmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Hoffmann of Manitou Beach. Mich.. and Lake Wales. Fla.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Sweetwater Clifton, former Knick center, who now drives a cab for a living, gets no pension because he played before 1964, the cutoff date for the National Basketball Association pension plan. He recalls: We used to play in those AllStar games and we all thought we were playing for pensions. That's what we thought it was for. But it wasn't.

title: Everywhere the Same Song: The Jug Runneth Over
description: Our philosophy of rehabilitation has been shipwrecked, Sweden's chief prosecutor said last year. Criminality will not be cured through prison rehabilitation.

title: Mary Alice Parker Is Bride Of James R. Hogue, Teacher
description: Mary Alice Parker and James Ryland Hogue were married yesterday St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J., by the Rev. S. Hughes Garvin.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Business. It was a very good spring. We're very optimistic about this summer. Those are the words Jeff Hohman, massmarket paperback buyer for the 303store nationwide B. Dalton Bookseller chain, but they jibe with the assessment of other paperbounders. In summers past, Americans showed a preference for books closely tied to blockbuster movies. In 1975 was Jaws, in 1976 The Omen, in 1977 Star Wars. Grease is drawing thousands of John Travolta's young fans into the theaters, but how many of them will go on to the racks for Pocket Books's novelization remains to be seen (521,000 copies so far). NAL/Signet's Damien: Omen II has 1,650,000 copies out so far, but the pattern of its sales hasn't been particularly affected by the film's release. Bantam promoted its softcover version of Jaws 2 so expertly that it was a best seller long before the movie was on exhibit; now that the shark thriller is drawing long lines at the box office, the sales continue strong (nearly 4,000,000 copies).

title: Haitian Pianist In Her Debut At Fisher Hall
description: Under the auspices of the Association Culture Haitienne, Micheline Laudun Denis made her New York piano recital debut last Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall. Mrs. Laudun Denis has to date pursued a career primarily in South America and her native Haiti, although her educational background has included instruction in New York with Adele Marcus.

title: Bakke May Change a Lot While Changing No Law
description: Perhaps no case in modern memory has received so much media coverage and scholarly commentary. With those words in the United States Supreme Court chamber last Wednesday Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. began his announcement of the Court's Judgment in case No. 76811, Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.

title: RESEARCH SUBMARINE TO STUDY OCEAN RIDGE
description: Alvin, the little research submarine that located the atomic bomb off the coast of Spain more than a decade ago and made some of the first dives to mountains on the sea floor, has been rebuilt with a stronger frame for longer, more nroductive explorations of the deer.

title: Deborah Stiles Is the Bride Of John Reeve
description: Deborah Anne Stiles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith N. Stiles Jr. of Summit. N.J., was married yesterday to John Richard Reeve, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Reeve Jr. of South Orange. N.J. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church in Summit.

title: Kauai Is Wild And Still Alive With Legends
description: Once upon a time, a great warrior named Kawelo fought a giant intruder on the tropic isle of Kauai. The warrior, prevailing, hurled his spear at the fleeing giant, but missed. The spear flew with such force that it went through mountain just below the peak. Even today, the hole in the mountain can be seen as a tribute to Kawelo's strength.

title: Radiation From 2 Air Force Units Called Acceptable
description: NORTH TRURO, Mass., July 1 A field survey of three radar units at North Truro Air Force Base has led the Air Force to conclude that microvave emissions there do not present an acute or chronic health hazard.

title: Mounted Police In Nassau
description: WHEN the Nassau County Police Department's mounted unit went on active duty yesterday, it joined an expanding circle of police forces nationwide that have reached into an earlier era in order to keep up with the times. The new unit includes 10 men, who will be stationed temporarily at Eisenhower Park In East Meadow and who will be used primarily to patrol the park and to control crowds. Eventually, however, the horsemen will be assigned to patrol some of the county's largest shopping centers.

title: Canada Week: Stress Is on Unity In Face of Threat From Quebec
description: OTTAWA, July 11  With Quebec separatists threatening to deprive Canada of its largest province, the federal Government has placed special emphasis on national unity and the Canadian identity in this year's Canada Week, a festival that reaches its climax tonight with pageantry, entertainment and fireworks marking the 111th anniversary of the founding of the Canadian federation on July 1, 1867.

title: Chinese Puzzles
description: FORMER President Richard M. Nixon recalls his memoirs that the announcement of his invitation to Peking, made nearly seven years ago, produced one of the greatest diplomatic surprises the century. The surprise, however, reflected a failure on the part of most China specialists to read their tea leaves accurately. Assessed in retrospect, the eviBence Is now clear that the Communist Chinese leaders had been reaching for decades toward an accommodation with the United States in order to offset their problems with the Soviet Union. Thus, while Mr. Nixon certainly deserves credit for responding to their bid, history ought to record that the initiative was essentially Chinese, and I daresay that it would have been undertaken even if Hubert Humphrey had enterectile White House.

title: LetterTHE EDITOR
description: Based on the way the lady negotiators of paperback rights operate (Paperback Auction: What Price A Hot Book by Susan Braudy, May 21), the dictionary makers are going to have to come up with a feminine form for macho. The same moneymad manipulation by men is called awful, but let a woman come down to that low level, and bring it off, and she's role model for the sisterhood.

title: Television This Week
description: 3 P.M. (7) GREAT ADVENTURE. The premiere of a weekly onehour adventure series; this week's episode, Brigantine Yankee: Bounty Day to Suva, focuses on an attempt to recover the anchor of the H.M.S. Bounty.

description: LONDON  The heirs of the great collectors of the past are selling Britain's art treasures in huge quantities. Much of the best work is going abroad, especially to the United States.

description: PITTSBURGH, July 1A suburban town's 1974 ordinance prohibiting the use of tape recorders at council meetings was declared unconstitutional this week by Common Pleas Court Judge John P. Flaherty.
