description: BOSTON  Action required! The message from Washington flashed out of a highspeed electronic printer in an airy fourthfloor office overlooking Boston Common. It was 12:45 P.M.

title: Counterrevolt Brewing on Abolishing the Legislature
description: WHEN Denis R. Hurley began his campaign for the Suffolk County Legislature last year on a platform calling for abolition of the very body he was running for, few people took him seriously.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE newAeganEaStth HicicsVille, bordering on Plainview, is a good place to know about, now that warm weather has set in and the idea of cooking at home has definitely paled. It is an informal restaurant offering homemade Greek and Middle Eastern specialties with prices at or close to the fastfood level.

title: Nancy Henderson Is Married to Peter D. Adams
description: Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Holderness School, where the bride's father is head of the history department and is a ski coach.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: CAVENDISH, VT. THE first thing one notices (with a sense of relief) is that there is no barbed wire, after all. There i&a fence, and a gate that locks  not exactly uncommon features of American life today but no barbed wire. There had been ugly rumors that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn had installed a barbedwire fence around his 50acre property in this verdant Vermont countryside, and the very idea could not be anything but appalling to a reader of The Gulag Archipelago, his mammoth threevolume account of the Soviet concentrationcamp system, in which barbed wire is a continual, nagging, malevolent presencealmost a character in the story. (The centenary of its invention is even remarked on in Gulag III as a particularly grim anniversary.)

title: It's Time to Consider Chinese Cabbage
description: July and early August are the perfect months to plant Chinese cabbage. By the time seed germinates and starts to grow in late August and September, the days are getting shorter and cooler. The weather is ideal. (The arrival of the Chinese ensemble at the Met is, of course, coincidental.)

title: Catherine Stefanelli Fiancee
description: The engagement of Catherine Frances Stefanelli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Stefanelli of Great Neck, L.I., to Brian Dean Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Morris, also of Great Neck, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: LONDON London, 1900, an exhibition of English turnofthecentury building on view at the Heinz Gallery of the Royal Institute of British Architects on Portman Square through July and August, London's architectural event of the summer season. Scheduled to tour internationally when it closes, the show includes photographs, drawings from the RIBA collection, and at least one spectacular model, Westminster Cathedral.

title: Fresh Air Fund Camp Buses Liberate 750 City Youths
description: Harold Jacobs, a 76yearold retired carpenter, was waiting in the George Washington Bridge bus terminal on Tuesday morning. But he wasn't going anywhere.

title: CHESS
description: International Masters Kim Commons of Woodland Hills, Calif., and Kenneth Rogoff of Somerville, Mass., persisted in using the rare Center Counter Game as their defense of choice in the United States Championship Tournament even though they lost three games with it and drew two with it.

title: Public TV Finds No Strings on Corporate Funding
description: When someone in the audience at an Overseas Press Club luncheon asked Robert MacNeil how he felt about the fact that his MacNeil/Lehrer Report on public television was being underwritten in part by the Exxon Corporation, Mr. MacNeil replied: It's the cleanest money we have.

title: Airlines Group Acts To Allow Lower Fares
description: MONTREAL, July 1 (Reuters)The International Air Transport Association overcame heavy opposition today and approved a measure allowing airlines to introduce lower rates.

title: Food
description: O ne of the most astonishing things about America is that, 202 years after the signing of the Declaration of Independence, there is still a large group of people who ask, Is there really such a thing as American cooking? The answer, of course, is a thundering Yes.

title: Are Trains Nearing the End of the Line?
description: MYSTIC WE are reminded daily of our responsibility to do all we can to conserve energy, but many of us who are residents of southeastern Connecticut and southwestern Rhode Island have been deprived of the opportunity to exercise this responsibility.

title: Barbara Patton Fiancee Of Dr. Paul Chisholm Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Patton of Danville, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean Patton, to Dr. Paul S. Chisholm Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chisholm of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Baltimore After MidnightAn Insomniacs Tour of Charm City
description: On a starless night in May I checked on my sleeping children, grabbed a flashlight and headed downtown for a 1:30 A.M. rendezvous. Except for the men working on the new subway system, Baltimore's main commercial strip was almost empty. I drove along the Inner Harbor past the 181yearold frigate Constellation, which provides graceful contrast to the 30story, fivesided World Trade Center. Farther along, the hulk of the Nobska loomed in the darkness. An old ferry boat that once plied the waters between Woods Hole and Nantucket, Mass., it is now restaurant with a great view.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1LEONARD KAiVISLER 6789CAMERA 5/KEN REGAN; LEONARD KAMSLER

title: A Belated New York Debut for the Panovs
description: Although Valery and Galina Panov, the former Kirov dancers who emigrated to Israel in 1974 have lived and worked in the West for four years, dancing in some 15 European countries and in rimy cities in Canada and the United States, they have never been invited to dance in New Yorkthe acknowledged dance capital of the world. This odd circumstance will now be remedied when the Panovs are seen as guest artists with the Berlin Opera Ballet, which is making its American debut at the New York State Theater on Thursday, in an engagement running through July 16. Not only will New Yorkers finally be able to see the Panovs dance, but the Company will also unveil two of Mr. Panov's major choreographic efforts, his fullevening production of Cinderella, to the Prokofiev score, and Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring.

title: Miss Sherman Becomes Bride Of F. W. Binder
description: Pamela Adamson Sherman, daughter of William Snyder Sherman of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Emily Adamson Sherman, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank William Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Binder of Wallingford, Conn.

title: Newport Recreates Beginning Of Bossa Nova With First Stars
description: In 1962, Stan Getz and Charlie Byrd released an album entitled Jazz Samba that launched the fad for Brazilian bossa nova or new wave music in American jazz and jazzpop circles. American enthusiasm for the.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: For quite some time before I went to see Arthur Kopit's Wings which will be giving its final performances at the Public today as part of the Yale Repertory Theater's brief visit to New York, I'd been puzzling over the contemporary theater's increasing preoccupation with illness and age, with senility and death. Mr. Kopit's alay takes us. with Eranhic persuasiveness, inside the strokedamaged brain of asilverhaired former aviatrix, charting each rugged, ragged step made by patient, doctors and nurses toward regaining the power of speech before death can impose a permanent silence.

title: How to Dub Aaaarghr Into English
description: Some time ago I was invited by a friend to help dub a Japanese kungfu movie into the English language. The movie was impressively entitled The Killing Machine, and starred a man named Sonny Chiba. Sonny Chiba, for those not in the kungfu know, is the Crown Prince of that ancient weaponless martial art, and inheritor of the title from Bruce Lee, who died, supposedly from a kungfu hand chop, a few years ago.

title: SHOPTALK Nimble Hands for Discriminating Ears
description: Asmall number of craftsmen who build and repair musicalinstruments have been attracting a highly specialized clientele to Westchester. Many of their customers are professional musicians.

title: A Man Who Paved The Road to Bonn
description: WASHINGTON  Henry Owen. One of those bright, shy, nameless, faceless public servants who quietly  behind the arras, as it were  pull the strings that move the colossus of Government. In Britain he would be part of the elite class of civil servants known as the mandarins. In France he would be an haute fonctionnaire, poised majestically within earshot of his minister.

title: The New Americans  A Young Graduate Speaks
description: MOST of today's [high school] graduates will be 40 years old when this century passes into the next. We are the generation that spans the centuries, reaching the turning point in our own lives as the course of human events themselves turn to the 21st century.

title: The Mayers Make Their Point on Court
description: WIMBLEDON THE Mayer brothers, Sandy and Gene, have not forgotten their rots, even as they wander in the exotic world of Wimbledon.Saridy Mayer defeating Adriano Panatta at Wimbledon last year.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICA'S GREAT ILLUSTRATORS, by Susan E. Meyer. (Abrams, $35.) The work of 10 American illustrators in the popular media from 1880 to 1930. THE DREAM OF A COMMON LANGUAGE, by Adrienne Rich. (Norton. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $2.95.) Meditative verse, coherent and musical; her best book.

title: Nobody Asked Him, But..
description: Jimmy Cannon was writing about Joe Namath when he typed, it all comes down to a man being great at something. He meant the quarterback but that line belonged on Jimmy Cannon's tombstone. In modern sportswriting, there have been two patron saints  Red Smith and Jimmy Cannon. Red Smith is still being great at something for The New York Times. Jimmy Cannon died in 1973 after a stroke had put him in hospital beds and a wheelchair for more than two years. But for those who miss him and for those who missed him, his brothers, Jack and Tom, have put together a collection of his columns in a new book that could only have the title it has, Nobody Asked Me, ButThe World of Jimmy Cannon. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $10.95).

title: L.I. Youth, 18, Arrested For Murder of Girl, 13, vAitnd Slain in Sand Pit
description: An 18yearold youth was arrested yesterday in the murder of a 13yearold girl in Port Washington, L.I., two weeks aeo.

title: Ramps Rampant
description: Ramps, the odoriferous wild onions that resemble scallions and taste like a cross between leeks and garlic, are nearer (and farther) than you think. More precisely, they are nearer and farther than we reported them to be a few weeks ago in describing the spring ramp festivals in the Appalachian foothills of West Virginia and North Carolina and the availability of this unusual vegetable in a local fancy fnnd ghnn A number of readers who are onto the gastronomic wonders of this untamed member, of the lily family reported their whereabouts as follows:

title: A NEW KIND OF ENVOY FOR THE NEW BRITAIN
description: The British Embassy in Washington was in something of a dither last July as it awaited the arrival of its new Ambassador. Not only was Peter Jay a newcomer to diplomacy, but he was also, at 40, a full 18 years younger than and centuries removed in style from his predecessor, Sir Peter Ramsbotham. His reputation for a rropant nonconformism had preceded him, and his connections in high places  he is the soninlaw of British Prime Minister James Callaghan  compounded the apprehension. There was, too, a promised innovation: Mrs. Jay, at her husband's insistence, was to serve as coambassador, and no one at the embassy was quite clear what that meant. Above all, everyone was well aware that Peter Jay, as economics editor for The London Times, had been a harsh critic of the economic policies of the Labor Government he was now to represent. In 1975, he had gone so far as to predict that democracy in Britain would be suspended by 1980 give or take a couple of years.

title: AirConditioning? Mostly, Homeowners Still Do Without
description: A tall cold drink under a spreading shade tree  that's the suburban version of airconditioning.

title: Jersey Family Enjoys Tourney Tennis.
description: Around Teaneck, N.J., Joe Golden is regarded as a tennis nut. He doesn't mind because he's had an experience that he'll never forget.

title: Leslie Parnas Practices Cello Diplomacy in Russia
description: With the confidence of an ambassador about to present his credentials to a friendly gov; ernment, cellist Leslie Parnas stepped off an Aeroflot plane in Leningrad this past spring and smiled.

title: Nebraska Electrocution Is Set
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 1 (AP)Robert W. Williams, 41 years old, was ordered yesterday to be electrocuted Nov. 15. The court said that Mr. Williams, convicted of murdering two women, committed crimes that were heinoUs and atrocious. A review by the Nebraska. Supreme Court may delay the execution. He also is said to have slain another woman after the killing of the first and to have kidnapped and raped another.

title: France to Mend Comoro Ties
description: Relations were broken off shortly after the islands became independent from France in 1975, but a coup last May brought to, power a proFrench Government that pledged close ties with Paris.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE The Ritz, comedy. Tonight only at 8:30, $5.50. Annie Get Your Gun, by Irving Berlin. Wednesday to next Siinday at 8:30 P.M. (through July 23). $5.50 to $7; discounts available for the elderly, students and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Routes 6 and 118.6281109.

title: An Escape From the Past Leads to Japan
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR FOR Motoko Ikeda Spiegel, getting a bachelor's degree in fine arts from the State University of New York campus at Purchase earlier this month was not just another venture into the groves of academe.

title: AT A GLANCE The Hewlett Packard Company
description: Note: Company paid dividends on a semiannual basis but with this month's payout will begin paying $0.15 each Nader

title: The Jewish Identity Crisis
description: THERE are, it is estimated, 140,000 Jews in Westchester. But I think there are more, many more, given the embarrasingly large number of young Jews who either no longer consider themselves Jewish (I'm a human being; I'm an atheist), or whose Jewishness is so lukewarm and unimportant to them that it will soon fade away.

title: YankeesRed Sox: Another Tea Party?
description: By the time the Red Sox mop up the Yankees, the House That Ruth Built will be more like the House That Rice Demolished. I've been mayor when both teams were in the doldrums and when both were competing in recent years for the pennant. I think there is a general positive spirit that prevails in both cities. when the rivalries are strong. Both the Yanks and Red Sox have great baseball legends  with a lot of baseball history on both sides, and they are building new legends.

title: A Labor Chieftain, Dutch Style
description: AMSTERDAM  Wim Kok is not your garden variety labor leader. He has never held a bluecollar job. He would like to see Dutch workers forgo real salary increases for the next few years. And he spends a good deal of time thinking about where multinational companies should invest their money.

title: Deaths
description: BRAUENMildred B., died on June 26, beloved wife of Andre Marcel Brauen. Private services have been held.

title: CBIME
description: There is nothing new in the concept of a fleeing criminal moving into a household for refuge, holding everybody hostage. One could rattle off any number of books, and films too, along that line. Mario Sagola's THE MANACLE (Macmillan. $7.95) is exactly that sort of book. Butsomehow Mr. Sagola  the pseudonym of a wellknown author, the jacket tells us  not only pulls it off in an original manner but has also managed to write a neat parable of good and evil.

title: T. V. Wagner Fiance Of Miriam C. Furey
description: Miriam Catherine Furey, a laboratory instructor in human anatomy at the University of Rhode Island, plans to be married Aug. 12 in Gales Ferry, Conn., to Thomas Vaughn Wagner, broker with the Westerly, R.I., realty firm of Kelly & Picerne.

title: Kathryn Pelz Bride Of Glenn R. Davis
description: Kathryn Louise Pelz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Pelz of Scarsdale, N.Y.. was married yesterday afternoon to Glenn R. Davis, son of Mrs. Edward Effinger of Asheville, N.C., and New Port Richey, Fla., and William C. Davis of Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: Carter Cites Plight Of Abused Children
description: WASHINGTON. July 1 (Reuters)President Carter has expressed concern over the mistreatment and neglect that have been the lot of millions of ch:1dren in the United States.

title: Susan Gifford Is Bride Of Frederick Schlomann
description: Susan Gifford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oak Hanna Gifford of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Frederick Ernest Schlomann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Schlomann of Woodstock. N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Congregational Church in the Gardens in Forest Hills, Queens, by the Rev. David J. Rowe.

title: Fromm Wins Final
description: MANHASSET, Li., July 1  Eric Fiomm of Columbia University defeated Mike Powers of Glen Head, L.I., 61, 63, in the final of the Eastern claycourt tennis championships today. Manny Iqbal of Pakistan and Bob Kessler of Manhasset, L.I., defeated Stan Ross and Warren Grossman of Great Neck, L.I., 64, 64, in the doubles final.

title: Love N.Y. Show Set at Lake Placid
description: To most members of the equestrian world, it is merely a continuation of the Lake Placid Horse Show, the second section, you might say. But to Mrs. C. T. Newberry of Ausable Forks, N.Y., who thought of the name, the I Love New York event, starting at Lake Placid on Tuesday, is something new and unusual in the horseshow business.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IN THE winter, cellars are vast receptacles. Wet boots are thrown into them, and the magazines and newspapers that you hestiate about tying up and carrying out to stand by the curb in the snow are allowed to accumulate in them.

title: Nancy Blank Fiancee Of Craig A. Severance
description: Nancy Lee Blank, a 1978 graduate of the Boalt Hall School of Law of the University of California at Berkeley, plans to be married Aug. 27 to Craig Adam Severance, who is attending the Stanford University Graduate School of Business. The ceremony will take place in Chatham, Mass., at the summer home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Blank of San Francisco.

title: The Discus Thrower
description: When Al Oerter walked into Mike Manuche's with Curley Harris, the headwaiter asked Harris, Are you sore or something?

title: FILM VIEW
description: Critics, I realize, have a habit of saying that this year is worse than last year and the future looks gloomy and wouldn't it be nice. to be able to return to some earlier golden age? These were pretty much the thoughts expressed the other night among some of my colleagues. with each person, in turn, qualifying his pessitnisim, wondering aloud if, perhaps, this was a perpetual delusion. Or might we be jaded, since we dasee more films than anyone else in his right mind would see? Mightheaven forfendwe be getting old? Might our sour reaction to so many 1978 movies simply be a sublimated desire to put a stoppaymcnt order on time?

title: AROUND THE Gaordrien
description: Time off Enjoy the wellearned holiday weekend.

title: R. D. Hayes Is Fiance Of Linda Wait Snyder
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Whitney Snyder of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Wait Snyder, to R. Dixon Hayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Hayes of Naples, Fla. The wedding is planned for Sept. 9 in Sewickley.

title: Tigers Triumph Over Yanks, 84
description: Dave Rajsich, the latest in the new Yankee line of pitching imports, arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday and said, I still don't know what's going on.

title: CALENDAR
description: July 79: Country Antiques Festival. Fairgrounds building off Rte. 20, Riverton. 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Special auction, Saturday 10 A.M. Benefit Child and Family Services.

title: 3 Threatened Europeans Leave Rhodesian Mission
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 1 (Reuters)  Threats by black nationalist guerrillas have forced three European missionaries to flee a major Roman Catholic school and clinic in southwestern Rhodesia, Bishop Henry Karlen of Bulawayo said today.

title: Vicki Jackson Engaged to Robert Taylor
description: Me future bride, who graduated summa cum laude from Yale, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, received a law degree from the Yale Law School, where she was an editor of The La Jouraal.

title: Accord Is Reported in Dispute Over Projects in Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, July 1 (AP)Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island and several groups have reached an agreement that will allow progress on some projects on former Navy land at Quonset point, an aide to the Governor said.

title: Mother's Plea: A Life
description: For a Life; Following is a copy of a letter that was sent to State Senator Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, whose remarks opposing the death penalty in New Jersey appeared on this page on June 18. Senator Feldman concluded his remarks with a quotation from former Justice Arthur Goldberg of the United States Supreme Court, who said: The deliberate, institutionalized taking of human life by the state is the greatest conceivable degradation to the dignity of the human personality,

title: 3 Children Drown in Drainage Pond
description: MARIANNA, Pa., July 1 (AP)Three children drowned in a mine drainage pond in Washington County today. Two had fallen from Styrofoam rafts and the two others had jumped in to try to rescue them. Fire Chief Bill Jenaway of East Bethlehem Township said none of the children could swim. The victims were identified as Dallas Butler, 11 years old, Joveda Butler, 12, both of Marianna, and Eugenia Jones, 10, of Pittsburgh.

title: SPORTS
description: SMITHTOWN SUSAN LIERS may not break any records in the 5,000meter racewalk at Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy. this Wednesay  unless there's an aggressive male chauvinist among her cornpgtitors.

title: Adrian Garrett Clouts No. 28
description: TOKYO, July 1 (AP)  Charlie Manuel homered twice, driving in three runs, as the Yakult Swallows posted a 73 decision over the Chunichi Dragons in the Japanese League today. Adrian Garrett blasted his 28th homer of the season and fifth in his last four games, but his Hiroshima Toyo Carp lost, 98, to the Hanshin Tigers.

title: The President Wants Him to Depart
description: In the three years of its existence, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has been sorely knocked about in its struggle to establish itself as regulator of the commodities markets. Earlier this year. Senator Thomas F. Eagleton called the agency one of the most screwed up in the whole Federal Government. Last week President Carter, in a televised news conference, asked David Gartner, a recently appointed commissioner, to resign.

title: Ann Keller, Student, Is Bride
description: The First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ann Elizabeth Keller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Keller of Riverside, Conn., to Reynolds Chace Springborn, son of Mrs. Thomas F. Dillon of Cos Cob, Conn., and Reynolds Springborn of New York.

title: July 4th Race Has. Reason to Celebrate
description: The $50,000 Formula Atlantic race on Tuesday at Lime Rock Park in Connecticut could be an oldfashioned Fourth of July bellringer. The purse is the largest ever offered for a Lime Rock race and the firstplace payoff of $10,000 also is a record, according to Jim Haynes, Lime Rock's general manager.

title: ANTIQUES
description: ON July 7, 1775, at the end of his second term as a schoolmaster, the young man who was to become Connecticut's first national hero decided to quit his job. On that day, Nathan Hale, then 20 years old and with an offer of a lieutenant's commission in the new Army, wrote to the proprietors of New London's Union School: I have thought of never quitting, but at present there seems an opportunity for more extended service.

title: D. S. Stilvvell Fiance Of Kathleen Kiernan
description: Mr. and Mrs. David H. Kiernan of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Joan Kiernan, to David Scott Stilwell. He is a son of Capt. Edward P. Stilwell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Stilwell, of Alexandria, Va.

title: Church Founder Excommunicates His Son, Garner Ted Armstrong
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1Culminating bitter struggle for control of the worldwide Church of God, Herbert Armstrong, the church's 85yearold founder, this week excommunicated his son, Garner Ted Armstrong, the television evangelist.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: In light of the precipitous climb in interest rates, the Federal regulators have authorized thrift institutions to issue new, higherrated savings certificates. Their intent is to keep funds flowing into the vital homemortgage market, but in New Jersey, where the statemandated ceiling on mortgage interest rates is 9% percent, the concept is suffering instant defeat.

title: GARDENING
description: AHOLIDAY weekend should be just that, and gardeners deserve a respite, a sort of independence day of their own, time to relax and to contemplate. But genuine gardeners will never put away their trowels and hoes for long. Cultivating plants is a pleasant pastime in itself.

title: Shelly Robbins Enzazed
description: The engagement of Shelly Beth Robbins, a psychological analyst with the Klein Institute of Behavioral Sciences in New York, to Andrew Scott Hodes, an assistant district attorney of Nassau County, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Selwyn Robbins of Roslyn, L.I., parents of the bridetobe. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Hodes of Lawrence, L.I.

title: Deaths
description: GLICKMANAlbert. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice (Horowitz). Devoted father of Bobbe Friedman and Gigi Grobstein. Adored grandfather of Seth, Matthew and Jenne. Dear brother of Sadie Ames, Rae Lowe, and Herbert. Funeral services Sunday, July 2, 10:30 A.M., Boulevard Park West Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett,L.I.

title: Susan McGoff Fiancee of Steven Roger Traisman
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. McGoff of Willlamston, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan McGoff, to Steven Roger Traisman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert N. Traisman of Wilmette, Ill. The wedding is planned for Aug. 6 in Williamston.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MODERN dimmer switches have solidstate circuitry that cuts down on the amount of power consumed when the knob is turned to dim the lights. Therefore, replacing an ordinary onoff switch with one that has dimmer control not only provides the luxury of infinitely varying the amount of light from the lighting fixture it controls  from fully on to fully off  but also can result in savings in the amount of electricity consumed.

title: Braths
description: O'CONNELL4Joseph A., on June 28, 1978, of N.Y.C. Brother of Mrs. Eileen Kirchhoff, Mrs. Mary Donohue, Mrs. Eleanor Hyatt. Thomas, Fran. cis and Lawrence O'Connell. Mass of Christian Burial at The Church of St. Gregory the Great, Harrison, N.Y. on Monday. July 3 at at 11 A.M. Friends may call at the Walter C. Coxe Company Funeral Home, 14 Calvert St. Harrison Sunday 2.4, 7.9 PM.

title: What's in Stock
description: Garden City: Actors Conservatory Theater at Ade1phi. Plaza Suite (8 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays; 4:30, 9 P.M. Saturdays; 7 P.M. Sundays; through July 9); Ten Little Indians (above schedule, July 1123); Arsenic and Old Lace (above schedule, July 2530); Olmsted Theater, Ade1phi University. Tickets $2.50 to $5.50. 7412313.

title: MACCHIAROLA NAMES 11 TO SCHOOLS STAFF
description: Frank J. Macchtarola, who was sworn in as Chancellor of New York City's public school system Thursday, announcedi, the appointment of 11 persons to his staff Friday and indicated to the Board of. Education that he would abolish the post of deputy channcedlor.

title: The Power of the Conservatives
description: CONSERVATIVE Party leaders, like their Liberal Party counterparts, like to bill themselves as relatively pure political semipros, but they can wheel and deal with the best of them.

title: BURNING UP THE LINKS
description: Nancy LOpez, the amazing rookie pro golfer, hit a spectator in the head recently, teeing off on the 10th hole of the Bankers' Trust Classic at the Locust Hill Country Club in Pittsford, N.Y. As she rushed up to him, gripping the gold cross around her neck, tears welling up in her walnut brown eyes, the injured man mumbled to a friend kneeling beside him, At least I'll get to meet her now.

title: Ain't Misbehaving or Saving His Love
description: KATONAH BOB HOWARD recalls sitting in a Harlem nightspot and playing Ain't Misbehavin for an audience that held several gangsters when the song's composer, Fats Waller, strolled in.

title: School Tax: No Quick Answers
description: MINEOLA AFTER nine months, 145 witnesses and 22,400 pages of testimony, the current method of financing public education in New York State has been declared unconstitutional, but the longawaited decision has raised new auestions and left a number of others unresolved.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Another round of dismal economic news was delivered last week, as the Labor Department reported that consumers suffered a sharp decline in buying power in May as inflation edged past an annual rate of 10 percent. Steep increases in the prices of foods housing and new cars combined to push the Consumer Pace Index up 0.9 percent, matching April's rise, the department said, while the average worker's real purchasing power declined 1.3 percent from April.

title: RaferJohnson Is Still Striving for Better Athletes
description: Eighteen years after he carried the United States flag in the parade of athletes at the Olympic Games in Rome, Rater Johnson is still maintaining a role of leadership in this country's track and field program.

title: Bogey Helps Rogers Gain Lead at 69--210
description: OAK BROOK, TIE, July 1  The eagle 3 that gave Bill Rogers the lead on the 12th hole would be called the turning point in conventional golf language, but Rogers invented an idiom of his own today. He found his turning point not in the midst of a round, but on the final hole, where a heroic bogey 5 averted a disaster.

title: Bill Would Allow Woodburning Stove
description: ADISPUTE over woodburning stoves in this Bergen County community, which many local and state officials initially regarded as just a neighborhood misunderstanding, has attracted attention throughout New Jersey and led to the introduction of legislation that would permit such stoves to be used in the home.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., July 1  Howdy Holmes of Ann Arbor, Mich., broke track record at Lime Rock Park today as he drove his March 78 BFord around the 1.53mile road racing circuit in 48.931 seconds for an average speed of 112.567 miles an hour. Holmes broke the unofficial record in qualifying for Tuesday's championship series for Formula Atlantic cars.

title: Most Candidates Are Reporting On Campaign Funds, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission says it has been more than 90 percent eftective so far this year in getting financial information about political candidates before the public.

title: GARDENING How to Combat Blight and Mildew
description: AMAHWAH reader asks: What caused some of my peony buds to turn dark this spring and fail to develop? I think it might be due to weather conditions. If it is a disease, please tell me how to combat it.

title: After Godot the Waiting Was Over
description: T HEvaudeville comics whose routines both pleased and educated the young Samuel Beckett went in for incongruous pairings: If one was chubby, outgoing, irrepressible, then his foil had to be lean, reserved and lugubrious. So it is with the buoyant Deirdre Bair and the visibly anxious subject of her book. Beckett is the sadlooking one, the Stan Laurel, man broody and obscure even for his friends and lifelong prey to all manner of apprehensions; she the uncomplicated Oliver Hardy, rattling on for more than 700 pages without a worry in the world! For Mrs. Bair has given us a remarkably fat, voluble book about a writer who declines absolutely to reveal anything of himself in public and whose writings have become with the years famously sparse and hermetic. Beckett's temperament, for sure, is not hers; her fluency in writing is not his.

title: Births
description: Richard and Karen Joyfully announce the birth of their daughter, Lilah Sierra on June 18th. Proud grandparents are Mr. & Mrs George Hart and Mr. & Mrs. Alexander Lowenstein. Delighted ereatgrandfather Is Benlamin Wit!stein. Litah is named in loving memory of maternal grandmother Lillian Hart and paternal areat.grandmother Pearl WIllstein.

title: Taking On the Undertakers
description: Of all buyerseller relationships, perhaps none is more onesided than that between a bereaved person and an undertaker. The mourner, distraught at his loss, guilty over doing less than the best and ashamed to bargain, too rushed to make prudent decisions and ignorant of alternatives, is at the mercy of the first funeral salesman he meets. And, as investigators for The Times and other publications have shown periodically since the appearance of Jessica Mitford's The American Way of Death in 1963, burial salesmen have been only too ready to take advantage of the buyer's vulnerability.

title: Mary Mead Fiancee Of J. Mark Lennon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Etna, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Hayward Mead, to 3. Mark Lennon, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lennon of Haddonfield. N.J.

title: First Woman Named Army Major General
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)The Army today named its first woman to the rank of major general.

title: Even the BacktoBasics Movement May Breed Ignorance
description: At Loyola University in Chicago, physicist Jeffry Mallow recently started a scienceanxiety clinic that is supported by the CarnegieMellon Foundation and is intended to help students who find that science courses make them feel like morons.

title: Notes: Sir Freddie Sees No Revolution
description: Has the Skytrain, the nofrills flight between New York and London that will be duplicated on the Los AngelesLondon route in September, revolutionized air travel? Many people like to think sobut not Sir Freddie Laker, the maverick boss of Britain's Laker Airways and Skytrain's creator. In New York a few days ago, where he touched down to pick up an award for opening new travel horizons to humanity, he made it clear he felt his efforts had made a mere dent in what he sees as an international cartel that is indifferent to ordinary travelers and his concept of a consumer democracy.

title: I NEVER WROTE FOR CHILDREN
description: Not long ago, an American journalist who is writing a book on children's books asked me for my general ideas on literature for children, my aims and purposes and what led me to the field. Well, this flummoxed me. I hadn't any ideas, general or specific, on literature for children and I did not set out with aims or purposes. I couldn't say that anything I had done was intended or invented. It has simply happened. Furthermore, I told him that I was not at all sure that I was in his field, even though children throughout the world have, some of them, been kind enough to read what I write. I said that it was strong belief of mine that I didn't write for children at all, that the idea simply didn't enter my head. I am bound to assume, of course, that there is such field  I hear about it so often  but I wonder if it is a valid one or whether it has not been created less by writers' than by publishers and booksellers. I am always astonished when I see books labeled for From 5 to 7 or From 9 to 12, because who is to know what child will be moved by what book and at what age? Who is to be the judge?

title: THE LIVELY ARTSSummer, and the Stage Fare Is Easy
description: IT'S summer  tuna salad, cot. tage cheese and fruitcup time. And from Garden City to Mon. tauk, playgoers will be served comparable diet: Neil Simon, Agatha Christie and Woody Allen, the fare that summer theater thrives on to wean audiences from television reruns and backyard barbecues.

title: EXTRA GASOLINE CAN BLAMED IN EXPLOSION IN AREA OF CITY HALL
description: A powerful explosion on a crowded corner near City Hall Friday afternoon that injured more than 150 people was caused when a spare gasoline can in an ice cream truck caught on fire, the police said yesterday.

title: Provincetown Board Ends Liquor License Challenge Involving a Morals Issue
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 1The Provincetown Board of Selectmen has reversed itself and decided to drop its legal challenge to the right of the Atlantic House to have a liquor license this summer contending that the court cost would be too high.

title: FIGHTING BREAKS OUT IN LEBANESE CAPITAL; 22REPORTEDKILLED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1  Heavy fighting broke out today between Christian militia groups and the Syriandominated Arab peacekeeping force, and at least 22 persons were reported killed in an assault on the Christian suburb of Ain alRummaneh.

title: LIBRARIANS WARNED ON TAX CUTS IMPACT
description: CHICAGO, July 1The concern of California librarians that their state's tax limitation amendment may represent a threat to the free public library system was contagious at the annual conference of the American Library Association here this week.

title: Garcia, a Veteran of Albany, Is Getting to Know the Ropes in Washington
description: WASHINGTONThe House buzzer, the staccato ring of bells that summons the members to the floor, sounded three times. Seated in his office on the top Building, Representative Robert Garcia stooped talkine and turned to an aide.

title: Graduating to a Job
description: THE frustrations of job hunting outlined in The Art and Science of Finding a Job [Opinion Page, June 18] by Thomas B. Witt are shared by many college graduates, some of whom graduated three years ago and are still unable to get a foothold in their fields. However, the article fails to pinpoint where the problems originate or how to alleviate the situation.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: Dimmer Switch Can Lighten BillsMODERN dimmer switches have solidstate circuitry that cuts down on the amount of power consumed when the knob is turned to dim the lights. Therefore, replacing an ortiinary onoff switch with one that has a dimmer control not only provides the uxury of infinitely varying the amount of light from the lighting fixture it con. trols  from fully on to fully off  but also can result in savings in amount of electricity consumed.

title: Modern Police Department Policy in Nassau County, and Elsewhere Across Nation, Is to Get a Horse
description: When the Nassau County Police Department's, mounted unit went on active duty yesterday, it joined an expanding circle of police forces nationwide that have reached into an earlier era in order to keep up with the times. The new unit Includes 10 men, who will be stationed temporarily at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow and who will be used primarily to patrol the park and to control crowds. Eventually, however, the horsemen will be assigned to patrol some of the county's largest shopping centers.

title: The Homesick American in Paris: Items for a. Survival Kit
description: The days were long, and Paris was mauve and pearly gray and white, under a pale blue sky. Beautiful orderly Tuileries, beautiful drifting Seine threading through the city, beautiful calm Notre Dame, part cathedral, part dark and glittery cave. Amiable concierge. Incomparable foie gras. Nevertheless, I was homesick.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports front bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: DINING OUT Disappointment in the Great Outdoors
description: WESTPORT LCOKING for a sidewalk cafe In Connecticut like looking for a needle in a haystack. But even in our short summer season, it is extremely pleasant to sit outdoors and sip and dine. That is why the discovery of a waterfront restaurant where one can dine al fresco on an airy screened porch and watch the Saugatuck River good news indeed. One just wishes the food were better.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: COMMUNITY education, it was hoped, would ease the transition of the mentally retarded from institutions such as Willowbrook into group homes throughout the state. It has worked here, according to Stanley Schear, chairman of the County Executive's committee on transitional services, but only to limited degree.

title: Minding the Business Of Others Minds
description: HAVE you ever wondered about people like Aristotle Onassis or J. Paul Getty or Howard Hughes  who amassed more riches than they could possibly have used? Or about those people who buy Cadillacs and convert them into trucks? Or why a man as wealthy as Nelson Rockefeller might be seen puttering around in a pair of wornout sneakers?

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have a peony growing in a sunny location. It has not flowered for three years. What can I do? M.B., Bayside, N.Y.

title: Births
description: Norman and Victoria (nee Grant) Axelrod Joyfully announce the birth of their daughter, Lauren Grant, on Wednesday, July 21, 1978.

title: ItalianAmericans in Politics: It's Our Turn
description: IT BEGAN, as political tides often do, in the clubhouse and wards of immigrant ghettos. Up on Park Hill in Yonkers, the people from the old country would get together for coffee and pastries under the candystriped awning of Caffe Puglie and talk of politics and politicians, and the young people would listen. Over in New Rochelle on weekends, it was meeting time for the Calabria Mutual Aid Society. In Mount Vernon, the Italian Civic Association became the center and, in White Plains, the creamcolored adobewalled Roma Athletic Club was the source.

title: FISHING
description: THE waters off the Island's eastern end are boiling with big game fish. And while the hunt for the great white sharks drew wide attention last week, the first broadbW swordfish  the king of the game fish  was being caught without fanfare in the Hudson Canyon.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: MODERN dimmer switches have solidstate circuitry that cuts down on the amount of power consumed when the knob is turned to dim the lights. Therefore, replacing an ordinary onoff switch with one that has a dimmer control not only prbvides the luxury of infinitely varying the amount of light from the lighting fixture it controls  from fully on to fully off  but also can result in savings in the amount of electricity consumed.

title: Celebrating the Fourth Close to Home
description: WHITE PLAINS WESTCHESTER'S splendid beaches, pools and parks were opened for the summer three weeks ago, but this long holiday weekend will find many county residents making their first visits. They will find some welcome improvements.

title: Author's Query
description: For A biography of Helen Keller, I would appreciate hearing from anyone with information or documedts relating to John Macy, literary critic and collaborator with Helen Keller and Anne Sullivan.

title: U.S. Agency Warns Congress of Possible Collapse of Pension Plans
description: WASHINGTON. July 1 (AP)Congress was warned today that pension plans covering 1.3 million people could collapse in the next 10 years because of financial problems, forcing a Government insurance program to assume liability for billions of dollars in unpaid benefits.

title: Pirates Defeat Mets, 10, On Starell's Hit in 8th
description: PITTSBURGH, July 1  Kevin Kobel of the Mets pitched a threehit shutout against the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, but that was only for seven innings. After throwing just 71 pitches, the lefthander was removed for a pinchhitter in the eighth inning, Skip Lockwood gave up a run in relief, Jim Rooker and Kent Tekulve held New York to four hits, and the result was a 10 loss for the Mets.

title: INTERVIEW
description: THERE is more to being a legislative whip than merely rounding up party members for vote or a roll call, according to Marie A. Muhler of this Monmouth County municipality. Mrs. Muhler, the deputy minority whip in the State Assembly, holds one of the four Republican leadership positions in the lower house of the Legislature, a post that ischosen by a party election at the beginning of each session.

title: TV VIEW
description: Even before its broadcast on ABC last Wednesday, Youth Terror: The View From Behind the Gun was generating tremors in commercial television. Stations around the country were balking the documentary's inclusion of strong street language. Some stations, primarily in the South, were simply refusing to carry the program. Others were requesting various sorts of deletions. Pamela Hill, the executive producer, said that ABC News had decided to stick with the program as it was shown when transmitted to affiliates about two weeks ago for prescreenings.

title: The Region
description: The United States Supreme Court last week finally vindicated the faith of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, and justified landmark preservation laws all over the country, by ruling that his railroad's Grand Central Terminal is of the ages.

title: Oahu's Riches: Beaches, Crops And History
description: Actually, there are two Hawaiis in Honolulu and its island of Oahu. My husband and I discovered them both during a short stay there recently. After a I3hour flight with a sixhour time difference from New York, we faced the urban world of downtown Honolulu. Almost everywhere we looked that first night, skyscraper hotels lined beachfront streets, shops hawked coral, puka shells and monkeypod dishes, and tourist America strolled in hibiscus or dahlia or orchidprinted muumuus and matematching shirts. Sinclair Lewis by the Pacific, I thought; it was then 4 A.M. New York time, and time to return to our hotel.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: On Feb. 26, a letter [Who's to Enforce Bans on Smoking?] was published in the Westchester Weekly section of The York Times. It opposed any laws against public smoking and was signed Arthur J. Stevens, Scarsdale. In an article in the Feb. 19 issue of The New York Times, Tobacco: A Potent Lobby, Michael C. Jensen identified Arthur J. Stevens as general counsel for the Lorillard Company and described the various techniques used by tobacco company lobbyists to oppose nonsmoking initiatives.

title: SPORTS
description: IF God had intended man to play jai alai, He would have given him sixfootlong arms shaped like baskets. That is what some people.

description: The marriage of Pamela Jane DrIscoil to Daniel Thomas Sweeney was Performed by a ??? of the Peace on May 19 in Middleborough, Mass. The bride ??? the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. ??? J. Driscoll of New York City and Shelter Island Mr. and Mrs. Iosenh Sweeney of Middleborough ??? parents of the groom.

title: $360 Million Approved by House For Rangelands and Its Animals
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  The House has passed a bill authorizing $360 million to improve Federal rangelands in the West and tighten controls on the national herd of wild horses and burros.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Pleasure Ship Sails for Nowhere, Returns in Chaos
description: What had been billed as a relaxingJ weekend cruise to nowhere turned into chaos yesterday when angry passengerscomplaining of dirty and cramped facilities forced the S.S. America to return less than six hours after she sailed from a Manhattan pier.

title: Carey Plans to Recall Legislature Next Week to Act on Crime Bills
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.L, July 1  Governor Carey said today that he would recall the State Legislature to Albany during the week of July 10 to deal with what many consider the most contentious elcctionyear issue, that of stronger laws against crime.

title: A Herd of Horses in a Range of Prices
description: THE HORSEY set in Westchester is not limited to blue bloods. There are many riding trails through parks and nature areas, and the county's many stables and riding academies serve up a variety of riding programs  including English and Western saddle, and show training  in a range of prices. Many offer trail riding as one element in a package of lessons. Only a few offer supervised trail riding on an hourly basis.

title: Associated Press
description: GOODBYE KISS: Vice President Mondale takes leave of former Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir after visit in Tel Aviv. Mr. Mondale later met with Defense Minister Ezer Weizman and Shimon Peres, Labor Party chief.

title: SEABROOK SUSPENSION PRAISED AND ASSAILEDI
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 1  Environmentalists and opponents of nuclear power joined today in praising the Federal Government's suspension of the construction permit for the nuclear plant at Seabrook, N.H.

title: Mailbox: Nancy Lopez in Men's Tourneys Is Advocated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ATLANTIC CITY SATURDAY morning came in chilly and overcast, with a dank, gray fog blowing over the Boardwalk. My wife and I rode up from our hotel for breakfast in Resorts International's Wedgewoodblueandwhite buffet restaurant; we then walked a mile or so back down the Boardwalk, amid the rentedbicycle pedalers and Tshirtcostumed strollers and past the penny arcades and tacky shops selling candy and kitsch.

title: Rocky Mountain Fever Vaccine May Soon Appear in Drug Stores
description: FREDERICK, Md., July 1 (AP)Within a year, a new vaccine designed to combat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a viral infection carried by ticks, may be on pharmacists shelves. No vaccine currently is available for the virus, which, in about 20 percent of the cases, causes damage to the kidneys, liver and nervous system.

title: Realty News
description: The sixstory office section of the mixeduse complex at 866 United Nations Plaza has changed hands for the first time since it was completed in 1966.

title: Ann BrownFiancee Of Benjamin Mason
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Brown Jr. of South Kent, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Tilliman Brown, to Benjamin L. Mason of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mason Jr. of Chestnut Hill and West Chop, Mass.

title: Mystic Seaport Keeps the Past Afloat
description: STRETCHING more than 100 feet above her deck, the riggings of the 1884 whaling ship Charles W. Morgan impress her visitors with the complexity of 19th century invention and 20th century preservation.

title: Study Cites Ways To Fill Water Needs
description: DIFFERING with Federal projections, the Tristate Regional Planning Commission has estimated that Westchester County would have enough water sources to supply its needs for the next 50 years if regulatory measures and conservation that would control usage are adopted.

title: Liaisons Dangereuses
description: DURING the Iasi 500 years a multitude of odd and unexpected characters have found their way into the British House of Commons; but I doubt if, at least in the postwar period, any of them have been quite so strange, or so deliberately, even aggressively unorthodox, as my old friend Tom Driberg. Though he did not live to complete his autobiograpny ne (ilea m August 1976he had chosen an extremely significant title. The ruling passionsof which he wrote were three: leftwing politics, the AngloCatholic church, and what he himself called deviant sex, the last passion being probably the strongest and, in his book, the most elaborately described.

title: Peking Publishes 1962 Mao Speech Conceding Failure of Great Leap
description: TOKYO, July 1 (AP)China today marked the 57th anniversary of the founding of its Communist Party with the first official publication of a speech delivered by Mao Tsetung 16 years ago.

title: Not So Bad? Or Too Bad?
description: If the Supreme Court really did follow the election returns, its decision in the Bakke case probably would have been more of a setback to the idea of affirmative action than it was. Traveling around this country, it's not hard to discover that Allan Bakke's cause was popular, just as his proposition seemed plausible; and in that light, the decision the Court handed down this week was probably as reasonable as could have been expected.

title: The Stupid Sickness
description: What if a manmade virus escaped from a geneticsresearch laboratory and started an epidemic of stupid sickness, depressing the national average I.Q. to 83? At this level, people have little or no capacity for tasks requiring intelligence. They are unable to drive a car safely, to fill in a tax return or control their baser impulses. Civilization, as we understand it, would simply crumble away as the machines broke down and nobody came to repair them.

title: The Anguish of Filling In The Last Open Spaces
description: Until recently, the village of North Hills was a quiet incongruity. Surrounded by the intensely developed town of North Hempstead, and less than four miles from Queens, it was threeandahalf squaremile oasis of golf courses and estates. Stores and offices were isolated in one small section of the village, and almost every one of the 263 residents lived on at least two acres of land. In all likelihood, North Hills's pheasants outnumbered its people.

title: Cultural Culture Hero
description: A SelfPortrait. By Kenneth Clark. 259 pp. New York: Hatper & Row. $12.95.LET me begin where Kenneth Clark ends, with the last words of his book, the concluding words of his speech in Washington when he was awarded a medal for his television series Civilisation':

title: Person to Person Brings The 1950's Back to Life
description: So many of them are gone now: John F. Kennedy, Marilyn Monroe, Humphrey Bogart, Maria Callas, Groucho and Harpo Marx, James Jones, Rear Admiral Richard Byrd. Dr. Vanneyar Bush, Duke Ellington. Television viewers, however, will have an opportunity to once again visit with these celebrated newsmakers of two decades ago when Person to Person: Selected Interviews 19531959 begins a 13week run this Thursday evening at 9 on Channel 13. And younger members of the home audience will haveperhaps for the first timethe opportunity of seeing in action that 1950's newscaster and interviewer without peer, Edward R. Murrow.

title: Jenkins Rides 2 to Hunter Titles
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 1  Rodney Jenkins, who has ruled the horse show jumper division for a decade, has come upon difficulties with his mounts this year.

title: Joan Williams Bride of James Dempsey
description: Joan Chalmers Williams and James Xavier Dempsey were married yesterday in Woodstock, Vt, in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Snows by the Rev. Francis J. Gately.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: William K. Vanderbilt was a man who liked to get things done. Unhappy with the condition of the Island's public roads at the turn of the century, he and his equally affluent friends and neighbors decided to build their own highway so they could race their thenrevolutionary motor cars. The Vanderbilt Parkway, completed in 1908 as the first concrete road in the world  and the first to charge a toll  meandered through the bucolic fields of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk, ending at a French restaurant on the shores of Lake Ronkonkoma. Only 11 miles of Vanderbilt Parkway (also known as the Long Island Motor Parkway) have survived creeping suburbanization. But the memory lingers on  reinforced by the Vanderbilt Parkway Auto Rally staged each year by the Half Hollow Hills Community Library. At 1:30 P.M. today, vintage cars will leave the library at 55 Vanderbilt Parkway to chug along the remaining thoroughfare from Dix Hills to Lake Ronkonkoma, sent off by a salute from the Half Hollow Hills Community Band and cheered on by spectators lining what has now become a historic district. To the victors will go prize ribbons  and the satisfaction of knowing that they traveled free along a road that cost the Vanderbilts $52 a year to use.

title: The World
description: We are not trying, nor will we ever try to play the Soviets against the People's Republic of China, nor viceversa, President Carter told a news conference last week. Yet keeping the floviet Union and China at odds by maneuvering between them has been part of American foreign strategy since the Nixon Administration forged closer ties with both Communist powers.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: RECENTLY the International League for Human Rights held a reception in honor of Mihajlo Mihajlov, Yugoslav author and journalist who has been imprisoned numerous times for writing what he believed to be the truth about his country. In his speech.

title: Brink's Is Robbed In Boston Again
description: BOSTON The actor Peter Falk is squatting on the sidewalk this drizzly night in Boston, diligently poking, with somewhat shaky hands, at a lock on the metal door of the Brink's garage. A corpulent man, known as Spanish Eddie, stands two feet behind the actor, whispering instructions in his ear.

title: Bonnie Gail Nitzberg Is Wed to Alan H. Ulan
description: The Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Bonnie Gail Nitzberg to Alan Howard Ulan. Rabbi Norton Shargal performed the ceremony.

title: Jefferson Monument
description: IT is because of accident, confusion and tradition that we celebrate the Fourth of July. It was on July 2, 1776, that Congressional delegates from rebellious colonies finally adopted Richard Henry Lee's Resolution of Independence (the New York delegates were still awaiting instructions on how to vote).

description: The art of caning in Midland Park. Page 17

title: Smith Seeking $100,000
description: MAYOR THOMAS F.X. SMITH of Jersey City has plans to launch an expensive gubernatorial bandwagon in 1981, but he insists that it might carry the hopes of some candidate other than himself.

description: ED EMBERLEY'S A B C Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $6.95. (Ages 3 to 7)

title: Lamplighter Winners Contrast at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 1  Miami Lakes Ranch's Prince Misko and Helmore Farm's North Course were contrasting winners of divisions of the Lamplighter Handicap on the grass at Monmouth Park today before a crowd of 17,699.

title: A Gorgeous Sound
description: IT is public knowledge that the greatest poets of any age go undiscovered until they are dead. Like most items of public knowledge, this one is almost perfectly untrue, but literary reputation is erratic enough to provide examples for any saw; good poets do get overlooked. One common phenomenon is the poet who, in the language of a former President.

title: New U.S. Air Chief for Korea
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)  Maj. Gen. George A. Edwards Jr. will become the new commander of the Air Force in South Korea effective July 24, the Defense Department announced yesterday.

description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: Everybody's Getting In on Foreign Investor Action
description: A businessman from the Netherlands who was in New York recently was talking about the investments he planned to make in American real estate. A farm somewhere in the Midwest, he said, and maybe an apartment building or two in Michigan.

title: ART Japan's Gift to Newark
description: NEWARK IN THE opinion of many people, Oriental art has become synonymous with Chinese art. Chinese art has been taught more ambitiously in our universities, researched more exhaustively by scholars and exhibited more abundantly in our museums and galleries than any other form of Oriental art.

title: STAMPS
description: The celebration of the Fourth of July is coming a day early for philatelists, with a new 15cent commemorative being issued tomorrow for George M. Cohan, re nowned actor, playwright, writer of popular songs, producer and selfproclaimed Yankee Doodle Dandy, born on the Fourth of July.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. The American Jew.

title: Daniel D'Allesandro, Beth A. Lill Planning To Marry on Sept. 2
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles James Lill of Rochester of the engagement of their daughter, Beth Ann Lill, to Daniel Anthony D'Alessandro, son of M. Daniel D'Alessandro of Secaucus, N.J., and Rose Carbone of Jersey City.

title: Bound By Hoops Of Steel
description: LONDONLinkage is in fashionable use these days and President Carter and Leonid L Brezhnev, try asthey may, tre not allowed to forget it. There is, however, another form of linkage, just as important, just as critical to the world's equilibrium but it safely makes the headlines. It is the linkage between the prosperity of the Western world and the stability of the third world.

title: BRIDGE
description: It is well known that bridge books on bidding, like some wines, do not travel well: A treatise on a European bidding system is unlikely to find much of a sale on this side of the Atlantic. And the same is true of time barriers. American books on bidding written in the 1950's are of little interest today, and anything preceding World War H is virtually unreadable.

title: A Manual Warns Social Workers Of Extension of Children's Rights
description: A new manual warns social workers that they face ir:creasing challenges :it! New York City's Family Court as a result of United States Supreme Court exten.. sions of due process rights for children. The manual, aiming to improve social workers effectiveness and services to children, has just been published by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

title: Donna Mileti Plans To Be Wed Aug. 5
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Mileti of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Mileti, to Frederick C. Benenson of London. He is a son of Charles B. Benenson of New York and Greenwich. Conn., and Mrs. Lewis B. Cullman of New York and Darien, Conn. After the wedding, which is planned for Aug. 5, the couple will live in London.

title: Rhodesian Killings Anger British Rightists
description: LONDON, July 1  The killing of eight British missionaries and four children in Rhodesia a week ago has renewed rightwing pressure on Prime Minister James Callaghan to change his policies in south. ern Africa, but he appears determined to stand fast.

title: World of Birnbaum
description: To the Editor: I am thankful for your article on Philip Birnbaum [The World of Birnbaum: One Version of Luxury, June 18] because it let him speak for himself. His name has unfortunately become a politicized epithet, too often used by those ignorant of what he has actually designed, good or bad.

title: DINING OUT
description: NEWARK'S Ironbound District, which gets its name from the railroad tracks that surround it, is an enclave of SpanishPortuguese restaurants in which Spanishspeaking locals rub elbows with dignitaries from the city's prestigious Art Museum.

title: U.S. Official DUMPS Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)Chairman William Bagley of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, upset over what he considered overzealous marking of confidential commission papers, gathered up the agency's stamps yesterday and threw them into the Potomac from Memorial Bridge. He had ordered all such stamps turned in, and there were eight. I know of no other way to deter indiscriminate use of a confidential stamp other than to destroy any and all of them, he said.

title: The Devolution Bill Last Week Passed Another Stage Toward Implementation.
description: LONDON  If Prime Minister James Callaghan seemed particularly cheerful and confident during his visit to the United States last week, he had good reason: he appears to be well on the way toward solving his Scottish problem. The Government's bill to give Scotland a measure of autonomy in some policy areas finally cleared the House of Lords last week. It now returns to the House of Commons but seems likely to be enacted without significant changes.

title: Carter Signs a Bill To End Fishing Rift With the Canadians
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)President Carter has signed legislation aimed at ending the monthold dispute between the United States and Canada over fishing rights, the White House announced today.

title: PEOPLE
description: To devote more of his time to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's complicated legal troubles, Robert E. Kirby, the company's chairman, needed an assistant. Now he has Douglas D. Danforth, the 55yearold former chief of industry products. one of Westinghouse's operating companies. Last week Mr. Danforth was named to a newly created position of vice chairman and chief operating officer of the huge electrical equipment manufacturer.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: MODEFRN dimmer switches have solidstate circuitry that cuts down on the amount of power consumed when the knob is turned to dim the lights. Therefore, replacing an ordinary onoff switch with one that has dimmer control not only provides the luxury of infinitely varying the amount of light from the lighting fixture it controls  from fully on to fully off  but also can result in savings in the amount of electricity consumed.

title: A Popular Reality at the Pipe Dream in East Hampton Is Blues Singer (andTheorist) John Hammond
description: John Hammond's soul was pierced so unforgettably at the age of 18 by the music of Robert Johnson, the Delta blues man, that he's never been the same since. the prformances Mr. Hammond heard, ?? recorded in Mississippi in the 1930's, feature the solo voice and guitar of Mr. Johnson on a dozen tunes that are still Reognized as highwater marks o ths genre. The intense mixture of beauty and pain, of lyrical flow and rhythmic tension, moved Mr. Hammond to teach himself guitar and to sing his heart out to anyzrwho would listen. week at Pipe Dream, the newly renamed jazz and blues club in East Hampton, LI., where Mr. Hammond will be making four appearances on Tuesday and Wednesday, they'll be coming to listen to his last concerts on the Island this yearin droves. The place is packed every time John appears, said John Johnson, coowner, with evident pride. He draws from Westhampton to Montauk.

title: 3 Die in CarTruck Crash
description: MONTPELIER, Ohio, July 1 (UPI)Three women were killed early today in a cartruck crash on U.S. 20 about four miles northwest of Montpelier in Williams County.

title: The State and Proposition 13
description: IT'S easy to say that New Jersey is not California. True, taxes have not produced a $5 billion surplus in New Jersey's coffers, and there already is a cap on both state and municipal spending.

title: Musical Americana Flourishes on Recent Disks

Over the past few months many new recordings have appeared, and there has been an especially strong emphasis on our long and unexpectedly rich choral tradition.

description: In the Church Center for the United Nations, Dr. Karen Maxine Mackler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mackler of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Heinrich Saenger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Saenger of Neumarkt, West Germany. Justice Arthur Markewich of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: Thailand to Train Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  Indochinese refugees will begin receiving Thai language lessons and vocational training this month under project funded by the United Nations.

title: Fashion Profile
description: It is April. Perry Ellis is about to begin his fashion show, a collection of fall and winter clothes that will later be unanimously praised by the members of the press and department store buyers who now wait unaccustomedly on bleachers set up around the runway, at the end of which there is a goal post with a large paper P in its center. Like a composed quarterback, Ellis signals, and the show begins.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS UNIT LAUDS DECISION IN BAKKE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)The United States Commission on Civil Rights yesterday praised the Supreme Court's ruling in the Allan P. Bakke case and urged President Carter to step up efforts to enforce Federal affirmative action programs.

description: RAINBOW, Conn.  When the history of the restoration of Atlantic salmon in the Connecticut River water. shed is written, 1978 will be regarded as the turning point, the year when a  dream was fleshed with reality.

He would contribute a sizable amount, running into the hundreds of thousands of dollars, to a national association for the handicapped.

title: HewlettPackard
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  A former employee of the HewlettPackard Company recalls that on his first day he saw an old gent, his sleeves rolled up, designing a circuit.

description: Even for the United States Supreme Court, the understatement was notable. The case, Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote, has received our most thoughtful attention over several months. Allen P. Bakke's suit, in fact, had passionately engaged the emotions of the Court, as six separate opinions, over 150 pages in all, and unusual personal statements from the bench amply demonstrated last week.

title: Florida Guardsmen Struck by Lightning
description: CAMP BLANDING. Fla.. July 1 (UPI) More than 20 Florida National Guardsmen were struck by lightning last night as they were working on communications equipment spread out over several thousand acres, Col. Agustin Gonzalez of the Guard said today. No serious injuries were reported. but three of the men were hospitalized overnight at the Jacksonville Naval Air

title: Yanks Weather Another Crisis: How Clouds Over Martin Lifted
description: The plaque, as yet unhung, lies on a table in Billy Martin's office at Yankee Stadium.

title: In Rock, the Music Must Sustain The Message
description: When we look back on the musical 1960's, much of what we recall bad a strongly political castfolksingers and rockers using music to galvanize the political nassions of the day. Bob Dylan and Joan Baez spring to mind immediately. But rock bands playing at political benefits, rallies and marches were a common occurrence, and political themes often formed the subject of songs. The.,60's were hardly all political, to be surethere was too much psychedelia and sensualism to make that generalization stick. But in comparison to our mostly mellow and conservative 70's, 60's music seems to have been positively charged with politics.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The annual appearance of the report: Modern Gold Coinage, from The Gold Institute/L'Institut de l'Or is always a treat  perhaps because gold is always a pleasure to read about. It's here now with the news that there were 46 countries that issued legal tender gold coinage in 1977. This is the same number as the year before, but there have been some changes  14 ins and 14 outs. This plateau has an upward tilt since we have been informed that June 1 of this year shows a score that is decidedly ahead of the same date in 1977. Hence the revival apparently goes on; there were only six governments issuing lege; tender gold coinage in 1972.

title: Harbor Hydrofoil
description: Saying Staten Island ferryboats would be able to take care of Manhattanbound commuters only until the late 1970's, New York City began in 1970 to investigate new ways to move people between the island and Manhattan. The Planning Commission said at the time that a major part of the study was an entirely new waterborne system, such as hovercraft and hydrofoil vessels?

title: Beaches: Funds for Repairs
description: The Littoral Society has come to dispute the wisdom of relying solely on groins and jetties. Dana Roivan, the New Jersey coordinator of the society, said that the society favored a program of beach nourishment undertaken in conjunction with the rehabilitation of jetties. Beach nourishment is, simply put, resupplying to beaches the sand that has been lost to the ocean.

title: Associated Press
description: GUATEMALAN INAUGURAL UNDER TIGHT SECURITY: An Indian boy waved as armored vehicles rumbled down an avenue in Guatemala City yesterday during inauguration of Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia as president. General Lucas was victor over five opponents in elections March 5. He faces increasing guerrilla violence in the country.

title: New Jersey Coast Is Losing War Against Erosion
description: THE bruises from last February's torrent of blizzarddriven waves linger all along the New Jersey coast as summer's beach season begins in earnest this holiday weekend for millions of freespending tourists and vacationers.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: This weekend's premiere of Cantigas, a dance work by Pauline Koner, at the American Dance Festival's new home at Duke University in Durham, N.C., just happens to serve as a reminder of one salient fact. It is that the incredibly trim and younglooking Miss Koner, who turned last week, is celebrating her 50th year in professional dance.

title: Nixon Welcomed to Kentucky by a Cheering Crowd
description: HYDEN, Ky., July 1 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon returned to public life in Presidential style today, cheered by crowds chanting, We want Nixon! and regaled by a brass band playing Hail to the Chief.

title: Carter Says Mideast Effort Could Shift to Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) President Carter has raised the possibility that American mediation efforts in Middle East peace negotiations could fail and suggested that the talks might eventually have to Ro back to a Geneva conference.
