Ottinger, the Democratic incumbent in the 24th District, to some 270,000 of his constituents.

title: Under Arrest at 17
description: ON Monday, June 12, for the first time in my life, I was arrested. It came as no surprise. I had spent most of Sunday preparing for it and I was not alone.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE LANDED GENTRY By Sophy Burnham. 311 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $10.

title: Someone Else's Dream
description: JOY WILLIAMS, author of the highly praised State of Grace and of many good short stories, is a talented, skillful writer. She evokes the feel and smell of certain moments with an eerie precision; for example, hot afternoons in the bars slightly sleazy motels, when it is really too early to be drinking and when any overheard conversation sounds insane. Certain characters, too, in her fiction. are entirely original and absolutely credible. But the time of their marriage he was just a gym teacher and smooth all over from the many showers he took. His hair was always damp. He chewed sugarless gum and could draw in his belly so tight that there was just about two inches of him between bellybutton and tailbone. The evidence suggests that Miss Williams could and probably will write an excellent novel, which The Changeling, unfortunately, is not.

title: SERIOUS CRIME RATE IS DOWN IN FIRST QUARTER OF 78
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation reports that the rate of serious crime in the first quarter of 1978 was 4 percent lower than that for the same period last year, despite, increases in the numbers of rapes and assaults.

title: A Hectic Week on the Merger Front
description: It was a hectic week on the mergerandacquisition front. Some of the latest developments:

title: ANTIQUES
description: Two unrelated events have focused attention in recent weeks on mechanical banks, those ingenious coin gobblers dating from the 1880's to about 1910 that are definitely increasing in importance to collectors.

title: FISHING
description: FOR those anglers in quest of fluke, the fishing along the New Jersey coastline and in the inlets and rivers ranges from good to superb these days. While this finetasting flatfish, also known as summer flounder, is the best inshore bet now, offshore it's a tossup between bluefish and sharks.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Parachutists and 200 Ships Open Celebration of July 4 Holiday
description: Eight Army parachutists trailing red smoke and carrying American flags jumped from an airplane onto targets at Liberty State Park in Jersey City and onto Liberty Island in New York Harbor to start the New York metropolitan area's celebration of the long Fourth of July weekend yesterday.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: At a time of year when countless dance and music festivals are popping up in bucolic settings, the New York City Ballet is about ready to take off for its summer quarters in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The company winds down its season at Lincoln Center today and, barely pausing to catch its breath, starts up again at Saratoga on Wednesday. (See Dance)

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I was surprised to read [How to Get Ticks Off, June 11] that one should remove ticks by pulling them out with tweezers. When I was a scout, I learned that one never should do that before killing the animal by suffocating it in a drop of oil. (Ticks breathe through their hind legs.) It seems that the animal is so greedy that it lets itself be killed by having its neck torn off rather than loosening the told of its jaws. The head remains in one's skin and causes painful inflammations.

title: Dr. Gary Edward Russolillo Weds Petrina Ann Carrabba
description: Petrina Ann Carrabba and Dr. Gary Edward Russolillo were married yesterday by the Rev. Henry Millan in the First Church of Christ Congregational in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Beauty
description: Achieving, and keeping, a fashionable hair style is usually possible during winter when the temperaturehumidity index is forgotten, but during the summer, goodlooking hair has often been unattainable for many women. New York hairdressers, always an ingenious bunch, have come up with a variety of new ways to deal with the usual summer hair problems: fine hair going limp, burgeoning frizzles, and thick tresses becoming unmanageable.

title: Newark School Gives Hope to Dropouts
description: NEWARK THERE is a small public high school here that offers no extracurricular activities, not even sports. Yet, its students, all of them former dropouts, seem to have at least as much of the fabled American school spirit as students at suburban high schools.

title: H. Meadwell Weds Francesca Hagadus
description: Francesca Hagadus, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Hagadus of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Hudson Campbell Meadwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Meadwell of Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Cheryl Tow Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chester Tow of Baldwin, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Beth Tow, to Keitn Jeffrey Pastuch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Pastuch of Brooklyn. The future bride attends New York University. Her father is president of Printing Machinery Sales and Service Inc. in Oceanside, L.I. Mr. Pastuch, an alumnus of the University of Bridgeport, expects to graduate next year from the New York Chiropractic College. His father is president of Rhoda Construction in Valley Stream, L.I.

description: EMERGENCY rooms in summertime are almost as busy as beaches. And, while the nature of injuries seen at Westchester hospitals differs from region to region, physicians agree that the most common summer accidents are those that are most easily preventable.

title: San Francisco Losing Its Fireworks Display
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (AP)The San Francisco Chronicle has canceled its annual Candlestick Park fireworks displayleaving the city without a major Independence Day celebrationbecause San Francisco just doesn't have the funds to back us up, a Chronicle spokesman, Phelps Dewey, said today.

Volk of Warwick have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Wilentz of Perth Amboy, N.J.

description: THE noblest of the elements is water, said the Greek poet Pindar more than 2,000 years ago and water will be a major element for many, people this Fourth of July in the nation's celebration of independence and the summervacation season.

title: Voluntary Hospitals In City Preparing For July 7 Strike
description: The League of Voluntary Hospitals, Preparing for a threatened strike by hospital workers on July 7, is laying in supPiles and drafting the 12hour daily work schedules that a strike would necessitate, according to Allen C. Abramson, the league president.

title: Miss Farrell Captures Final in Straight Sets
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 1 Cathy Farrell of Dunkirk, N.Y., who headed the draw, won the Westchester open tennis tournament in straight sets today. In the final at the Saw Mill River Courts, Miss Farrell, who is ranked 13th in the East, defeated unseeded Lisa Dodson of Chappaqua, 63, 63.

title: Dream of Humanities Center About to Come True
description: From an office high in a skyscraper on the Avenue of the Americas, Columbia philosopher has bpen creating an institution, 450 miles away in North Carolina, where advanced scholars will seek new answers to such ageold questions as What is man? and What is the meaning of human life?

title: FOOD
description: 1 SOUTHAMPTON THE experts insist that vanilla, chocolate and strawberry are the biggestselling icecream flavors, but Robert Sjogren will tell you that it isn't so. At his little white homemadeicecream stand on Route 27 in Southampton, it's cantaloupe, white Oreo and fresh raspberry.

title: Air Force Introduces A Maternity Uniform
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 1 (AP)The Air Force has officially recognized motherhood. By late summer, the Air Force said, a maternity uniform will be available at base exchanges for the first time.

title: Sakharov Backs Soviet Stand on Nuclear Power Use
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, normally the Soviet Union's most prominent dissident, has come out in support of the Soviet position favoring the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.

description: The Rich Life of Marjorie Merriweather PoSt. By William Wright. Illustrated. 265 pp. Washington: New Republic Books. $12.50.

description: PORT JEFFERSON WITH its narrow streets, sloping hills and spectacular view of Long Island Sound, Port Jefferson retains all the ambience created by the sea captains, shipbuilders and merchants who settled here more than 100 years ago.

title: Hospital Outlays Disputed
description: TRENTON THROUGHOUT the country, the Federal and state governments are striving to contain soaring healthcare costs by imposing tough restrictions on the introduction of costly medical resources and equipment.

title: Hammond's Blues Shine on the East End
description: JOHN HAMMOND'S soul was pierced so unforgettably at the age of 18 by the music of Robert Johnson. the Delta blues man. that he's never been the same since. The performances Mr. Hammond heard, all recorded in Mississippi in the 1930's, feature the solo voice and guitar of Mr. Johnson on a dozen tunes that are still recognized as highwater marks of the genre. The intense mixture of beauty and pain, of lyrical flow and rhythmic tension, moved Mr. Hammond to teach himself guitar and to sing his heart out to anyone who would listen.

title: Westerners Are More Welcome
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iraq, once vigorously antiWestern and firmly aligned with the Soviet Union, is showing signs of change. It is opening up to the West, has curtailed its cooperation with the Communist bloc and has suppressed its own Sovietoriented Communists.

title: Grand Central decision reinforces preservation movement. Page 5.
description: Observing the American tradition of restless pioneering, Walt Whitman was fascinated in 1845 with the country's pulldownandbuildoveragain spirit.

title: News Summary
description: Fighting broke out in Beirut between Christian militia groups and the Syriandominated Arab peacekeeping forces. At least 22 people were killed in the Christian suburb of AM alRtunmaneh. After a brief lull, the fighting resumed and spread to Ashrafiyeh in east Beirut. President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon telephoned the Syrian President, Hafez alAsad, in an effort to end the fighting, the Beirut radio said. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: TUXEDO AREA'S SALE REMAINS A QUESTION
description: TUXEDO, N.Y.Is the huge Sterling Forest tract on the fringe of the New York City metropolitan areaa tract of 33 square miles that is halfagain as big as Na.nhattan Islandup for sale or isn't it?

description: THE withdrawal this week of the House minority leader, Gerald F. Stevens, from the Republican gubernatorial race left one of the two remaining G.O.P. contenders  Lewis B. Rome, the Senate minority leader  somewhat startled and scrambling to play catchup.

title: Linda Carol Graef To Be Bride in Fall Of Wilton L. Jones
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rene Graef of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Carol Graef, to Thomas Lawrence Jones of New York, son of Mr and Mrs. Wilton Lawrence Jones of Easley, S.C. A wedding in September is ilanned.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The scanting or omission of many famous names one of the several surprising things about the Sam Wagstaff collection of photographsor least, the beautiful but bizarre selection of more than 160 photographs from the Wagstaff collection that is now on view at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place at Washington Square East, through Aug. 25.

title: Dana Zalaznick Engaged
description: Mr, and Mrs. Charles Zalaznick have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dana Sari Zalaznick, to Edward Rbss Gorel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Gorel. Both families are of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Ronnie Peterson of Sweden and Jacky Ickx of Belgium are expected be at Watkins Glen, N.Y., for worldchampionship racing on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. On Saturday there will be a sixhour endurance race starting at noon. On Sunday, a 186mile CanAm Challenge race will begin at 3:15 P.M. The Grand Prix of France will be held at Dijon next Sunday.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: CONGRESS is considering an Administration fiveyear plan to pump $150 million annually into rehabilitating urban parks.

title: The Bakke Case in a Higher Court
description: When King Solomon ordered the baby cut in half, he could safely count on a natural law, rooted in a mother's love, to rescue the secular power from committing an outrage. Now that the Supreme Court has narrowly carved up the legal equities in the Bakke case, only a higher law can assure that Americans respond justly. If we seek it, we too shall find it rooted love.

title: YEMEN ASKS ARAB LEAGUE TO EXPEL SOUTHERN YEMEN
description: CAIRO. July 1  The Foreign Minister of Yemen appealed tonight to the Arab League to expel Southern Yemen from the 22nation group.

title: Informants Are a TwoEdged Weapon
description: WASHINGTON  It was neither luck nor investigative skill that led agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to John Dillinger when they gunned him down outside a Chicago movie theater in 1934. Neither luck nor skill helped agents three decades later to find the spot in the Mississippi woods where three civil rights workers were buried after being brutally murdered by Ku Klux Klan members. With Dillinger, the bureau had help from Anna Sage, an informant who reportedly agreed to cooperate after agents threatened to deport her to Rumania. In Mississippi, agents were led to the burial site by an unidentified informant paid $25,000.

title: A Long Radio Battle Won by the Station Of New York City
description: WNYCAM, New York City's publicaffairs radio station, has won the first battle in a 30year war with a big Minneapolis radio station over the use of the same frequency. But the legal war goes on.

title: ART VIEW
description: This year marks the 60th anniversary of the death of the Austrian painter Egon Schiele. A little advance of the exact date of this anniversary, which falls on Oct. 31, the Sabarsky Gallery, 987 Madison Avenue at 77th Street, has mounted loan exhibition of drawings and watercolors on single themethe selfportraits that are among this artist's most obsessional and powerful subjects. The exhibition remains on view throughout the summer.

title: Furbish Louseworts Saved and So Is Dam
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)The furbish lousewort, an endangered plant, is not expected to block construction of the DickeyLincoln dam project in Maine, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Murderous Fact and Fiction
description: IN The Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight, Jimmy Breslin tried to combine a Runyonesque sort of humor with a serious love story, which difficult for the best of,writers; ultimately that novel was a hybrid failure. The beginning of World Without End, Amen was a brilliant porttait of an alcoholic New York City cop; it fell apart when Mr. Breslin took.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Who owns music? No, wait. That's not a frivolous question, or one posed by a Marxist economist to justify the state's control over art and artists. The man who has raised the issue, not for the first time in his distinguished career, is Virgil Thomson, who seems invariably to ask the question that other musicians and music critics prefer to dodge, even if they suspect that such key questions exist. Here is the 81yearold composer and critic advising the 1978 graduates of the Mannes College of Music the other day on how to view themselves and their relation to the society they live in:

title: Linda Ann Raggi Is Married To Lieut. Joseph. Paul. Ciola

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD SENATOR BETTY HUDSON picked up a sheet of paper from her desk and began reading off the numbers. State legislators in California are paid $23,232 a year and receive $30 a day for expenses, plus mileage allowance, and 5 percent of the legislators are women, she said.

title: Schmidt's Visit Demonstrates Nigeria's Muscle in World Trade and Black Opinion
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  For very good reasons, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany last week began his first trip to black Africa in Nigeria. For the same reasons, President Carter last April began his first trip to black Africa here. Western officials believe that whatever the uncertainties of African development, Nigeria, the most populous and one of the richest nations on the continent, will eventually soread its influence if not its hegemony throughout Africa.

title: Nancy Lea Ryan Bride Of Malott White Nyhart
description: Nancy Lea Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Andrew Ryan of Hamilton, Ohio, was married yesterday evening to Malott White Nyhart, son of Georgia White Nyhart of Weston, Conn., and Eldon Howard Nyhart of Indiananolis.

title: INTERVIEW
description: PEEKSKILL WHEN John E. Ilayes Sr. was Mayor of this northern Westcherler city a quartercentury ago, the job went unpaid and there was no city manager to handle the administrative routine. But the Mayor then, as the Mayor now. was able to make a difference, and John Walsh, an early colleague of Mr. Hayes who became City Clerk and is now City Manager, recalled the Mayor's early influence after a recent ceremony:

title: Trade Gap Narrows, With Drop in Steel Imports Showing the Way
description: A trade deficit of $2.24 billion for May, announced last week, on the face of it offered no reason for dancing in the streets. But consider what came before: $2.86 billion in April, $2.79 billion in March and the record bigdaddy deficit in February of $4.52 billion.

title: Dispute Over Scarborough (Water) Fare
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR GEORGE DAVIS, a banker who lives in Scarborough ordinarily pays about $25 a quarter for water at his residence at 166 River Road. Last August he received threemonth water bill for $385 90 I thought that something might be amiss, he said.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Future of the Past in Paris
description: Travel is a state of mind, as much as moving from place to place. It is a heightened awareness of a strange city's colors, rhythms and nuances. There are messages to all of the senses about a city's style.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on international developmentassistance bill, passed. 49 to 30, June 26. 2. Vote on amendment to prohibit aid to nations that are gross violators of human rights, passed, 75 to 4, June 26. 3. Vote on biomedical and behavioral research bill to establish a Presidential commission for the protection of human subjects of biomedical and behavioral research. passed, 68 to 10, June 26. 4. Vote on resolution to approve United StatesUnited Kingdom tax treaty, requiring a twothirds vote of those present for passage. passed, 82 to 5, June 27.

title: Rhode Island Law Upheld Limiting Ban on Sex With Minors to Men
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 1 (UPI)A Rhode Island judge has upheld the constitutionality of the state's carnal knowledge law which bans only men from having sex with minors.

title: Another Rumanian Theatrical Master Gets a Showing
description: Something extraordinary is on the docket for New York theatergoers this week. Liviu Ciulei's lavishly praised Juilliard production of Frank Wedekind's Spring Awakening reopens fora twoweek run at the Public Theater on Friday. Last December Spring Awakening (as adapted by British playwright Edward Bond) had five public performances at the Juilliard Theater Center, which is now run by Alan Schneider, and it created a sensation. It sold out at once, and the Juilliard's switchboard was clogged with calls requesting seats. The new engagement at the Public is in response to this deI/land.

title: Trolley Lovers Of Vienna See A Clear Track
description: VIENNA, June 25Only a city fascinated by its own past and forever looking backward would go out of its way  and tie up trafficto celebrate the 75th anniversary of its municipal streetcar system.

title: DINING OUT Italian Delights to Tempt the Palate
description: WESTCHESTER'S world of ItalianAmerican cooking is so densely populated that a onceaweek column cannot possibly hope to do it justice while covering other cuisines at the same time. This is by Italian Delights to Tempt the Palate way of apology to the many deserving places not covered here. Today's roundup highlights five of the Italian restaurants we've visited in the year and half at this station.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (Reuters)An agreement was reached today between the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen Union and the Pacific Maritime Association on a threeyear contract, averting a threatened walkout by 11,500West Coast dock workers.

title: Elizabeth S. Garrity Bride of Phillip Ellis
description: The Lady Chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N. Y., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Elizabeth Seton Garrity, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lawrence Garrity of Rye, to Phillip A. Ellis of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Ellis of San Leandro. Calif.

title: Finding Hints
description: Drew S. Days 3d, Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, discussed the impact of the Bakke decision with Robert Reinhold, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: Smoking's Still a Burning Issue
description: Aproposal by the County Board of Health to prohibit smoking in theaters, hospitals, schools and restaurants except in designated areas appears to be going up in smoke amid intense lobbying by the tobacco industry and restaurateurs.

title: INVESTING Rare Books Lure Collectors Seeking Stability, Low Risk
description: Disappointed by the performance of the stock and bond markets and weary of watching inflation eat into their profits and yields, small investors are increasingly moving their funds into alternative investment arenas that promise them more protection. One such field, long dominated by wealthy collectors and academics, is rare books.

title: Mary Tucker Wed in Pelham
description: In the Roman CathoEc Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Pelham, N.Y., yesterday, Mary Evelyn Tucker daughter of Mr., and Mrs. William D Tucker Jr. of Pelham, was married to. John Alden Grim, son of Mrs. Dee Forest Grim of Fargo, N.D., and the late Mr. Grim.

title: ART
description: WATER MILL ROBERT DASH might be called the unofficial court painter of Sagaponack. However, his court is not the vilage's residents, but rather the landscape. Sagaponack's roads, buildings, fields and skies are his sitters, and he paints them over and over in all seasons, understandingly and lovingly. Sagaponack has a singular personality, different from that of any other place on the South Shore, and Mr. Dash captures that personality in his own distinctive way.

title: Smithsonian Unearths 42 Adrian Designs
description: WASHINGTON  Greta Garbo languished in an Adrian dress in Grand Hotel. Joan Crawford pined in one. Norma Shearer, Carole Lombard and tiny Janet Gaynor, Adrian's wife, romped across the screen in his dresses and gowns during the 1930's and 1990's. inspiring hundreds of American women to leave darkened movie houses and head for their sewing machines. Seventh Avenue wasn't far behind, churning out simulations of Adrian: exotic fantasy creations rampant with animal motifs or patched with sequined or embroidered insets.

title: THEATER Shakespeare Is Back On Stratford Stage
description: SHAKESPEARE returns to the American Shakespeare Theater on Wednesday, with Lynn Redgrave as Viola in Twelfth Night directed by Gerald Freedman, the new artistic director. It should be a banner occasion, considering that most of the theatrical knowitalls had buried the company when it didn't have a season last summer.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The nation's major commercial banks raised their prime lending rate Friday by a quarterpoint to 9 percent and, while the increase was not unexpected, it caused an erratic stock market to sag a bit further.

title: Sunday Observer
description: A showbusiness man told me recently of an actor whc turned down a role because it required him to die at the end of the movie. The actor thought it would be bad for his career. Having enjoyed a run of successes during the past few years, he felt like a man with a future and believed that dying might put an end to it.

title: GARDENING
description: WRILE the spring rush is over, there are plenty of things to do in the garden during July and August to offset the summer doldrums, although the slower pace should allow time to enjoy the fruits of your labors.

title: State Cancer Drive Focuses on Women
description: THE New Jersey division of the American Cancer Society is mounting an educational offensive against smoking by teenage girls and young women.

title: Yonkers School Board Votes to Dismiss Iannacone
description: WHITE PLAINSThe Republicandominated Board of Education in Yonkers has voted to dismiss Dominick lannacone as administrator of one of its adulteducation centers. Mr. Iannacone, who was the Democratic candidate for Mayor last year, charges politics in his soaclal to The New Yore Times.

title: Miss Graham's Clytemnestra Danced
description: One can only feel sorry for those who missed the single performance of Martha Graham's masterpiece, Clytemnestra, Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Pioneer in Use of Bulk Milk Tank Is Honored on Dairy Day Upstate
description: COPAKE, N..Y, June 28As a boy on the farm, A. C. Fisher got tired of lifting and carrying 10gallon milk cans, each weighing 110 pounds when filled, from the cooling sheds of dairy farmers and transporting them to milk processing plants.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: SIX months have passed since State Supreme Court justice gave New Castle six months to plan for 3,500 apartments. So far, it has rezoned for one. That's one down, 3,499 to go, wisecracked the town's Supervisor, Charles Banks.

title: O.A.S. Calls on 3 Members to End Rights Abuses.
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Tha Organization of American States ended its eighth annual General Assembly today by declaring its strong support for human rights in general and specifically calling on Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay to eliminate abuses.

title: D. R. Ludwigson to Wed Sandra Bondy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Bondy of Carefree, Ariz., formerly of North Salem, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Lee Bondy, to David Roger Ludwigson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus Ludwigson of Duluth, Minn. The wedding is planned for Aug. 19 in Carefree.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College. Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Man of La Mancha, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Friday (through Aug. 12). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: NEW ISSUES RAISED ON SCHOOL FINANCING
description: MINEOLA, LLAfter nine months, 145 witnesses and 22,400 pages of testimony, the current method of financing public education in New York State has been declared unconstitutional, but the longawaited decision has raised new questions and left a number of others unresolved.

title: New York CoinTelephone Users Get a Bad, but Bubbly, Message
description: The price went up from 10 to 30 cents last week for a number of coin telephone calls in New York Citythe socalled twounit calls such as those between lower and midtown Manhattan and the farthest areas of the city, including all of Staten Island.

title: It's Outsiders vs. Lebanon's Inside Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Once a tolerant crossroads of civilizations, Lebanon has become an international tarbaby, trapping Arabs, Israelis, the big powers and now the UnitedNations in its sticky feuds and passions, some ancient and some modern.

title: Beatha
description: SINGERJules H.An exemplary Individual. A most unselfish, kind and guying person. An outstanding community leader. Trustee of Great Neck Synagogue. Trustee of the Men's Club of Temple BethEl end Trustee of the Village of Saddle Rock.

title: Metaphors, Metaphors
description: By David Plante. 301 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus it Giroux. $8.95.

title: United Press International
description: McCOVEY REACHES A HOME RUN MILESTONE: Willie McCovey of the Glanti being greeted at the plate by teammates after hitting his 500th career home run in the game of a doubleheader Friday at Atlanta. San Francisco defeated the Braves in both games, 109 and 105.

title: The Great Bagel Bowl
description: AFTER I left the Island last summer and traveled along the highways of America, I suffered the slings and arrows of outrageous heartburn. In cities across the continent I found an appalling lack of bagel quality. Once I even tried the frozen, grocery variety bland little cannonballs. I grimly concluded that the real cost of leaving the Island was the dearth of edible bagels in my life. (Also, I missed my family.)

title: BEHIND THE REST SELLERS
description: At last count, there were 3,000 diet books, 2,000 selfimprovement treatises and 1,000 sex manuals, give or take a few hundred. Inevitably, someone had to come along to combine the three categories in one allpurpose book called The Dieter's Guide to Weight Loss During Sex  as Richard Smith has, in his new trade paperback best seller from Workman Publishing Company.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE SECOND WORLD WAR, by A. J. P. Taylor. (Berkley/ Windhover, $7.95.) A profusely illustrated account of the global conflict's political and military aspects by a distinguished British historian who not only has a knack for telling a complex story concisely and clearly but vision broad enough to comprehend the roles played by nations other than his own homeland.

title: Edel's James Biography Coming In Paper From Avon on Aug. 20
description: There was no razzledazzle auction; no inflated claim of the sixfigure transaction; nothing to grab the lapels of the dollarfixated bookchat columnists. Yet the quiet, editorially minded arrangement whereby Avon Books will bring out Leon Edel's five volumes of Henry James is by far the most significant paperback publication of the year.

title: French Nuclear Testing Set
description: PARIS, July 1 (Reuters)This year's French nuclear tests are to begin in a few days at Mururoa Atoll in the Pacific, according to French journalists who have just been taken on a tour of the area by military authorities. The officers said the weapcns to be tested were for the multiplewarhead M4 missile for submarines.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Administration last week set forth its views on proposals to cut the capitalgains tax. It landed with both feet.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Matthew L. Wald unfairly characterizes Connecticut as a rich state that ignores the poor [May 7].

title: ChurchState Issue Is Raised in Dallas Over Schools Post
description: DALLAS..Tuly 1Candidates for the top job in the Dallas school system. the eighth largest urban district in the coun try, have found that their religious views and habits are as much a factor in the selection process as their stands on desegregation or budgeting. The result has been a heated debate that has brought questions of the separation of church and state into the search for someone to fill the $47,500ayear superintendent's post.

title: Long Island/ This Week
description: 4.MAGANSETT  A Fourth of July Celebration, with works by Rufus Coes, Rae Ferren, Newtown McMahan, Norman Seaver,

title: Deaths
description: JENKIN  Jack, Beloved husband of Beatrice. Devoted father of Leonard & Richard. Adored grandfather of Emily, Jesse & Sarah. Loving broth. er of Murray, Rase & Beniamin. Fond brotherinlaw & dear uncle. Services Sunday, July 2, 11:15A.M. at Schwartz Brothers, 114.03 Queens Blvd.

title: Autumnal Madness Is Arriving This Week for Dolphin Rookies
description: The advent of pro football during the summer months manages to infuriate many followers, who object to the squeezing of the seasons by professional sports promoters. Since most people associate the game with autumn, autumnal madness being a favorite cliche, football seems to take the brunt of the anger about overlapping seasons.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Astros Trounce Padres As Lemongello Stars, 92
description: HOUSTON, July 1 (AP)  Mark Lemongello scattered seven hits for the game and singled in a run in Houston's sixrun fifth inning as the Astros routed the Padres, 92, tonight.

title: Miss Goldman, C. E. Goodell Wed,
description: Patricia Ann Goldman and Charies. Ellsworth Goodell, a former Senator from New York, both of Washington, were married yesterday morning at the bride's home by Judge Theodore New.: man, Chief Judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

title: C.F.L. Prepares to Open With Metcalf as Feature
description: TORONTO, July 1 (UPI) The nineteam Canadian Football League, which this season will feature Terry Metcalf of the Toronto Argonauts, will begin play on July 11 when the Montreal Alouettes, the defending Greg Cup champions, play the Ottawa Rough Riders hnd the Winnipeg Blue Bombers play the British Columbia Lions.

title: GARDENING
description: A HOLIDAY weekend should be just that, and gardeners deserve a respite, a sort of independence day of their own, time to relax and to contemplate. But genuine gardeners will never put away their trowels and hoes for long. Cultivating plants is a pleasant pastime in itself.

title: Syracuse's Crew Loses at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 1  The rains held off while the thirdround races of the 139th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta were contested today, then arrived just in time for the luncheon interval. When the weather had cleared, Tim Crooks put on one of the brightest performances of the regatta.

title: Forego, at Age 8, Still Defying the Odds
description: By noontime, racing's favorite millionaire had stretched out comfortably and was sound asleep on the floor of his stall at Belmont Park.

title: Note from a UniverseWatcher: We Are the Newest, the Youngest And the Brightest Thing Around.
description: Somewhere, on some remote planet set at precisely the right distance from a star of just the right magnitude and right temperature, on the other side of our galaxy, there is at this moment a committee nearing the end of a yearlong study of our own tiny, provincial solar system. The intelligent beings of that place are putting their signatures (numbers of some sort, no doubt) to a paper which asserts, with finality, that life is out of the question here and the place is not worth an expedition. Their instruments have detected the presence of that most lethal of all gases, oxygen, and that is the end of that. They had planned to come, bringing along mobile factories for manufacturing lifegiving ammonia, but what's the use of risking strangulation.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BROOKLYN  Sculpture for the blind and visually impaired. Trained guides for tactile viewing. Through July 9, New England Center for Contemporary Art, Rte. 169. Wednesday through Sunday 1 to 5 P.M. Phone 7748899.

title: Luretta Bybee Is Married To Leslie L. Riek, Banker
description: Loretta Bybee, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. W. Cecil Bybee of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Lesley Lloyd Riek, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Roland Riek of Midland, Tex., were married yesterday by the Rev. Howard H. Hollowell, the bride's grandfather, in the First United Methodist Church of Midland.

title: A 700 Word Tough Tender Pro
description: IF Jimmy Cagney was a sportswriter, he would have been Jimmy Cannon (we couldn't afford subjunctive on our block). A tough guy who cries a lot, a staccato marshmallow, also the fellow you have to clear it with to get into the gang, and the guy who defends you best on the way out. His speech was rough but fastidious, because be had found the words himself and he valued them, like a gangster's jewelry. So much for style. Jimmy Cannon knew you had have a voice of your own to be beard in the din of an evening paper, and he developed a riveting one. There were a lot of rich voices around in his day: Dan Parker, Joe Williams, Frank Graham. You didn't read them for information, of which you got choking amounts elsewhere, but for mood and attitude, as you would choose a guy to talk to in a bar after the game. Laconic witty, indignant, the closest thing you could find to talking to the mirror.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HE can taste it already. Fame, stardom perhaps, as the Jarvis of Suffolk County. That's what Lou Modica is dreaming about these days, and the dream may end up having substance. Unless Governor Carey turns thumbs down  and Mr. Modica promises that doom will befall him if he does  the voters in Suffolk County may soon the gain the right, unique in the state, to put a Californiatype Proposition 13 on the ballot. And Lou Modica, a semiretired Islip businessman, is the man who plans to head the drive to get it there.

title: Author's Query
description: We are preparing for publication letters written by J. Robert Oppenheimer prior to 1996. The principal archival collections have been consulted, and the edition is nearing completion. We would appreciate hearing from individuals who have, or know of. such letters.

title: Letters: The Traps Set for the Befuddled
description: Please tell Mary Z. Gray, the author of A Simple Traveler's Lament (Travel Section, June 11) that she has many benighted sisters out here groping in the same tangle of unclear road signs. I say sisters, because I have yet to meet a man who admits to being lost, and who stops to ask directions. Everything she mentioned in her article has happened to me.

title: Old Young Country
description: THESE two excellent books complement each other neatly in conveying the drama of the postwar Yugoslav experience. Dusko Doder conveys the human texture of Yugoslav life today; Dennison Rusinow explains and analyzes its institutional development.

title: Barbara G. Coffee And Steven Jay Wolf To Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Coffee Jr. of Seneca Fa'ls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Grace Coffee, to Steven Jay Wolf, son of Edith Wolf and Leon Wolf, both of New York. Miss Coffee and her fiance plan to be married in September.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: THE mere mention of an energy crisis is met with a collective yawn by the average citizen these days. However, hundreds of New Jersey homeowners are heeding the warnings that this country faces staggering increases in energy costs, if not critical shortages of supply, in the next 20 years.

title: Diana Vivian Wed in Bermuda
description: Diana Vivian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Vivian of Plainfield, N.J., was married in Warwick, Bermuda, yesterday to Dr. Earl W. Brian, son of Mrs. Earl W. Brian of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Dr. Brian. The Rev. Lewis Davidson performed the ceremony in Christ Presbyterian Church.

title: P.B.A SEEKS MEDIATOR AS NEGOTIATIONS RECESS
description: Negotiations between the city and its S,000 police officers were recessed yesterday, and a spokesman for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said they were stalemated.

title: What's Doing in the BERKSHIRES
description: IDENTITY  The Berkshires are highlands between the Connecticut and Hudson River Valleys. In the days when inland travel was by riverboat or horse or oxdrawn wagon, they were a barrier. A history by Richard D. Birdsall of Berkshire County, the westernmost county in Massachusetts. states that early settlers found themselves inhabitants of an almost isolated region largely selfcontained and geographically independent of both the Yankee and the Yorker. Well, things have changedsome.

title: A Guide to the State's Beaches and Swimming Facilities
description: The following table lists the state parks with swimming facilities and the 16 towns and cities on Long Island Sound with beaches open to nonresidents. Parking space at local beaches is generally limited and, where indicated, restricted to local residents. Hours indicate when lifeguards are present. The beaches in shore communities not listed are closed to nonresidents. Except where indicated, admission to beaches or pools is free.

title: Rent and Subway Fare Up in France
description: PARIS, July 1 (Reuters)The price of coal, rents and subway tickets went up today in the third wave of price rises in France since the March elections. Among items increased in price in May and June were rail fares, electricity and gas, postage stamps, cigarettes and gasoline.

title: Pope Seeks Unity of Churches
description: VATICAN CITY, July 1 (AP)Pope Paul VI called today for a more resolute collaboration to resolve differences between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox churches. Speaking to a delegation of the Orthodox Patriarchate of Constantinople, the Pope said he looked forward to the day when we can commemorate together all the apostles and all the eastern saints in a great eucharistic concelebration of unity.

title: Susan Hendl Dances in Goldberg Variations
description: Two New York debuts in The Goldberg Variations on Friday at the New York State Theater were not likely to add much dimension to the stature of Adam Luders and Susan Hendl. A ballet that accompanies Bach through the polyphonic explorations of his Goldberg Variations, it provides no star turns but is very much a dance of large masses and small ensembles. But the two New York City Ballet dancers brought something of their own to bear upon the Jerome Robbins work and turned in performances that left little to be desired.

title: ART
description: BROOKFIELD IN Connecticut, art exhibitions must sometimes fight for attention with idyllic surroundings, but there can be few places where the competition is stiffer than at the Brookfield Craft Center (Route 25, between Danbury and New Milford).

title: The Gives: Bonn Growth, U.S. Energy
description: BONNAn American diplomat on a morning jog down the bicycle path that runs along the Rhine near the United States Embassy recently encountered a reporter running in the other direction.

title: Homespun Parties For the 4th of July
description: INDEPENDENCE Day, at least in Connecticut, is returning this year to the simple pleasures of picnics, band concerts and cornmunity fellowship. After three years of elaborate and often expensive celebrations commemorating the Bicentennial, the emphasis is on homespun togetherness.

title: Wind Tricky for LI Sailors
description: The joys of sailing Long Island Sound often are as fleeting as the wind. That's the problem. Just when the wind is most appreciated, during the leisurely days of summer, it seems to disappear. And if there is a breeze in the morning, it seems to last just long enough to lure a sailor into the middle of the Sound.

title: Phils Beat Cubs, 21, Take 4Game Lead
description: CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)  Bob Boone's homer and Ted Sizemore's runscoring single provided the offense, and Randy Lerch and Ron Reed took care of the pitching today as the Philadelphia Phillies gained a 21 victory over the Chicago Cubs and took a fourgame lead in the National League East.

title: Tactics Thwart Government Attacks on Pension Fund
description: WASHINGTON  In the old days, the teamsters union handled a complaint from a member by feigning deafness or with a knock on the head. If the whiner persisted, he might have received an offer a pair of cement shoes. That usually did the trick. with Federal investigators, the teamsters can't be so blunt, of course, but they have elevated evasion to an art. One way or another, the union has thwarted Government attempts to clean up its Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund, one of the larger pension plans in the United States with 450,000 members and a value, it says, of $1.4 billion. New allegations in the last two weeks only underscore how effective the resistance has been.

title: How It Was, How It Is
description: For the last six months, two worlds have existed side by side on the fourth floor of The New York Times's West 43d Street headquarters.

title: Newport Jazz
description: New York may be the jazz capital of the world, but Los Angeles has had a steady level of jazz activity for years, too, mostly because the film and television studios have attracted so many fine musicians there, and they get together periodically in various jazz combinations to purify their souls. Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall the Newport Jazz Festival brought together two manifesttions of the presentday Los Angeles jazz scene. The result may not have offered quite enough particulars to make sweeping generalizations about jazz in Southern California, but it did make for an interesting evening.

title: Australia to Pay Family $7 Million for the Cocos
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 2 (Reuters)  Australia announced today that it would buy the Cocos Islands from their British owner, whose family was given them by Queen Victoria.

title: Deciding on Colors for G.M.'s 1981 Models
description: WARREN, Mich.  In the days of Henry Ford, it was easy to choose a car color. You could pick any color you wanted, as long as it was black.

title: At Goshen, the Finish Line for an Era
description: GOSHEN, N.Y. THE signover a decaying railroad station reads, Welcome to Goshen, Home of the Hall of Fame of the Trotter. Across the street the old Occidental Hotel, opened in 1841 when the first locomotive steamed into town, stands as a monument to a bygone era.

title: Bakke Ruling Supports Rights Goal, Carter Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  In his first public reaction to the Supreme Court's decision in the Bakke case, President Carter said Friday that the ruling confirmed his Administration's commitment to affirmative action and allowed the implementation of affirmative action at all levels of American life.

title: U.S. Envoy to Chile, Recalled in Dispute, Returns
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2  Ambassador George W. Landau, who was recalled to Washington for consultations because of a reported lack of cooperation by Chile's military regime in the investigation into the murder of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, returned here today.

title: Break in Water Main Halts West Side IRT
description: A watermath break at Canal and Varick Streets last night halted West Side IRT service south of Times Square to Borough Hall and South Ferry. A Transit Authority police spokesman said service might not be resumed by rush hour this morning.

title: Beth Carol Steinberg, Student, Wed to Joshua Mermelstein
description: Beth Carol Steinberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Steinberg of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, and Joshua Mermelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Mermelstein of Belle Harbor, Queens, were married yesterday

title: IRAN REMAINS EAGER ON GULFSTATE PACE
description: TEHERAN Iran, July 2  Although there have been no new talks as yet, recent upheavals in the Persian Gulf have increased Iran's interest in negotiating a mutual security pact in the area, according to several leading officials here.

title: A Design Problem On Relay Satellite Delays Launching
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is redesigning the electronic system of giant tracking and data relay satellite, originally planned for a 1980 launching, because Russian radar in Eastern Europe would excessively interfere with its effectiveness.

title: Fed Action Stirs New Questions
description: Today the Federal Reserve lifts the rate it charges banks for borrowing its funds  but the rise, announced Friday, is not as large as had been expected In the credit markets, nor does it have the approval of the chairman of the Fed.

title: Agatha Christie Drama, Black Coffee, Is Staged
description: OLNEY, Md.  With its white clapboard structure and its wide front porch filled with patrons in pastel cotton and white shoes, the Olney Theater looks like the incarnation of summer theatergoing, but its programs are more individual than most, and it makes a point of producing one or two new plays each season. For example, its executive producer, James D. Waring, a friend and longtime champion of the Irish playwright Hugh Leonard, has used the theater to introduce a number of his works to America, including Da, currently running with acclaim and success on Broadway.

title: 14 BLACKS ARE SLAIN ON RHODESIAN FARM
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 2 Fourteen black farm laborers and children were shot and burned to death last night by a group of 25 nationalist guerrillas who attacked a whiteowned cattle ranch in eastern Rhodesia, according to a military spokesman.

title: Holocaust TV Series, Criticized, Is Sidelined by West Germans
description: BONN, July 2  Directors of West Germany's largest television network have decided that a West German version of the Holocaust series on the Nazi extermination of the Jews will be shunted from the main channel to a group of regional stations, a decision described as effectively burying the programs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rita C. Fishman Married To Sarni Sassoon Sheena
description: Rita Claire Fishman and Sami Sassoon Sheena were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph Simckes at the Cottage on the Park at Hampshire House.

title: MONDALE SAYS BEGIN AGREES TO A PARLEY WITH EGYPT AND U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, July 2Vice President Mondale said today that Israel had agreed to attend a foreign ministers conference with Egypt and the United States in London later this month.

title: Ballet: Martha Graham in Lamentation
description: The Martha Graham Dance Cornpany ended its first season at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday night with screams of Martha resounding through the air. The house was full and included a visiting group of artists from China who found themselves witness to thousands of spectators springing up as one and roaring when Chairman Martha appeared to take a bow.

title: Cashin's Clothes: Three Decades of Comfort
description: Bonnie Cashin is an American fashion institution. Her first poncho appeared in Hollywood in 1945 when she was designing clothes for 20th CenturyFox. Her mother sewed it up. Miss Cashin is still making ponchos.

title: Rowing: Bulgaria, Britain Sweep Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 2  Britain and Bulgaria divided all the honors today as the 139th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta ended under cloudy skies.

title: Michael Arshansky, City Ballet Dancer, Makeup Artist, Dies
description: Michael Arshansky, an actor and dancer who created the role of Drosselmeyer in George Balanchine's version of The Nutcracker and who appeared in other character parts with the New York City Ballet, died last Friday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Firefighters' Strike In Memphis Brings Blazes and Curfew
description: MEMPHIS, July 2  City officials ordered a curfew tonight after 205 fires, most of them thought to have been set by arsonists, broke out in the first full day of a strike by Memphis's union firefighters.

title: Australia to Impose Life Penalty On Traffickers in Narcotic Drugs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 2 (Reuters)  Australia is to increase its penalty for trafficking in narcotics to life imprisonment because it believes the present maximum of 25 years is not enough.

title: Rising Steel Demand Opens Mills
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa. July 2  Glenn Goode, a young steelworker, stood in the 42inch rolling mill at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant here, supervising a group of workers near the roller where refrigeratorsized pieces of red hot steel blocks were being squeezed into narrow beams, destined for some construction project.

title: Deaths
description: ANGERTLawrence. Beloved broth, er of Edna Schultz, Sylvia Israeiit Sally Feintuch, Shirley Blum. and Pearl Ribak. Services today 1 P.M from Nassau North Chapels. 55 North Station Plaza (Poo. RR Ste tion). Great Neck. New York.

title: Radio
description: 89 AM, WKCR. Two Masses; Requiem, Bruckner.

title: Market Place
description: HUSKY Oil Ltd., shares of which reached a peak of 47 and change when it had three suitors, has cooled a bit now that PetroCanada and Alberta Gas Trunk Line have said they do not plan make bids for the company.

title: Chess:
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Lubomir Kavalek's 10thround victory over Kenneth Regan of Paramus, N.J., the United States junior cochampion, was typical of the kind of exact play that brought him victory in the United States Championship Tournament. The Wasnington granamaster wound up the tounament here in the Fine Arts Hall of Ambassador College with a fine 104 score.

title: 2 Persons Killed and One Injured In New York Highway Crashes
description: Two persons were killed and another man was injured yesterday in two accidents on the Henry Hudson Parkway the police reported.

title: Building Irregularities Reported
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)  Hundreds of thousands of dollars in expenditures at Boston's John F. Kennedy Federal Building cannot be accounted for because of false. inadequate or nonexistent records. The Boston Sunday Globe reported. A General Services Administration audit of the project, obtained by the paper, found that billings submitted to the agency misrepresented work performed.

title: Hampton Concert Celebrates His 50 Years in Jazz
description: Lionel Hampton celebrated his 50th year in jazz Saturday night in Carnegie Hall with a special Newport Jazz Festival tribute. The Borough of Manhattan officially proclaimed Saturday Lionel Hampton Day; before the program was over one was ready to proclaim 1978 Lionel Hampton Year.

title: Duplicate Dresses Create a Problem
description: When two women wear the same dress to a party, trouble erupts, at least internally. And there can be a similar conflagration, apparently, when a cartoonist dresses characters in cartoons for different advertiser clients in the same outfits.

title: U.S. Weighs Requiring Disclosure on Used Cars
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commission is considering regulations that would require usedcar dealers to disclose on a window sticker such information as the approximate mileage on a used car and repairs made by the dealer that cost more than $100.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME. July 2 The Socialists, Italy's thirdstrongest party, sought today to break the deadlock in the fourdayold presidential election by formally introducing the candidacy of Sandro Pertini, 82 years old, a founder of the party and a onetime leading antiFascist.

title: Fur Seal Is Born in Mystic
description: MYSTIC, Conn., July 2 (AP) Mother and baby are doing fine at the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium following what may be the first birth in captivity of a northern fur seal, an aquarium spokesman said today. The pup was born Friday and was nursing from its mother and seemed to be doing well, according to Julie Ladwig. The birth was part of the aquarium's effort to breed sea animals in captivity.Northern fur seals are very skittish and no attempt has been made to approach the mother and pup and the baby's sex had not even been determined.

title: Tariff Increase Refused For Stainless Cutlery
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)President Carter has refused to set special tariffs on stainless steel knives, forks and spoons because it would add to inflation, the White House says.

title: Carey Using Big Supporting Cast in Reelection Campaign's Television Commercials
description: Testimonials to Governor Careyby the actress Helen Hayes and half a dozen New York politicianshave started appearing on television screens in an advertising campaign that is unusual for an incumbent.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 10mile strip of redtide algae see off Atlantic City was causing no problems for swimmers and other vacationers yesterday, authorities said.

title: NEED TO TAP HUDSON FOR WATER DISPUTED
description: The Tristate Regional Planning Commission, differing with Federal projections of the metropolitan area's future water needs, has concluded that New York City will not have to tap the Hudson River to meet consumer demand for the next 50 years.

title: Commodities
description: ONE of the glaring ironies of the prices of commodity futures in recent months has been the sharp decline in costs of raw materials at a time when inflation is accelerating.

title: Waterfront Events Are Highlighted On 2d Day of Holiday Celebration
description: Thirty sailing ships raced down New York Bay. Army parachutists put on a spectacular program for Coney Island beachgoers. Off the Bay Ridge shore, the Police Department simulated airsea rescues.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON LOST in the hubbub over whether to cut capitalgains taxes is another Republican taxcut proposal that would slice $113.4 billion from Federal income taxes over the next three years. Its sponsors  Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York and Senator William V. Roth of Delaware  argue that a tax cut would actually increase Federal tax collections because it would generate increased economic activity. The bill, which has been floating around for a time, lost by only 23 votes in the House in March, and its proponents hope that, after the overwhelming passage of the Proposition 13 taxreduction initiative in California, they will prevail later this year.

title: Busy Weekend For Air Travel
description: Several airlines, citing preliminary figures, indicated yesterday that travel records were broken Friday, with the lines carrying more passengers more. miles than ever before.

title: NEED TO TAP HUDSON FOR WATER DISPUTED
description: The Tristate Regional Planning Commission, differing with Federal projections of the metropolitan area's future water needs, has concluded that New York City will not have to tap the Hudson River to meet consumer demand for the next 50 years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ArtcoBell Corporation, Temple, Tex., manufacturers and distributors of educational furniture, and producers and distributors of food products, has announced the resignation of Bonner B. Hardegree as president, member of the executive committee and board member. Also resigning, as vice chairman and a director, was R.V. Hardegree. The company announced the appointment of Oliver N. Oldham, executive president, as interim chief operating officer.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Fourth of July weekend may be the busiest ever for American airlines, in what promises to be a record year for the industry, thanks to lower fares. [Page 29.]

title: ROCKEFELLER CITED URGING DRUG IN RIOT
description: BUFFALO, July 2  A state study never made public says that former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller suggested during the September 1971 riot at Attica prison that the tranquilizer Librium be put into the inmates' water supply, according to published reports.

title: Golf: Miss Blalock Gains Lead
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., July 2 (AP) Jane Blalock birdied the 17th hole twice today and earned a onestroke advantage with a threeunderpar 141 after two rounds in a rainplagued, $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: New Faces in Southern Politics: Women, Young and Outsiders
description: ATLANTA, July 2  Every time I run, people run the same race against me, reflected Bill Clinton, the 31yearold whiz kid of Arkansas politics. They say, This guy is being foisted on us  like I'm a creation of the media who's been cloned somehow with an Ivy League education and long hair.

title: Around the Nation
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 2 (UPI)  Gov. Meldrim Thomson is threatening a multiminiondollar damage suit against the Federal Government for what he called its asinine decisipn to suspend construction of the $2.3 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: For Children, Fun at a Fast Clip
description: Parents who have struggled to cut their offspring's hair know what a chore it is to get a wriggling child to sit still. Worse yet, their efforts aren't always appreciated.

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 3,1978

title: 5 Airlines Sued Over Rerouting
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reuters) The Civil Aeronautics Board has filed suit charging five airlines with overcharging passengers unable to fly on Northwest Airlines because the line is being struck.

title: Houston Mail Service Expanded
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)  Houston yesterday became the 13th United States city to be designated as an international exchange office for the receipt and dispatch of international airmail. Postmaster General William F. Bolger said that international airmail mailed in the Houston area would get substantially better service than before because of direct flights abroad.

title: Outdoors
description: WEEKS of warm weather now stretch invitingly ahead for city folk, and one way to enjoy them is to engage in the gentle sport of nature observation during daytime walks in Central Park. Within that stonewalled rectangle of 840 acres of lawns, woods, walkways, lakes and streams is far more in the way of nature's handicraft than the casual visitor might expect.

title: A Las Vegas Love Story
description: Gambling changed my life. It started with speed reading. I used to dawdle over recipes while the food grew stale. Or I would spend time talking to people. At work I looked forward to the coffee break.

title: Handling Natural Disasters: U.S. Cities Are Vulnerable
description: Everybody knows from newspaper datelines, most recently those from Salonika, Greece, two weeks ago, that catastrophes occur in faroff places. But in Washington, the people in the Federal Disaster Assistance Administration have to assume that someday an upheaval of nature will, with catastrophic consequences, strike a more familiar city.

title: Letter: On Prescribing Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Complaining Of Arts Center Practices
description: HOLMDEL, July 2  Thousands of irate New Jersey concertgoers are complaining to consumerprotection officials and state leaders that the Garden State Arts Center has failed to fill ticket orders, neglected to make refunds and increased prices without notice.

title: U.S. Economists Study Japan Surplus
description: TOKYO, July 2  Four academic economists from the United States are to arrive here tomorrow to examine the reasons for Japan's huge balanceofpayments surpluses, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Waterfront Events Are Highlighted On 2d Day of Holiday Celebration
description: Thirty sailing ships raced down New York Bay. Army parachutists put on spectacular program for Coney Island beachgoers. Off the Bay Ridge shore, the Police Department simulated airsea rescues.

title: Gibson and Aides Seeking Raises
description: NEWARK, July 1 In its first working session, the newly elected Newark Municipal Council today adopted pay raises for its members and other city officials totaling more than $500,000.

title: An Earthquake Jars Northern Part of State.
description: A section of North Jersey near the New York border was jarred over the weekend by an earthquake that a scientist said yesterday was the largest in the area in 10 years.

title: Events
description: Music

title: The Peril of Delay in School Financing
description: While declaring New York State's system of financing the public schools unconstitutional, Justice Kingsley Smith of the State Supreme Court added two sound political judgments. The first was that the State Legislature brought the ruling upon itself by blocking all efforts at reform. The second was that unless it now corrects the pattern of inequities, the courts will be forced to dictate what may be harsh remedies.

title: Union Leader in Tax Debate
description: LAS VEGAS, June 28Once he was the enfant terrible of American labor, railing at George Meany with one side of his mouth and threatening visions of cities crippled by strikes with the other.

title: A Tentative Accord Is Reached to Avert Trashnien's Strike
description: LITTLE FALLS, July 2 (UPI)  The Mayor of Elizabeth said today that a tentative contract had apparently been reached with garbage collectors who had threatened to strike 67 northern New Jersey municipalities tomorrow.

title: Paper Using Cold Type
description: With today's issue, The New York Times abandons a 19thcentury printing process for one more in tune with the technology of modern industry.

title: It's Like Newport of Old At Saratoga Springs Fete
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 2  The Newport Jazz Festival tried to go home again this weekend  back to the big, openair musical carnival it was when it began at Newport, R.I.

title: 4 Bystanders Are Struck By Chinatown Gunfire
description: Three women and a 2yearold girl were struck by gunfire outside a Chinatown restaurant yesterday afternoon in what the police said could have been a clash between rival gang members who escaped in the crowd. The girl was reported in serious but stable condition last night, and the women were not seriously hurt, the police said.

title: Miss Krupsak Tests Her Parries And Thrusts for the Duel Ahead
description: Trying out campaign themes in the first week of her gubernatorial candidacy, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak is directly challenging a major thrust of Governor Carey's campaign  that he was too busy dealing with fiscal crises in the state, city and other communities to nurture his personal and political imagery.

title: The Stage at the Stadium
description: THE mood of Yankee Stadium last week for the YankeeRed Sox series was magnificently hostile, a collision of separate needs and collective memory. When in the second game the Red Sox undressed Ron Guidry, Yankee Hero No. 1, a vicious border clash broke out in the upper deck. It raged for minutes before peacemakers and Rich Gossage could restore order. A fan with as little sympathy for violence as for the Yankees mused that the combatants probably were method actors dramatizing the most recent George SteinbrennerBilly Martin brouhaha.

title: Sports World Specials
description: I'm sore all over.

title: PROTESTANTS FIGHT EAST GERMAN MOVE
description: EAST BERLIN, June 28  East Germany's Protestant leaders have launched a public drive against Government plans to introduce compulsory military instruction into the high schools.

title: Oh Paces Victory
description: TOKYO, July 2 (AP)  Clyde Wright, a former major leaguer, and liajirne Kato combined on a fivehitter and Sadaharu Oh hit a threerun homer, his 22d of the Japanese League season, as the Yomiuri Giants beat the Taiyo Whales, 7.2, today to earn a split of a doubleheader.

title: Oil OverPricing Alleged
description: WASHINGTON July 2 (UPI)  The Department of Energy has accused the Shell Oil and Getty Oil companies of more than $59 million in crude oil cost and pricing violations.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: For a Middle East Treaty Organization
description: Amid the general exhaustion and apprehension that has come with stalemate in the Middle East, it is easy to overlook a key fact. The major players share one common concern in addition to their need for peace: The Israelis, Egyptians, the Saudis, Jordanians, Lebanese, possibly the Syrians, maybe even the Libyans, all worry about the Russians. Keeping the Russians out is an objective shared not only by the crucial Middle Eastern countries but by the United States as well.

title: Gold Miner Guilty in Killing
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 2 (AP) Charles Brunn, a 20yearold gold miner, was convicted of voluntary manslaughter yesterday in the slaying of two prospectors last December in a dispute over a mining claim. Earl David Russell, 18, was acquitted in the killings.

title: SURROGATE LAMBERT NOW UNDER INQUIRY
description: Marie M. Lambert, who last fall won election as the first woman surrogate in Manhattan, despite being rated not approved by the City Bar Association, is being investigated by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, which is examining the financing of her aggressive campaign for office.

title: Air Crash Kills 4 in Family
description: DENISON, Iowa, July 2 (AP)  A singleengine airplane crashed while trying to land for refueling at Denison Airport last night. Four members of a family from Elgin, Ill., were killed and three others were injured.

title: Business People
description: The feuding at The Bond Buyer Inc. has broken out again. Last Friday, following the corporation's annual meeting, Francis J. White and Eugene Krajewski were dismissed as president and as vice president and secretary, respectively. Their sacking came on the heels of a decision by the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division affirming a lower court ruling that denied the two men an injunction to block their discharges.

title: A Vessel's Misadventure En Route to Harbor Fete
description: At the 69th Street Pier in Brooklyn, Peter Rice, a crewman on the schooner Berta de Ibiza, told about the ship's unexpectedly dramatic arrival on June 23. The Portugueseregistry vessel was one of the most spectacular participants in Saturday's opening of Harbor Festival 1978.

title: Marta Beth Leipzig Wed To Dr. Michael Berman
description: At the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R. I., yesterday, Marta Beth Leipzig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Leipzig of Lauderhill, Fla., was married to Dr. Michael L. Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs Harold Berman of Boston and Lauderhill. Rabbi Theodore Lewis performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising
description: THEY were an unusual pair, the lieutenant and the Specialist 5, but unusual only because of their surroundings  the prefatory cocktail reception for the flashy annual television Clio awards. They were drinking and noshing just like the other fetegoers, but the uniforms seemed out of place amid the moderately outlandish evening wear. And their hair was noticably shorter than most.

title: 14 BLACKS ARE SLAIN ON RHODESIAN FARM
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 2  Fourteen black farm laborers and children were shot and burned to death last night by a group of 25 nationalist guerrillas who attacked a whiteowned cattle ranch in eastern Rhodesia, according to a military spokesman.

title: 2 AGENCIES STUDYING GUIDELINES ON BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  Lawyers in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission are reviewing existing programs and guidelines to see if they should be revised in light of the Supreme Court's Bakke decision, the heads of both agencies said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Joining Tours of Arab Countries A Different Story for U.S. Jews
description: Ahlan wa sahla, or Welcome in Arabtc, was the indiscriminately friendly salutation on the travel brochure mailed from Los Angeles. Offering the magic of the Arabian Nights, it was an invitation to join a fourweek Arabian Adventure tour to six Middle Eastern countries: Yemen, the Sudan, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar and the fJnited Arab Emirates.

title: News Summary
description: Vice President Mondale said that Israel has agreed to attend a foreign ministers conference with Egypt and the United States in London later this month. He made the announcement after a 90minute meeting in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his Cabinet. Mr Begin said that Israel was prepared to to study, analyze and act upon any new peace proposal that Egypt offers. [Page 1.]

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 3,1978

title: Air Travel Reaches New Height
description: Tens of thousands of passengers are crowding the nation's airports over the long holiday weekend, in what many airlina experts say is the busiest travel period in American aviation history. For the last year, traffic on United Statesflag carriers, spurrsed largely by a proliferation of cutrate fares, has surged.

title: Somali Leader Criticizes West
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, July 2 (AP) President Mohammed Siad Barre today criticized Western paralysis in not helping his nation and suggested he might be deposed by proSoviet junior army officers unless he received the $15 million in weapons aid he has requested from the United States.

title: Dance: Pauline Koner Carolina Theater
description: DURHAM, N.C.  From all appearances, moving to North Carolina has been one of the American Dance Festival's happiest moves. The Friday and Saturday night performances at the Festival's new home, Duke University's Page Auditorium, were enthusiastically applauded by audiences that took evident delight in watching dance.

title: Memo to Rafshoon
description: WASHINGTON  Gerald Rafshoon. described as a darkly handsome media wizard, has been newly installed across the street from the White House in an office that is richly redolent of symbolism; it used to be Richard Nixon's hideaway office, and as such is the perfect place to plot a comeback in the polls and to do away with all this wallowing in Angolagate.

title: Group Fighting Abortion Planning to Step Up Its Drive
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1  The National Right to Life Committee, declaring that abortions were a prelude to a medical holocaust, asserted this weekend that through aggressive political action, it would step up its campaign for a humanlife amendment to the Constitution to prohibit abortions except in cases in which the woman's life was endangered, and to prohibit euthanasia.

title: Annie Get Your Gun Presented at Jones Beach Theater
description: Annie Get Your Gun is floating across the watery stage of the Jones Beach Theater this season, and, to judge from its beginnings, it is still a wonderful rouser of a musical that can easily establish a beachhead in the hearts of any audience at sea or ashore.

title: Nixon, Hailed in Kentucky Town, Stresses the Need for U.S. Strength
description: RYDEN, Ky., July 2  Just outside a town so remote that most radio stations do not reach it, so tiny that it has a twoman police force and so poor that it could not pay its light bill :last winter, Richard M. Nixon made an attack today on the global dangers of Communism and rose to the defense of the military, the Central Intelligence Agency and the freeenterprise system.

title: Carter Signs Forestry Bills
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)  President Carter has signed a package of three bills consolidating elements of current Federalstate cooperative forestry programs and for forestry research, the White House announced this weekend.

title: George L. Stout, at 80
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 2 (AP) George L. Stout, known internationally as an expert and author on art restoration, died last night at Stanford Medical Center after surgery. He was 80 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MIDTOWN UNDERFOOT There are some diversions on hand during the long holiday period with minimal fanfare today and tomorrow, ranging from free to reasonably priced.

title: Books of The Times
description: Can there really be room for yet another study of Edgar Allan Poe? There may be little left for original scholarship, admits Julian Symons, himself a critic, poet, and mystery writer. But there remains, in his opinion, the need for a new approach to Poe.

title: Novel Mortgage Plan Backed for Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 2  A novel $100 million mortgagefund plan, designed to prevent middleclass citizens from deserting this city in favor of the suburbs, is drawing support froni savings and loan executives, whose backing would be required to make it work.

title: Jazz: David Murray's BigBand Sound
description: In a sense, the tenor saxophonist David Murray was responsible for the inception of the important new jazz series at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. It was a performance by Mr. Murray that first convinced Mr. Papp to do something with the music, but months went by without the saxophonist giving a performance there. Apparently he was marshalling his forces, for on Saturday and Sunday he was at the Public leading an 18piece big band.

title: Bathhouse Wipes Out An Endangered Fish
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The Interior Department is taking a tiny fish off the endangered species list because, having become a victim of a bathhouse, it is now extinct, departmental officials said today.

title: Scenario for a Third World War Contrived by European Experts
description: A Soviet SS17 missile's nuclear warhead is detonated over Birmingham, England. on Aug. 20. 1985. Perhaps 300.000 people are killed and 250,000 seriously injured. In immediate retaliation two submarinelaunched ballistic missiles, one American and one British, destroy Minsk. in the Soviet Union.

title: SAMUEL WARSHAIJER
description: Samuel Warshauer, senior vice president of Melnor Industries Inc. of Moonachie, N.J., died of a heart attack Saturday while on vacation in Tel Aviv. He was 63 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Brokerage Profits Show Strong 2dQuarter Gains
description: Heavy trading volume on Wall Street during the second quarter of 1978 is likely to result in strong earnings for the securities industry. And, coming as it has after a generally disastrous first quarter, the surge probably means brokerage and investment banking firms will wind up firmly in the black for the first half of the year.

title: Caution Follows Market Surge
description: The opening six months of 1978 brought Wall Street record volume and a rally in the market  the best of all worlds for traders  but when the curtain rang down on the first half last Friday, both the trading pace and stock prices had receded from the heights, and caution lingered once again.

title: New Faces in Southern Politics: Women, Young and Outsiders
description: ATLANTA, July 2  Every time I run, people run the same race against me, reflected Bill Clinton, the 31yearold whiz kid of Arkansas politics. They say, This guy is being foisted on us  like I'm a creation of the media who's been cloned somehow with an Ivy League education and lone hair.

title: 11 Historic Structures Receive Federal Funds for Preservation
description: ALBANY, July 2 (UPI)  Eleven historic architectural structures throughout New York State will receive a total of $224,566 in Federal grants for their preservation.

title: Some of Meyner's ExColleagues Hail Him on His 70th Birthday
description: PRINCETON, July 2  Governor Byrne invited former Gov. Robert B. Meyner to play tennis yesterday at Morven, the Governor's official residence here, and also invited about 30 officials from the Meyner administration for a surprise birthday party for their former boss.

title: Streets of Dublin Show the Scars of Battle With Builders
description: DUBLIN  Dublin is a city in a state of siege. In a war between the promoters of speculative construction and the protectors of the city's heritage, battles are being fought on both sides of the Liffey, from Hume Street to Mountjoy Square, with skirmishes in the most fashionable neiebburtmods.

title: The jersey Indians
