description: JERSEY CITY OBSCURITY is playing a close and exciting professional ball game in a metropolitan area of 15 million souls and drawing 223 spectators. No one playing baseball this season for the Jersey Indians has developed a fear of crowds, throngs, mobs or hordes, or been threatened by a flying press of fans. It is lonely in the deep green reaches of Roosevelt Stadium, where the Indians defeated the Holyoke Millers the other night by 54 before 223. Roosevelt Stadium is where Jackie Robinson played his first minor league game, in 1946. Baseball crowds here once reached 40,000. But now the sturdy, oddly handsome ball park hard by Newark Bay mixes mostly memory and desire.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: China Official Asks Flexibility
description: HONG KONG, July 2 (UPI)  A need for bigger, better and more flexible economic thinking to reach ambitious national development goals was emphasized today by Yu Chiuli, Vice Premier of China.

title: Firefighters' Strike In Memphis Brings Blazes and Curfew
description: MEMPHIS, July 2  City officials ordered a curfew tonight after 205 fires, most of them thought to have been set by arsonists, broke out in the first full day of a strike by Memphis's union firefighters.

title: Syria Threatens to Swing Iron Fist As Battle Spreads to Beirut Market
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2  Heavy fighting raged for the second day today between Syrian troops of the Arab peacekeeping force and Christian militiamen. Damascus said it was determined to strike at trouble makers in Lebanon with an iron fist.

title: Behind British Bid for U.S. Bank
description: LONDON, July 2  Anthony Barber, who as Chancellor of the Exchequer presided over Britain's disastrous dash for growth in the early 1970's, is thinking big again.

title: Auto Racing: Andretti Wins French Grand Prix
description: LE CASTELLET, France, July 2 (UPI)  Maio Andretti led from the first lap and steered his Lotus to victory in the French Grand Prix Formula One race today to raise his lead in the world drivers championship standing.

title: Projections At Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2Jack Yardley called it the worst weather for a first week of Wimbledon that he had seen in 32 years.

title: Salyut 6 Astronauts Spend Day Photographing Earth and Mates
description: MOSCOW, July 2 ( UPI)  The four astronauts aboard the space station Salyut 6 spent the day today photographing the earth and one another, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: U.S. Nine Wins
description: TOKYO, July 2 (AP)  Derek Tatsuno held off a late Japanese rally as he picked up his second victory, a 51 triumph today that gave the United States allstars a lead of three games to two in their college championship series. Tatsuno struck out six, walked none and gave up seven hits, including five in the last two innings, while Pat Proulx and Tim Tolman hit home runs for the Americans.

title: Flying Doctors of South Africa Aid the Blacks of Neighboring Lands
description: MBABANE, Swaziland, June 27  For the wizened old black man, it was the moment of truth  the moment when he would learn whether, after two cataract operations, he would be able to see again, or whether he would go through life hardly able to count his fingers in front of his face.

title: Metropolitan and Other Museums Fume at Washingtonfirst Policy
description: As the National Gallery of Art in Washington basks in the success of its new East Building, recently unveiled to the plaudits of art and architecture critics throughout the country, it is a growing target for criticism from other museum officials, who complain about the gallery's aggressive tactics of acquisition and exhibition.

title: Racing: Radar Ahead Takes Swaps Stakes
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 2 (AP) Radar Ahead, the heavy favorite, won the $223,300 Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park today, scoring his fifth victory in seven starts this year. Afterwards his handlers expressed the opinion that he might be the third best 3yearold in the nation.

title: Marcy Rosenbaum Wed to Kenneth Yeager
description: Marcy Sue Rosenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rosenbaum of East Meadow, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kenneth William Yeager, son of Col. Robert F. Yeager, U.S.A.F., retired, of Malcolm, Neb., and Maxine Yeager of Houston. Rabbi Jerrold Bobrow performed the ceremony at the Rosenbaum home.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAINTGERMAINENLAYE, France, July 2 (UPI)  KlausPeter Thaler of West Germany sprinted through rain to victory in the third stage of the Tour de France roadcycling race today but failed to shake off Jacques Bossis of France, who moved into a 20second overall lead.

title: A Season of Streaks, Upsets and Jumbled Standings
description: Eightynine days after it began, the baseball season bounces toward its midpoint this Week with record crowds, deposed managers, injured stars, piqued owners and jumbled standings that threaten the brief and stormy reign of the New York Yankees as world champions.

title: Soccer: Cosmos Crush Surf, 41
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 2  Just when it appeared that another complete domination by the Cosmos would go unexploited, the North American Soccer League champions exploded for three goals in the last 24 minutes tonight and defeated the California Surf, 41.

title: Rain Postpones Western Open
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 2  The final round of the 75th Western open was postponed today after allnight rains left the Butler National Golf Club course in unplayable condition, with some areas seriously flooded. Rain had also fallen Thursday, Friday and yesterday.

title: Most Candidates Are Reporting On Campaign Funds, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission says it has been more than 90 percent effective so far this year in getting financial information about political candidates before the public.

title: Delta Sues C.A.B. Over 3 Routes
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  It was inevitable, everyone agreed, but now it has happened: A major airline nervous over the Civil Aeronautics Board's new policies favoring competition, has sued to stop the agency.

title: ECONOMIC COUNCIL EXPECTS GOOD YEAR
description: TRENTON, July 2  A strong rebound in the state's economy during the second quarter should set a pattern for the remainder of the year, according to the New Jersey Economic Policy Council.

title: Opera: Newport Festival Opens
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 2  America's newest festival, the Newport Opera Festival, officially came into existence last night with a concert at Beechwood, the former home of Mrs. Vincent Astor. Thus Newport now has two festivals concentrating on Romantic music. Ten years ago the Newport Music Festival, using the salons of the great houses here, dedicated itself to forgotten aspects of the 19thcentury repertory, and it is still flourishing. Indeed, it opens on Saturday, the day before the opera festival closes. But there are also prefestival concerts in direct conflict with Newport Opera Festival events.

title: Migrants to North Touch Mississippi Roots
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., July 2  The movement of black America from South to North during the middle years of this century has been called the greatest voluntary migration of people in world history.

title: After Stormy Start, S.S.America Resumes Her Voyage to Nowhere
description: ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, off New Jersey, July 2  Some of them still have no running water in their cabins. Some have cold water, others have only hot. Some have toilets that will not flush; others, toilets that will not stop flushing.

title: A Belgian Teacher Slain in Manhattan At Y.M.C.A. Hotel
description: The body of a 62yearold Belgian college instructor who had been visiting this city as part of an aroundtheworld tour was found yesterday morning in her ransacked room at Sloane House, a midtown Y.M.C.A. residence.

title: Minister Fights Beach Tag Fees
description: CAPE MAY, July 2 (UPI)  Dr. Carl McIntire, the fundamentalist preacher who gained national publicity for his Viet2010; nam War victory marches, plans a march tomorrow to try to stop Cape May from collecting fees on his private beaches.

title: Nixon, Hailed in Kentucky Town, Stresses the Need for U.S. Strength
description: HYDEN, Ky., July 2  Just outside a town so remote that most radio stations do not reach it, so tiny that it has a twoman police force and so poor that it could not pay its light bill fast winter, Richard M. Nixon made an attack today on the global dangers of Communism and rose to the defense of the military, the Central Intelligence Agency and the freeenterprise system.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Campers who enjoy being spoiled should like the 10 Second Automatic Tent, which is carried in a threefootlong nylon case, opens like an umbrella and needs no pegs to hold it down. It features a builtin frame, a zippered screened entrance, two screened windows, a selfcontained floor and a crown made of cotton to reduce condensation. It sleeps two persons. The 10 second claim by the manufacturer, Sunshine Cover and Tarp of Chatsworth, Calif., is authenticthe nylon tent springs open with a snap when it is laid out correctly on the ground. It was not conceived as a backpacking item (it weighs more than 10 pounds), and so is used best for camping with a car or a canoe. For $69 through the J.C. Penney catalogue.

title: How It Was, How It Is
description: For the last six months, two worlds have existed side by side on the fourth floor of The New York Times's West 43d Street headquarters.

title: MONDALE SAYS BEGIN AGREES TO A PARLEY WITH EGYPT AND U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, July 2  Vice President Mondale said today that Israel had agreed to attend a foreign ministers conference with Egypt and the United States in London later this month.

title: United Merchants Ends Bankruptcy
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. ended bankruptcy proceedings. The textile concern, which had filed for Chapter XI on July 12, 1977, met its selfimposed deadline for completion of the proceedings.

title: The Price of E.P.A. Industrial Standards
description: Letters

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: There are approximately 20 questions that are asked with uncommon recurrence within the course of any given year.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In British football, what does it mean to give a player a yellow card'?

title: The Second Black Manager
description: WHEN Larry Doby was a rising young star with the Newark Eagles of the Negro National League, he sometimes imagined what life might be like in the majors, but he always dismissed that notion quickly because black men didn't play in organized baseball. When the Cleveland Indians hired him and he won election as center fielder on the major league AllStar team, he realized that the next step up would have to be a job as manager. He didn't entertain serious aspirations in this direction, though, until six years ago, when he was one of Gene Mauch's coaches with the Montreal Expos.

title: Jane Schwartz Is a Bride
description: Jane Paula Schwartz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Schwartz of Providence, R. I., and Jeffrey Hofman Kramer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Kramer of Huntington, L. I., were married yesterday by Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman in Temple BethEl in Providence. Dr. Schwartz, a dentist, was formerly on the faculty of the Harvard School of Dental Medicine. Dr. Kramer is an internist.

title: Carter Said to Have Approved Plan Moving Border Control to Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  President Carter has approved a plan calling for creation of an agency within the Treasury Department to control and manage the nation's borders, according to a number of Administration sources.

title: Agriculture Department Delays Issuing New Food Stamp Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Food stamp regulations that eliminate the partialpayment requirement and establish new eligibility standards may go into effect in some states by late October, almost four months later than the Department of Agriculture had originally planned.

title: In the Storm Center
description: WASHINGTON  Last October, Dr. Harold Spaeth of Michigan University appeared on National Public Radio to talk about the Bakke case. He had programmed a computer on the voting pattern of the nine Supreme Court justices, he said, and on the issues in this case. On the basis of the computer analysis, he could predict that the Court would decide unanimously in favor of Allan Bakke.

title: Quiet on Credit Markets
description: With the credit markets semiclosed today and completely closed tomorrow for the Fourth of July, relatively little financing activity is scheduled this week. Because of this lull, interest rate levels are unlikely to undergo any real test until newissue activity builds up next week.

title: Mozambique's President Allows 80 to Come Back From Portugal
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, July 2 (Reuters)  President Samora Machel has allowed 80 people who were expelled from Mozambique in March of last year to return, according to a presidential statement today.

title: The Value of Perquisites
description: Perquisites  better learn about them now before the Government legislates them right out of existence.

title: Paper Using Cold Type
description: With today's issue, The New York Times abandons a 19thcentury printing process for one more in tune with the technology of modern industry.

title: 15 Arab States Plan To Impose Embargo On Regime in Aden
description: CAIRO, July 2 (UPI)  Fifteen moderate Arab countries agreed today to impose a political, economic and cultural blockade on the Marxist Government of Southern Yemen, which has been accused of involvement in the assassination of President Ahmed Hussein alGhashmi of Yemen.

title: End of the Best Little Ranch in Texas
description: DALLAS, July 1  They auctioned off the Chicken Ranch this week in bits and pieces, an ignominious kind of end for a Texas institution that had been around nearly as long as the Alamo and was surely the object of as much affection.

title: Koch Gets Plan for Cleanup of Times Sq. by 1980
description: An action program designed to drive out much of the sex industry and criminals and hustlers from the sleazy Times Square area within 18 months has been submitted to Mayor Koch for his approval.

title: Catfish Hunter Lives His Longest Season
description: LAST Week's Monday Night Baseball game between Boston and New York was over. Boston had won, 41, and the patient in the private room in Lenox Hill Hospital shut the lights and went to sleep. In the morning he would be put under general anesthetic, and his right shoulder would be manipulated in an attempt to free him from a pain that had soured his spring and summer. As he slept, he had no way of knowing that one borough away, in the Bronx, his condition was being discussed by two veteran opponents  Carl Yastrzemski and George Scott  who wished him well. Catfish Hunter might even have been snoring.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 2  The massive Polish victory over Brazil in the final of the world open team championship in New Orleans Friday was a remarkable triumph in the face of great obstacles.

title: Lake Placid Road Job Resuming
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Tiny yellow ribbons flutter in the breeze along the shoulders of Route 73, marking the edges of a controversial $4.7 million construction project designed to improve the road, one of the major gateways to Lake Placid, site of the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Bakke Case and Coast Tax Vote Called Threat to Minority Rights
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 2  A new, wave of conservatism, illustrated by the Bakke decision and by the Proposition 13 tax cut referendum, is emerging in America and threatening the civil rights achievements of minority groups, Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said here today.

title: The Unreachable Terror in Cambodia
description: The bloody clash of nationalities and ideologies continues unabated in Indochina. Vietnamese forces are reported fighting deep in Cambodia once again, and meeting fierce resistance. So acute is the millenary hatred between Vietnamese and Cambodians that neither army takes many prisoners. And civilians on both sides of their border suffer unspeakable horrors.

title: Jazzmen Take to 52d Street
description: The last time the Newport New York Jazz Festival tried having a free, openair jazz fair on West 52d Street, it was successful but far from ideal as far as hearing the music was concerned. But yesterday afternoon's fair, which was produced in association with Jazzmobile and the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company and brought the 25th Newport Festival to an end, provided some firstrate music, heard over surprisingly good sound systems. As long as one did not mind standing, listening conditions were just about perfect.

title: Yanks Sweep By 32 and 53
description: The limping Yankees made some headway yesterday by sweeping a doubleheaer from the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Syrian Forces Encircle Lebanese Christian Strongholds
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3  Syrian troops encircled and shelled Lebanese Christian strongholds of east Beirut today in an apparent move to break the force of the Christian militias once and for all.

title: 2 U.S. Newsmen in Soviet Choose Not to Participate in Libel Hearing
description: MOSCOW, July 3  Two American reporters told a Soviet judge here today that they had decided not to participate in any court hearing on a libel charge lodged against them by the Government's television agency.

title: North Korean Fishermen Stage Demonstration at Panmunjon
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 3 (AP) Four North Korean fishermen rescued by South Korean Navy vessels after they sank their boat stripped to their underwear and cursed the South Koreans today after they were handed over to a representative of their Government.

title: Guidry Is Star of A.L. Stars
description: Using the theory that two heads are better than one, Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, and Billy Martin, manager of the Yankees and manager of the American League AllStar team, yesterday named seven pitchers to the American League squad for the July 11 AllStar game in San Diego. An eighth pitcher will be named later this week.

title: 104 Cases of Fireworks Seized by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) Federal, marshals, the Government reported, seized thousands of illegal fireworks today at six roadside stands in Wyoming, as part of a nationwide crackdown on holiday explosives outlawed more than a year ago.

title: BYRNE WILL REVIEW RIOT MURDER DEATH
description: TRENTON, July 3  Governor Byrne has agreed to review the life imprisonment sentence of a black 34yearold former marine convicted three times of the murder of a white Plainfield policeman during a riot in 1967.

title: Suspect Dies in Shooting at Court
description: DANIELSON, Conn., July 3 (AP)  A former Willimantic policeman held on assault charges was fatally shot on his way to court today after he grabbed a service revolver from a rookie officer and shot him in the stomach, the police said.

title: BTR Purchases 28% Of Worcester Stock
description: Worcester Controls announced that holders of 431,000 shares, or 28 percent of the company's common stock, had sold their shares to the United States subsidiary of BTR Ltd., a diversified British concern that is acquiring Worcester Controls

title: European Truck Drivers Block Roads in a Protest
description: VIENNA, July 3  Angry longdistance truck drivers today blocked major European eastwest and northsouth highways to protest against a new Austrian roadtransit tax.

title: 9 Big Bands on Parade At Festival in Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., July  The Newport Jazz Festival ended its twoday venture into Upstate New York yesterday with a 12hour parade of nine big bands at the Saratoga Perfanning Arts Center that George Wein, producer of the festival, carefully described as the greatest collection of big bands assembled at one time in recent history.

title: Atlantic City Is Facing the Loss Of Blenheim Hotel, a Landmark
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 3  The dome, towers and cupolas of the Blenheim Hotel, which have stood in bizarre, sandcastle splendor above the honkytonk of the Boardwalk here since 1906, will he demolished this year by its new owners and replaced with a modern hotelgambling casino unless the city or state blocks the move.

title: Upcoming Talks Spur Franc Rise
description: PARIS, July 3  The French franc rose sharply against the dollar again today as speculation intensified that European leaders plan new moves to stabilize their currencies at a meeting in Bremen, West Germany, next Thursday and Friday.

title: Sheiks of Beverly Hills: Lawsuits at the Door
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. A couple of Saudi Arabian sheiks whose style of living brought them recent notoriety have now been slapped with a total of five lawsuits between them. The sheiks troubles started when they planted plastic flowers and explicitly painted statues around the mansion they purchased not long ago. They then threw.a lavish party in an effort to mol.lify their outraged neighbors.

title: Insurance Premiums Are Slashed For 2.1 Million in Military Service
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)  Insurance premiums for 2.1 million active duty servicemen and women and 818,000 reservists were reduced effective last Saturday because of the continuing favorable mortality experience among military per sonnel, Veterans Administrator Max Clelansaid today.

title: Rate Cuts, Better Service Seen in Truck Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  Deregulation of the trucking industry would have no clearly defined impact on small communities, but might result in improved shipping service, according to a study just released by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Swedish Tourist Dies in Moscow Of Wounds Inflicted in Ax Attack
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (AP)  Henry Johannesson, the 71yearold Swede injured last week when a young Russian man attacked him with an ax outside a Moscow hotel, died today in a hospital, informed sources said. His wife Eve Helen, 65 years old, and Anar Andersson, 83, died in the attack.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Wednesday about the New York City rentstabilization program, a mechanical error caused several lines about maximumbaserent increases to be added to a quotation from Marty Markowitz, a Brooklyn tenant leader and State Senate candidate. In fact, Mr. Markowitz, in his comments, had referred only to the new, lower rentrise limits that the city had adopted for stabilized apartments.

title: Shah of Iran Forbids Royal Family To Make Profits on Business Deals
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 3The Shah of Iran has issued discreet orders to bar members of his royal family from business deals in which they stand to benefit, and a private code of conduct is to he imposed on them.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A weaker dollar helped raise prices of preciousmetals futures yesterday, despite the usual light preholiday trading and several light waves of profit taking on the Commodity Exchange in New York. There were also sharp gains in several key foreigncurrency futures traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's International Monetary Market.

title: U.S. Envoy Meets With Gromyko
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (AP)  United States Ambassador Malcolm Toon met today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said Mr. Gromyko and Mr. Toon, who requested the meeting, discussed some issues of bilateral SovietAmerican relations.

title: Topics
description: Star Wars

title: Egypt to Attend London Parley, Mondale Is Told
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 3  President Anwar elSadat formally accepted an American invitation today to send Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel to London later this month to meet with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Jones Beach Holds First Rock Concert
description: JONES BEACH, L.I., July 3  Fresh on the heels of Annie Get Your Gun, which opened on Thursday, the Jones Beach Theater began a series of con. temporary concerts last night. In case anyone might wonder, this doesn't mean Stockhausen and Boulez; it means rock, the first such concerts ever held at the 8,200seat facility.

title: PEKING ENDS ALL AID TO THE VIETNAMESE, RECALLING ADVISERS
description: PEKING, July 3  China announced the formal end of all economic aid projects in Vietnam today as the feud between the two countries deepened.

title: Jane Blalock Golf Victor; Miss Lopez Finishes 10th
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., July 3 (AP) Jane Blalock pulled away from the field with birdies on the fifth and sixth holes today and easily won a $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament for her 20th career victory.

title: BODY OF STOWAWAY FOUND AT KENNEDY
description: The body of a 20yearold Jamaican man was discovered at Kennedy International Airport Sunday night when a suitcase in which he had stowed away fell from a conveyor belt and split open on the tarmac below.

title: Deaths
description: Aires, Frieda

title: Fire Officials Survey IceCream Companies For Gasoline in Trucks
description: The New York City Fire Department surveying the 19 plants across the city that dispatch icecream trucks to determine whether the trucks routinely carry spare cans of gasoline.

title: Big Problem of Small Business: Raising Capital for Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  In May the shareholders of Presto Products Inc. assembled in Appleton, Wis., for their company's annual meeting. It should have been a haonv occasion. Presto had turned in yet another year of healthy growth and substantial earnings. John E. Lynch, Presto's founder and president, reported that its net income in 1977 was $4.68 million on sales of $58.05 million.

title: 60 Flee Potomac Flooding
description: KITZMILLER, Md., July 3 (AP)  At least 60 people were evacuated this morning from their homes near the West Virginia border after heavy rains overnight tau sed the swollen Potomac River to overflow its banks, the authorities said. The authorities said that more families would probably be advised to seek higher ground asevacuation efforts continued. No injuries were reported.

title: Summer Beyond Wish
description: A long time ago I lived in a crossroads village of northern Virginia and during its summer enjoyed innocence and never knew boredom, although nothing of consequence happened there.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, JULY 3, 1978

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: THE controversy over the new New York State tax law that would tax bonuses and money earned under corporate profitsharing plans more steeply than money earned in wages is being resolved, to the relief of the business community.

title: Stocks Sag Along With Turnover
description: With many market participants observing a fourday extended weekend, stock prices weakened yesterday in the slowest session since a January snowstorm cut trading hours short. The exchanges will be closed today for the Fourth of July holiday and will reopen tomorrow.

title: All U.S. Markets Closed
description: All stock and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Foreign markets, including the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges, are open. Most businesses, including banks, will also be closed today.

title: A Dracula Who Dresses To the Teeth
description: With his California suntan and healthy good looks he seems an unlikely candidate to portray a vampire who sleeps all day and drinks all night. But not only is George Hamilton depicting Dracula (in a movie that has been on location around the city), he will also he the first Dracula to be outfitted  cape and all by the dignified Dunhill Tailors, normally clothiers to such nonTransylvanian types as Governor Carey, Walter Hoving and Paul Newman.

title: Deaths
description: CHERNOWMichael The Board of Overseers of The Albert Einstein College of Medicine Of Yeshiva University expresses its profound regret at the passing of Michael Chernow, beloved husband of Stella. Michael Chernow with his wife, Stella, was a Founder and a devoted friend of the College of Medicine. To his wile and to his entire family we offer our sincere condolences. Eli L. Rousso, Chairman Board Of Overseers Dr Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University

title: Events
description: Theater

title: Books of the Times
description: Brothers, the first of the stories in My Disappearance in Providence, doesn't show what Alfred Andersch can do. A rather pale vignette of two brothers in Germany waiting for World War II to begin and for themselves to be

title: Marcy Rosenbaum Wed to Kenneth Yeager
description: Marcy Sue Rosenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rosenbaum of East Meadow, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kenneth William Yeager, son of Col. Robert F. Yeager. U.S.A.F. retired, of Malcolm, Neb., and Maxine Yeager of Houston. Rabbi Jerrold Bobrow performed the ceremony at the Rosenbaum home.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION GIVEN NEW SUPPORT BY SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  The Supreme Court indicated strong support today for affirmative action programs that remedy past discrimination in employment, even when they conflict with established union seniority systems.

title: Woman Mentioned for Fed
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (Reuters) President Carter plans to nominate Nancy Teeters, an economist, to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve

title: Ernest R. Breech Dies; Was Board Chairman Of the Ford Company
description: ROYALOAK, Mich., July 3 (AP)  Ernest R. Breech, who helped Henry Ford II rebuild Ford Motor Company after World War II, died tonight. He was 81 years old.

title: Shah of Iran Forbids Royal Family To Make Profits on Business Deals
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 3The Shah of Iran has issued discreet orders to bar members of his royal family from business deals in which they stand to benefit, and a private code of conduct is to be impbsed on them.

title: ... As Da vid Hockney Roams Through History for His Effects
description: What people refer to in London as David Hockney's Magic Flute is one of the most conspicuous successes that the Glyndebourne Opera has had since it was founded in 1934.

title: Violin: Cecylia Arzewski Depends on Bach
description: Bach's unaccompanied violin works would not strike many performers as ideal selections to fill an entire New York debut recital program, but Cerylia Arzewski clearly has a mind of her own, and she introduced herself at Carnegie Recital Hall late last month playing Bach's Partita No. 1 in B minor, Sonata No. 1 in G minor and Partita No. 2 in D minor.

title: Oklahoma, With Plenty of Clean Water, Air and Open Space, Is Coming Into Its Own
description: OKLAHOMA CITYSummer arrived here recently, and residents of this steamy city prepared to go underground. Literally underground, because O.K. City, as it likes to be known. is really two cities in one Above ground are the shining glass and steel towers, monuments to Oklahoma's accelerating economic boom, and below are the tunnels, blocks and blocks of winding, airconditioned passages that connect most of the major downtown buildings with one another.

title: Bean Triumphs in Playoff With Rogers at Western
description: OAK BROOK, III., July 3  Andy Bean, a 25yearold blond giant of 6 feet 4 inches, 210 pounds and a prodigious appetite for Italian food, beat Bill (Buck) Rogers by one stroke on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today to win the 75th Western open golf tournament.

title: A Case for Controls
description: If inflation is caused by concentrations of economic power, then it follows as the night the day that the way to control inflation is to control those concentrations of power.

title: Pursuits
description: Today may be what people mean when they talk wistfully about an oldfashioned Fourth of July. True, some traditions have been eroded. In the name of fireworks safety, Boston has gone to the extreme of banning the cannon that boom during the annual outdoor rendition of the 1812 Overture. There's even a catch whistling Yankee Doodle  it was recently appropriated as the Connecticut state song. Still, today promises to be a calm birthday in a calm year.

title: Newcombe Eliminated By Ramirez
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 Raul Ramirez is enjoying his finest Wimbledon, Sandy Mayer says don't count him out against Bjorn Borg, and Chris Evert and Billie Jean King set the stage for another centercourt showdown.

title: Order on Busing Funds Sought
description: CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP)  The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked today for a court order that would tap $15 million from state school funds to pay for busing for desegregation in Cleveland. Federal District Judge Frank J. Battisti is scheduled to consider the motion at a hearing on Thursday.

title: Quebec Seeks Aid To Industry
description: MONTREAL, July 2  Quebec, a major supplier of newsprint and other paper and pulp products to the United States, has proposed a modernization program of close to $1.5 billion to save its biggest manufacturing industry from decline and job losses.

title: 2 U.S. Newsmen in Soviet Choose Not to Participate in Libel Hearing
description: MOSCOW, July 3  Two American reporters told a Soviet judge here today that they had decided not to participate in any court hearing on a libel charge lodged against them by the Government's television agency.

title: Hit Man for the Yankees
description: The first time that Al Rosen was ever aware of a person named Billy Martin was back in 1949 in San Diego and they met with fists cocked. They met near the pitcher's mound, alongside the horizontal body of Lou Tost, who was Martin's teammate and who was horizontal because Rosen had lust decked him. We were playing in the Pacific coast League then, Rosen was saying, diverting his cares from the big, bad Boston Red Sox. I was on the San Diego club and Billy was with Oakland. I went out to the mound for a simple reason: The guy who batted before me, Max West, had just hit a home run. So, Tost, the pitcher, stuck one in my ribs.

title: TIMES WINS A DELAY ON CURARE APPEAL
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 2  The New York Times and M.A. Farber, one of its reporters, were relieved tonight from the responsibility to comply immediately with a State Superior Court order requiring the surrender of notes, recordings. memorandums and other news material that helped lead to the current prosecution of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich for allegedly murdering five hospital patients.

title: In J-A-Z-P-A-N, Miss Ichinohe Mixes Old Nippon and New U.S.
description: On the strength of a program of seven works presented by Saeko Ichinohe and Company on Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church. it appears that Miss Ichinohe is most drawn to choreography that blends traditional Japanese dance and everyday movement styles with American moderndance technique. At worst the inherent differences serve only to inhibit each other, ending in irritating stylistic impasses, as in JAZPAN, where five dancers must cope with small running steps and Oriental hand gestures mated to the swinging center torso impulses of jazz dance set to the unlikely rhythms of Chick Correa.

title: Around the Nation
description: Most of western Montana and parts of Idaho, Wyoming and South Dakota lost power early yesterday and Sunday night when lightning struck a regional transmission line.

title: Karpov and Korchnoi Arrive in Philippines
description: Anatoly Karpov, the 27yearold world chess champion, and Viktor Korchnoi, his 47yearold challenger, arrived in Manila within hours of each another yesterday to begin preparations for their world title match a $500,000 clash set to open in the northern Philippine city of Baguio on July 17.

title: Midge Costanza: Enduring a New Life In a Niche in the White House Cellar
description: WASHINGTON  Margaret Costanza is woman scorned. In lieu of fury, she registers irritated bewilderment.

title: Taiwan
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.The inauguration of Chiang Chingkuo as President of the Republic of China in Taiwan last month pointed to a continued and likely increased importance for Taiwan in the web of interdependent advanced countries of the Pacific. The new President and Y. S. Sun, his designated Prime Minister, will direct the policies of a country whose development has made it far more important economically and politically than when the United States promised it protection in a security pact almost a quarter of a century ago.

title: Lute: Patrick O'Brien Plays
description: The lute, although long since reclaimed from the rubbish heap of musical history, still does not turn up in solo recitals as frequently as its present popularity would seem to indicate.Most lute players confine their public appearances to ensemble work, even though the solo literature is enormous. So Patrick O'Brien's solo recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last month, his New York debut, was a welcome prospect.

title: Sanitation Crews Vote To Accept a New Pact
description: WEST PATERSON, July 3 (AP) Sanitation workers voted overwhelmingly today to accept a pact with two contractors associations, averting a strike that would have affected garbage collections in 67 communities in northern and central New Jersey.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JULY 4, 1978

title: Court Upsets Jersey's Curb on Medicaid Abortions
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 3  Citing an apparent and clearcut conflict between state and Federal law, a New Jersey Superior Court judge set aside today a state law that bars Medicaid funds for abortions unless the life of the mother endangered.

title: Page Airways Group Investigated by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  Two Federal grand juries are investigating the business practices of aviation and construction companies controlled by James P. Wilmot, a Rochester business executive who has gained a national reputation as a fund raiser for the Democratic Party.

title: Rights Leaders at Odds on Whether Corporate Seats Pose a Conflict
description: CHICAGO, July 1  There is a rising debate within the civil rights movement over whether its leaders face a potential conflict of interest when they serve on the boards of major corporations.

title: Deaths
description: ALTESFrieda. Of 273 Milton Road. Rve, N.Y.. on July 3, 1978. Beloved wile of William Altes. Devoted mother of Richard Altes. Loving grand. mother of two grandchildren. Funer al services 10 AM. July a, at the Community Synanogue of Rye, Forest Avenue, Rye, N.Y. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. Family will receive during bereavement at home In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Cancer Society would be appreciated

title: Court Upsets Restrictions in Jersey On Abortions for Medicaid Clients
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 3  Citing an apparent and clearcut conflict between state and Federal law, a New Jersey Superior Court judge set aside today a state law that bars Medicaid funds for abortions unless the life of the mother is endangered.

title: Levitt, Citing UtilityTax Increase, Rejects Yonkers's 19 7879 Budget
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 3State Comptroller Arthur Levitt rejected a $153 million budget for the city of Yonkers today, leaving the state's fourth largest city with no budget for its new fiscal year, which began Saturday.

title: The Right Way to Fight for E.R.A.
description: The pressure on Congress to extend the deadline for ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment will reach a crescendo next weekend as marchers and lobbyists descend on Washington. They see their just cause as a tantalizing three states short of the 38 needed for adoption and seek a reprieve from almost certain defeat in their sevenyear struggle for women's rights. But the means by which they prevail should not be subordinated even to a noble end. To alter the amendment procedures with the extension they demand would, we think, cause even greater damage than a further delay in the ratification of the E.R.A.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 3  A new state law that went into effect over the weekend eases requirements that local government employees live where they work.

title: Gunmen Seize Chilean Consular Office in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 3 (AP)  Five armed persons invaded the Chilean consular office this evening, took four hostages and demanded freedom for four Puerto Rican nationalists imprisoned in the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: West German Smashes European Mile Record
description: STOCKHOLM, July 3 (AP) Thomas Wessinhage of West Germany clocked 3 minutes 52.50 seconds and smashed the European mile record at an international track and field meet today.

title: Mondale's Mission: Israelis' Fears Persist
description: JERUSALEM, July 3  The visit of Vice President Mondale to Israel did little to allay the country's growing fears that the United States is poised to apply strong pressure on the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin to be more forthcoming in the effort to revive the boggeddown Middle East peace initiative.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A New Judge In A.T.&T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 The Justice Department's fouryearold antitrust suit to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been reassigned in Federal District Court Here tram Judge Joseph C. Waddy, 67 years old, who is ill, to the court's newest judge, Harold H. Greene, 55.

title: Faction in Lebanon Trying To End Vendetta Traditions
description: ZGHARTA, Lebanon, July 1  We have finished with the eyeforaneye business. said Selim Bey Karam, chief of one of the five ruling families in this feudal stronghold in northern Lebanon. We are tired of fighting and killing each other  tired of old women wearing black.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 1,026
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (UPI)  The Soviet Union has launched another in its Cosmos series of satellites, the Soviet press agency Tass today. It said that Cosmos 1,026 was launched yesterday and was orbiting the earth every 89 minutes at an inclination of 51.8 degrees and at distances ranging from 129.8 miles to 162.1 miles.

title: JUSTICES BACK F.C.C. ON OFFENSIVE WORDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that the freespeech protection of the First Amendment does not bar the Government from prohibiting radio broadcasting of words that are patently offensive but fall short of the Constitutional definition of obscenity.

title: 8 LATIN COUNTRIES SIGN AMAZON PACT
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3  Eight South American nations signed a treaty today to develop and protect the Amazon basin, one of the last remaining great open spaces in the world.

title: Lakshmi In Dances From India
description: DURHAM, H.C. July 3  The American Dance Festival tries to provide audiences with new dance experiences and with a sense of dance's rich heritage. Thus, last evening there was Indian dancing by Lakshmi Shanmukham at Duke University's Page Auditorium, while on Saturday morning there was a special demonstration class devoted to the technique of Mary Wigman, the German expressionist dancer.

title: Court in Memphis Orders Striking Firefighters to Co Back to Their Jobs
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 3  Striking firefighters, whom city officials have accused of setting hundreds of fires to call attention to their pay demands, today were ordered to return to work at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

title: U.N. Names New Press Chief
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3 Rudolf Stajduhar, a former Yugoslav journalist and a member of the United Nations staff since 1966, has been appointed director of the Press and Publications Division. He has served as head of the United Nations Information Center in New Delhi and as spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Middle East.

title: Mets Postponed, Will Play 2 Tonight
description: The New York MetsPhiladelphia Phillies game was rained out at Shea Stadium last night and rescheduled for tomorrow night, starting at 8:05 o'clock.

title: Deaths
description: ISRAELAndrew C Of Chicago, III formerly of Stamford, Conn., and New York City, in an auto accident in Phoenix, Arizona. on June 30. Be. loved husband of Carol, devoted father of James and Joanne. son of Adrian C. Israel, and the late Eleanor L. Israel, grandson of Jeannette V. R. Levison, brother ol Ellen J., Nancy L., and Thomas C. Israel. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in Mr. Israel's name to the American Cancer Society or Yale University.

title: Chinese Gave at Least $10 Billion
description: Estimates of the amount of aid given by China to Vietnam in the last 20 years range from $10 billion to $18 billion, according to Government analysts and figures made public by Chinese leaders at various times. Vietnam's principal benefactor over the years has been the Soviet Union, which continues to provide about $500 million a year, while Chinese aid in recent years has been no more than $300 million a year, a State Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Vacation Shuts English Town
description: BURNLEY, England  Lucas Aerospace, the biggest employer in town, closed down last Friday. So did the Mullard Simonstone television tube factory, the Michelin plant, the Oxford weaving mill, the W. H. Oddies bakery chain, Burnley Engineering, the Marks & Spencer label printing works and Robert Tyrer's Windmill model shoo.

title: Nuclear Plant Gets Repairs
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 3 (AP) The Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant at Vernon will remain closed for at least 10 days while cracks are repaired in a safety container that surrounds the reactor, it was announced today. The cracks were discovered last week, and the reactor was shut down Saturday.

title: Cloudy Skies Threaten a NotSoGlorious Fourth
description: A mild rain made a fizzle out of two New York Harbor Festival events yesterday and caused concern about the possible scrubbing of today's flyby of 75 vintage and classic aircraft intended to celebrate the 75th anniversary of man's first powered flight.

title: HIGH SCHOOL WOMEN CAUSE ISRAELI FUROR
description: TEL AVIV, July 3  Women of high school age have stirred a political furor by petitioning the Israeli Parliament to reject a proposed law to exempt them automatically from military service if they cite religious reasons.

title: Economic Scene
description: THOMAS A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, does not believe that the great corporations of our economy possess vast power within the political democracy, as Prof. Charles E. Lindblom of Yale contends in his recent book, Politics and Markets. To the contrary, Mr. Murphy contends that consumers hold true lifeordeath power over the corporations.

title: Davis Leads by Eight Pins In West Coast Bowling
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 3 (AP)  Dave Davis won seven of eight games to overtake Bill Spigner going into the final round of the MONO Fresno Professional Bowling Association open tournament today.

title: Eckersley Beats Yanks 3d Time, 95
description: BOSTON, July 3  The Boston Red Sox upstaged the Boston Pops tonight, igniting a display of fireworks that excited the Fenway Park fans as much as Arthur Fiedler's 50thanniversary fireworks will thrill nearly half a million people along the banks of the Charles River tomorrow night. The Yankees would have preferred waiting for tomorrow's show.

title: Thicket of Restrictions Impeding the Use of Solar Devices
description: Last year Paul Keplinger, a heating and plumbing contractor, built a solar energy collector in his front yard in Arlington, Va., a not unattractive cedarframed arrangement of translucent panels 10 feet long, 6 feet wide and 5 feet high.

title: Richard Ward Day, 61; Principal of Prep School
description: Richard Ward Day, the principal of the Montclair Kimberley Academy in Montclair, N.J., and for 10 years the principal of the Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., died yesterday after a short illness. He was 61 years old.

title: Chessie: Quarter Net Off, Loss in Half
description: BALTIMORE, July 3 (Reuters) The Chessie System, a holding company for the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, reported lower profits for the second quarter and a $29 million loss for the first half of 1978

title: A.T. & T. Case Bekan With Appeal on Rate
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  When the American Telephone and Telegraph company asked for a 9 percent rate increase in September 1970 it touched off a chain of events that led to what a Federal judge described as the largest and most impressive civil rights settlement in the history of this nation.

title: Scalpers at Wimbledon Are Caught in the Pinch
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 Some of the toughest tickets in sports for centercourt Wimbledon  went to waste the other day as the police swooped down on scalpers who were taking advantage of record crowds to demand $93 a seat.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Soviet Regional Security Official Is Killed in Unspecified Accident.
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (Reuters)  A former highranking security officer has been killed in the course of his duties as Interior Minister of the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, according to a report reaching Moscow today. He was 52 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Wednesday about the New York City rentstabilization program, a, mechanical error caused several lines about maximum-baserent increases to be added to a quotation from Marty Markowitz, a Brooklyn tenant leader and State Senate candidate. In fact, Mr. Markowitz, in his comments, had referred only to the new, lower rentrise limits that the city had adopted for stabilized apartments.

title: Defendants in Capital Crime Cases Given More Latitude on Evidence
description: WASHINGTON. July 3The Supreme Court ruled today that every person who is convicted of a crime that may result in the death penalty must be permitted to offer broadranging mitigating evidence in an attempt to forestall such a sentence.

title: AN EXCONVICT GETS 25 YEARS IN KILLING
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 3(AP) Ricky A. Knapp, a former convict and parttime tree surgeon, was given the maximum sentence of 25 years to life today in the beating death of Linda Jill Velzy, a young Long Island woman who was a student at Oneonta State College.

title: N.A.A.C.P., in Policy Shift, Asks Sanctions Against South Africa
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 3  The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called for a wide range of economic sanction against South Africa to help bring about an end to that country's official policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.

title: Montauk Thriving With One That Got Away and Other Tales
description: MONTAUK, L.I.  This has been a fishing village at the farthest reaches of Long Island for more than a century, but many say the real fishing boom came after the success of Jaws.

title: $81 Million Award Set For Berkey
description: A judge signed a formal judgment yesterday awarding $81.4 million in damages to Berkey Photo Inc. in its antitrust case against the Eastman Kodak Company. Ile also said Kodak would have to pay $5.6 million to Berkey for attorneys fees.

title: Forego Takes to Track Seeking Earnings Mark
description: Yesterday it was a youngster, Moreton Binn's Jose Binn, a 2yearold colt, who occupied center stage at Belmont Park. Today, eyes will be on an oldtimer, Forego.

title: Deaths
description: DOOSECharlotte (nee Mauss) on July 3, 1978. Beloved wife of Hans. Devoted mother of Marianne Hetzel, Ursula Popule and Ute Giarizzo. Dear sister of Emmy Hirsch and Greta Loose. Loving grandmother of Christine, Hans and Thomas. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd. Rego Park. Service Wednesday 12:45PM. Funeral will follow. Interment Washington Memorial Park, Paramus NJ.

title: LEVITT ASKS INQUIRY ON CITY'S CONTRACTS
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt recommended yesterday that the City Investigation Commissioner look into the City Law Department's practice of awarding more than $1 million in consultant contracts to a small group of real estate appraisers without getting Board of Estimate approval.

title: Times Wins Delay on Surrender of Curare Case Notes
description: HACKENSACK. July 2  The New York Times and M.A. Farber, one of its reporters. were relieved tonight from the responsibility to comply immediately with a Stale Superior Court order requiring the surrender of notes, recordings. memorandums and other news material that helped lead to the current prosecution of Dr. Mario F. Jascalevich for allegedly murdering five hospital patients.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Heidi Byers Herrington Is Married to a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Heidi Byers Herrington, a lawyer with the Civil Division of the Department of Justice, to Eli Whitney Debevoise 2d, a lawyer with the Washington firm of Surrey, Karasik & Morse, took place yesterday at the First United Methodist Church in Greensburg, Pa.

title: Cloudy Skies Threaten a NotSoGlorious Fourth
description: A mild rain made a fizzle out of two New York Harbor Festival events yesterday and caused concern about the possible scrubbing of today's flyby of 75 vintage and classic aircraft intended to celebrate the 75th anniversary of man's first powered flight.

title: Indians Rout McGregor And Trounce Orioles, 90
description: The Baltimore Orioles' starting rotation, which earlier this season was beginning to draw comparisons with their successful 1971 foursome, faltered again last night as the Orioles continued to slip out of the pennant race in the American League East. The Indians rapped out 16 hits against Baltimore in a 90 romp in Cleveland.

title: PEKING ENDS ALL AID TO THE VIETNAMESE, RECALLING ADVISERS
description: PEKING, July 3  China announced the formal end of all economic aid projects in Vietnam today as the feud between the two countries deepened.

title: Court in Memphis Orders Striking Firefighters to Co Back to Their Jobs
description: MEMPHIS, Term., July 3  Striking firefighters, whom city officials have accused of setting hundreds of fires to call attention to their pay demands, today were ordered to return to work at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Mozart at Glynciebourne: An Intimate Magic Flute..
description: GLYNDEBOURNE, England  As musical experience. Glyndebourne's Magic Flute this summer conforms to the norm opera lovers have come to expect from this lovely south England festival. Intimate operas benefit mightily from the intimate setting, but the actual musical performance is not up to top international standards. The conducting is often firstclass, several of the singers are usually honorable or promising, and extensive rehearsal guarantees admirable standards of ensemble. But the general level of singing, while rarely downright bad, is not really very high.

title: Canada's Link of Tax Brackets And Inflation Stirs U.S. Interest
description: OTTAWA For the last four years, Canada has had in effect a device aimed at keeping inflation from automatically raising personal income taxes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)  The National Labor Relations Board ordered an election today among players on United States teams of the North American Soccer League to determine whether they want to be represented in leaguewide collective bargaining by the N.A.S.L. players' association.

title: Notes on People
description: With a kiss from a kidnapper, 11yearold Mauro Carassale was released yesterday by the Sardinian bandits who had held him for 70 days mostly in the rainy outdoors, it turned out The boy was turned over to a family emissary for a ransom reported between $175,000 and $310.000. The youth had been abducted from the Emerald Coast seaside home of his parents, offering himself in place of his sick brother. The release followed, by eight days, a plea from Pope Paul VI, who called the boy a little lamb and a symbol of innocent goodness. The boy reported that the kidnappers said. Forgive us, Mauro, as they released him. He was the seventh child kidnapped for ransom in Sardinia since 1966 and one of 22 persons kidnapped in Italy this year.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3  The proSaudi Government of Yemen was accused today of having sent troops across the border yesterday into Marxistgoverned Southern Yemen, where they reportedly occupied two villages.

title: Exporting Of Alaskan Oil Urged To Prevent Oversupply on Coast
description: Scarcely a year alter On first started to snake its way down the Alaskan pipeline  a pipeline that Congress authorized during the Arab embargo to lessen America's dependence on foreign oilexperts are warning that the nation is starting to frustrate the very purpose of the $10 billion project. By allowing the flow from the line to continue backing up on the West Coast, they say, the United States is impairing its quest for greater energy selfsufficiency.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 3, 1978

title: Exporting Of Alaskan Oil Urged To Prevent Oversupply on Coast
description: Scarcely a year after oil first started to snake its way down the Alaskan pipeline  a pipeline that Congress authorized during the Arab embargo to lessen America's dependence on foreign oil experts are warning that the nation is starting to frustrate the very purpose of the $10 billion project. By allowing the flow from the line to continue backing up on the West Coast, they say, the United States is impairing its quest for greater energy selfsufficiency.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION GIVEN NEW SUPPORT BY SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  The Supreme. Court indicated strong support today for affirmative action programs that remedy past discrimination in employment, even when they conflict with established union seniority systems.

title: JUSTICES BACK F.C.C. ON OFFENSIVE WORDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 The SupremE Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that the free. speech protection of the First Amend. ment does not bar the Government from prohibiting radio broadcasting of words that are patently offensive but fall short of the Constitutional definition of obscenity.

title: Family Planning Official Named
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)  Dr. Irwin M. Cushner, a professor of medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, was named today to head family planning programs in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare starting in September. Dr. Cushner, 54 years old, is board chairman of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, the research wing of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America

title: Deaths
description: WARSHAUERSamuel. The Officers, Boards and Staff of the Jewish Corn mullity Center on the Palisades mourn deeply the untimely death of a cherished leader Sam was a won. derfully unique till beautiful human being whose gentle, generous and scholarly involvement made him a ma ior force in the Jewish life of our community. As Chairman of the Board of Governors. Director and Trustee of J.C.C. on the Palisades, Sam's presence is irreplaceable. We will miss his wise counsel and warm friendship. We grieve deeply, and wish to express to Ruth, the children, grandchildren and all the family, that we share in their deep sense of loss. May the bright light and warmth of Sam's life help to console the family and all of us who mourn his death.

title: Gayle Martin Plays In Final for Pianists
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (AP)  Gayle Martin, the only American among 12 pianists in the final rounds of the Tchaikovsky musical competition, performed yesterday.

title: Montauk Thriving With One That Got Away and Other Tales
description: MONTAUK, L.I.  This has been a fishing village at the farthest reaches of Long Island for more than a century, but many say the real fishing boom came after the success of Jaws.

title: Financial General Sued By Two Arab Investors
description: WASHINGTON July 3 (AP)  Financial General Bankshares and most of its officers and directors have been sued for $3 million in damages by two Arab investors involved in an attempt to gain control of the company.

title: Egypt to Attend London Parley, Mondale Is Told
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 3 President Anwar elSadat formally accepted an American invitation today to send Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel to London later this month to meet with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Caddies at Western Tourney Also Carry Load as Scholars
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 3  There are many college scholarship programs for caddies in the United States, but the granddaddy of all is the Evans Scholars Foundation. In existence since 1930, the foundation is the principal beneficiary of the Western open, which was conducted here last weekend by the Western Golf Association. The W.G.A. also administers the Evans Scholars program.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Chaos At Sea on an Unhappy Ship
description: At 6:15 last Friday evening Capt. Ion Tourvas sounded a bonechilling blast on the foghorns of the S.S. America and the nearly 40yearold ship began turning into the Hudson River for its maiden voyage under new ownership, heading for the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: High Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  High interest rates feed inflation by raising the cost of everything bought with borrowed money, from a split level in the suburbs to a new machine tool. Yet, despite the generally accepted proposition that inflation is the nation's No.1 enemy, interest rates are going up. A few weeks back. mortgage rates crossed the 10 percent barrier in Califorlia. Last Week, the Federal Reserve Board, the independent agency that rules over such matters, raised the rate it charges member banks to 7 percent, and major banks raised the rate they charge their most creditworthy customers to 9 percent  both quarterpoint increases.

title: Soviet Protests British Decision To Grant Refuge to a Diplomat
description: LONDON, July 3 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union protested today against Britain's decision to give refuge to a Soviet diplomat and demanded access to him.

title: Marie Curie, Irwin Shaw Novel And Miss Woodward Due on TV
description: A trio of dramatic programs, each destined for different television systems, will deal with the biography of woman of science for public television, translate to home screens an Irwin Shaw novel for a consortium of independent stations and star Joanne Woodward in a fourhour movie for a network. Each program is based on a book.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Yields on new threemonth Treasury bills yesterday rose above 7 percent to their highest levels since 1974.

title: Rising Spanish Socialist Shunning Dogma
description: MADRID  He is heir to one of the most radical Socialist movements in Europe. He is 36 years old, and it would not be altogether surprising if, in the not too distant future, he became Prime Minister of newly democratic Spain. So Felipe Gonzalez, the shaggyhaired first secretary of the Socialist Workers Party, is edging toward the center of the political spectrum.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, July 3,1978

title: New York Police Use New Type of Wanted Poster
description: The New York City Police Department has introduced a new type of wanted for murder poster and authorities say the posters have already contributed to the arrest of several suspects.

title: Justices Back California and New Mexico on Water
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  The Supreme Court today strengthened the position of the Western states in their decadeslong dispute with the Federal Government over control of water rights, ruling in two cases that the United States had exceeded its authority in water disputes with California and New Mexico.

title: Bridge:
description: Overall United States supremacy was quite obvious in the World Pairs Olympiad in New Orleans during the last two weeks. Symbol of this supremacy was the retention of the Solomon Trophy, which has been monopolized by Americans since it was put into play by the late Charles Solomon of Philadelphia 12 years ago.

title: Teacher Union Chiefs Urge a Halt to the Use Of Competency Tests
description: DALLAS, July 3  The leadership of the nation's largest teacher organization called today for a halt to the trend toward minimum competency examinations for student promotion and graduation.

title: Truck Driver Killed
description: A truck driver was killed in a fiery crash involving his rig and a city bus near the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, the police reported.

title: Developing Bloc Irked On Trade
description: GENEVA. June 3  Developing countries complained today that they were being treated on a takeitorleaveit basis by the big industrialized powers in trade liberalization negotiations here.

title: Nursing Instructor, 44, Found Stabbed to Death In Her Apartment on the Upper West Side
description: A 44yearold nursing instructor was found bound and stabbed to death in her Upper West Side apartment yesterday morning.

title: Atlantic City Is Facing Loss of a Landmark
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 3  The dome, towers and cupolas of the Blenheim Hotel, which have stood in bizarre, sandcastle splendor above the honkytonk of the Boardwalk here since 1906, will be demolished this year by its new owners and replaced with a modern hotelgambling casino unless the city or state blocks the move.

title: George M. Cohan Stamp Is Issued in Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 3 (UPI) George M. Cohan, the entertainer, was honored today on the 100th anniversary of his birth with the issuance of a 15cent postage stamp.

title: China's Oil Output Rises
description: TOKYO, July 3 (AP)  China's crudeoil output climbed 11 percent and natural gas production 14.6 percent in the first half of this year, compared with the JanuarytoJune period of 1977, the Hsinhua press agency reported today. Crudeoil processing increased 8.1 percent and drilling footage 66.7 percent as China's oil industry fulfilled its first halfyear plan, Hsinhua added. As usual, Hsinhua gave no production figures.

title: Mollie K. Moran, at 83, a Leader In Coney Island SocialCivic life
description: Mollie K. Moran, a founding member of the woman's division of the Coney Island United Jewish Appeal who played a prominent role in Coney Island's civic and social life, died Saturday at the Kings Highway Hospital in Brooklyn after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Dynamics to Modify Accord With A.T.C.
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced at its headquarters in St. Louis that it had agreed with the American Telecommunications Corporation to modify the terms of their previously announced agreement under which General Dynamics would acquire the El Monte, Calif.based telecommunicationsequipment manufacturing company.

title: No Recurrence of Chlorine Leak
description: COVINGTON, KY., July 1 (UPI)  The Roselawn Community Swimming Pool, where more than 300 people were made ill by leaking chlorine gas Wednesday, has been reopened without any recurrence of the leak. There were no fatalities from the chlorine, although a halfdozen people remained hospitalized Friday for respiratory treatment.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JULY 4, 1978

title: Female Officers Arrest Men Searching for Prostitutes
description: In a new tactic against prostitution in midtown Manhattan, the Police Department has assigned three decoy plainclothes police women to patrol the streets on the lookout for John,or men who patronize prostitutes.

title: Andrew Israel Dies in Car Crash; ExNew York Architect, Was 37
description: Andrew C. Israel, an architect who formerly lived in Stamford, Conn., and New York City, was killed in an automobile accident Friday in Phoenix. He was 37 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Many Cat Owners Have Dogs
description: CHICAGO (UPI)  The Pet Food Institute says 50 percent of the cat owners in the United States also own a dog. There are an estimated 23 million cats in American homes and apartments.

title: America Sails Again After Undergoing Inspection
description: The S.S. America returned to port yesterday and, despite complaints by many passengers that their weekend cruise had been a disaster, she sailed again eight hours later after inspectors said they had found only minor violations.

title: Swedish Wonder Mine Now a Loser
description: KIRUNA, Sweden  Well within the Arctic Circle, deep inside a mountain, more than 4,000 Swedish miners and engineers have been extracting highgrade iron ore for decades. The project, which until recently was the main supplier to the blast furnaces of Western Europe, resembles not so much a mine as an underground civilization from the realm of science fiction.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Sonatrach, Algeria's national oil and gas company, has given final approval to a contract providing for delivery of 4 billion cubic meters of natural gas a year to West Germany for 20 years beginning to 1984. The move was a result of a delay in the United States approval of agreements with the El Paso Company and Tenneco Inc. for the shipment of some 20 billion cubic meters of natural gas a year to the United States, the official Algerian press agency said yesterday.

title: A Rational Anthem
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif.  With the approach of the AllStar game, a small band of walking otological wounded celebrates the 97th annual indictment of the 72nd Congress, which, in the year of our Lord 1931 and doubtless under the influence of the Great Depression, gave birth to a bill conferring a form of knighthood upon an ancient British drinking song by making it our official national anthem. I speak, more in sorrow than in anger, of The Star Spangled Banner.

title: A Volley of Biggies
description: VENTURA, Calif.  The Fourth began with a bag of firecrackers from Falkowski's.

title: I.B.M. Asks Memorex Mistrial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP) Citing a jury deadlock, the International Business Machines Corporation asked that a mistrial be declared in the $1 billion antitrust suit filed against the giant computer concern by the Memorex Corporation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Hall Rented by P.L.O. Is Bombed
description: PARIS, July 3 (Reuters)  A bomb caused heavy damage to a hall rented by the Palestine Liberation Organization early today, the police said, but it was nearly empty and no one was seriously injured. They said a previously unknown group calling itself Talion Law claimed responsibility for the blast and said it was in retaliation for the bombing of a Jerusalem street market last week in which two Israelis died and 12 were injured. The P.L.O in Beirut claimed responsibility for the Jerusalem attack.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: No Progress Reported in Efforts On New York Hospital Contract
description: Two New York City labor disputes marked time yesterday, with no reported signs of progress.

title: Economic Indicators Off in May
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to foretell business trends, registered a slight dip of 0.1 percent in May, according to the preliminary reading published today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STATING THE CASE Prices being what they are, gone are the days of rockbottom vacation tabs in New York State resort areas. But a nostalgic, documented look backward at popular state vacation spots of the 19th century is proviaea in a new exhibition at the NewYork Historical Society, ranging from travel brochures of the time to rates. A typical hotel room price, according to the new display, was a mere $2.50 a day some 100 years ago.

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 5,1978

title: Lois Staysky, a Teacher, Is Wed to Isaac Mozeson
description: The marriage of Lois Staysky to Isaac Elchanan Mozeson, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Leon M. Mozeson of Portland, Me., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Staysky, in Rego Park, Queens. The bridegroom's father, spiritual leader of Congregation Sharai Tefileh in Portland, performed the ceremony

title: U.S. Cellist Is Moscow Winner
description: MOSCOW, July 4  Nathaniel Rosen, a 30yearold cellist with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, won a first prize in the Tchaikovsky Competition last night, becoming the first American instrumentalist to capture a gold medal since Van Cliburn took the honor in piano 20 years ago.

title: Four Motorcyclists Are Wounded When New Mexicans Open Fire
description: QUESTA, N.M., July 4 (UPI)  A confrontation between seven carloads of area residents and a score of Colorado motorcyclists at a northern New Mexico campground resulted in gunfire last night. Two men and two women cyclists were wounded one seriously

title: Best Buys
description: ALONG with an extended holiday weekend, consumers have some additional cause for rejoicing this week. Food prices went down in New York City, reducing the cost of feeding a family of four by nearly 1 percent. According to the New York City Deparment of Consumer Af fairs, the 41item weekly market basket rang up a bill of $83.83 for the weed. ending June 30, or 0.9 percent lower than the $84.58 reported for the weelending June 23.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., July 4  Bobby Rahal of Greenwich, Conn., moved from seventh place on the starting grid to first on the 12th lap to win the S40,000 Formula Atlantic race at Lime Rock Park today by five seconds over Howdy Holmes of Ann Arbor, Mich. Rahal drove a Ralt RTI while Holmes, who had been the fastest qualifier, drove March 78B..

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Connors, Gerulaitis, Okker And Borg Reach Semifinals
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 Drama. artistry and emotion overflowed at Wimbledon today.

title: Finding Ingredients
description: In Puerto Rico cooks use equal amounts of culantro and fresh coriander leaves. The flavors are similar but culantro, a dark green serrated leaf, is more pungent Culantro leaves are available in Manhattan in certain Puerto Rican vegetable and produce markets. If you can't find them, use all fresh coriander leaves. Fresh coriander leaves are known as cilantrillo.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Meadowland Plan Asks Building Of 3 Solid Waste Recycling Units
description: SECAUCUS, July 4  A $100 million plan to build a baling facility and two recycling plants to handle garbage disposal for 114 North Jersey communities has been drawn up by the Hackensack Meadowlands Deirelopment Commission.

title: Gen. Kurt Student of Germany; Planned Mussolini Rescue Raid
description: Gen. Kurt Student, the German comminder credited with developing modern airborne tactics, died Saturday at the age of 88 in Demgo, West Germany, accordine to a hospital snokesman.

title: Pirates 3, Expos 1 (1st); Pirates 4, Expos 3 (2d)
description: AT PITTSBURGH  Bert BIyleven knocked in all three Pittsburgh runs with a basesloaded double in the second inning of the first game and scattered five hits over eight innings before leaving w??n a sore arm. Blyleven (85), who has won his last five decisions, was relieved by Kent Tekulve. In the second game, homers by Willie Stargell, Omar Moreno and a tworun shot by Bill Robinson helped the Pirates to sweep the doubleheader. Montreal's Tony Perez hit a pair of home runs, his sixth and seventh of the season, to account for all of the Expo scoring off Don Robinson (52). Tekulve also got a save in the second game, giving him 11 for the season.

title: Hill Plays Down Peabody Coal Rift
description: ST. LOUIS  A year ago last month, Roderick M. Hills took over as chairman and chief executive of the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer and one of the world's largest coal mining and marketing operations.

title: Solid Leaders Aid Success of Tea Men
description: FOXBORO, Mass., July 4  It is not a surprise that the New England Tea Men is the North American Soccer League's most successful of the six expansion franchises and one of the best over all.

title: Six Injured in Paterson Fire
description: PATERSON, N.J., July 4 (AP)  A fire swept through five downtown apartment buildings here yesterday, injuring three residents and three firemen and leaving 40 families homeless, authorities said. Fire officials said the cause of the blaze was not known.

title: SevenPlayer Trade Is Part of CelticsBraves Shift
description: Seven Boston Celtics and Buffalo Braves, including such stars as Nate Archibald and Billy Knight, are expected to change uniforms after the owners of National Basketball Association teams approve the Braves move to San Diego and the transfer of ownership of the two franchises.

title: U.S. Decides to Permit Israeli Sale 01 50 to 60 Jet Fighters to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  The Carter Administration, in a decision with important implications for American policy toward both the Middle East and East Asia, has agreed to allow Israel to sell 50 to 60 advanced fighter planes to Taiwan.

title: Massenet's Sapho Due Jan. 23
description: Massenet's rarely heard opera Sapho will be revived in a concert performance next Jan. 23 at Carnegie Hall by the Friends of French Opera Robert Lawrence. the organization's music director, will conduct, and the main role of Fanny Legrand will be taken by the Swedish soprano Elisabeth Sbderstram. The opera, based on a novel by Alphonse Daudet, will also have in the cast Donald Grobe and David Griffith, tenors; Ronald Hedlund and Anthony Becerril, baritones, Glenys Fowles, soprano; Betty Allen, mezzosoprano, and John Seabury, bass.

title: Around the Nation
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 4 (AP)  About 100 people held a march and rally in President Carter's hometown today to protest what they called the unfair treatment of a black woman imprisoned for slaying a white man she asserts tried to rape her.

title: Jersey City Group Set Up to Halt Increase in Abandoned Buildings
description: JERSEY CITY  Concerned about the increase in abandoned multifamily dwellings, city officials have formed a Housing Policy Committee that will make specific recommendations to Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith next month.

title: Hanoi Discounts Impact Of Aid Cutoff by Peking
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 4 (AP) Vietnam's Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs said today that China's withdrawal of all aid to Vietnam would not seriously affect his country's development programs.

title: CURRENCY
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)  The dollar declined today in busy trading on Europe's money markets after it sank to another record low against the yen in Tokyo.

title: Americans Learn To Take High Tea
description: And, speaking of the science of Life, have you got the cucumber sandwiches cut for Lady Bracknell?

title: Books of The Times
description: SOMETIMES the most original books, arise out of the most commonplace themes.
