Lying, by Sissela Bok is about precisely what the title says, it is a restatement of a problem as old as the need for mutual trust in human society. But it hits the mind like a spanking offshore breeze on a torpid summer day. Perhaps its bracing freshness is partly due to its appearance at a time of moral torpor, when public mendacity has been the prevailing political climate.

title: Hooks Criticizes Bakke Decision; Sees a Time of Crisis for Rights
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 4 (AP)  Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today criticized the Supreme Court's ruling in the Allan P. Bakke case as ambiguous and said this was a time of crisis for civil rights in America.

title: Padres Get 4th in Row, Top Giants
description: Dave Winfield's firstinning grand slam paced San Diego to a 75 victory over San Francisco yesterday as the Padres continued their surge and the Giants, though still leading the National League West, continued their nosedive.

title: Youth, 16, Shot For Laughing, Fighting for Life
description: A 16yearold boy shot in the head on Sunday night on Morningside Heights by a passerby who apparently objected to his laughter was listed in critical condition yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital and was being kept alive by a respirator.

title: AirConditioners: A Look at Repairs
description: SIDEWALKS sizzle, the asphalt goes gummy underfoot and skyscrapers wrinkle in the corrugating heat  it's air conditioning season. And now, just when you need; it, the sweating, straining little machine in the window quits. Can it be fixed? Usually. Properly and cheaply? That's far less likely, according to one recent consumer test. Given an airconditioner in perfect operating order but with one interior wire deliberately disconnected, 7 out of 11 repair shops checked in the city misdiagnosed the problem or charged for unnecessarily costly repairs ranging up to $98.

title: Careers
description: SOME fresh breezes Of change are blowing through those classrooms populated by a record number of eager candidates for Master of Business Administration degrees. This year about 50,000 men and women graduated with the degree, after studying two years daytime or four years and more in evening sessions.

title: The Miraculous Cheeseless Cheesecake
description: TRADITIONAL Jews interpret the Bible as forbidding meat and dairy dishes at the same meal, but, instead of resting content with the wisdom of the sages, Ralph Goodman and Heinz Rohr wanted to do something about it. They own The Cake Stylists Inc. of Queens, and they dreamed of producing a cheesecake that was parve  neither meat nor dairy  and thus acceptable at any meal.

title: Cricket Test Abandoned
description: LEEDS, England, July 4, (Reuters)  The third and final cricket test between England and Pakistan was abandoned as a draw today when the final day, like the previous four, was ruined by rain. England had already clinched the series by winning the two previous games by wide margins.

title: Afghan Boy, at 8, Looking to College And His Ph. D at 11
description: An 8yearold Afghan boy who has completed the high school curriculum and apparently is able to perform prodigious feats of learning, has been brought to New York and is living quietly in Elmhurst, Queens, while his father seeks help to further his education.

title: A Casual Dinner in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico WHEN we were invited to dine at La Fortaleza, the Governor's mansion in Puerto Rico and the oldest government house in the Western Hemisphere still in original use, we found the invitation irresistible. Not only because the building itself is a splendidly maintained, even elegant, historic monument. And not only because it would give us a fine opportunity to discuss the ins and outs of Puerto Rican cookery with the chef. But because we knew that the chatelaine of the mansion is a lady named Kate Donnelly of Baldwin, L.I.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSEthel. On July 2. Beloved wife of the late John Anders. Surviving are son Arthur and nephew Richard Waltens. Service Ttr..trsday, 10 A M. at Guardian Angel Church, 191 16th Ave NYC. Friends may call Wednesday, 25 and 79 at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. NYC.

title: U.S. Envoy Speaks on Soviet TV
description: MOSCOW, July 4  After refusing him permission to speak on television last July 4, the Soviet authorities allowed Ambassador Malcolm Toon to appear today. The American's remarks, which were videotaped, avoided pointed references to human rights.

title: Business People
description: Everett B. Harris retired last Friday  but just for the weekend. The president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be back on the job this morning in a new capacity, as president emeritus.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Events
description: Theater

title: A Conservative Pause In French Politics
description: LONDONThe French Parliamentary elections in March were significant not just for France but for all Europe. They marked a serious check to a seemingly inexorable rise of the French left. Why, did the left falter? Is there some larger significance?

title: ANOTHER CEASEFIRE BROKEN IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon. July 4 Heavy artillery fire erupted here again this afternuon. breaking the third ceasefire in as many days between Syrian troops and Lebanese Christian militias.

title: Benjamin Werne, Lawyer, Rabbi And ExProfessor at N.Y.U., 74
description: Benjamin Werne, a lawyer, teacher and rabbi, died of heart failure, Sunday, in South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Rockville Centre. L.I.

title: A Traveling Salesman's Story
description: ATLANTA, Ga., So Jimmy Carter will get rid of those threemartini lunches, and all those selfstyled populists in Congress will ban gasguzzlers from the highways and byways, and all the little people will be happy. Right? Wrong.

title: How to Change Careers by Really Trying
description: Anthony J. Profita knew what he wanted. He wanted to be a doctor, maybe a pediatrician. But he had spent more than half of his life fixing cars and managing gas stations.

title: Blumenthal Shapes Bill For Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  With rare candor about political purposes, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal and several Democratic House tax writers are trying to shape a taxcut bill whose chief virtue, all hands concede, would be its ability to attract Democratic votes.

title: $110,500 Coast Handicap Is Won by Effervescing
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP)Taking an early lead, Effervescing breezed to a 31/2length victory in the $110,500 American Handicap at Hollywood Park today.

title: Man's Body Is Found In Park on West Side
description: The body of a 33yearold man, described by the police as a professional photographer by vocation and a burglar by avocation, was found early yesterday morning on a slope of Riverside Park off West 153d Street by a passing motorist.

title: New York and 13 Other States No Longer Face Loss of Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)  New York and 13 other states cited in February for failure to enforce their highway truckweight laws are now making a good faith effort and are no longer threatened with loss of Federal highway funds, the Transportation Department says.

title: Inmate Killed in Ohio Prison
description: MARION, Ohio, July 4 (UPI)  An inmate was stabbed to death and several others were injured in fighting in the honor ward of the Marion Correctional Institute this morning, prison officials said.

title: Carey Will Reconvene Legislature on July 12
description: Governor Carey has announced that he will order the Legislature back to Albany on July 12 to act on crime legislation.

title: Firefighters Return in Memphis, But Dispute on Wages Continues
description: MEMPHIS, July 4 (AP)  Firefighters reluctantly halted a threeday strike today, restoring fire protection to the 800,000 residents of this Mississippi River area who had suffered through a long weekend filled with arson.

title: Tampa Bay 10 Victor
description: LAMPA, Fla. (AP)  The Tampa Bay captain, Rodney Marsh, slammed his sixth penalty shot of the season into the goal with two minutes left to give the Rowdies a 10 victory over the Rochester Lancers in North American League soccer action tonight. The Lancers. including their trainer and several others who left the bench, protested the penalty call. Marsh crashed to the grass in front of the Rochester goal after being tripped by a Lancer. Rochester players protested that Marsh was fouled outside the penalty area.

title: 20 FoodHandling Concerns Are Cited on Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department cited 20 foodhandling establishments yesterday for violations of the health code. In addition, four establishments were given a final inspection.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt will formally submit to Israel today its proposal for a fiveyear transitional period in the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan any', the Gaza Strip and the eventual return of the lands to Jordanian and Egyptian administration. The plan is said to include specific security arangements for Israel during the fiveyear period and the creation of Palestinian councils in the areas. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Elmira Fire Kills Woman and Son
description: ELMIRA, N.Y., July 4 (AP)  A woman and her 2yearold son were killed this morning when a fire raced through twostory apartment house at 456 Oak Street.

title: Wine Talk
description: ONE of the cardinal rules of the newspaper business is to avoid superlatives in reporting. Calling something the first, the biggest, the youngest or anything else with est at the end can only lead to trouble. Someone always writes in to tell of something older, bigger or younger.

title: Festivities Mark C & O Canal's 150th Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  When President John Quincy Adams turned the first spade of dirt to begin construction of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal on July 4, 1828, he proclaimed the event the most fortunate incident in my life.

title: Cleveland Working to Improve Reputation
description: CLEVELAND, July 1  A group of important businessmen here have got together on a $4.3million campaign to improve Cleveland's reputation, apparently not a moment too soon.

title: Machinery, Manufactured Goods Replace Oil as the Top U.S. Import
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  Imports of machinery and transport equipment and of manufactured goods, mostly from Western Europe and Japan, have overtaken oil imports as the biggest drains in the nation's expanding trade deficit.

title: Desai Seeks to Remove Another Major Dissident
description: NEW DELHI, India, July 4 (AP)  India's political leadership moved tonight to purge from government another key dissident in the governing Janata Party.

title: Tuna Boat With 6 Missing
description: SAN DIEGO, July 4 (AP)  The Coast Guard searched a wide area of Mexican waters today for a tuna boat and six missing crewmen. The body of one crewman, Enrique Gomez, was found by passing fishermen 15 miles south of San Diego.

title: Technology The Wonders Of the Frisbee
description: WASHINGTON ANCIENT Greek discus throwers probably never suspected that they would be the forerunners of a toy that would surpass the HulaHoop and yoyo in popularity and mesmerize scientists with its aerodynamic uses.

title: Rockland Store Boycott Urged
description: NORTHVALE, N.J., July 4 (AP)  A group of mayors in Bergen County said they would ask New Jersey residents to boycott stores in neighboring Rockland County, N.Y., if New York continued a ban on heavy traffic on Route 9W. Noise and congestion from trucks diverted from the New York road are ruining the character of much of Bergen County, said William Lenskold, Mayor of Northvale and president of the group, the Northern Valley Mayors Association.

title: American League
description: AT CHICAGO  Eric Soderholm's ninth home run in the seventh snapped a 11 tie and defeated Ferguson Jenkins (84). Ron Schueler and Greg Proly combined to pitch a fourhitter for Chicago. Schueler lasted the first five innings, allowing two hits before leaving with an injured finger on his pitching hand. Proly, recalled from the minor leagues on Monday, hurled the last four innings and picked up his first American League victory.

title: Standardbred Horse Farms Grow and Prosper in jersey
description: MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP, N.J.Just seven years ago, the grassy pastures and paddocks that now make up the AptTwo Acres standardbred breeding farm here were grain fields. When the grain farm floundered, in stepped Mayo and Don Sister, two brothers with enough money from their banking and construction interests to parlay into reality their dream of a breeding farm for trotters and pacers.

title: Air Force Is Criticized For Purchase of Sand
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)  Senator William Proxmire criticized the Air Force today for spending $18,799 in tax funds to buy 2,8 million tons of sand for the golf course at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas.

title: Violence and Vandalism In Schools Found Rising
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI)  In the last 10 years, violence and vandalism in the nation's schools have increased from an occasional incident to a daily, costly, debilitating problem, the American Federation of Teachers reports.

title: Pearson Is Winner In Firecracker 400
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (UPI)  David Pearson outraced Cale Yarborough's challenging Oldsmobile on the last quarterlap to win the Firecracker 400 today by less than a car length.

title: Mola, a Traditional Art, Survives
description: Gladys de Iglesias, who lives on a tiny island in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Panama. devotes a part of every day to a traditional art form that is being spoiled by its own success.

title: Bridge:
description: In the double knockout team event, such as New York's prestigious Von Zedtwitz. there always comes a time when one team, remaining uniquely undefeated. wishes the conditions provided for a single knockout. As it is, they face several further matches against teams that have survived in the oncedefeated bracket.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Radio
description: Music

title: UTurn for Okinawa: From RightHand Driving to Left
description: NAHA. Okinawa  Japanese officials are preparing to turn this island aroundor at least the roads.

title: How the Big Apple Got Its Name
description: My mother was visiting from Canada recently and one night, apropos of nothing at all, she said to me:

title: National League
description: AT ST LOUIS  Bobby Murcer's leadoff homer in the fifth, only his fourth of the season, snapped a 44 tie and offset a fourrun Cardinal rally an inning earlier. The blast helped Chicago to win its eighth game against St. Louis in eight meetings. George Frazier (02), a rookie and the second of four Cardinal pitchers, was the loser, yielding Murcer's home run and two additional runs. Dave Geisel, in relief, posted his first major league triumph.

title: Deficiencies at Manhattan Plaza In Choice of Tenants Is Charged
description: Federal housing officials say that tenants were selected under inadequate procedures at Manhattan Plaza, the new apartment complex for members of the performing arts and neighborhood residents west of Times Square.

title: A Record Loss At British Steel
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)  Britain's staterun steel corporation posted record $820 million loss in the year ended last March 31, the British Steel Corporation said today. The losses accumulated at the rate of $2.2 million day and amounted to $4,157 for each of British Steel's 197,100 employees.

title: Notes on People
description: IN Algiers, a diplomatic official said, unofficially, that the Canadian Ambassador, Pierre Champentier, met yesterday with Foreign Minister Abdel Azit Bouteflika protesting the case of Dalila Maschino. the 26yearold Algerian woman allegedly abducted from Montreal in April by her brother. Her husband, Denis Maschino, also 26, has said his wife was drugged and flown by chartered plane to her family, which objected to her marriage to a Christian and, according Mr. Maschino, still had plans for her to marry an Algerian Moslem. In a dispatch from Algiers, the Paris newspaper L'Aurore reported Monday that Mrs. Maschino had been forced into an arranged marriage on June 22 with Djamal Driss, a 31yearold heir whose credentials included completion of a computerization course in San Francisco.

title: City Accepts a Proposal for Settling Dispute in ItalianAmerican Unit
description: Acting in a dispute between rival factions over control of New YorkCity's largest ItalianAmerican antipoverty organization, the Human Resources Administration has accepted a proposal aimed at resolving charges of nepotism against the organization's executive director, Mary C. Sansone.

title: Reservoirs Dip Below Spill Level
description: TRENTON, July 4 (AP)  New Jersey's water reservoirs have dipped below the spill level, but it would take a prolonged drought to create a serious water supply problem, a spokesman for the New Jersey Water Resources Division has said. The spokesman, Walter O' Rourke, said less rainfall than normal was expected for July.

title: Ground Is Broken in White Plains For Area's Largest Enclosed Mall
description: WHITE PLAINS. July 4  In a move that merchants, developers and governmert officials said would open the way to the final development of this city's center, ground has been broken for an $80 million enclosed shopping mall on what had long been a largely untouched urbanrenewal tract.

title: Disk Golf: Is Your Frisbee Game Up to Par?
description: Pasadena, Calif. Bartenders, gardeners and scientists are among a growing number of golfers who shoot the breeze with phosphorescent Frisbees across fairways whose holes resemble metal trash baskets.

title: Chess:
description: The 1978 United States championship in Pasadena only partly settled the question of who will represent this country in the interzonal tournaments for world championship aspirants scheduled for next summer. The two leaders, Grandmasters Lubomir Kavalek who captured first prize, $4,200, and James Tarjan, the runnerup, are assured berths in the interzonals, but the third American is not yet determined.

title: Market Place
description: KINDERCARE Learning Centers, the largest professional operator of day care schools in the United States, has already capitalized on its inhouse resources by selling sweat shirts, caps, bibs and jackets to some 20,000 students in its 240 centers in 23 states. It also will photograph for a fee.

title: ERITREAN SITUATION HAS NATO WORRIED
description: United States and West European intelligence analysts and military planners are saying that the SovietCuban movement toward Eritrea is the most important strategic development facing the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Nixon's Appointees to High Court Voting Less as a Bloc With Burger
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  The legacy Richard M. Nixon left the Supreme Court  four generally conservative Justices who dominated the tribunal's rulings over the last five years  has apparently lost its cohesiveness.

title: TV:Tom and Joann Brings Television Into the Script
description: TELEVISION daughter whines at television mother: Mothers on television never act so gross. Television mother explains: They've got to be nice or you just change the station... In life, you can't iust change the station.

title: Bsendorfer Pianos Set for U.S. Debut
description: VIENNA FRANZ LISZT, the 19thcentury lion of the keyboard, wasn't only a composer and a great showman, but also a terror to concert managers  he would wreck the piano in every performance. Until he found himself in front of a Rosendorfer.

title: BUSINESS  Digest
description: Oil has fallen to third place among the nation's imports and is no longer the dominant factor in the expanding trade deficit, according to an analysis of Commerce Department figures. Imports of machinery, transport equipment and manufactured goods have expanded sharply in the first five months of the year and now contribute more than oil to the trade imbalance. The shift in trade patterns is leading to new policy decisions within the Carter Administration. [Page A1.]

title: PrizeWinning Recipes of the Caribbean
description: Although there were a lot of lagniappes thrown into a recent visit to Puerto Rico  dinner with the Governor and his wife, visits to the island's restaurants and so on  the principal and original reason for the visit was to act as a judge at a Caribbeanwide cooking competition, open to cooks and chefs of hotels and restaurants of the entire region. The event was sponsored by the Caribbean Tourist and Hotel Association.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Arecipe for a Chinese soup lists, among the ingredients, two tablespoons of cornstarch dissolved in three tablespoons of water. This is to be added to the soup at the very end. Should the soup be boiling when the mixture is added, and how long should it take for the soup to thicken?

title: Coaster Nuts Talk Old Thrills and Test a New One
description: SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 3  They call themselves coaster nuts and coaster freaks and even coaster maniacs. And they smile tight, prideful smiles.

title: Helping the Dumped
description: With the proliferation of singleroomoccupancy hotels in cities across the nation have come crimes and assaults that anger citizens in their neighborhoods. For some time, their protests and the ire of the press have turned on exmental patients who are being dumped onto city streets. But in New York, for example, only about onetenth of the discharged patients live in S.R.O. hotels, comprising about a quarter of their population.

title: For Atlantic City, All Bets Are On in Bad Weather
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 4  The sun did not penetrate the heavy overcast today, so those who intended to spend the holiday here stayed home or went to the gambling casino.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, JULY 4, 1978

title: Time Shares Gain Popularity
description: Sight unseen, James Houck Jr. of Lutherville, Md., bought himself the right to use a room in the Breckinridge, a hotel on the beach in St. Petersburg, Fla., for one week a year for the next 25 years. He paid $3,000 in cash two years ago, and he has yet to set foot in the room.

title: 2 in France Are Given 20 Years In Smuggling of Heroin to U.S.
description: PARIS, July 4 (Reuters)  Two French citizens were sentenced today to 20 years each on charges of having headed the socalled French Connection ring that smuggled henun from the Riviera to New York.

title: The American Diet, Then and Now
description: WE Americans love to eat. And we love nothing better than eating lots of the foods we love best. In 1976. for instance, the average American satisfied his evergrowing sweet tooth by downing 493 eightounce soft drinks, treated himself to more than 18 pounds of ice cream and between 1950 and 1976 increased consumption of beef by 90 percent. Not surprisingly, we are eating less and less of the foods we believe, for a variety of reasons, we should avoid. And so over the years we cut back on candy bars (seen as empty calories), drastically reduced consumption of foods considered fattening, such as bread and fresh potatoes, and cast a dietary frown upon foods we are told contribute to a high cholesterol level: eggs, butter, whole milk, heavy cream.

title: Upper Nile Is Winner; Forego 5th
description: If cheers, applause, homemade love signs and other assorted affection could have put Forego over the $2 million mark yesterday, he would have made it easily.

title: Americans in China Have Hot Dogs on 4th
description: PEKING, July 4 (Reuters)  Hundreds of people munched hot dogs in Peking today at the city's best party of the year, the Fourth of July celebrations.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 5, 1978

title: Italy's Abortion Law Is Working
description: ROME. July 4  A spot check at several Rome hospitals and clinics indicates that Italy's new abortion law is working, if. not as well as feminists would like, then not as badly as might have been expected in this strongly Roman Catholic Country.

title: Economic Scene
description: WHILE most leading business economists still see the American economy heading into slowdown short of outright recession in the next 18 months, a growing minority  especially among those close to the financial and investment community  believes an actual recession could arrive even before the middle of 1979.

title: Zachry Named to N.L. Staff
description: Someone old (Phil Niekro, 39), someone new (Pat Zachry, selected for the first time), someone borrowed (Ross Grimsley, last year with Baltimore, this year with Montreal) and someone Blue (Vida) lead the pitching contingent selected yesterday by Manager Tom Lasorda for the National League AllStars.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRONT AND CENTER Come and meet those dancing feet. The opening lyric of the famous old tune 42d Street  spells part of the story about the 20thanniversary festival starting tonight at the Clark Center for the Performing Arts in the heart of midtown. This of course, should make the fiveday event accessible to everybody, with nightly performances at 8 at City University's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. The programs are also reasonably priced at $4.50, with students and the elderly admitted for $2.50.

title: Change in State's Bar Exam Set; License for Wider Practice Seen
description: The bar examination  the bane of generations of New York lawyers  will be substantially modified in a year, the State Court of Appeals has announced, with one day of the twoday test to be devoted to standardized questions on Federal rather than New York law.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Initial Success

title: A PACT GIVES POLICE $2,400 OVER 2 YEARS
description: A tentative agreement that would give each New York City police officers a salary increase of $2,400 over the next two years was reached last night between negotiators for the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Behind Rockets' Red. and Other, Glare
description: It was hours before show time. The Shimmering Shamrocks, Blooming Chrysanthemums, Coiling Cobras and Hong Kong Yang Bangs were still in boxes. As a blustery wind cut across New York Harbor, a dozen workmen stood on barges in the rain and stuffed bombs the size of cannonballs into cardboard mortars.

title: Survey Reports Water Flow Of Rivers Is Back to Normal
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)  The water flow in the nation's five largest rivers has settled to near normal levels, according to the June report of the United States Geological Survey.

title: Japan May Lift Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, July 4 (AP)  Japan's June trade surplus is likely to increase sharply from May's surplus of $631 million to total more than $1.4 billion, the Finance Ministry's International Monetary Bureau said today.

title: Dennis E. Puleston, a Professor, Is Killed by Lightning in Mexico
description: Dennis E. Puleston Sr., associate professor of anthropology at the University of Minnesota, was killed by lightning June 29 at a Maya archeological site in Merida, Mexico. He was 38 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: DANIEL LEVY
description: Daniel Levy, a Manhattan lawyer, died yesterday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island following a brief illness. Mr. Levy was 74 years old.

title: Mitchell Paces Nippon
description: TOKYO, July 4 (AP)  Bob Mitchell, formerly of the Milwaukee Brewers, hit a threerun homer in the first inning as the Nippon Ham Fighters breezed to a 61 victory over the Lotte Orions in Japanese baseball today. Mitchell's 23 homers this season lead the Pacific League.

title: Afghan Boy, at 8, Looking to College And His Ph. D at 11
description: An 8yearold Afghan boy who has completed the high school curriculum and apparently is able to perform prodigious feats of learning, has been brought to New York and is living quietly in Elmhurst, Queens, while his father seeks help to further his education.

title: U.S. Aide and 3 Die Near Manila
description: MANILA, July 4 (AP)  An American personnel expert and three Filipinos died yesterday when a van of the United States Agency for International Development plunged 200 feet down a cliff north of here, the police said today. The victims were David Leon of Washington, his driver and two women trainees, the police said.

title: Chinese Refugees Report Bribery and Corruption Persist in Vietnam
description: HOKOW, China, June 30 (Reuters) Chiang Yuanfeng, a 25yearold ethnic Chinese from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, says she paid Vietnamese officials two ounces of gold for false travel documents to enable her to reach China.

title: State Standardbred Farms Are Prospering
description: MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP  Just seven years ago, the grassy pastures and paddocks that now make up the AptTwo Acres standardbred breeding farm here were grain fields. When the grain farm floundered, in stepped Mayo and Don Sisler, two brothers with enough money from their banking and construction interests to parlay into reality their dream of a breeding farm for trotters and pacers.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A YOUNG MAN traveling around town with cumbersome portable radio/tape deck pressed to ear but blaring to one and all is not an uncommon sight. On the downtown Second Avenue bus last Saturday, writes Jay Howard Heyman, the level of sound wasn't the surprise. Rather it was the choice of music  Beethoven's Sixth. Loud (very loud) and clear.

title: CONGRESS BACKS OFF ON BUDGETSLASHING
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  With Congress adjourned for the Independence Day break, the folks back home are hearing a lot of talk about all the budgetslashing that has been going on up on Capitol Hill since Proposition 13 was passed in California.

title: A PACT GIVES POLICE $2,400 OVER 2 YEARS
description: A tentative agreement that would give each New York City police officers a salary increase of $2,400 over the next two years was reached last night between negotiators for the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: ExCity Counsel Criticizes Audit
description: Disputing allegations in a state audit report, W. Bernard Richland, former New York City Corporation Counsel, said yesterday that the city had stopped giving its realestate appraisal work to only a handful of men a year ago.

title: Western Aviation Leaders Face Hard Choices on New Jetliners
description: Aviation leaders of the Western world are nearing a series of hard decisions on a new generation of jet airliners to fill huge impending gaps in carrier fleets.

title: Real Estate
description: THEY loved us in Woodhaven. said Vincent Riso. Near Forest Park in the Woodhaven section of Queens. the Briarwood Organization, of which Mr. Riso is president, is completing 48 condominiums, begun two years ago.

title: Advertising
description: THE only surprise about George Lois's new agency  everyone seemed to know that he was going to start one  is its president. Richard J. Gershon.

title: Western Aviation Leaders Face Hard Choices on New Jetliners
description: Aviation leaders of the Western world. are nearing a series of hard decisions on a new generation of jet airliners to fill huge impending gaps in carrier fleets.

title: Zachry Wins 2Hitter, 40, in Met Split
description: Only hours after being named to the National League AllStar team, Pat Zachry of the New York Mets shut out the Philadelphia Phillies on a twohitter, 40, in the opener of last night's twilightnight doubleheader.

title: In Bad Weather, All Bets Are On
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 4  The sun did not penetrate the heavy overcast today, so those who intended to spend the holiday here stayed home or went to the gambling casino.

title: Playing With Crime in Albany
description: When the New York Legislature recessed recently, it brought down the curtain on some dreadful playacting on crime. The performance mocks the seriousness of the problem and even the political importance that the rival parties ascribe to the issue.

title: Winning By Losing Elections
description: WASHINGTONBefore the 1978 election campaign, and its more wanton opportunists, are full upon us, Congress should restructure the grotesquerie that makes it possible for a loser in a Federal election to get much more out of it (financially, at least) than the winner.

title: Behind Rockets' Red, and Other, Glare
description: It was hours before show time. The Shimmering Shamrocks, Blooming Chrysanthemums, Coiling Cobras and Hong Kong Yang Bangs were still in boxes. As a blustery wind cut across New York Harbor, a dozen workmen stood on barges in the rain and stuffed bombs the size of cannonballs into cardboard mortars.

title: Ulster Policeman Is Slain
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, July 4 (AP)  Terrorists killed a Northern Ireland reserve policeman today outside a police post near the border with the Irish Republic, the authorities reported. A spokesman said that three gunmen shot Constable Jacob Rankin as he left the Castlederg post and then fled across the border, about three miles to the south.

title: Japanese Banking Colony in Germany
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany  At the end of the Konigsallee, one of the country's most elegant streets, is a neon enclave with signs that read Toshiba, Bank of Tokyo and Asahi Pentax. Thyssen and Klikknerstahl, two German industrial giants, are there too, but with bit parts in the light show.

title: 4,000 Marijuana Smokers Rally; Exhibit Little Fear of Herbicides
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  A preliminary Government survey shows that 36 percent of tested marijuana samples contain some residue of the highly poisonous herbicide paraquat. But there was little evidence of any widespread fear among the thousands of smokers who converged on the nation's capital today in what has become an annual publicity campaign for legalization of the substance.

title: Newport Opera to Do 3 Concerts a Day
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 4  The Newport Opera Festival, which gave its inaugural concert on Saturday night, is now operating on full schedule. That means three concerts a day until the festival's end on July 9. It also means a colossal amount of work for the young musicians who are bearing the brunt of a literature with which they are, by and large, unfamiliar. Very few American musicians  or musicians anywhere, for that matter  have done much exploration into the minor Romantics who are being so prominently featured on Newport Music Festival programs.

title: Secret Longings? Rent a Life
description: IN his book Future Shock Alvin Toffler asserted that we were becoming a modular society, a module being a unit that is interchangeable or disposable. We have even, in big cities, he wrote, created the disposable person: Modular Man,  people with whom we have limited involvement relationships, whose inner lives we don't share. Examples could range from a transaction with a shoe salesman to the shortterm romantic liaison formed in a singles bar. These modular people in our lives are interchangeable, specialized, disposable.

title: Machinery, Manufactured Goods Replace Oil as the Top U.S. Import
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  Imports of machinery and transport equipment and of manufactured goods, mostly from Western Europe and Japan, have overtaken oil imports as the biggest drains in the nation's expanding trade deficit.

title: U.S. Markets Had Day Off
description: All stock and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Foreign markets, including the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges, were open. Today is a normal business day, with all domestic markets, banks and most businesses open.

title: The Courthouse That Graft Built
description: The architectural stepchild of them all  New York City's Tweed Courthouse  had a roofraising party the other day to celebrate the start of structural repairs and the announcement that the city's most despised landmark will be preserved for a new use. Until now, this fine AngloItalianate monument to the peculations of the notorious Tweed ring has had few friends. Only architectural oddballs gave a finial for its fate. There have been so many threats by so many mayors to demolish it that its very existence is a miracle.

title: The Retreat From Fenway
description: BOSTON, July 4  Billy Martin, who has had precious little comfort from his pitchers, batters or his employer lately, gut a smidgen of help today from a power even greater than George Steinbrenner. The rain from heaven that the Yankees manager had been praying for doused these genteel precincts, washing out an encounter with the Red Sox and beginning a onemonth ceasefire in hostilities between the baseball champions and the Boston insurgents.

title: U.N. Disarmament Session: Benchmark or Something More Modest?
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3 The General Assembly's special fiveweek session on disarmament ended last weekend with its participants sounding uncertain as to whether their effort was a benchmark in progress toward curbing

title: Katherine Alvord Denson
description: Services for Katherine Alvord Denson, the wife of John Denson, a former editor of The Trib, The New York Herald Tribune and Newsweek magazine, will be held at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow at Oak Hill Cemetery in Washington. Mrs. Denson, who was born in Washington, died of cancer on Friday at her home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Besides her husband, Mrs. Denson, who was 63 years old, is survived by her mother, Mrs. Cyril Jones of Fort Lauderdale.

title: Mayor of Yonkers Calls Council Meeting to Replace Rejected Budget
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 4  In an effort to replace the Yonkers budget rejected yesterday by the State Comptroller, Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli today ordered the City Council to take up the matter Thursday, but an impasse between the Mayor and Council may prevent immediate action.

title: Barrel of Town's Cannon Stolen
description: BALDWIN, Wis., July 4 (UPI)  The Fourth of July celebation did not start with its usual big bang today. Someone stole the barrel of the town's cannon during a severe rainstorm Saturday morning. The brass cannon, weighing 300 to 400 pounds, dates from 1877 and was to have been fired this afternoon to signal the beginning of the holiday festivities.

title: Soviet Prison Official Kills Azerbaijan Security Chief
description: MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)  A prison official killed the Interior Minister of the Republic of Azerbaijan and two other officials last week, then shot himself to death, a spokesman said today.

title: U.S. TO GIVE ISRELIS A SADAT PEACE PLAN FOR OCCUPIED LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  An Egyptian Government peace proposal, calling for a fiveyear transitional period of rule in the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan and Gaza Strip and their eventual return to Jordanian and Egyptian administration, will be formally submitted to Israel tomorrow.

title: Rain Grounds ClassicPlane Flyby, buttes a Fine Day for Lifeboat Races
description: It was a great day for crops and grass yesterday, but a virtually record rainfall ruined Fourth of July plans for much of New York City's Harbor Festival and for many celebrations in the metropolitan area

title: Kerr Leaving Yale U. Press
description: Chester Kerr, director of the Yale University Press since 1959, will retire from that post on June 30, 1979. He is the third director of the press, which was founded in 1908. He will be 65 years old next month.

title: Grudges and Corruption Inquiry Color Governorship Race in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU  The cloud of an unsuccessful investigation into public corruption is hanging over the Hawaii election this year.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THERE is, of course, a good deal of difference between food preparation in a professional kitchen and that in a home. One of the most obvious reasons is the number of hands and the number of hours that can be employed in wellstaffed restaurants in the preparation of what are known in French as les fonds de cuisine or the bases for cookery. These would include an assortment, some of which require hours of simmering, the tedious task of putting the sauces through sieves and so on.

title: Tuning Out Protectionism
description: A sigh of relief was heard round the world when the Supreme Court ruled recently against tariff protection for the Zenith Radio Corporation. The Court's ruling, pverturning a Customs Court decision requiring countervailine duties on imported electronics equipment, will allow United States trade negotiators to avoid a bitter confrontation with their European and Japanese counterparts. No judicial action, however, can relieve the continuing pressure in this country for greater protection against foreign competition. That will depend on a greater commitment to growth and trade by the world's other major economic powers.

title: Automation May Peril Job Growth
description: PARIS, July 4  The United States and other Western industrial countries may face a period of jobless growth in the 1980's, even if President Carter and other nations leaders succeed in their declared aim of expanding business investment and ending the world recession.

title: A No Frills Welfare Dilemma
description: With the chance for major welfare legislation now lost, at least for this session of Congress, Senator Moynihan has come up with a plan to salvage some reform. In so doing, he has presented an uncomfortable dilemma, testing whether supporters of reform are, as he puts it, loudmouths or liberals. The plan promises fiscal relief for state and local welfare spending, especially for New York City, which adds $310 million a year to what the Federal and state governments contribute. That relief would surely be welcome to this city's hardpressed treasury. Yet we find the plan difficult to support in its present form. It would help needy local governments but do too little for needy people.

title: Bitter Munson Is Still Hoping To Be Traded
description: BOSTON, July 4  Some of George Steinbrenner's friends threw a birthday party for him the other night. They did not invite Thurman Munson. Reggie Jackson, in fact, was the only Yankee player invited. But then, you do not invite Thurman Munson and George Steinbrenner to the same party.

title: Miss Legendre Wed To A.C. Patterson
description: Bokara Legendre, daughter of Mrs. Sidney Ledgendre of Medway Plantation, Mount Holly, S.C., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and the late Mr. Legendre, was married yesterday to Arthur C. Patterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. El!more C. Patterson of Bedford, N.Y., and Fishers Island, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Sturtevant performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Fire in Ouebec Cabin Kills 8
description: BLANC SABLON, Quebec, July 4 (AP)  A woman, her six children and a 3monthold baby died in a fire yesterday that destroyed the frame fishing cabin shared by two families on an island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, the police reported.

title: Chinese Artists Awed by City
description: Their picnic was rained out, and their parade too; mist and fog blocked most of the views from the top of the World Trade Center; rain dampened and chilled them as they rode the Staten Island ferry. It was, to be blunt, not exactly ideal as the first sightseeing excursion in the New World for 150 of China's most dazzling performing artists. The dancers, singers, actors and acrobats cheerfuly made do anyway. They marveled at the height of the World Trade Center. They oohed at the Statue of Liberty. They took turns at the wheel of the ferry. They inspected the kitchen of a fastfood restaurant. They photographed one another everyplace they went.

title: F.B.I. Offers Reward For 2 Cubans Wanted In Murder of Letelier
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (Reuters) The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it would pay up to $20,000 for information leading to the arrest of two Cuban exiles wanted in connection,with the assassination of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: U.S. Decides to Permit Israeli Sale Of 50 to 60 Jet Fighters to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  The Carter Administration, in a decision with important implications for American policy toward both the Middle East and East Asia, has agreed to allow Israel to sell 50 to 60 advanced fighter planes to Taiwan.

title: Nixon's Appointees to High Court Voting Less as a Bloc With Burger
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  The legacy Richard M. Nixon left the Supreme Court  four generally conservative Justices who dominated the tribunal's rulings over the last five years  has apparently lost its cohesiveness.

title: MISUSE OF U.S. FILES ON MILLIONS FEARED
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Social Security Administration's financial and medical files on millions of Americans are not properly safeguarded from potential loss, destruction, abuse or misuse, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: Ernest Robert Breech, 81, Is Dead; Aviation and Automotive Official
description: Ernest Robert Breech, long regarded as one of the country's top executives in the aviation and automotive fields, died Monqay night at the William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich., at the age of 81. He suffered a heart attack a week ago.

title: Seabrook May Be Site Of WindPower Tests
description: SEABROOK, N.H. July 3 (UPI) The company attempting to build New England's largest nuclear power plant says that it is willing to test wind power as a source of electricity.

title: CONSUL'S ABDUCTORS GIVE UP IN SAN JUAN
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 4  The first political kidnapping in the history of Puerto Rico ended after 17 hours today with the safe release of the Chilean consul, Ramon Gonzalez Ruiz, and another Chilean national.

title: Holiday Is Quiet in Carolina Town As Walkout by Police Continues
description: NEW BERN, N.C., July 4 (AP)  The holiday was quiet as this coastal town remained without city police protection after a walkout by the 34man force last Friday night.

title: The Boones Bridge Generation Gap as Duet
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 4 A lot has happened to Pat Boone in the last year or so, and most of it is named Debby. Mr. Boone, now an almost frighteningly youthfullooking 44, was a pop icon of the mid1950's, covering rock hits by black artists in a laundered way that appealed to the white audiences of the day. When real white rock arrived full force with Elvis Presley in 1956, Mr. Boone evolved in a softer, more middleoftheroad direction. His career over the last 22 years hasn't really sustained him at the top of the charts, but he's managed an honorable life on televison and at suburban and Las Vegastype theaters.

title: Boy Bitten on Neck When Petting Leopard
description: LAFAYETTE TOWNSHIP, July (AP)  A pet leopard lunged at and bit a 4yearold boy, the state police said today.

title: U.S. TO GIVE ISRAELIS A SADAT PEACE PLAN FOR OCCUPIED LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  An Egyptian Government peace proposal, calling for a fiveyear transitional period of rule in the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan and Gaza Strip and their eventual return to Jordanian and Egyptian administration, will be formally submitted to Israel tomorrow.

title: Begin Survives a Confidence Vote. On Women's DraftExemption Bill
description: TEL AVIV, July 4  Prime Minister Menachem Begin today survived an opposition move in Parliament to depose him because he had sponsored legislation that would enable Israeli women to evade compulsory military service automatically by claiming religious objections.

title: 2 Held in St. Louis Sniping
description: ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP)  Two St. Louis men were arrested today in connection with a sniping incident in which Woman was killed and five others injured, the police said. The police said the men, 29 and 27 years old, fired on about 200 people in the parking lot of a restaurant early Saturday morning.

title: Geneticist Studies Fruit Flies to Determine How Species Split in Two
description: HONOLULU  A geneticist here believes that he is zeroing in on the most critical step in evolution, the moment when a species splits to become two. His goal is to see how, on the molecular level, this occurs.

title: LONDON'S OBSERVER REPORTED IN PERIL
description: LONDON. July 4  Fleet Street sources reported today that The Observer. perhaps the world's most admired Sunday newspaper in the two decades immediately following World War Il, is in peril.

title: Rain Grounds ClassicPlane Flyby, but It's a Fine Day for Lifeboat Races
description: It was a great day for crops and grass yesterday, but a virtually record rainfall ruined Fourth of July plans for much of New York City's Harbor Festival and for many celebrations in the metropolitan area

title: Slowdown In Economy Seen for '79
description: The nation's economy Will experience both slower growth and a faster rate of inflation next year, according to a report issued yesterday by the Economic Forum of the Conference Board.

title: Catholic Bishops in South Africa Appeal to Vorster Over Detainees
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 4 (AP)Roman Catholic bishops in South Africa appealed to Prime Minister John Vorster in an open letter today to release or charge 19 detained Catholics and to abandon the uncompromising policy of apartheid.

title: Byrne Measure Is Drafted to Seek Curbs on BoardingHome Abuses
description: TRENTON, July 4 As a result of fmdings of widespread abuses in boarding homes, the Byrne administration has drafted legislation that would tighten controls on the 1,800 homes where 40,000 New Jerseyans, many of them exmental patients live.

title: Let Em Eat Cake Back in Berkshires
description: The rather heavyhanded revival by the Berkshire Theater Festival makes one thing clear. The demise of Cake was not, as the program notes suggest. a matter of the work's being ahead of its times. It was unequal to them.

title: Earl P. Stevenson, 84; ExDirector and Head Of Arthur Little Inc.
description: Earl P. Stevenson, retired chairman of Arthur D. Little Inc., a research and corporate management concern in Cambridge, Mass., died June 28 in Boston at the age of FA. His lived in Boston.

title: Chevrolet Engine in Olds Brings Refund of $8,000
description: NATCHITOCHES, La., July 4 (AP)The General Motors Corporation and local car dealership have been ordered to refund more than $8,000 to a Shreveport man who bought a 1978 Oldsmobile containing a Chevrolet engine.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An audit by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt found that the Clarkstown School District in Rockland County was overpaid $111,142 in state aid for student bus transportion between 1974 and 1977.

title: MISUSE OF U.S. FILES ON MILLIONS FEARED
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 The Social Security Administration's financial and medical files on millions of Americans are not properly safeguarded from potential loss, destruction, abuse or misuse, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, July 4  Italy's small Republican Party proposed its leader, Ugo La Malta, as a compromise candidate for the nation's presidency today as the presidential electors went through their ninth inconclusive round of balloting.

title: Personal Health
description: DESPITE the professed sexual liberalism of the day, when comes to sex among the elderly. Victorian attitudes persist. Society's disapproval of sexual activity in senescence is reflected in such common expressions as dirty old man, old goat or lecherous ola fool to describe a man who pursues sexual in. terests into his twilight years. or robbing the cradle to describe an older person who selects a much younger mate.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Cook's Travel Kit

title: Parole Examiners Hear Mitchell
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 5 (UPI) John N. Mitchell, the former United States Attorney General, was interviewed today by parole examiners who will recommend whether he should be released from prison at Maxwell Air Force Base. Mr. Mitchell, 64 years old, has served about seven months of a onetofouryear sentence for Watergate crimes.

title: How a Manager Skips Temptation
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) Bobby Cox, manager of the Atlanta Braves, vowed to himself that his relief specialist, Gene Garber, wouldn't pitch in last night's game against the Los Angeles Dodgers  and he didn't. Garber was listed as the starting center fielder, instead.

title: Death
description: CHERNOWMichael The Officers and Staff of the American Jewish Committee express their sorrow at the passing of Michael Chernew, a dedicated worker on behalf of the Committee's Appeal for Human Relations. A cofounder and pastpresident of Monet Jewelers, as well as its chairman, he was a leader in industry and philanthropy alike. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: 30% Inflation Rate Fails to Daunt Israeli Pound
description: TEL AVIV, July 5  Israel has experienced nearly 30 percent inflation since controls on foreign currency transactions were lifted eight months ago.

title: Publicker to Move
description: Publicker Industries, distiller and chemicals producer, plans to move to Greenwich, Conn., sometime this year from Philadelphia, where it was founded in 1913. About 200 employees will be affected by the move, which is being made, a spokesman said, to bring Publicker closer to the the people it does business with. The new headquarters will be in the Greeenwich Gateway Office Building complex, now under construction.

title: CARTER PUSHING AID FOR BOAT PEOPLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  President Carter has ordered American ships to pickup refugees who have fled Indochina in boats and will allow the refugees to resettle in the United States if they wish, a highranking State Department official said today.

title: Canada to Continue Search for Fragments Of Satellite That Fell
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 Canada said today that radioactive debris from a Soviet satellite mishap in January could still be injurious and that it was consequently continuing a recovery program as a matter of urgency.

title: Deaths
description: Amdur, Irma

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MORE OF THE MET Any increase in visiting hours is good news from one of the world's great treasuries of art, and the Metropolitan Museum has just initiated a broader schedule for the rest of the summer. The new rotating agenda ensures that every gallery in the building will be open at least half of each weekday, Tuesday through Friday. Certain galleries  Greek and Roman, Egyptian and the Costume Institute  will be available at all times. And the museum reports that every attempt will also be made to keep open all galleries during public hours on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Beame, a Family Man, Picks $55,000 Pension
description: Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that ha had chosen a pension option that would give him about $55,000 a year after 46 years of working for the New York City government.

title: Business Taps SciFi For Ideas
description: SEATTLE July 5 (AP)  The world of science fiction is moving into a new dimensioncorporate planning.

title: Waldheim Holds Up Transfer of Soviet U.N. Aide
description: GENEVA, July 5  The reassignment of a Soviet United Nations official from the organization's headquarters in New York to head of personnel at its European office here has been suspended pending an investigation into allegations that he is a senior officer in the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency.said he would also examine with great attention reports that Vladimir K. Lobachev, head of the United Nations Conference and General Services Division here, is also a K.G.B. agent. Mr. Lobachev is now in Moscow to recruit interpreters for the United Nations.

title: California Assembly Approves '79 Budget; Aid for Abortions Cut
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 5 (AP) The California Assembly approved a $15.1 billion state budget early today after antiabortion forces scored a major victory by cutting abortion funds for poor women by more than twothirds.

title: Taiwan Buys U.S. Corn
description: ATLANTA, July 5 (AP)  A group of Taiwanese businessmen signed contracts today to buy 101,000 metric tons of Georgiagrown corn for more than $11.6 million. The buying mission of businessmen and Government officials is on a sixweek, 15city tour of the United States, and plans to purchase $750 million in American goods, ranging from nuclear energy equipment to lettersorting machines, during the visit.

title: Building Superintendent Fights Filth and Eviction
description: When I came here. across the street there used to be a big department store. There was a restaurant where the men used to come in wearing high hats and it was lovely.

title: STATE WORKERS GAIN KEY ALBANY VICTORY
description: ALBANY, July 5  Governor Carey tonight signed a bill repealing the penalty in the state's Taylor Law that places pub lic employees who engaged in an illegal strike on probation for one year.

title: Evert, Navratilova in Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 Chris Evert avenged last year's loss to Virginia Wade, 86. 62, today and joined Martina Navratilova in the women's singles final at the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: New Woes for Liner America
description: New troubles hit the liner America yesterday, just when it seemed that her problems had been ironed out and she was bound for Nova Scotia with a boatload of happy passengers. Stormy weather off the New England coast forced cancellation of a stopover at Martha's Vineyard and also disrupted the ship's recently mended plumbing.

title: 4 Arrested in Pentagon Protest
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (Reuters)Four people threw red liquid over a model of the cruise missile, the United States' latest nuclear weapon, at the Pentagon today. The demonstrators, who were arrested, had gained access to the closely guarded Defense Department headquarters by joining one of several conducted tours for the public.

title: Ginzburg, Soviet Dissident, Goes On Trial Monday Near Moscow
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (Reuters)Aleksandr Ginzburg, a Soviet dissident, is to go on trial next Monday, his wife said today.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: TOKYO, July 5  Nobuhiko Ushiba, Japan's spokesman on international economic matters, predicted early this year that the yen would stay around the thencurrent level of 240 to the dollar. Today, however, the yen touched 200.50 to the dollar on the foreignexchange market, coming close to breaking the psychological level of 200. In hotels, in fact, the rate given travelers was 198.

title: Legacy of the '78 Supreme Court: Shift on Prosecutors and the Press
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Continuing controversy over the climactic Bakke decision has tended to obscure two major developments of the Supreme Court term that ended this week.

title: Deaths
description: AMOURIrma on July 5th, 1978 Mother of Ruth Bean and Louise. Kavall. Sister of Tilda, Laura, Lee. Greenbaum, and Elsie Netzcr. Grandmother of Frank. Barbara, Robin and David. Services will be Private.

title: Exhibition in Paris Is Devoted to Rodin's Burghers of Calais
description: PARIS THERE are development gaps within the great art boom that marks our century. The most mistreated of modern art's poor, not to say forgotten, cousins is sculpture. One practically has to put it up in the heart of traffic for people to notice it. But then, that is where it belongs, as the greatest sculptor of modern times, Auguste Rodin, came to realize.

title: Construction Up 2.9% in May
description: New construction rose 2.9 percent in May to an annual rate of $198.6 billion, the Commerce Department announced yesterday. For the three months ended in May, the increase over the same 1977 period was 9 percent to an annual rate of $191.1 billion.

title: Vandalized South Bronx Project Gets New Chance
description: The unfortunate story of South Haven Houses in the South Bronx is headed for a happier turn. But the happier turn will not be too soon.

title: Dance: Machine Keeps the Past Alive
description: CHOREOGRAPHY for Broadway musicals has long been looked down upon as a poor cousin to what goes on in ballet and modern dance. Useless to mention names like Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins or even that of George Balanchine, who provided the dance for a number of musicals, among them On Your Toes and I Married an Angel.

title: Henry Steeger, 49, Former Editor And Publishing Concern Officer
description: Henry Steeger 9th, a former vice president and associate publisher of Popular Publications, editor and film maker, died Monday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center of cancer. He was 99 years old.

title: Abercrombie Name Sold
description: HOUSTON, July 5 (AP)  Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. today completed the acquisition of the exclusive rights to use the Abercrombie & Fitch name. clearing the way for the opening of a new A. & F. store in Beverly Hills, Calif. Abercrombie earlier this year closed all stores operating under its name because of financial difficulties. Oshman's also said it might open other A. & F. stores and run a mailorder business under the Abercrombie & Fitch name.

title: Economic Scene
description: CONGRESS has been struck by a tidal wave public support, rolling eastward from California and Proposition 13, for tax reductions for the middle class and affluent investors.

title: U.S. Plans European Maneuvers
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  Some 13,000 Army troops and 98 F4 jet fighters will travel to West Germany in August and September for annual fall maneuvers, the Pentagon said today. The troops, will comprise elements of the Fifth Infantry Division from Fort Polk, La., units from Fort Carson, Colo.; Fort Bliss, Texas; Fort Lewis, Wash., and from national guard and reserve organizations. The jet fighters will fly from Seymour Johnson Air Force Base N.C.

title: U.S. Seizes 11 Intruders At the Syrian Embassy
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Eleven persons were arrested today after an unsuccessful attempt to occupy the Syrian Embassy here, the Secget Service said.

title: Full S.E.C. Report Out On Auditors
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The Securities and Exchange Commission today urged Congress not to impose direct Government regulation on the accounting profession at this time. Instead, the agency recommended that auditors be permitted to continue their efforts toward selfregulation, accompanied by active commission oversight.

title: Broadway, Broadway Gets Under Way on East 73d Street
description: THE call for the first rehearsal of Broadway, Broadway was for noon yesterday, but well before 11 o'clock the producer, Edgar Bronfman Jr., his assistant, Patti Hassler, his general manager, James Walsh, and his production stage manager, Larry Forde, had gathered at the Manhattan Theater Club at 321 East 73d Street.

title: Single Federal Agency Is Urged To Oversee Deep Seabed Mining
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI)  Congressional auditors urged today that a single Federal agency be named to oversee deep seabed mining despite predic tions from some experts that such mining was not likely to be profitable in this century.

title: Education Department Absolves Montclair of Funds Misuse Charge
description: MONTCLAIR, July 5  The State Department of Education has cleared the Montclair school system of accusations that it had misappropriated funds, but in a report made public today it recommended administrative changes for better bookkeeping and conformity to state policy.

title: Students' Debt Rise Stirs Fear
description: Half of this fall's freshmen at fouryear private colleges will owe an average of $5,000 when they graduate in 1981, and by 1986 that figure may triple, the Student Loan Marketing Association estimates.

title: EGYPTIANS SAY PLAN FOR PEACE CONTAINS COMPROMISE LEEWAY
description: CAIRO, July 5  Egypt today made public the details of its latest Middle East interim peace plan. Cairo sources said it contained several flexible points opening the way for compromise, even though there were still differences with the Israeli proposals presented last December.

title: Communist Party in San Marino To Form a Coalition Government
description: SAN MARINO, July 5 (AP)  The Communist Party will form a leftist coalition government in San Marino, the oldest republic in the world, the republic's executive branch announced today.

title: Strikes Halt British Chrysler
description: LONDON, July 5 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation's unit in Britain has halted all car production at its two assembly plants because of disputes with unions, the company said today.

title: A Family Transplanted to the Farm
description: IT is a picture postcard come to life. Geese paddling on the pond. The old stone farmhouse cool in the shadow of giant shade trees, Sweetsmelling grass, freshly mowed. The distant hum of a tractor toiling through sundrenched fields.

title: Schmidt's Journey to Africa: A Reflection of Bonn's Growing Political Commitment on the Continent
description: BONN, July 5  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's trip to black Africa last week, the first by a West German chief of government, underscored his country's growing political involvement on the continent and Mr. Schmidt's personal willingness to pliy an innovator's role.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: C. Arnimit Smith, the onetime financier, who was a close friend and financial backer of former President Richard NI. Nixon, went on trial in California Superior Court in San Diego yesterday on charges of theft, forgery and tax evasion. Me case began two and a half years ago when he was indicted by a county grand jury.

title: Canada Gains Final
description: STOCKPORT, England, July 5 (UPI) Canada edged Australia today, 16.13, and gained the final against the United States, the defending champion, in the world lacrosse championships. Earlier in the tournament, the Americans thrashed the Canadians by a record 284 score.

title: I.M.F. Gold Sales Down
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (Reuters)Developing nations trimmed their purchases sharply today at the International Monetary Fund's monthly gold auction, 20,800 ounces from the 925,000 ounces purchased in June, the first time they could buy under special rules.

title: Fiat to Supply Chrysler, Ford
description: ROME, July 5 (UPI)  Fiat, the Italian auto maker, will supply lightweight engine parts to the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, a company official said today.

title: William Parish, 56, Photo Editor At White House, of Heart Attack
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI)  The White House photo editor, William Parish, died of a heart attack today at George Washington Hospital after collapsing at his desk. He was 56 years old.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IT IS hard to make a television set a discreet item in a room. If people have the space, they often have a television room  somehow the set seems less odious if it is in its own space.

title: Casino Issues Gain
description: The casmo stocks, taking their cue from dynamic action in Resorts Inter. national scored substantial gains yesterday white the market generally sagged

title: Text of Egypt's New Peace Plan
description: CAIRO, July 5  Following is the official English translation of the new peace proposals that Egypt has given to the United States for relay to Israel.

title: Quake Shakes Palm Springs
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 5 (UPI)  A small earthquake shook this desert resort community before dawn today, jolting residents awake but causing no injuries or damage.

title: Carey Starts Campaign to Hold New Democratic Coalition Support
description: Governor Carey, fearful of a move in the New Democratic Coalition to cancel its endorsement of his reelection, has started a vigorous campaign to hold the group's support.

title: Accord Is Reached to Reorganize Federal Law Enforcement Agency
description: WASHINGTON. July 5  The Carter Administration and key Congressional leaders have agreed on a plan to reorganize the troubled Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, hoping to increase grants and eliminate state government vetoes of how localities can spend the Federal money.

title: JOINT CHIEFS LOSING SWAY UNDER CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The Carter Administration has substantially altered the nation's military leadership by appointing officers who are technicians and managers rather than combat veterans to the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Hockey Star, 17, Is Always Ahead of Himself
description: With mock fear he asked if it was safe to walk the streets of New York. The joke was that Wayne Gretzky, now 17 years old, has been thwarting assaults,aince he began outclassing the big boys as a 5yearold allstar player on a hockey team for 11yearolds.

title: Farah Is Making Bank Payments
description: The Farah Manufacturing Company of El Paso, Tex., has made payments on bank loans it had missed, the company announced yesterday. The cash for the payments of about $1.05 million was generated by cutting expenses, the company said. It said that it expected to make a principal payment of $250,000 on the loans due Aug. 1 and that all future quarterly payments would be made on time.

title: State's 8% Tax Take From Casino May Be Triple What Was Forecast
description: TRENTON, July 5  State officials said today that no decision had been made on how to spend the estimated $40,000 a day in taxes that New Jersey is getting from the Resorts International gambling casino at Atlantic City. The revenue during the first year is likely to be considerably higher than the annual $12 miliion originally projected.

title: Where to Go to Pick Out a Parquet Floor
description: Add variety to parquet's attributes of texture, warmth, and price competitive with other fine floor coverings. An industry spokesman estimated there are now about 3,000 variations of parquet flooring, with new patterns being offered regularly.

title: Brought to Justice
description: BOSTON, July 5  The latest signal of intensified repression in the Soviet Union is a libel suit. Two American correspondents, Craig Whitney of The New York Times and Harold Piper of The Baltimore Sun, have been taken to court for reporting that friends and relatives of an imprisoned Soviet Georgian dissident thought a television scene of him confessing had been fabricated.

title: Events

title: Ghana's Leader, a General, Quits And Is Succeeded by His Deputy
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 5 (Reuters) Gen. Ignatius Kutu Acheampong resigned today as Ghana's head of state, the armed forces announced.

description: By running for Governor, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak has raised an array of bizarre political possibilities.

title: Home Improvement

Yet in most cases it is not that the closet space is inadequate, but that the space is not being used efficiently.

title: Otto W. Timm; He Built His First Plane in 1909
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 5 (AP)  Otto W. Timm, a pioneer in American aviation who reportedly gave Charles A. Lindbergh his first airplane ride, is dead. He was 84 years old.

title: Bank Offers Small Savers TreasuryRate Certificates
description: The largest commercial bank in Maine announced yesterday that it had created a means by which small savers could share in the benefits of the new sixmonth certificates linked to Treasury bill rates, but Federal regulators voiced doubts about the legality of the plan.

description: AMF Inc. has entered into $125 million of sevenyear revolving credit agreements with 12 banks. The credits supersede similar ones that AMF had maintained with nine banks, aggregating $80 million, and which had a remaining term of four years, said Frank

title: Market Place
description: THE Chemical Fund, which will observe its 40th birthday tomorrow, has had a distinguished history for the most part.

title: McKee Contract
description: The McKee Corporation, a Clevelandbased international engineering and construction concern, said that its Belgian affiliate, McKeeTractionel Petrochem Engineers of Brussels, had won a contract to provide engineering services for a multimilliondollar lubricatingoil additives plant. The new structure will be built at Feluy, Belgium, for Edwin Copper S.A., a wholly owned affiliate of the Ethyl Corporation.

title: HarteHanks Acquisition Backed
description: HarteHanks Communications Inc. said it had obtained all the necessary approvals for its previously announced acquisition of the Southern Broadcasting Company for $57 million.

title: Ethyl Purchases Hardwicke Chemical
description: The Ethyl Corporation announced yesterday that it had purchased the Hardwicke Chemical Company of Elgin, S.C., for $15 million. Hardwicke is a specialty company, employing 100 workers. Its principal products are pesticide intermediates.

title: Britain Approves Use Of an Air Base by U.S.
description: LONDON, July 5  Over loud and continuous objections from local residents, the British Government announced today permission for the United States Air Force to base some of its refueling tanker planes at a field in the Cotswold Hills, the heart of the English countryside.

title: Cardboard Furniture: Quick and Easy
description: MOST people would never dream of building their own furniture. There are all those complicated variables involved, such as upholstery, spring s, stitching, welting and stuff ing, not to mention frame construction. It's too timeconsuming. And it's just not any fun.

title: POLISHSOVIET TEAM RETURNS TO EARTH.
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (UPI)  The PolishSoviet Soyuz 30 space team returned safely to earth today with a packet of mail from two orbiting comrade astronauts, ending an eightday mission that included history's third double docking of manned space vehicles.

title: Backgammon:
description: The Rhode Island Backgammon Classic, under the direction of Mike Passarelli, was held June 16 to 18. In honor of the event, those three days were officially Rhode Island Backgammon Weekend, and the 25point finals match took place in the State House Rotunda. There Paul Foster took first place, defeating David Groner, recent winner of the Metropolitan Open. Al Tesaro took the consolation, Paul Coppenwrath won in the intermediate section, and William Evans was victorious among the beginners.

title: Nets Get Another Prospective Buyer
description: A group headed by Alan N. Cohen, former president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, is the latest prospective buyer of the financially troubled New Jersey Nets.

description: Mets vs Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: He's Still in Charge, but the Southern Sheriff Is Changing
description: ATLANTA, July 5  A story is told in the South about a venturesome New Yorker vacationing in Alabama who decides to pull off a country road for bite to eat.

title: Yanks Are Beaten, 32; Mets 75 Losers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 5  As if the 98degree weather wasn't hot enough for the Yankees tonight, the benching of Reggie Jackson for their game with Texas indicated that life in the Yankee family could be heating up again.

title: Samuel H. Pottle, 44, a Composer

title: Unlicensed Movers: Cheap But Risky
description: THEY are actors, dancers, writers, mothers, fathers, students, sculptors, firemen, scientists, retirees and job hunters. What they have in common is that they are also unlicensed movers, and their sideline, illegal though it may be, is meeting a need in an increasingly mobile society.

title: I.B.M. to Study Foreign Operation
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was making a study to see whether giving greater selfsufficiency to its foreign business units would better serve customers in countries where it operates. Among changes to be studied is the conversion of the company's General Business Group into a worldwide, wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Westway Builders, Citing Data Error, Win a Delay on Key Hearings
description: Citing anomalies in some of their traffic projections, the builders of the Westway yesterday asked for and got a delay in hearings on their request for an airquality permit for the controversial $1.16 billion highway.

title: 2,300 Workers Strike American Standard
description: American Standard Inc., maker of braking systems, building products and mining equipment, said yesterday that 2,300 workers had struck plants in Louisville and Paintsville, Ky., and in Dearborn, Mich. The company said it expected negotiations to resume shortly.

title: Cosmos Are Beaten, 10, By Tea Men in Overtime
description: FOXBORO Mass., July 5  The casual and sloppy Cosmos were defeated by an enthusiastic New England team, 10, at Schaefer Stadium tonight before 30,126 fans, the largest home crowd to watch this expansion club.

description: Morning

Husband of the late Herrietta Short Tebb, brother of Mrs. Gordon (Florence) Brown of Pleasantville, NY. Survived by one niece and three nephews. Memorial service Thursday (today) 5 PM Christ Church Methodist, Park Ave at 60th St. NYC Interment Hollywood Cemetery, Richmond Va.

title: Mexico Steel Output Up
description: MEXICO CITY, July 5 (UPI)  Mexico's steel production in the first five months this year was up 24 percent from the like 1977 period, the National Iron and Steel Industry Chamber reported today. From January to May of this year the Mexican industry produced 2.7 million tons of steel, against 2.2 million tons in the 1977 period. Advanced production systems, a higher domestic demand and a slight increase in exports accounted for the rise, the chamber said.

title: Back to Basics in the Middle East
description: Egypt's plan for a Middle East peace is no more promising than Israel's and that is hardly news. Neither is the much fussedover agreement of each Government to send its foreign minister to London for a meeting with Secretary of State Vance. In everyone's eagerness to demonstrate movement, it seems to have been forgotten that direction also counts.

title: Financial Weaknesses Denied by the Owners Of London Observer
description: The owners of The Observer, one of London's most respected Sunday newspapers, denied a report in yesterday's issue of The New York Times that the British publication was financially imperiled and that its future was in doubt.

title: Greek Orthodox Church Approves Greater Role for Clergy and Laity
description: DETROIT, July 6  A new charter that allows.the clergy and laity substantially greater participation in the administration of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America was approved today at the church's 24th biennial ClergyLaity Congress.

description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI)  Los Angeles has the worst air quality in the nation, the National Wildlife Federation said today.

title: U.S. Appoints Fact Finder to Avert Hospital and NursingHome Strike
description: A factfinder was named yesterday by the national director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to strengthen efforts to avert a strike tomorrow against 61 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City metropolitan area.
