description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Robert S. Strauss, the chief trade negotiator for the United States, declared loday that the European Economic Community would have to offer more trade concessions to American farmers or the Geneva trade talks would fail.

description: TORONTO, June 29  Orthodox Jews must do a better job of reaching their collegeage youths, says Rabbi Bernard Rosensweig, the new president of the Rabbinical Council of America, an association of Orthodox rabbis.

title: Hers
description: A CITY person encountering nature hardly recognizes it. has no patience for its cycles, and disregards animals and plants unless they roar and exfoliate in spectacular aberrations. Preferring the city myself. I can discern natural phenomena better when books point them out; I also need to verify what I think I've seen, even though charts of phylia and species are orderly whereas nature is wild, unruly.

title: Roadway Express Increases Earnings
description: Roadway Express Inc., the nation's largest common motor carrier, with an average haul of 931 miles, yesterday reported earnings of $14.1 million, or 69 cents a share, up 23.7 percent, on revenues of $232.9 million. which were up 25.1 percent for the second quarter ended June 17. This represented a new record for the quarter and for the six months' net of $22.7 million, or $1.11 a share, up 19.5 percent on revenues of $431.5 million, or 24.1 percent higher than a year earlier.

title: Cohn Joining Wolfson Drive
description: Roy M. Cohn has become the latest in a succession of lawyers to represent the financier Louis E. Wolfson in his 11year struggle to overturn his 1967 conviction and imprisonment for securities laws violations. The New York lawyer, who has been the Florida financier and sportsman's personal counsel for some time, said yesterday he would lia idle future rounds in the long campaign.

title: WHITE HOUSE BRIEFS 4 SOVIET REPORTERS

title: Health Care Centers For Needy Are Found Overstaffed in Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Although the Government has estimated that 43 million Americans lack adequate access to health care, the 112 neighborhood health centers set up in the nation to provide care are generally overstaffed and are not experiencing great demand for their services, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Luca Petromarchi, Italian Aide
description: ROME, July 5 (UPI)  Luca Petromarchi, a retired diplomat who served as Italian Ambassador to the Soviet Union and to Turkey, died Monday. He was 83 years old. In World War II. Mr. Petromarchi was sentenced to death in absentia by a Fascist court for his role in negotiating Italy's armistice with the Allies. He emigrated briefly to Brazil after the war, then returned home to join Italy's Marshall Plan negotiating team. marchi was sentenced to death in absentia by a Fascist court for his role in negotiating Italy's armistice with the Allies. description: THEY are here. For the first time. China has sent us members of the Peking Opera Troupe that toured the world and always bypassed the United until the Cultural Revolution stopped such touring altogether.

title: Soviet Nuclear Blast Detected
description: STOCKHOLM, July 5 (AP)  The Soviet Union set off its fifth underground nuclear explosion of the year in its regular testing grounds northwest of the Semipalatinsk area in Kazakhstan today, the Uppsala Seismological Institute reported. The blast, triggered early today, was recorded by seismographs seven minutes later at 6.7 on the openended Richter scale, an institute official said.

description: Q. Wax was deposited on both our glass and our silver candlesticks, from socalled dripless candles. Do vou know of any Way to remove this wax? D. P., New York City.

description: A FAMILY FORTUNE. By Jerome Weidman. 474 pages. Simon & Schuster. $10.95.

title: Design Notebook
description: A DINER is the most American thing there is. London had the coffee stall and George Bernard Shaw. in Pygmalion. showed just what could be done with it on the stale. Berlin has a whole army of equivocal carts that serve frankfurters all day and all night. In Moscow, a fourwheeled tanker comes round the boulevards with kvass in hot weather. Rut only this country has the diner. The diner ought to be on wheels, but it isn't. You ought to be able to sit in it. and eat, and go somewhere, all at the same time. Rut something went wrong, and the diner sat down on the ground like a lovesick elephant that just wouldn't go any farther.

description: The Rev. Leon H. Sullivan announced yesterday that he had expanded his six principles for the guidance of the practices of American corporations operating in South Africa to include, among other things, a provision that black workers be free to form their own unions.

title: Kosygin, in Supreme Soviet, Assails U.S. Trade Curbs
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (AP)  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin accused the United States today of hampering economic cooperation by unwillingness to establish normal trade relations. He spoke at the opening of the regular summer session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament.

title: Men Buy Cheaper Suits, Hurting Some Makers
description: When American men start belttightening, the odds are long that they are doing it on a suit costing well under $400. For with today's level of inflation, few middleincome consumers can afford to buy a $400 suit, long considered the Cadillac of men's clothing.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP)  The American Legion of Pennsylvania is holding its 60th annual convention in Philadelphia. the site of the group's 1976 convention after which 29 people died of a mysterious illness.

description: MOSCOW, Thursday. July 6 (AP) Elmar Oliveira of the United States shared first prize for violin with Ilya Grubert of the Soviet Union in the sixth international Tchaikovsky Competition, officials announced early today.

title: McCovey Clout Helps Giants Win
description: The San Diego Padres suffered at least a temporary setback in their attempt to make the National League West a fourteam race yesterday. They lost, 54, to the divisionleading Giants at San Francisco on Jim Dwyer's basesloaded sacrifice fly in the 10th inning.

title: US. GROUP SNUBBED BY DUBLIN'S LEADERS
description: KILLARNEY, Ireland, June 29  A major IrishAmerican organization, the Ancient Order of Hibernians in America, is holding its annual meeting on Irish soil but with little encouragement from the Irish Government.

description: LONDON, July 5  Thirty years ago today, Britain's National Health Service was born in an atmosphere of hope and contention.

description: CAIRO, July 5  Egypt today made public the details of its latest Middle East interim peace plan. Cairo sources said it contained several flexible points opening the way for compromise, even though there were still differences with the Israeli proposals presented last December.

description: THE REVISIONISTS REVISED. A Critique of the Radical Attack on the Schools. By Diane Ravitch. 194 pages. Basic. $8.95.

description: WASHINGTON, July 5  If we are to understand what is to happen at the ecosummit in Bonn where, next week, the seven largest nonCommunist industrial nations are sending their heads of government and finance ministers, we must remember the story of Br'er Rabbit and the Briarpatch.

title: Luzinski Star of N.L. Stars
description: Greg Luzinski of the Philadelphia Phillies outpolled his closest pursuer among the outfielders. George Foster of the Cincinnati Reds. by nearly a million votes to win his third straight starting spot on the National League AllStar team for next Tuesday night's game in San Diego.

description: PERSON TO PERSON can still make television journalists nervous. The late Edward R. Murrow, a towering figure of integrity in broadcast journalism, remains a beacon of inspiration for those who would have television treat news seriously and, if necessary, courageously. These same people worry about growing trends to. ward fluffier features and gaudier cosmetics.

title: Baloney Pictures
description: Mayor Koch, who swore he would not waste his time on such things, has started cutting ribbons: one to mark construction of the Hyatt Hotel, once the Commodore; another for a businessassistance center in the South Bronx; a third for a leaserenewal by a magazine in Rockefeller Center, and then one for the tearing down of some El tracks in Queens. He had a reason: These are big ribbons, he said.

title: Luzinski Home Run, Triple Spark Phils
description: The New York Mets, who missed a doubleheader sweep over the Philadelphia Phillies by one pitch Tuesday night in Shea Stadium, sought to redeem themselves as the teams met again last night. However, Greg Luzinski dashed the Mets hopes by driving in two runs with a triple and his 19th home run of the season in Philadelphia's 75 victory.

title: Waldheim Calls Bonn Crucial
description: GENEVA, July 5  The United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, stressed today that any progress that the leaders of Western industrialized countries and Japan make in harmonizing their economic views at their summit meeting in Bonn next week would be crucial to the whole world.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt's interim peace plan was announced officially, and Egyptians contended that it contained flexible points, giving room for compromises. The proposal represents Cairo's position for talks between foreign ministers in London this month, as proposed by the United States to bring Israel and Egypt together. [Page Al: Column 6.]

title: MetroGoldwynMayer Reports Higher Earnings
description: MetroGoldwynMayer Inc. continued its recordbreaking results in the three and ninemonth periods ended May 31. In the threemonth period, the company recorded net income of $13.1 million, or 90 cents a share, up 76 percent from a year ago on revenues of $106.9 million, or 44 percent ahead of the 1977 total. It was the best performance achieved for any quarter in the company's history, according to yesterday's report.

title: U.S. Car Output Off In June
description: DETROIT, July 5 (UPI)  Domestic passenger car production, slowed by the start of the 1979model changeover, dropped in June to its lowest level since midwinter, the Big Four auto companies reported today.

title: Proposition 13 Is the No. 1 Issue For Teachers at National Parley
description: DALLAS, July 5  Probably the most popular button worn by delegates to the National Education Association convention here bears a drawing of two dice and the words, 13 You Lose.

description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: COMMODITIES
description: Soybean and grain futures prices climbed sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, while the tropical commodities plunged and traders in precious metals generally marked time. Brokers had ready explanations for all three trends.

title: New Woes for Liner America
description: New troubles hit the liner America yesterday, just when it seemed that her problems had been ironed out and she was bound for Nova Scotia with a boatload of happy passengers. Stormy weather off the New England coast forced cancellation of a stopever at Martha's Vineyard and also disrapted the ship's recently mended plumburg

title: Singapore Emerging as Major Banking Center
description: SINGAPORE  With the active encouragement of the Government, Singapore is gradually emerging as a major offshore banking center in Asia, an increasingly vital link in the financial chain between New York and London, and Tokyo and Australia.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.. July 5Bucks, a smoothmoving bay gelding owned and ridden by Mike McCormick of Plano, Tex., won the first intermediate jumper class today at the opening session of the sixday I Love New York horse show.

title: Deaths
description: SPIEGELFrances L. died on July 5. 1978. Devoted wife of the late Step hen, survived by loving nieces end nephews. Graveside services will be held Friday July 7th. 11 AM, Mt. Sin. al Memorial Perk. New Haven. Conn.

title: Pension Funds Weigh M.A.C. Bid
description: New York City's major banks and municipal pension systems are considering a request from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to increase their unguaranteed lending commitments to the city by up to $300 million, their spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Sound
description: IN the early days of the phonograph, only stentorian voices like Caruso's successfully overrode the surface noise while weaker sounds often failed to register at all. String instruments, for example, were totally lost among scratches and swishes unless fiddlers fastened trumpetlike tin funnels to their instruments to bolster the sound, thereby making even the finest violin sound like a kazoo.

title: Bakke: Lost Candor
description: NEW HAVENSolomonic. judicial statesmanship with such words scholars and pundits greeted the Supreme Court's decision in the Bakke case. The praise is not surprising. The case seemed to involve a clash or irreconcilable principles: equality of opportunity for all, regardless or race: and reparation, advantage even, for those who could not share equally in that equality, because of society's past biases. Nor was the conflict simply one of abstract principles. An allocation of social goods was directly involved. Since every applicant could not be admitted to medical school, reparation for some meant depriving others of an equal, colorblind chance.

title: Israelis Disappointed By Cairo's New Plan But Will Go to Talks
description: JERUSALEM, July 5  Egypt's interim peace plan for the %Vest Bankand the Gaza Strip met official silence in Israel today. But some officials, speaking in private, said it was a disappointment that served to illustrate the wide gap between Israel and Egypt on the issues of peace.

title: Academics Learning the Ways of Business
description: Last month George D. Smith was a residential dean and instructor at Harvard University, where he earned a Ph.D. in history two years ago. Now he is spending his days studying accounting, marketing and finance, hoping to become a business executive.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE are lots of flowers on my zucchini, but I never get any fruit and how come my yellow squash never gets any bigger than a pencil stub? are some of the frustrations frequently voiced this time of year. One can add cucumbers and melons to the complaint list, and sometimes pumpkins as well. The problem centers on sex. Now, I'm not suggesting you send your butternut to the psychiatrist. But if you have healthy plants with lots of blossoms and no fruit, do check out their sex life.

title: Village Farms Wins in Polo
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 5  Village Farms of Gilbertsville. N.Y., defeated Fairfield, Conn., 95, and Brandywine edged the Centaurs, 87, today in the opening round of the Monty Waterbury 18goal polo tournament at Hickox Field. Brandywine will meet Meadowbrook Friday afternoon at Hickox Field. The winner will face Village Farms on Sunday at Bethpage State Park for the championship. The Village Farms attack was led by Heath Manning with four goals and Mimo Gresada with three. Allan Scherer scored all five Fairfield goals.

title: Kempff, at 79, Gives Bach Recital
description: WILHELM KEMPFF has never been adequately known or appreciated in this country. Partly it is because he hasn't played here very much. Partly it is because the German Idealism that nourishes his inwardness is not universally exportable.

title: Israelis Disappointed By Cairo's New Plan But Will Go to Talks
description: JERUSALEM, July 5  Egypt's interim peace plan for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip met official silence in Israel today. But some officials, speaking in private, said it was a disappointment that served to illustrate the wide gap between Israel and Egypt on the issues of peace.

title: IsraelTaiwan Jet Deal in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 The State Department, confirming that the United States had approved the sale of advanced Israeli fighters to Taiwan, said today that it was not clear whether the Taiwanese were prepared to go through with the proposed deal.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins Appeal And Wears Her Lucky Dress
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 Martina Navratilova calls it her lucky dress because she has never lost a match in it. For a while at Wimbledon today, however, it appeared that the 21yearold lefthander had lost a chance to wear the dress in her semifinal with Evonne Goolagong.

title: Man, 23, Is Arraigned In Slaying of Boy, 11, On Street in Brooklyn
description: A man who allegedly celebrated his 23d birthday in Brooklyn Tuesday night by firing six revolver shots, one of which was said to have killed an 11yearold boy, was arraigned on seconddegree murder charges last night.

title: The Grapes of Plenty
description: Watching The Grapes of Wrath on television the othernight was an odd experience. The movie version of John Steinbeck's novel about the Joad family's hard journey from friendly but parched Oklahoma to green but unfriendly California was as affecting as we remembered; but this time on screen it was accompanied by commercials for I.B.M. about some successful small businesses. There, in color, were tributes to the combination of ambition, imagination, hard work and the I.B.M. computer that raises families to affluence; and there, in black and white, was the memorable story of the cruelties of nature, of man and of the system that grind families down.

title: Texas Man, 76, Seeks Divorce So Wife Can Receive Medicaid
description: DALLAS, July 5 (UPI) C.W. and Ruth King's marriage has withstood 49 years, a disease that has eroded her mind and body and the financial problems the affliction caused. But now bureaucracy is coming between them.

title: James Daly, Actor, Is Dead at 59; Took Many TV Character Roles
description: James Daly, the character actor whose more than 600 television credits included a leading role in the Medical Center series and who also appeared on the stage and in movies, was pronounced dead on arrival at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Sante Fe Buys New Equipment
description: The Santa Fe Railway announced that it had purchased $185 million in equipment to meet current and expected traffic increases.

title: Notes on People
description: THE former Black Panther party leader, Eldridge Cleaver, was helped to settle in France six years ago by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, then Finance Minister, officials in Paris confirmed yesterday. They said that Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, on strictly humanitarian grounds, helped Mr. Cleaver obtain a residence permit. The black leader was a fugitive from a court in California, where he had been charged with attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon. He arrived in France by way of Algeria. Mr. Cleaver, who returned to the United States in 1975 and announced he had become a bornagain Christian, still awaits trial in Oakland, Calif. The statements that prompted the official comment in Paris are from an excerpt from Mr. Cleaver's new book. Soul on Fire, appearing in New York magazine.

title: Home Beat
description: SARINA MASCHERONI says the idea of lilies came about while playing tennis with a friend. Do something with lilies, said her athletic churn. And I thought, there are roses and peonies, but therearen't any lilies . . .

title: Brief Urges a Rehearing On Police Search Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI)  The National Association of Broadcasters said today that it had joined with several other news organizations in filing a friend of the court brief with the Supreme Court for a rehearing on the Court's ruling on police searches.

title: Memorex And I.B.M. In Mistrial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (AP)  A mistrial was declared today in the $1 billion Federal antitrust suit brought by the Memorex Corporation against the International Business Machines Corporation after the jury reported it would be futile to continue deliberations, which began June 8.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Washington

title: Bridge:
description: For those who like to study the performance of the world's greatest players, the world championship book, which has been published by the American Contract Bridge League for the last quarter of a century, is an annual treat.

title: Decline in Fertility Predicted
description: The Population Institute sees clear signs of a worldwide decline in fertility, United Press International reports. Birthrates have fallen by 15 percent in about 90 countries since the 1960's, the institute says. Those countries account for about half the population of the developing world.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of America New York has named Robert Range, James P. Reilly and Coleman Travelstead vice presidents of the international banking subsidiary of the Bank of America.

title: Jersey Casino Took In $16 Million for June
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 5  Resorts International reported today that its daily take in June from the nation's only legal gambling casino outside Nevada averaged $534,627 and that its gross for the month was $16,038,805.

title: Practicing Digging Up the Past, Class Finds Artifacts of the 30's
description: A cache of broken bottles, license plates and clay pipes from the 1930's Was found under several feet of soil in a Brooklyn cemetery yesterday by a group of Brooklyn College students on an archeological dig.

title: TRIAL WITNESS CITES SEARCH FOR CURARE
description: HACKENSACK, N.J. July 5  A pharmacologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the compound he had developed for detecting curare was accurate, although it had never been used before to seek out curare in embalmed bodies buried for a decade.

title: Blind Protesters Gather in Capital To Assail Aviation Rules on Canes
description: WASHINGTON. July 5  More than 1,000 blind people and their supporters demonstrated at the Department of Transportation today, calling for an end to safety regulations requiring them to surrender their canes upon boarding airliners.

title: NORWALK IDENTIFIES 2 MURDERED WOMEN
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 5The bodies of two young women were found yesterday in a secluded wooded area here. Each had been stabbed several times.

title: 2 Officers Elevated At Gimbel Midwest
description: Thomas G. Grimes was named chairman and chief executive officer and Burnett W. Donoho was named president and chief operating officer of the Gimbel Brothers Midwest Division, with headquarters in Milwaukee.

title: Idiot's Delight Staged in Williamstown
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. In Idiot's Delight Robert Sherwood predicted our past with considerable foresight.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne urged an international group of businessmen in New York City yesterday to examine the State of New Jersey in terms of future business and trade.

title: TRIAL WITNESS CITES SEARCH FOR CURARE
description: HACKENSACK, July 5  A pharmacologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the compound he had developed for detecting curare was accurate, although it had never been used before to seek out curare in embalmed bodies buried for a decade.

title: A Modernist At Home: All Antiques
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. LONG before he became aware of Pablo Picasso, Jacques Lipschitz, Henry Moore and Alexander Calder, Joseph Herman Hirshhorn had an eyea very sharp eye  for antiaue furniture.

title: Jersey Casino Took In $16 Million for June
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 5  Resorts International reported today that its daily take in June from the nation's only legal gambling casino outside Nevada averaged $534,627 and that its gross for the month was $16,038,805.

title: Judge Denies Cianfrani Plea
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (UPI) Judge Edward R. Becker of Federal District Court today denied a request by Henry J. Cianfrani, the former state senator, for a reduction of his fiveyear prison sentence for racketeering and mail fraud. Mr. Cianfrani has been serving two concurrent fiveyear prison terms at the Allenwood Federal Prison, a minimum security facility, since Feb. 20.

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI. Pakistan, July 5 (Reuters)  Pakistan's military leader. Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq, today introduced civilian politicians into his Government for the first time since he seized power a year ago.

title: Strauss Pressing European Nations To Lift Curb on U.S. Farm Imports
description: WASHINGTON. July 5  Robert S. Strauss, the chief trade negotiator for the United States, declared today that the European Economic Community would have to offer more trade concessions to American farmers or the Geneva trade talks would fail.

title: ANOTHER CEASEFIRE COLLAPSES IM BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5  Another overnight truce in the fierce exchanges of fire between Syrian soldiers and Lebanese Christian militia units collapsed today as Lebanese and Syrian leaders held urgent consultations in Damascus to try to end the fighting, now in its fifth day.

title: The Egg and Albert Moore: Flexibility and Maximum Space
description: CORNWALL, CONN. ALBERT B. MOORE is an illustrator and graphic artist by profession, but for quite a while now he has been dismayed by what he feels is this country's reluctance to use new technology in housing construction. Being a highly inventive man, he responded by building a number of experimental structures, and in 1975 he built his first house here, using his own patented system of construction. He calls it the Moore Triangular Mesh Structural Tension System.

title: Singelis Quits Metrocare Post
description: Theodore Singel is, who last week was granted what was termed a temporary leave of absence as president of Metrocare Inc., the Floridabased nursing home and retirement colony operator, has submitted his resignation as a director, the company reported yesterday.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Koch, Carey Visit Amex
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch visited the American Stock Exchange headquarters yesterday, continuing their efforts to prevent the Amex from moving to nearby Connecticut or New Jersey.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Trading was light in the credit markets yesterday, following the long holiday weekend, and prices of corporate and municipal bonds were little changed, traders said, citing slight retail demand for the bonds.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 3 More Companies Cut Copper Prices
description: Three major producers have cut the price on copper cathodes by 2 cents to 63 cents a pound following a similar move last week by the Duval Corporation.

title: Judge Eases Deadline For High School Plan On Balancing Classes
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn has agreed to postpone the deadline he set for the submission of a plan by the Board of Education on the desegregation of Andrew Jackson High School pending the outcome of an appeal.

title: Happiness Is Success Against the Best
description: The hot new jockey drove a babyblue Cadillac, and he lighted a cigarette with a practiced hand as he waited for the bartender to take the order. Any minute now, if the Hollywood stereotype was going to survive, the jockey should be slipping the elastic band off a roll of bills the size of a head of lettuce, waving a tall blonde to the cable and calling for champagne. But Cadillacs and tobacco are about as close as Jeffrey Fell gets to the stereotype of jockeys as swaggering playboys.

title: Legacy of the '78 Supreme Court: Shift on Prosecutors and the Press
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Continuing controversy over the climactic Bakke decision has tended to obscure two major developments of the Supreme Court term that ended this week.

title: Dollar Hits New Low In Japan
description: The United States dollar hit record lows and hovered near the 200yen mark in Tokyo yesterday, and a Japanese market source indicated that the Government seemed prepared to absorb a further decline, according to United Press International.

title: U.S. Plans Exclude Government Owners
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Unlike the British service, the national health insurance plans being examined by the Carter Administration and Congress do not propose government ownership of hospitals, nor would doctors be paid by the Government.

title: High Noon in Judge Griesa's Court
description: The contest between Federal Judge Thomas Griesa and Attorney General Bell over the files of the F.B.I. continues to escalate in ways that threaten both the cause and image of justice. The District Judge has ordered Mr. Bell to give the files of 18 informants to lawyers for the Socialist Workers Party to assist them in a $40million civil suit charging four decades of unlawful disruption of legal political activity. The Attorney General resists, fearing the loss of confidentiality for countless other Government informants.

title: Blind Protesters Gather in Capital To Assail Aviation Rules on Canes
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  More than 1,000 blind people and their supporters demonstrated at the Department of Transportation today, calling for an end to safety regulations requiring them to surrender their canes upon boarding airliners.

title: Hook Named Insurer's Chief
description: Harold Swanson Hook, who was the president of three different life insurance companies before reaching the age of 40, has been named chairman and chief executive of the American General Insurance Company in Houston, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Benjamin N. Woodson, who retired.

title: Chicago Bridge Makes Rowan Offer
description: The Chicago Bridge and Iron Company said it was mailing to shareholders of the Rowan Companies, its offer to purchase shares of Rowan common stock for $24.50 a share. The offer is scheduled to expire on July 27. Chicago Bridge had reduced the purchase price for Rowan shares to $24.50 a share from $26 a share on Monday.

title: Ballet: Copplia Opens Jacob's Pillow Festival
description: BECKET, Mass., July 5  The 46th Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opened last night with a performance of Copplia by the Berkshire Ballet of Pittsfield.

title: Vandalized South Bronx Project Gets New Chance
description: The unfortunate story of South Haven Houses in the South Bronx is headed for a happier turn. But the happier turn will not be too soon.

title: Museum Is Going Way of Horse and Buggy
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Peter Delaney, harness keeper, has celebrated his birthdays at what is now the Carriage Harness Museum since he went to work there in 1910. But the party last week to mark his 105th birthday was the last such celebration at that classic carriage house.

title: Judge in Oklahoma Returns to Shell Oil
description: A Federal judge in Oklahoma who deserted the oil business for the groves of academe and the bench, has decided to retrace some of his steps. District Judge Joseph W. Morris has announced that he will resign Aug. 1 to become vice president and general counsel of the Shell Oil Company.

title: About New York: A Hidden Side of the Bronx
description: As good as the last World Series should have been for the Bronx, it is remembered by the Borough President for the night Howard Cosell kept showing a burning building on television.

title: AIELLO REELECTED TO EDUCATION POST
description: Stephen R. Aiello was reelected president yesterday of the newly appointed Board of Education, whose future as a fulltime, fullsalaried body remains in doubt.

title: Otis Rush Sings Blues at Club
description: OTIS Rush, who's at the Top of the Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, through Sunday night, has not performed in New York since the late 50's, when he was at the Apollo Theater. But his reputation grown through occasional recordings and reports from Chicago, where he lives, and for some time now he has been widely considered the most gifted and original of Chicago's bluesmen.

title: New Firecrackers Maim 6 People;
description: Two powerful new varieties of fireworks  each the equivalent of an eighth of a stick of dynamite and one of which is used by the military in simulated combat  caused the loss of all or parts of fingers or at least sic residents of the New York metropolitan area during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Monmouth Is Attraction For Racing Fans in Area
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 5With Belmont Park dark and with New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation offices accepting bets on the cheaper horses racing at Finger Lakes, hundreds of New York's racing fans visited Monmouth Park today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: European aircraft producers jumped off to a lead in the race for $70 billion in orders for a new generation of mediumsized airliners. Swissair and Lufthansa signed preliminary contracts to buy a scaleddown version of the Airbus A300 manufactured by a fournation European consortium. Total value of the initial orders, including spare parts, was put at $467 million. The agreement accelerated the timetable for producing the new Airbus, giving Europe an early edge over American aircraft manufacturers. [Page A1.]

title: TRANSIT EMPLOYEES VOTE NEW CONTRACT
description: By a margin of less than 1,000 votes, members of the Transport Workers Union accepted a new contract yesterday with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The vote on the contract  first signed in April, with the threat of a transit strike loomingwas 12,489 to 11,; 509.

title: Brazilian Inflation Drops
description: BRASILIA, July 7 (UPI)  Brazilian inflation for the first half of 1978 totaled 21.2 percent, 1.3 percentage points below the inflation rate for the first half of 1977, the Finance Ministry announced today. Officials had expected a decrease in the rate for the second quarter, but said they did not expect to make much progress in the accumulated index for July, August and September, months in which inflation was low last year.

title: WALTER E. BRANDT
description: Walter E. Brandt, for 25 years power chief engineer at the Empire State Building, died Tuesday at Suncoast Hospital in Largo, Fla., after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Seminole, Fla.

title: Visa Planning to Enter Travelers Check Market
description: Visa announced yesterday that it was planning to enter the travelers check business, becoming the second of the nation's two major bank credit card systems to attempt an invasion of the lucrative territory long dominated by the American Express Company.

title: Taiwan Rejects Israeli Plane Offer
description: WASIIINGTON, July 6 (AP)  Taiwan today rejected a proposal that it purchase Kfir fighter planes from Israel, but American officials said the decision would not greatly intensify pressure on President Carter to decide what planes and how many the United States will sell to Taiwan.

title: A.&P.: Troubles and High Share Trading
description: At the baked goods counter in a Manhattan A.& P. store, Dee Alexander crossed her arms and leaned against her shopping cart.

title: Executives' Confidence Up
description: Business executives in toplevel positions have grown more confident about the economy since the first of the year, according to the Conference Board's measure of confidence.

title: Mets Subdue ErrorPlagued Cubs, 96
description: The Mets and the Chicago Cubs, miles apart in the National League East race, played similarly erratic baseball last night at Shea Stadium. If you weren't a purist, it made for an exciting game.

title: Kaufman & Broad Told To Repair Home Defects
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI)  The Government today ordered one of the nation's biggest homebuilders to repair possibly thousands of defective houses and tell prospective buyers the truth about community facilities, taxes and other items.

title: E.P.A. Says Nuclear Power Plant Has Not Assured Marine Safety
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., July 6 (AP) The prime builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant has failed to prove that warm water from the plant will not harm marine life off New Hampshire's coast. according to testimony from the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Up from History's Dustbin
description: Respected Comrade Berlinguer, I am writing this letter to you on the eve of the 40th anniversary of the tragic death of my father, Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin. At that time I was only two years old and naturally was unable to remember my father. But my mother, who had spent many years in Stalin's prisons and camps,

title: Carrier Price Up 4% On AirConditioning
description: The Carrier Corporation, a leader in the airconditioning industry, announced price increases yesterday of 4 to 6 percent on airconditioning equipment. The increases, effective Aug. 23. will apply to equipment sold under the Carrier Bryant Day and Night and Payne brand names.

title: Amex Oil And Gas Issues Gain
description: Selected oil and gas stocks, partly reflecting steppedup activity in the West Pembina area of the province of Alberta, posted the sharpest group gains yesterday in Wall Street. These issues, trading on the American Stock Exchange, were standouts in a market that as a whole showed no definite trend.

title: Congress's O'Neill and Byrd: Two Leaders, Two Styles
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., envelops issues, Congressmen and even Presidents in an irresistible bear hug. Robert C. Byrd treads more gingerly, as wary of a precedent as of a President.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Dow Denies Dumping a Chemical That Could Cause Birth Defects
description: LANSING, Mich., July 6 (AP)  A spokesman for the Dow Chemical Company has denied that the company is responsible for discharging into two rivers a chemical that state officials say is one of the most poisonous substances known.

title: U.S. Affirms 2Way Investigations of Companies
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 In a significant victory for the Securities and Ex, change Commission, a Federal district court has reaffirmed the agency's authority to conduct an independent investigation of a company, even if that company is also being investigated by the Justice Department.

title: Europe's Airbus Makers Win Lead In Race to Sell MediumSize Planes
description: Europe's airliner manufacturers jumped off to a lead yesterday in the race for orders for $70 billion worth of newgeneration middlesize planes expected to be sold between now and 1990.

title: PrivateHospitals Strike Averted
description: A strike against 61 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes serving 20,000 patients in the New York metropolitan area was averted last night when the union and managements accepted the recommendations of a Federal factfinder. The strike was to have started at 6 A. M. today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar moved higher on the world's foreignexchange markets yesterday as traders nervously waited to see if any substantive economic news would come out of the ninenation Common Market economicmeeting in West Germany, The Associated Press reported.

title: Eight Doors to the Past
description: Somewhat like the fictional village of Glocca Norm in Finian's Rainbow, the historic village of Hurley in Ulster County, a twohour drive from New York City, returns to its past one day a year this year it's tomorrow.

title: Otis Rush: A Blues Event of the Year
description: The sign on the street in front of the Top of the Gate. Bleecker and Thompson Streets, simply said Otis Rush Blues Band. and there had been little advance notice in the media that something out of the ordinary was going on. But on Mr. Rush's opening night on Tuesday, the Top of the Gate was packed.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Singers wanted, no experience necessary. That's what Grace Church, Broadway at East 10th Street, is looking for tonight at 7. The church is having another of its Summer Sings choral readings open to anyone who likes to sing. Tonight's work is Bach's Christmas Oratorio. Admission is $2.50. You will be given a copy of the oratorio and shown to your place in choir stalls. There will be a break for refreshments. The next evening in the series is July 21, with works by Haydn and Bach. Information: AL 42000.

title: REJECTION BY ISRAEL OF SADAT PLAN SEEN
description: JERUSALEM, July 6  Israel indicated today that it would formally reject Egypt's new peace plan when the Cabinet met on Sunday. But the Cabinet is expected to authorize Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan to participate at a meeting in London this month with Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel of Egypt and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Europe's Airbus Makers Win Lead In Race to Sell MediumSize Planes
description: Europe's airliner manufacturers jumped off to a lead yesterday in the race for orders for $70 billion worth of newgeneration middlesize planes expected to be sold between now and 1990.

title: Notes on People
description: Over the vociferous protests of the Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of Northern Ireland's Protestant extremists, Roman Catholic mass was said yesterday in the crypt chapel of the House of Commons in London for the first time since the 16thcentury Reformation. The mass was celebrated by Basil Car dinal Hume, Archbishop of Westminster and a leader of English and Welsh Roman Catholics. in memory of St. Thomas More, beheaded on orders by King Henry VIII on July 6, 1535. But Mr. Paisley, who stood with fellow Members of Parliament, said: Before this service proceeds I want to make a solemn protest. You cannot reverse 400 years of history in this service today. He was interrupted by shouts of get out and rubbish after he called the mass a blasphemous fable and a dangerous conceit. Another Protestant Member of Parliament from Northern Ireland also protested, but two others. George Thomas, Speaker of the House of Commons, and Lord ElwynJones. Lord Chancellor, read the lessons of the mass. Cardinal Hume said that he was not at all distressed by Reverend Paisley's actions.

title: Schlitz's Man from CocaCola
description: How do you go after Budweiser in the beer business? You might try hiring a CocaCola man. That's what the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company did recently in its battle to regain second place among the nation's biggest beer companies, behind AnheuserBusch, the maker of Budweiser. It had been edged out by the Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris & Company.

title: Advertising
description: THE Axiom Market Research Bureau and W.R. Simmons & Associates Research, the two important services in syndicated magazine audience research  a field that apparently can't afford two  are merging to form the Simmons Market Research Bureau. It will be a joint venture, with the majority interest held by the Simmons management, which will continue to manage, supplying two people to the threeman board. Axiom, which produces Target Group Index, is a subsidiary of the J. Walter Thompson Company and has not turned a profit since it began here in 1972, according to Don Johnston, chairman of Thompson.

title: Art People
description: FIRMLY ensconced in its quartets on Schermerhor Row, the burgeoning New York State Maritime Museum will officially announce its presence in this city next Wednesday with the opening of a show. uildina the Waterfront: The Genesis of the Schermerhorn Row Block. The small storefront exhibition at 16 Fulton Street, says the museum's director, H. Claude Shostal, is done by a young staff to tell the public what we are and what we're up to.

title: Upstate judge Orders Berkowitz Committed to Psychiatric Center
description: David R. Berkowitz, the convicted 44caliber killer, was declared insane yesterday by a Clinton County Surrogate in Plattsburgh, N.Y who ordered him transferred from the jurisdiction of the state's Department of Correctional Services to that of the Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Ghana 's New Military Chief Frees Political Prisoners Held 3 Months
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 6 (Reuters) Ghana's new military ruler, Lieut. Gen. Fred W. K. Akuffo, released opposition political figures today who had been detained in March after a closely contested referendum on the country's political future.

title: No Plowshares Yet From the U.N.
description: Not a single weapon will be scrapped as a result the first special session on disarmament of the United Nations General Assembly, which ended last week. Nor will any weapons order be canceled. The only product of five weeks of talk was a set of guidelines for more talk and study. Diplomats and academic junketeers have insured themselves against layoffs for years to come, and the American and Soviet Governments have again shown how well they can cooperate at the barricades behind which they arm in the name of peace. It would be wrong, however, to dismiss the special session as a mere boondoggle.

title: Times Is Rejected on Its Appeal in CurareData Case
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal of lowercourt order requiring The New York Times and one of its reporters, M. A. Farber, to surrender all notebooks, statements, recordings and other news information gathered in the investigation of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, who is now on trial accused of murdering five hospital patients.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An electrician pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he participated in a scheme to kick back a percentage of his fee to members of the Lodi Housing Authority, which approved his contract for work on a lowincome housing project.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Gov. Brown, Citing Proposition 13, Cuts $388.5 Million From Budget
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 Explaining that he was motivated by Proposition 13's changes in government financing in California, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. trimmed $388.5 million today from the state budget.

title: Japan and Soviet, Despite Tension, See Booming Trade
description: TOKYO. July6 At the Foreign Ministry here, a special room on the sixth floor is reserved for receiving Soviet diplomats.

title: Phyllis Newman on L.I.
description: Phyllis Newman, actress and singer, Brooks Kerr, pianist, and Sonny Geer, drummer, will give a benefit performance Sunday night at 8 for the Guild Hall, the arts center at 158 Main Street in East Hampton, L.I., in the hall's John Drew Theater. Tickets are $10 and $15.

title: Market Place
description: IS Houdaille Industries, a miniconglomerate making auto bumpers, construction materials, pumps and machine tools, a takeover candidate? Action in the shares of this highly regarded industrial corporation suggests it may be. In March the shares advanced from 16 to 18 and in April they reached 22.

title: Deaths
description: AGULNEKHarry. Beloved husband of Sarah devoted father of Alvin, Dr. Milton and Dr. Robert, dear brother of Saul, loving grandfather. Services Friday 1:30PM at Gutterman's Lincoln Square Chapels Sway at 66th St., NYC

title: Hungary Reaches Westward
description: CHILMARK, Mass.Janos Kadar, whom the Russians installed in power in Hungary nearly 22 years ago and who has held that power longer than any other leader of a Warsaw Pact state, is the pragmatist supreme among Sovietdominated Communist rulers  and unquestionably the most successful of them.

title: Road to Wimbledon Titles
description: The Philadelphia Flyers yesterday named Bob McCammon, 37yearold coach of the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League, successor to Fred Shero, who left his job as head coach of the Flyers May 18 to become coach and general manager of the New York Rangers. The Mariners, Philadelphia's farm club, were A.H.L. champions last season. . . . Jude Drouin received notice from Bill Torrey, general manager of the New York Islanders, that the club would not be offering him a contract for next season. The Islanders thereby relinquished their right to compensation for Drouin, should the free agent sign with another club. Drouin was with the Islanders for 31/2 seasons.... Bob Plager, a former St. Louis player, has been named specialassignment scout for the Blues. Plager retired last season but was reactivated briefly and then sent to Salt Lake City to coach the Blues farm club.... He's a guy with no brains who makes up the rules as he goes along, said Earl Weaver, the Baltimore Orioles manager, after Umpire Marty Springstead ejected him from a game Wednesday night,reigniting an old feud. I don't care, Springstead said in response to Weaver's remarks. He's no Marilyn Monroe. Do you think I want to look at that midget every day? Twice last season Weaver and Springstead were involved in disputes. The latest ejection was Weaver's 60th in 10 seasons as a major legue manager and it was the sixth time Springstead had banished him.

title: Factory Life: In a FastChanging World, 0llie's a Constant
description: Two things have remained constant at Angler's Company Ltd. since it was founded in 1995 to manufacture fishermen's pouches. One is a product called Cuffettes, a pair of plastic cuffs worn by typists to protect blouse sleeves from ribbon ink and general office grime; it is an early Angler's invention that still sells well. The other is Olive Hitlin.

title: Dashboard Symbols Will Help U.S. Drivers
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Starting with 1981 models, the dashboards of American cars will be dotted with drawings of tiny oil cans, gas pumps, thermometers and other symbols intended to help the driver push the right button.

title: Broncos File Suit
description: DENVER, July 6 (UPI) The owners of the Denver Broncos filed suit in Unioted States District Court today to prevent Crush International Inc., from licensing orange crush items that are associated with the professional football team. The reason for the suit is to determine ownership so we can then clean up the market, an attorney for the Broncos said. The dispute between us and Crush International who owns t he t rademark.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WKCR. Erwartung; Variations for Orchestra; Kol Nidre; Chamber Symphony No. 2. Schoenberg.

title: Broadway
description: DOROTHY LOUDON will star in Michael Bennett's new musical, which is still untitled, but which Mr. Bennett and his colleagues always refer to as Ballroom. is based on the television play Queen of the Stardust Ballroom, and Mr. Bennett has already worked on it for months in his studios downtown. Ballroom goes into workshop performances at Joseph Papp's Public Theater on July 24, and by then it is expected that Vincent Gardenia will be in the cast opposite Miss Loudon. It is not certain, although it is at least likely, that after the Public Theater, Ballroom will go to the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn. Then it will open on Broadway, probably at the Majestic.

title: Girls Found Stabbed To Death in Norwalk Tied to Prostitution
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 6  One of the two young women found stabbed to death in Norwalk on July 4 was facing charges of prostitution in Stamford, according to the local State's Attorney's Office, and the other had supported herself through prostitution since last September, according to a former foster mother.

title: Honey Fed to Infants May Cause Botulism, Linked to Crib Death
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 6 (UPI) Honey and other raw agricultural products fed to infants less than a year old may produce botulism poisoning, suspected cause of some unexplained infant crib deaths, the world's largest honeyproducing cooperative said in statement issued yesterday.

title: Happiness Is a Fast Horse
description: Sports of The Times

title: Stein Aids Krupsak Drive
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan is playing an important role in helping Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak organize a governorship nomination campaign that has so far been in disarray.

title: U.S. Scientists Arrive in Peking
description: HONG KONG, July 6 (Reuters)  A 14member American scientific delegation led by Frank Press, director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, arrived in Peking today for an official visit, the official press agency Hsinhua reported. The delegation was greeted at the airport by Chiang Nanhsiang, Deputy Minister of the Chinese Scientific and Technological Commission; Chou Peiyuan, Vice President of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and Leonard Woodcock, the chief American liaison officer in China.

title: REJECTION BY ISRAEL OF SADAT PLAN SEEN
description: JERUSALEM, July 6  Israel indicated today that it would formally reject Egypt's new peace plan when the Cabinet met on Sunday. But the Cabinet is expected to authorize Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan to participate at a meeting in London this month with Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel of Egypt and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: ISRAELI PLANES BUZZ BEIRUT IN WARNING TO SYRIA ON ATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6  Israel sent fighter planes low over Beirut today to underline warnings to Syria to end its shelling of Christian sectors in the Lebanese capital.

title: Avenue of Americas And Broadway to Get A Special Bike Lane
description: Special fourfootwide lanes for bicycles will open next Wednesday along Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan.

title: Kreisky Holds an Urgent Meeting Over Blockade by Truck Drivers
description: VIENNA, July 6 (Reuters)  Chancellor Bruno Kreisky called business leaders to his office for an urgent meeting today in an attempt to end a fourday trade blockade by truck drivers that is threatening Austria's economy.

title: Deaths
description: HALLERWilliam Paul an July 6. 1978 of Garden City. husband of the late Helen Oements, deer brother of Frederick J. Also survived by 11 nieces & nephews. Friends may call at the Fairchild Chapel Franklin Ave at 12th Street Garden City. Saturday & Sunday 25PM. Servka at The Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, Monday 10:3tIAJA. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. In li?? of flowers. contributions to The Cathedral Memorial & Endowment Fund would be appreciated.

title: TRANSIT EMPLOYEES VOTE NEW CONTRACT
description: By a margin of less than 1,000 votes, members of the Transport Workers Union accepted a new contract yesterday with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The vote on the contract  first signed in April, with the threat of a transit strike looming  was 12,489 to 11509.

title: C.H. Calhoun, ExCorrespondent
description: Crede H. Calhoun, a former New York Times correspsndent in Latin America, died in Panama City yesterday after suftering a heart aftacL He was 83 years old.

title: Irish Music to Fill The Air at South St.
description: An evening of Irish music will be presented by Rakish Paddy, four musicians and singers, tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at Pier 15 of the South Street Seaport Museum, South Street near John Street on the East River.

title: DEMOCRATIC RIVALS ATTACK EACH OTHER
description: Governor Carey and his Lieutenant Governorturnedopponent, Mary Anne Krupsak, hurled political attacks at each other across Manhattan yesterday on the issues of the Westway, care of the mentally ill and other aspects of their administration's record.

title: A DaytoDay Menu That Plays the Losing Combinations
description: The Scarsdale Diet, as devised by Dr. Herman Tarnower of the Scarsdale Medical Group, is based on chemical reactions between foods rather than quantities of foods. It is said to maintain normal energy levels while resulting in weight losses of up to 20 pounds in 14 days. The diet is not recommended for cardiac patients and no one should stay on it for more than 14 days at a time.

title: Court Appoints Manager to Run Affairs of Islanders
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 6  State Supreme Court Justice Douglas F. Young today appointed John 0. Pickett Jr. of Upper Brookville, L.I., as manager to conduct the affairs of the New York Islanders of the National Hockey League during the litigation between Thomas J. Thornton and Roy Boe, the president of the team.

title: Frankle Valli at Wollman
description: THE opening concert of the popmusic series at the Wollman Rink in Central Park has traditionally been something far more conservative than the youthoriented fare that normally dominates the series; so adultpoppish, in fact, that Wednesday's opening was the first that this writer can recall attending.

title: Events
description: THE DISPOSAL by William Inge, directed by Ann Raychel, presented by Maria Norman and Duo Theater. At INTA R, 420 West 43d Street, at 8.

title: FrenchGerman Money Plan Is Debated
description: BREMEN, West Germany, July 6 A major quarrel was brewing here tonight among Western European leaders over a FrenchWest German plan to create a zone of monetary stability in Western Europe early next year.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP)  A Federal judge ordered state education officials today to set aside $14.4 million from Ohio school transportation funds to pay for busing in a Cleveland school desegregation plan in September.

title: Center in Hawaii Feels Out Distant Quakes at Sea
description: HONOLULU, July 1  On June 12, at 10:06 P.M. Hawaiian time, sudden slippage beneath the Pacific floor 60 miles east of the Japanese city of Sendai in Japan sent tremors around the world. Buildings in Sendai collapsed, killing 21 persons and injuring 350. Subways in Tokyo screeched to a halt.

title: Carter Aides Oppose House Bill Providing a Rise in Road Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Robert S. Strauss, a top Presidential adviser, today called on transportation and highway industry groups at a White House meeting to reduce their demands for Federal aid, thus lessening the inflationary impact of a transportation bill now before the House.

title: Mozart al Fresco by the River
description: A Mozart piano concerto is scheduled and a gorgeous red sunset is hoped for tomorrow night at the eighth annual Music by the Hudson summer festival at Lyndhurst, the former 19thcentury estate in Tarrytown.

title: Shearson Settles in Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Shearon Hayden Stone Inc. and three of its employees of securities fraud for what it called excessive and unsuitable transactions in customer options accounts from Oct. 1, 1973, to July 1975.

title: Deaths
description: COHENAlfred E. Beloved uncle of Estelle R. Green & Mark D. Rothenberg & greatuncle of Peter, Roni & Sara. Service Friday, July 7. 9:45am. The Riverside 76 St & Amsterdam Av.

title: Braves Fall To Dodgers In 11th, 51
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP)  Dave Lopes blasted a grandslam home run in the bottom of the 11th inning today to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 51 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: S.E.0 Asks More Data Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved, as expected, a set of proposals that voald require companies to disclose more information atmt how they are governed.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1978

title: Court Upholds C.A.B. Action
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The United States Court of Appeals here denied today a petition by Delta Air Lines to overthrow the award of new routes to Hughes Air West, Frontier Airlines and Southern Airways.

title: Auctions
description: BEGINNING tomorrow and throughout most of next week. auction buffs will be busy in New England attending house sales, bidding for decoys or buying Oriental rugs. Country auctions are held, of course. throughout the year. But the pace quickens considerably in July and August, when collectors and dealers have more time to investigate the wares. What follows are highlights of the week ahead.

title: Burger Debates in a Bookstore
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger just wanted to buy some paperbacks. Audrey Hair wanted to discuss the Bakke case. She said that the Supreme Court ruling was sure to make it harder fot her to get into law school.

title: Appeal by Times in CurareData Case Is Rejected
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal of a lowercourt order requiring The New York Times and one of its reporters, M. A. Farber, to surrender all notebooks. statements, recordings and other news information gathered in the investigation of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, who is now on trial accused of murdering five hospital patients.

title: Art: Graphics in Brooklyn
description: DESPITE its somewhat Easten European ring Graphicstudio U.S.F. is the name of the workshop in which a wholly American experiment in printing flourished from 1968 to 1975 at the University of South Florida in Tampa. It also is the title of a show at the Brooklyn Museum that commemorates the experiment with 190 works by more than 20 artists and a fully illustrated catalogue (through July 16).

title: Judge Upholds F.B.I. Raids on Scientology Church
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP)  The Government won a major victory in its battle with the Church of Scientology when a judge ruled yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's seizure of thousands of church documents was legal.

title: Factory Life: In a FastChanging World, Ollie's a Constant
description: Two things have remained constant at Angler's Company Ltd. since it was founded in 1945 to manufacture fishermen's pouches. One is a product called Cuffettes, a pair of plastic cuffs worn by typists to protect blouse sleeves from ribbon ink and general office grime; it is an early Angler's invention that still sells well. The other is Olive Hitlin.

title: Politics And the E.R.A.
description: In 1976, Jim McDuffie won one of the four seats from North Carolina's 22d State Senate District, finishing third in an atlarge race, just a thousand votes behind the leader. But when Senator McDuffie sought reelection last May, he came in fifth, 4,000 votes behind the top man, and lost his seat.

title: Borrowing Is Off at Banks Here
description: Business loans at New York City banks declined $150 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday, but credit analysts were quick to point out that despite the flatness in borrowings here, demand for shortterm credit nationally is likely to continue strong.

title: N.E.A. Stands Firm on Its Quota System
description: DALLAS, July 6 While the rest of the country was busy analyzing the nuances of the recent Supreme Court decisions on affirmative action, the National Education Association met here this week for its annual convention with stringent requirements  some called them quotas for minority representation.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.( A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Van Ingen, Smith Take Medal in Anderson Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 6  Two lateafternoon finishers, Peter Van Ingen and Steve Smith of Meadowbrook, fired a betterball 65, six under par, to win the medal in the John. G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament today

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 6  Governor Byrne signed into law today a bill creating a separate office of administrative law in the Department of State.

title: Barbarct Cushing Paley Dies at 63; Style PaceSetter in Three Decades
description: Barbara Cushing Paley, the wife of William S. Paley, the chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of cancer at their apartment in New York City yesterday after a long illness. She was 63 years old.

title: Resorts, Athena in Stock Deal
description: Athena Communications Corporation has jumped into the action of Resorts International Inc. in a big way. Yesterday, the two companies announced that Athena had agreed to turn in its warrants to buy 463,439 shares of Resorts Class A common stock at $38.84 a share, to get in return, a total of 255,000 of these shares at no cost.

title: Kaiser Unit In Offer for Oil Concern
description: Kaiser Resources Ltd., a leading Canadian coal mining company, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to buy an 83 percent stake in Ashland Oil Canada Ltd. for about $23.97 a share, or about $318 million, in cash. The shares are owned by Ashland Oil Inc. of Ashland, Ky.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver futures moved down sharply yesterday on the Comex here, influenced by traders' surprise at the lack of interest shown by bidders at the International Monetary Fund gold auction Wednesday and the dollar's relative strength on foreignexchange markets.

title: British Chief Rabbi Assails Israel For Hard Line on Mideast Peace
description: LONDON, July 6  Dr. Immanuel Jakobovits, Chief Rabbi of Britain and the Commonwealth, spoke out strongly today against what he called the intransigent stance of Israeli political leaders and religious elements on the issues involved in negotiating a peace accord with the Arabs.

title: Canada, Safeguarding Its Wildlife, Curbs Hunt for Minerals in Yukon
description: OTTAWA. July 6  To protect roving caribou herds and other wildlife, the Canadian Government today prohibited further exploration for oil, gas and other resources in a 15,000squaremile wilderness area making up approximately the northern third of the Yukon Territory.

title: Fans Camping At Gate for Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6Three years ago, they began queueing for the men's singles final on a Thursday. Last year, they arrived on Wednesday. This year, Steve Usher, Doug Rouse and Harry Helps began unpacking their bags in front of the gates of the All England Lawn Tennis Club on Tuesday night.

title: A Grasso Appointee Unable to Take Post
description: HARTFORD, July 6 (UPI)  Gov. Ella T. Grasso this week announced the appointment of a dead man to a nonsalaried post.

title: Beame's Gracie Mansion Tenancy Put $30,000 Extra on His Pension
description: Grade Mansion is not only a nice place to live, for the Mayor of New York City; it also helps increase his pension after he retires.

title: The Pop Life
description: BOB DYLAN and Neil Young both have new records out (actually Mr. Young. whose records arc never out on schedule as a matter of policy, has delayed his another week) and that double arrival must tempt any rock critic into beardpulling profundity. This beardless critic will try for a more straightforward approach. Neither Mr. Dylan's StreetLegal nor Mr. Young's Comes a Time is likely to rank among either man's greatest albums. But both provide a good deal of pleasure, nonetheless.

title: Stein Taking an Important Role In Assisting Krupsak Campaign
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan is playing an important role in helping Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak organize a governorship nomination campaign that has so far been in disarray.

title: Administration Expects Economy to Lag in 1979
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Faced with a 6.9 percent rate of inflation this year, higher than it had expected, the Carter Administration disclosed today that it was planning for slower economic growth and only a very small improvement in unemployment in 1979.

title: Javits Criticizes Sadat Proposal, Calling It Unimaginative Rehash
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits criticized the new Egyptian proposal for an interim Middle East peace accord today, calling it an unimaginative and disappointing rehash of previous Arab positions.

title: W.H.A. Expects Aeros to Fold
description: The World Hockey Association concluded its annual meetings here yesterday without making an official announcement of the fate of the Houston franchise, but Howard Baldwin, the league president, said,'It seems unlikely that the Houston Aeros will continue to operate in the W.H.A.

title: Berliners Make First Dance Visit
description: If dancers talked their way through ballets. tonight's performance of Giselle by the Berlin Opera Ballet would resemble a Romanticperiod version of the legend of Babel. The mad young maiden of the title will be danced by Eva Evdokimova, a Swiss ballerina dancing her first New York Giselle. Her princely suitor, Albrecht, will be danced by Vladimir Gelvan, a Latvian, and the Russian dancer Valery Panov will be seen as his peasant counterpart.

title: Five Bludgeoned in Central Park By Roving Gang Carrying Clubs
description: A gang of young men wielding baseball bats and tree branches ran through the Central Park Ramble Wednesday night, attacking strollers and joggers.

title: Stage: Pins and Needles
description: IT was a surprise to all concerned, not least the authors, when the modest musical revue Pins and Needles. produced under the auspices of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. became a runaway success on Broadway and all over the country.

title: Manhattan in Paris? La Dfense Complex Is Under Siege
description: PARIS, July 6  From his office on the 36th floor of a smokedglass tower building, PierreLouis Filippi has one of the grandest views of Paris.

title: Rock: The Little River Band
description: The Little River Band, which was at the Bottom Line for a onenight showcase on Wednesday and will open for Jimmy Buffett at Belmont Park on July 15, is the sort of group in which every single element sounds derivative, yet which manages to make a pleasing impression nonetheless.

title: Experts on Justice Are Debating Treatment of Youthful Offenders
description: Shortly after Governor Carey saw A news story reporting that a 15yearold boy who had been convicted of two murders on New York subway trains had been sentenced to a fiveyear term  the maximum permitted under the state's juvenile justice laws  he announced that he would soon propose legislation enabling the state to deal much more severely with similar of fenders and offenses.

title: Toxicologist Tells of Evidence of Curare in 3 Bodies
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 6  Drawing on a large sheet of paper tacked to an easel at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a toxicologist today traced the sharp distinctive peaks that he said had registered on his analytical apparatus when he tested for curare in the bodies of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: Economic Scene
description: AS worry increases in political and economic circles over the likely longevity of the current expansion, which is now in its 40th month, analysts are looking for telltale signs of trouble  and are beginning to detect a number of reasons for worry.

title: I New York Campaign Going National
description: It's an innocuous little phrase. But when Frank Langella, Broadway's Dracula, aimed those piercing eyes at the camera on Valentine's Day and said, I love New York, swirled his cape and added, especially in the eeeevening, people from all over the country began clamoring for a weekend of Big Apple nightlife.

title: Books: A Dick Francis Whodunit
description: ACCOUNTANCY and amateur steeplechase riding would appear to be an odd combination of trades for the hero of a suspense novel. But it is a combination that works well in Dick Francis's new whodunit, Risk, as smooth a thriller, if somewhat lightweight, as is likely to turn up this season.

title: L.I.R.R. Line Halted for 2 Hours
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 6 (UPI)  Equipment trouble shut down the Long Island Rail Road's Port Washington line for nearly two hours at 8:30 o'clock this morning, delaying an estimated total of 2,000 passengers, when the trouble stalled the 7:53 A.M. train from New York west of Manhasset, L.I.

title: West Germans Say New Nazi Case Raises Question About Democracy
description: BONN, July 6  At a time when West Germany is preparing for the visit of President Carter next week and a highlevel economic meeting of the major Western nations July 16 and 17, a case from the Nazi past is again calling the credibility of West German democracy into question.

title: Yanks, Behind Tidrow, Defeat the Rangers, 72
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 6  Reggie Jackson, made out by some people to be the skeleton in the Yankee closet. emerged from involuntary seclusion tonight and returned to the lineup against the Texas Rangers.

title: They Campaign in Manhattan
description: Governor Carey and his Lit utenant Governorturnedopponent, Mary Anne Krupsak, hurled political attacks at each other across Manhattan yesterday on the issues of the Westway, care of the mentally ill and other aspects of their administration's record.

title: Five Bludgeoned in Central Park By Roving Gang Carrying Clubs
description: A gang of young men wielding baseball bats and tree branches ran through the Central Park Ramble Wednesday night, attacking strollers and joggers.

title: Proxmire Assails Navy On Aid to Shipbuilders
description: WASHINGTON, Iuly 6 (UPI) Hie Navy is attempting to bail out two large shipbuilders, senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today.

title: Topics
description: Raised Canes

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1978

title: Bridge:
description: The Big Apple Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, beginning today at the Statler Hilton Hotel, will have more of an international flavor than usual. Several foreign players who competed in the World Olympiad in New Orleans last week have made plans to be here, including the Philippines women's team that represented the Far East in the Venice Trophy matches.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Judge Finds Bell in Contempt In Informer Case
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell was held in contempt of court yesterday for refusing to release the files on 18 informers who spied on the Socialist Workers Party for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Confusion and a 10Year Task
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 When the drafters of the 1969 Coal Mine Health and Safety Act were told nearly a decade ago that an Auer breather was available to provide coal miners with a closedcircuit oxygen recue apparatus in case of fire, they heard it as hour breather.

title: New York Campaign Going National
description: It's an innocuous little phrase. But when Frank Langella, Broadway's Dracula, aimed those piercing eyes at the camera on Valentine's Day and said, I love New York, swirled his cape and added, especially in the eeeevening, people from all over the country began clamoring for a weekend of Big Apple nightlife.

title: Five Perish as Flash Floods Hit Rochester, Minn.
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., July 6 (UPI)  Seven inches of rain sent flash floods rolling through homes and businesses today, killing elderly patients trapped in a flooded elevator in a nursing home and sweeping cars from the roads. More than 4,000 people fled their homes, and hundreds of houses were reported destroyed.

title: 18YearOld Vote Gains in Spain
description: MADRID, July 6 (Reuters)  The lower house of Parliament approved proposed legislation today giving Spaniards the right to vote at the age of 18, instead of 21. The Senate must approve the proposal before it is presented to the people in a referendum.

title: Jonathan Schwartz, the Singer
description: FOR his debut as a cabaret singer at Michael's Pub, Jonathan Schwartz, who is best known as a Sunday morning disc jockey on WNEWAM, is drawing on a rich and very logical repertory the songs of his father. Arthur Schwartz, who, with Howard Dietz as lyricist, was one of the major contributors to that golden age of the musical theater in the 1930's and in the postwar years.

title: Guards Stay Off Jobs At Tennessee Prison
description: NASHVILLE, July 6 (UPI)Guards dissatisfied with wage proposals stayed off their jobs today at the Tennessee State Prison, but supervisors, teachers and counselors stepped in and assumed their duties.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN the Labor Party first emerged in England in 1906 as a political power, it was said, according to Quentin Bell, that the book which had exerted the greatest influence on the members of this young party was Unto

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: REGINALD P. ROSE

title: A History of Ups, Downs
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6  Kaufman & Broad Inc., America's largest multinational home builder, said it was unaware of any problems with the 20,000 homes it had built from 1972 to 1976. This is an old issue, a spokesman said. There are no problems that we know of that have not been resolved.'

title: Utility Settles a Suit for $20,000
description: NEWARK, July 6The Public Service Electric and Gas Company agreed today to pay $20,000 to a former employee who charged that she had been denied promotion and then dismissed because she had resisted the sexual advances of her superior.

title: BOSTON COMMUTERS STRANDED BY STRIKE
description: BOSTON, July 6 (AP)  About 1,300 bus and trolley drivers voted to return to work tomorrow morning, ending a oneday walkout that crippled Boston's transit system.

title: Skipper Wins Pace Series First Event
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 6  Rambling Willie was the main focus of interest at the Meadowlands tonight as six outstanding freeforall performers awaited the start of the first leg of the American Pacing Championship. The question was whether the rambunctious Rambling Willie would continue on his way to become the harness sport's top moneywinner at his gait.

title: Again, the Spell Of Tanglewood
description: TANGLEWOOD! What a host of fancies, memories, associations and anticipations the word conjures up. For thousands of musicians some well into middle age by nowit is the place where, suddenly, one summer, they changed from gauche, selfconscious students into incipient professionals, wiser in the ways of the music world than they had ever thought they'd be, touched in some ineluctable way by the Tanglewood mystique.

title: Deaths
description: POTTERSHarold A. Beloved husbend of Beetryce. Devoted father of Michael end Donald. Dear brother of David. Loving grandfather. Services today. 12 noon. BouleverdParh Wear 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: 2 DERELICTS SLAIN IN A BROOKLYN LOT
description: Two 57yearold men described by the police as apparent derelicts were found hacked to death in a junkstrewn lot near the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday.

title: Car Sales In June At Record
description: DETROIT, July 6  Domestic car sales in June hit a record 949,849 units, despite a slowdown in the selling pace for the last 10 days of the month, the four major American auto makers reported today. The June totals thus lifted sales for the first half of 1978 to the highest level since the 1974 oil crisis and second only to the pace set in the first half of 1973.

title: Italy Repays Loan Early
description: BONN, July 6 (Reuters) The Bank of Italy has repaid in advance about S1 billion remaining from the $2 billion borrowed from West Germany in comber 1976, a Government spokesman said yesterday. The Spokesman said the West German Government welcomed the repayment, which had not been due until September, as proof that Italy's balance of payments had been developing favorably.

title: About Real Estate
description: MONMOUTH BEACH. N.J.  Rare is the condominium buyer with the patience of Jacob Greenman. It usually takes five years for a condominium this size to sell out, he said.
