His philosophical attitude explains the equanimity with which he has lived with a handful of other buyers since mid1976 in an oceanside highrise condominium called  when he bought  the Shores at Monmouth Beach.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Back in 1958, the Maryknoll order of Roman Catholic missionaries sent a young veteran of several years in Latin America, the Rev. Joseph Michenfelder, to the Columbia School of Journalism to learn more about communications. Father Michenfelder then opened an information bureau for his order in Lima, Peru.

title: CARTER MAKES PLEA FOR PEACE IN BEIRUT
description: WASHINGTON. July 6  President Carter appealed today to all parties with influence over the situation to try w end the fighting in Lebanon immediately and to exert themselves to restore stability and peace to that battered Middle Eastern country.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Citicorp plans to offer a 20year, 5250 million issue in notes during the week of July 24 with a floating interest rate tied to that of sixmonth Treasury bills. Citicorp, the holding company for Citibank, and the First Boston Corporation, the lead underwriter of the issue, announced the plan yesterday.

title: Faces of Love, A Swiss Film
description: IF ONE movie can ever be considered less essential than another, then Faces of Love, a serenely windy, emptyheaded movie about art, love, death and table manners, is probably the least essential film you're likely to come upon this summer. It adds less to one's sum total of experience than, say, Jaws 2, which at . least teaches one about the care and operation of plastic sharks.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 4 Makeup Days Denied To Meadowlands Track
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 6  The New Jersey State Racing Commission today denied Meadowlands Race Track's request for four makeup days in August. The stateOwned Meadowlands had sought Aug. through II to compensate for days lost last winter because of inclement weather and other factors.

title: Deaths
description: Agutnek, Harry

title: Jersey Unit Votes to Hold Teachers Responsible for Pupil Performance
description: TRENTON, July 6  The New Jersey Board of Education voted unanimously today that public school teachers be held responsible for their students progress and that they be evaluated annually.

title: Prospects Look Good For Angler
description: Tuesday's northeast gale, which persisted through much of Wednesday along the New Jersey. New York and New England coasts, severely curtailed offshore fishing the early part of this week.

title: Honduran Editor Is Held After Series on Cocaine
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 6 (UPI)  Honduran police have arrested the editor of El Tiempo, a newspaper that recently published several stories linking highranking members of the military regime with cocaine dealing.

title: A Patriot's Tale
description: PHILADELPHIA It was a holiday morning when I first realized it. From my window I could hear the sounds of a nearby smalltown band in their yearly celebration of whatever it was that flags were flying for that day. In my mind I could see the whole scene as a heartwarming cover on the Saturday Evening Post.

title: Lord Mmples of Britain, Former Transport Aide
description: LONDON, July 6  Lord Marples. former Transport Minister who introduced parking meters to Britain and empowered the police to tow away vehicles, died today in Monte Carlo, his lawyer here said. He was 70 years old.

title: Music's Not All That's in the Air
description: IT was a few minutes after 8. We were finishing dinner with sumptuous custard tarts topped with strawberries and blueberries. Outside, the setting sun was playing light tricks on the Berkshires, splashing the green hillsides with streaks gold and yellow. From the glassenclosed round room at Alice's Restaurant, we had a panoramic view of nature orchestrated by the day's last rays. Near our table, a serenelooking young man with long blond hair plucked away the remains of our citylife tensions with a soothing lute. We had a few more sips of wine before leaving for the concert at Tanglewood across the road. It was a heady moment, with thoughts of the setting, the music and everything else we would see and do in the Berkshires in the next few days. We couldn't help thinking of that line about the hills being alive with the sound of music.

title: With Heavy Packs to the Summit
description: With the economic summit of allied leaders in Bonn fast approaching, the Carter Administration is working overtime to disarm its critics abroad. Western Europe and Japan see the United States thirst for O.P.E.C. oil as the principal source of the huge American trade deficit and thus, indirectly, as the major impediment to world economic recovery. Not so, counter the Administration's economists: the latest trade figures show a decline in foreign oil purchases and a spectacular increase in American imports of industrial products. In other words, they contend that the key to reducing the American trade deficit and strengthening the dollar lies in open markets abroad, notably a greater welcome for American agricultural products, and in economic stimulus in Europe even at the risk of some inflation.

title: Sports in Art in Queens
description: SPORT was once one of the predestined subjects of art. By stretching the human body to its uttermost, sport gave subject matter of an arresting and immediately understandable kind to painters and sculptors alike. Without the discus and the javelin, without boxing and wrestling, and without the standard track events the Greeks and the Romans would have lost a great deal of good art. Sport was integral to British art in the 18th century. From Gericauli to Degas, French artists prized the racehorse as a symbol of disciplined energy.

title: CLAUDE EMIERLY, HIROSHIMA SPOTTER
description: Claude Robert Eatherly, who. as a young Arrny Air Corp pilot. picked hole through the clouds over Japan in his bomber on the morning of Aug. 6, 1945 and radioed the B29 Enola Gay to drop its atomic bomb on Hiroshima. died of cancer last Saturday in Houston. He was 59 years old.

title: ISRAELI PLANES BUZZ BEIRUT IN WARNING TO SYRIA ON ATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6  Israel sent fighter planes low over Beirut today to underline warnings to Syria to end its shelling of Christian sectors in the Lebanese capital.

title: U.P.I. Plans a Computer Center
description: United Press International announced plans yesterday to triple its computer capacity and set up a new communications and technical center outside New York City.

title: Ainslee Cox Strikes Up the Goldman Band
description: It is safe to assume that most symphony conductors look down their noses at the prospect of conducting bands. That is not true, however, of Ainslee Cox, who for the last four years has been music director of the Oklahoma Symphony Orchestra. For longer than that  since 1969. to be exact  he has been a conductor of the Goldman Band, sharing the responsibility with the band's music director, Richard Franko Goldman. Tonight he will lead a program by the band in Dam rosch Park at Lincoln Center called Regards to Broadway?, which will offer excerpts from famous American operettas and musical comedies. Programs don't get much lighter than this.

title: For Children
description: ALEXANDER M. WHITE NATURAL SCIENCE CENTER, a special center to introduce young people to the plants, animals and rocks of New York City, open from 10:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, (closed Suoddy, Monday and holidays), at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th street. A slat! member is always present to assist and explain. Call 8731300.

title: ISRAELIS CONCERNED OVER SYRIAN ATTACK
description: JERUSALEM, July 6  Three key Israeli officials warned today that Israel would not permit the annihilation of Lebanese Christians by Syrian forces.

title: Lyttle Stars in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 6 (AP)  A tworun single by a former New York Yankee, Jim Lyttle, led the Hiroshima Toyo Carp to a 122 rout of the Yomiuri Giants. Lyttle's hit came during an eightrun second inning in which three Yomiuri pitchers set a Japanese record by walking 10 batters, six of them with the bases loaded.

title: Deaths
description: DVORKINMeyer, on July 5 In his 82nd year. Father of Judith and Spencer, grandfather of Elizabeth, Constance, Kate, and Julia, brother of Joseph and Philip. Services Sunday July 9, 10 A.M., at The Riverside, 76 St. 8. Amsterdam. Friends may visit at the Chapel Saturday 7 to 9 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Institute For Retired Professionals, New School, 66 W. 12 St., NYC.

title: It's Connors vs. Borg in Final Again
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6  It seemed so easy. Straight sets. Total dominance. Were Bjorn Borg and Jimmy Connors that far above the rest of the oack in men's tennis?

title: The Scarsdale Diet: If It's Spinach And Cheese, It Must Be Friday
description: SCARSDALE. N.Y.  This is where the losers live, the real losers. This is the home of the famous 14day Scarsdale diet. Half the town seems to be on it

title: TV Weekend
description: AS the commercial networks settle into a summer pattern of mostly reruns. Public Television is seizing the opportunity to monopolize reviewer attentions. This weekend Channel 13 has two firsttimeever presentations worthy of note: Peg o my Heart on Saturday at 10 P.M., and Black at Yale: a film diary on Sunday night at 11.

title: Management
description: DISCRIMINATION suits by employees against employers have become so numerous that the American Arbitration Association has jumped into the fray.

title: Cruyff Scheduled to Play In 2 Cosmos' Exhibitions
description: ROCHESTER. July 6  Johan Cruyff, currently the most sought after soccer player in the world, will play in two exhibition games for the Cosmos at Giants Stadium in September.

title: Ballet: Panovs Dance Cinderella With Berliners
description: ADOUBLEHEADER in the ballet world turned up at the New York State Theater last night when the Berlin Opera Ballet made its United States debut and presented Galina and Valery Panov, the Russian ballet stars who were formerly with the Kirov, as guest artists in their own New York debut.

title: A New TV Idea: Shows for Old People
description: READING, Pa.  No one is out because it is so hot. Gauzy heat hangs at knee level on the streets. Children are in their homes watching cartoons MagiIla Gorilla, that sort of thing. Old people are in their homes, or in their nursing homes, watching other old people on their television screens.

title: Supporters of the Equal Rights Amendment Gathering for March in Washington Sunday
description: One year ago this Sunday, suffragist Alice Paul died at the age of 92. And on the first anniversary of her death, thousands of women are expected in Washington to march on the Capitol in support of the equal rights amendment.

title: Casino Dealers to Vote on Whether to Unionize
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 6  Some 500 casino dealers recently trained by Resorts International will vote Aug. 31 on whether they want to be unionized.

title: Lichfield to Open Its Houses Tomorrow
description: Private and public buildings in Litchfield, Conn., which has been designated a historic district, will be on display tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. as part of Litchfield's Open House Day.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thurday, July 6. 1978

title: A TOP F.B.I OFFICIAL DISCHARGED BY BELL
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The former head of the New York regional office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Wallace LaPrade, was discharged today by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell. Mr. LaPrade had been a key figure in the investigation of illegal investigative techniques used by the bureau against antiwar radicals.

title: Victory Cheers Quebec's Liberals
description: MONTREAL, July 6  An overwhelming victory for the opposition Liberal Party in a byelection in the western Montreal suburb of Notre Dame de Grace yesterday has given further evidence of the party's comeback from its defeat in November 1976 by the proindependence Parti Qubcois.

title: At the Movies
description: THE theater manager in Albuquerque, where we had a sneak preview, told me, Listen, the best proof you've got a hit is that everyone who went to the toilet ran up the aisle and ran back, and the popcorn business was the worst in the history of the theater.

title: A TOP F.B.I. OFFICIAL DISCHARGED BY BELL
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The former head of the New York regional office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Wallace LaPrade, was discharged today by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell. Mr. LaPrade had been a key figure in the investigation of illegal investigative techniques used by the bureau against antiwar radicals.

title: Publishing: The Legs Behind the Book
description: THE muscles in an athletic author's legs caused some agonizing at Random House last year. The legs belong to James F. Fixx and they were shown on the run, muscles awesomely bulging, on a photograph that was being considered for the dust jacket of Mr. Fixx's The Complete Book of Running.

title: Restaurants
description: As much as innovation and highstyle design are to be applauded in the creation of both restaurant interiors and their menus, we have had such an abundance of newness in the last two years that it can be downright relaxing and refreshing to revisit an oldfashioned undesigned restaurant such those that once abounded in neighborhoods all over the city.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 6  A new initiative is being undertaken by five Western countries to win acceptance of their joint independence plan for SouthWest Africa, the territory also known as Namibia.

title: Screen: 'Mouse And Child'
description: THE trouble with "The Mouse and His Child," a particularly elegant children's film opening today at the Guild Theater, is that it isn't really meant for children. The title characters, who are linked hand-in-hand and activated by a windup key in the father's back, begin life in a toy store. But a long and complicated series of adventures lead them to witness beatings, slavery, warfare, an electrocution and a very bad experimental play. They also have occasion to explore the idea of infinity, think about what it means to be self-winding and generally ponder the philosophical condition of Toyhood.As expertly as this animated film has been directed (by Fred Wolf and Chuck Swenson), scored (by Roger Kellaway and Gene Lees) and, especially, written (by Carol MonPere, who adapted Russell Hoban's novel), 83 minutes is a long time for an adult to think about mice. And for children, many of the bleak, gray, rat-ridden settings may seem at least as scary as they are whimsical.Violence and destruction are often made to appear harmless enough in the world of animated films, a world in which characters can be squashed by boulders or run over by trucks and then trot away with nary a scratch. But here, the comic relief comes in the form of grown-up witticisms a young child won't necessarily understand. And the darkish backdrops, though artfully rendered, generate a cumulative gloom.Manny the Rat, the villain of the piece, has the wickedest front teeth in the garbage dump, over which he presides. He also has the voice of Peter Ustinov, all flourishes and rolling r's, to make him the most high-toned blackguard this side of Captain Hook. And the supporting cast, including a big green bird with theatrical pretensions (whose lines are spoken by Cloris Leachman) and a frog dressed as a giant white glove (played by Andy Devine), is correspondingly clever. A great deal of talent has gone into the making of a movie that may never find its audience  or may not have any audience to find.

title: Carey and Miss Krupsak Criticize fach Other Over Westway Project
Youth Shot for Laughing Dies; 2 Boys, 13 and 16, Are Arraigned
description: Hugh B. McEvoy, a 16yearold seminary prepatory student who was shot in the head on Morningside Heights last Sunday by one of two juveniles who apparently objected to his laughter, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been in a coma for four days.

title: Stage: All's Well Comes to Park
description: THE New York Shakespeare Festival opened its Central Park season Wednesday with a production of All's Well That Ends Well that looks as though it were being performed before a funhouse mirror.

title: Scientist Tells of Tests for Curare
description: HACKENSACK, July 6  Drawing on large sheet of paper tacked to an easel at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a toxicologist today traced the sharp distinctive peaks that he said had registered on his analytical apparatus when he tested for curare in the bodies of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: British Sleeping Car Fire Kills 11
description: TAUNTON, England, July 6 (Reuters)  Eleven people were killed and thirty injured when fire engulfed two sleeping cars on a Londonbound express near this town in southwest England today.

title: Chain Buys New Mexico Paper
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., July 6 (AP)Boone Newspapers Inc. announced today the purchase of The Daily Range in Raton, N.M. The general manager of The Selma TimesJournal, E. Wilson Koeppel, has been named editor and publisher of the paper. Boone owns newspapers in Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, Iowa, Missouri and New Mexico.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WIMBLEDON. England, July 6 (UPI)  Hie Nastase yesterday accepted a $5,000 fine and a threemonth suspension for misconduct that will keep him out of Grand Prix tournaments until October.

title: Bank Certificate Legality Studied
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will not reach a decision until early next week on the legality of sixmonth savings certificates linked to Treasury bill rates just introduced by the largest commercial bank in Maine, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Dance: Clark Center Festival
description: ONE hesitates to call the Clark Center for the Performing Arts a venerable institution, for the little dance studio and producing agent has kept its sturdy, grassroots personality in a decidedly lively way over its 20 years of existence. Typically, this year's monthlone summer dance festival at the City University Graduate Center Mall on West 42d Street is dedicated to Thelma Hill, the late, muchloved modern dance teacher. Over the years, Clark Center has nurtured a host of fledgling choreographic talents, among them the then unknown Alvin Ailey and Meredith Monk.

title: Republicans Chiefs Prod Congress on Tax Cutting
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Republican leaders, signaling that they intended to make tax reduction a major issue in the Congressional election campaign, declared today that it was time for Congress to begin a longterm program of tax cutting, even if that meant that some initial rise in the Federal budget deficit and the rate of inflation.

title: U.S. Judge Finds Bell in Contempt In Informer Case
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell was held in contempt of court yesterday for refusing to release the files on 18 informers who spied on the Socialist Workers Party for the Federal Bureau of Investieation.

title: Can High Prices Turn Back Import Surge?
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Economists in the Carter Administration are betting on the classic effects of the price mechanism to turn back the surge of imports that have caused the nation's trade deficit to swell a mighty 79 percent from last year's level.

title: Rail Certificates
description: The trustee for the Milwaukee Road was authorized to issue trustee certificates for about $437 million by Federal judge in Chicago. The certificates are being issued in connection with the Federal Government's financial assistance for rehabilitation of the railroad's tracks, locomotives and cars. The Milwaukee Road is about 95 percent owned by the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation.

title: Gasoline Stocks Drop in Week
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that gasoline stocks for the week ended June 30 declined to 228.4 million barrels, compared with 230.1 million barrels for the previous week.

title: RULING ON TAX GAIN FOR RENTERS IS SET
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it would expedite a ruling on a New York State law enabling apartment renters to use their share of a building's property taxes as a Federal incometax deduction. But the officials gave no indication of what the ruling would be.

title: . . . The Mood in the Streets
description: CAIRO  The citizens of Cairo and Alexandria, like their counterparts in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, want the peace that seemed so promising in November the peace that has eluded so many for so long.

title: Consumer Borrowing Near Peak
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  Consumers continued borrowing money at nearrecord levels in May, particularly for automobiles, the Federal Reserve said today. Installment debts grew by $3.86 billion in May, the secondlargest increase on record, after growing $3.72 billion in April.

title: Miss Navratilova Rallies to Take Wimbledon Crown
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 Two summers ago, Martina Navratilova left the stadium court at Forest Hills sobbing uncontrollably, her head buried in a towel. Today, after her singles victory at Wimbledon, Miss Navratilova was the toast of women's tennis.

title: CelticsBraves Switch Voted
description: The National Basketball Association Board of Governors approved the switch in ownerships of the Buffalo and Boston franchises yesterday and realigned two of the four divisions to make room for the Buffalo Braves move to San Diego.

title: Your Money
description: THOUGH basic fire insurance premiums are rising at comparatively modest rates, the same cannot be said for the total cost of homeowner policies.

title: ISRAELIS REINFORCE TROOPS ON BORDERS; SYRIA ALERTS UNITS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 Israel was reported today to have reinforced its military forces near the borders of Lebanon and Syria to backup a warning that it would not remain inactive if Syrians continued bombarding Lebanese Christians districts in Beirut.

title: Books of The Times
description: What To Dance is really about comes through most vividly in one episode contained in this determinedly different view of life inside the Soviet Union.

title: Wholesale Prices Up 0.7% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 Food prices rose substantially in June on the farm and on wholesalers shelves, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today, but other wholesale prices showed some signs of moderation. Over all, wholesale prices rose seventenths of percent in June, it said.

title: Judge Rules Snepp Violated Contract and Must Forfeit Profits on Book
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va. July 7  A Federal district judge ruled today that Frank W. Snepp 3d, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, violated his contract in writing an unauthorized book about the agency and ordered that his illgotten gains be turned over to the Government.

title: Ernst & Ernst and Leidesdorf to Combine
description: Ernst & Ernst, one of the Big Eight accounting firm, and S. D. Leidesdorf & Company, a New York: based accounting tirrn, announced yesterday that they had combined their practices. The announcement was made jointly by Ray J. Groves and Harry R. Mancher, the managing parlers of Ernst & Ernst and Leidesdorf.

title: Jim Nabors Show Goes Off Air
description: There will be a new look, or, more accurately, new looking, on WCBSTV during the time period from 9 to 10 A.M. weekdays starting Monday.

title: No Commercials for Affirmed
description: Around the race track, it has been said that nothing brings out the worst in people as rapidly as their first really good horse. When the horse they own happens to become a triple crown winner, the temptation to make hay while the sun shines can be irresistible.There are rights to be sold, endorsements to be arranged, Tshirts and other products to be marketed. Yet no such commercialism has touched Affirmed, the gldn 3yearold colt owned by Lou Wolfson.

title: ...The Mood in the Streets
description: CAIRO  The citizens of Cairo and Alexandria, like their counterparts in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, want the peace that seemed so promising in November  the peace that has eluded so many for so long.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Giants Top Reds, 76, as Blue Gets 12th
description: CINCINNATI, July 7 (UPI)  Willie McCovey and Darrell Evans hit homers in a threerun fifth tonight as the San Francisco Giants posted a 76 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the first game of a doubleheader. In the second, Mike Lum's fourth homer of the season, a tworun blast in the fifth. gave the Reds a 21 victory.

title: Walkout by 15,000 in Construction Idles Major New York City Projects
description: A strike by unions representing more than 15.000 construction workers has halted work on hundreds of millions of dollars in building projects in New York City and has idled thousands of other nonstriking workers.

title: Guidry Loses First Game As Brewers Beat Yanks
description: MILWAUKEE, July 7  About an hour before he faced the Milwaukee Brewers tonight, Ron Guidry was discussing the prospects of pitching through the season undefeated.

title: Maritime Nations Agree to Pact on Crew Standards
description: LONDON, July 7 (AP)  Seafaring nations reached agreement today on the first international accord specifying regulations and minimum requirements for masters and crews of merchant ships.

title: Nehemiah, Williams Win In European Track Meet
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, July 7 (AP) Steve Williams, Renaldo Ntht:rniah and Willie Smith of the United States, plus Don Quarne of Jamaica and Marlies Ockner of East Germany scored victories yesterday in an internatinal track and field meet.

title: Youth Killed and Man Is Injured In Attacks in an East Side Park
description: A 16yearold boy was beaten to death and a 21yearold man was reported in critical condition yesterday at Beekman Hospital after the two were attacked in Lower East Side park.

title: Hotel Employees Strike in Rome
description: ROME, July 7 (AP)  About 700,000 hotel employees went on a 24hour nationwide strike today to press demands for higher pay. The walkout came in the middle of the tourist season, forcing vacationers to carry their own luggage, make their own beds and take their meals elsewhere than in hotel restaurants.

title: Tomato Growers Set
description: The California Tomato Growers Association and the H.J. Heinz Company have reached agreement on price and contract terms for 1978 processing of tomato tonnage. the association said. In addition, it said that this year's estimates of total processing tomato production in California were more than one million tons below the 1977 level of 6.6 million tons.

title: SyrianIsraeli Strain Disrupts U.S. Peace Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 The revived threat of a SyrianIsraeli showdown over the new outbreak of strife in Lebanon has created at least a temporary complication for the Carter Administration's plans to get EgyptianIsraeli negotiations under way in London in 10 days.

title: Pins and Needles, Musical, Is Staged
description: It was a surprise to all concerned, not least the authors, when the modest musical revue Pins and Needles, produced under the auspices of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, became a runaway success on Broadway and all over the country.

title: Down by the Louisiana Shore
description: THE FOUCHONE, La.All winter I had strained for this return to the sea, drawn back in an annual cycle as regular as the tides. We reached this obscure sandbar in the night. I jumped trom the van, released. Briney mist filled my nostrils. The sand was cool, pliable between my toes. My ears pulsed with the breakers.

title: Philippines Has Surplus
description: MANILA, July 7 (UPI)  Despite trade deficit of $460 million, the Philippines had an overall balanceofpayments surplus of $S3 million in the first half of 1978. the central bank reported today. The report also said that the value of the Philippine peso had appreciated with the weakening of the United States dollar overseas. International reserves rose by 26 percent from the June 1977 level to reach $1.9 billion in June this year, the bank said. The trade figures showed that export receipts totaled $1.49 billion, up by 13 percent at the end of June, but irrutIort payments rose by 24 percent to $1.95 billion over the similar period.

title: U.S. AGENCY DEFENDS TWO CHRYSLER CARS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today defended the performance of the Chrysler Corporation's Omni and Horizon subcompact cars and said that could find no hazard in the handling characteristics of the two new vehicles.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE RCA Corporation has moved a step toward the introduction of television record playing. with both video and sound, in the home. A staff member at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J.. has invented a record player in which video disks are au toniaticany fitted without damage to their fine and delicate grooves.

title: Teachers Growing Anger Over Evaluation Demands
description: TRENTON, July 7  When the State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, returns tomorrow from China, where he has been a guest of the Ministry of Education for the last two weeks, he will find the uproar over public school education in New Jersey has not ebbed while he was away. On the contrary, it has intensified.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT OFF TO 5.7% FOR JUNE, L0WEST IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The unemployment rate fell sharply in June to 5.7 percent of the work force, its lowest level in nearly four years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Dawkins Undergoes Surgery
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP)Darryl Dawkins, a Philadelphia 76er center, underwent a I hour operation yesterday to remove loose cartilage from an injured right shoulder.

title: Spiraling Through
description: Let's talk plain about heat. Every July people write me and say, Doctor Magneto, what is this heat thing that makes me so miserable day and night?

title: Joint Legislative Panel Resuming Inquiry on Taxpayer Discontent
description: TRENTON, July 7  A special joint legislative committee on tax policy will resume its inquiry into the public's attitude on taxes next week with hearings in Willingboro and Newark.

title: Carters Have 32d Anniversary
description: Thurmont, Md., July 7 (UPI)  President and Mrs. Carter quietly celebrated their 32d wedding anniversary today. Before having dinner with family members, the Carters played tennis at the Presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains. They were married on June 7,1946, at the Methodist Church in Plains, Ga.

title: Patulski, Bears' End, Will Be Out for Season
description: CHICAGO, July 7 (UPI)Walt Patulski, a defensive end for the Chicago Bears, underwent surgery today for an acute slipped disk and will be unable to play this season, the Bears announced. Dr. Stewart Laurie performed the surgery in Rochester, N.Y.

title: GATT to Give Report Monday
description: GENEVA, July 7  The chief negotiators of the major industrialized powers, who are gathering here this weekend for a final weeklong drive for agreement on the essentials of a package of tradeliberalization measures, will take time off Monday to report on their efforts to the developing countries.

title: 2 Contracts Halted In Ship Construction
description: Two contracts for the construction of ships have been halted, it was disclosed.

title: Central Park Ramble Becomes the Scene of Hunt for Gang
description: The police fanned out through the darkening Central Park, roaming the narrow, twisting paths of the Ramble, driving slowly over the closedoff roadways, stopping to question strollers.

title: Seabrook Issue to Be Resolved
description: CONCORD. N.H., July 7 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency will attempt to resolve the stalled Seabrook nuclear power plant issue by the end of the month, an agency lawyer said today. Representative Norman E. D'Amours, Democrat of New Hampshire, had said earlier that the agency would try to make a decision by July 21, when construction of the plant is scheduled to stop. Mr. D'Amours commented after members of the state's congressional delegation met today with Joan Bernstein, chief counsel for the E.P.A., which is reviewing the suitability of the Public Service Company plant's cooling system.

title: Police Seek 2,000 Guards
description: The Police Department is planning to hire more than 2,000 schoolcrossing guards starting Monday in anticipation of the opening of school next September.

title: Savin Net Up 82% On 65% Sales Rise
description: The Savin Business Machines Corporation reported an 82.9 percent advance in fourthquarter profits on a 65.6 fxrcent revenue rise. For the year, the maker of office copying machines reported more than a doubling of profits on an 81 Percent revenue increase

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 8, 1978

title: Judge at Jascalevich Trial Limits Testimony of Expert on Poisons
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 7  Sustaining a vigorous objection by the defense, the judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich today barred a toxicologist from testifying about one test that indicated the presence of curare in the body of an alleged victim.

title: Unionization of Chinese Restaurant Breaks a Grim Tradition
description: For as long as Chinese restaurants have been popular, the knowledge that their waiters and busboys work 12hour days for tips and less than a dollar an hour in wages has been an open secret in every Chinatown in the country.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: Herbert J. Stern's tenure as a United States Attorney for New Jersey from 1971 through 1974 produced an unparalleled record of successful whitecollar prosecutions. His first case resulted in the bribery conviction of executives of nine major oil companies. Later, he secured the conviction of scores of Federal, state and local public officials.

title: Letter: On Tax Rebellion
description: To the Editor:

title: MALAYSIA ELECTING PARLIAMENT TODAY
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. July 7 After a campaign restricted to two weeks because of what officials described as the possibility of violence, Malaysians are voting tomorrow in an election that is expected to return the governing National Front to power.

title: Soviet Launches Rocket Carrying Salyut 6 Cargo
description: MOSCOW, July 7 (UPI)  The Soviet Union launched a robot rocket, called Progress 2, into orbit today, carrying food and fuel to two Soviet astronauts orbiting the Earth aboard the Salyut 6 space station.

title: NyeWest, Defenders, Ousted in Anderson Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 6 Gerry Nye Jr. And Marty West, the defending champions, made a hasty exit today from the 42d annual John G. Anderson Memorial Golf tournament.

title: COMMODITIES
description: After their sharp price decline Thursday, silver futures turned around yesterday and climbed 4 cents and more. While such rapid changes appear to be puzzling to some onlookers, regular traders consider it part of the fastmoving game.

title: Ratification of City's Transit Pact Blocked in Court by Dissident Unit
description: A court order blocking ratification of the contract of the Transport Workers Union was obtained yesterday by a group of dissident bus and subway workers who voted to reject the agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: About New York
description: There was a man crawling on the sidewalk in Times square the other day, and a week earlier another derelict also had been seen devolving in misery on all fours. Neither man was noticed receiving a helping hand from passersby, and for good reason, it can be argued, because in Times Square a man might as easily draw a weapon from his rags as crawl.

title: Wallis Quits as Head of Public Broadcasting Corp.
description: In a move that stunned other members of the board because it came without warning. W. Allen Wallis yesterday resigned as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and relinquished his seat on the 15person board, as well. His term was to have expired in 1980.

title: Sadat Flies to Vienna to See Peres
description: CAIRO, July 7 President Anwar elSadat left today for Vienna where he will meet with Shimon Peres, the Israeli opposition leader, to discuss the Cairo's new peace proposal. The Vienna talks will precede a meeting in London this month by the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers, with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance present.

title: Reserve Mining Company to Remain in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 7The Reserve Mining Company, embroiled for more than a decade in an environmental battle with state and Federal officials, will remain in business in Minnesota, corporate officials announced here today.

title: Unionization of Chinese Restaurant Breaks a Grim Tradition
description: For as long as Chinese restaurants have been popular, the knowledge that their waiters and busboys work 12hour days for tips and less than a dollar an hour in Wages has been an open secret in every Chinatown in the country.

title: Wasting Energy on Con Edison
description: The irrepressible Robert Abrams, the Borough President of the Bronx and candidate for State Attorney General, and Andrew Stein, the energetic Borough President of Manhattan, have been urging the city to appropriate funds fora feasibility study of a public takeover of Consolidated Edison. Before research dollars and a precious supply of civic energy are tossed away on their suggestion, a few sips of realism might help to subdue the heady prospects of cheap power under local public ownership.

title: Hospital Pact to Raise Costs 11%
description: New York hospital officials estimated yesterday that the wage settlement reached Thursday night between the city's private voluntary hospitals and the union representing 37,000 of their workers would raise costs to taxpayers and patients 11 percent.

title: Wisconsin to Get Storm Aid
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  President Carter declared Wisconsin a major disaster area today, clearing the way for the use of Federal funds to repair damage caused last month by severe storms, flooding, hail and tornadoes. The storms, on June 25, extensively damaged private and putlic property. The President also declared an emergency for North Dakota, permitting Governmentowned mobile homes to be used by persons left homeless by tornadoes in Grant County July 4 and 5.

title: 2 Owners Take Gamble For Chance in Cane Pace
description: When Alex Rothschild ventures from his oceanfront Malibu home of rock and glass for a weekend in Las Vegas, a single roll of the dice may cost him $10,000. But for the silverhaired Californian, retired from his importexport business, this is a form of therapy  a way to pass the time.

title: Business and the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Representatives of business and industry won several major victories in the Supreme Court during the term that ended this week but, as usual, suffered setbacks along the way.

title: Massachusetts Budget Approved
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)  The Massachusetts Legislature enacted a $5 billion state budget late today, but Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said that he did not plan to sign it until the House and Senate adjourned for the year, possibly on Sunday.

title: MARY BARLOW
description: Mary Barlow, a former teacher of English and mathematics at the Kew Forest School in Forest Hills, Queens, died yesterday in her home, at 4 Dartmouth Street in Forest Hills, after a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title: Justice, Ethics and Government Regulations
description: CHICAGONumerous economic studies show that government regulation of business is costly, ineffective, harmful, stifling, and otherwise destructive. Yet past regulatory activities continue, new regulations proliferate, and millions continue to believe in the desirability of more and more government regulation.

title: Russian Women Trounce U.S. Team in Basketball
description: KOBE, Japan, July 7 (UPI) Ulyana Semenova, the world's tallest woman basketball player at 6 feet 11 inches, scored 18 points today in powering the Soviet Union to a 9242 victory over the United States on the final day of a fournation tournament.

title: General Signal Winner In Long Battle for Leeds
description: A 20month takeover battle involving six companies ended yesterday with the announcement by Leeds & Northrup that it had reached tentative terms of merger with the General Signal Coraoration.

title: OWNERS OF AMERICA WILL MAKE REPAIRS
description: After much stormy sailing  literally as well as figuratively  the liner America will stay put for awhile in New York Harbor under the terms of an agreement announced yesterday between the ship's owners and the State Attorney General's office. The owners, Venture Cruise Lines, promised to make repairs and to see that bookings do not exceed accommodations before the ship sails again.

title: Soviet Will Begin Trial Monday For Activist Defended by Carter
description: MOSCOW, July 7The Soviet authorities announced today that Anatoly Shcharansky, a Jewish dissident whom President Carter has defended publicly, would go on trial Monday. The official charges are high treason and espionage, which carry a possible death penalty.

title: ISRAELIS REINFORCE TROOPS ON BORDERS; SYRIA ALERTS UNITS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 Israel was reported today to have reinforced its military forces near the borders of Lebanon and Syria to back up a warning that it would not remain inactive if Syrians continued bombarding Lebanese Christians districts in Beirut.

title: American League Passes 10Million Crowd Mark
description: One day from the halfway mark of the baseball season, the American League has surpassed the 10million mark in attendance, the A.L. announced today. Thursday night's attendance raised the A.L. figures this year to 10,087,748, an increase of 4 percent over last year at a similar date.

title: Frederick J. Port, the Chairman And Chief of ESB RayOVAC, 63
description: Frederick J. Port, the chairman and chief executive officer of the ESB Ray0Vac Corporation and an advocate of batterypowered cars, died early yesterday after a long illness at his home in West Chester, a suburb of Philadelphia. He was 63 years old.

title: Gerry Mulligan Sticks to Basics With His Group at Story Towne
description: Gerry Mulligan has been so full of surprises in recent years that it comes almost as a letdown to find him playing the role of the basic Gerry Mulligan the baritone saxophonist, composer and occasional pianist who staked out his claim to jazz eminence more than 20 years ago with his West Coast quartet.

title: Parker Pen Cites 43.6% Sales Gain
description: The Parker Pen Company is writing bettter numbers these days minus its problem division but with the benefits of its fastgrowing Manpower employment services.

title: Congdon: Cottage Industry  in Publishing
description: Thomas Congdon edits books. He sort of works for E. P. Dutton & Company. He works for them, he says, in the sense of a little old man cobbling shoes in a thatched hut who, when he gets done with the shoes, goes and peddles them through Florsheim. I'm the little cottage industry inside the big compound, he says. And it's just delicious. It's just a great principle. I have the license to be selfish.

title: Riders Hail a Rebel Bus Driver
description: James A. Kerrigan's refusal to drive a bus he believed was unsafe has led to his suspension by the Transit Authority and his emergence as a kind of hero to several thousand Staten Island bus riders.

title: Giants, Colts of 1958 Play It Again for Laughs
description: Twenty years ago they played the game for real. They put on their helmets, shoulder pads and game faces and went into the swirling winds of Yankee Stadium for the championship of professional football. After four quarters the game was tied, and then, in the first suddendeath overtime in the history of the game, the Baltimore Colts, on a touchdown run by Alan Ameche, defeated the New York Giants, 2317. They still call it, the greatest game ever played,

title: Soviet Will Begin Trial Monday For Activist Defended by Carter
description: MOSCOW, July 7  The Soviet authorities announced today that Anatoly Shcharansky, a Jewish dissident whom President Carter has defended publicly, would go on trial Monday. The official charges are high treason and espionage, which carry a possible death penalty.

title: Cosmetics for Black Women: The Timing Was Right
description: Barbara Walden laughs when people refer to her as the black Estee Lauder. Well, in a smaller way, perhaps. Miss Walden is a cosmetics entrepreneur with a milliondollar business, Barbara Walden Cosmetics, thriving nicely these days. She might not have become involved with it except that theatrical makeup did freaky things to her skin when she was a young actress storming Hollywood.

title: Gains in Sales at Chains Lift June From Doldrums
description: A combination of warm June weather and apparently enticing summer merchandise produced strong chainstore sales increases  and some record resultsfor the month.

title: Chinese Troupe Dances Peking Opera Excerpts
description: What was most fascinating about Thursday night's program by the Performing Arts Company of the People's Republic of China was its variety. The second of the programs offered by this troupe at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was a sort of cultural vaudeville show. And because it contained everything from scenes from the Peking Opera to precision line routines that would not have looked out of place at the Radio City Music Hall, it was not only fascinating, but also charming. amusing, surprising and sometimes even perplexing.

title: Consumer Notes: State Advises Buyers on New vs. Used Car Value
description: Prospective automobile buyers are being advised by the State Division of Consumer Affairs to consider carefully the advantages and disadvantages in choosing between a new and used car, weighing such factors as depreciation, warranties, credit opportunities and the private owner versus the used car lot.

title: Alvin Ailey Dance Company Encounters Problems on Brazil Tour
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7  The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, on its first tour of Latin America in 15 years, has been exuberantly received by ebullient audiences in Brazil. Initial backstage friction, however, made the choreographer threaten to cancel his opening night at Rio's municipal theater.

title: The Vintage Jukebox Still Sounds Sweet
description: Jukeboxes have come a long way. At the turn of the century, only juke joints  Southern brothels  had windup jukeboxes. But now, collectors will cross the country for an old Wurlitzer in an Art Deco cabinet, and shiny new jukeboxes are given to 16yearolds.

title: Strike Off, but Some Walk Out
description: FLINT, Mich., July 7 (AP)  A strike by 7,000 workers against a General Motors Corporation truck assembly plant was narrowly averted today, but not in time to prevent several hundred workers from leaving their jobs. Sam Duncan, President of Local 598 of the United Auto Workers, said word of the settlement did not reach the workers who left.

title: Two Reporters Notebooks: Mideast Peace Outlook . . .
description: CAIRO, July 7  After President Antiwar elSadat made his startling journey to Jerusalem last November, he declared he had broken down the psychological harrier to peace in the Middle East. More than seven months later the psychological harrier still exists, reinforced by prejudice, and frustrations over the current deadlock.

title: And Then They Turned To Clothes
description: To Michaele Vollbracht, an illustrator who became a designer, Fashion is so much fun if you can have fun with it.

title: Miss Navratilova Rallies to Take Wimbledon Crown
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7Two summers ago, Martina Navratilova left the stadium court at Forest Hills sobbing uncontrollably, her head buried in a towel. Today, after her singles victory at Wimbledon, Miss Navratilova was the toast of women's tennis.

title: CURARECASE JUDGE LIMITS TOXICOLOGIST
description: HACKENSACK, July 7  Sustaining a vigorous objection by the defense, the judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich today barred a toxicologist from testifying about one test that indicated the presence of curare in the body of an alleged victim.

title: BELL IS GIVEN STAY OF CONTEMPT ORDER
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell won a stay yesterday of an order holding him in contempt of court for refusing to release informer files in a $40 million suit by the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Detectives Hunt Clues in Ax Murder of 2 Derelicts
description: Plainclothes detectives, admitting they had few clues and no real leads. canvassed the Red Hook section of Brooklyn yesterday, talking with friends and acquantenaces of two derelicts hacked to death early rhursday in a small lot filled with abandoned automobiles.

title: Van Der Veen Suspended
description: SAN DIEGO, July 7 (AP)  Jan Van Der Veen was suspended yesterday by the North American Soccer League and the San Diego Sockers because of too many rule infractions. Marvin Milkes, general manager of the Sockers, said the N.A.S.L. suspension applied to the remaining home games on the San Diego schedule.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THOSE GOLDEN DAYS Some happy memories of Hollywood's sunny, nevernever land days will at least be suggested in two new cabaret acts down in Greenwich Village over the weekend. One show stars no less than Butterfly McQueen, the famed Prissy of Gone With the Wind. Across the Village, a oneman performance by Charles Busch will create a varied gallery of West Coast citizens titled Hollywood Confidential.

title: TaxCut Issue Dominates State Legislators Parley
description: DENVER, July 7  Two state legislators rode out to rope a steer last night at little rodeo staged for the National Conference of State Legislatures. They missed and the steer wandered off unroped.

title: Radioactive Contamination Worst At Pennsylvania and Jersey Sites
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP)  The sites of two former nuclear ore processing plants in Pennsylvania and New Jersey are the most hazardous of 26 former atomic energy sites in the United States where radioactive contamination was found, the Federal Energy Department says.

title: Colonial Stores Acts To Block Takeover
description: ATLANTA, July 7 (Reuters)  Colonial Stores filed suit today to block a $114 million takeover proposal from Cavenharn Ltd., the large European supermarket and foodprocessing concern that owns Grand Union in the United States.

title: John H. Wheeler, Political Leader
description: John Hervey Wheeler, a bank president who was a leading civil rights and political figure in North Carolina's Democratic Party circles, died Thursday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 70 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: A major upset occurred in the preliminary round of the Regional Knockout Team Championship at the Statler Hilton Hotel here Thursday night. Nearly all the 25 competing teams had to play threeway matches, needing to beat at least one of the two other teams in their own group.

title: Railroad Tender Set
description: The Boston & Maine Corporation said that the Interstate Commerce Commission had approved a plan for the railroad to make a tender offer for its 6 percent mortgage bonds at $800 for each $1,000 principal amount. The company said the approval affirmed a decision last December by an administrative law judge. The railroad said that the decision would become effective July 26. It added, however, that the tender offer must also be approved by the Boston & Maine reorganization judge in the Federal District Court in Boston.

title: U.S. Hints That Trials Of Russian Dissidents Will Affect Relations
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The United States expressed deep concern today over the opening Monday of the trials of the Soviet dissidents, Anatoly Shcharansky and Aleksandr Ginzburg, and implied that their fates would affect overall SovietAmerican relations.

title: Western Europeans Planning New system To stabilize Currency
description: BREMEN, West Germany, July 7 Western European leaders, in a move seen as an attempt to reinvigorate the flagging movement toward European unity, pledged today to set up anew European monetary arrangement by the end of this year. They also expressed hope that the new arrangement would stabilize their currencies on foreignexchange markets and strengthen the ailing United States dollar.

title: Military May Join Hunt For Smugglers of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI)  Dr. Peter G. Bourne, President Carter's special assistant for health affairs, has drafted a master plan for cracking down on drug smuggling into the United States that calls for use of Air Force jets and Navy ships, officials said yesterday.

title: Options Market Plans Halted
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, following a request by the securities and Exchange Commission, it withdrew its proposal to establish an options market and ac cepted an extension of the agency's voluntary moratorium on the expansion of options trading.

title: Events
description: DR PEPPER CENTRAL PARK MUSIC FESTIVAL: ROBERT KLEIN and DION, W??man Skating Rink, Fifth Avertie and 59th Street, 6:30

title: Central Park Ramble Becomes the Scene of Hunt for Gang
description: The police fanned out through the darkening Central Park, roaming the narrow, twisting paths of the Ramble, driving slowly over the closedoff roadways. stopping to question strollers.

title: Notes on People
description: When President Carter went fishing last week with his wife, Rosalynn, and daughter, Amy, he didn't know that they were being automatically entered in the NorfolkVirginia Beach BluefishTuna Tournament. What's more, the First Family conducted itself well with rod and reel. Mr. Carter is currently in first place in the men's competition, having hauled in a 24pound, 8ounce tuna, and Mrs. Carter is in third place in the women's division with her catch of a 25pounder. Amy also caught a 25pound fish, species uncertain, and will receive a plaque as Angler of the Week, said George Roper 2d of Virginia Beach, the tournament secretary. The tournament will last through July.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1978

title: ISADOR LUBIN DIES, 82; IN BRAIN TRUST
description: Isador Lubin, who was once called Franklin D. Roosevelt's favorite economist, died of heart failure Thursday night in a hospital at Annapolis, Md., near his country home. He was 82 years old and lived at 1095 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Hospitals Call Cost Curbs Success
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The voluntary effort by hospital administrators and doctors to curb soaring hospital costs is achieving dramatic success so far, health industry officials said today.

title: CAREY WON'T TALK OF A PRIMARY LOSS
description: WELLSVILLE, N.Y., July 7 Governor Carey declined today to say whether he would support Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak if she defeated him for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court today denied a request from the Chicago Park District to delay a weekend rally scheduled by a Nazi group, the National Socialist Party of America.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Allegheny Cutting Price Of Stainless Steel 15%
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of stainless steel, in an unusual move, announced yesterday that it was cutting the price on stainless steel plate, major product, by 15 percent to counter severe behindthescenes discounting by competitors.

title: Solomons, Once Battleground, Gains Independence
description: HONIARA, Solomon Islands, July 7 (Reuters)The 200,000 people of the Solomon Islands, the scene of major battles between the United States and Japan during World War II, received their independence today from Britain.

title: Remembering Bobby Shelton and the Ku Klux Klan
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.When Robert Shelton, Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, recently claimed the K.K.K. was having a resurgence, painful pictures were brought back into my mind. He declared that because President Jimmy Carter was elected by 94 percent of the black vote and 84 percent of the Jewish votes there would be a white people's revolt.

title: 2 Get 15 Years as Vietnam Spies
description: ALEXANDRIA, July 7  A former United States Information Agency officer and a Vietnamese graduate student, both insisting that they were innocent, were sentenced today to 15 years on their conviction of being spies for Vietnam.

title: Yonkers Council Reverses Itself On Seeking Utility Tax Increase
description: YONKERS, July 7  The City Council last night reversed itself and voted, 7to 6, against sending a homerule message to the State Legislature asking permission to raise the utility tax from 1 percent to 3 percent.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Christian Democrats Agree to Support Socialist for the Presidency
description: ROME, July 7  In a lastminute concession to save their working alliance with the left today, Italy's ruling Christian Democrats accepted Sandro Pertini, a Socialist, as candidate for the presidency.

title: Air France Will buy 4 Airbuses
description: Air France announced yesterday that it intended to buy four of the scaleddown Airbus A300 widebody jets to be built by Europe's multination manufacturing consortium.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended July 1 fell to 2.68 million tons, down 2.3 percent, from the 2.749 million tons of the week before, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Two Reporters' Notebooks: Mideast Peace Outlook...
description: CAIRO, July 7  After President Anwar elSadat made his startling journey to Jerusalem last November, he declared he had broken down the psychological barrier to peace in the Middle East. More than seven months later the psychological barrier still exists, reinforced by prejudices and frustrations over the current deadlock.

title: Ratification of City's Transit Pact Blocked in Court by Dissident Unit
description: A court order blocking ratification of the contract of the Transport Workers Union was obtained yesterday by a group of dissident bus and subway workers who voted to reject the agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: H.F.C. Debt Practices Challenged by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  In September 1976, Paul Riggins was officially declared bankrupt and relieved of his obligation to repay his debts, which included $1,500 he owed the Household Finance Corporation.

title: Moon Is Discovered In an Orbit of Pluto, The Outermost Planet
description: Astronomers at the United States Naval Observatory in Washington announced yesterday that they had discovered a moon in orbit around Pluto, the outermost known planet in the solar system.

title: The Entertainer: FundRaiser for Politics
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The big money people in politics today are no longer the Clement Stones and Stuart Motts, devalued into insignificance by the $1,000 contribution limit, but the Bob Hopes, Glen Campbells, Frank Sinatras and other performers who can raise 20 to 80 times the StoneMott limits in an evening.

title: Apollo Win 10th Straight
description: HEMPSTEAD ?? July 7  the New York Apollo recorded their 10th straight victory last night with a 3 ?? triumph over Sacra?? Gold Charlie McCarthy, the Apollo's leading scorer and also the leading scorer in the SoeAmerican Soccer League, had two goals and one a??

title: Houghton in Pact
description: The Houghton Mifflin Company has entered into an agreement to buy 327,400 shares of its common stock held by Western Pacific Industries Inc. Purchase price will be $30 a share, the companies said in an announcement. Western Pacific, a diversified New York company, had announced only last March that it had purchased more than 6 percent of Houghton Mifflin shares, and that last April it had increased its interest to 10.2 percent.

title: Moon Is Discovered In an Orbit of Pluto, The Outermost Planet
description: Astronomers at the United States Naval Observatory in Washington announced yesterday that they had discovered a moon in orbit around Pluto, the outermost known planet in the solar system.

title: Berkowitz Is Shifted to Hospital
description: MARCY, N.Y., July 7 (AP)  David R. Berkowitz was transferred under heavy guard today from a state prison in northern New York near the Canadian border to the Central New York Psychiatric Center here.

title: Judge Bars Garfield's New Restrictions on Trains
description: NEWARK, July 7  The city of Garfield was barred by a Federal judge today from implementing a new safety law to restrict railroad freight traffic on halfmile track spur that runs down the middle of a harrow fourblock residential street.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 8

title: Tobacco Unit Questions Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Tobacco Institute has taken issue with a study that says people with bad hearts are more susceptible to crippling chest pains when they sit near cigarette smokers. The study, the results of which were published in yesterday's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine, involved tests conducted at the Veterans Administration hospital in Long Beach, Calif. The institute contended that interpretations of the smoking experiments are both extravagant and unfortunate.

title: Panovs in Cinderella With Berlin Opera Ballet
description: A doubleheader in the ballet world turned up at the New York State Theater Thursday night when the Berlin Opera Ballet made its United States debut and presented Galina and Valery Panov, the Russian ballet stars who were formerly with the Kirov, as guest artists in their own New York debut.

title: Holding the Line on Foreign Aid
description: There is still time for the Carter Administration defend the endangered foreign aid bill, which is as vital to American interests as it is to economic progress poor nations. Two million American jobs now depend on exports to thirdworld countries. Moreover. unless the poor countries can be helped to feed themselves, world food shortages will send America's supermarket prices soaring.

title: MACCHIAROLA LISTS PLANS FOR SCHOOLS
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, New York City's new School Chancellor, yesterday outlined tentative steps he plans for reducing class size, integrating the teaching staff and devising a uniform method of hiring public school teachers.

title: New P.P.G. Headquarters
description: PITTSBURGH, July 7  P.P.G. Industries plans to build a 40story office building in downtown Pittsburgh at cost of $50 million, it was announced yesterday. The building, to contain a million square feet of office space, will become the new headquarters of P.P.G., a leading producer of chemicals, glass, coatings, resins and fiberglass.

title: White Queens Youths Accused Of Assault in Bus Racial Attacks
description: Three white students at a junior high school in Floral Park, Queens, were charged yesterday with having injured several black youths  pupils at the same school  when they threw rocks and bottles at two city transit buses carrying the students.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT OFF TO 5.7% FOR JUNE, LOWEST IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The unemployment rate fell sharply in June to 5.7 percent of the work force, its lowest level in nearly four years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Sadat Flies to Vienna to See Peres
description: CAIRO, July 7 President Anwar elSadat left today for Vienna where he will meet with Shimon Peres, the Israeli opposition leader, to discuss the Cairo's new peace proposal. The Vienna talks will precede a meeting in London this month by the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers, with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance present.

title: 2 Get 15 Years as Vietnam Spies
description: ALEXANDRIA, July 7  A former United States Information Agency officer and a Vietnamese graduate student, both insisting that they were innocent, were 1 sentenced today to 15 years on their conviction of being spies for Vietnam.

title: Paul Reif, Composer For Films, Theater, More Serious Works
description: Paul Reif, composer, died at his home in New York City yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WNCN. Le Roi d'Ys Overture. Labe; Trio in E, C.P.E. Bach; St. Francis of Assisi Preaching to the Birds, Liszt.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: V. A. Yermakov, Soviet Editor

title: Hardart Adds Units
description: The Horn & Hardart Company said that it had purchased three Burger King restaurants in Brooklyn from the Burger King Corporation. This brings to 16 the number of restaurants owned and operated by Horn & Hardart as part of a plan to raise the number to at least 20 this year.

title: Gambling, Oil and Gas Stocks Rise
description: The stock market's trading interest  and price gains  centered yesterday in companies that might enter the casino scene in Atlantic City and in selected oilandgas issues with a stake in Canada.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1978

title: Hills Follows Folger In Coffee Price Cuts
description: Another coffee price skirmish is brewing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan charged that Governor Carey's plan to continue placing former mental patients in Upper West Side hotels was a ridiculous and dangerous sham.

title: Arab Businessman Starts Bid For OKC
description: Ghaith R. Pharoan has started filing documents to make a cash tender offer for between 500,000 and 950,000 shares of the common stock of the OKC Corporation, a spokesman for the Arab businessman said.

title: Prenderville Succeeds Farley
description: ALBANY. July 7  Gov ern o r Carey announced the designation yesterday of John M. PrenderviHe, who has been the actin. chairman of the State Athletic Commission since February, as the commission's permanent chairman.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 7 (AP) The bodies of four aides to Bishop Abel Muzorewa, a black member of Rhodesia's transitional Government, have been found in graves in the southeastern part of the country, a military spokesman said today.

title: Mets Lose to Cubs, 97; Montanez Clouts His 12th
description: Mired 13 games out of first place after losing 48 of their first 83 National League games, the Mets tried something new last night. They sent Tom Hausman, a 6foot5inch, righthanded pitcher whom they acquired as their first freeagent purchase on Nov. 23, 1977, to the mound against the Chicago Cubs in the second of a fourgame series at Shea Stadium.

title: Jazz: Hamilton at a Club
description: Scott Hamilton, the 23yearold tenor saxophonist whose assimilation and development of the classic saxophone styles of the 30's and 40's has been heard on Sunday nights at Eddie Condon's for much of the last year, has moved into Crawdaddy, 45th Street at Vanderbilt Avenue, where he will be leading a trio through the end of July.

title: Deaths
description: ATLASSybil S. of Miami Beach, in her 75th year. Beloved wife of Ed Emanuel Atlas, devoted mother of Irving Max Atlas of Watertown, NY, cherished grandmother of five, loving niece of Aunt Dottie Kravat of West Palm Beach, Fla. Member of Leon Atlas Chapter of A.M.C. Hadessah Chapter of West Palm Beach, treasurer of the Lincoln Chapter of Hadasseh for 10 years, member of ORT. Services Sunday July 9th, 1 PM, at The Riverside 76th St &

title: Cosmos Win, 20; Beckenbauer Scores
description: ROCHESTER, July 7  The Cosmos recovered from a lethargic first half and defeated the Rochester Lancers, 20, tonight for their 18th victory in 22 games in the North American Soccer League this season.

title: I.A.T.A. Opens Door to More Air Fare Cuts
description: MONTREAL, July 7 (Reuters)For airline travelers, who have been flying in record numbers as a result of a vast assortment of cutrate fares, the future shines even brighter.

title: Hynes Is Nominated By Governor to Head Racing, Betting Unit
description: Governor Carey has selected Charles J. Hynes, the special state nursinghome prosecutor, to be chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, the Governor's aides reported yesterday.

title: Delaware Urges States to Adopt A Regional Policy on Ocean Use
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 7 (AP) Delaware officials presented proposals today to representatives of other East Coast states for a regional organization to coordinate ocean policy and the use of ocean resources.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 8, 1978

title: Xcor Tender Offer
description: Xcor International Inc. said in Oak Brook , Ill., that it planned to make tender offer for all the shares of World JaiAlai Inc., subject to a minimum tender of 80 percent of the 3.3 million shares outstanding. It said it would offer Xcor common valued at $15 plus new $10 issue.

title: Western Europeans Planning New System To Stabilize Currency
description: BREMEN, West Germany, July 7 Western European leaders, in a move seen as an attempt to reinvigorate the flagging movement toward European unity, pledged today to set up a new European monetary arrangement by the end of this year. They also expressed hope that the new arrangement would stabilize their currencies on foreignexchange markets and strengthen the ailing United States dollar.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The unemployment rate fell to 5.7 percent of the work force in June, the lowest level in nearly four years, the Labor Department reported. Teenagers accounted for about half of the improvement, while adult men accounted for most of the rest. But a top Administration economist warned that the improvement was likely to wane as economic growth slows. [Page 1.]

title: Chase Begins Selling Notes In London
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said that its Chase Manhattan Overseas Banking Corporation subsidiary had begun selling $150 million in floatingrate notes in London.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: To forestall possible civilrights lawsuits, New Jersey utilities have been putting together programs to hire more women and minoritygroup males.

title: Blaze in a Rio de Janiero Museum Ruins More Than 1,000 Artworks
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8  A fire in Rio de Janeiro's Museum of Modem Art destroyed more than 1,000 works of art in 30 minutes today. Museum sources said the blaze had ruined the entire collection of oil paintings, sculpture, engravings and other small art objects before being controlled.

title: When Do Gestures to Peking Become an AntiSoviet Tilt?
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter Administration is fascinated with the possibility of a close relationship with the People's Republic of China. The Chinese in turn seem intrigued by this infatuation, even though they continue to assault the United States verbally at nearly every opportunity. Recently, with the Panama Treaties approved and the strategic arms talks seemingly close to final accord, the goahead has been given to probe the Chinese question in several volitical economic and military areas.

title: Chet Atkins and Les Paul at Club
description: Chet Atkins and Les Paul appeared for a singlenight showcase Thursday. at the Bottom Line. And hard as it may be to believe, given that both men are such veterans, it was reportedly the first time Mr. Atkins had ever played in New York and the first time both men  who have recorded together  had ever performed as a duo in public.

title: Authors
description: I wish to collect the correspondence of Mark Van Doren with a view to possible publication. If anyone has letters from him, I would be grateful if copies were sent to me. DOROTHY VAN DOREN c/o Hill and Wang 19 Union Square West New York City 10003

title: Sprouts Will Please The Laziest Planters
description: When my That friend Nipa Tomasky invites guests to her home for an Oriental lunch, she chooses many of the ingredients for the soup and salad from a little sprout garden on her kitchen shelf. Quartsized glass jars hold sprouting seed of soya and mung beans, alfalfa, lentils and grains.

title: BRIDGE
description: In spite of the fact that computers are designed largely by men, one would not normally suspect them of being prejudiced against women. But there was some unexpected evidence for this during the recent World Pair Championships in New Orleans. Repeatedly the computer located in Boston but provided with information by officials on the tournament site announced the results of the open pairs  almost entirely a masculine event  within three minutes, but needed more than an hour of coaxing by baffled officials before it would spew out the women's standings.

title: Can Shakespeare Go Home Again to Stratford.?
description: The players voices rang hollowly in the scruffy confines of a church basement on Manhattan's Upper West Side, their Elizabethan accents sounding an incongruous contrast to the cinderblock walls, sagging basketball hoops and battered folding chairs that were the setting for their labors. Lynn Redgrave, looking boyish in tricorn hat and cutoff white jeans, was about to be drawn into a mock duel. Joseph Bova, cutting the air with his sword, muttered a non-Shakespearean wisecrack that broke up the other actors and the scene. On the sidelines, director Gerald Freedman laughed along with the rest and quietly signaled for another runthrough. This time the scene played flawlessly and Mr. Freedman, calling a halt for lunch, knew that another segment of Twelfth Night had fallen into place.

title: Nuts and Bolts Of Coffee Mugs
description: Will they never run out of ideas for whimsical coffee mugs? Probably not, as long as potters are making them by hand and are looking for new challenges. The latest idea is a series of five mugs using hardware motifs (nuts, bolts, screws, threads, pipes) as handles or bases or rims: just the thing for the plumber, carpenter or do-it-yourself type. In white, they are $8 each at Pizazz, 811 Lexington Avenue

Unfortunately, some points still have not been realized by environmental lawyers.

title: Nazi March Compromise Was a Tough Test
description: WASHINGTON  For months earlier this year, the angry voices and faces of the citizens of Skokie, Ill., recalled on the nation's televison screens the horrors of concentration camps, the lost relatives. Rolling up shirtsleeves and blouses to show the tattooed identification numbers, the residents of the heavily Jewish Chicago suburb were adamant: There would be no Nazi parade through their village. Equally determined was Frank Collin, the Nazi leader. He and his band of racial purists would goosestep through Skokie at the first legal opportunity.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Ihad an unsettling experience the other day while watching some music on television. Watching is not quite the right word, since I was listening, too, in the rather detached way one tends to listen to music on television. But let it stand. Anyway, there were Isaac Stern and Andre Previn conversing about the dilemmas and delights making music and teaching others to make it, all in a most informal,. natural and engrossing fashion. Then, as you would expect and want in such a program, the two stopped telling and began showing, choosing as an exhibit the last movement of Franck's Sonata for violin and piano. They were playing the Franck splendidly, as you also might expect. Still, after a few minutes I found myself hardpressed to pay attention to the music and I wished they would go back to talking about it.

title: Concert by Carnegie Hall Ushers
description: Ushers in concert halls probably hear more music than anyone else. Most of them are in their jobs for that very reason. And sometimes they retaliate by giving a concert themselves. This happened on Wednesday night, when five ushers at Carnegie Hall took to the stage of Carnegie Recital Hall to present a brief program. ne program was also unusual, de parting from the conventional in almost every respect. Tim Kerwin played on the horn a transcription by Wendell Hoss of two movements from Bach's Solo Cello Suite No. 3 in C and Gliere's Nocturne for Horn and Piano. Amy Kriegler, flute, was heard in Enesco's Cantabile and Presto for Flute and Piano and later was joined by Susan Shaw, bassoon, for VillaLobos's Bachianas Brasileiras No. 6.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE BEST OF ROALD DAHL. (Vintage, $4.95.) A reviewer once remarked that the first strengths of Roald Dahi's storytelling are an ingenious imagina. tion, a fascination with odd and ordinary detail, and a lust for its thorough exploitation. The judgment is confirmed in this new selection by the author of 25 of his macabre talet from four volumes published over the last 30 years.

title: Bomb Explodes in Canary Isles
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, July (Reuters)  A bomb exploded outside an army barracks here today, causing slight damage but no casualties, the police said. It was the second bombing in two days in this Spanish island group, and the police said they suspected a separatist group called the Movement for the Autonomy and Independence of the Canary Archipelago.

title: A Renovated Waterfront, Cleared of Rotted Piers, Has Changed Into a Spectacular Recreation Area
description: BALTIMORE  It would come as a surprise to the generations of travelers to whom Baltimore was a grimy pit stop on the road to Washington, but this old pumpkin of port has turned into a magnificent carriage. Urbanologists from all over the world troupe here to learn how superannuated metropolises can be recycled. Its once moribund downtown hums with vitality, its renovated waterfront draws throngs every weekend and its old ethnic neighborhoods, formerly the butt of derision, are now viewed as a source cultural richness.

title: Sam Rivers Big Band Performs
description: Sam Rivers, a saxophonist, flutist, pianist, composer, and founder of the jazz performing space Studio Rivbea on Bond Street, has been leading big bands for some time now. They have been heard uptown and downtown in a variety 01 locations, and their quality has varied according to the caliber of players and the amount of rehearsal time available. But the bands always sounded like Sam Rivers bands, with densely layered ensemble parts that built to massive climaxes and then suddenly subsided for improvised solos.
