But it could be an unlucky number for state-supported community college programs and year from now the picture is expected to be bleaker at the prep level.

title: Visiting the MacLeishes
description: IT is a fine day early in March. We drive west Vermont, south along the Connecticut River on Route 91, past Bellows Falls and Brattleboro, into Massachusetts. One exit after Greenfield we turn off for Conway, a small farming town that has been home base for Archibald and Ada MacLeish since 1927. At the end of town, following directions, we find a road with the sign: NOT PASSABLE IN WINTER AND SPRING. The road climbs steeply between snowbanks, and when it reaches Uphill Farm it stops abruptly. The town plow has gone no farther. We park behind the house, stretch ourselves into the bright air, and the back door of the farmhouse opens: Archibald MacLeish bounds out  a tweed jacket over a sweater, brown beret tilted on his head, his step springy, years old.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Midyear economic forecasts: from President Carter's Council of Eco nomic Advisers comes word that inflation will heat up and cut into the rate of economic expansion. Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the council, forecasted a 7.2 percent gain in consumer prices for 1978 up from January's estimate of 6.1 percent. That should mean a 4 percent rise in overall economic growth this year and next, instead of the 4.5percent rise forecast earlier. At the same time, James T. McIntyre, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, forecasted a drop in the budget deficit for fiscal 1979 to $48.5 billion from an original estimate of $60.5 bil- lion. .. The Conference Board, echoing Administration predictions, said the nation's real economic growth would be 3.3 percent next year, down from the current 3.8 percent rate. In a separate report, the nonprofit business research organization said it found that confidence in the economy had risen among the 1,500 chief executives surveyed.

description: EAST BERLIN, July 8 (AP)  An East German who contended that he need not perform military service because of the postwar demilitarization of Berlin by the four Allied victors has been sentenced to five years in orison.

title: Salvaging Lebanon
description: During Lebanon's devastating civil war in 197576, Syria's Arab peacekeeping force tacitly allied itself with Christian Phalangists and dealt a nearly fatal blow to a coalition of Lebanese and Palestinian Moslems. But that only left a nation that no one could govern while factional armies formed and feuded. Now Syria seems bent on using a new outburst of fighting among Christian factions as a pretext for destroying the Phalangists, perhaps in the hope of drawing the entire country under its control. But that is precisely what Israel has feared since authority collapsed Lebanon, once its only peaceful neighbor. In that terrible anarchy lie the seeds of a major regional conflict.

title: 'Viva Italia!,' Starring Vittorio Gassman, Returns to Day of Separate-Sketch Film:The Cast
description: "Viva Italia!" is a cheerful attempt to revive the sort of European sketch film ("Love at Twenty," "Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow," "Boccaccio 70") that was so popular in the 50's and 60's but slipped out of style (and public favor) in the 70's, as much because of the availability of the half-hour television drama as because the quality of the sketch films themselves declined."Viva Italia!" isn't likely to turn back any clocks, but it is so good-humored and, on balance, so entertaining that one feels like wishing it well. Of the film's nine episodes, four are very, very good and two are quite nice. The other three can be sat through without too much pain.The Italian movie, which opens today at the Paris, is the work of three directors  Dino Risi, Mario Monicelli and Ettore Scola  who, for reasons of modesty or maybe friendship, have declined to identify their individual contributions. It may be just as well. Of the three, only Mr. Scola ("We All Loved Each Other So Much," "A Special Day") has had any success here recently. Neither Mr. Risi ("The Easy Life," "The Priest's Wife") nor Mr. Monicelli ("The Organizer," "My Friends") has a distinctive style that would make it easy for anyone not a psychic to attach the director to his sketch.The three film makers, however, do share an amused, appreciative, sometimes jaundiced view of Italian life that fuses the parts into a charming entity. It's not by chance that each of the film's best sketches has a particularly national identity, if not as the Italians really are, then as Italians like to see themselves, especially in the persons of three of the country's finest actors, Vittorio Gassman, Alberto Sordi and Ugo Tognazzi.The three throw-away pieces are stateless, jokey stories that could as easily be French, Japanese or American.Largely because of their material, Mr. Gassman and Mr. Sordi dominate the movie, with Mr. Sordi starring in three of the four best sketches. The actor, whom you may remember in the early Fellini classic, "The White Sheik," is supremely funny as a lecherous Papal aristocrat who, on his way to a dreaded family dinner, attempts to help a pedestrian who's been run over. Never has a noble been so ineffectually obliging.The rich fellow, a cartoon character of the sort Peter Sellers loves to play, drives an ancient Rolls-Royce that he describes as his "itinerant living room" (because the back seat is so handy for casual assignations). He also suspects (happily) that everyone he meets is either on his way to an orgy or going home from one, and he fusses constantly about "the Lefevre schism," which he fears is the only thing his family will be able to talk about. He is, of course, oblivious to the death rattles of the injured pedestrian beside him.Mr. Sordi is also marvelous in the concluding sketch, a funeral that turns into a Fellini-esque celebration, and in the movie's most effectively moving episode, which is about a middle-aged son (Mr. Sordi) who cons his old mother (beautifully played by Emilia Fabi) into a freezingly efficient home for the elderly.Mr. Gassman has great fun with the role of a Cardinal of the church who, by force of his oratory (and such theatrical props as candles, bells and liturgical music), more or less neutralizes the reform-minded, socialist spirit of the members of a working-class parish, and as a waiter in one of those simple, rustic country restaurants that's become popular with the jet set. This sketch features a magnificent kitchen brawl between the waiter and his lover, the chef (Mr. Tognazzi) during which shoes get left in the minestrone, one combatant's toup is replaced by a large squid and a cigar goes into the stew. It's the kind of mayhem to warm any very small child's heart.The movie pretty much comes to a halt in a sketch about an Arab terrorist and an airline stewardess, in another sketch about a fellow whose wife has been kidnapped, and in one about a couple of actors being interviewed in connection with a porn film. None of them, though, is very long.

title: Marijuana Seized in French Ship
description: MIAMI, July 8 (AP)  About 12 tons of marijuana, valued at $500,000, have been seized from a disabled French fishing vessel, the Coast Guard reported yester; day. A Coast Guard spokesman said the marijuana was discovered Thursday after the 65foot boat, which radioed for assistance, was towed into Miami. The spokesman added that the crew was in custody of the French consulate and would be deported.

title: A New Way to See Paris From Its Canals
description: There's a new way to tour Paris. Everybody knows the Seine and the bateaux mouches that ply it all day, their polyglot loudspeakers telling tourists which monuments are which. But now an enterprishig travel agency is running a motor launch up from the Seine and through the seven miles of the contiguous St. Martin and St. Denis canals, to the old Paris district of La Villette and beyond, to the northern suburb of St. Denis. With no loudspeakers, thank you very much.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: On May 21 you carried an Opinion article in Westchester Weekly written by Edward R. Walsh and titled Bicycle Riding: Our Most Dangerous Sport. Several times Mr. Walsh makes reference to Westchester County and areas concerning bicycle safety that the county could benefit from if implemented by local or county jurisdictions. The impression the reader gets is that concern on the part of county government for bicycle safety does not compare with that generated in other areas.

title: The List of U.S. Senate Candidates in Massachusetts Is Complete

title: Conservationists Assail Efforts To Keep the Great Lakes Open
description: LANSING, Mich., July 7 (AP)  Efforts to open the icebound Great Lakes permanently for winter shipping threatens the environment and should be ended, a Michigan conservation group says.

title: What's Doing in HONG KONG
description: OVERVIEW  Not long ago, the Ambassador Restaurant served up a twoday feast, advertised as a Chinese imperial banquet, that included elephant trunk, bear's paw and a concoction made from the tongues of 100 birds, among other delicacies. This adven- cure in gastronomical history, served on gold dishes by waiters attired in traditional silk robes, cost $12,000 for the 12 diners, a group of Japanese television celebrities. The banquet was modeled on meals catered for the emperors of the Ching dynasty and took three months to prepare, including time for the cooks to find the bear's paw in China. Stewing the 15pound paw to edible tenderness took three days alone.

title: For Future Dog Breeding, Frozen Semen Is Revolutionary Aspect
description: Selective breeders will travel hundreds, even thousands of miles and spare no expense, effort or time in order to mate their bitches with particular stud dogs. So the vast impact of frozen semen, when it becomes available to the public under controlled conditions, should have dramatic and tarreaching effects on future generations of canines. Besides the time, expense and effort saved, it will be possi= ble to pass on the desirable traits of champions long dead, and parentage data should provide absolute identification.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS The World's Her Stage for Dance

Last May, at the Theater of Riverside Church in Manhattan, she presented her annual spring concert, including her amusing A Set for Players, and she regularly teaches at the Chimera Foundation Studios in Manhattan, home of the Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis dance companies. Last year she was a guest teacher in Mexico City, and this week she will be in Avignon, France, to conduct a threeweek teaching residency in connection with the Nikolais company's appearance at the Avignon Festival.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In the role of Warren Beatty's greedy, hysterical, murderous wife in Heaven Can Wait, Dyan Cannon is the most revivifying comic spectacle of the current movie season. Miss Cannon  slim and long as a shoelace and beautiful in the way of a woman who uses every artifice and then, from time to time, says to hell with it  is no newcomer, but each time she appears her funny, furrowedbrow intensity is a surprise. She was very appealing as the dimwitted wife in Bob and Carol and Ted and Alice, and, in The Last of Sheila, she was a tonic as the bitchy talent agent who could say I loathe my luggage as if she really meant it. She has a particular gift for discovering the humor in characters who are totally selfabsorbed and have no idea they are funny, which may be why she was so successful her direction of Number One, a short film about very small kids whose selfabsorption matches that of the people Miss Cannon plays so well.

title: Still Affirmative On Equal Rights
description: With the Bakke decision still under analysis, the United States Supreme Court may have dropped the other shoe on the subject of affirmative action last week. The Justices let stand a lower court ruling upholding the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's affirmative action program. The Court did not set any precedent, but for those who wondered whether the Bakke decision five days earlier striking down quota systems in university admissions undercut equal employment settlements involving specific percentages, the simple timing of the ruling mattered. Moreover, the settlement by the world's largest corporation with the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission is similar to plans embarked on by hundreds of companies, big and small.

description: IM THE cook, owner  everything, said Ruth Artinian, who, together with her husband, Harout, decided two years ago to open the only Armenian restaurant in Bergen County. It is in Fort Lee.

title: War Is Heaven
description: ROLF STEINER wants to be called an adventurer rather than a mercenary. In other words, he didn't do it for the money. He sees himself as a cut above the soldiers for hire who infested Africa the 1960's. He was after something else: noble causes, the chance to prove himself, warfare as a path to selfrevelation. It all sounds a bit too much like Lancelot in the Tropics.

title: FollowUp on the News

title: Abiding the Rail
description: IT IS estimated by Conrail that 58,000 Westchester residents are caught up on the treadmill of commuting. Twice daily, five days a week, they ride the rails to and from offices in New York City. How do they while away the time? Some study. Some prepare for today's or tomorrow's work. Some play cards  for both low and high stakes. At least one has tried free entertaining with a magic show. Nearly all have found some interest to absorb the hours.

He did not speak Yiddish, as did most of the Jews in that town and all over Poland, but Polish and also German, because Galicia was the part of Poland that belonged to Austria.

title: Equipment For an Eeler

In Connecticut waters, one needs no license to set one or two eel pots. For more than two, the state requires a $10 fee. In NeW York State no license is required in tidal waters.

title: Borg Overcomes Connors For 3d Wimbledon Crown

title: The World
description: It is not for a lack of peace plans that the EgyptianIsraeli negotiations remain stuck in the mud. The latest proposal  by President Anwar elSadat  will be on the table next week in London where the Foreign Ministers of Israel and Egypt, accompanied by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, are expected to hold the first direct talks between their countries in six months. Judging from Israel's initial response to the plan, however, it wasn't clear what progress the ministers could make except to agree to meet again. And that is not unimportant.

title: Black Protest Is Monitored by Klan As a Mississippi Boycott Continues
description: TUPELO, Miss., July 8  Two hundred and forty black protesters marched quietly through the sultry and almost deserted streets of this troubled town in northern Mississippi today with a contingent of Klu Klux Klansmen monitoring the march on citizens band radios.

When spring turned into summer, the red color of his tree began to fade, and he became disappointed with his purchase. His red maple was no longer red.

title: GARDENING Beware of the Black Vine Weevil
description: INSECT pests that can be seen are the easiest to control. But the sneaky ones are difficult, especially those that feed at night and hide during the day. You never know that the little beasties are around until plants suddenly take a turn for the worst. Closer inspection discloses that something has been eating them, and then the battle begins.

title: Heidelberg's Old City Gets a Facelift
description: This summer the ancient German university town of Heidelberg, an indispensable stop for American tourists since Mark Twain discovered it for us in 1878, will not be celebrating the 100th anniversary of his visit. Yet it was Twain's glowing praise of Heidelberg in A Tramp Abroad that sparked an American interest that has remainedalight through the intervening century, fanned hi the 1920's by Sigmund Romberg's operetta The Student Prince in Heidelberg. Last year half a million Americans came looking for the romantic Old Heidelberg that Twain described: beer gardens full of students thumping steins to the rhythm of traditional drinking songs; the crumbling towers of the medieval castle in the rose light of evening; the cobbled streets and gabled roofs of the Altstadtthe Old Cityseen through morning mists of the Neckar River. Heidelberg was the city it seemed time changeuntil

title: U.S. Diet Shows Taste for Change

Figures to support or deny. such contentions have been available all along from the United States Department of Agriculture, but until recently have not been gathered into one handy place. Now, the Center for Science in the Public Interest. a consumer organization, has produced The Changing American Diet, which covers from about 1910 to 1976.

For instance, the Leonard Bernstein Festival of American Music, running through July 23 at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, offers workshop and professional performances of all sorts of Bernstein pieces, along with other contemporary works and some major jazz.

title: ChinaVietnam Row Last Week, Turmoil in the Yemens and in Africa Make Fresh Waves in the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON  Rudyard Kipling was fond of calling it the Great Game  the I50year contest between Russia and Britain for control of a strategic link between South Asia and the Middle East. Today the Great Game goes on between Russia and the West, as evidenced by the pro-Communist coup in Afghanistan two months ago  part of much larger and more complicated contest for influence the African and Asian countries encircling the Indian Ocean and its vital oil routes, a contest which pits not only Western nations but China too against the Soviet Union.

Piles for the building, which was constructed on the headwaters of the Nissequogue River for reasons that county officials today avoid discussing, had to be driven more than 200 feet. As it neared completion seven years ago, snickering critics said it was leaning, or at the very least sinking evenly.

title: The Economy's High Blood Pressure
description: The latest figures on unemployment and inflation provide further evidence that the Carter Administration's taxcut proposals are now out of date and need be redesigned. Read separately, they offer cause for both cheer and concern; the sharp decline in the unemployment rate to 5.7 percent is heartening but the continuing high rate of increase in wholesale prices signals further trouble ahead. Taken together, the figures demonstrate that the American economy still suffers from inadequate investment and productivity. We seem unable to return to acceptable levels of unemployment without at the same time returning to unacceptable levels of inflation.

title: Headliners
description: Westward the star of Empire sinks off the edge of the world, leaving to show for its presence only pink spots on the map and a dwindling handful of anachronisms. Last week, the news arrived from next to nowhere: The Cocos Islands, nearly on the equator about 1,600 miles west of Australia, are joining the modern world of national sovereignties and cash economies. The Australian Government announced that will pay John CluniesRoss, known as King of the Cocos, $7 million for the islands. Settled with Malay laborers by Mr. CluniesRoss great-great-grandfather 150 years ago, the islands were granted in perpetuity to his family by Queen Victoria in 1886. Since then, CluniesRosses have been the virtual monarchs over five and a half square miles of coconut palms, distributed over 27 islands in two atolls. The present Mr. CluniesRoss, sometimes called Ross V, succeeded at 16 when his father was killed by Japanese bombs. After the war, a United Nations factfinding mission visited the islands and described Mr. CluniesRoss rule as feudal and anachronistic, and no doubt it was, with Ross V, barefooted and bedaggered, exercising what authority got exercised. Britain formally transferred administration of the islands to Australia in 1955. Ross V, after years of rejecting Australian sovereignty, formally gave in in 1972 but retained title to the property. Now, after rejecting previous offers, he will cash in as well. The first thing Australia will have to do, apparently, is find out where Cocos is for sure and count the newborn democrats. News reports in the last few years have given the islands population at 490 (1972), 150 (1975), 500 (1975 again), 654

description: Fourteenth Street is one of the busiest streets in New York. Buses and trucks jam the street on their way crosstown. The sidewalks are filled with crowds going in and out of shops and looking over bins filled with merchandise along the sidewalks. Voices, music from transitor radios, and the roar of traffic fill the air.

A catalogue is available for $4, or a subscription to this plus the next three for $12. The address is New England Rare Coin Galleries, P.O. Box 1776, Boston, Mass. 02105.

title: Louisville Firemen Avoid Strike
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.. July 8 (AP) strike by this city's 580 firefighters was averted for the time being today as negotiators for the city and firefighters agreed to return to the bargaining table. The decision to return to the bargaining table came during a preliminary state Board of Labor Relations hearing on an Unfair labor practice charge filed by Local 345 of the International Association of Firefighters. The union has charged with city with failing to bargain in good faith, referring to Mayor William Stansbury's offer of a 5.5 percent pay rise for all city employees.

title: Electricity Plant in West to Use Hot Water From Underground

title: Challenging the Gifted Student

And what benefits will a school's entire population derive from a program created for the special needs of just a few students?

description: WEST WARWICK, R.I. Mr. Chin originally was charged with five mur ders, but the grand jury did not accept the charge involving the patron.

title: TV VIEW
description: O nce again, public television is showing its commercial counterpart a better way to realize the potential of the medium. And once again, predictably, the publictelevision example is an import from Britain. This time, it's a fourpart series called Faces of Communism, produced by John Fanshawe for Yorkshire Television, member of the Trident Television Group. (Packaged by WNET, with Joan Konner producer, it will begin on many PBS stations tonight and can be seen on Channel 13 beginning tomorrow at 8 P.M.) The writer and narrator is Robert Kee, who provides a clue to the success of the project. Remarkably well preserved for a man who will be 60 next year, Mr. Kee has been described by one lofty British publication as the most alert and learned of all television journalists. At the very least, on the basis of these four programs, he appears to be unusually competent. Born in Calcutta, he has had a busy journalistic career, including the position of correspondent for The Observer during the Suez crisis and, from 1972 to 1976, anchorman for the British commercial channel's lunchtime news. In the latter position, a press release notes, he built a huge following, particularly among housewives. Mr. Kee is also a historian, with a special interest in Ireland. His most recent book is The Green Flag: A History of Irish Nationalism.

title: Bobby Short Marks 10 Years at Carlyle

title: Hucksters
description: NOW comes that smothering midsummer bore, baseball's socalled AllStar Game, which started 45 years ago as a circulation booster for The Chicago Tribune and has developed into the Trac II Classic, a massive sales campaign for razor blades. Apart from the reek or nUCKsteriSm, the only trouble with the promotion is that the teams are not allstar teams, the method of selection is cumbersome, inefficient and flagrantly dishonest and it is no ball game when a pitcher throwing a nohitter has to leave after three innings. The good thing about it is that receipts help finance the players pension system.

title: For Alcoholics: Treatment in a Mansion . . .

Renorts of the incident that followed also mentioned that Mr. Capote had recently been treated for his condition at the Smithers Alcoholism Rehabilitation Unit. The publicity enhanced and widened the reputation Smithers already had as a dryingout spot for the rich and famous. It also made the staff of Smithers furious.

title: How to Get Oil by Selling Oil
description: Imports now account for about 40 percent of the oil consumed in the United States. That is slightly less than last year, but enough to put our international trade balance deeply in the red and  more important  leave us vulnerable to another Arab embargo. A tough energy program to reduce consumption remains the only longterm response to this dependence. However, as recent reports of the disappointing oil production in Alaska suggest, minor changes in Federal regulations could sharply increase domestic production and reduce the trade deficit within a few years. A shrewd program for greater selfsufficiency begins, paradoxically, with oil exports.

title: The Delaware Undammed
description: The House of Representatives will have an opportunity today to protect the Delaware River from a threat that has been hanging over it for 16 years  the threat of a dam at Tocks Island just above the Delaware Water Gap between Pennsylvania and New Jersey. An omnibus parks and rivers bill would designate 114 miles of the middle and upper Delaware as part of the wild and scenic rivers system, thus making it difficult to proceed with the costly and destructive project. The Delaware could then be preserved as one of the last great freeflowing rivers in the Northeast.

title: Michigan Backers Say They Have Signatures for Vote on Tax Cut
description: DETROIT, July 9  Backers of a 50 percent property tax cut in Michigan, encouraged by former President Gerald R. Ford's endorsement, announced today that they had the minimum number of petition signatures needed to place the proposal on the November ballots.

title: BIG CITIES IN STATE LOSING POPULATION
description: There has been a marked shift of population in New Jersey since 1970 from the big cities and the five northeastern counties to rural areas, according to the states Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Mrs. Vanderbilt To Seek Rent Law
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 (UPI) Louise Vanderbilt, whose late husband's grandfather, built the Breakers mansion here, said that she would ask the City Council on Wednesday to enact a rent control ordinance.

title: Site of Indian Massacre in Virginia Believed Found
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 9 (AP) On the morning of March a 2.1622, English colonists in a palisaded fort on what is now Carter's Grove Plantation invited some Indians into the fort to eat and socialize.

title: The Case for Nautilus: Full Range
description: Nautilus machines were designed by Arthur Jones of De Land. Fla., for his personal use about 20 years ago, but only in the last eight years have these devices, which are employed for short periods of intensive resistance exercise been marketed. Most National Football League teams use them in strength training, as do some professional baseball teams and colleges. Many athletes, notably Billie Jean King, have been rehabilitated on the machines after major surgery or injury.

title: Swoon Song: Rebuilding
description: ST. LOUIS ROOTING for the Chicago Cubs is a lamentation, interrupted by drumbeats of hope, and is at length sustained by faith. After a characteristically speedball start, the Cubs are idling in second place. Second place is Chicago Cub country. So are third, eighth and tenth, some of the places where the Cubs have finished since winning their last pennant 33 years ago.

title: Letter: On Wiretap Bill
description: To the Editor: strongly disagree with your editorial of June 29, A Model Wiretap Bill in Peril. It urges the House Judiciary Committee to relinquish its jurisdiction over the foreign intelligence surveillance hill (II.R. 7308), and accuses me of joining an obst ruction to that measure.

title: Kriegel Plans Legal Magazine
description: Jay L. Kriegel, who made a reputation in New York City in the early 1970's as one of the more abrasive members of the Lindsay Administration's inner circle is becoming an entrepeneur. In association with Esquire Magazine and Britain's Associated Newspaper Group, he will publish The American Lawyer; the latest entry in an increasingly crowded legal publication field. (Vere Harmsworth, head of the Associated Newspaper Group, is also chairman of Esquire).

title: Portent of Soviet Dissident's Trial
description: MOSCOW, July 9  No political trial in the last decade has contained the array of issues and emotions that the proceeding against Anatoly F. Shcharansky, a Jewish dissident accused of high treason,

title: Man Charged in Shoving Of Woman Onto Tracks
description: A man accused of robbing a woman at knifepoint and then shoving her into the path of an oncoming subway train on Saturday was held pending arraignment yesterday On charges of attempted murder, robbery, burglary and resisting arrest.

title: Study of U.S. Decline in Precollege Test Scores Arouses a Dispute
description: The latest attempt to examine the reasons for the national decline in scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test has become the subject of a dispute over its conclusions and methodology.

title: Salyut 6 Is Joined by Soviet Craft To Resupply Space Laboratory
description: MOSCOW, July 9 (AP)  The unmanned spaceship Progress 2 docked with the Soviet Union's orbiting Salyut 6 research station today to resupply the space laboratory and deliver letters from home to its twoastronaut crew, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: 2 Ships Collide Off Cape Town
description: CAPE TOWN, July 9 (AP)  A Norwegian chemical tanker, the 18,674ton Team Pollux, collided with a Japanese fishing trawler in a dense Atlantic fog last night southwest of here, Cape Town's radio reported today. Three crewmen of the trawler were slightly injured.

title: GENERAL TAKES LEAD IN BOLIVIAN VOTING
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 9  The first general election in Bolivia in 12 years took place today with great confusion at the polls and charges by the opposition of fraud in favor of the military Government's candidate for president.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atlas Corporation, Princeton, N.J., a diversified natural resources, services and manufacturing company, said Glen Elkins had been named senior vice president.

title: 6 Held After Discovery Of 10Ton Drug Cache
description: TRENTON, July 9 (AP)  Six men were being held on $500,000 bail each here today as the police in New Jersey and Connecticut sought several persons who had fled an airfield where 10 tons of marijuana and a DC6 aircraft were seized.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Loss.Proof Knife

title: Soviet Layer Cake
description: WASHINGTON  What are the Russians up to?

title: EGYPT'S PEACE PLAN FORMALLY REJECTED BY ISRAEL'S CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, July 9  The Israeli Cabinet today rejected as completely unacceptable President Anwar elSadat's peace proposal calling for an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip.

title: DESAI AVERTS SPLIT IN GOVERNING PARTY
description: NEW DELHI, July 9  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai has emerged from the recent crisis in the ruling Janata Party with more political strength than before. and the party appears to have averted a split over his decisive actions against dissidents within it.

title: Pullbacks In Fiscal Policy Seen
description: United States fiscal policy may be reaching a more conservative turning point, prompted to a large degree by an unorthodox alliance of businessmen, the Federal Reserve and taxpayers, all weary of inflation and ready to fight it, the Conference Board concludes in a report scheduled for release today.

title: TRIGGS CITES ARREST IN REFUSING U.S. JOB
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 9 (AP) Gene A. Triggs said over the weekend that he has withdrawn his name from consideration as Deputy Secretary of Agriculture because he feared publicity about his arrest in 1976 on a charge of soliciting sex from an undercover policewoman.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Rematch

title: Group Seeks to Bring Old Carrier To New York for Naval Museum
description: Save the Intrepid, the cry that echoed through the Pacific fleet on at least five occasions when the 41,000ton aircraft carrier sustained heavy damage during action against the Japanese in World War II, is being used as a slogan by a nonprofit group negotiating with the Navy to bring the carrier to New York as an international aerospace and naval memorial museum.

title: DR. HELEN HANTSCHE
description: Dr. Helen Hantsche, a leader in GermanAmerican affairs in New York City for many years, died in her Manhattan home Friday. She was 92 years old.

title: Judge Orders Damages Paid in Stadium Dispute
description: SEATTLE, July 9 (AP)  A Federal judge has ordered a company in Portland, Ore., to pay King County, Wash. more than $12 million in damages in a dispute over its construction contract for the Kingdome stadium in Seattle.

title: Failures in Child Welfare System Spur Reevaluation of Programs
description: When the Legislature reconvenes and begins to consider Governor Carey's proposals on how to deal with 13- to 15yearolds accused of murder, the objects of its attention, according to public and private child care experts, will be chil

title: Planned Visit of a Nuclear Ship Is Protested by 7,000 in Japan
description: SASEBO, Japan, July 9 (Reuters) Some 7,000 people demonstrated peacefully today against the proposed visit of a nuclearpowered vessel for repairs at a local shipyard after it leaked radiation on its first voyage.

title: Schlitz Agrees To Payoff Bar
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  The Schlitz Brewing Company has agreed to the terms of a Securities and Exchange Commission order to prevent the company from making payoffs to wholesalers and retailers.

title: Court's Decision on Language Stirs Broadcasters
description: A few nights before the Supreme Court issued its decision upholding the Federal Communications Commission's reprimand of a New York City radio station for broadcasting indecent language, ABC News presented a

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 10, 1978

title: Adele Geffen Wed To Dr. Charles Eil
description: Adele Geffen, a lawyer with the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Eil, a fellow in the endocrinology training program at the National Institute of Health in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Joel Geffen, a cousin of the bride's father, performed the ceremony at the Newton White Mansion, community house in Mitchellville, Md.

title: . . . And a Program for the Families
description: No, Joan Kroc is not an alcoholic, and never has been. She is a selfdescribed social drinker who likes to sip rose wine and an occasional martini. Nor, she says, does she have any close rela tives or friends who are drunks.

title: Municipal Bond Test Set
description: The municipal bond market will be severlytested this week as it tries to absorb an extremely heavy amount of new bonds. In addition, a $421 million issue of bonds of the Grand River Dam Authority in Oklahoma is tentatively scheduled to be priced this week for salemext week. I expect the market to lose some ground over the next few weeks as it scrambles to place a heavy calendar of new negotiated financings, said Robert Grimmig, a vice president with Merrill Lynch and Company.

title: New CanAm Race to Brown
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 9  For better or worse, the old CanAm she ain't what she used to be. The CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup, the glamorous showpiece of North American road'racing in the late 1960's and early 1970's, now suggests a neighborhood in transition.

title: 6 Are Injured as Manholes Explode In Early Hours on Upper East Side
description: Explosions blew out two manhole covers on the Upper East Side early yesterday, injuring six persons, including two police officers.

title: A Dialogue, of Sorts, on Life, Poetry, and the End of the Universe
description: Five months ago The New York Times published a piece on the creation of the universe and its probable end which left me  and doubtless many other devoted readers  breathless for elucidation. Not because the piece was obscure: it was well and simply written. And not because its theme was beyond us: nothing is more persistently present in the contemporary mind than the end of the world.

title: Giants, Jets Ready
description: The Giants and the Jets of the National Football League open training camp this week in their respective suburban hideaways, the Giants at Pace University in Pleasantville, N.Y., the Jets at Hotstra University in Hempstead, L.I. All the workouts will be open to the public.

title: Jury Requiring Much Time to Decide SCM v. Xerox
description: HARTFORD, July 9  Over the course of a year, the jurors sat patiently in the secondfloor courtroom of the Federal Building here while the lawyers, their witnesses and the judge filled a trial transcript that grew to 43,931 pages  the longest jury trial un record in the nation's Federal courts. Now, it is the turn of the lawyers and the judge to wait, with seemingly less patience, while the nine jurors deliberate their verdicts in the SCIM1I Corporation's extraordinary $1.52 billion antitrust case against the Xerox Corporation. They will enter their 27th day of deliberations tomorrow.

title: Homework
description: Publication of Kenneth Bay's and Herman Kessler's Salt Water Flies in 1972 (J.B. Lippincott Company, 150 pages, illustrated, $8.95) marked the first time that an angler could find a wide selection of saltwater flies under one cover. The work covers everything from tarpon to sea trout, and considerable space is devoted to the actual tying of the flies.

title: Jail Death Protested in Mexico
description: OAXACA, Mexico, July 9 (AP) Thousands of residents protesting against the death of a young man in jail marched to the Oaxaca state governor's home yesterday demanding the ouster of the state police chief, according to witnesses. Police officials say the young man committed suicide.

title: Ford Is Considering Race in 1980 Without Entering State Primaries
description: DENVER, July 9  Former President Gerald R. Ford is thinking about seeking the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination without contesting the party's primaries.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: ALL AL FRESCO There's still more free music scheduled for the Rockefeller Center area, with a new lunchtime series beinab presented on Mondays as a diversion for visitors and workers. Starting at noon today, Rupert Holmes, the singer, composer and recording star, will initiate the programs held in the Center's Lower Plaza. Their sponsor is Station WYNYFM, which is titling the seriesMusic for a Movin Easy Summer. But if you're busy at the office today, on Wednesday from 4:30 to 6 P.M. there is the Center's weekly Music For a City Evening event at the Chanel Gardens, this time featuring the sounds of Lee Castle and his Jimmy Dorsey Orches-tra.

title: Reds Beat Giants, Trail by 3
description: The Reds were beginning to feel uncomfortable in the middle innings of their game against the San Francisco Giants yesterday at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati. They were trailing to naucio ana the Giants, 20, after five innings and had managed to get only one hit. A loss would tumble the Reds five games behind the Giants, the leaders of the National League Western Division, with a threeday AllStar game break to ponder their plight.

title: Restructured Irvine Prospering
description: IRVINE, Calif, July 9  A year ago, following a fierce bidding war over the Irvine Company, many Wall Street experts feared that the wealthy new owners, who spent $337.4 million to acquire the land development concern, had emnarked upon too risky a venture. For one thing, the experts reasoned, the $240 million in debt required to finance the acquisition would lead to hasty selling of choice income property.

title: Man Is Awarded $5,040 In the Killing of His Cat
description: HASTINGS, Minn. (AP)  The owner of a black cat stood to be $5,040 richer because Eagan city officials did not give his pet due process of law.

title: OUSTED OFFICER GOT BIG FORD CO. BONUS
description: An executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company, forced to retire after the company's top management held him responsible for a plan to pay a bribe in Indonesia in 1975, later received a large unexpected bonus, according to company sources.

title: Gunman in London Wounds exPrime Minister of Iraq
description: LONDON. July 9  A former Prime Minister of Iraq was shot and seriously wounded outside his West End hotel this morning. the latest victim in a series of violent incidents here involving people with connections to the Middle East.

title: Around the Nation
description: DAVIE, Fla., July 9 (UPI)  About 100 robed and hooded Ku Klux Klansmen, led by a Grand Dragon on horseback and another member carrying a Bible, held an hourlong parade here yesterday.

title: Coast Bank to Cut Rents
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP) The Bank of America has announced it will cut rent to its California tenants to reflect its tax savings from Proposition 13, which mandated a reduction in state property taxes. The bank, which owns tour Mice buildings in California, said yesterday that it would pass as much as $11 million in tax savings this year on to tenants, not shareholders. Its 52story headquarters building has 275 tenants. It owns two other buildings in Los Aneeles and one in San Diego.

title: PHOENIX HOUSE UNIT HOLDS BLOCK PARTY
description: Neighborhood residents and former drug addicts shared a disco beat, a host of game booths and a general feeling of community yesterday at the second annual Riverside House block party at 73d Street between Broadway and West End Avenue.

title: Courvilles Golf Victors
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 Jerry Courville Sr. and his son, Jerry Jr., won the 92d Anderson Memorial betterball golf tournament today by routing Mike Moraghan and Torn Gleeton, 7 and 6.

title: Malaysia's Ruling Coalition Wins, But Voting Shows Minority Unrest
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 9 Malaysia's ruling National Front won a sweeping new fiveyear mandate in federal and state elections yesterday, but the opposition scored gains that appear to reflect the Chinese community's unhappiness over Government policies.

title: OUSTED OFFICER GOT BIG FORD CO. BONUS
description: An executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company, forced to retire after the company's top management held him responsible for a plan to pay a bribe in Indonesia in 1975, later received a large unexpected bonus, according to company sources.

title: Plans to Alter John Brown Memorial Arouse Protest Upstate
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Since 1859, John Brown's body has been a-moldering in the grave here, far from his antislavery campaigns in Osawatomie, Kan., and his raid on the Federal arsenal in Harpers Ferry, Va., that led to his capture and hanging.

title: Rock: Dione DiMucci
description: UNLIKE Frankie Valli, who opened the Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival at the Woninon Rink Wednesday night, Dione DiMucci  who was there Saturday night  hasn't been doing all that well of late. But Dione, as he's always been known, is in many ways the more interesting artist.

title: Immediate Family Staged Downtown
description: TWO old sisters live in a large house. Charlotte's husband is dead, and Florrie's has been gone for years. Each has two grown sons, and Just the Immediate Family portrays a family reunion to celebrate the weddine of one of them

title: A President for All Italians
description: ROME, July 9  Sandro Pertini, the Socialist partisan fighter who was sworn in as Italy's president today, has a reputation for honesty, courage, dignity, informality, wit and, as he said today, a willingness to listen to others than myself.

title: In Support Of Israel
description: WASINGTONWhen Senator Abraham Ribicoff voted for the Middle East plane sales last May, he expected to be innundated by angry mail from his constituents. And there were some bitter words.

title: Senate Staff to Examine Mrs. Talmadge's Charge
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  The staff of the Senate ethics committee will bake a preliminary inquiry into a charge by Betty Talmadge that her husband, Senator Herman E. Talmadge, lied about paying gift taxes on securities he gave her, Carl Eardly, a counsel to the committee, said today.

title: Henry H. F. Trefflich, Importer of Animals, Dies at 70
description: Henry H. F. Trefflich, who retired five years ago as the country's largest importer of wild animals and as proprietor of a famed animal dealership in lower Manhattan, died on Friday at his home at 431 East Union Avenue in Bound Brook, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: Signs of Moderate Growth
description: The economy showed signs of settling into a more moderate pace at the end of the strong second quarter, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Wants Plaza Named for Rockefeller
description: ALBANY, July 8  Governor Carey has made it known that he would like the Empire State Plaza complex here named after former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Americans Still Using Less Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The latest bulletin on oil consumption from the Department of Energy reports that Americans used slightly less refined oil during a recent fourweek period than they did a year before.

title: AllStu Poll: Players Disagree With 50% of Fans
description: IF the ballplayers, and not the fans, had picked the starters for tomorrow night's AllStar Game, half the 16 players chosen would have been left out, a poll by The New York Times indicates.

title: Girl's Goat Stolen at Fair
description: DEL MAR, Calif. (AP)  Somebody got her goat at the Southern California Exposition near San Diego, says Colleen Bartlett, 10 years old, a 4H Club member from San Marcos. I think someone just reached over and picked up my goat and walked off with it under their coat, she said.

title: Growing Rhodesian War Stuns Those Who Ridiculed Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 6  The guerrilla war in this country has grown measurably in its brutality on all sides and in the extent of military operations. Not three years ago, farmers at a country club in the rural hamlet of East Centenery laughed, telling each other stories of inept and cowardly guerrillas running in fright at loud noises. They said that blacks would never pcse a serious mili tary threat to whites. Today no one here, white or black, is laughing much.

title: The Big Race Captivates France
description: ST. GERMAIN-EN-LAYE, France, July 9  The Tour de France bicycle race descended on this town a week ago, and by now life has almost returned to normal. The banners that hung from windows  Let's Go, Hinault, Another Victory, Thevenet - have been taken down, the talk in the brasseries is back to the weather, inflation and even politics, and the traffic and the constant rain of this summer have wiped out the markings on the Avenue des Loges that showed 500, 400, 300, 200, 150, 100, 50 meters to the finish line.

title: 100,000 Join March for Extension Of Rights Amendment Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  A crowd of nearly 100,000 demonstrators, including many men and children, gathered on the Mall here today and marched more than a dozen blocks in muggy, 90 degree heat to support an extension of the sevenyear deadline for ratification of the equal rights amendment.

title: Device for Extracting Hydrogen From Water Is Still Mystifying
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9  Mystery continues to surround a 63yearold California man's invention of a process capable, he says, of economically extracting hydrogen from water, but scientists are beginning to be more receptive to his claims.

title: 225 Teachers to Learn How to Look at the Arts
description: More than 200 schoolteachers will today start studying the creation and the perception of art in hopes of passing along ways of looking at art and beauty to their students next fall.

title: Jersey Is Investigating Penthouse Casino Bid
description: The New Jersey state police have begun an investigation into court findings in Britain that Penthouse Casino Ltd. let criminal elements use its premises when it operated a London casino in 1971.

title: A Touch of Italy in Brooklyn
description: There was dancing and parading in the streets, and a brass band, as ItalianAmericans in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn celebrated an ancient annual festival in honor of St. Paulinus of Nola. The highlight of the festival is the carrying, by 150 men, of a giant monument, or giglio, to the saint through the streets to Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church.

title: China Trying to Cut Birth Rate
description: HONG KONG, July 9 (AP)  China is trying to cut its birth rate to less than 1 percent within three years, two Communist newspapers reported here. China has not disclosed its birth rate or population, which foreign estimates have placed at above 800 million.

title: Prof. George Kenner, Known for His Work On Protein Synthesis
description: MOLD. Wales, July 9 (Reuters) George W. Kenner, an internationally known scientist, was found dead today after having set out 13 days ago to ponder scientific problems while walking in the rugged hills near here.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON

title: Cabaret: Dakota Staton
description: WHEN Dakota Staton first won attention in the mid1950's, she was compared to Dinah Washington and Sarah Vaughan. Today, at the Playboy Club, 5 East 59th Street, where she's appearing through Saturday. there is still plenty of evidence of her Dinah Washington roots, just a suggestion of her relationship to Miss Vaughan and a considerable coating of a style that might be associated with Sophie Tucker.

title: Plans to Alter John Brown Memorial Arouse Protest Upstate
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Since 1559, John Brown's body has been amoldering in the grave here, far from his antislavery campaigns in Osawatomie, Kan., and his raid on the Federal arsenal in Harpers Ferry, Va., that led to his capture and hanging.

title: Scientists Finding Garden Slugs Useful in BrainFunction Studies
description: PRINCETON  Dr. Alan Gelperin, a Princeton University neurobiologist, is trying to find out how the brain works. But instead of studying man's sophisticated organ of intelligence, he is examining the brain and nervous system of the slug, a relatively common garden pest that is close to the bottom of the intelligence scale.

title: U.S. Moving to Improve its Relationship With Angola
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  The United States is trying to improve relations with the Marxistled Government of Angola and to help reduce that country's heavy dependence on Cuba and the Soviet Union.

title: CARTER CONDEMNED FOR INDIAN POLICIES
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, July 9  The Carter Administration has been roundly condemned by a panel of Indian scholars and activists for its Indian policies and its lack of Indian policies.

title: American's Mode Due From France
description: Ken Partiss is a good old boy from Georgia with a most unlikely story.

title: John Harper Joins Oversight Board
description: John D. Harper, retired chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America, has joined the recently created Public Oversight Board, which monitors the performance of accountants who represent publicly held companies before the Securities and Exchange Commission. This division of the accounting profession, established by the Institute of Certified Public Accountants, is known as the Practice Section. Mr. Harper's appointment completes the fivemember board.

title: Mets Defeated by Cubs, 41
description: Krukow, Murcer & Sutter. That's not a law firm, but the trio of Chicago Cubs who proved most responsible yesterday for a 41 defeat of the Mets at Shea Stadium.

title: Portent of Soviet Dissident's Trial
description: MOSCOW, July 9  No political trial in the last decade has contained the array of issues and emotions that the proceeding against Anatoly F. Shcharansky, a Jewish dissident accused of high treason. holds for people inside and outside the Soviet Union.

title: Most Art Destroyed In Rio Fire
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9 (UPI) Restoration experts at the fireblackened Museum of Modern Art said today that they may be able to salvage only 50 of about 1,000 works of art damaged or destroyed yesterday in a flash fire that turned two exhibition halls into smoking piles of ash in 30 minutes.

title: Advertising
description: GENERALLY speaking, the world of publishing seemed pleased about the merger of Simmons and Target Group Index, the warring factions of syndicated magazine audience research, to form the Simmons Market Bureau. But, clich or no clich, a wait-and-see attitude did seem to prevail.

title: Commodities
description: THE stunning advance in wheat futures prices last week, a period shortened by the Independence Day holiday, not only dominated dreary commodity markets but also surprised the traders who follow normal supplydemand statistics.

title: Screen: 'Replay,' In French:Case of Amnesia
description: THERE is a taxi driver character in "Replay," and oh! what a terrible time he has. His passenger is a high-strung sophisticate with no definite destination in mind, and with a tendency to leap frantically out of the cab without warning, forgetting all about paying her fare. "Left? Right?" asks the driver. The woman replies that she doesn't care. She is too desperate, too agonized to care, and the movie's premise depends upon the notion that hers is an interesting condition. This poor, exasperated cabbie has ample reason to think otherwise, though. So will poor, exasperated you.It seems that there has been a slow-motion automobile accident, one that landed Cecile (Marie-Jose Nat) in the hospital, swathed in bandages but with her mascara intact. When she awakens from her coma, she does not recognize Franois, her husband (Victor Lanoux). He, realizing that his wife has total amnesia, lumbers out to the hospital corridor and stares off into space. And she, understanding the extent of her predicament, begins to cry. She does this very photogenically, standing with her back against a wall and photographed in profile, wearing a black negligee. One arm is flung across her chronically furrowed brow.All too early in "Replay," the director Michel Drach, establishes himself as a man of problematically refined tastes. Miss Nat's search for her true identity leads her to pretty sites all over Paris, and wherever she flees, she manages to do most of her running in the same ensemble of leather skirt and fur-trimmed coat, with a pair of shoes to match.It's certainly possible to make an effective romantic thriller while worrying about nice shots and just the right outfits, but Mr. Drach simply isn't the man for the job. When he wants to show that Cecile, who thinks she has run away from Franois, is actually being pursued by him, Mr. Drach positions the two of them on a beautiful, rain-drenched street, with Cecile walking briskly and Franois following alongside in his car. This is lovely to look at, but  since the street is otherwise deserted, and Cecile takes no notice of the car at her elbow  it does give one pause about the plot.Perhaps the convoluted story line is unimportant, since "Replay" is, au fond, a tale of amour. But Mr. Drach, in attempting to interweave two highly compatible genres, manages to make Cecile and Franois's love affair play second fiddle to the secret of Cecile's past. And the secret, when it is at long last revealed, merely serves to place everyone in a very unflattering light. This is hardly necessary, since Mr. Lanoux has been vaguely boorish throughout, and Miss Nat (who is actually Mrs. Drach) has been nothing but tiresome in her hysteria.Mr. Drach's premise, from a book by Dominique St. Alban, is not without intriguing possibilities, but the director's attention to cosmetic details is at odds with the sense of estrangement and rediscovery that is pivotal to the tale. And his heroine's amnesia, which ought to be the film's most compelling element, is simply one more gimmick in a movie that's overloaded with them.

title: Marine Fly Fishing: A Rewarding Frustration
description: ANEARLY full moon was setting over Massachusetts Vineyard Sound, and a soft land breeze carried the smell of bayberries, pitch pines and scrub oaks to me.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a move at the National Conference of State Legislatures to support state spending limits was inaccurately characterized in The Times Saturday. The lawmakers were eagerly, not secretly, promoting constitutional spending limits.

title: Cefalo Rides the Highs
description: IT should have been a perfect moment  my first college touchdown. But I was too scared to enjoy it. I had muffed the call.

title: Miss Blalock Wins by 7 Shots
description: WHEELING, W.Va., July 9 (AP) Jane Blalock, playing what she called the most consistent golf of my life, won her second consecutive Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament today, breezing to a sevenshot victory in the $75.000 Wheeling Classic

title: Let Legislators Legislate, Not Regulate
description: The dispute over legislative vetoes flared again in Washington last week. The House voted to give either chamber of Congress the right to veto future regulations issued by the Department of Housing and Urban Development for its community development program. The purpose, behind a banner of principle, was to deter Secretary Harris from again trying to require localities to spend most of their community development money in poor neighborhoods  a rule that many legislators feel violates the spirit of the law. But the House action, with its overtones of hindering aid to the poor, points toward further interference with a program that is already too sensitive to political pressures.

title: Elder Beats Trevino. On 8th Playoff Hole
description: MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP)  Lee Elder parred the eighth extra hole today to beat Lee Trevino in a suddendeath playoff and win the $150,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament. It was Elder's third tournament victory in 11 years on the tour. revmo Dogeyea the 197yard, par3 eighth hole when he missed a sixfoot putt, enabling Elder to take the $30,000 first prize.

title: Mexico Welcomes Boom In Its Tiny Stock Market
description: MEXICO CITY, July 9  Mexico's tiny stock exchange is experiencing an unexpected boom that Government officials hope will eventually lead to a restructuring of the country's entire capital market.

title: LEBANESE PRESIDENT INSISTS HE'LL RESIGN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 9  President Elias Sarkis was letting the announcement of his resignation stand today despite widespread pleas for him to stay on to avoid introducing a political vacuum to this troubled country.

title: Publishers
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  The Association of American Publishers says that it plans to file a friend of the court legal brief supporting the right of Frank Snepp, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, to write about the C.I.- A.'s operations. The brief will be filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth District.

title: James McLernon Is Named President Of VW Of America
description: James W. McLernon, 50 years old, president of the Volkswagen Manufacturing Corporation of America, will become president and chief executive officer of Volkswagen of America, a new company resulting from the merger of VW's manufacturing arm here with Volkswagen of America, the sales and marketing company in this country.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANRose. belc,,ed wife of the late Harry. devoted mother of Frieda Ispass, Mickey and Nathan. Dear grandmother and great.grano=trier. Services today, 10 Aim, a! Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd.. Manhasset, L.I.

title: 72 SEIZED AT RALLY OF NAZIS IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, July 9  More than 2,000 people milled around in Marquette Park this afternoon, hundreds of them exchanging racial slurs and insults, as the National Socialist Party of America held its longsought rally in the racially tense Southwest Side neighborhood. uespite frequent outbreaks of scuffling that led to at least 72 arrests, the 400 or more riothelmeted policemen drawn up in phalanxes around the barricades that protected the band of about 25 brown-uniformed Nazis kept the volatile situation under control during the hourlong rally.

title: Verdi's Falstaff
description: OPERA THEATER, being produced by WNET/13, is bringing 11 weekly programs of light and serious music to the summer scene by way of new productions and reruns. One of the original presentations can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13: Verdi's Falstaff, a British Broadcasting Corporation production being distributed by TimeLife Films.

title: EGYPT'S PEACE PLAN FORMALLY REJECTED BY ISRAEL'S CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, July 9  The Israeli Cabinet today rejected as completely unacceptable President Anwar elSadat's peace proposal calling for an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip.

title: Dr. Robin Winkler Bride Of Dr. James Doroshow.
description: Dr. Robin Beth Winkler and Dr. James Halpern Doroshow, physicians, were married yesterday in the Fair Lawn (N. J.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Simon Glustrom.

title: Newman Finds Success In Houghton Investment
description: Howard Newman, the 57-year-old railroad man turned conglomerateur, insisted from the start that Western Pacific Industries controversial $7.3 million purchase of Houghton Mifflin's stock was a fine investment.

title: Serrano Keeps Title
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 9 (AP) Sammy Serrano of Puerto Rico retained the World Boxing Association junior lightweight title last night, knocking out 0 Young Ho of Korea in the ninth round. The bout at Roberto Clemente Coliseum was Serrano's sixth defense of the title he won in 1976.

title: Events
description: Music

title: NO MORE MONEY,KOCH TELLS POLICE UNION AFTER PACT SETBACK
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City was prepared to rearrange terms in renewed negotiations for a new contract with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, but he emphatically ruled out any pay increases beyond those in a tentative settlement that was rejected by the union on Saturday.

title: On the Inevitable
description: AMHERST, Mass.The Keynesian revolution is over, its dream of perpetual prosperity through government demandmanagement permanently interred. Monetarism, the new economic doctrine promising economic salvation through a return to the laissezfaire politics of predatory capitalism, is temporarily ascendant. But the bankrupt policies of the 1920's will not resolve our economic problems. The central debates of the coming decade will revolve around the politics and economics of the planned economy.

title: Q: What Brings Sweat to the Brow of a Met Curator? A: Tut.
description: Over at the Metropolitan Museum, they are trying stay calm, but the tension is mounting. They have done their best to think through all possible problems, to prepare for all exigencies  and indeed, it is well they have a battle plan.

title: Koch, on WINS, Plugs City as Winner
description: Mayor Koch is on the air everyday promoting Radio Station WINS as part of the allnews station's New York Wins advertising campaign. Both the Mayor's office and the station say that what Mr. Koch is promoting is New York and that the station has merely given him a vehicle for doing that.

title: U.S. Trade Will Suffer, Study Says
description: The United States is headed for another year of decelerating industrial growth and accelerating inflation, according to the McGrawHill Publications Company's midyear world business outlook, which was released during the weekend.

title: A Few Good Places To Get in Shape
description: WHEN Arnold Schwarzenegger is in New York he works out at the MidCity Health Club. For Diane Keaton the New York Health & Racquet Club is the choice.

title: Pornographer on Wanted
description: A convicted pornographer, Michael Thevis, is to be placed on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted List tomorrow, the bureau said. Mr. Thevis, of Atlanta, is described by the bureau as a multimillionaire who built a network of 238 corporations that control 40 percent of the nation's pornography. He was serving 81/2 years for interstate transportation of obscene materials and conspiracy to commit arson when he walked away from the jail in New Albany, Ind.

title: Woman Installed to Be Distributor of Communion
description: RUMSON, July 9  When Mrs. Catherine Haran was 7 years old, she climbed over the altar railing at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, which at the moment was deserted, and then for several seconds stood looking back at the empty pews.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What would be the monthly pension payment from the Na- tional Football League for a player like George Blanda, who is credited with 16 active years from the time the plan began in 1960 to his retirement in 1976?

title: Bridge:
description: 2 Women Champions Clash In the Big Apple Knockout

title: His Medium Is the Car Window
description: The two knights on horseback, lances held high, are preparing to joust on a craggy cliff. In the background, surrounded by a forest heavy with trees, looms a fairytale castle. In the top right hand corner a ringed planet swirls in a starry sky.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 10, 1978

title: Baseball Bangs The Drum Loudly For AllStars
description: IT is only an exhibition game, but it has been advertised, publicized and glamorized into the most splashy exhibition game in sports. Most of all, it has become a giant of sports marketing.

title: Andrews of Ludlum On the Metals of Africa
description: E. F. Andrews, vice president for materials at Allegheny Ludlum Industries, has made numerous trips throughout the southern parts of Africa in the last year to get a sense of how the various political struggles would affect supplies of key raw materials.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a move ar the National Conference of State Legislatures to support state spending limits was inaccurately characterized in The Times Saturday. The lawmakers were eagerly, not secretly, promoting constitutional spending limits.

title: 58,663 at Belmont For Rock n
description: There were two major invasions of Belmont Park yesterday. The first one was the usual crowd of racing fans. The second one was by rock-and-roll fansmostly teenagers  later in the afternoon.

title: Duryea Makes Israeli Whistle Stop
description: KFAR HABAD, Israel, July 7 What was Perry B. Duryea, Republican candidate for Governor of New York, doing today in a sweltering Israeli cooperative, combing through workshops, cuddling Russian immigrant children and learning the art of wearing a yarmulke?

title: NO MORE MONEY,KOCH TELLS POLICE UNION AFTER PACT SETBACK
description: City Could Rearrange Contract Terms Rejected by P.B.A., but That's It, Mayor Declares

title: 100,000 Join March for Extension Of Rights Amendment Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  A crowd of nearly 100,000 demonstrators, including many men and children, gathered on the Mall here today and marched more than a dozen blocks in muggy, 90degree heat to support an extension of the sevenyear deadline for ratification of the equal rights amendment.

title: Turnabout Is Predicted In Demand for Tax Cuts
description: ATLANTA, July 9 (UPI)  The new head of the National Association of Counties predicted yesterday that the same people now demanding tax cuts will ask that taxes be reimposed, as soon as needed services are slashed.

title: Steingut's Vote Against Death Penalty May Help a Challenger, 26, in Primary
description: The year that Stanley Steingut's Brooklyn neighbors elected him as an Assemblyman, Helene Weinstein was born.

title: Kaiser Expansion
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced a major expansion of the Koblenz, West Germany. rolling mill of its wholly owned subsidiary, Kaiser Aluminium Europe Inc. The program is expected to significantly increase the mill's capacity to produce rolled aluminum products, Kaiser said. The cost of the Koblenz program is expected to total about S11.6 million.

title: Berlin Ballet: Galina Panova in Giselle
description: NEW YORKERS had yet another glimpse of the Panovs, or at last one member of that muchdiscussed pair of Russian dancers, when Galina Panova appeared in the Peasant Pas de Deux in the Berlin Opera Ballet's Giselle on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Opera: Menotti Twin Bill
description: COOPERSTOWN. N.Y.  It may come as something of a surprise to stumble on a plucky little professional opera company based in the heart of James Fennimore Cooper's rural midstate New York. Actually, the Glimmerglass Opera Theater of Cooperstown is just part of a burgeoning phenomenon all over the country these days  opera thriving in vacationland, sideby side with traditional summerstock theatricals.

title: Seasoned Pitcher, 77, Is Still Throwing Batters for a Loop
description: NORTH BERGEN, July 9  If you happen to be near Hudson County Park here next Sunday, stop by Baseball Diamond No. 5 and watch. You may not be able to believe your eyes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS. July 9 (AP)  Howard Davis survived two knockdowns today and stretched his undefeated streak as a professional to eight with a unanimous 10round decision over Norman Goins in a nationally-televised lightweight bout at the Convention and Exposition Center.

title: American's Trial in Japan Raises Trade and Ethical Issues
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, July 9  The atmosphere in the Yokohama district court on a hot summer day was sleepy. The judge had bustled back from a quick curryrice lunch. He wore a black gown, without a wig. The prosecuting attorney came in late, carrying a huge purple furoshiki wrapper full of legal documents.

title: Bell Broadens Campaign Bid In Senate Race
description: MENDHAM, July 9  Jeffrey K. Bell said today that he was broadening the basis for his Republican campaign for the United States Senate beyond his call for extensive Federal tax cuts that was the cornerstone of his primary campaign.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: U. S. Steel to Shut Plant Permanently
description: The United States Steel Corporation said that it would permanently phase out a steel fabricating plant in Antioch, Calif., which the company had shut down two years ago because of a lack of business. The plant had employed 145 skilled workers.

title: Taiwan Foreign Trade Up
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 10 (UPI) Taiwan's foreign trade in the first half of 1978 amounted to $10.5 billion, up 28.2 percent over the similar period last year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics announced today. It registered a surplus of $676.4 million. Exports in the period increased by 34.3 percent to $5.6 billion, with industrial products taking 88.1 percent.

title: 4 Agencies to Pool $209 Million In Effort to Save Public Housing
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Four Federal agencies disclosed today that they would pool resources in an experimental effort to rescue troubled public housine proiects around the nation.

title: Joe Davis, a Snooker Champion Who Retired Unbeaten, Was 77
description: LONDON, July 10 (AP)  Joe Davis, world snooker champion for 19 years be ginning in 1927, died today in a convalescent home. He was 77 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: ALTHOUGH he used to be a Pentagon official, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, has not hesitated to criticize defense spending since his election to Congress. Mr. Aspin. a Ire- quent critic of Government spending, has now taken the Army to task for spending $50,000 a year for groomtroopers in communities near Fort Polk, La. He told Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander Jr. that the authorities at Fort Polk had unleashed a band of groomtroopers looking for soldiers with their hands in their pockets. Mr. Aspin complained in a letter that what the Army calls courtesy patrols, consisting of two sergeants and a driver, roam the Polk area looking for soldiers with their hats off, hands in their pockets and soldiers who litter or fail to salute officers. Mr. Aspin said that it's all a waste of money for patrols to give tickets for minor offenses to soldiers off the post. Whoever dreamed this up ought to be ticketed for his own poor personal appearance  working without his head screwed on, said Mr. Aspin.

title: Israeli Parliament Bids Countries Intervene in the Dissident Trials
description: TEL AVIV, July 10  The Israeli Parliament in Jerusalem appealed today to parliaments and governments the world over to intervene on behalf of dissidents on trial in the Soviet Union. Two of the dissidents  Anatoly Shcharansky and Aleksandr Ginzburg  are Jews.

title: Mercantile Seat Price Up
description: A seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the nation's secondlargest commodity futures market, sold yesterday for $199,000, up $7,000 from the previous sale last Wednesday and $1,000 below the record price paid March 29.

title: Accused Provenzano Trial Briber Killed in Wreck
description: A 45-year-old resident of Kingston, N.Y., who was arrested June 14 and charged with soliciting a bribe to act as a partial juror in the murder trial of Anthony Provenzano, was one of four persons killed in a plane crash near Westerly, R.I., at 8:20 o'clock Sunday night.

title: Five Hurt as a Train Crash Halts Baltimore Washington Service
description: BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP)  Commuter trains between Baltimore and Washington were halted today after freight train collision slightly injured five persons, and officials said they did not expect service to be restored until tomorrow.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The Last Test Pilots See a TestPilotless Future
description: POMONA, N.J.  As national heros, they were lonelier than Achilles, more aloof than Ted Williams, prouder than a new papa. And in the years between Lindbergh's transAtlantic flight and the start of the space age, no other group in America had quite their swash and buckle.

title: Fed Asks Congress for ReserveInterest Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The Federal Reserve Board today submitted two pieces of proposed legislation to Congress that would sharply alter the structure of banking in the nation.

title: 2 Japanese Planning an Atlantic City Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY. July 10  Two Japanese entrepreneurs announced today that they had signed a longterm lease with an option to buy the historic Shelburne Hotel on the Boardwalk here. They said they planned to open a gambling casino in it by next spring.

title: A China Balance
description: In trying to normalize relations with the Peking Government within the framework of the Shanghai Communique of 1972, the Carter Administration seems to misunderstand the mind of the Asian people.

title: F.B.I. Informant in Klan Asserts He Shot and Killed a Black in 63
description: ATLANTA, July 9  The Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief paid informant in the Ku Klux Klan in the early 1960's has told the Alabama authorities that, while on the bureau payroll, he shot black man to death, then kept quiet about the killing at the instruction of an F.B.I. agent, according to investigative documents.

title: GEN. LAMPERT DIES; EXDEFENSE OFFICIAL
description: Lieut. Gen. James B. Lampert, a vice president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense under President Johnson. a former West Point superin tendent and the last United States High Commissioner of the Ryukyu Islands, died of cancer yesterday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

title: WESTCHESTER WINS KEY RULING ON JOBS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 10  The State Court of Appeals, in a decision eagerly awaited by many municipalities, has upheld Westchester County's right to replace tenured Civil Service employees by contracting work to a private concern,

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday gave the wrong closing date for the Tutankhamen show at the. Metropolitan Museum of Art. The closing will be April 15, 1979.

title: Washington Journal
description: THE two young bachelors sprawled in the deep grass of Farragut Square, in the shadow of the Admiral's rather imoosina statue. three blocks from the White House. munching on their fastfood lunches, sipping their sodas through straws, grousing about the oppressive midday heat, watching the impressive parade of young women pass by and trying to figure a way out of returning to their desks and their jobs in the nearby Office of Management and Budget.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: PARIS, July 10  The dollar dropped sharply again today as foreign-exchange markets got their first real chance to react to last Friday's pledge by European Common Market leaders to work for a new zone of monetary stability in Europe and sought to gauge prospects for the economic summit meeting opening on Sunday.

title: Airline Stocks Join in Market Rally
description: Commercial airline and cargo airline stocks shared honors yesterday with selected drug and aerospace issues to lead the market higher in a modest afternoon rally. Meanwhile, some favorites of last week  namely, the casino stocks and Canadian oil-and-gas producers continued to move ahead.

title: 3 Women on Safety Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  Susan B. King, who was recently named as chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission by President Carter, presided over her first meeting today. Two of the other three commissioners also are women, including Edith Barksdale Sloan, who was chosen vice chairman of the commission today.

title: Deaths
description: DANTOShirley S. The Department and Staff of the Philosophy Department of Columbia University extend to their colleague Arthur Danto and to Elizabeth and Jane our deep sympathy at the death of his wife and their mother, Shirley S. Danto. Shirley Danto was our good and loyal friend, and we grieve with her family.

title: LEVITT ASKS CHANGE ON PENSION CONTROL
description: ALBANY, July 10 (AP)  Arthur Lefitt, the retiring State Comptroller, formally proposed to the Legislature today that it take away from his successor control over $9 billion in public employee pension funds.

title: Accused Provenzano Trial Briber Killed in Wreck
description: A 45-year-old resident of Kingston, N.Y., who was arrested June 14 and charged with soliciting a bribe to act as a partial juror in the murder trial of Anthony Provenzano, was one of four persons killed in a plane crash near Westerly, R.I., at 8:20 o'clock Sunday night.
