title: House Defeats Effort To Exempt Tocks I. From Wild Rivers Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The House of Representatives, by a vote of 275 to 110, today rejected an effort to block designation of a 39mile stretch of the Delaware River between New Jersey and Pennsylvania as a wild and scenic river to be protected by the Federal Government.

title: Firestone Defends 500
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Firestone executives, under growing pressure from the Government and consumer organizations to recall a muchcriticized line of radial tires, today clung to their assertions that mishandling of the tires by their owners was primarily responsible for blowouts.

title: Fred Wilt to Coach Purdue Women's Track
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 10 (AP)  Fred Wilt, a retired agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and former world recordholder in the indoor twomile run, has been named women's track coach at Purdue University.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The number of welfare cases in Nassau County declined for the first six months of this year to the lowest number in the last 11 years, Francis T. Purcell, the County Executive reported.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: The Kremlin's Bloody Omelet
description: There was a time  it seems long ago  when whatever the Soviet rulers did to suppress dissent would find reputable defenders in the West. The softminded among them would argue that the actions were being misreported or, at least, misconstrued by an unfriendly capitalist press. The tougherminded might grant that excesses did occur, but justify them as paving the way to the millenium. Their favorite line: You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs. If there is any encouraging aspect to the trials of Anatoly Shcharansky and Aleksandr Ginzburg, it is that even on the left such justifications are not much heard anymore.

title: Physicians at Bellevue Made Improper Use Of Funds, Goldin Says
description: Doctors at Bellevue Hospital and their families have collected more than $200,000 in reimbursements from the city for noncredit educational courses that included such subjects as yoga. tourism, modern dance and the martial arts, City Comptroller Harrison .1. Goldin has charged.

title: Norma Karnali Is Heading Out on Her Own
description: For Norma Kamali, one of the hottest fashion designers around and known in the trade as Hot Kamali, the opening yesterday of her new boutique, OMO (for On My Own) at 6 West 56th Street was a scene of controlled bedlam.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE drop in the unemployment rate to 5.7 percent in June has raised hopes in some quarters that stagflation, that partnership of inflation and economic stagnation, may at last be breaking up. It may be a vain hope indeed.

title: Beaths
description: CALLAHANElizabeth. Staff of Babies Hospital mourns the loss of their beloved colleague Elizabeth Callahan. We extend our deepest symPaths, to her family and friends. Reposing at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr, Tenafly, NJ, Tuesday, July 11, 2.Apm, 7.9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ. 10am, Wednesday, July 12.

title: Fairbanks Ponders A Broadway Debut
description: I HAVEN'T been to the beach once and I've only seen about two old friends since I got here, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., was saying. We're working every day, changing lines, adding sketches, dropping others, learning new songs, forgettine old ones.

title: Sports Today
description: AllStar Game, at San Diego. (Television  Channel 7, 8:30 P.M.)(Etadio WatS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Rich Gets Cash for Restaurants
description: Charlie Rich, the country-and-western singer, is living up to his name. The American Equity Corporation reported it would pay $6.5 million to three men, including Mr. Rich, for Wendy's of Nashville Inc., a chain of hamburger restaurants in the Nashville area.

title: Occidental Unit Gets $35 Million Loan
description: LONDON, July 10 (UPI)  The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago announced today a $35 million syndicated loan agreement with Occidental Boliviana Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: REALESTATE SCHOOL IS SUED OVER EXAMS
description: NEWARK, July 10  The Educational Testing Service of Princeton, which conducts examinatons for a wide variety of academic and professional institutions, charged a business school operating in Union today with pirating information from its tests for realestate brokers and sales agents.

title: M.A.C. Delays Lawsuit Against Pension Funds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday put off until later this week the filing of a suit against the police and fire fighters unions pension funds over their refusal to purchase the corporations bonds.

title: 125,000 Trucks Recalled by Ford Over Engine Fan Viewed as Peril
description: DETROIT, July 10 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company today recalled about 125,000 medium and heavy trucks to replace engine fans that might crack and throw blades.

title: Trade Tower Bomber Holds 4 for 10 Hours Before Police Move In
description: A Polishspeaking mechanic, carrying what he said was 80 pounds of dynamite, held four persons hostage for more than 10 hours on the 36th floor of the World Trade Center yesterday. Policemen rusnea the room as a fight broke out between the captor and his hostages  with one hostage beating him with the stanchion of a New York State flag  and the officers wrestled him to the ground.

title: 2 in Texas Charged in 5 Killings
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., July 10 (UPI) refinery worker and a 30-year-old mother of three, accused of kidnapping and killing five of his former inlaws because of hard feelings related to a divorce, were charged today with capital murder.

title: British Scientist Sues Over Book on Cloning
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) prominent British research scientist and biologist today filed a $7 million suit against a Philadelphia publisher, J.B. Lippincott Company, charging that a book on human cloning is a hoax.

title: Political Power for Women: Five Colleges Join to Pave the Way
description: Five small women's colleges, aided by a $250,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation, announced yesterday the formation of a network of programs to help women enter public life and run for political office.

title: Refurbished Roosevelt Opens
description: WESTBURY, L.I. July 10  The Sonny Werblin touch, which had been felt in the past at the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park and by the New York Jets, was in evidence here tonight as Roosevelt Raceway opened a 39night summer meeting.

title: Partial Pact At Geneva Talks Seen
description: GENEVA, July 10  President Carter's chief trade negotiator, Robert S. Strauss, predicted today that the major industrial powers participating in trade talks here can take a substantial package of agreements to the economic summit meeting in Bonn next week.

title: HANOI OFFICIAL SEES MOVES FOR U.S. TIES
description: TOKYO. July 10 (Reuters)  Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, Phan Hien, said today that he expected new developments in relations between the United States and Hanoi and that talks on American servicemen missing in action would be conducted in Honolulu.

title: A Painful Setback for Cefalo
description: I once received 12 injections for pain during a high school football game in Pittston, Pa. I played another high school game with 16 stitches in my back and still gained 301 yards in 30 carries.

title: RALLY OVER TRIALS DRAWS 1,000 PEOPLE
description: The trial of two Russian dissidents was protested here yesterday at a noon rally in the garment district and also, apparently, by a small fire bomb near the Soviet tourist agency in Rockefeller Center.

title: VANCE IS ASSAILED FOR SOVIET TALKS IN FACE OF TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's decision to go ahead this week with strategicarms negotiations despite the trials of two major Soviet dissidents drew sharp political criticism today.

title: Michel Gusikoff, 85, a Violinist, Composer and a Concert Master
description: Michel Gusikoff, a violinist, composer and retired concert master of major American symphony orchestras, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 85.

title: Trade Tower Bomber Holds 4 for 10 Hours Before Police Move In
description: A Polishspeaking mechanic, carrying what he said was 80 pounds of dynamite, held four persons hostage for more than 10 hours on the 36th floor of the World Trade Center yesterday. Policemen rushed the room as a fieht broke out be- tween tne captor and his hostages  with one hostage beating him with the stanchion of a New York State flag  and the officers wrestled him to the ground.

title: 20 Millionth Museum Visitor
description: WASHINGTON. July 10 (AP)  Katherine Rinehart, 14 years old, of Charlottesville, Va., yesterday became the 20 millionth visitor at the two-year-old National Air and Space Museum.

title: Running of Bulls Put Off Again As Pamplona Mourns
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, July 10 (Reuters)  Most of the tourists who had come here for the annual running-of-the-bulls festival had gone, and the streets today were filled with mourners.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennwalt Division Begins New Plant
description: The J. F. Jelenko division of the Pennwalt Corporation will begin building a $5 million plant in Armonk, N.Y. in September to house its offices and facilities for making alloys for dental laboratories.

title: City's Health Chief to Order Abortions by Lincoln Hospital in Bronx
description: New York City's Health Services Administrator said yesterday be would order abortions to be performed at Lincoln Hospital  whose physicians have never performed abortions there  even if it meant brinairut in outside doctors.

title: Head of Con Edison Labels Critic Of 1977 Blackout Obstructionist
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Angered by charges that his company's managerial failures were a major cause of the blackout in New York City and Westchester County a year ago, Charles F. Luce, chairman of Consolidated Edison, lashed out at critics during a House Energy Subcomittee hearing today.

title: A Dose of Reality for New York's Police
description: Just as a new contract between New York City and its police union was to be announced last weekend, something went very wrong. The union leaders did not dare submit the deal they had negotiated to an angry membership that seemed determined to reiect it.

title: 2 Drown in Bear Mountain Lake
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 10(UPI)  Two New York City men drowned yesterday afternoon while trying to swim to an island in Lake Welch in Harriman State Park, the Palisades Interstate. Park police reported. A third man was rescued from the lake by a park employee in a boat. The police identified the victims as Ivan Pereira, 23 years old, and Lidardo Arias, 26, both of 56-41 Van Cleef Street, Corona, Queens. The third man was identified as Mr. Pereira's brother, Carlos, 19, of the same address.

title: $1 Million for Highway Safety
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The House voted today to give the National Transportation Safety Board $1 million extra for highway safety investigations.

title: Bolshoi Tenor In a Debut
description: NEWPORT. R. I., July 10 Two music festivals more or less bumped into each other in this picturesque resort town over the weekend. While the Newport opera festival offered the concluding events of its first season, the more established Newport Music Festival inaugurated its 10th year with a pair of prefestival concerts (the official opening night will be this Friday with the American debut of the Soviet pianist Igor Zhukov).

title: House Defeats Effort To Exempt Tocks I. From Wild Rivers Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The House of Representatives, by a vote of 275 to 110, today rejected an effort to block designation of a 39mile stretch of the Delaware River between New Jersey and Pennsylvania as a wild and scenic river to be protected by the Federal Government.

title: Gerulaitis Beats Dent, 61, 76; Rosewall Loses at Forest Hills
description: Plunged into hot, humid conditions on a clay court after four weeks of cool, rainy weather on grass at Wimbledon, players in the new $300,000 Forest Hills Invitation tennis tournament presented a poor show last night.

title: In the Wake of the Snail Darter
description: The snail darter, the tiny fish that blocked a Federal dam project in Tennessee, has stuck in the throat of many a Congressman. One senator suggests that revulsion against environmental excess may lead Congress to undermine the Endangered Species Act; that is the law that led the Supreme'Court to decree that the Tennessee Valley Authority's Tellico Dam could got be completed because it would destroy the last habitat of the rare snail darter. The Senate will provide the first test of this backlash sentiment when it considers amendments to the act this week.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d Is Killed In Auto Collision Near His Home
description: Driver of Second Car Also DiesSecretary Injured Along With Woman Operating a Third Vehicle

title: Beaths
description: BACHMANMorris beloved husband, father and grandfather. Rest In peace. Service will be held at Hellmans Funeral Home, 172 St & Grand Concourse, Bronx NY. July 11th. at 12 neon. Interment Washington Cemetery, Dean, N.J.

title: Skylab Loses Altitude Again From Power Problem
description: HOUSTON, July 10 (AP)  For the third time in less than two months, the Skylab spacecraft has developed power system problems that have caused it to lose attitude, the National Space and Aeronautics Administration reports.

title: Backers of Tax Cut in Michigan Meet Filing Deadline
description: DETROIT. July 10  Backers of a taxcutting amendment to the state Constitution similar to California's Proposition 13 said today they had met the state filing deadline with enough petition signatures to put their measure on the ballot in Michigan next November.

title: DeBusschere Seeking $275,000 from Nets, Boe
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 10  A judgement of $275,000 was filed today in State Supreme Court on behalf of Dave DeBusschere against the Nets and Roy Boe, president of the financially troubled National Basketball Association franchise.

title: NEW YORK'S LOANS ARGUED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The HouseSenate conference on the New York City loan guarantees began today with the House members offering a compromise bill that was immediately rejected by the Senate.

title: Three Vital Appeals
description: If Judge Oren Lewis's decision is upheld by Federal appeals courts in the case of Frank Snepp, the former Central Intelligence Agency official who wrote a book called Decent Inter

title: 2 British Leaders Assail Soviet Dissidents
description: LONDON, July 10  Prime Minister James Callaghan and Dr. David Owen, the Foreign Secretary, speaking in the House of Commons, condemned the trials of the Soviet dissidents today. But Dr. Owen re jetted demands that Britain break sporting, cultural or economic links with the Soviet Union or halt negotiations on security issues.

title: New British Jet Will Use U.S. Engine
description: Britain approved yesterday a $500 million program for production of new 70- to 110passenger airliner to be offered for sale to the rapidly expanding number of airlines serving small cities and towns.

title: People Streaming Out of Beirut As 2 Sides Build Arms Stockpiles
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10  People were streaming out of this battered capital today, particularly from the predominantly Christian eastern side where people feared a resumption of major hostilities between Syrian troops and rightwing Christian militia forces.

title: 3Year High Hit by Bill Rate
description: Government borrowing costs rose to the highest level in more than 3 years in yesterday's Treasury bill auction.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d was the family philanthropist of his generation of Rockefellers and probably the least public of the five grandsons of the oil magnate whose name was synonymous with wealth.

title: Pel
description: About 200 grade school children from the Harlem community marveled at the soccer wizardry of Pele yesterday at a clinic designed to foster interest in the sport and encourage the area's youngsters to stay in school and earn a degree.

title: Official Who Backed Mrs. Ghandi Is Found Dead Near Suicide Note
description: NEW DELHI, July 10 (Reuters)  Krishan Chand, the lieutenant governor of Delhi officially criticized for his actions during the emergency rule of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was found dead in a well last night, the police said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 10  Val De Loire, a jumper who competed with the French and Spanish equestrian teams until last year, won the Adirondack grand prix yesterday at the closing session of the I Love New York horse show.

title: Tropicana Votes Merger Despite Bar
description: Shareholders of Tropicana Products Inc. voted yesterday to go ahead with their company's proposed $488 million merger into the Beatrice Foods Company. despite a court ruling, announced over the weekend, that temporarily bars the merger.

title: Real Places
description: GREENWICH. CONN. HERE in the sylvan world of corporate estates, gardeners can fix the trees like puppies, so they don't bear fruit. The morning traffic of executives disappears into a sunlaced glade marked American Can Company, and if you curl around a hillside with it you suddenly drive from woods to beneath a giant tinted lair of a headquarters.

title: Beaths
description: GROSSReuben E. The Rosh Henshiva. the Gaon. Harav Moshe Feinstein. the officers, directors. faculty and student body of Mesivtha Titereth Jerusalem express their dew and heartfelt sorrow on the sudden passing of Our distinguished alumnus, scholar. writer and counsel; founder of the Mesi vtha of Staten Island. presently our resident division. and internationally renowned benefactor of Torah education, Reuben E. Gross. May his wife. Blanche. his children, Avery. Alex, David. Chav va. Benita, Shularnith, Judy, Naomi and Donny, his sister. Clay., and his brother. Herman Gross. find comfort and solace in perpetuating the great and noble deeds of this unique Person whose impression on our history and development is truly indelible.

title: Military Takes Over in Mauritania With a Reportedly Bloodless Coup
description: PARIS, July 10  A military coup occurred early this morning in the West African nation of Mauritania, the scene of a protracted guerrilla war and power rivalries involving France, Morocco and Algeria.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Abraham on Fall Clothes Trend
description: Fall clothes are beginning to decorate department store racks around the country, and, in some cases, customers will be paying considerably more for their apparel this year than last.

title: The Last Test Pilots See a TestPilotless Future
description: POMONA, N.J.  As national heros, they were lonelier than Achilles, more aloof than Ted Williams, prouder than a new papa. And in the years between Lindbergh's transAtlantic flight and the start of the space age, no other group in America had quite their swash and buckle.

title: Father Accused of Persuading Daughter, 14, to Be Prostitute
description: DETROIT, July 10 (AP)  The police say that a father has been charged with persuading his 14-year-old daughter to turn to prostitution for pocket money.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Brown & Williamson Industries, Louisville, Ky., has elected Leonard W. Arentsen vice president and controller and Gary G. Herzberg vice presidenttreasurer.

title: 13 Restaurants in New York City Cited for Health Code Infractions
description: New York City's Health Department cited 13 restaurants yesterday for violations of the Health Code. They were listed as follows:

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 10 1978

title: H.E.W. Seeks 4% Liniit For Waste in Programs
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare proposed a goal today for trimming waste in three welfare programs.

title: Horse Named Lebon (Maybe) Bombs on Belmont Auction Block
description: ELMONT, L.I., July 10  The seller was there. The auctioneer was there. The District Attorney was represented and the press turned out in force. The only ingredient missing from today's thoroughbred auction at Belmont Park was money. Apparently no one could work up sufficient enthusiasm to spend real dollars on an animal enjoying the protective custody of the Nassau County District Attorney, a horse whose identity, ownership and ability are all in dispute and whose racing career may be behind him.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Another drop in the dollar's value overseas set off advances yesterday in foreign currency futures, particularly on the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and in precious metals futures.

title: TWO PRISONERS MI SEATS IN MALAYSIA
description: KUALA LUMPUR. Malaysia, July 10  The largest majority obtained by any candidate in the parliamentary elections over the weekend was won by a member of the opposition who did not campaign and who appeared unlikely to be able to represent the people who elected him.

title: The Talk of Mexico City
description: Altitude, Character, Too Many People

title: Jascalevich's Lawyer Challenges Expert on Curare
description: HACKENSACK, July 10  The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich today questioned whether a toxicologist's tests had proved that vials, which had been labeled curare and which had been taken from Dr. Jascalevich's locker, contained the drug.

title: Richard Sylvester, a Yale Scholar
description: Prof. Richard S. Sylvester, a member of the Yale University faculty for 22 years and a scholar of English Renaissance literature, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in New Haven. He was 51 years old.

title: Congress Tells How to Lobby
description: If you want to learn how to be a lobbyist, you ask another lobbyist, right?

title: CBS Looks For Salant Successor
description: At CBS News, the wait seems interminable for the big news: Who will succeed Richard S. Salant as president of the division when he retires after his 65th birthday next April?

title: 5 Win Humanitas Prizes
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10  The Humanitas Prizes, established in 1974 to get human values into primetime television, were won today by the authors of Special Olympics and episodes of Family and All in the Family.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 10  Patrons of Resorts International's gambling casino in Atlantic City bet an average of $3.12 million a day in June, according to figures released here today by the Casino Control Commission. The gamblers averaged losses of $535,000 a day.

title: Bridge:
description: It is never surprising when the topranked team wins a major knockout event, as happened in the Big Apple regiona I championships played at the Statler Hilton Hotel during the weekend.

title: 10 Injured as Car Crashes Through Window of Store in Massapequa
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., July 10  A car lurched off a highway, smashed through the plateglass windows of an ice cream store and slammed into a crowd of customers and employees here last night, leaving 10 people injured  two seriously  in a pandemonium of screams and terror.

title: Sindona Sues Tisch over Stock
description: Michele Sindona, onetime head of the nowdefunct Franklin National Bank, who is fighting extradition to Italy where he faces bank fraud charges, has filed a $100 millionplus suit against Loew's Theatres Inc. and its chairman, Laurence A. Tisch.

title: TV: Canada's Top Drama on Channel 13 Tonight
description: IN STILL another of its special summer programming packages. WNET/ 13 is reviving Psyche: Films on the Mind for four weeks. The title is vague enough, obviously, to include anything from Ingmar Bergman's Persona to Todd Browning's Freaks. The series. however. concentrates on lesserknown films. Tonight's offering, on Channel 13 at 9:30, is Dreamspeaker, a Canadian Broadcasting Corporation drama made on location in British Columbia.

title: Secret Trusts Reportedly Aided Humphrey Family
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)  A large Minnesotabased corporation used a network of secret trusts to contribute perhaps $1 million in stock to the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and his family, the ScrippsHoward News Service reported today.

title: Sadat Disappointed at Israel's Rejection of Peace Plan
description: VIENNA. July 10 (Reuters)  President Anwar elSadat said today that he had been very disappointed by Israel's rejection of Egypt's peace proposals, but he was advised by two top European Socialists today to continue his Middle East peace initiative.

title: Cocaine and Hollywood
description: Los ANGELES THE high that cocaine gives lasts 20 minutes and costs $30. In Hollywood, where it has been the chic luxury drug for the last three years, a growing number of producers. direc- tors and, especially, actors, are now turning to it as their main energy source  even when they are working. Unlike amphetamines, which it most resembles, coke is very subtle; and for better or worse, according to a number of interviews with people in the industry, the creative decisions on a substantial group of recent motion pictures have been made under the influence of the drug.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets were quiet yesterday with several days of heavy financing about to begin.

title: Solomon, ExInvestment Banker, Is Sworn In as a Deputy for Koch
description: Stressing that his administration was dedicated to getting out of the way of the private sector's efforts to create jobs and to reap profits. Mayor Koch yesterday swore in Peter Jay Solomon as Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Developmeat.

title: VANCE IS ASSAILED FOR SOVIET TALKS IN FACE OF TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's decision to go ahead this week with strategicarms negotiations despite the trials of two major Soviet dissidents drew sharp political criticism today.

title: Carey Discusses Issue of Juvenile Criminals
description: Governor Carey confronted the issue of crime twice yesterday: once, by his choice, at the funeral of a student allegedly killed by a 13-year-old boy, and once, unexpectedly, on a television program. At the funeral he promised to institute a program to divert youths from crime.

title: Japan Exports Up for June
description: TOKYO, July 10 (AP)  Japan's certified exports for June on a dollar basis rose 20.3 percent from last year to about $8.56 billion, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday. July 10,1978

title: Shell Oil's Well Dry Off New Jersey Coast
description: HOUSTON, July 10  The Shell Oil Company announced today that its first effort to find oil and gas off the New Jersey coast had failed, and that it was abandoning its first exploratory well in the undersea Baltimore Canyon Trough, 73 miles east of Atlantic City.

title: House, 3628, Votes Day for Grandparents
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters) The House today voted 362 to 8 to set aside the first Sunday after Labor Day, which is the first Monday in September, in tribute to grandparents.

title: Winfield Fetes 10,000 Kids
description: SAN DIEGO, July 10  Dave Winfield of the San Diego Padres threw a cookie-and-doughnuts party for children today on the eve of baseball's AllStar Game, and more than 10,000 youngsters showed up.

title: Housen, on Streak, Cards 68 to Lead Ike
description: CLIFTON. N.J., July 10  Bob Housen, a 40-year-old insurance executive who has won the New Jersey amateur golf championship twice, knows that golf is a streaky game.

title: Rusco Says Its Troubles Are Studied
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July 10  Only one question was asked today at the annual meeting of Rusco Industries: Why is the company in trouble?

title: 1,450 Steel Workers Are Eligible For Special Unemployment Help
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Labor Department ruled today that 1,450 laidoff workers at six plants of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation I were entitled to special unemployment benefits because they had lost their jobs as a result of increased imports of foreign steel products.

title: Ailing Forego Retired at Age
description: Forego has been good to us and it's time we were good w him.

title: Rate Is Up a Bit For Mortgages
description: The average rate on conventional home mortgages accepted yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation rose slightly, to 9.615 percent from 9.596 percent a week earlier, the quasigovernmental agency said. The rate a year ago was 9.633 percent.

title: Air Mail Service Organizer Dead; Calamity Jane, Buffalo Bill Friend
description: DEALS. Md., July 10 (AP)  Chase Carpenter Gove, who helped organize the United States Air Mail Service, died here Saturday.He was 95 years old.

title: Von Horvath's Tales Opens Yale Rep Sept. 28
description: The Yale Repertory Theater will open its 13th season Sept. 28 with Odon von Horvath's Tales From the Vienna Woods, the first of seven productions to be given through May19.

title: A Texas Airline Buys 9.2% of National's Stock
description: Texas International Airlines, a regional carrier based in Houston, disclosed yesterday that it had purchased 9.2 percent of the common stock of National Airlines, the country's llth-largest carrier, in a possible move to gain control.

title: Dissident Tells Latvian Meeting Of Soviet Moves Against Culture
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 10 (AP)  Helena Celmina, a dissident from Latvia, has told the Fourth Latvian Youth Congress that the Soviet Union is trying to destroy the Baltic land's native culture and is depriving Latvians of human rights.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: HOW IT TICKS Those behind-thescenes tours on Tuesday through Thursday out at the Museums, the multibuilding complex on Route 25A in Stony Brook, L.I., are tours with a difference. The typical museum visitor rarely gets a chance to learn how exhibitions are planned, designed and installed, how collections are cared for And stored, how programs are developed and what a museum staff does. The current twohour sessions, conducted by staff members, start at 9:30 A.M. and 7:30 P.M. and are continuing through July 25. The Stony Brook premises include an art museum, a carriage museum, several period buildings and a museum store.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d Is Killed In Auto Collision Near His Home
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d, the 72-year-old philanthropist and eldest member of one of the nation's wealthiest families, was killed last night in a headon collision of cars in Westchester County. The collision took place on a rural road 12 miles north of New York City near the Rockefeller family estate at Pocantico Hills.

title: Beaths
description: LUBINIsador. Husband of Carol (nee Riegelman). Father of Alice L. Everitt and Ann L.Buttenwieser. Brother of Marian Lubin. granettather of William L., Carol H., Jill A.and Peter L.Buttenwewieser. Burial seeice private. Memorial service at 12 noon Tuesday, July 11 at the Albert List Academic Center of the hew School for Social Research. 65 Finn Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to Brandeis University, Waltham. Mass would be appreciated.

title: Newport Jazz: Concert vs. Festival
description: THE 25th season of the Newport Jazz Festival, which ended last week, was the most widespread, geographically, in its sometimes spotted history. This time, the festival had one foot in New Jersey, where it sponsored a weekend at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., and another foot in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where it went for another weekend, while the main body of the festival settled in New York City for 10 days.

title: 2 YOUNG GIRLS DIE, 3 ARE SAVED IN FIRE
description: Two small sisters were killed yesterday when a fire broke out in their apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, but two of their young sisters and a third little girl were saved by teenagers who broke into the burning apartment before firemen arrived.

title: Residency Law Looms for New York City Workers
description: Frustrated by the Legislature, which has refused to act on a series of homerule messages, the City Council prepared yesterday to pass a controversial local law that would require all city employees hired after Sept. 1 to live in the city.

title: Books of The Titnes
description: INNOCENT ERENDIRA AND OTHER STORIES. By Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Translated from the Spanish by Gregory Rabassa. 183 pages. Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: Levitt Reports a Misuse of Drugs By Three State Mental Hospitals
description: ALBANY, July 10  Patients at three psychiatric centers in New York State Iwere frequently given powerful drugs in dosages exceeding recommended maximum levels and were often given two or more drugs simultaneously, even though state guidelines caution against this practice, according to a study released today by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Economy

title: Around the Nation
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 10 (AP)  William M. Kunstler, the New York lawyer who was arrested on the first day of Joan Little's murder trial in 1975, was briefly held in custody again today on what was to have been the opening day of Miss Little's trial on escape charges.

title: Rittenour, Friendship Fuse Jazz
description: LEE RITTENOUR and his band. Friendship, who were at the Bottom Line on Sunday night. normally inhabit the recording studios of Los Angeles. One hears them playing slick, anonymous backup on countless records and it is very easy to take them for granted. But, in person, Mr. Rittenour and friends project a warmth and involvement that, coupled with their impressive technical expertise, make them one of the most enjoyable jazzfusion outfits the writer has encountered in some time.

title: Letter: On the Highway Trust Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Berlin Troupe Dances Cinderella
description: STRUCTURALLY, Valery Panov's Cinderella for the Berlin Opera Ballet goes through the appropriate dramatic motions in its retelling of the familiar fairy tale. But because the specific choreographic motions devised by Mr. Panov within this structure range from the pleasant to the uninspired, the production requires sensitive performances by its principal dancers to provide it with charm and fantasy throughout all three acts.

title: WESTCHESTER WINS KEY RULING ON JOBS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 10  The State Court of Appeals, in a decision eagerly awaited by many municipalities, has upheld Westchester County's right to replace tenured Civil Service employees by contracting work to a private concern:

title: 2 Japanese Contract to Buy Hotel In Atlantic City to Open a Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 10  Two Japanese entrepreneurs announced today that they had signed a longterm lease with an option to buy the historic Shelburne Hotel on the Boardwalk here. They said they planned to open a gambling casino in it by next spring.

title: New Support Is Reported for Unified Force Theory
description: By ricocheting spinning electrons off the nuclei of atoms, a group of physicists from Stanford and Yale Universities and other institutions have discovered convincing new support for a theory that would unify two of nature's fundamental forces.

title: Lawyer Named To Monitor Schlitz
description: MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP)  The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company today named a Philadelphia lawyer, Daniel J. McCauley Jr., to monitor the company's compliance with the terms of a Securities and Exchange Commission order to prevent the company from making payoffs to wholesalers and retai lers.

title: Jackson Ill, Out of AllStar Game
description: SAN DIEGO, July 10  Baseball began its threeday midseason break today and shifted its focus and feuds to the home of the San Diego Padres, where the American League, minus Reggie Jackson, will try to end a six- year losing streak tomorrow night in the 49th AllStar Game.

title: Muncey's Hydro Wins
description: MADISON, Ind., July 10 (UPI)  Bill Muncey drove to his fourth straight unlimitedhydroplane victory yesterday, capturing the Indiana Governor's Cup in the Madison regatta on the Ohio River. He had an average speed of 109.409 miles an hour.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Harvester Shifts Parts Production
description: The International Harvester Company, Chicago, said that it planned to shift about $25 million of parts production previously bought from outside suppliers to its own plants in an effort to use its factories more fully.

title: 2 DISSIDENTS
description: MOSCOW, July 10  Anatoly Shcharansky, a dissident whose case has disrupted SovietAmerican relations, was put on trial for treason today in a closed Moscow courtroom. He was accused of having maintained regular contacts with toreign intelligence agents and having passed them state secrets. He reportedly denied the charges as absurd.

title: DR. JOHN PIERCE LAMBERT
description: Dr. John Pierce Lambert, a psychiatrist who retired in 1975 after serving since 1954 as medical director of Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, N.Y., died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at Four Winds Hospital.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JULY 11, 1978

title: Jascalevich's Lawyer Challenges Expert on Curare
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 10  The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich today questioned whether a toxicologist's tests had proved that vials, which had been labeled curare and which had been taken from Dr. Jascalevich's locker, contained the drug.

title: Talcott Unit Sought
description: The Republic New York Corporation and the Talcott National Corporation said that a letter of intent had been signed for the proposed acquisition by Republic of James Talcott Inc.'s factoring division for about $107 million. They said, the venture would be part of a restructuring of the debt and preferred stock of both Talcotts.

title: Britons, in a Poll, Oppose Further Nationalization
description: LONDON, July 10  A poll published here today indicates that a large majority of British voters oppose further nationalization of their country's industry and believe public ownership of railroads, steel plants and other enterprises has not been successful.

title: Baseball's New Name: Jack Clark
description: SAN DIEGO, July 10  All the big hitters brought their bats here for tomorrow night's AllStar Game Jim Rice, Rod Carew, Pete Rose, George Foster. Joe Morgan, Greg Luzinski, Steve Garvey, George Brett, Carlton Fisk, Richie Zisk and Jack Clark.

title: Military Takes Over in Mauritania With a Reportedly Bloodless Coup
description: PARIS, July 10  A military coup occurred early this morning in the West African nation of Mauritania, the scene of a protracted guerrilla war and power rivalries involving France, Morocco and Algeria.

title: Non.Communist Leader Dies in Vietnamese Jail
description: Iran Van Tuyen, a prominent Vietnamese lawyer who opposed the regimes of Ngo Dinh Diem and Nguyen Van Thieu during the Vietnam War, died in prison in northern Vietnam 20 months ago, according to information received by his daughter in the United States.

title: Bolivian Vote Count And Claims of Rivals Causing Uncertainty
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 10 A slow official count of votes and conflicting claims by candidates today left the outcome uncertainin Bolivia's first general election in 12 years.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) over-thecounter

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday gave the wrong closing date for the Tutankhamen show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The closing will be April 15, 1979.

title: District Attorney Says He Lacks Jurisdiction On Brooke Deposition
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 10 (UPI) The Middlesex County District Attorney CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 10 (UPI) rn declined today to seek perjury charges against Senator Edward W. Brooke, saying that he lacked jurisdiction.

title: Carey Orders Increase In State Staff Levels At Mental Institutions
description: ALBANY, July 10 Governor Carey, sensitive to charges that his administration dumped mental patients into communities without the facilities to care for them, has ordered an increase in staffing levels at state institutions and a broader program of staterun community services.

title: Carter Would Reshuffle Agency Aiding Law Officials
description: WASHINGTON. July 10 (AP)  President C4rter granted a reprieve today to the Law Enforcement Assistance AcHinistration, an agency he had criticizeu as wasteful and that his advisers had considered abolishing.

title: Federal Mediators Enter Postal Pact Bargaining
description: WASHINGTON, July H) (AP) Federal mediators stepped into the stalled negotiations today between the Postal Service and unions representing more than 554,000 employees.

title: F.B.I. Informant in Klan Asserts He Shot and Killed a Black in 63
description: ATLANTA, July 9  The Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief paid informant in the Ku Klux Klan in the early 1960's has told the Alabama authorities that, while on the bureau payroll, he shot a black man to death, then kept quiet about the killing at the instruction of an F.B.I. agent, according to investigative documents.

title: Taxes &
description: WASHINGTON THE threevolume, 1,300page report on the accounting profession prepared for Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission landed on Capitol Hill last week. Congress was unimpressed.

title: Northern Ireland Recovers Body Of Constable Kidnapped by I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 10 (AP)  The authorities today recovered the body of William Turbitt, a police constable who was kidnapped June 17, after receiving a tip from the Irish Republican Army guerrillas who killed him.

title: Moore, 80, Is Hardly A Reclining Figure
description: LONDON THE most famous of living sculptors is an Englishman called Henry Moore. Like everyone else in that kind of txisition. he has his de- tractors, people who think that it is high time that he moved over and gave others a chance. But he also has his fervent, lifelong and unalterable admirers  and nowhere more so than in this country.

title: Judge Continues Bail In 9Ton Drug Seizure
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP)  A Superior Court judge here refused today to reduce bail of $500,000 each for six suspects held in the seizure of more than nine tons of Colombian marijuana at a small airoort here

title: Big Atlantic Oil Find Reported in Britaiit
description: LONDON, July 10  Britain may have found a vast new oilfield in largely unexplored area of the Atlantic Ocean, a discovery that could extend the country's selfsufficiency in oil by several years.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JULY 11, 1978

title: State Legislators Struggle to Find Healthful Remedy for Growing AntiTax Sentiment
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Putting some politicians in a room with Howard Jarvis to hear him explain Proposition 13 is like assembling the regional sales managers of a struggling patent medicine company with the man who has just News Analysis rectesigned the bottle and the label. They just know he is going to make them all rich.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, July 10 (UPI)  President Carter's top science adviser met with Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China today in Peking and the two agreed that an exchange of technological information could lead to increased United StatesChinese trade.

title: After a Year With Hooks as Leader, N.A.A.C.P. Shows New Vitality
description: SEATTLE, July 10  After a year at the helm, Benjamin L. Hooks has found that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is sometimes a smoothsailing ship to steer and at other times a difficult one.

title: Advertising
description: No one ad agency or person dominated the 57th annual awards show of the Art Directors Club, held last evening at a reception in the Union Carbide Gallery. The only one that came close to making a big splash was the team of Miller Brewing and McCannErickson, which together took two gold awards and two silvers  all for television commercials, a favorite advertising medium with many creative people.

title: F.T.C. INVESTIGATING CAR INSURANCE BIAS
description: WASHINGTON. July 10  The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was investigating alleged discrimination against minorities by insurance companies that use geographic location, or redlining, in fixing eligibility and price for automobile insurance.

title: 25th Heart Transplant Made
description: RICHMOND, July 10 (AP)  Gayle IStracener. 42 years old, of Harrisburg, Pa., today became the 25th recipient of a transplanted heart at the Medical College of Virginia here. Mr. Stracener was listed in satisfacthry condition after the fourhour surgery. The heart he received was flown in last night from a New York City hospital, a spokesman said.

title: Gas From Ruptured Chlorine Line Injures 37 at a Paper Mill in Ohio
description: CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, July 10 (AP) Gas pouring from a ruptured chlorine line at the Mead Corporation injured 37 workers today and forced the evacuation of about 300 others, the authorities said.

title: For the Race, Fashions Far From the Pits
description: A few years back the women who showed up for the Six Hours of Endurance race at Watkins Glen, N.Y., all looked like imports from California. They were so lanky in their tight white pants topped by colored Tshirts. And of course, their hair was straight. They flaunted the uniform.

title: Iraq ExPremier Dies in London, And Two Suspects Are Arrested
description: LONDON, July 10 (Reuters)  The British police today held two suspects in the killing of a former prime minister of Iraq, the latest in a series of Arab politicians who have met violent deaths in London.

title: 2 DISSIDENTS
description: MOSCOW, July 10  Anatoly Shcharansky, a dissident whose case has disrupted SovietAmerican relations, was put on trial for treason today in a closed Moscow courtroom. He was accused of having maintained regular contacts with foreign intelligence agents and having passed them state secrets. He reportedly denied the charges as absurd.

title: I.T.T. Seeks Drop In Telex Rates
description: ITT World Communications Inc., subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said that it had tiled a request with the Federal Communications Commission to reduce rates on Telex calls by as much as 25 percent.

title: Bell Canada to Test Electronic Phones
description: Bell Canada announced in Toronto that it would begin installing all-electronic telephones on a trial basis in early August. A total of 1,000 phones will be tested over an eightmonth period.

title: $55,000 Missing From Dandn
description: The disappearance and possible theft of about $55,000 in tickets and box-office receipts for the hit Broadway musical Dancin  are being investigated by Manhattan detectives, the Shubert Organization said yesterday.

title: N.I.T. Is in a Struggle for Teams
description: Faced with the loss of two of its three automatic berths in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament, the Eastern College Athletic Conference has pro- posed that the field for the N.C.A.A. tournament be expanded from 32 teams to 99 teams. However. E.C.A.C. officials admit that by making this proposal they could be jeopardizing the future of the National Invitation Tournament, the oldest postseason college basketball tourney and a competition dear to the hearts of E.C.A.C. member colleges.

title: Pact Reached On Uranium
description: BRUSSELS, July 10 (AP)  The nine countries of the European Common Market have reached a compromise with the United States that is expected to lead to a resumption of American shipments of enriched uranium to Europe, European and United States officials reported today.

title: Jury Finds Monopoly By Xerox
description: HARTFORD, July 10  A Federal jury said today that the Xerox Corporation had maintained an illegal monopoly of plainpaper copying machines, but it apparently reduced sharply the amount of damages likely to be won by the SCM Corporation in its long antitrust action against Xerox.

title: Lesson of Shaba: Carter Risked Serious Credibility Gap
description: WASHINGTON. July 10  On May 25. when President Carter accused Cuba of having backed the attack by Kantangans on Zaire's southern province of Shaba, some intelligence officials doubted that the Administration had conclusive eviNews

title: Judge Rules Falstaff Violated Beer Pact
description: Damages amounting to $1.2 million were assessed yesterday against the Falstaff Brewing Corporation of San Francisco for breach of contract entered in 1972 when it acquired P. Ballantine & Sons.

title: Market Place
description: THE Baltimore Canyon, a $1 billion gamble off the Jersey shore 73 miles from the nation's newest casino in Atlantic City, has become an even longer shot than it was.

title: French Recycling Plant on L.I.
description: Late this summer, the Town of Hempstead, L. I., will open a new garbage recycling plant that includes $23 million in French machinery.

title: Horse Named Lebon (Maybe)Bombs on Belmont Auction Block
description: ELMONT, L.I., July 10  The seller was there. The auctioneer was there. The District Attorney was represented and the press turned out in force. The only ingredient missing from today's thoroughbred auction at Belmont Park was money. Apparently no one could work up sufficient enthusiasm to spend real dollars on an animal enjoying the protective custody of the Nassau County District Attorney, a horse whose identity, ownership and ability are all in dispute and whose racing career may be behind him.

title: General Foods Cuts Coffee Prices By 20
description: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's No. 1 coffee roaster, lowered wholesale prices on its ground coffee by 20 cents a pound to $2.73. This followed similar action last Friday by the Folger Coffee Company, No. 2 roaster, a division of the Procter & Gamble Company, and Hills Brothers Coffee Inc., the nation's No. 3 roaster.

title: U.S. Sees No Change in Stance
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  A State Department spokesman said today that the United States had not been informed in any official way that Vietnam was ready to establish full diplomatic relations without any pledge of financial aid from Washington.

title: Big Waves About Air Waves
description: Recently the two ranking members of the House of Representatives Cornmunications subcommittee proposed to bestow the biggest giveaway of monopolybusiness power in recent history on holders of television and radio station licenses. They coupled their largess with the elimination of the public's historic right to have its tastes in programming considered and to be exposed to divergent views on public issues.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5 30 P M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95303; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691000; CONNECTICUT (203) 3457767.

title: Beaths
description: ROSENBERG-Fred-Beloved husband of Frieda. Devoted father of Inge Mund and Margot West. Dear brothor of Hugo. Loving grandfather of Linda Kamras, Douglas Mund and Kenneth West. Greatgrandfather of MiViael, Jason and Jeremy Kernres. Services Tuesday 2:30PM 'The Riverside Brooklyn, Ocean Parkway at Prospect Park.

title: SISTER NATALIE CASEY
description: Sister Natalie Casey, president since 1966 of Dominican College, Blauvelt, N.Y., died yesterday in St. Dominic's Convent in Blauvelt. She was 61 years old and lived at the convent.

title: AntiAngloSaxonism
description: The Supreme Court recently declared seven ancient AngloSaxon words unfit for general broadcast on radio and television. All seven refer to bodily wastes or sex. What was found offensive was not the subject matter they dealt with, but the use of AngloSaxon vocabulary to discuss it.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The new growth industry in Chicago is covering financial news.

title: Agency's New Offices Save G.S.A. $15,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Joel W. Solomon, chief of the General Services Administration, toured a new Government office today and found beauty and efficiency for $15,000 less than his agency had been willing to spend.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Instant Bargain

title: Savoring the Flavor Of Chinatown
description: If you called Emily Tom a snoop, she wouldn't be insulted. She'd be flattered. Over the years, she's found that there's a great education to be had in peeping through doorways, keeping her eyes open and being feisty enough to speak up, ask questions, poke her nose into things that are, truly, none of her business.

title: Republicans Likely to Get a Deal For Supporting Carey's Crime Bills
description: ALBANY, July 11  The Assembly's Democratic majority would be likely to authorize a bond issue for prison constructionwhich it has resisted if that would close the deal with the Republicancontrolled Senate on the crime bills Governor Carey is seeking, a senior aide to the leadership said today.

title: Agriculture Officials Report Action to Stop Grain Elevator Blasts
description: WASHINGTON. July 11The grain industry was put on notice today that the Agriculture Department would move toward a ban on recirculation of grain duSt, a practice suspected to be a cause of the explosions that pose a constant threat to grain workers and facilities.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi -
description: CURBSIDE MELTING POT: Warm weather tends to make the individual in us more visible, and this view of pedestrians waiting for a light at 57th Street and the Avenue of Americas shows the diversity that is New York.

title: KIN OF KLAN VICTIM SEEK MORE ANSWERS
description: DETROIT, July 11  A member of the family of Viola Liuzzo. a Detroitarea woman slain in March 1965 while engaging in civil rights activities in Alabama, said here today that, despite recent newspaper and television disclosures on the involvement of a Governmentpaid informer in the shooting incident, many questions still remain.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO SET FOR TALKS TODAY
description: GENEVA, July 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here tonight pledging to work toward overcoming remaining obstacles in the negotiations on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Correction
description: In an article by Donald Light Jr., published on July 5, the Center for Biomedical Education was incorrectly identified as part of New York University. It is part of City College.

title: Real Estate
description: PRINCETON. N.: AT Princeton University it is fit I., think in terms of decades. The year 1990. after all, is only l years away. By then, says John P Moran, the vice president for facilities, the entire Princeton Forrestal Center will be developed with 2.75 million square feet of officeresearch space in addition to housing and commercial facilities.

title: World Inflation At Rate of 8.8%
description: PARIS, July 11 (UPI)  The average annual inflation rate in 24 industrial countries stands at 8.8 percent, with most of the speedup in higher consumer prices in North America, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

title: Moynihan Charges White House Is Trying to Destroy Welfare Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that the White House was quietly trying to wreck his $5 billionayear no frills welfare revision bill and described the attempt as kind of dumb.

title: Trade Center Bomb
description: The sinisterlooking device with which along with four loaves of dark bread a Polishspeaking machinist allegedly held four persons hostage for more than 10 hours Monday at 2 World Trade Center contained only a flattened CocaCola can, the notice said yesterday_

title: Youth in the Rockefeller Crash Was a Top Student.
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, July 11 David Laurent Low, the 16yearold driver of the car that collided head on yesterday with one carrying John D. Rockefeller 3d, killing both of them, was a straightA student at Briarcliff High School and one of our superstars, his principal. Joseph Troy, said today.

title: Weekly Steel Output Drops
description: Steel production in the United States for the week ended July S fell to 2.63 million tons, down 2 percent from 2.65 4nillion tons produced the week before. according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Estonian Aims at a Future Perfect
description: The Estonian language has no articles, no gender, no prepositions, not much of a present and only a doubtful future.

title: $36 BILLION IN ARMS INCLUDING NAVY F18 IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The Senate overwhelmingly approved a controversial Navy fighterplane program today, and then passed an overall military spending bill authorizing the Pentagon to spend $36 billion for weapons.

title: South Africa Orders Investigation Into Death of Black Held by Police
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 11  The South African Government has ordered highlevel police inquiry into the death of a young black man who plunged to his death from the fifthfloor offices of the security police in Port Elizabeth yesterday. Stephen Biko received his fatal head injuries 10 months ago while in the custody of the same police force in the same building.

description: TANGIER,MOrOCCO

description: The owners of the Chrysler Building, an Art Deco structure rich in ornamentation and lighting designed to symbolize the essence of New York and the auto industry, yesterday opposed its designation as a New York City landmark.

title: TV: Their Son Is Their Victim
description: SOMETIMES a production is so bad, so obviously turned sour, that it perversely demands its own share of attention. Daddy, I Don't Like It Like This is that kind of production, available to the dauntless on CBS tonight at 9. The script was written by Burt Young, who also costars with Talia Shire. Both actors were Academy Award nominees for their performances in Rocky.

description: HACKENSACK, July 11  After number of unsuccessful attempts to get into evidence a scientist's report showing no curare in one of the bodies of the five persons Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich is accused of murdering, the defense attorney shouted the results of that report to the jury today.

title: Keystone to Back Oppenheimer Offer
description: The Keystone Custodian Fund of Boston, with $1.6 billion under management, voted to recommend that shareholders approve an amended offer for its takeover by the Oppenheimer Management Corporation of New York for about $17.7 million in cash. Although Keystone would operate separately, merger of the two would bring assets under management to nearly $3 billion.

title: Nuclear Report Casts Doubt on Most Plans For Disposal of Waste

title: Record I.M.M. Seat Price
description: A membership on the International Monetary Market division of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange sold yesterday for a record $114.000, up $4,000 from the previous mark set last Friday. The 1. M. M. provides a market in foreign currency, Treasury bill and gold futures, among other commodity futures contracts.

title: A Covey of Coups
description: When regimes in several distant lands are toppled within a matter of days, there is a temptation to impose connections for the sake of symmetry. The result usually more a tribute to imagination than to reality.

description: The Bond Baking Company, which once operated 94 plants nationwide, was saved from bankruptcy yesterday by a bank loan secured through the help of the City of Philadelphia.

title: House Unit, 420, Backs Bank Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The House Committee on Banking, Currency and Urban Affairs approved unanimously today legislation that would prohibit many of the banking practices that last year forced Bert Lance, the former Budget Director, from office.

title: Times and Daily News Set Deadline of Aug. 8 On Pressmen Contract
description: The New York Times and The Daily News set an Aug. 8 deadline yesterday for a new contract with the Pressmens Union.

title: Wine Talk
description: NO city in the world is more readily identified with wine than Vienna  and not just in song. There are dozens of vineyards literally within the city limits, and it is said that Viennese connoisseurs know every one of the local wine makers by name and can easily identify all the wines from the city's vineyards, such as griming, sievering, nussdorf and kahlembere.

Jascalevich, accused of murdering five hospital patients.

title: Manslaughter Laid to Sergeants In the Death of 2 Army Trainees
description: COLUMBIA. S.C.. July 11 (AP)  Two drill sergeants who put recruits through excessive and prolonged physical training on their first day in camp have been charged with involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of two trainees, according to Army officials.

description: WOONSOCKET, R.I., July 11 (AP) Paul Linwood Smith, former managing editor of The Woonsocket Call and a member of a prominent Rhode Island family, died today at Woonsocket Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Moscow SitIn Now in 3d Week
description: MOSCOW, July 11 (AP)  Seven Pentecostalists from Siberia seeking permission to emigrate to the United States began their third week barricaded inside the American Embassy today. The embassy staff has tried to persuade them to leave, but an official said that embassy policy is not to force refugees out.

title: $100 Million Toll in Minnesota
description: ST. PAUL July 11 (UPI)  Recent tornadoes, floods, heavy rains and hail caused damage estimated at $100 million or more in Minnesota.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: STREET scene: I was on a bus headed for the Port Authority Bus Terminal on a beautiful weekday afternoon, writes Regina Cione. It all happened on 49th Street and Broadway, where the bus usually turns southbound and heads straight for the Port Authority. But not on this particular day.

title: Q8A
description: Q. All my life I have served the green salad with the main course. So did my mother. A friend suggests that this is improper, that you should serve salad as a separate course. What do you think?

description: SAN DIEGO, July 11  BasebaU staged its 49th AllStar Game tonight in the home of the revived San Diego Padres, with the American League trying to end a sixyear losing streak despite the absence of four of its ranking players.

description: HONOLULU, July 11 (AP)  A Vietnamese delegation begins meetings here tomorrow with American officials in an effort to identify Vietnam War victims.

description: MINEOLA, L.I. July 11  The executors of the estate of Joan Whitney Payson were ordered by a court today to pay the Metropolitan Museum of Art a $1.5 million balance on a 35 million pledge made during a casual conversation between Mrs. Payson and the museum's president.

title: Fora Summit Host, Bonn Is the Height of Provincialism
description: BONN, July 11  On the bad days, when the town dozes in the Rhine mists, when the traffic piles up alongside the train tracks that split the Government district in halt, when everything in Bonn must be seen through a windshield wiper's arc an American, whc usually tolerates the place, calls it secondrate Albany.

I believed in government's ability to manage, to right wrongs and make things work. I was also obviously totally ignorant of government and its functioning.

title: Knowing The Opposition
description: SAN DIEGO, July 11  Despite his reputation as baseball's best bluer, Rod Carew had an AllStar average of only .111 before tonight's game. Only three hits in 27 official times at bat in 10 previous games. No extrabase hits. Rod's the type of hitter, said Billy Martin, the New York Yankees manager who was directing the American League squad, that likes to get to know pitchers. title: YONKERS ASKS RAISE IN TAX FOR UTILITIES
description: YONKERS, July 11 The City Council voted last night to send a homerule message to the State Legislature asking for permission to raise the utility tax from percent to 3 percent.

title: VIETNAMESE REPORT CHINESE OVERFLIGHT
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11  Vietnam charged today that Chinese warplanes flew over its territory Sunday and said that the Chinese Embassy in Hanoi had rejected a Foreign Ministry note protesting the incident.

description: CRIME

title: United Press International
description: ONE FOR ENERGY: On the first anniversary of the state's Energy Department, Commissioner Joel R. Jacobson gave his secretary, Terry Sellmeyer Newark, a taste of birthday cake. Commissioner Jacobson marked event announcing delay in start of 10year energy master plan until Oct. 11.

title: Scotland Finds Itself
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland  When demonstrators last week threw horse manure into the House of Commons the subject under debate was Scottish devolution. There is no significance in that. It would, in fact, have been quitehard in the past two years to catch members of Parliament debating anything else but Scottish devolution. One bill on the subject failed last year. Now a second bill is almost through all its torturous stages, the most complicated piece of legislation ever undertaken by a British Government.

title: Two Held in Alleged Firebombing Of Home in Rochester Killing One
description: ROCHESTER, July 11 (AP)  A young man and a teenager were charged with murder and arson in the apparent firebombing of a twofamily home here early today that killed an elderly woman and injured 12 other persons the nolice said

title: A Chain Reaction of Promotions
description: David J. Sherwood, 55 years old, was named presidentelect of the Prudential Insurance Company yesterday, succeeding Robert A. Beck, who, as previously announced, will become chairman and chief executive officer on Sept. 15.

title: House Panel Votes Bill to Speed Deporting of Nazi War Criminals
description: WASHINGTON. July 11 (AP)  The House Judiciary Committee voted 21 to today to close what was described as loophole in the immigration laws to permit the deportation of Nazi war criminals.

description: Music

description: SAN SEBASTIAN. Spain. July 11 (Reuters)  Three days of violence that forced cancellation of Pamplona's annual bullfight fiesta spilled into this Basque capital today.

title: Bonn Eyes Stimulus
description: BONN. July. 11  The West German Government is considering a fiveyear plan of public spending and investment stimulants to serve as a partial reply to expected demands at the economic summit conference here Sunday and Monday that the nation promote more economics rm Eh.

title: An Eruption on Sun, The Most Potent Ever, Disrupts Sea Contacts
description: An eruption on the sun, in some respects the most powerful ever recorded, occurred at 6.43 A.M. yesterday, disrupting Coast Guard ship-to-shore communi, cations, saturating Xray detectors on two satellites and sending magnetic clouds streaking through the solar systern.

title: WRITERS IN PROTEST NEAR SOVIET MISSION
description: Arthur Miller, Edward Albee and other leading literary figures conducted a quiet protest outside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday against the trials of dissidents in the Soviet Union.

title: Associated Press
description: CAPTURED: Sgt. Don Elmer of the Cherry Hill police, holding white bag, watched as another officer held handcuffed man to the ground Monday after what was described as a highspeed 10mile chase of two suspects after a restaurant robbery in Cherry Hill. Checks and cash worth about $6,000 were taken from the restaurant.

title: Slatkin to Conduct in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, July 11 (UPI)  Leonard Slatkin, music director of the New Orleans Philharmonic, has been appointed music director and principal conductor of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

title: Homebuilding on Leased Land Attacked in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU  One of the customs that have evolved here, the building of homes on leased land, has come under heavy pressure as more people are demanding that big landholders be required to sell residential properties to the owners of the homes that occupy them.

title: A Correction
description: In an article June 28 in The Living Section that described the development of a liquid yogurt called Le Shake, the word with was inadvertently used in an explanation about the product. The statement should have said that Le Shake ... had a threeweek shelf life without addition of preservatives...

title: SuperSonics Sign Wilkens To a FiveYear Contract
description: SEATTLE, July 11 (AP)  Lenny Wilkens, who led the Seattle SuperSonics out of an early season slump and into the National Basketball Association championship series, signed a fiveyear contract today, the team announced.

title: Carey Signs Bill on Police Widows
description: With the gubernatorial election campaign as a backdrop, Governor Carey yesterday dramatized his signing of a bill to increase the pensions of the widows of policemen and firemen killed in the line of duty.

title: Bolivian Leftists Charge `Gigantic Fraud
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 11 (Reuters) Bolivia's leftwing opposition walked out of the La Paz electoral court today alleging fraud and a conspiracy to deny it victory in the general elections held on Sunday.

description: A listing of new corporate bonds in The Times on Monday carried an incorrect rating for a Diamond State Telephone Company issue at 9 percent due in 2018: The rating is Aaa.

title: Golden Cards 67, Leads Golf

title: Chicago Sting Is Aided by 3 West German Players

title: Energy, Drug and Airline Shares Outshine Casinos
description: Prominent energy issues, buoyed mainly by rumors of possible oil finds, led the stock market higher yesterday. The drugs and airlines continued to show strength, while the recently popular casino group was hit by widespread losses. Trading volume picked up smartly.

title: General Cable to Buy Shares From BICC
description: The General Cable Corporation has reached an agreement to purchase from B1CC Ltd. 2,869,000 shares of General Cable stock, representing 20.1 percent, owned by the British concern, at $18.50 a share, or approximately $53 million.

title: Potential Hazards Are Reported From Some Health Store Herbs
description: CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI)  Certain herbs and plants offered in health food stores can be dangerous to a person's health, says an article in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: GOV. GRASSO TO LET PARTY NAME TICKET
description: HARTFORD, July 11  Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced today that she planned to throw open the Democratic State Convention this month to let the delegates choose her running mate in this year's election, a move that would be unprecedented in the state's politics.

title: 60Minute Gourmet

title: CHARGES ARE FILED IN MRS. GANDHI CASE
description: NEW DELHI, July 11  The Government of Prime Minister M6rarji R. Desai took its first legal step today toward prosecuting former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi over her authoritarian rule by filing preliminary charges against her in a magistrate's court.

title: Xerox Jury Backs SCM In 2 Shifts
description: HARTFORD, July 11  The Federal jury in the SCM Corporation's antitrust. case against the Xerox Corporation. today reversed two of the verdicts it reached yesterday, thus sustaining SCM's major remaining claim against Xerox.

title: Court Backs Some Laetrile Use
description: DENVER, July 11 (AP)  Terminal cancer patients are entitled to laetrile injections under a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Cir cuit, which ordered the Food and Drug Administration to set guidelines with all due dispatch for the use of laetrile.

title: HouseSenate Panel Fails to Gain Agreement on Aid for New York
description: WASHINGTON. July 11Members of the House of Representatives and the Senate failed again today to reach a cornpromise agreement on a bill to give New York City Federal loan guarantees.

title: Grain Crop Outlook Off
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Farmers arc expiqled to harvest 6.15 billion bushels of corn this fall, 4 percent less than the record crop of 1977, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Higher Prices, Volume Lift Cateroillar's Profits
description: Increased selling prices and higher volume lifted profits of the Caterpillar Tractor Company by 28.2 percent in the quarter ended June 30 and 25.3 percent for the halfyear.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO SET FOR TALKS TODAY
description: GENEVA, July 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here tonight pledging to work toward overcoming remaining obstacles in the negotiations on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Higher Oil Prices Offered for Energy Bill Help
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger has offered the oil industry an immediate increase in prices of newly discovered oil if its executives will urge Congress to approve the controversial tax portion of the Administration's longdelayed energy bill.

title: WIFE OF DISSENTER EJECTED FROM TRIAL
description: MOSCOW, July 11  The wife of Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, one of the dissidents being tried in the Soviet Union, was ejected from the courtroom today after clashed with a prosecution witness, and relatives of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, another dissident, were barred from his trial as the proceedings went into secret session to hear testimony on the capital charge of treason.

title: Some Legislators See 2 Recent Trials As Carter Crackdown on Release of Inforrnatio
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The Justice Department's handling of two separate cases has prompted a number of Congressmen, civil liberties lawyers and other experts to tear that the Carter Administration is developing new legal methods for imposing Government secrecy.

title: Carter Calls Meeting on Unauthorized Disclosures
description: WASHINGTON. July 11  President Carter summoned key members of Congress to the White House today to discuss an epidemic of unauthorized disclosure of classified information from Capitol Hill that the President said was drying up intelligence sources and damaging national security.

title: BROTHER JOSEPH DANAHAR
description: Brother Aquilinus Joseph Danahar, member of the Christian Brothers order and for 43 years a member of the faculty and staff of Manhattan College, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, died Sunday at St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains, after a monthlong illness. He was 75 years old.

title: House Unit To Weigh Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Al Ullman, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the panel would resume consideration of a taxcut proposal next week, signaling probable failure for the Administration's efforts to prevent a substantial reduction in capital gains taxes.

title: Israeli's Analyze Cairo's New Peace.Proposals and Term Them a Retreat
description: JERUSALEM, July 11  A week before a meeting in London of representatives of the United States, Israel and Egypt on the stalled Middle East peace effort, Israeli officials are contending that Egypt's recent peace plan is a retreat from the stance it took in direct talks with Israel.

title: Careers
description: THE travel agency business conjures glamour  flying into the wild blue yonder, dining on a terrace overlooking the Riviera, guessing at the meaning of Stonehenge and conveying this to clients.

title: U.S. Yacht Wins in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, July, 11(Reuters) Wildfire, an American boat, scored its second victory this week by winning the third race in the Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5Meter class here today. Wildfire, with Albert Fay at the helm and a borrowed boom after an accident yesterday, started out best and was in the lead most of the'way. 4

title: Sports News Briefs

Humphrey said today that newspaper reports that the Minnesota Democrat had left trusts for his family valued at well in excess of $1 million were exaggerated, and he flatly denied that the trusts included gifts of stock from Dwayne 0. Andreas, a wealthy businessman who was Mr. Humphrey's close friend.

If works, the technique would permit utilities to burn highsulfur coal without running afoul of any environmental laws, including some that the Government has not even begun to enforce.

The Rev. Martin O'Regan, 41 years old, was expelled by the Government after being convicted last year of failing to report thepresence of black nationalist guerrillas on his remote mission three miles from the eastern border with Mozambique.

He has kept his laconic style, his unresolved ambiguities, and has retained Crane's ability of balancing the real and the symbolic in ways that stimulate the intellect as they stir the emotions.

title: GOING OUT Guide

Startine at noon two hours before curtain time, show pa. trons and pedestrians will find Betsy Palmer supervising a onehour sale of theater memorabilia in front of the Ambassador, on 49th Street west of Broadway, where the actress costars with Charles Kimbrough in the longrunning comedy. Sale proceeds go to the Foster Home Division of the Salvation Army, which is supplying band music, as their commissary truck serves coffee and doughnuts  free, but contributions will be appreciated.

If the legislation finally passes, it will offer the city's leadership a last chance to make constructive use of the nation's help.

title: Rivlin Bids Fed, Carter and Congress Cooperate
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The director of the Congressional Budget Office warned today that, without better coordination among the Federal Reserve Board, Congress and the Carter Administration, the chances for a recession are great. warning against dangers of monetary and fiscal overreaction to the acceleration of price increases in recent months, the director, Alice M. Rivlin, said that more coordination was necessary among the Fed, which runs monetary policy, and Congress and the Administration, which jointly determine spending and tax levels.

title: Questions Cooking Students Ask Most
description: ISUDDENLY woke up; looked at my watch. It was 5:30 A.M. tried to collect my thoughts and figure out where I was. Obviously, it was another hotel room, but where? Was it Chicago? No. Chicago was last week. Tampa? No. Tampa was the week before. Ann Arhnr that's where I was. I sighed. I wasn't insane after all, although I was getting there, after seven weeks of nonstop teaching in Baltimore, Philadelphia, Houston, Redwood City, Los Angeles, Tampa and Chicago. Finally came Ann Arbor, and my last series of classes before heading back home to Connecticut to rest for a couple of weeks before starting all over again.
