title: John D. Rockefeller 3d (19061978)
description: The third John D. Rockefeller, gentle and self-effacing, tended to operate outside of public awareness. Shy, persistent, idealistic  such were the adjectives used to describe this least flamboyant of the grandsons of the controversial oil magnate. Far more attention was focused on brothers Nelson, the politician, David. the banker, and Winthrop, the late governor of Arkansas. John Rockefeller once jokingly described himself as the only one of the brothers who was unemployed. But his death in an automobile accident this week deprives the ,family of its chief philanthropist, the man who was responsible for shepherding the family's philanthropic interests.

title: Notes on People
description: VICE PRESIDENT MONDALE, who is often called on at the White House to swear in newly appointed officers, broke the monotony of the job yesterday by going for laughs. On entering Me Roosevelt Room for the swearing in of two ambassadors, he spied some champagne and said in mock amazement, Booze? In the White House? Then, when the new Ambassador to South Korea, William Gleysteen, put his right hand on the Bible to be sworn in and raised his left hand, Mr. Mondale reached over and took the right hand off the Bible and moved the left hand into its place. The hardest problem is always remembering your right hand, he told Mr. Gleysteen. That's what you get with a leftist Administration. He then swore in Morton Abramowitz as Ambassador to Thailand. His duties done, Mr. Mondale shooed out the photographers as he headed for the champagne, saying, There's a new form of decadence here. It's the first time we've had champagne in this joint.

title: Living in the Follies of the Past
description: FOLLIES are the icing on the cake of architecture, the conceits, fantasies and esthetic oddities built not for utility, but for caprice and art. Architectural handbooks and dictionaries define a folly as a functionally useless structure, usually a tower or sham classical or Gothic ruin erected in a planned landscape for purely ornamental purposes  to evoke a kind of cultural and visual nostalgia, or to enhance a view. Their design was often credited to eccentric builders bent on the indulgence of personal esthetic whims; useless and idiosyncratic structures, they were, therefore, follies.

description: SAN DIEGO, July 12  Baseball's deep thinkers today are trying to explain why the AllStar Game is the National pastime. With its 73 victory last night, the National League now has won the last seven games, 15 of the last 16 and 20 of the last 22 but only Lee MacPhail, the American League president, appears to be embarraSsed. AS he should be. But in the AllStar rivalry, it's not whether you win or lose, it's how you stage the game. And this one was staged impeccablythe fastball picher, Rich Gossage, against the fastball hitters when the game was on the line in

title: Besselink Posts 67 in State Open
description: GROSSINGER. N.Y., July 12  AJ Besselink of Las Vegas, Nev., struck a blow for senior citizens and the medical profession today in the first New York State open golf championship.

title: Profit Gains Lift Stocks For 5th Day
description: A string of sparkling profit reports helped to send the stock market higher yesterday for its fifth consecutive modest advance. But the casino issues, the market's standout performers during the last six weeks, met selling pressure for the second day in a row.

title: An Amendment: Other Mayors Also
description: We owe former Mayor Hearne an amendment of the record to have it show that he was not alone in having his taxfree city residence counted as income for pension benefits. Although he is the most prominent recent beneficiary of this accounting wizardry, he did not invent it. It was enshrined, we are told at City Hall, in pension law in May O'Dwyer's time and has been available to all officials living in official housing. Our concern is not with the author or even the beneficiaries of such clever counting but only with the idea that it should be countenanced.

title: Carter Urges Extension For Rights Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter today urged the House Judiciary Committee to vote for an extension of the sevenyear deadline for ratifying the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Vivid Scars of 77 Blackout Remain in City
description: In the aftermath of last year's great blackout, New York City officials promised swift action and a steady flow of funds to stabilize neighborhoods ravaged by looters. The proMises were aimed at restoring the commercial and residential life of areas that had already been suffering from severe decay.

title: 120 Survivors of Camp Blaze in Spain Expected to Die
description: SAN CARLOS DE LA RAPITA, Spain, July 12 (Reuters)  Some burned survivors of the gastruck explosion that devastated a Mediterranean campground near here yesterday were flown to burn centers in West Germany, Belgium and France in attempts to save their lives. But others were so severely burned that doctors would not allow them to be moved.

title: Justice Dept. Investigating Report Linking Informer to Violent Crime
description: WASHINGTON. July 12  The Justice Department began a formal inquiry today to determine whether Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. was involved in violent crime while he was a Ku Klux Klan informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and whether bureau agents helped to hide the fact.

title: Moynihan Says He Was Asked to Fight Soviet Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, disclosed today that a responsible White House official had asked him to bring public pressure on the Government to ban the sale of American technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Cairo Security Police Again Seize a Paper; Judge Overturns Move
description: CAIRO, July 12  The Egyptian security police confiscated during the night the lastest issue of a leftist party newspaper, which resumed publication to test President Anwar elSadat's suppression of dissent, but the police action was overturned by Egypt's Attorney General, Ahmed Moussa.

title: Accentuate The Positive
description: BOSTON, July 12  Can the meeting of Israeli. Egyptian and American foreign ministers in London next week revive the Sadat initiative? Is there life after death?

title: Wife Fears Shcharansky Execution And Foresees Wave of Persecution
description: GENEVA, July 12  Avital Shcharansky, the wife of the Soviet dissident being tried on charges of spying for the United States, said here today that she is convinced the Russians have decided to execute her husband, and that his trial is the signal for a vast new wave of persecutions.

title: EARNINGS RCA Profit Up 12%; CBS Advances 8%
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday a 12 percent gain in earnings for the three months ended with June on a 13 percent rise in revenues.

title: Home Improvement
description: AN airconditioner is the first thing most homeowners think of when outside temperatures start to climb into the high 130's, but there was a time when the only thing used to keep cool was a window or attic exhaust fan  and these tans can still be a great help during hot weather. Far from being obsolete, fans are actually more popular than ever for making homes and apartments more comfortable, especially in the evening when outside temperatures drop.

title: . . . And the Dark Path
description: WASHINGTON  The greatest advantage of all to being blind seems to be occurring with increasing regularity in the season of the year in which we currently find ourselves. Traditionally, summer is the time for beer and baseball. More recently, yet another B has joined the list: Blackouts.

title: SEICHARANSKY'S LINK TO REPORTERS CITED
description: MOSCOW, July 12  Regular contacts with American reporters emerged today as the Government's main argument to sustain a capital charge of treason and espionage against Anatoly B. Shcharansky as his trial went through its third day.

title: Airlines Hold Talks On Merger
description: Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines announced yesterday that they had completed a sevenmonth merger feasibility study and that their top executives were negotiating terms for a possible merger.

title: PRESIDENT DEPLORES THE RUSSIAN TRIALS AS BLOW TO LIBERTY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter condemned the trials of Anatoly B. Shcharansky and other Soviet dissi dents today as an attack on every human being who lives in the world who believes in basic human freedom and is willing to speak for these freedoms or fight for them.

title: 17 Hurt When Bus Overturns
description: HEREFORD, Md., July 12 (UPI)  A bus carrying a Baptist church choir from Louisville, Ky., overturned today on Interstate 83 north of Baltimore, injuring at least 17 persons, the state police said. The choir was on its way to a performance in Baltimore County. None of the injuries were serious.

title: International Paper Gains
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaker, reported yesterday a secondquarter profits gain of 17.3 percent, while GeorgiaPacific Corporation, another leading forest products producer realized a 25 percent rise.

title: Auerbach, Knicks Will Meet Today
description: The meeting at which Red Auerbach will be offered the presidency of the Knicks will be held today.

title: Let's Leave John Brown's Body Alone
description: John Brown's body may be aturnin rather than amolderin in his grave as the Lake Placid Olympic ski jumps rear their aggressive concrete towers in clear view of the quiet Adirondack farm where he and a dozen followers lie buried. As if that visual damage were not bad enough, the New York State Office of Parks and Recreation plans to improve this pastoral site with $650,000 worth of paved parking lots, picnic grounds, sewers and a visitororientation center. All that is required is the Adirondack Park Agency's permission to reclassify the bucolic setting from wild forest to intensive use and the busywork can begin.

title: Justice Marshall Refuses to Quash Times Subpoena to Yield Curare Data
description: A second United States Supreme Court justice refused yesterday to block a New Jersey court order directing The New York Times to submit the files of one of its reporters on Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich to the judge presiding at the surgeon's murder trial.

title: CORRECTION
description: The address of the Drama Commit. tee Repertory Theater, which appeared yesterday in a review of Crane's Way, was incorrect. The theater, where the show will be per. farmed tonight, is at 17 West 20th Street.

title: Gasoline Stocks Down in Week
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that gasoline stocks for the week ended July 7 declined to 225.7 million barrels, compared with 229.1 million barrels for the previous week.

title: Giscard Oil Warning to Carter
description: PARIS, July 12  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France put President Carter publicly on notice today that next weekend's economic summit meeting in Bonn will fail unless he takes drastic action to cut back United States oil imports.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Newark funeral director, who admitted he had cremated the body of an 80-year-old female pauper and sought to stage a fake funeral for an alleged narcotics dealer, was ordered to close his funeral home.

title: Cefalo: Drafted Into a Dream
description: By 3 P.M., my mother was saying her rosary in a corner of the kitchen. My Aunt Helen, who had a set of rosary beads from Jerusalem that had been blessed by the Pope, was praying in another corner. I was depressed.

title: U.S. to Study Import of Fish Kill At a Salem County Nuclear Plant
description: TRENTON, July 12  Thousands of fish are being killed daily at a nuclear power plant in Salem County, and Federal officials will meet tomorrow in Manhattan to assess the situation.

title: GARDENING Day Lilies Aren't Shy in Shade
description: DAY lilies ask very little but give a great deal. With very little care, the plants show off their blossoms from morning to dusk and then fade away. For day lilies are just that, flowers for a day. Their botanical name, Hemerocallis, is taken from the Greek  hemera meaning day and kalles, a kind of lily.

title: 4 DEAD AFTER RAID BY RHODESIA REBELS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 12 (AP)  Black nationalist guerrillas attacked a 50vehicle tourist convoy in northwestern Rhodesia this afternoon, killing 4 people and wounding 16, military officials reported.

title: In Canada, the Provinces Seek to End the National Lottery
description: OTTAWA, July 12  The lottery business, a $200 million a year activity here involving four out of every five Canadians as players and creating a new group of instant millionaires with the regular draw every two months, has become the newest battleground in the continuing power struggle between the national Government and the 10 provinces.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Charles A. Carlson Jr. was elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Lukens Steel Company yesterday, succeeding W.E. Mullestein, who will retire Aug. 31. Currently vice chairman, Mr. Carlson joined Lukens, the country's oldest steel company, in 1939 and advanced through sales, purchasing and administrative posts to become senior vice president in 1973. He was named executive vice president in 1975, president in 1976 and vice chairman a year ago. He will take over his new job on Sept. 1.

title: Martin Drives Bounty Hunter to Grand Prix Power Boat Victory
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J. JULY 12  Bounty Hunter, driven by Billy Martin of Clark, N.J., crossed the finish far ahead of the field today,to win Grand Prix offshore power boat race by 4 minutes.

title: Carey Retains Homeowners
description: ALBANY, July 12  Governor Carey today signed a bill designed to retain the current system of realproperty tax assessments, which favors the owners of oneand twofamily homes over holders of apartment and industrial property.

title: Notes on People
description: ARETIRED cookie baker, Walter Poenisch, was reported yesterday to be swimming in the Florida Straits from Havana to Marathon in the Florida Keys. Havana radio, monitored in Miami. said that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba chatted with Mr. Poenisch, who was 65 years old on Tuesday, before seeing him off on his marathon swim Tuesday night. The longdistance swimmer was said to have set off on a 105mile course in a shark protection cage pulled by a support boat piloted by his wife. If he makes it to Marathon, he will have beaten Diana Nyad to the feat. Miss Nyad's plan to make a similar Cuba-to-Florida recordbreaking journey on July 21 has received widespread publicity. Mr. Poenisch, who is from Grove City, Ohio, has been a marathon swimmer for 15 years and is credited with swimming 122 miles in the Florida Straits in 1976.

title: JOAN LITTLE PLEADS GUILTY OF ESCAPING
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 12  Joan Little, whose firstdegree murder trial here three years ago attracted national and international attention, pleaded guilty today to prisonescape charges and was sentenced to six months to two years in prison.

title: 2 Are Shot as Basques Clash With the Police In 4th Day of Violence
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 12 (Reuters)  Two people were reported shot and wounded in this northern Spanish city tonight in new clashes between riot policemen and Basque nationalists.

title: Husbands, Wives and Rivals
description: SHORTLY after the big break in the Son of Sam case, two broadcasting executives one in radio, the other in television reached from the bed to the telephone. It was the same bed, but two phones  and one of them was dead.

title: Times Plea on CurareCase Data Is Denied
description: A second United States Supreme Court justice refused yesterday to block a New Jersey court order directing The New York Times to submit the files of one of its reporters on Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich to the judge presiding at the surgeon's murder trial.

title: C.A.B. Asked to End New Route Awards
description: National Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to deny new route awards to Texas International Airlines that would increase the smaller carrier's direct competition with National. Texas International announced at the beginning of the week that it had acquired 9.2 percent of National's stock and left open the possibility of seeking control.

title: Study for Carter Asks Bigger Role For Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  A report on the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today that the nation's highest military body was playing a limited role in defense policy, hampered by the historic unwilling- ness of the military to assign its best officers to jobs on the joint staff and plagued by procedures that inhibit initiative and need major overhaul.

title: jazz: Don Elliott Leads A Jazz Trio at Citicorp
description: DON ELLIOIT, the vibraphonist, mellophonist and singer (he started his career as Hi in the vocal group called Hi Lo Jack and the Dame) who became prominent in jazz with the George Shearing Quintet in the early 50's, has been a behind-the-scenes performer for most of the last 20 years as a producer and performer on commercials. Recently, however, he has been returning to his jazz roots.

title: Ashland Assails Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Ashland Oil Company accused the Department of Energy today of using ambiguous and confusing rules to force the company to pay $52.1 million to the Treasury in alleged overcharges to customers.

title: New Judge Sees Another View From the Top
description: Freddy Martinez slumps in the defendant's chair. He is charged with wifebeating. A police officer is on the witness stand, and the officer is testifying that after the police arrested Mr. Martinez, he told them: I didn't beat her up. All I did was smack her around.

title: Overseas Notes Of J.C. Penney
description: About $100 million of notes of the J.C. Penney Company are scheduled to be sold overseas by a syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation, the underwriter said yesterday.

title: Just 110 of 3,076 Arrested in Blackout Sentenced to More Than Year
description: only 110 of the 3,076 people arrested on looting and other blackoutrelated charges during the citywide power failure that began last July 13 have been sentenced to jail terms of a year or more, according to a report issued yesterday by New York State court and criminal-justice officials.

title: Books of The Times
description: FAMILIES. By Jane Howard. 282 pages. Simon&Sdaister. $9.95.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE AND BREEZY Tonight at 8:30 it's Puccini's Tosca at the Central Park Mall, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue, as Vincent La Selva conducts the New York Grand Opera Company. The rain date is Tuesday.

title: Expert Asserts Curare Caused Death in Jersey Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 12  An anesthesiologist who has specialized in the study of curare disagreed today with the listed cause of death of one of five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell that Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich is accused of murdering in 196566 with lethal doses of the muscle relaxing drug.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, July 12 (UPI)  Taking four aspirin a day can cut the risk of fatal or crippling stroke in half for men who have had warning signs of an impending attack, the New England Journal of Medicine reported today. However, the drug offers no similar help to women.

title: 4 REPORTEDLY CITED IN KOREAN SCANDAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The House ethics committee voted secretly today to proceed with disciplinary action against four present members of the House for their alleged misconduct in the Korean influencebuying scandal, according to Congressional sources.

title: Disks: Straussian Arias
description: MONTSERRAT CABALLE is best known for her excursions into the Italian bel canto repertory, and justly so. But for a woman so often accused of placidity, she has in fact shown a com

title: Economic Scene
description: TIP: Has Its Time Finally Arrived?

title: Resumption of Increased Rents In 35,000 Apartments Ordered
description: Tenants of about 35,000 rentcontrolled apartments in New York City must resume paying special laborcost rent increases of up to 7.5 percent, provided their landlords put the increases in escrow accounts while the validity of the increases continues to be argued in court.

title: Vance and Gromyko, in Geneva, Seek Agreement on Arms Treaty
description: GENEVA, July 12  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance conferred for more than four hours with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in an effort to narrow differences blocking a new treaty limiting strategic arms. He then conveyed to Mr. Gromyko a message for Leonid I. Brezh- nev, the Soviet leader, expressing President Carter's concern over the fate of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the dissident on trial in Moscow.

title: F.D.I.C. Suit Against Franklin National Head
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has filed a multimilliondollar suit charging Laurence A. Tisch, head of Tisch Hotels and the Loews Corporation with a breach of fiduciary duties in the sale of 340 million worth of stock of the defunct Franklin National Bank, while serving as its board chairman.

title: Doubleday Throws A Bookstore Party
description: Jacqueline Onassis, briefly interrupted, looked aside and said, I'm talking to a brilliant author.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Van DykXerox Trial
description: NEWARK, July 12 (AP)  Twelve Xerox Corporation attorneys crowded one side of a Federal courtroom here today, across from three lawyers for a small New Jersey concern that has accused the huge corporation of creating a monopoly in the business copier industry.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, July 12,1978 Petition Filed By:

title: Vivid Scars of 77 Blackout Remain in City
description: In the aftermath of last year's great blackout, New York City officials promised swift action and a steady flow of funds to stabilize neighborhoods ravaged by looters. The promises were aimed at restoring the commercial and residential life of areas that had already been suffering from severe decay.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figuresfrom major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Cosmos See Streak End at 23
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 12  New England put an end to the Cosmos 23game winning streak at Giants Stadium tonight before a crowd of 62,497 with a 31 triumph, the second victory for the Tea Men over the Cosmos in one week.

title: Q&A
description: Q We have a terrazzo kitchen floor and have applied several coats of varnish to it. After about six months the floor is very dull. Can you tell us how to remove the varnish? What would you suggest for a betterlooking floor? R.M., Philadelphia, Pa.

title: Skylab Batteries Are Recharged In An Effort to Keep Craft Aloft
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reuters) Scientists successfully recharged the batteries on the Skylab space station today, the first step in renewed efforts to stabilizt the 85ton craft and keep it from falling back to earth.

title: Hotel, Another Victim of Legion Disease, Sells Belongings
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12  In the Trysting Place, the room where Glenn Miller played; where hundreds of Philadelphia debutantes came out somewhat stiffly while trying to look beguiling; where, too, almost everything that was socially significant here went on for seven decades, batlunats are piled against the walls today for sale at cut rates.

title: Tracy Austin Triumphs In First W.T.T. Match
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 12 (UPI) Tracy Austin, making her World Team Tennis debut with Anaheim last night, scored a 63 victory, but the Oranges dropped a 3028 decision to the Sun Belt Nets.

title: Carter Says U.S. Kept Vow on Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reuters) President Carter said today that the United States had kept its pledge to reduce oil imports and unemployment and now wanted West Germany and Japan to expand their economies and buy more American goods.

title: Stage: Story's Look At the Irish Conflict
description: DAVID STOREY is a solidly realistic writer and a good one, but in trying his hand at historical allegory, as in Cromwell. he seems to be wearing heavy gloves.

title: NAMIBIA GUERRILLAS ACCEPT WEST'S PLAN ON FUTURE OF AREA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 Western negotiators have obtained approval of a plan for ending the 11yearold guerrilla war in SouthWest Africa and bringing the disputed territory to independence as the new black African state of Namibia.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: I.B.M. Offers New Type Of Checkout Scanners
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a computerized supermarket checkout system in which standard functions can be adjusted to meet the individual preferences of stores.

title: Dance: 2 Premieres By Asian Americans
description: THE Asian American Dance Theater has the unusual aio of presenting modern dance rooted in the Asian American experience. On Tuesday. the company appeared in the continuing Clark Center summer dance festival at the City University Graduate Center Mall. But, sad to say, a chance was lost to communicate that particular esthetic.

title: Prosecution of Welfare Fraud Said to Lag in Brooklyn
description: New York State's Welfare Inspector General said yesterday that although one of three welfare fraud cases reported in New York City came from Brooklyn there had been no prosecutions there.

title: An Antiques Dealer in England Who Keeps More Than He Sells
description: BROAWAY, ENGLAND H. W. KEIL is one of this country's bestknown dealers in antiques. but half the furniture filling his handsome 17thcentury showrooms here is not for sale. puring his at years in the business he has simply refused to part with his most prized possessions.

title: House Backs $1.3Billion Parks and Recreation Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  The House today passed legislation authorizing approximately $1.3 billion for more than 100 park, conservation and recreation projects.

title: NAMIBIA GUERRILLAS ACCEPT WEST'S PLAN ON FUTURE OF AREA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 Western negotiators have obtained approval of a plan for ending the 11 yearold guerrilla war in SouthWest Africa and bringing the disputed territory to independence as the new black African state of Namibia.

title: SEICHARANSKY'S LINK TO REPORTERS CITED
description: MOSCOW, July 12  Regular contacts with American reporters emerged today as the Government's main argument to sustain a capital charge of treason and espionage against Anatoly B. Shcharansky as his trial went through its third day.

title: SARKIS BID TO QUIT ASSAILED IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12  Lebanon's most influential rightwing Christian leader, former President Camille Chamoun, scathingly attacked President Elias Sarkis today for having submitted his resignation last week during the most serious situation ever faced by Lebanon.

title: Letters
description: Caring for Roses

title: A NUCLEAR SHOWER MIGHT REACH EARTH
description: About five days from now, a shower of nuclear particles caused by Tuesday's violent solar flare may reach the Earth, potentially endangering two orbiting Soviet astronauts and people flying in supersonic transport planes, a Government astronomer reported yesterday.

title: POLITICS IS BLOCKING ANTICRIME MEASURES
description: ALBANY, July 12  The Republicans want a tough anticrime package and so do the Democrats. They even favor essentially similar measures.

title: Bridge:
description: Generalizations about the behavior and manners of bridge players have very limited validity. Some Americans have been known to come back from European tournaments and comment adversely on the ethics of European players, by which they mean, it seems, the ethics of a few players from one particular part of Europe.

title: Market Place
description: TaxFree Fund Vs. Savings

title: Profit Slump Seen In Carter Warehouse
description: PLAINS, Ga.  Undistributed profits of $330,000 from President Carter's share of a family warehouse business, accumulated over a period of years, apparently have been wiped out since he took office, according to financial information that has come to light and interviews with the President's personal financial advisers.

title: NEW &
description: Future Heirlooms

title: JobSharing Sought in Europe
description: PARIS, July 12  With unemployment in Western Europe running at the highest levels in postwar history, labor leaders are demanding that governments and companies agree to the sharing of available jobs. in tseigium, tsritain and Italy during recent weeks large labor unions have won battles to lower the workweek below 40 hours and to restrict overtime in the hope of forcing employers to hire new workers.

title: Morris, the Cat, 1 7, Dead
description: Morris, one of the best Tv performers of his kind, died over the weekend in his native Chicago. He was 17 years old and, his veterinarian said, he diedof old age.

title: Sound
description: IT is an incontrovertible fact that the besttasting fish are the ones you catch yourself. Something similar, I suspect, applies to recordings. I, for one, treasure some of my private tapes more deeply than the finest professional products. Aside from a few sonic family mementos that succeed in epitomizing cherished aspects of character in the recorded voices, I am particularly fond of sonic snapshots taken on my travels to accompany my slides. Often, to my surprise, I find that the sounds evoke memories of places and events more vividly than the photographs.

title: U.S. Yacht Wins in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, July 12 (Reuters) Wildfire, an American boat, scored her second victory this week by winning the third race in the Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5Meter class here yesterday. Wildfire, with Albert Fay at the helm and a borrowed boom after an accident, started out best and was in the lead most of the way.

title: Italian Communist Party Sharply Criticizes Trial of Soviet Dissidents
description: ROME, July 12  The Italian Communist Party, in a communique today, sharply criticized the trial of two dissidents now under way in the Soviet Union.

title: Japan Plans Imports to Trim Surplus
description: TOKYO, July 12 (Reuters)  Japan said today that it planned to trim at least $4 billion from its huge trade surplus by initiating emergency imports, including $1 billion worth of enriched uranium ore from the United States. Of the amount, $1.2 billion is definitely set, and the rest is almost certain.

title: Chicago Auto Mechanics Strike
description: CHICAGO, July 12 (Reuters)  Some 4,000 union auto mechanics went out on strike here today, closing down service departments at almost 300 Chicagoarea new car dealerships. The strikers, who earn $7.60 an hour, were offered a raise of $2.60 an hour over three years. Their demands were not known.

title: A Senate Panel Backs Bill to Let Supreme Court Turn Down Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved unanimously a bill that would permit the Supreme Court to refuse to decide cases presented to it. No action has been taken in the House.

title: Ali Says He Will Help Indians in Land Fight
description: With the Statue of Liberty as a symbolic backdrop, Muhammad All yesterday pledged to aid American Indians in their opposition to proposals that they contend would rob them of land entitlements and other treaty rights.

title: Newark Council Gives Top Officials Big Pay Raises
description: NEWARK, July 12  Despite the opposition expressed at a public hearing, the Newark City Council today voted substantial pay increases for its members. Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and other top officials in the city will share in an ad- ministrative salary increase totaling nearly $600,000.

title: New Fire Forces 103 Families FroIn Apartments in the West Bronx
description: The smell of smoke remained, but by yesterday morning the fire trucks on University Avenue had been replaced by rows of moving vans as 103 families prepared to abandon another middleclass corner of the West Bronx.

title: World News Briefs
description: ALGIERS, July 12 (AP)  West Saharan guerrillas announced a ceasefire today as a goodwill gesture toward Mauritania's new military junta. But the new Mauritanian leader implied he would goon fighting.

title: Various Corporations List Sales and Earnings for Latest Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, ( A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Millions of barrels

title: New York Police Graft Film Topic
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12  Corruption within the New York City Police Department will become the subject of a major Hollywood movie next year. Orion Pictures Company has just purchased, for $500,000, Prince of the City by Robert Daley, former Deputy Police Commissioner for Public Affairs. The book, which will be published in November, tells the story of Detective Robert Leuci, whose testimony and secret tape recordings led to the indictment of 52 members of the Special Investigation Unit to which he belonged.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Federal Panel Proposes Major Effort to Modify Weather by the 80's
description: By the early 1980's, it will probably be possible to increase accumulations of mountain snow by 10 to 30 percent and, before the end of that decade, achieve similar increases in rainfall on Middle Western farms, a Federal panel reported yesterday.

title: Grasshoppers Plague Four States
description: SHERIDAN LAKE, Colo., July 12  All you have to do is take one step into the fields in southeastern Colorado and you make grasshopper waves. They fly up in front of each foot, 50 or more at a time, a surging foam of flying bugs.

title: Albania Confirms China Is Ending Economic Aid
description: VIENNA, Thursday, July 13 (Reuters)  The Albanian Government announced today that China had suspended all economic aid to Albania and had withdrawn all experts assigned to the country.

title: LRS. Planning to Audit Talmadge's Tax Returns
description: Washington, July 12  The Internal Revenue Service will audit the 1975 and 1977 tax returns of Senator Herman E. Talmadge because of reported irregularities in his financial affairs, sources said.

title: Nuclear Test Held in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 12 (AP)  A weaponsrelated nuclear device with a yield of from 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT was detonated beneath the Nevada desert today, causing a shock wave felt in Las Vegas nearly 100 miles to the south. There were no problems, a Department of Energy spokesman, Dave Jackson, said. He said there were no reports of any radiation leak from the device, buried 1,800 feet beneath Yucca Flat.

title: World Bank In Record Loan
description: The World Bank said yesterday had completed its largest single borrowing  a 75 billion yen bond issue in Japan.

title: U.S. Backs $600 Million Program To Improve Mass Transit in State
description: NEWARK, July 12  The Federal Government gave formal approval today to a 1600 million masstransit program for New Jersey, and the state will hire planners from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to help decide how best to spend the money.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Falls in New York After Remarks by Carter
description: The dollar fell against leading world currencies in late New York trading yesterday , eliminating most of the gains that it made in earlier trading abroad.

title: Deaths
description: ABELSHannah, beloved wife of the late Chester, devoted mother of Morton, adored grandmother of Wendy. Dear sister of Etta Gilman. Services Boulevard Park West', 115 West 79 St, Thursday, 10:15 am

title: Tax Cuts Face New Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Carter Administration today got its two biggest economic guns, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Charles L. Schultze, to aim the heaviest fire to date at a Republican plan for a huge tax reduction.

title: The New York Times/Jim Simpson
description: NEIGHBORHOOD PORTRAIT: Youngsters using a scaffold yesterday as they worked on mural on the wail of building at 609 Main Street in Hackensack.Luisa Belinda Cassanello, standing, and her twin sister, Luisa Annabelle, took part in project sponsored by the Bergen County Community Action Program.

title: SHOICI MATSUMARA
description: Shoici Matsumara, deputy regional director of marketing with the Caltex Petroleum Corporation, 380 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, died Tuesday of cancer in Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 50 years old and lived at 200 Winston Drive in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: This Is a Recording: No Sale, Thank You
description: Good evening, Mr. A. Ward, a strange voice exclaimed when I answered the phone. I am Mrs. Roseanne DelBello and I am caning to inform you that you have been selected to answer four simple questions. Answer them correctly and you will be eligible to win a complete, homedelivered salad set. including serving bowl, individual plates, spoon, fork and handsome glass dressing carafe.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, playing on his third surface within a week, led the New York Apples to a 2822 victory over the Phoenix Racquets before 3,312 at the Felt Forum Tuesday night. World Team Tennis began the second half of its schedule following the Wimbledon break.

title: Expert Certain
description: HACKENSACK, July 12  An anesthesiologist who has specialized in the study of curare disagreed today with the listed cause of death of one of five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell that Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich is accused of.murdering in 196566 with lethal doses of the muscle relaxing drug.

title: PRESIDENT DEPLORES THE RUSSIAN TRIALS AS BLOW TO LIBERTY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter condemned the trials of Anatoly B. Shcharansky and other Soviet dissidents today as an attack on every human being who lives in the world who believes in basic human freedom and is willing to speak for these freedoms or fight for them.

title: Beards Sprout All Over at Paris Art Show
description: PARIS THIS summer's show of sculpture and painting at the Musee SandeIle is devoted to a theme as original as it is inexhaustible: the beard.

title: Nastase, Fibak Win Quickly, Quietly
description: Following straightset triumphs by Hie Nastase and Wojtek Fibak before 3,828 fans yesterday afternoon at the $300,000 Forest Hills Invitation roundrobin, the evening program brought out more people (5,203), more bugs and more exciting but erratic tennis.

title: Books: Memoir of African Food
description: FIRST CATCH YOUR ELAND. By LOOMS van der Post. 217 pages. Morrow. $8.95

title: Dance: Berlin Opera Ballet
description: TUESDAY evening's performance of Valery Panov's Cinderella at the New York State Theater made it clear that the dancers of the Berlin Opera Ballet not only come from many countries, but they also represent several different balletic styles. That the company is not composed of lookalikes or danceal ikes is one of its charms. But sometimes the Berliners allow eclecticism to run rampant.

title: The Politics of Marriage
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 12  It is not good that the man should be alone, the Lord is quoted as saying, for attribution, in the Book of Genesis. I will make him an help meet for him.

title: Barrage of Charges Opens Special Albany Session
description: ALBANY, July 12  The Legislature returned in special session today to consider a large roster of measures, with Democrats asserting they were here to complete urgently needed bills and Republicans charging that the session was waste of time designed to bolster Governor Carey's chances for reelection.

title: Bank Earnings for Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) Over-the-counter.

title: Javits Alleges the Administration Limits Northeast Defense Works
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Senator Jacob K. Javits accused the Carter Administration today of a bias against the Northeast, especially New York, in alloting military construction funds and in assigning defense facilities and forces.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (UPI) The Matson Navigation Company today filed with the Federal Maritime Commission a proposal to increase general freight rates by 2 percent in its West CoastHawaii steamship service.

title: Advertising
description: McGrawHill Home Book

title: Events
description: Music

title: New Judge Sees Another View From the Top
description: Freddy Martinez slumps in the defendant's chair. He is charged with wifebeating. A police officer is on the witness stand, and the officer is testifying that after the police arrested Mr. Martinez, he told them: I didn't beat her up. All I did was smack her around.

title: Man Injured in Queens Explosion Suspected as Pipe Bomb Builder
description: An unidentified man who police believe was making pipe bombs was severely injured yesterday in an explosion in an apartment in Astoria, Queens.

title: Fire Island Squatters  Fighting Eviction
description: Eddie and Mary Rant have summered in the Skunk Hollow area of Fire Island, L.1., for the last 32 years, but they have not lived the kind of summer life that is usually associated with the seasonal residents of the barrier beach.

title: U.N. Rights Inquiry in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 12 (Reuters) A delegation of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights arrived here today for a 10day investigation of alleged violations of human rights in Chile,

title: Grasshoppers Plague Four States
description: SHERIDAN LAKE, COlo., July 12  All you have to do is take one step into the fields in southeastern Colorado and you make grasshopper waves. They fly up in front of each foot, 50 or more at a time, a surging foam of flying bugs.

title: But in Britain, the Idea Just Might Be a Favorite
description: LONDON, July 12  One of the most animated spots in the cavernous Waterloo .Station here is the Cashcade office, where, as in hundreds of such centers throughout Britain, the customer has the chance to win money instantaneously.

title: Postal Workers Go to Washington To Demonstrate for New Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Thousands of disgruntled postal workers, most of them from New York City, demonstrated in front of United States Postal Service headquarters here today, urging labor negotiators to conclude a new contract to avert a possible disruption next week.

title: U.S. Plans a Major Health Report
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)  The Surgeon General will issue a major report this fall designed to help Americans fight against obesity, alcoholism and many other costly everyday health prob. lems, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., said today.

title: Rites Held for Youth, 16, Killed In Collision With Rockefeller Car
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, July 12 Friends, relatives and a representative of the Rockefeller family gathered here this afternoon for a memorial service for David Laurent Low, the 16yearold driver of a car that collided Monday with one carrying John D. Rockefeller 3d, killing both of them.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerseyan Reaches Pact to Buy Rockies
description: Arthur Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking magnate, agreed yesterday to purchase the Colorado Rockies of the National Hockey League and keep them in Denver for for the next two seasons.

title: 5 Are Arrested In Club Attack In Central Park
description: Four adults and a juvenile were arrested yesterday and charged with clubbing strollers and joggers with baseball bats and tree branches in the Central Park Ramble on July 5. .

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE A Wealth of Hammers, A Feast of Nails
description: Hardware buffs would rather go to a wellstocked hardware store than to Bloomingdale's on sale day; they would rather stroll on Canal Street and Chambers Street and browse in the various hardware stores than visit the chic boutiques on Madison Avenue.

title: ROTHERMERE, OWNER OF 2 LONDON PAPERS
description: LONDON, July 12  Viscount Rothermere, publisher of The London Daily Mail and its sister paper, The Evening News, until he handed over control to his son, Vere Harmsworth, in 1971, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Merlin Sails to Record Time
description: HONOLULU, July 12 (AP)  Merlin, a 67foot yacht, sailed past the western point of Maui yesterday morning to finish first in the 2,300mile Victoria-toMaui race. Skippered by Doug Fryer of the Corinthian Yacht Club in Seattle. Merlin finished in a record time of 10 days 2 minutes 37 seconds. The previous record of 12 days 17 hours 53 minutes was set by Joli in 1974.

title: Molester Suspect Killed By a Housing Policeman
description: A housing police officer yesterday shot and killed a suspect who had one hand shackled to a wall of a Brooklyn station house but wHo reportedly had grabbed the officer's gun as his other hand was freed.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1978

title: Los Angeles Mayor Threatens to Drop Games
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (UPI) Mayor Torn Bradley, who began the push to bring the 1984 Olympics here, said yesterday he would drop the whole matter if the International Olympic Committee rejected a contract offered by a private organizing committee.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 12, 1978

title: Study for Carter Asks Bigger Role For Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  A report on the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today that the nation's highest military body was playing a limited role in defense policy, hampered by the historic unwillingness of the military to assign its best officers to jobs on the joint staff and plagued by procedures that inhibit initiative and need major overhaul.

title: Last 2 Jackson Brigade Members Guilty in Bombings and Robberies
description: SEATTLE. July 12  The last known members of the radical George Jackson Brigade, Therese Ann Coupez and John W. Sherman, were found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court here on eight felony counts. Their trial had lasted three weeks.

title: G.E. Earnings Outpace Record Results of 1977
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday a 17 percent jump in net income in the second quarter on a 13 percent increase in revenues. That brought the company's earnings gain for the first half to 16 percent on an 11 percent increase in revenues.

title: THOMAS L. SIMS
description: Thomas L. Sims, a vice president of the McCannErickson advertising agency, died of cancer Sunday in Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital at the age of 55. His home was in IlaStings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: TV Film Stirs Fight
description: A documentary film about blacks in Britain is the subject of a dispute between WGBH, a publictelevision station in Boston, and David Koff, the film's producer and director.

title: High Defense Official Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Stanley R. Resor of New Canaan, Conn., to be Under Secretary of Defense for policy. Mr. Resor, 60 years old, has been representative at the negotiations on mutual and balanced force reductions in Vienna since 1973.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1978

title: POLITICAL PRISONERS IN U.S., YOUNG SAYS
description: GENEVA, July 12 (AP)  Andrew Young, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, today compared dissidents in the Soviet Union to civil rights campaigners in the United States and said there were political prisoners in both countries. commenting on the trials this week of two prominent Soviet dissidents, Mr. Young said in an interview that the Soviet Union was making a terrible mistake in trying to stifle the human rights movement. But he made it plain he felt that the situation of the dissidents should not be dramatized.

title: COMMODITIES Soybean, Grain Futures Decline on Bearish News
description: Soybean and grain futures prices dropped yesterday in reaction to the Federal crop projections issued after last Tuesday's close, despite widespread skepticism in the trade about. some of the figures.

title: Aoki Leads in British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 12 First Tom Weiskopf lost his concentration and a twostroke lead with doublebogey 6 at the 17th hole: Then Severiano Ballesteros arrived at the 17th tied for the lead, only to hook his first two shots and settle for a bogey 5.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: L.I.R.R. Malfunction Delays 53,000 Commuters

title: Justice Dept. Investigating Report Linking Informer to Violent Crime
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Justice Department began a formal inquiry today to determine whether Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. was involved in violent crime while he was a Ku Klux Klan informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and whether bureau agents helped to hide the fact.

title: CREDIT MARKETS New Issues Strengthen Municipals
description: Municipal bonds rose in price yesterday, with some issues up as much as half a point, as the market for tax-exempt securities absorbed a large amount of new issues, according to traders.

title: Japanese Criticized On Trade
description: GENEVA, July 12  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's chief trade negotiator, chastised Japan today for lack of progress in the current round of trade talks, provoking the Japanese to express dismay at the criticism.

title: Sentimental Journeys: Making Clothes Like Old Again
description: Wbile many people balk at wearing hand-me-downs, there are notable exceptions  such traditional outfits as a wedding or christening dress.

title: EXPERTS CITE A WAY TO END GRAIN BLASTS
description: WASHINGTON. July 12  The techrology already exists to prevent most grainelevator explosions of the kinds that have killed S5 workers and injured 179 others since 1976, according to experts attending a symposium at the National Academy of Sciences Auditorium here.

title: U.S. Welcomes the Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The White House issued a statement today saying that President Carter welcomes the agreement reached today in Luanda and that the United States will continue to cooperate fully in carrying it out.

title: Of Men, Machines and a Blackout
description: A year ago, as the report by Robert Curvin and Bruce Porter on the OpEd page reminds us, the lights went out in New York City and the looting went on. Investigation, or at any rate speculation, started at once into the causes of both. Predictably, progress has been better along the former line than along the latter.

title: International
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: INVESTORS WARNED OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG. July 12  A church body claiming to represent more than half of South Africa's 26 million people today urged foreign countries and corporations with financial holdings here to radically revise their investment poli- cies in light of the bolstering effect that foreign investment was said to have had on the dominant position of the ruling white minority.

title: Feng Shui: A Little Decorating Magic
description: IN Hoag Kong, Lin KeFan, a violinist, thought his career would blossom if he hung a red hexagonal mirror outside his window. His neighbors across the street believed the mirror had brought sudden illness on their family and that with its removal, their ailments would cease. In Taiwan, Ju Mu, a movie director, has begun sleeping in a bed with rounded corners in an effort to preserve his marriage.

title: Backgammon:
description: Summer is the season for backgammon in Europe, with major international tournaments being held back-to-back throughout June and July.. This year, Crockford's summer backgammon championships and the Curzon House tournament in London will be followed by the European championships in Monte Carlo; Former European champion Joe Dwek won at Crockford's last week by beating Charlie Witz of Chicago in the finals. In the semifinals, Dwek defeated Gino Scalamandre, also a topranked competitor. In other results at Crockford's, Hermes Michaelides won the first consolation and Peter Gold took the second consolation.

title: Morgan 2dQuarter Earnings Up 10.4% Against 77
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, announced yesterday that secondquarter operating earnings rose 10.4 percent, compared with the corresponding yearago period.

title: Georg Jensen Closed For Rent Arrears
description: Georg Jensen, one of Madison Avenue's more prestigious retailers, was closed yesterday morning by two city marshals before its 10 A.M. opening hour for not having paid its rent.

title: The Myth of Blackout Looters . . .
description: In 1965 when the lights went out, New Yorkers of all classes and in all neighborhoods reacted with a cool that became part of the city's folklore. When the lights went out on July 13, 1977, massive looting erupted immediately and spontaneously in every area of the city where poor blacks, hispanics  and even a few whites  lived near unguarded stores.

title: Samoans Lead Junior Golf
description: SAN DIEGO, July 12 (AP)  Americans generally led in the second round of the annual junior world golf tournament today. Two Samoans were pacesetters in two age groups  Angel Lanekilde was two strokes ahead among girls 13 to 14 years old, and Rod Mitchell was tied for the lead among boys 11 to 12. A field of 670 boys and girls from 35 nations was competing.

title: Globe Halts Merger
description: Globe Union Inc., maker of auto batteries, said it had agreed with the Square D Company to terminate a merger accord. Globe concluded a new agreement on June 27 calling for Johnson Controls Inc. to acquire the battery company.

title: A.L. Ponders N.L. Dominance
description: SAN DIEGO, July 12  Why should the National League beat the American League seven straight times in baseball's AllStar Game, 15 times in the last 16 years and 21 the last 26?

title: Garrett, Lyttle Homer
description: TOKYO, July 12 (AP)  Two former major leaguers, Adrian Garrett and Jim Lyttle, homerecl to pace the Hiroshima Toyo Carp to a 165 victory over the Hanshin Tigers today. Garrett's clout was his 29th of the season and Lyttle's was No. 18.

title: Capital Smoking Ban Won't Affect Politics
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)  The District of Columbia City Council today tentatively banned smoking in most public areas of buildings in the capital, but the move will not affect the Federal politicians's legendary smokefilled rooms.

title: Folk Rock: John Prine
description: JOHN PRINE, who was at the Bottom Line Monday night, has written some clever songs. He has a rather black sense of humor that is tinged even at its zaniest with an underlying current of despair. One of his songs tells of a promotional visit to the Middle West by Sabu the Elephant Boy, star of numerous Hollywood jungle melodramas, and makes Sabu sound like a forlorn figure, freezing in shopping centers in his corduroys.

title: About New York
description: Politically, Armando Drago sounds bit right of center as he complains that welfare has dried up the spawning ground for eager young shoemakers. It is a plight that would have occasioned little sympathy in the 1960's. when a liberal could overdose on guilt in any one of the Drago stores around the city, his conscience lashed with each pop of the shine rag by one of Drago's bent bootblacks, his pants cuff at brow level of the quiet worldweary men with the stained hands working for the Dragos.

title: Home Beat
description: SeeThrough Artistry

title: Bruyere Continues to Lead In Tour de France Cycling
description: TOULOUSE, France, July 12 (UPI)  Belgium's Joseph Bruyere retained the overall lead today after the 12th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race. Organizers canceled the first half of the stage, claiming the racers were taking it too easy.

title: House Panel Votes Bill to Speed Deporting of Nazi War Criminals
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)  The House Judiciary Committee voted 21 to 5 today to close what was described as a loophole in the immigration laws to permit the deportation of Nazi war criminals.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Hers
description: IHAVE taught school for 12 years. I've taught grammar school, high school, alternative school, business school and college; math, English, English as a second language, journalism and creative writing. I've also been a writer for 28 years, the writing years and the teaching years overlapping. I ought to be able to tell how to teach people to write.

title: Hickey Examines His First Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.. July 12  On a bright day that erased the memory of Jets losses past, 48 rookies, none of whom experienced a 311 wonlost season last year, opened camp today and were joined by 18 veterans.

title: 5 Are Arrested In Club Attack In Central Park
description: Four adults and a juvenile were arrested yesterday and charged with clubbing strollers and joggers with baseball bats and tree branches in the Centra1.1 Park Ramble on July 5.

title: Steinbrenner's Voice Is Heard
description: The Yankees, faced with changes in personnel and their owner's renewed involvement, but no change in their physical miseries, resume their disappointing season today with a 2 P.M. game against the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: CORRECTION
description: The address of the Drama Committee Repertory Theater, which appeared yesterday in a review of Crane's Way, was incorrect. The theater, where the show will be performed tonight, is at 17 West 20th Street.

title: Carter Orders Pension Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)  President Carter signed today an executive order creating an 11member commis, sion to study pension systems around the country and to develop guidelines for the nation's public and private pension programs.

title: Coal-to-Oil Site Picked
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., July 12 The Governments of the United States and West Virginia and the Gulf Oil Corporation announced here today a tentative joint entry into the risky business of exotic fuels.

title: They Find the Missing Pieces
description: CRACK! A guest's overzealous toast shatters a Rose Point crystal goblet made by Cambridge in 1928. How will 1 e er replace it? the hostess wonders, trying to smile nonchalantly.

title: Harold Rosenberg Is Dead at 72 Art Critic for The New Yorker
description: Harold Rosenberg, for many years art critic of The New Yorker and known for his forthright championship of the American Abstract Expressionist painters, died Tuesday after a stroke complicated by pneumonia at his summer home in The Springs, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: 10 Food Places Are Cited by City For Violations of the Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of 10 food places cited for healthcode violations, one restaurant that had corrected an earlier violation and a tavern that was closed for failing to do so.

title: House Panel Proposes A Compromise on Bill For New York's Loans
description: House of Representative conferees trying to reach agreement on Federal loan guarantees for New York City proposed to the Senate yesterday a new compromise that would make $1.7 billion of guarantees available to the city in two installments and preserve the Senate's onehouse veto of the second installment.

title: Working Space: Six Top Offices
description: IN many ways, our offices are much like the clothes we wear, iconographical clues to the person underneath, or, in this case, to the person behind the desk. They are image builders, statements of purpose, pictures with hidden levels of meaning. The offices shown here belong to a range of people, all of them successful their chosen professions. Their offices are evocative expressions of who they are.

title: Through the Clouds to the Summit
description: The task facing the Western leaders assembling in Bonn this weekend has not changed much over the last 18 months, though the agenda has broadened. Essentially, the question is how to get West Germany and Japan, but especially Germany, to expand their economies and to reduce their huge trade surpluses so as to assure healthy growth to the entire industrial community. Unwilling to jeopardize the low inflation rate on which he has staked his political future, Chancellor Schmidt insists that German growth requires more exports; more exports require a stronger dollar; a stronger dollar requires a balanced American trade; and such balance requires the United States to reduce its imports of oil. Heal thyself, he kept telling us.

title: F.D.A. Declares a Contraceptive Not as Effective as Ads Contend
description: WASHINGTON. July 12 (AP)  The makers of a new contraceptive suppository, especially popular on college campuses and among teenagers, were criticized by the Food and Drug Administration today for promoting it as 99 percent effective in preventing pregnancy.

title: Fire Island Squatters.  Fighting Eviction
description: Eddie and Mary Rant have summered in the Skunk Hollow area of Fire Island, L.I., for the last 32 years, but they have not lived the kind of summer life that is usually associated with the seasonal residents of the barrier beach.

title: Hollywood Is Discovering Broadway
description: WE all know that turnabout is fair play. But the question is, bow often does turnabout take place? Once in a lifetime, would you say, stealing a phrase from a current revival that's a lot of fun? At least it's happening for the theater right now. In one respect. For years and years films have been draining the theater of its best talents. Up pops a new playwright and, after a single hit, he's gone, never to return. Hollywood, or wherever it is they make pictures now, has claimed him, chained him. Along comes a new actor, trained in the theater's workshops and nursed along from one Off Broadway production to another until at last he lands big in the center of town, and, of course he's gone, too. Sometimes, somebody comes back  as George C. Scott often does, as Jack Lemmon is doing right this minute  but most often it's oneway travel, and kiss 45th Street goodbye.

title: Carter Deal Seeks to Win Military Over to Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  The White House has agreed to press for improved air defenses and a new mediumrange bomber for the Air Force in order to gain the support of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for a new agreement with Moscow limiting strategic arms, officials said today.

title: APARTMENT BLAST TIED TO RADICALS
description: An explosion m a Queens apartment Wednesday night may have averted a series of bombings planned by the Puerto Rican radical group known as the F.A.L.N., police officials said yesterday.

title: 2 Dissidents Whose Trials in Soviet Are a Cause Clbre
description: MOSCOW, July 13  Three days ago, when Anatoly B. Shcharansky went on trial for his life, he caught sight of his older brother, Leonid, for the first time since being arrested 16 months ago as Leonid walked into the courtroom.

title: BIKE PATH PROJECTED:Artist's conception of a two mile long public bicycle path is being planned as part of development of the former Dodge Estate in Chatam and Madison Townships. Pathway would occupy 10 acres of office park.
Medicaid Abortion Curb Is Lifted
description: TRENTON, July 13The Department of Human Services announced today that it would begin paying for medically necessary Medicaid abortions in New Jersey pending a court ruling on the constitutionality of a state law prohibiting such payments.

title: Sculpture Under a City Sky
description: WE are all aware that New York itself is the greatest sculpture show on earth, with its splendid buildings and bridges and other architectural arrangements, but each year artists keep adding their bit. And strenuous as it may sound in prospect, a tour of their outdoor handiwork can be a relaxing way to spend a summer day. So, with a fond nod to such hallowed sculpture sites as the garden behind the Museum of Modern Art, here is a suggested tourof more recent installations.

title: Chase Net Up 65% and Chemical 13%
description: Led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which reported that secondquarter earnings jumped by 65 percent over a year earlier, four big New York City banks yesterday announced substantially higher operating profits. Other banks reporting were the Chemical Bank, the Irving Trust Company and the Bank of New York.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Beatha

title: POLICE GIVEN DATA ON BOAST BY ROWE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala:, July 13  Police sources here said today that they had information that might support Gary Thomas Rowe Jr.'s assertion that he killed a black man in Birmingham in 1963, while Mr. Rowe was on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's payroll as an informer in the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Beaths
description: ROCKEFEU_ERJogn D.. III. Nis belief that the birthright of every child is to be wanted and loved helped raise population and family planning concerns from obscurity to a high level of priority. His leadership at home and in world councils guided those in positions of influence to use it in support of this belief. His unique philanthropic slatesmarship was the lifeline of many causes and projects which had not vet achieved that degree of maturity and social acceptance which aloha can insure a sound future. And his gentleness, generosity and integrity inspired his colleagues and warmed his friends. We mourn his passing, and extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Rockefeller and the family.

title: July 1-10 Auto Sales Up 8.9%
description: DETROIT, July 13  The United States auto industry, led by a record performance by the General Motors Corporation, today reported strong sales for the first 10 days of July. July 110 Auto Sales Up 8.9%

title: Marijuana Help for Cancer Victim
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 13 Thi State of New Mexico has certified a 27yearold cancer victim as the first patient in the nation's first legislatively mandated therapeutic marijuana program.

title: Expert to Lead Walking Tour In Central Park
description: IT will be a little like being treated to a tour of Buckingham Palace by the Queen herself. Central Park Henry Hope Reed's domain. As curator of the park and coauthor of Central Park: A History and a Guide, he has spent so much of his life there that he knows not only every monument, path and bridge, but also trees, rocks, topography and the many hidden gardens, vistas and curiosities that the public never sees.

title: Indian Group Prepares to Finish Washington Trek
description: BALTIMORE. July 13  Ending 3,000mile protest march that began five months ago in San Francisco, more than 500 American Indians and an assortment of ethnic supporters, including a contingent of Buddhist monks from Japan, prepared to break camp near here today for the last leg of their walk to Washington.

title: Koch Seeks Expanded Works Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Mayor Koch, testifying before a Senate subcommittee today, proposed an expansion of President Carter's laborintensive publicworks bill from $1 billion to $2 billion for 1979. He also said it also should be modified to include major construction projects.

title: Single Women Over 30: Where Are the Men Worthy of Us?
description: The reality for Erica Abeel, and for many women like her who are single, in New York and over 30 years of age, is that the unattached men they meet tend to fall into one or more of the following categories: bores, emotionally

title: Jersey Acts in 9W Feud With Its Own Truck Ban
description: ALPINE, N. J., July 13  A new salvo was fired today in the New York StateNew Jersey border feud over heavy truck traffic on a route that crosses the state line on the Palisades.

title: HEALTH PLAN IN 80'S IS PRESIDENT'S GOAL
description: WASHINGTON. July 13  President Carter. in a statement of principles to be announced by the end of this month. will propose that a national health insurance program be phased in slowly in the late 1980's. a top White House health adviser disclosed today.

title: A Spectacle of Fear
description: The conviction of Aleksandr Gizaburg and the trial of Anatoly Shcharansky constitute an attack on freedom itself. They remind us once again that this supposed superpower. fearing its own people more than any foreign adversary, permits them not even the most limited human rights of belief and expression. But the trials also make frustratingly clear how little the United States can do to change this depressing condition, not just in the Soviet Union, but for so many of the world's people.

title: Ginzburg Given 8Year Sentence By Soviet Court
description: MOSCOW, July 13  Aleksandr Ginzburg, a human rights advocate who managed a fund aiding the families of political prisoners, was found guilty today of antiSoviet agitation and propaganda and was sentenced to eight years in a strict labor camp.

title: For Children
description: SKETCHING IN THE GALLERIES, a new sum. mer program for children 9 to 12, at I:30 P.M. Tuesday through Friday, in the Junior Museum Library, and then on to the galleries to discuss and sketch works of art, at The Metropolitan Mu. scum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. Sketching materials are provided: tickets, limited to 20 class, are SI. Call 0795500.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Heliothermal Corporation, Denver, manufacturer and distributors of solar energy components and systems, and fabricators of sheet metal products, has elected Elliott R. Husney of Denver as president and chief executive officer, and ltzhak Matza of Tel Aviv as chairman.

title: PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN BONN FOR TALKS
description: BONN. July 13  President Carter arrived here tonight for a state visit to West Germany and a sevennation economic meeting on the major political and monetary problems confronting the Western alliance and Japan.

title: Swimmer Reaches Florida 33 Hours After Leaving Cuba
description: MARATHON.Fla. July 13  A retired baker from Ohio reached the Florida Keys today, saying he had swum through sharkinfested waters from Cuba in 331/2 hours. His claim of a new distance record for ocean swimming was immediately contested by those who said he had not followed the guidelines for official recognition.

title: Subsidiary Duns A.T.& T.
description: AmeriCan Telephone and Telegragh Company lawyers fighting the Government's 1974 antitrust suit against the company apparently forgot to pay $488.08 bill in May. The result was curt notice threatening disconnection the bill was not paid  sent by a diligent A.T.& T. subsidiary.

title: Carter's Quest: Line on Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Almost since taking office a year and a half ago. President Carter has seemed perplexed in his hunt for the right formula for dealing with the Soviet Union. He has tried bold initiatives, harsh public language. private compromises, quiet diplomacy and lures of summitry  but success still eludes him.

title: Crafts and Ballet At Eisenhower Park
description: A day of crafts and dance will be found in Eisenhower Park, East Meadow, L.I., on Sunday.

title: Carter Nominates Three
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (Reuters) President Carter announced today his nominations for three Government positions. They were: Roger A. Markle of Salt Lake City to be director of the Bureau of Mines at the Interior Department, replacing Thomas Falkie, who has re- signed; Richard V. Backley of Fairfax, Va., to be a member of the Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, and William K. Smith of Illinois to be chairman of the board of directors of the United States Railway Association. re placing Arthur Lewis, who has resigned.

title: 2 Charged With Boston Slayings
description: BOSTON, July 13 (UPI)  Two suspects charged with killing five men in the Blackfriars Lounge, a downtown pub, pleaded not guilty today to multiple murder charges. The authorities said that the killing occurred while arrangements Were Dein mane tor the sale of cocaine. Municipal Judge Francis X. Morrissey ordered Robert Italiano, 36 years old, and William Ieradi, 32, held without bail pending a hearing next week.

title: State Welfare Inspector Is Disputing Allegations
description: New York State's Welfare Inspector General yesterday disputed yesterday an assertion by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office that 37 letters asking for information about cases of alleged welfare fraud had gone unanswered.

title: Soprano Is Serious About Light Opera
description: Georgia McEver is somewhat annoyed. She has been a leading member of the Light Opera of Manhattan company for some time, and she thinks the difficulties of singing in operetta are not appreciated. She believes that opera managers dismiss operetta singers as beneath their notice and that because of her background she hasn't been given a chance to prove herself in opera-

title: Cruises by America Suspended Following. $439,000 in Penalties
description: The owners of the stormtossed and plumbingplagued liner America were fined more than $400,000 yesterday for customs violations and then suspended indefinitely all cruises from New York City.

title: Books: Groucho Marx
description: THIS massive book, replete with interviews with Groucho Marx and with just about everyone (not really everyone) who knew him must surely be the definitive

title: The Saga of a Russian Fascist in Connecticut
description: Information has recently come to light regarding one of the more bizarre political stories of this century.

title: CREDIT MARICETS
description: New York State sold 5104 million in general obligation bonds yesterday. with $41 million left unsold to investors by late afternoon, said an official of the Chase Manhattan Bank, which led the underwriting group. The bonds return from 4.7 percent in 1979 to 6.75 percent in 2008.

title: Rail Commuters Fight Fare Rise
description: NEWARK, July 13  Two organizations representing commuters from the New Jersey Shore filed suit today in an effort to halt a fare increase scheduled to go into effect Oct. 1.

title: McEnroe Tops Martin Before Switch of Tennis Ball
description: The Great Tennis Ball Controversy, otherwise known as the $300,000 Forest Hills Invitation, brought the tournament director to his knees yesterday as he succumbed to the players demands and switched to a heavier ball.

title: Four Movies, Two for Children and Two From Abroad, Open:Screen: 'Bread and Chocolate'
description: WE COULD be in Elysium where it's always summer. We watch a boat with a pair of lovers laze its way across sun-bleached water. On shore, a family prepares to picnic on grass whose greeness is absolute. Nearby we see some friends stand self-consciously for a group photograph. The chamber music that scores this idyll is real. It's being supplied by a tense-looking quartet that sits on camp chairs and civilizes the landscape with sound.Everything is perfect until the arrival of an outsider. He is tall and well-built but, close up, he looks most peculiar. His face is aged but his hair is remarkably full and youthfully brown. There is something so unblemished about his skin, so dramatically dark about his eyebrows and mustache, he could be wearing make-up or  and this is the thought that occurred to me  he might possibly be dead. Is he the new arrival in Elysium who's not yet had time to unpack?The fellow sits down to listen to the music while he eats a sandwich. When he takes a bite, the chamber music group abruptly stops playing. The leader stares at him in disapproval. They can't play if he's going to eat in that fashion. He is clearly a fellow who's never given much thought to his manner of munching.This sequence, which opens Franco Brusati's new Italian film, "Bread and Chocolate," is filled with mystery and a good deal of wit. Nino (Nino Manfredi), the fellow who has so rudely interrupted the concert on the lawn, has not died and gone to heaven, but he has wandered into a setting almost as unreal, at least to him.Nino, an immigrant worker from southern Italy, has made himself comfortable on the lawn of an elegant Swiss resort hotel where, most of the day and much of the night, he works as a temporary waiter. The hotel guests are people who travel through life first-class. Nino is forever steerage.In "Bread and Chocolate," which opens today at the Baronet, Nino aspires to move upward in a world of rigidly fixed rules. The film is the picaresque tale of his attempts to fit into the life of a place that speaks a different language (German) and tolerates him only as long as he accepts the crumbs left on tables by a voraciously consuming, casually unfeeling society. The Swiss bourgeoisie loathe the invaders from the south.In one of the moments of clarity that the screenwriters impose on Nino from time to time (for our edification if not his). Nino says, in effect, there is bound to be friction when you have two million Italian workers in a nation of five million people."Bread and Chocolate," which was written by Mr. Brusati, Mr. Manfredi and Iaia Fiastri, means for us to accept Nino as a tragicomic hero as he wanders, like a lead-footed Candide, into one hard-luck situation after another. He is wrongly accused of a child's sex murder (actually committed by a priest, who makes no effort to hide his guilt). He's later dischargedd from the hotel because he has urinated in the street in broad daylight.A millionaire Italian banker, who recognizes Nino's homesickness and befriends him, turns out to be an embezzler who loses all Nino's savings. In the film's most bizarre episode, Nino is taken in by a group of Italian immigrants who run an illicit chicken-plucking business. They live in a chicken coop and, so the movie indicates in a sequence that desperately needs the humor and discipline of Luis Bunuel, are quite happily turning into chickens.Through all this, Nino maintains a muddled optimism of the sort that has the effect of patronizing a character rather than illuminating it. Nino is patronized not only by the Swiss but also by the people who made the film.Neither Mr. Brusati nor Mr. Manfredi possesses the kind of overview of man and his society that would fuse the various comic and melodramatic episodes into a consistent whole. Instead of being shocking or moving or funny, their movie is sentimental.Mr. Manfredi, like his makeup, is much too obvious and mechanical an actor to be able to sneak up on us with something unexpected.
