Every scene is a confrontation between us and Mr. Manfredi's busy, pushy performance, which negates the character he plays and calls attention, instead, to the actor behind it.The script is not great. It wants to have several characters for the price of one. When it suits the convenience of the authors, Nino assumes a sort of bargain-basement, Chaplinesque innocence. At other times he must behave as one who is basically dim-witted. Then, too, he's a fellow who can question the gods.Innocence, especially, is being hustled here. The film reaches a low point in a drag show put on by Nino and two friends at the Italian workers' barracks. I think we are meant to be touched by the condition of these virtually stateless persons, but they have so much in the way of costumes, makeup and lighting that you might be reminded of an act at Reno Sweeney.Anna Karina has the film's few genuine moments as a young Greek woman, a teacher, who has come to Switzerland to make her fortune and who, briefly, is infatuated by Nino. There are many moments of promise  as when Nino attempts to pass for German by dying his hair blond  but Mr. Brusati and Mr. Manfredi, having had their inspiration, make no decent theatrical of it. They are all too knowing as film makers, but not especially interesting ones.

title: The Pop Life
description: CARLENE CARTER'S debut album, called Carlene Carter, has received an enormous amount of attention. Here is 22-year-old singer suddenly getting feature stories in national magazines, making a flashy promotional tour, gracing the cover of Warner Brothers Records glossy promotional magazine and otherwise attracting the sort of organized attention that people took such a dim view of three years ago with Bruce Springsteen. Moreover, before his promotional push, Mr. Springsteen had already made two records and won a fervent following through steady touring. Hardly anyone has ever heard of Miss Carter.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON LOAN GUARANTEE FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  The Senate and the House of Representatives reached a compromise agreement today on a bill to provide New York City with $1.65 billion of Federal loan guarantees, the keystone of the city's plan to avert bankruptcy.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Soybean futures contracts dropped sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following the Department of Agriculture's revised supplydemand estimates.

title: Californians Leaders In World Junior Golf
description: SAN DIEGO, July 13 (AP)  Californians held top spots in the 1517 age group yesterday after the second round of the 11th annual World Junior golf tournament.

title: Market Place
description: THE Firestone Tire and Rubber Company may be saved from further stock market losses by its $1.10 dividend despite the possibility of a recall of as many as 12 million radial tires for passenger cars.

title: DESIGNERS BLAMED FOR ROOF COLLAPSE
description: In its final report on the causes of the roof collapse at the Hartford Civic Center last January, the Hartford City Council has found that the structual design by the engineering firm of Fraioli-Blum-Yesselman was flawed and that these design deficiencies were the initiating cause of the collapse.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHEN Ovid was banished, he was the most civilized man in a Rome that was dying of civilization. He had so articulated its excesses, its indulgences had found such a perfect form for them, that they seemed to be natural. He was the worst kind of subversive: one who tell us, in irresistible poetry that it is all right to do as we please.

title: Gas Station Held Up In an Unlikely Place
description: Three men took over a service station yesterday at Tillery Street and Flatbush Avenue Extension in Brooklyn, held it for 20 minutes awaiting the arrival of an armored truck and then fled after wounding two guards and stealing only $70, from the station's employees.

title: BorgWarner Raises Some Of Its Prices
description: The New York division of the BorgWarner Corporation announced that it would increase prices by 4 percent to percent on all engineered machinery airconditioning products effective Monday.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Series of preferred United Technologies stock with a value of $50. That preferred stock can be converted into 1.25 shares of United common stock

title: Year After Blackout, Con Ed Has New Safeguards
description: In the year since its systems failed. plunging 8.3 million New Yorkers into darkness, the Consolidated Edison Company says it has substantially revised its emergency procedures.

title: The Truth About the Yankees
description: When the major leagues left off playing baseball to shill fora razor blade this week, the New York Yankees were two games closer to the top of their division than the New York Mets were in theirs. If that doesn't tell George Steinbrenner. Billy Martin and the Bronx clientele something, then it's time the truth was put in writing: come Rosh haShanab, the champions of North America will be former champions.

title: Three Wells in Bogen Are Shut After Jersey Finds a Cancer Agent
description: ALLENDALE. N.J., July 13  Three of the six artesian wells that provide this Bergen County community's drinking water have been ordered shut by New Jersey because they are severely contaminated with a suspected cancer-causing chemical.

title: EnergyTax Bill Is Taken Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Senate and House conferees working on the controversial tax portion of President Carter's troubled energy bill met today for the first time in seven months to give the President symbolic backing as he left for the economic summit meeting in Bonn.

title: Dayton May Build New Detroit Store
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, operators of Hudson's, Detroit's largest department store, announced that would build a new 320,000-square-foot store in the downtown area if a planned shopping center there, requiring Federal and local funds, is completed.

title: Korf Withdraws Steel Complaint
description: Korf Industries said it was withdrawing, without prejudice, a complaint filed last September with the Treasury Department that alleged that French steelmakers had been selling wire rod in the United States at belowcost prices.

title: Camps in Soviet Differ in Severity
description: Under a piison code adopted in 1970, there are three forms of detention facilities in the Soviet Union  regular prisons for dangerous habitual criminals, educational labor colonies for minor firstoffenders and labor camos for political prisoners and some classes of criminals. Aleksandr Ginzburg was sentenced yesterday to be sent to labor camp.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Hungarian Rhapsody No. 1, Liszt; Sinfonia in B flat, Seixas; Procession of the Nobles, RimskyKorsakov; Suite for Two ClarinoTrumpets, Biber; Carnival in Prague, Smetana; Sinfonia, Bach.

title: Curare Caused Two Other Deaths, Expert Testifies
description: HACKENSACK, July 13  An anesthesiologist who has specialized in the study of curare and other such musclerelaxing drugs testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he was reasonably certain that two more or Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims Carl Rohrbeck and Nancy Savino  had died of curare poisoning.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Burroughs Corporation, second only to the International Business Machines Corporation in the office-equipment field, reported yesterday a 16.2 percent increase in secondquarter profits on a revenue gain of 15 vercent.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE SWARM, directed by Irwin Allen; starring Michael Caine and Katherine Ross, at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters.

title: Opera: A Rarity
description: AFAILURE at its first performance in Weimar under the aegis of Franz Liszt in 1858, Peter Cornelius's The Barber of Bagdad is now regarded by many connoisseurs as a masterpiece of German comic opera. Even at that, this delightful work is rarely heard in the United States so the New York Lyric Opera's revival at the New York University Theater Wednesday night was a welcome event.

title: Garrett Hits 30th
description: TOKYO, July 13 (AP)  Adrian Garrett cracked his 30th homer of the Japanese baseball season, a tworun shot in the fourth inning, as the Hiroshima Toyo Carp blanked the Hanshin Tieers. 60, today. Garrett, formerly with the California Angels, now is eight homers ahead of Sadaharu Oh, Japan's homerun king. Koji Tabuchi of the Tigers has 23.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO UNABLE TO RESOLVE ARMSACCORD ISSUES
description: GENEVA, July 13  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, were unable in their talks here to resolve two major issues obstructing a new strategic arms limitation treaty, but they did agree that new ideas they discussed provided a basis for a possible breakthrough later.

title: Crenshaw In 3Way Open Tie
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 13 Can one hole dictate the outcome of a major golf tournament? After two rounds of the 107th British Open championship, with Ben Crenshaw, lsao Aoki and Severiano Ballesteros tied for the lead at 139 today, the answer appeared to be an emphatic yes.

title: Police in Cleveland Go on Strike
description: CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP)  Cleveland policemen went on strike tonight over the city's dismissal of 13 patrolmen who had refused to obey an order to patrol crimeridden housing projects alone in daytime hours.

title: FRAUD IN ELECTIONS DENIED BY BOLIVIANS
description: IA PAZ, Bolivia, July 12  A report charging widespread fraud in Bolivia's elections last Sunday, made by a team of 10 international observers that included lawyer from Washington, has been rejected by the military Government here as interference in the nation's internal affairs.

title: Bonn alks: Host of Problems
description: At a time when the Western world and Japan are h,lintvd by the twin specters of inflation and economic stagnation, President Carter and six other leaders of industrialized nations are scheduled to attend their annual economic summit meeting this weekend, to try to agree on an economic plan that will affect every and indirectly.

title: Pop: Laura Nyro at Club
description: LAURA NYRO, who made few records and fewer public appearances during the mid1970's, is giving her New York fans a number of chances to see her this summer. She opened a soldout round of appearances at The Bottom Line Wednesday night, and on Saturday, July 22, she will be at the Dr. Pepper Music Festival in Central Park.

title: Philip Morris Offers 2 Million Shares
description: Philip Morris Inc. has made a public offering of 2 million shares of common stock through an international investment group headed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 3 Top Nominees Drop Out of Ra ce For President of Lutherans
description: CHICAGO, July 13  Three leading nominees, including the overwhelming favorite, announced today at a biennial convention that they were not candidates for president of the Lutheran Church in America. Each cited a desire to remain in his current post.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Beaths

title: Albus Winner by Stroke On 69210 in State Open
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y. July 13 Jim Albus, in his first year as head professional at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I. played steady golf to win the first New York State open championship today.

title: Innings and Outings
description: THE BAD NEWS BEARS GO TO JAPAN. &reeled by John Berry; written by Bill Lancaster; directors of PhotOgraloM. Gene Polito and Kozo Okazaki; ecktor. Richard A. Harris; music by Robert Kruger; groduCed bv Michael Ritchie; released by Paramount Pictures. At the Guild. 50th Street and Rockefeller Plaza, and other theaters. Running time; t2 minutes. This film is rated.

title: 11 Persons Are Hurt As Two Trains Crash In North White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 13 Eleven persons were injured this morning when Conrail Harlem Line train taking on passengers at the North White Plains station was struck in the rear by an empty train.

title: Iacocca, in Rift With Henry Ford, Ousted as President of Auto Maker
description: DETROIT, July 13 In one of the most dramatic shakeups in the history of the Ford Motor Company, Lee A. Iacocca was ousted today as president of the company by Henry Ford 2d, the chairman.

title: Money Supply in Peak Growth
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve, went on record for the first time today with a forecast of slowing in the upward spiral of interest rates.

title: Court Invalidates Law  For Apartment Tower Over Modem Museum
description: A state law enacted to let the Museum of Modern Art build a 92story apartment tower atop the museum was declared unconstitutional yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Screen: Spacelings:Earthbound Spacelings
description: IF I WERE 10 again, I don't think I'd mind the fact that the space vehicle featured in the opening of "Return From Witch Mountain" looks like a flying pith helmet, or that the subsequent special effects are equally tinny.On the other hand, I think I'd very much enjoy watching telekinetically gifted kids from another planet applying their special powers to such earth-bound situations as car chases (when another vehicle gets in the way, they lift it) and fight scenes (they vanquish enemies with the flip of a flying garbage can). On balance, I think I'd be even more tickled by this Disney movie's abundance of mischief than tired by its emphasis on good, clean, freckle-faced fun.Two young spacelings, a cute boy and an adorable girl, are transported from Witch Mountain to the Rose Bowl, where their Space Uncle instructs them to "have a lot of fun" and "never energize unless it's absolutely necessary."They plan only an ordinary, Disneyland kind of visit to Los Angeles ("I can't wait to see the museums and go to all the concerts!" the girl exclaims).But soon they are separated, and involved in all sorts of intrigue: Tia (Kim Richards) has been adopted by a harmless, good-hearted, perfectly interracial gang called the Earthquakes, and Tony (Ike Eisenmann) has been captured by Christopher Lee and Bette Davis, who play the gruesome twosome of the piece. Mr. Lee and Miss Davis mean to incorporate poor Tony into their plan to take over the entire world.Tony is brainwashed by the villains, and Tia sets out to rescue him, aided only by the Earthquakes and a very smart goat.Tia has been so nicely brought up, on whatever planet she came from in "Escape to Witch Mountain," this film's predecessor, that she is forever thanking people, even  as when the goat does her a good turn  when it isn't exactly necessary. But her search for Tony affords the film some authentically hilarious moments, especially when the goat takes a taxi ride, and during an elaborate sequence in which the siblings wreak havoc with an Old West exhibit at a museum.The two young principals are serviceable, but not nearly as lively as some of their co-stars  Christian Juttner, as the tallest Earthquake, steals virtually every scene he doesn't share with Miss Davis or Mr. Lee.The material makes negligible demands upon the latter pair, but they manage to be agreeably wicked throughout. Mr. Lee's particular vice is supposed to be wild ambition; we know this because he dresses much more elegantly than the average megalomanic might. And Miss Davis's weakness is her greed, which she amply demonstrates with a series of dry asides.John Hough's direction, ungainly at its best, is occasionally downright cruel. Shooting snub-nosed kids from a low camera angle is not a very nice thing to do, and neither is shooting Miss Davis in close-up when her heavy makeup seems designed for long shots. She's supposed to look frightening much of the time, but there's such a thing as gallantry, too.

title: South Africa, Wary on Peace Pact, Wants Firm CeaseFire in Namibia
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 13 The South African Government, reacting warily to the announcement that a Western plan for black majority rule in SouthWest Africa had been accepted by nationalist_ guerrillas, emphasized today that South African troops would be withdrawn from the territory only when a ceasefire had taken hold.

title: Advertising
description: YESTERDAY. N.W. Ayer ABH International, New York, became the darkhorse winner of the sometimes confusing race for the $22 million SevenUp Company account, nosing out the Leo Burnett Company, cnicago. Burnett, however, was named to make ads for Quirst, a new SevenUp lemonade, and other products.

title: Art People
description: ALREADY an industrious group, gallerygoers may soon be working even harder at their art appreciation if Art About Art. opening at the Whitney Museum next Thursday, is any indication. And there's a good chance it is, for the idea of the show and the book it's based on came from Jean Lipman, who has been in on the ground floor of several trends  if a trend can be said to have floors.

title: Nagasaki's Magnificent Past Is About All City Still Has
description: NAGASAKI, Japan  A long time ago, the gardener explained, some general named Grant  I do not know which country he was from  came here and planted that tree. The general was Ulysses Simpson Grant; 99 years ago in May the former President climbed the cobbled streets of this famous but now faltering city and planted two banyan trees.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Gloria Schaffer, Secretary of State of Connecticut, will be nominated to serve on the Civil Aeronautics Board, the White House said yesterday. If con firmed by the Senate, Mrs. Schaffer, 4 years old, will be the second woman to serve on the board. She will join Elizabeth Bailey, the first woman C.A.B. member.

title: Assembly Panel Ties Mortgage Rates to Redlining
description: ALBANY, July 13  Bowing to heavy pressure from the Democratic leadership, the Assembly Banking Committee today approved a bill to link an increase in the homemortgage rate to laws against redlining.

title: Celtic Owner Not Worried
description: While Red Auerbach met yesterday at an undisclosed site in New York with David A. (Sonny) Werblin and Mike Burke, John Y. Brown, 1,5v0 miles away in Florida, expressed doubt that the meet- mg would result in Auerbach's leaving Brown's Boston Celtics for the New York Knicks.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 14, 1978

title: Art: 500 Years of Women at the Met
description: MORE than half the people in the world are women, and right now they are making their full share of the world's art. But until lately, and for reasons that will not be entered into here, they did not so much make art as motivate it.

title: Film: French Let's Face It
description: AWOMAN stands at a railway station, dressed as a kind of cutrate Victoria Holt heroine. in a floorlength white suit and huge, outlandish hat. Then two men approach and look the woman over from neaa to toe. She goes home with them. to a cottage by the sea in Brittany. and there is so much leering and smirking and pregnant pausing that it looks as we're on the verge of witnessing something smutty. The photography is grainy and amateurish, and the music the kind of thing you hear in supermarkets, just to heighten the intimations of softcore porn.

title: REVAMPING ORDERED IN APPEALS PROCESS
description: TRENTON, July 13  The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered a reorganization of the overloaded and boggeddown Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title: Iacocca, in Rift With Henry Ford, Ousted as President of Auto Maker
description: DETROIT, July 13 In one of the most dramatic shakeups in the history of the Ford Motor Company, Lee A. Iacocca was ousted today as president of the company by Henry Ford 2d, the chairman.

title: Mets Beat Reds and Seaver, 42
description: CINCINNATI, July 13  To put it in its simplest terms: The New York Mets beat Tom Seaver tonight.

title: 6th Suspect Seized in Clubbing in the Park
description: A sixth suspect, a juvenile, was arrested early yesterday in the beating and clubbing of joggers and strollers in Central Park last week. The police said the suspects showed no remorse and even boasted that they would engage in similar actions again.

title: Rock: Atlanta Rhythm Section
description: THE members of the Atlanta Rhythm section, which played at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central .Park on Wednesday evening, must be ruminating on the fickle fancies of the rock press these Gays. uuring the early 70s, when they made their first few albums, they were generally ignored by the press. Then few writers began touting them as one of the best bands in the South. By the mid70's they were being described with increasing frequency as the best the South had to offer. Then they scored two hit singles and went from playing clubs and small hauls to playing in coliseums and stadiums. Suddenly their records and performances began to be dismissed by reviewers as too slick and formulaprone.

title: Ward Resigns asi Head of Prisons To Become Housing Police Chief
description: ALBANY, July 13  Benjamin Ward, the state's controversial Corrections Commissioner for the last three years, has unexpectedly resigned to become chief of of the New York City Housing Authority police.

title: Monfort Plans Plant
description: GREELEY, Colo., July 13 (AP) Monfort of Colorado Inc., the nation's largest cattle feeder, said today that it had obtained options to purchase land in western Kansas for construction of $15 million slaughter and custom meatcutting plant. The land options are near Scott City and Oakley. The plant the company intends to build would nearly double Monfort's beefproduction capacity. The company reported revenues of $365.3 million last year from the sale of 525,000 cattle and 687,000 lambs processed at its Greeley headquarters.

title: Tea Men's Victory Puts a Dent In Cosmos
description: The invincibility of the Cosmos at Giants Stadium has come to an abrupt end. The North American Soccer League champions have shown that they can be beaten at home.

title: Stage: Liviu Ciulei's Spring Awakening
description: A Director's Play

title: Associated Press
description: FUSCHL, Austria, July 13 (Reuters) Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel discussed Middle East peace issues today with President Anwar elSadat in an unexpected meeting, and he described the talks as very useful.

title: Saxophones Sound a Classical Note in Modern's Garden
description: Although it has been performing for 19 years, in major concert halls and elsewhere, the New York Saxophone Quartet still hears amazed comments from the audience such as I never knew a saxophone could sound like that.

title: Dragsters: Super Speed, Nicknames
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J. July 13 They call them Starvin Marvin, Big Daddy, the Snake, Grumpy, the Mongoose and the Orange Barron. They drive chargedup machines more than 200 miles an hour for short distances, most of them hoping their brief fling will pay for the trip to next week's races.

title: Jersey Acts in 9W Feud With Its Own Truck Ban
description: ALPINE. N. J.. July 13  A new salvo was fired today in the New York StateNew Jersey border feud over heavy truck traffic on a route that crosses the state line on the Palisades.

title: PROTECTION SOUGHT IN POLICE SEARCHES
description: WASHINGTON. July 13  The American Civil Liberties Union and three groups representing virtually all the daily newspapers in the country asked Congress today to enact legislation to protect citizens who were not suspected of a crime from unannounced police searches.

title: Union Bancorp In Settlement
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13 The Union Bancorp of California announced today that it had settled a major portion of litigation regarding its banking relationship with U.S. Financial Inc., a real estate development company that went bankrupt in 1973.

description: UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio, July 13 Last night, the people of this prosperous little suburb of Columbus lifted a finger for electronic democracy.

title: Economic Scene
description: DENVER

title: Restaurants
description: Mimi Sheraton

title: Broadway
description: Louis La Russo 2d gets new contender ready for stage ring.

title: 3 Accused in Fatal Beating
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., July 13 (UPI) Three Elizabeth teenagers have been charged in the fatal beating of Richard Udet, 36 years old, and the assault on his friend, Ramon DeOcampo, 17, after the youths allegedly verbally abused Debra Pitman, a friend of Mr. Udet, and threw beer cans in her car while she waited at red light.

title: On Preachers, Prisoners and Power
description: As Ambassador Andrew Young has now demonstrated in his reaction to the Soviet political trials, it easy to say or do something that is simultaneously humane and dumb. In fact, the entire nation is in danger of making just such a response.

title: Sixth Suspect Is Seized in Clubbing Of Button and Five in Central Park
description: A sixth suspect, a juvenile, was arrested early yesterday in the beating and dubbing of joggers and strollers in Central Park last week. The police said the suspects showed no remorse and even boasted that they would engage in similar actions again.

title: Barclays In 3Sided Takeover
description: LONDON, July 13  Barclays Bank and a big pension fund have concluded a novel, controversial deal involving the takeover of another of Britain's investment companies.

title: Men's Store Chain Sues Con Ed for Looting Loss
description: A chain of men's clothing stores has filed a classaction suit seeking $306.7 million in damages from Consolidated Edison and New York City on behalf of merchants whose stores were looted as consequence of last July's major power blackout.

title: North Central Airlines, Southern Air to Merge
description: ATLANTA, July 13 (AP)  North Central Airlines and Southern Airways announced today that they had agreed in principle to merge, a Southern official said.

title: How Police Broke the Case of BaseballBat Clubbings in Central Park
description: Within hours of the beating in Central Park last week of six men, two teams of detectives began investigating, under the supervision of Deputy Chief Martin E. Duffy, the commanding officer of Manhattan detectives.

title: Dee Leads by Stroke In New Jersey Open
description: SUMMIT, N.J. July 13 Jimmy Dee of Ridgewood, fresh from a victory in the Ike Championship on Tuesday, stayed right on course yesterday with 36, 3672 for a onestroke lead in the opening round of the Now Jersey State open at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

title: Steelworkers
description: PITTSBURGH, July 13  The United Steelworkers of America had assets totaling $150,984,736 as of Dec. 31, 1977, according to a financial report disclosed today.

title: Associated Press
description: OVERCOME BY GRIEF, the relative of a victim of Tuesday's gastruck explosion in Tarragona, Spain, collapses during funeral services. More than 100 bodies, most of them unidentified, were buried yesterday. Official death toll is 181 and hospital officials predict that 120 survivors will die of their wounds. Trucks carrying dangerous cargo have now been banned from country roads.

title: Texaco Details Well's Progress
description: Texaco's stock rose again yesterday amid persistent rumors that the company had struck gas beneath the ocean floor off New Jersey. It closed up % at 253/4, and up 17/8 from the two-and-ahalfyear low that it hit last week.

title: Cabaret: A Songwriter Sings
description: LIKE many pop songwriters who are not also performers, George David Weiss is not a name that will ring a bell with most listeners, although the titles of many of his songs will. They include Too Close for Comfort, Oh, What It Seems to Be, Wheel of Fortune and The Lion Sleeps Tonight.

title: Bargaining Resumed in Albany on Anticrime Plan
description: ALBANY, July 13The Legislature resumed bargaining today on tough anticrime measures, with Republicans charging that Democrats were blocking their proposals, but nevertheless it was said to be making substantial progress in reaching a compromise. Both sides remained optimistic on eventual agreement.

title: Some Change Evident At the Center of Power
description: One year after the July 1977 Con Edison general power failure, the windowless room from which the utility monitors its maze of power lines still resembles a television news studio with its digital displays, curved desks and blue and brown schematic drawings of power lines arching around the green walls.

title: Criminals Yes, Adults No
description: Searching for political advantage in the recent incidents of teenage violence, New York's Governor Carey and his Republican challenger, Perry Duryea, have been playing a game of oneupmanship with juvenile crime. Fortunately the blitz of press releases ana OII-Ule-curt prescriptions has now given way concrete legislative programs. As the State Legislature reconvenes, it faces a clear choice between Republican proposals to transfer more juvenile cases to adult courts and a plan by the Governor for formal trials and stiffer sentencing in Family Court. Governor Carey's approach, though flawed, is the more appealing; keeps sight of the fact that we are, after all, dealing with children.

title: Senate Approves a Bank For Consumer Coops
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 In a major victory for consumer advocates, the Senate today approved legislation to create an independent national bank for consumer cooperatives. The measure was approved, 60 to 33, after a daylong debate.

title: Topics
description: Yet another South African has died in police custody, the 22d nonwhite casualty since 1976. Jimmy Kruger, the Minister of Justice, says that Lun. gile Tabalaza took his own life by leap. ing from a fifthfloor window of the Port Elizabeth Security Police building, the same building in which Stephen Biko received the injuries that led to his death. To avoid the embarrassments of the Biko affair, Mr. Kruger has this time ordered an investigation by a senior police officer. But he was quick to observe that last year 40 prisoners committed suicide in France, implying that South Africa was once again being judged by a double standard.

title: P.B.A. Rejects a Revised Offer by New York City
description: New York City offered a revised contract to policemen yesterday, but the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association's delegate assembly overwhelmingly rejected it only hours later. Shortly after that at P.M., 100 offduty officers began demonstrations outside Police Headquarters in Manhattan.

title: Business and the Law
description: PREPAID legal plans come in many different forms, but the underlying concept is similar to that of group health insurance. Money is paid in advance for legal services, ordinarily by middle-income people who will seek help in matrimonial, personaldebt and landlordtenant matters.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Beatha

title: China Reserves Put at $3 Billion
description: PEKING, July 13 (Reuters) Deputy Prime Minister of China, Li Ilsiennien, who is in charge of the economy, discussed China's financial needs with the Mitsui Group of Japan today and disclosed that the nation's foreigncurrency reserves stood at almost S3 billion, Japanese sources said.

title: New Fare: Carlin Glynn
description: THE Carlin Glynn story sounds like the stuff of a bestselling women's novel: A 38-year-old Manhattan actress, who uncomplainingly spent most of the last 15 years being a helpmate to her husband and a mother to her three children, decides to return to her career. She winds up making her Broadway debut as the star of a bigtime musical, even though she had never sung before in her life.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: More than 70 members of one of America's wealthiest and most influential families gathered under a cloudless blue sky yesterday to bury the ashes of their patriarch, John D. Rockefeller 3d, in the family cemetery at Pocantico Hills.

title: Man Arrested at White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (Reuters) man who drove his car up to the White House gates and demanded to see President Carter was arrested today, the police reported. Secret Service agents at the gate told the man, identified as Milton Casnmore of Illinois, that Mr. Carter was out of the country. The President left earlier today on a fourday visit to West Germany. Mr. Cashmore, standing beside his car with the aid of crutches, told agents before his arrest: Open the gate and let me in. Jimmy Carter is fired. I'm going to sleep in the White House tonight.

title: Guerrillas Free 40 U.N. Soldiers Seized in Lebanon
description: TYRE, Lebanon, July 13 Palestinian guerrillas today freed the last of 40 United Nations peacekeeping soldiers who had been held hostage in what was described by both sides as a misunderstanding.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: FOR years, the print press has been putting television under the scrutiny of reviewers and reporters who generally find the medium wanting, if not downright menacing. Television, however, has been oddly shy about judging its print brethren. Except for an occasional CBS Views the Press in the past, the electronic side would seem to be suffering from a whopping inferiority complex.

title: United Air Choice Due On Planes
description: A $500 million choice by United Air Lines between a new Boeing twinaisle plane, the 767, and a scaleddown version of the European Airbus A300 is expected to be made today at a special board meeting.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: There are 16 new opera faces in Westchester this weekend. A group of young pnlessionals who have been studying at the Manhattanville Summer Opera Workshop in Purchase are giving two performances titled Opera High. lights. The highlights are scenes from Verdi's Falstaff, Puccini's Madama Butterfly, Mozart's Marriage of Figaro and Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier. Tonight and Sunday at 8 P.M. in Browason Hall's Little Theater. Admission is $1. From New York City, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 4, and then the Cross County Parkway east to the Hutchinson River Parkway east. Get off at Route 120 and continue to Purchase Street. Information: (914) 9469600.

title: Ramapo Rings to Old Jazz Sound
description: Did you hear about New Jersey and all that jazz? It's a crash course in Mahwah: two weeks of the sweetest sounds this side of Basin Street under the rubric of The Fifth Annual Ramapo College Summer Jazz Festival and Workshop.

title: 2 Senators Ask Criminal Code Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Strom Thurmond chided a House subcommittee today for proposing only minimal action on revising the Federal criminal code, calling the panel's proposal barely first step.

title: M. T. A. AUDIT FINDS FRAUD ON EXPENSES
description: Levitt Says That 33% of Accounts Submitted by HighRanking Employees Were Rigged

title: I.C.C. Official Ousted On Misconduct Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission today notified Richard W. Kyle, its deputy Congressional relations officer, that he was being dismissed effective tomorrow on charges of official misconduct.

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: BigName Stocks Rise In Sluggish Day for Dow
description: Bigname stocks such as Teledyne, Boeing and Texaco moved higher yesterday along with a number of lesserknown issues, while the general market remained on an even keel. Call options for Teledyne and Texaco scored sharp percentage increases.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON LOAN GUARANTEE FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  The Senate and the House of Representatives reached a compromise agreement today on a bill to provide New York City with $1.65 billion of Federal loan guarantees, the keystone of the city's plan to avert bankruptcy.

title: POLICE GIVEN DATA ON BOAST BY ROWE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 13  Police sources here said today that they had information that might support Gary Thomas Rowe Jr.'s contention that he killed a black man during racial unrest in Birmingham in 1963, while Mr. Rowe was on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's payroll as an informer within the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Auto With $5 Million in Securities Hijacked in the Financial District
description: Two gunmen stole $5 million in securities  about half of them negotiable yesterday by hijacking a station wagon in the financial district in lower Manhattan.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO UNABLE TO RESOLVE ARMSACCORD ISSUES
description: GENEVA, July 13Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, were unable in their talks here to resolve two major issues obstructing a new strategic arms limitation treaty, but they did agree that new ideas they discussed provided a basis for a possible breakthrough later.

title: Jury Clears Donation to Lindsay
description: A report issued by John F. Keenan, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, has concluded that there is no evidence to indict anyone in the case of a $30,000 cash contribution by the developer of the Bronx Terminal Market to former Mayor John V. Lindsay's Presidential campaign.

title: Danbury Artisans
description: Mention the Danbury Fair in Connecticut and one thinks of the giant annual display of the products and artifacts of the American hinterland prize bulls and sows, tomatoes the size of cantaloupes and cantaloupes the size of pumpkins, sunflowers, petunias, apple pies, tractors, housewares and furniture  in all, 267 acres of everything two centuries of purveyors of agricultural and industrial products could think of.

title: Jazz: Bob Brookmeyer Is Back
description: OB BROOKMEYER'S gruffly singing valve trombone has not been heard in New York for more than a decade, period that he has spent in California, much of the time out of the jazz world. In New York he had been a distinctive soloist as well as a composer and arranger with both the Gerry Mulligan Concert Band and the Thad JonesMel Lewis Band. And he had been joint leader of a small group with Clark Terry

title: Young's Remarks to Paris Paper
description: PARIS, July 13 (AP)  Following are Andrew Young's remarks on political prisoners in an interview published yesterday by the Paris Socialist daily Matin. The remarks were made in English, published in French, and translated back into English. They are followed by the text of a statement issued in Geneva today by Mr. Young commenting on the interview with the Paris newspaper.

title: Thomas Hess, Art Expert, Dies; Writer and Met Official Was 57
description: Thomas B. Hess, consultative chairman of the Department of 20thCentury Art at the Metropolitan Museum and for many years editor of Art News magazine, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack and collapsing at his desk in the museum. He would have been 58 years old today.

title: Schmidt Says U.S. Holds Key to Economic Accord
description: BONN, July 13  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that the will of Europe and Japan to make sacrifices to improve the world's economy was dependent in large part on the United States ability to convince them it can control its energy imports and inflation.

title: Squires Takes First In Central Park Run
description: Peter Squires, a 28-year-old Yonkers school teacher, was the best among 1,305 runners who competed Wednesday night in Central Park in a race for local business people. Squires raced the 3.5 miles in 16 minutes 40 seconds in the second of a series of three park races for companies and organizat ions.

title: Ramapo Rings to Old Jazz Sound
description: Did you hear about New Jersey and all that jazz? It's a crash course in Mahwah: two weeks of the sweetest sounds this side of Basin Street under the nibric of The Fifth Annual Ramapo College Summer Jazz Festival and Workshop.

title: Bass Is Plumber's Pipe Dream
description: Jack Gasnick, urban fisherman, admits to a gnawing, if mild frustration.

title: Ginzburg Given 8Year Sentence By Soviet Court
description: MOSCOW, July 13  Aleksandr Ginzburg, a human rights advocate who managed a fund aiding the families of political prisoners, was found guilty today of antiSoviet agitation and propaganda and was sentenced to eight years in a strict labor camp.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thirty bicycle enthusiasts followed Transportation Commissioner Anthony R. Ameniso in a ride around midtown Manhattan to celebrate the opening of the first bicycle lanes in the city.

title: Elizabeth Eaton Butterfield, 65, Founder of Bryn Mawr Book Sale
description: Elizabeth Eaton Butterfield, founder of the Bryn Mawr book sale in Cambridge, Mass., which started as a charitable effort and turned into a fulltime occupation, died of cancer in Boston Wednesday at me Sidney Farber Clinic of the Harvard Medical School. She was 65 years old and a resident of Cambridge.

title: United Technologies And AMBAC Merge
description: HARTFORD, July 13 (AP)  Stockholders of AMBAC Industries agreed today to a merger with the United Technologies Corporation, officials of both companies said.

title: Publishing: Charlton Heston
description: THAT February day in 1957 was a tense time for Orson Welles: no longer the wonderboy director, his reputation now somewhat in eclipse, he was supposed to start filming a new movie, Touch of Evil. Set in a sleazy town on the TexasMexico border, it was a suspense story starring Mr. Welles as a sadistic sheriff and a younger actor as the detective hero.

title: Yankees Change But Still Lose, 61
description: Maybe next the Yankees should try the out-of-the-hat lineup strategy that helped turn their season around last year. They tried to improve by doing things the owner's way yesterday and it didn't come out any better than the first half of the season, when they did it the manager's way.

title: YOUNG DENIES SEEING U.S.LAW LIKE SOVIET'S
description: GENEVA, July 13  Andrew Young, under attack for saying there were political prisoners in American as well as Soviet jails, denied today that he had meant to equate the status of political freedom in the United States with that of the Soviet Union.

title: 3 Franklin Indictments
description: Three former top officials of the Franklin National Bank were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal fraud charges for allegedly falsifying the bank's records to conceal losses of more than $5 million.

title: Shortchanging Our Children
description: BROADWATER, Neb.Why is juvenile crime soaring to new records? Why should life be so unbearable that the suicide rate for youngsters between 5 and 14 years old has doubled in the last few years? Why do so many youngsters who graduate from reform schools end up in prison?

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 13 (Reuters)  Three white men appeared secretly in court today in connection with what political sources here said might become a major Rhodesian financial scandal.

title: Quadruplets Born in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, July 13 (UPI)  Prematurely born quadruplets, weighing about 11/2 pounds each, were reported doing as well as could be expected today, one day after their birth. Doctors said that the quadruplets, three girls and a boy, were born to Mr. and Mrs. Lynn Schwehach. The infants, born at Barnes Hospital, were taken to the neonatal intensive care unit at Cardinal Glennon Memorial Hospital.

title: Evans Stops Mike Quarry
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 13 (AP) Tommy Evans of Richmond, Calif.. stopped Mike Quarry of Los Angeles in the eighth round of a scheduled 10round lightheavyweight fieht last night at the Oakland Auditorium. Referee Rudy Ortega stopped the fight at 2:54 of the round. Evans has 10 victories two defeats and a draw. Quarry is 66-11-6.

title: 2dQuarter Nets Up 31% at Reynolds and Kaiser
description: Two leading aluminum producers, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, both reported 31 percent jumps in their secondquarter earnings, reflecting continued strength in the automotive and container markets for the metal.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: MARY GAY SHERROD

title: Trade Pact Drafted for Bonn Talks
description: GENEVA, July 13  The United States and other major Western powers agreed here today on new steps toward liberalizing world trade and eliminating unfair commercial practices. They nope the agreement in principle, which they will take to the weekend economic summit meeting in Bonn, can form the basis for a new set of international trading rules for the 1980's.

title: GIVE TO THE FRESH AIR FUND
Beaths
description: FERGUSONNorma Bidwell on July 12, in her910 year, in Nassau, Bahamas, her home for the past 32 years. Survived by her brother, Miles Oakley Bidwell. also a resident of the Bahamas. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Bahamas Humane Society, Nassau. Bahamas are suggested.

title: Two New Bond Issues Among 8 Bills Signed Into Law by Governor
description: TRENTON, July 13 (AP)  Two bond issues, a special school construction aid program and new control over professional licensing boards were among eight bills Governor Byrne signed into law today.

title: Foes of the Tocks Island Dam Dominate a Hearing
description: PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 13  Environmentalists carried a coffin into a public hearing on the future of the Delaware River today, urging death with dignity for the proposed Tocks Island Dam project.

title: Method of Releasing Psychiatric Patients Upheld by State Court
description: ALBANY, July 13  In a reversal of lowercourt ruling, New York State's Court of Appeals today upheld the state's program of deinstitutionalizing mental patients by discharging them into the community.

title: How Police Broke the Central Park Clubbings Case
description: Within hours of the beating in Central Park last week of six men, two teams of detectives began investigating, under the supervision of Deputy Chief Martin E. Dufty, the commanding officer of Manhattan detectives.

title: U.S. Urges a Court to Reinstate Sentences in Texas Police Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  The Government asked a Federal appeals court today to reinstate 10year prison terms for three former Houston police officers who were convicted in the drowning of a young MexicanAmerican suspect in their custody.

title: Dentist Is Appointed As Trustee of N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Maurice J. Saklad, a Manhattan dentist, has been named a trustee of New York University, John C. Sawhill, the president of the university, announced yesterday.

title: Efforts to Lure Middle Incomes Back to the City
description: Urban Affairs

title: In Collection of Clothes for Golfers, Fashion Follows Function
description: Tennis players have outnumbered golfers in the last few years by more than three to one. While children as young as 10 wield a tennis racquet with enthusiam, the bulk of the golf population is 35 years oldand older.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: AS the Hudson River goes, so goes Ossining. At least that is the way many have come to view this northern Westchester County community over the years. And in a sense  it is still true. Although the commercial heyday of the Hudson  and such river towns as Ossining  is past, the river and the village still offer beautiful tableaux. And for Hudson watchers, the vista from the village's hills, which gently slope to the river, offer as good a vantage point as any for a spectacular view.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY HIGH COURT REAFFIRMS MIRANDA
description: ALBANY, July 13  The New York State Court of Appeals, reaffirming the state's strict interpretation of the socalled Miranda decision, ruled today in four cases that the police must scrupulously honor a suspect's right to have a lawyer present when they interrogate him.

title: Associated Press
description: FUSCHL, Austria, July 13 (Reuters) Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel discussed Middle East peace issues today with President Anwar elSadat in an unexpected meeting, and he described the talks as very useful.

title: Brademas and O'Neill Are Named In House Inquiry on Korea Bribes
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Representative John Brademas of Indiana, the House majority whip, accepted $2,950 in $50 bills from a foreign national at a time when he was involved in drafting legislation to prohibit such contributions, the House ethics committee reported today.

title: Expert Links Two Other Deaths To Curare in Jersey Murder Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 13  An anesthesiologist who has specialized in the study of curare and other such musclerelaxing drugs testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he was reasonably certain that two more of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims  Karl Rohrbeck and Nancy Sevino  had died of curare poisoning.

title: Notes on People
description: The actor Hume Cronyn, his secretary and a real estate agent were held at gunpoint and locked in the basement of Mr. Cronyn's suburban home by a woman and man who ransacked the house. The police in Pound Ridge. N.Y., said that the woman cased the home there of Mr. Cronyn and his wife, the actress Jessica Tandy. on July 5. posing as a prospective buyer of the $750,000 property. By appointment, the woman returned Wednesday afternoon with her architect and a local real estate agent, and the architect confronted Mr. Cronyn, his secretary, Sylvia Brooks, and the unidentified real estate agent with a gun. The two men were handcuffed and the woman tied up by the intruders, who locked the three in the basement. They managed to escape, however, and call the police. The robbers, who had been gathering up art and other valuables, abandoned the loot and escaped before the police arrived. At the time of the incident, Miss Tandy was in New York in her role in The Gin Game, a Broadway play from which Mr. Cronyn has re-

title: Bass Is Plumber's Pipe Dream
description: Jack Gasnick, urban fisherman, admits to a gnawing, if mild frustration.

title: 2 Planes Collide on Runway
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 13 (AP)  The Clarkstown police said two singleengine planes collided today on a runway at the Ramapo Valley Airport near here. No injuries were reported.

title: About Real Estate
description: When the tide of real estate activity is low, many a distressed property can be left high and dry, to become a sign of resurgence in the industry when it is picked up at last.

title: The New York Times/ Neal Boonzi
description: More than 70 members of one of America's wealthiest and most influential families gathered under a cloudless blue sky yesterday to bury the ashes of their patriarch, John D. Rockefeller 3d, in the family cemetery at Pocantico Hills.

title: Jaundice Toll Heavy in Bombay
description: BOMBAY, July 13 (Reuters)  About 350 people died of jaundice here in the first six months of this year in an outbreak theauthorities say was mainly caused by contamination of the water supply by sewage. Dr M.K. Vaidya, chief executive health officer of the Bombay Municipal Corporation, said that 40,000 cases were registered.

title: Senators Ask Brezhnev To Aid 2 U.S. Newsmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  A majority of Senators asked Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today to intervene in the slander charges brought against two American correspondents, Craig R. Whitney of The New York Times and Harold D. Piper of The Baltimore Sun.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 14, 1978

title: YOUNG ISSUES DENIAL ON U.S. PRISONERS
description: GENEVA, July 13  Andrew Young, under attack for saying there were political prisoners in American as well as Soviet jails, denied today that he had meant to equate the status of political freedom in the United States with that of the Soviet Union.

title: Billy Taylor At Last Finds Time To Play
description: Billy Taylor, the pianist and composer, has been a tireless spokesman for jazz for the last decade, serving on seemingly endless list of boards, committees, foundations and funds. At tomorrow night in Town Hall, he will speak for himself, playing a concert of his own music with the Collective Black Artists Ensemble, conducted by Slide Hampton.

title: Cancer Chemical's Presence Shuts 3 of 6 Artesian Wells in Allendale
description: ALLENDALE, NJ., July 13  Three of the six artesian wells that provide this Bergen County community's drinking water have been ordered shut by New Jersey because they are severely contaminated with a suspected cancer-causing chemical.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, July 13 (AP)  The International Tennis Federation outlawed the controversial doublestrung spaghetti racquet for at least the next year by adopting a rule today that for the first time defined what a racquet is.

title: Informer Is Subject of TV Movie
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13  Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., the Federal Bureau of Investigation informer who told the authorities in Alabama that he killed black man while on the bureau's payroll, is the hero of a nearly completed twohour movie made for television.

title: Weekend Catchword Is Bluefish
description: Large quantities of bluefish are sweeping through the New York Bight and Long Island Sound. Tice fine blue fishing is augmented by the arrival of weakfish. While both blues and weals are the best bet this weekend throughout much of the region, mako shark fishing also is good in the Bight.

title: Film: More 'Bad News Bears'
description: "THE BAD NEWS BEARS Go to Japan" is the third in the comedy series about the California baseball team with the pint-sized players who have dirty mouths and hearts of driven mush. The title tells only part of the story.The Bad News Bears, who last time out won their big game in the Houston Astrodome, do go to Japan and they do play some baseball, but most of the time they and their schlock promoter (Tony Curtis) are searching for material worthy of their raffish talents. The film is a demonstration of the kind of desperation experienced by people trying to make something out of a voyage to nowhere.Though this film was written by Bill Lancaster, who wrote the original "Bad News Bears," produced by Michael Ritchie, who directed the first film, and directed by John Berry, who helped to make "Claudine" such a lark, "The Bad News Bears Go to Japan" has the appearance of a movie made by people who didn't know how, or who didn't care, or who possibly turned over their responsibilities to Japanese Airlines and the Japanese Tourist Bureau, whose principal interests are prominent among the screen images.Mr. Curtis plays a seedy agent named Marvin Lazar, a character who seems to be a comic valentine to Irving (Swifty) Lazar, one of Hollywood's most successful agents and most active legends. Marvin, after conning the Bears into going to Japan to make his fortune, is himself conned and conquered by the Bears who persuade him to go straight, which is just about the only road left open to a fellow whose credit cards have all been ceremoniously cut in two. When given a chance by the material, Mr. Curtis projects a picture of second-rate hucksterism that is all the more funny for being so blatantly rude and transparent.Of the original Bears remaining in the new movie, Jackie Earle Haley is perhaps best remembered as the little Bear who seemed old for his size and years but now, with his years and growth in size, he seems only a little old to be hanging around the Bears. A most attractive newcomer is 6-year-old Scoody Thornton, a small, incurably optimistic boy who persists in sticking up for Marvin when all the other Bears know him to be the failed scoundrel he is.A Japanese star, Tomisaburo Wakayama, plays the taciturn coach of the Japanese team and Dick Button appears in a comic cameo as himself as he describes a televised karate match entirely in figure-skating terms."The Bad News Bears," which opens today at neighborhood theaters, isn't the sort of bad movie that angers you. It's sad in the way of something that's been abandoned. It deserved better from the people involved."The Bad News Bears Go to Japan," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains most of the mildly vulgar language that was so popular in the first two "Bears" films.

title: Around the Nation
description: TOPEKA. Kan.. July 13  Agriculture officials from four farm states called today for the release of banned pesticides to combat infestations of grasshoppers that are damaging thousands of acres of crop and range lands.

title: Electrical Concern's Net Up 15%
description: Secondquarter profits of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation climbed 15.3 percent to a record $74.8 million, or 86 cents a share, from $64.9 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier, the Pittsburghbased electrical and uranium company reported yesterday.

title: Carter Campaign Unit to Pay U.S. Treasury $3,28!
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  An industry leader and a corporate group have been fined and President Carter's campaign committee has been ordered to pay the United States Treasury $3,285.14 because of the handling of Mr. Carter's appearance at a New York business luncheon in 1976.

title: Bridge:
description: Few duplicate clubs ever have the experience of having a world champion from some other part of the world drop in to take part in a game. This happened recently at the Barclay Bridge two, in Jackson Heights, Queens, and the distinguished visitor was Marian Frenkiel of Poland.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Beatha

title: Spain to Dismiss a Police Captain
description: RENTERIA, Spain, July 13 (Reuters)  Municipal officials said riot policemen smashed shop windows with their rifle butts here today after charging through Basque demonstrators barricades, and Interior Ministry sources in Madrid said the police captain in charge would be removed immediately.

title: Hillenbrand Places $50 Million in Notes
description: Hillenbrand Industries, Batesville, Ind., has completed a private placement of $50 million of 20year notes with two institutional lenders at a rate of 91/2 percent.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: PAUL PARNES

title: At the Movies
description: WORD that Tom Stoppard had agreed write the screenplay of Graham Greene's The Human Factor prompted a telephone call to the distinguished young playwright at his home in Iver Heath, about 20 miles from London, where he lives with his wife, Miriam, and their four children.

title: Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.1. July 13  His room these days is in a dormitory, hardly the setting for a $100,000-a-year quarterback who is the bestknown asset of the New York Jets. But as Richard Todd prepared to put on pads for the first time this year he reflected on the almostshy country boy from Alabama who had become in two seasons a lion of Manhattan's upper East Side.

title: 5 Airlines May Land At Midway
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  The Civil Aeronautics Board, in a move that could reduce congestion at O'Hare Airport in Chicago, today tentatively awarded five airlines the authority to operate out of Midway Airport, which is now virtually unused.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, July 15

title: Art: Portraits Star At the Modern
description: THERE are times when there is nothing more agreeable in the visual arts than a portrait in which artist and subject are seen to face each other on equal terms, each bringing a certain pressure to bear on the visible result. A true portrait is, after all, a kind of interview in which certain details of character and personal history are vividly revealed. But as with interviews, too, some of the interest of a portrait lies in what remains concealed. An effective portrait always leaves us with a sense of mysteries beyond the immediately visible.

title: Breakdown Traps 13,000 Aboard 15 Conrail Trains
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 14  Nearly 13,000 rushhour commuters were trapped for two to three hours aboard 15 Conrail trains this morning because of an electrical power failure in the New RochelleWoodl awn area.

title: Limits Set for Light Bombers
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  The Air Force today imposed speed and other flying restrictions on 138 of the A37 B Dragonfly light bombers flown by six Air National Guard and Mr Reserve units. The action was taken because of buffeting action in the plane's tailwing elevafor section at high speeds, the Air Force said. It added that there had been no accidents attributed to this problem and that the restrictions were precautionary.

title: MISS WIDDEMER, 93, POET, AUTHOR, DIES
description: Margaret Widdemer, a prizewinning poet and author of 32 novels, died yesterday in Nathan Littaur Hospital in Gloversville, N.Y. She was 93 years old. She moved from New York to Gloversville a few years ago.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (UPI) The authorities say they will seek dismissal of charges against 39 handicapped protesters arrested during a demonstration to call attention to their need for special buses.

description: A sparkling rally, fueled by reports of improved corporate profits, a record order for commercial aircraft and hopes for a peaking of interest rates, sent the Dow Jones industrial average racing ahead by more than 15 points yesterday in its best gain since the huge spring surge in stock prices.

title: Helen Tower Gilmour Wed to Alec M. Wilson
description: Helen Tower Gilmour of New York was married yesterday to Alec Maclaine Wilson of Farnham, England. The Very Rev. Sturgis L. Riddle performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Carter Pushes New Plan On CapitalGins Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  The Carter Administration is working with liberals on the House Ways and Means Committee to draft an alternative plan to reduce capitalgains taxes, but it is highly uncertain how the effort will tare because of momentum behind existing proposals.

title: Sadat Returns Home; Says Israeli Exchanges Were Very Successful
description: CAIRO, July 14  President Anwar elSadat returned home today, saying his trip to Austria, where he met with the Israeli Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, and the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, had been more than successful.

title: Books of The Times Vietnam Generation
description: There were 27 million draftage men who made up the socalled Vietnam Generation. In the decade of war, two million served. Chance and Circumstance is about the other 25 million. They did not have to go to Vietnam. But many bear psychological scars; many, when they compare their lot to those who became wartime casualties, are walking wounded.

title: City Pension Funds Tie Loan to a Pending Tax Bill
description: Despite Congressional agreement on a bill to provide New York City with Federal loan guarantees, the municipal pension funds said yesterday that they could not commit themselves to further lending to the city unless they received favorable treatment in a related bill now before the Senate.

title: Auerbach Turns Down Offer to Be Knicks President
description: Flattery lost out to tradition yesterday when Red Auerbach turned down the presidency of the Knicks to remain with Boston and finish his career there as president and general manager of the Celtics.

title: UNION SEEKS INQUIRY ON A SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: TRENTON, July 14  The head of the state employees union has asked the State Attorney General's office to investigate alleged outside business interests of Louis Perone, the superintendent of the state's School for the Retarded at Woodbridge.

title: OPEC Nations Debate Use of Declining Dollar
description: LONDON, July 14 (UPI)  A dozen nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries argued today about the merits and penalties of abandoning the dollar as OPEC's official currency for buying and selling oil.

title: News Summary
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky was sentenced by a Moscow court to 13 years in prison and labor camps for treason, espionage and antiSoviet agitation. He was accused of having given secrets to the Central Intelligence Agency, a charge that he denied as absurd and that President Carter also told Soviet leaders was false. [Page 1,Column 6].

title: McEnroe Beats Fibak; Both Reach Semifinals
description: Billy Martin called it the Wimbledon effect, recalling the chilly, rainy weather that plagued last week's championship at the All England Lawn Tennis Club. The effect caught up with the S300,000 Forest Hills Invitation yes. terday as a fine drizzle came down.

title: 'The Swarm,' By Allen, Flies Onto Screens
description: Some day, African killer bees may wind up having the last buzz on us, but for the time being they simply aren't scary, at least not in Irwin Allen's "The Swarm." When Mr. Allen films large numbers of bees from afar, they look like clouds of nutmeg or, sometimes, like peculiarly chunky smog; up close, they suggest a naturalist's documentary about habits of the hive. A couple of times, Mr. Allen offers gigantic blowups of the bugs, in hopes of generating a "Towering Antennae" effect, but still the bees don't look as if they'd hurt a fly. Mr. Allen might just as well have devoted his talents to man-eating goldfish, poodles on the rampage or carniverous canaries."Oh, my God  bees, bees, millions of bees!" cries a helicopter pilot, who, needless to say, is not long for this world. The horde is headed for a sweet little town where the movie theater is playing "The Towering Inferno," Mr. Allen's previous exercise in pre-fab pandemonium, and where the local drugstore must do land-office business selling hair spray to the schoolmistress, played by Olivia de Havilland. Once they arrive, the bees slaughter everybody they can get their stingers on.Mr. Allen stands to gain a great deal from the bloodthirstiness of his swarm, but there isn't much in it for the bees. We see a few bee's-eye point-of-view shots of innocent picnickers and the like, but their motives are never made clear. Are they out to avenge themselves on mankind? Michael Caine, playing the entomologist of the piece, hazards a guess or two, but nothing he says is helpful to Richard Widmark, as a general on Bee Patrol. "I always credit my enemy, no matter what he may be, with equal intelligence," Mr. Widmark grimly observes. Because the military's first 10 or 12 schemes to outsmart the little devils are unsuccessful, Mr. Widmark's assessment sounds very fair.It could be argued that "The Swarm" is the surprise comedy hit of the season, what with Katharine Ross as a doctor, Mr. Allen's cutting to something noisy every time he doesn't know how to end a scene and exchanges like this one, as an attempt to poison the pests goes kerflooey:Entomologist Caine: "They're not touching the pellets. They seem to sense it's something that will kill them."Rival scientist Richard Chamberlain (worriedly): "They're brighter than I thought."Distinguished senior scientist Henry Fonda (knowingly): "They always are."There ought to be a word for what actors do in movies like this one; in fact, there probably is. In any case, players like Mr. Fonda and Mr. Caine manage to cooperate with the material without seeming compromised by it. Mr. Caine can apparently do anything, except give a bad performance.There are no black principals in the large, all-star cast. There are frequent references to "the war against the Africans," by which the characters, of course, mean their battle with the bees. Nevertheless, it's a very unfortunate bit of phrasing."The Swarm" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") for no discernible reason. The film contains no harsh language, very little romance, and only the mildest and phoniest-looking kind of violence.

title: A Rare Bar Mitzvah in Khartoum
description: By good luck, while walking in Khartoum one morning in March of last year. I stumbled upon a bar mitzvah in progress in the humpy old synagogue next to the Egyptian Cultural Institute on Palace Avenue. This was the first such ceremony in the Sudan in five yearsthe tallith was mousechewed  because there were only two Jewish families left in town and they hadn't had the necessary quorum of 10 men for public worship. They'd had no rabbi either, but now a man of some learning, an insurance lawyer, Maurice Aelioe, had arrived, a refugee from Ethiopia's civil war in Eritrea. He had seemed appropriate; and several English tourists whom the family took a liking to bad wandered into town, which solved the problem of the quorum. Maybe because of the delay, nobody seemed to have tears in his eyes, except the Englishman and me.

title: I.B.M. Profit Climbs 5% In Quarter
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday a 5 percent increase in profits for the second quarter this year, which was the same increase it had in the first quarter. Revenues were un 11.4 percent.

title: Consolidated Papers Net At $11.1 Million
description: Earnings of Consolidated Papers Inc. in the second quarter totaled $11.1 million, or $2.13 a share, almost double the $5.7 million, or $1.10 a share, earned in the similar three months last year.

title: Town in West Virginia Asking U.S. for Loan
description: VIENNA, W. Va., July 14 (AP)  As a protest against a Federal proposal to guarantee $1.65 billion in loans io New York City, this small Ohio River community is asking the Government to guarantee a =0,000 loan to repair city Dark.

title: Aide to Califano Reported Slated To Head Social Security Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  Hale Champion, who has been the right arm of Secretary Joseph A. Califano Jr. in running the huge Department of Health, Education and Welfare, will soon be named Commissioner of Social Security, Administration sources say.

title: Industries Raise June Output 0.3%
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  The nation's industries increased their output by 0.3 percent in June, the weakest performance since winter storms forced factories to close, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Atlantic City Judge Orders Bans on Ku Klux Klan
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 14  A Superior Court judge ordered severe restrictions today on Ku Klux Klan activity here, including bans on the distribution of literature tending to incite violence and on assembly by two or more Klan members without a city permit.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BUT NOT FORGOTTEN The Rise of the Great Tycoons is the commentary subject of today's guided walking tour presented by the Museum of the City of New York, and the downtown area covered will range from the Customs House at Bowling Green to St. Paul's Chapel, via Trinity Church and its famous burial ground. The tab for the twohour trek is $3  it's rain or shine, and no advance reservations the group meets at 2:30 P.M. at the south end of City Hall Park, Broadway and Park Row. The nearest subway stop, on all lines, is Fulton Street.

title: CLYDE C. RANDOLPH
description: Clyde C. Randolph, who retired in 1958 as a vice president for manufacturing of Western Electric, died Thursday at his home in LauderdalebytheSea, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Business a Bonanza In Whodunit Fiction
description: WARREN, N.H.  As if bankers did not have enough to worry about with the prime rate soaring, the turmoil in Zaire jeopardizing international credits there and sour realestate loans from notsomany years ago still haunting them.
