description: In percent

title: THREE RAIL UNIONS REACH PAY ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Three big operating unions have reached a tentative agreement with the nation's railroads on a settlement that could raise wages by 35 percent over 39 months.

title: U.S.CHINA EXCHANGE IN SCIENCE IS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  The President's science adviser, just back from China, held out the prospect today of broad scientific and technical cooperation between the United States and China as a prelude to greatly expanded commerce between the two nations.

title: A County in Virginia Is Symbolic Of Turn to Black Rule in South
description: SURRY Va.  Walter N. Hardy remembers how he registered to vote by flashlight, writing on the hood of his car in front of the home of a white registrar.

title: Trucking Diminishes in Alpine as Police Study Ban
description: ALPINE, July 19  Heavy trucking through this Bergen County borough of 1,300 residents appeared to have diminished today, but the police were awaiting further guidance before enforcing state, county and local travel restrictions that went into effect yesterday against the big longhaul, 18wheelers.

title: Basque Disorders Point Up Spain's Biggest LongTerm Political Problem
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 14 The five days of disorders that shook northeastern Spain this week have singled out the Basque region as the biggest longterm political problem facing the centerright democratic Government that has emerged in the aftermath of the Franco dictatorship.

title: West Gets Warning On Growth
description: BONN, July 14  President Carter and other Western leaders are being warned by the Organization. for Economic Cooperation and Development that they face slower economic growth and higher unemployment next year unless they urgently agree on new steps to get their economies moving fastr.

title: Albany Leaders Draw Tough Bill On Youth Crime
description: ALBANY, July 14  Democratic and Republican negotiators agreed in principle today on adult trials for defendants as young as 13 years old charged with the mostserious crimes, with prison sentences of seven years to life for murder. By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Traditionally, in political campaigns, political reporters and analysts tend to advance a major theme for each campaign and write their articles around that theme. The Krupsak candidacy is no exception. Understandably. considering the nature of her announcement, the theme advanced by political reporters, including your own Frank Lynn. has centered on Mary Ann's being with the Governor one day and against him only a few days later. The questions most often asked by the press concern this apparent turnabout.

title: I.C.C. Aide Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  An official of the Interstate Commerce Commission has been dismissed for alleged official misconduct and has responded by accusing A. Daniel O'Neal Jr., the commission chairman, and several other officials of flagrant and clearcut violations of agency rules of conduct.

title: Brooke and Wife Agree on Property Settlement, Concluding Divorce
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 14  Senator Edward W. Brooke and his estranged wife, Remigia, were declared divorced today, ending a twoyear court battle and sparing the Senator further embarrassing disclosures in the increasingly bitter proceedings.

title: W. Steele Gilmore, Editor, at 94; Directed War Censorship Board
description: DETROIT, July 14 (AP)  W. Steele Gilmore, former editor of The Detroit News, died Wednesday in his hometown Ind. He was 94 years old.

title: Moving Bank Attracts Police
description: GAYLORD, Mich. (AP)  State police officers got a real surprise when they responded to a burglar alarm from the Gaylord State Bank  the bank was being taken away. A construction crew working on a permanent building was moving the bank's temporary quarters, but had forgotten to disconnect the alarm system.

title: Rights For Urban Bicyclists
description: New York City's army of bicyclists is growing, even as cycling conditions deteriorate and cycling becomes more difficult. With potholes in record numbers and sizes, plus traffic jams and fumes, cycling in New York is often closer to combat than pleasure.

title: Blast Victim Tied to Church Unit
description: A man injured in an explosion Wednesday in what the police believe was a bomb factory and command post of the F.A.L.N. was identified by the police yesterday as William Morales, a onetime associate of an Episcopal Church panel on Hispanic affairs.

title: Philadelphia Is Crippled by Strike Of More Than 19,000 Employees
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14  More than 19,000 municipal employees went on strike here today, crippling most govern. mental services other than firefighting and law enforcement.

title: Warrant Issued for Times Reporter in Jascalevich Case
description: HACKENSACK. N.J.. July 14  A bench warrant for the arrest of a New York Times reporter was issued today by a Superior Court judge because he had not complied with a subpoena demanding that he submit his news file on Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich to the judge presiding at the surgeon's murder trial here.

title: Eastern Quits Pact For Airline Strike Aid
description: Eastern Airlines, in a step that could weaken the ability of other carriers to endure long work stoppages, said yesterday that it was withdrawing from a 15member pact designed to help other members during strikes.

title: A Breakthrough in Namibia
description: Good sense and good diplomacy are prevailing the important southwest corner of Africa, soon to become Namibia, we hope. Good sense was shown by South Africa last April when it agreed to a Western plan for independence. Now it has been shown by Sam Nujoma and his colleagues in S.W.A.P.O., the SouthWest Africa People's Organization and guerrilla force. The good diplomacy was practiced by five Western nations  the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Canada  and by the leaders of the frontline African states who persuaded Mr. Nujoma to agree. Their joint efforts may not only lead to peaceful transition to majority rule in Namibia but also point to a way out of the Rhodesian impasse.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Polishspeaking machinist who held four persons hostage at the World Trade Center earlier this week has been indicted on kidnaping and coercion charges,the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: There was something ironic about the presentation of the Department of Energy's first award for exceptional public service to Dennis Hayes, chairman of Solar Action, the group that organized the nationwide Sun Day demonstrations on May 3. The award was presented in Washington by James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Energy. Accepting the award, Mr. Hayes said the occasion was one of the more ironic in my life. He noted that Sun Day had been organized largely in protest against the Department of Energy and a Federal budget which we felt did not devote enough emphasis to solar energy. However, said Mr. Hayes, Mr. Schlesinger's department not only joined the Sun Day program but has demonstrated growing support for solar energy. This, Mr. Schlesinger said in presenting the plaque to Mr. Hayes, may not be a symbol of love at first sight, but it may be the basis of a growing relationship.

title: Santa Fe to Present Act III of Berg's Lulu
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 14 (UPI) The Santa Fe Opera will give the American premiere of the controversial third act of Alban Berg's Lulu next summer. The world premiere of the entire work will take place at the Paris Opera next February, with Pierre Boulez conducting.

title: Senate Republicans in Albany Offer A Proposal to Reduce Cigarette Tax
description: ALBANY, July 14  After recently killing Governor Carey's plan to try to stem the flow of smuggledin cigarettes by cutting back on the tax, Republicans in the State Senate today floated a taxcut proposal of their own that would hold the tobacco industry responsible for any financial losses the state suffered from reduction in taxes.

title: Gerald Freedman Directs Twelfth Night in Connecticut
description: STRATFORD, Conn., July 14  After missing a season for lack of funds, the American Shakespeare Festival has come back to life with a production of Twelfth Night that is, I am sorry to say, more anxious to please than pleasing.

title: Berlin Opera Ballet Presents Two New York Premieres on Program
description: The Berlin Opera Ballet presented mixed bill of five ballets, including two local premieres, Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Oddly, collective copulation seemed to be a thematic keynote in most of them.

title: Oliver Messel
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 14 (Reuters)  Oliver Messel, a wellknown British theatrical designer, died at his home here yesterday, a family spokesman said. He was 74 years old.

title: United Press International
description: UPS AND DOWNS: Rookies and tree agents at the Philadelphia Eagles camp practice on obstacle course. Veterans reported to Eagles camp yesterday.

title: In Defense Of the Counselors
description: Here are all the distressed letters from lawyers. Most of them are hurt rather than angry. A few days ago, in this space, I published the Guiding Principles for the Conduct of Life and naturally included a precept which, one would suppose, even children follow intuitively. Avoid lawyers, advised, under almost all circumstances.

title: U.S. Bars Role in Killing in Dallas
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell announced today that the Justice Department would not prosecute a Dallas policeman who has already been convicted on state charges in the death by shooting of a young MexicanAmerican five years ago.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 14 Cindy Ferro of the Forest Hill Field Club retained her Elizabeth Goss roundrobin golf title yesterday when she picked up a maximum of 9 points against three opponents at the Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: Betsy Prahl Is Wed To Dr.R.J.Mulcare
description: Rena Elizabeth Wadt Prahl of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert John Mulcare, a New York vascular surgeon. The ceremony in the chapel of the St. James Episcopal Church was performed by Canon William Chase, assisted by the Rev. Carol Anderson.

title: Sports Today
description: National Hot Rod Association's Spring Nationals, at Columbus, Ohio. Professional Skateboard Association world speed championships, at Akron. Ohio, will also be included as a segment of this show.

title: OFFER BY PRESLEY TO F.B.I. REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)  An internal memorandum of the Federal Bureau of Investigation stows that Elvis Presley, who died last August, once volunteered his services as an informer, it was reported today.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: TRANQUIL ON THE OUTSIDE, the interior of Princeton's historic Alexander Hall is humming with the sound of renovation. As work crews tackle renewal and install better facilities for the handicapped, the preservation the exterior of the American Georgian building, designed by John McComb and completed in 1817, is assured.

title: William Leonard Named to Head CBS's News Division Next Year
description: William A. Leonard, who spent 30 years with CBS News in varied capacities after starting as a street reporter for WCBS. the New York radio station, yesterday was named to succeed Richard S. Salant as president of the network's news division when Mr. Salant reaches the mandatory retirement age of 65 dext April.

title: Watson and Oosterhuis Tied for Lead
description: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND, July 14  Torn Watson, the defending champion, and Peter Oosterhuis, who has not won a tournament in four years, shared the thirdround lead at 211 today in the 107th British Open golf championship.

title: About New York
description: Lunch hour, summer of 78, City Hall Park: A year ago you could be fairly sure at this hour that there was Mayor at his desk across the way, nibbling a tunafish sandwich. But the new Mayor is more adventurous and roams up to Chinatown, crosscutting through the great swirl of midday hunger that is worth an anthropologist's giving up lunch hour to watch.

title: New Haven Commuters Say Things Aren't Always So Bad
description: When a transformer at Pelham failed yesterday morning, 13,000 commuters sat in stalled trains, reading their papers, finishing the crossword puzzles and turning. One of them, Darrell Ball, was thinking about Los Angeles.

description: MOSCOW, July 14  Following is a transcript of Anatoly B. Shcharansky's closing words before sentencing today in a Moscow court, as drawn from notes taken by his brother, Leonid:

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times yesterday, written by The Associated Press, gave the wrong surname for the late daughter of the utopian writer Edward Bellamy. She was Marion Bellamy Earnshaw, who died Wednesday in Springfield, Mass., at the age of 92.

description: MOSCOW, July 14 (Reuters)  The official press agency Tass announced yesterday that Vladimir P. Khatuntsev had taken over as the agency's general director.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14The Palestine Liberation Organization sought today to compel radical, Iraqiinfluenced guerrilla groups to cooperate with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon.

description: CINCINNATI, July 14  Having come full cycle in their strange 17year history by beating Tom Seaver, the New York Mets turned to less cosmic matters tonight and dropped a 63 decision to the Cincinnati Reds.

Jascalevich to the judge presiding at the surgeon's murder trial here.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, July 14  After two ballots today, the Lutheran Church in America narrowed its presidential candidates to. three. The winner is expected to be chosen tomorrow morning.

description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  The Senate voted today to impose a limit on toppaid White House aides but backed 150 percent rise in President Carter's travel allowance and refused to cut his unlimited entertainment budget..

description: OTTAWA, July 14  Some 2,500 Eskimos of Canada's Western Arctic are due to acquire ownership of 37,000 square miles of land under an agreement announced jointly today by the Canadian Government and an Eskimo organization.

description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Paul R. Connolly, a partner in the prestigious Washington Law firm of Williams and Connolly, died of a heart attack here today at the age of 56.

title: A Law of Inversion: The Leveling of American Society
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.Doughboys in 1918 had a much higher opinion of their officers than did G.I.'s a quarter of a century later. The officers had not changed. For instance, Douglas MacArthur, a general in both world wars, was just as arrogant, just as fearless, just as conceited, and just as brilliant on VJ Day as on Armistice Day.

title: In a New England Town, a Taste of East Africa
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass The town is quintessential New Eng, land: ancient trees spreading leafy shade, a little stone church, white clapboard houses, historical markers studding the lush green landscape.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dualpurpose in vestment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage differences (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: Ford Raising Fiesta Price
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 14 (AP) The Ford Motor Company said today it was raising the suggested retail price of its West Germanbuilt Fiesta subcompact car by 4.6 percent, to $4,141 from $3,958. The new prices, which take effect Monday, represent the third increase of the model year. The car was introduced at the start of the model year at $3,680 for the strippeddown version. The new price is 12.5 percent above that.

title: Trucking Diminishes In Jersey Community As Police Study Ban
description: ALPINE, N.J., July 14  Heavy trucking through this Bergen County borough of 1,300 residents appeared to have diminished today, but the police were awaiting further guidance before enforcing state, county and local travel restrictions that went into effect yesterday against the big long haul, 18wheelers.

title: CAMBODIAN OFFICIAL ARRIVES IN THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 Deputy Prime Minister Ieng Sary of Cambodia arrived here today for a longawaited and muchdelayed visit, which was finally brought about through Chinese mediation.

title: 2 VOTES IN BRITAIN SHOW PARTIES CLOSE
description: LONDON, July 14  A pair of Parliamentary byelections yesterday gave no comfort to any of the party leaders, Labor, Conservative or Liberal. The chief message seemed to be that the coming general election will be extremely close.

title: Leaders Across the U.S. Denounce Sentencing of Dissidents by Soviet
description: Political and civic leaders, Jewish groups and labor leaders across the nation yesterday denounced the sentencing of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish dissident, to 13 years of imprisonment and hard labor. New York University, the largest private university in the United STAIRS, canceled all its exchange programs with the Soviet Union in reaction to the convictions of Mr. Shcharansky and other dissidents in closed courtrooms there.

title: 2 Sides Are Far Apart In Postal Contract Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) A Fede ral mediator says contract talks between the United States Postal Service and nego tiators for 554,000 postal workers are ve ry far apart on everything. The contract will expire at midnight Thursday.

title: Patents
description: Olin B. King, president of S.C.I. Systems Inc., Huntsville, Ala., was granted patent 4,100,551 this week for the electronic printer. It sets down letters, figures and pictures transferred to it from cathode ray terminals or teleprinters, and is small enough to be used in aircraft and police and fire emergency vehicles.

title: Henry Ford 2d
description: Never complain, never explain, Henry, Ford 2d says. Because his name is Ford, he usually doesn't have to.

title: ExHousing Chairman Of Lodi Pleads Guilty To Kickbacks Charge
description: NEWARK, July 14 (AP)  A former chairman of the Lodi Housing Authority pleaded guilty today to charges that he had participated in a scheme to accept kickbacks from contractors who wanted to do business with the municipal agency.

title: A Fair Deal for Drivers
description: In New Jersey, as in some other states, many drivers are paying very high automobile insurance rates for inferior service, not because they are poor drivers but because their age group or place of residence has a statistically higher rate of accidents. New Jersey's insurance commissioner says three out of four of the million drivers now assigned to a risk pool have good driving records.

title: Martha Wiseman in Piano Dance
description: Martha Wiseman appeared to have tempestuous love affair with a piano at her Wednesday night program of dances in Columbia University's Earl Hall Auditorium. There, in one corner, stood this upright piano and there on the piano bench sat Miss Wiseman looking dreamy at the beginning of Piano Pieces. When she moved away, she moved in tense kicks and turns. But always she returned to that piano.

title: Social Worker Recalls 6 Suspects in Park Clubbings
description: The six young men arrested on charges of clubbing six men in Central Park last week had participated in a voluntary neighborhood counseling program designed to help high risk adolescents. but withdrew, separately, from the program a year ago, the program's director said yesterday.

title: Miss Postlewait Tied For Golf Lead at 68
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 (AP) Kathy Postlewait birdied three of the last four holes to match Janet Anderson's fourunderpar 68 andtie for the openinground lead today in an $85,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Jackson's Double, Nettles's Single Win Struggle
description: George Steinbrenner's S.O.S. (Save Our Season) lineup didn't last long. One day after the Yankee owner said Gary Thomasson would play the outfield regularly and Manager Billy Martin said Reggie Jackson would not play designated hitter against some kghanded pitchers, Jackson was in the lineup against Ken Kravec, Chicago's lefthanded pitcher, and Thomasson was not.

title: Carter, Greeted in Bonn, Reaffirms Pledge by Kennedy to Defend Ally
description: BONN, July 14  Recalling a line used by John F. Kennedy 15 years ago, President Carter drew a burst of applause from several thousand Germans in the town square here today when he pledged to defend your land as if it were our own.retaliation for the Shcharansky conviction. Instead, Mr. Carter stressed that his Administration would continue to seek cooperation with the Soviet Union in spite of this adverse circumstance.

title: Body Recovered From Hotel
description: VICTORIA, Tex., July 14 (AP) Workers recovered the final body yesterday from the wreckage of the Denver Hotel, which collapsed Tuesday on four demolition employees who were trying to bring the building down in pieces. The fourth body brought out was that of Adelaido Zuniga Deleon, 28 years old, of Nuevo Laredo, Mexico.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Columbus Busing Order
description: CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP)  A Federal appeals court today ordered Columbus public school officials to proceed with a courtimposed desegregation plan.

title: Fed Revises M1 Increase
description: The Federal Reserve Board revised downward yesterday the figures it released on Thursday that showed that the nation's money supply had bulged in the week ended July 5 by record amounts. The board said that the reports of memberbank deposits it had used were incorrect.

title: Jersey Court Bars a Pension Plan For Teachers Local Board Set Up
description: TRENTON, July 14 (UPI)  The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled yesterday that school boards had no power to establish their own pension plans for teachers.

title: Bridge:
description: The laws of the rubberbridge game do not always correspond completely with the duplicate code, which was revised three years ago. This is partly because the rubberbridge player cannot turn to a director for guidance. There is a subtle difference, for example, between the two laws relating to an insufficient bid.

title: Lido Anthony Iacocca
description: He sat on the rostrum next to the boss on a September day nine years ago, trying to keep his face frozen. But occasionally the grin slipped out. The boss, Henry Ford 2d, was telling the world that he had dsismissed Semon (Bunkie) Knudsen, the company president. Now there was a clear track to the presidency. Fifteen months later, Lido Anthony Iacocca, Lee to everyone, with his fancy suits and big cigars  and brilliant grasp of the automobile business  was president of Ford. The only question was how long, for all his brilliance and Machiavellian instincts, he could last.

title: New Era in Reproduction Seen In British Laboratory's Embryo
description: The first authenticated birth of a baby whose embryo derived from fertilization and culturing in a laboratory, expected soon in Britain, will open the way for a new era in the control of human reproduction.

title: Ambushing Civil Service Reform
description: President Carter's admirable attempt to reform the Civil Service was chugging along nicely in Congress until some House members plotted an ambush. If they can be outrun next week, the new measure promises some intelligent new approaches to management Government.

title: President and Chancellor: Shaky Link, Under Repair
description: BONN, July 14  Early this year, when relations between President Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt were in one of their periodic difficult passages, the Chancellor was reported to have complained: He does not even turn the music down when you call, and with all the violins and trumpets going you cannot understand a Minn.

title: Australian Sailor Wins
description: SANDHAMN, Sweden, July 14 (AP)  Frank Tolhurst of Australia, in Arunga III, won the 5.5Meter yacht Gold Cup sailing title after defeating Albert Fay or the United States, in Wildfire, in the fifth and final race yesterday.

title: Poorer Lands Assail West's Trade Stand
description: GENEVA, July 14  Developing countries fired a broadside today at the industrialized nations forha reached a framework of tm ing for a final accord on trade withcmt having consulted them.

title: KOCH IS TO APPROVE HOSTOS RENOVATION
description: Mayor Koch has decided to approve a $3.3 million renovation program for Hostos Community College in the South Bronx. according to city officials involved with the City University's master Plan.

title: PBS to Do 4 Operas Live From the Met
description: Live performances of four operas Verdi's Otello and Luisa Miller, Smetana's The Bartered Bride and Puccini's Tosca  will be televised from the Metropolitan Opera House next fall by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Dances by a Pair of Loft Veterans
description: Dance created through the collaborative efforts of choreographers and cornposers was once a fashionable experimental art form. Its popularity has not waned entirely. On Thursday at the Theater for the City of New York, Rrata Christine Jones and Roberta EscamillaGarrison, two veterans of the loftdance scene, had a go at it. The results left one in awe of the strength and persistence of delusion. With a little more energy and purposefulness the evening might at least have verged on the pretentious, but this was dance that could most charitably be called inept.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times yesterday, written by The Associated Press, gave the wrong surname for the late daughter ot the utopian writer Edward Bela. my. She was Marion Bellamy Earnshaw, who died Wednesday in Springfield, Mass., at the age of 92.

title: News Summary
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky was sentenced by a Moscow court to 13 years in prism and labor camps for treason, espionage and antiSoviet agitation. He was accused of having given secrets to the Central Intelligence Agency, a charge that he denied as absurd and that President Carter also told Soviet leaders was false. [Page 1,Column 6.)

title: China Tightens Vietnam Border
description: TOKYO, July 14 (AP)  China has tightened controls on the entry of ethnic Chinese from neighboring Vietnam, accusing the Vietnamese of taking advantage of the situation to send spies and other bad elements.

title: New Haven Commuters Say Things Aren't Always So Bad
description: I've never seen anything like this on the freeways, said Mr. Ball, who moved to Stamford from the West Coast six weeks ago, as he hurried through Grand Central Terminal three hours late. There, you can always take another route. But when you're on a train, you're locked into a box.

title: New Era in Reproduction Seen In British Laboratory's Embryo
description: The first authenticated birth of a baby whose embryo derived from fertilization and culturing in a laboratory, expected soon in Britain, will open the way for a new era in the control of human reproduction.

title: OffDuty Police Officers Step Up City Hall Protests
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, whose delegate assembly has twice rejected tentative contracts with New York City, announced yesterday that, starting Monday, the police would crack down on minor traffic violations that might ordinarily be ignored.

title: Beaths
description: BERLLYRose. Beloved wife of Paul. Devoted mother of. Bonnie, Howard and Carol. Loving sister of Marcia Kleinman. Adored grandmother of Iris. Cherished friend of many. Services were held Friday at Gutterman's", ROckvilleCentre,L.I.

title: Carter, Greeted in Bonn, Reaffirms Pledge by Kennedy to Defend Ally
description: BONN, July 14  Recalling a line used by John F. Kennedy 15 years ago, President Carter drew a burst of applause from several thousand Germans in the town square here today when he pledged to defend your land as if it were our own.

title: Letter: On Delivering Electricity
description: To the Editor: The Times's editorial of July 8, Wasting Energy on Con Edison, takes exception to my call for a cityfunded, professional feasibility study to determine alternatives to the current system of delivery of electricity for New Yorkers by Con Edison. Although your editorial makes some good points, I believe that the conclusion you reach is to some extent misdirected.

title: Safeway Reports Sharp Climb In Profits For Second Quarter
description: The company said at its Oakland, Calif., headquarters that net income for the 12 weeks to June 17 amounted to $41.3 million, equal to $1.58 a share, a jump of 35.8 percent from $30.4 million, or $1.17 a share, for the like period a year ago.

title: THREE RAIL UNIONS REACH PAY ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Three big operating unions have reached a tentative agreement with the nation's railroads on a settlement that could raise wages by 35 percent over 39 months.

title: FRED G. GILLIKIN
description: MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., June 14 (AP)  Fred G. Gillikin, who led the Coast Guard's first rescue operation, died yesterday. He was 100 years old.

title: New Soviet Coupon for Carter
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (AP)  For the second time Komsomolskaya Pravda, the youth newspaper, printed a coupon to be mailed by readers to President Carter calling on him to take concrete actions in your own country to uphold human rights. It said it was repeating the coupon, which includes a drawing of New York, the Statue of Liberty, a large magnifying glass held up to a barred prison window and the caption Freedom to the freedom fighters!!!, in response to numerous reader requests.

title: Rules for U.S. Funds To Pay for Abortions Tightened by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, issued regulations today tightening the rules under which Federal funds may be used to pay for abortions.

title: The Gershwin of the Livery Stable
description: Franz Schubert, who wrote Symphony in C Major, never heard the masterpiece played and he died broke. Paul Vance is responsible for such musical landmarks as Catch a Falling Star, Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weenie, Yellow PolkaDot Bikini, Calcutta, Leader of the Laundromat, Run, Joey. Run, Playground In My Mind, Hot Pants, Without Your Love, Mr. Jordam and 992 others, and he can't stop making money. While I sleep, I make money, he says. I go on a picnic and make money.

title: Next Year in Jerusalem
description: In March and April, during interrogation, the chief investigators warned me that in the position I have taken during investigation, and held to here in court, I would be threatened with execution by firing squad, or at least 15 years. If I would agree to cooperate with the investigation for the purpose of destroying the Jewish emigration movement, they promised me early freedom and a quick reunion with my wife.

title: Dollar Drops Slightly On Eve of Bonn Meeting
description: The dollar closed slightly lower against most leading world currencies in late New York trading yesterday, after gaining a bit in earlier European trading, while awaiting a weekend economic summit conference in Bonn.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, July 14,1026

title: The New York Times/ Mary Ann Hardiman
description: EASY READING: A young woman removed her shoes and made herself comfortable as she read a book on a bench yesterday in Central Park.

title: Resignation Announced by Iacocca Amid New Signs of Discord at Ford
description: DETROIT, July 14  Lee A. Iacocca announced his resignation today, as expected, as president of the Ford Motor Company amid new disclosures of discord on the board of directors.Ford Motor Some members of the board said the had approved the resignation only after Henry Ford 2d, the company's chairman, said he could no longer tolerate Mr. Iacocca's presence.

title: Albany Leaders Draw Tough Bill On Youth Crime
description: ALBANY. July 14  Democratic and Republican negotiators agreed in principle today on adult trials for defendants as young as 13 years old charged with the mostserious crimes, with prison sentences of seven years to life for murder.

title: Tor Colored Girls Closes Tomorrow
description: After 876 performances, the Joseph PappNew York Shakespeare Festival production of Ntozake Shange's For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf will close tomorrow.

title: Vermont Legion Disease Cases
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 14 (UPI) The Medical Center Hospital of Vermont announced today that it had found four confirmed or highly suspect cases of Legionnaires disease in the last month. All four patients have survived, and spokesman said two had been discharged. Last year 17 people in Vermont died of the disease.

title: A Mix of Styles In New York's Neighborhoods
description: They're offbeat, individual, antiestablishment. Or they're romantic creative and ambitious. They're also young, graceful and confident; or old, indefatigable and proud. The images may not be precisely what an advertising man had in mind, but they're all part of New York.

title: Associated Prus
description: DISTRESS SIGNAL: As a symbol of the plight of the American Indian, the United States flag was flown third and upside down on staff at Indian encampment yesterday in Marriottsville, Md. The group's crosscountry protest march will culminate today in Washington.

title: Associated Press
description: FAREWELL FOR NOW: Pat Satterlee, a 27yearold commercial fisherman, embraces his grandmother before sailing from San Diego on an 8,000mile trip to Australia. His vessel is a 35foot rowboat.

title: Kodak Seeks Berkey Retrial
description: Lawyers for the Eastman Kodak Company have moved for a retrial of the civil antitrust suit won by Berkey Photo Inc. on the ground that jury findings that led to the damage award totaling nearly $81.4 million were contrary to the weight of the evidence.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Unaudited net asset values of publicly traded investment shares, formerlytheftied as Closed End Funds, as of Friday. Also shown is losing listed market price of each fund's shares, with the percentage difference between the net asset value and the stock price.

title: Israel Paying for Tour By Mrs. Shcharansky
description: The current European tour of Mrs. Anatoly Shcharansky to publicize the plight of her husband, the Jewish activist sentenced yesterday to 13 years confinement, was orchestrated and paid for by the Israeli Government, CBS News reported last night from Paris.

title: Cleveland Police Accept Order to End Strike
description: CLEVELAND, July 14  After a oneday strike, Cleveland's 1,500 policemen agreed today to go back to work when court order directed arbitration of their grievances.

title: Mrs. Carter and Amy Visit Beethoven House
description: BONN, July 14 (Reuters)  While President Carter discussed affairs of state today, Rosalynn Carter and their 10yearold daughter Amy visited the birthplace of Ludwig van Beethoven. They listened to Beethoven piano variations played by a music teacher from Cologne.

title: City Will Try To Show U.S. It's Jes Folks
description: Are New Yorkers too sophisticated to be likable?

title: Tin Council Raises Prices
description: LONDON, July 14 (Reuters)  The International Tin Council today raised the metal's support prices despite opposition from the United States, but at the same time it was agreed to keep the new levels frozen for a year, delegates said.

title: Rangers and Jenkins Beat Red Sox, 43
description: BOSTON, July 14 (AP)  Bobby Bonds singled in two runs in the sixth inning to lead the Texas Rangers, behind the pitching of Ferguson Jenkins, o a 43 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title: Gender and Power: Capital Women Tell How They've Fared
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Because this city deals only in one commodity  power  it has been until very recently a man's town., Now this is changing gradually, and women in power are finding that their gender does not dilute their authority significantly although it does make a difference.

title: New Effort Scheduled To Restabilize Skylab
description: HOUSTON, July 14 (UPI)  Scientists trying to save Skylab from an uncontrolled crash through the atmosphere are going to try again next week to restabilize the 84ton space station.

title: Two Brothers Take Over Argus in Canada After Aggressive Bid
description: MONTREAL, July 14  One of Cana da's biggest corporate prizes, the Argus Corporation, which controls about $2 billion worth of assets, has been taken over by two brothers still in their 30's after some of the most aggressive tactics seen in Toronto boardrooms in years.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: United Airlines chose the Boeing 767 over a scaleddown version of the European Airbus produced by a fournation consortium. The $1.2 billion, 30plane order was the largest dollar amount ever placed for a single airliner or even a package of planes. United also ordered 30727's, bringing the total Boeing sale to $1.6 billion. [Page 1]. industrial production increased only 0.3 percent in June, the least since last winter, according to the Federal Reserve. This is one more sign that economic growth is slowing down, although a Commerce Department economist said, it might take several more months to assess the economy's performance. [23.)

title: Your Money
description: FIGURING out what pension or profitsharing benefits are yours to keep and what can be done with that money when you change employers can be a mind.boggling task  a challenge fit for a gaggle of lawyers.

title: Enlarged Gambling Casino Opens
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 14 (AP)  Resorts International Hotel Casino today opened a greatly expanded casino with more slot machines and more gaming tables. The crowds ran in and filled it to capacity in two minutes.

title: Resignation Announced by Iacocca Amid New Signs of Discord at Ford
description: DETROIT, July 19  Lee A. Iacocca announced his resignation today, as expected, as president of the Ford Motor Company amid new disclosures of discord on the board of directors.

title: Florida Pro Wins11th Straight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 19  Florida Pro stormed through the stretch to win the $106,500 Beacon Course onemile trot at the Meadowlands before 20,500 fans tonight.

title: Old Africa Hand
description: TO the world at large John Stockwell was an unknown figure until the dramatic publication of In Search of Enemies. Within the Central Intelligence Agency, however, where he worked as a covert officer for 12 years, he was fairly well known. Except for a tour in Vietnam, which ended with the end of the war, he had spent most of his career in his birthplace  Africa. He tells us that he personally knew nearly all 900 members of the C.I.A.s Africa division.

title: Voters at Sea
description: GROTON ELECTION Day will come early this year for Connecticut men who go on 90day patrols in August or early 4eptember aboard the Navy's nuclear submarines.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDEN phlox are reaching their climax, now that the tall, summerblooming varieties of the perennial Phlox paniculata are opening their flowers.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSETT  Naivestyle oils by Ann Stanwell; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, except Wednesdays; through July 79; Gallery East, Main St. Reception today 3 to 6 P.M.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The oldtimer was sitting on the porch talking to the boy when Earl came home from work. Earl was tired of the oldtimer with his stories about all he had seen in the old days. Earl had heard them all hundreds of times.

title: Brooklyn School on Probation
description: Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn is the city's first public school put on probation by state regents and may lose the right to give diplomas. Page 35.

title: Franco Brusati Aims His Lens at Solitude
description: ROME Franco Brusati is something of a paradox. The Italian playwrightdirector's latest film, Bread and Chocolate, opened Friday in New York and created a critical controversy. Although Vincent Canby of The Times scored the bittersweet comedy, other reviewers found much in it to praise. Meanwhile, Mr. Brusati has a longrunning play in Paris, he has just finished a stint as a member of the Cannes Film Festival jury and by and large his five earlier films were well received by critics throughout the world and did well at the box office. Indeed, Bread and Chocolate was a solid success in Italy, continues to be a smash hit in France and won a Silver Bear award at the Berlin Film Festival. Yet, despite all these acknowledgements of success, Mr. Brusati has not made a film in four years. Why? The theme of Bread and Chocolate provides a clue to an explanation.

title: Federal Agency Releases Tire Quality Standards
description: DETROIT, July 14  The Federal Government today released its first set of uniform standards for measuring the quality of tires beyond existing tire safety standards. The prevailing school of thought is that the new guidelines will confuse consumers. however.

title: Late Bloomer Wins Sheepshead by Head
description: Late Bloomer almost blossomed too late yesterday. The Greentree filly got up in the final strides on Belmont's turf, stuck her head in front of the French import, Waya, and carried off first prize of $68,800 in the Sheepshead Bay Handicap.

title: FLOYD H. CROWDER
description: Floyd H. Crowder, a former vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Thursday in a medical center in Tampa, Fla. He was 58 years old and lived in Tampa.

title: Young Travelers: Shared Fellowship
description: They are an international community. Thousands of hostelries have been built for them and they subsidize thousands more. They help keep railroads in the black throughout the world and bus companies are organized for their benefit. Beyond the material realm, however, they form a society, for shared needs give rise to shared customs and traditions.

title: Women and Minorities Make Up Less Than 6% of F.B.I. Agents
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Women and members of minority groups make up less than 6 percent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's agents, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: Where a Disability Need Not Be a Handicap
description: FISHKILL, N.Y.  There is a long, winding road in this rural village in Dutchess County, 70 miles from New York, that led to equality for the mentally and physically handicapped years before the current drive on their behalf.

title: Depositors Interested In Unusual Interest
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) small bank has devised a gimmick for attracting new depositors  offering $27,000 MercedesBenz instead of interest payments.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: GROWNUPS are often afraid to say the word cancer. How then do you think children feel when they hear the word? Most people think of cancer as a death sentence. It need not be. I am 10 years old and last year I had cancer.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Yankees play the Kansas City Royals at 2 P.M. today and 8 o'clock tomorrow night in Yankee Stadium. The New York Mets play the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium at 8 P.M. Wednesday and at 5:30 P.M. Thursday in a twilightnight doubleheader. The Mets play the Atlanta Braves Friday and Saturday nights at 8 o'clock and next Sunday at 2 P.M. The Jersey Indians will play at 2 P.M. today and 7:30 P.M. tomorrow and Thesday nights at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City, N.J. On Wednesday, Thursday and Friday nights, the Indians will play at 7:30.

title: Singers Who March To Their Own Drum
description: DURING dinner at the Coach House in Wainscott, music from the Sandy Rapp Combo starts out with such a gentle, ethereal lilt that it barely intrudes on one's consciousness. Yet five songs into the set  as a harmonious version of Make the World Go Away emanates from the bandstand  a handful of can'twait couples are already dancing, and scattered but increasingly insistent applause greets the end of each tune.

title: Victoria: Pacific Port
description: England is the mother of Canada's western cities, and none ha's retained as much of the mother country's character as Victoria, capital of British Columbia. It retains ivycovered Tudor buildings, doubledecker buses and Englishstyle gardens.

title: Inventing a Plot For Sgt. Pepper
description: How do you write a motion picture entitled Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band? That was the problem I had to solve when producer Robert Stigwood asked me to do just that at our first meeting 27 months ago. The result will come before the critics this Friday.

title: ECUADOREANS VOTING FOR PRESIDENT TODAY
description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 15  The plans of the military to withdraw from power after six years of rule here enter a critical phase tomorrow as Ecuadoreans vote in their first presidential election in 10 vents.

title: Aden Opens Battle Site Of Coup for Reporters
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, July 15 (Reuters)The present South Yemeni rulers successfully cut off the late President Salem Robaye Ali with a few hundred supporters in a battle at Fort Torshnyne, to judge by a tour of the area where Mr. Robaye All was seized.

title: Simon: Preaching the Word for Olin
description: One of the most vigorous defenders of the existing economic system is the John M. Olin Foundation, established and funded by the 85yearold former chairman of the $1 billion Olin Corporation. For the last few years the foundation has concentrated on support of scholarship in the philosophy of a free society and the economics of the free market, as the executive director, Frank O'Connell, puts it. That means, among other things, grants to such institutions as A.E.I. and the Hoover Institution, support for the Friedman and Wattenberg television programs, and funding of centers for the study of free enterprise. In all, the foundation and Mr. Olin personally give some $3 million a year to such projects.

title: Design
description: When in 1970, Georges Pompidou, President of the Republic of France, came to visit Richard Nixon, President of the United States, he gave him, in the name of France, a present: a painting by Sonia Delaunay. It was a connoisseur's graceful homage to one of the artists who has strongly marked the physiognomy of our time.

title: Sergeant, Snarled in Chute Line, Hangs Under Plane for 5 Minutes
description: POPE AIR FORCE BASE, N.C., July 15 (UPI)  A soldier making a routine jump from a C130 plane became snarled in his static line and hung under the plane 1,000 feet above earth for about five minutes until the crew could haul him in, base officials said yesterday.

title: Real Work Starts for Two Tchaikovsky Winners
description: This is where the real work begins. Elmar Oliveira said a few days ago as he and Nathaniel Rosen considered the probable impact of having won gold medals and first prizes in the recently concluded 1978 Tchaikovsky Competitions in Moscow. Mr. Oliveira knew vinereor ne spoxe. loaay, he is playing Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in the Clarence Summer Concerts in Buffalo, and Mr. Rosen, is performing Tchaikovsky's Rococo Variations and Dvorak's Cello Concerto with the Pittsburgh Symphony at the Ambler Festival in Philadelphia.

title: B.J. Nevins Weds Maria V. Guernica
description: In the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N. Y., yesterday, Maria Victoria Guernica, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro Guernica of New Canaan, Conn., was married to Brooke Jonathan Nevins, son of Mr. and Mrs.

title: Crime Story Fed to Press By Police Is Found False
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 15 (AP) Delaware State Police, in an effort to crack a burglary ring, planted a false news story about a theft of valuable paintings from a retired judge's home.

title: Praise by the Served Repays His Service
description: JUST as it shouldn't be news when dog bites man, it shouldn't be news when man does job. But in this day and age,. when almost everybody has a bad word to say about repairmen, and when everybody wonders what became of such oldfashioned virtues as courtesy, helpfulness and consideration, Richard Gardner rates as news.

title: Back to school, show for goats
description: School in Bergen County, where a Roman Catholic family argued that it was the obligation of parents to instruct their children at home in sexual matters.

title: A Year Later, Johnstown Still Risks Flood Danger
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 15 (UPI)The old men of the mountains like to tell how, back in 1889, John Hess lashed down the whistle of his locomotive and raced ahead of a 75foot wall of water to warn the people that the lake is broke.

title: THE LETELIER INVESTIGATION
description: SEPTEMBER 21, 1976 Eugene M. Propper sat eating lunch in the cafeteria at the Federal courthouse in Washington, D.C., the courthouse where Judge John Sirica presided over the Watergate trials. Only 29, tall, slender and neatly bearded, Propper had worked upstairs for almost five years as an Assistant United States Attorney, but planned to leave soon for private practice, having tired of casework in burglaries and petty corruption.

title: Cynthia V. Kenna Becomes the Bride Of Oliver Mullins
description: Cynthia Vertie Kenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kenna of Woodbridge, Conn., was married yesterday to Oliver Clinton Mullins, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Mullins of Pittsburgh.

title: Events Today
description: HERB GARDEN TIME: Familiar and unfamiliar herbs season; 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Brooklyn Botanic Garden, IMO Washington Avenue.

title: Soviet Warns U.S. of Showdown
description: MOSCOW, July 15 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today coupled a bitter condemnation of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish dissident sentenced yesterday to 13 years in prison and labor camps, with a warning that President Carter's human rights campaign was opening the way to a SovietUnited States confrontation.

title: Cover: Painting by Sandy Huffaker / Picture credits, Page
description: CONTENTS. PAGE 4

title: Sen. Talmadge Accused Of Influencing a Lease
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (AP)  An associate of two brothers involved in a land deal with Senator Herman E. Talmadge has alleged that the Senator later influenced the Postal Service to rent space in an office building that the two brothers had constructed, The Atlanta JournalConstitution reported today.

title: Brown Confounds Predictions, Weathers the TaxRevolt Storm
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15  In a development with national political implications, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. appears to have landed on his political feet after the upheaval that grew out of the California taxpayers revolt.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Having grown up on the Upper West Side of New York City, where on a clear day I had a fine, square, minuscule view of the Hudson River if I stood on the toilet seat, I came to Mrs. Colby's series of love letters to the joys of living in that section of Manhattan encumbered by a certain amount of skepticism. I had heard that it is now a dangerous, dirty, hostile territory; that elderly citizens are attacked on the streets and others, in mortal fear, enclose themselves behind three locks in. grim oneroom apartments.

title: Elise E. Cox, a Travel Agent, Is the Bride of Francis Cuzzi
description: Elise Ehret Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Bingham Cox of New York and Amagansett, L. I., was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity in East Hampton, L. I., to Francis Emanuel Cuzzi.

title: Jane Fonda Does a Cameo
description: COUNT me among the Philistines. I've never been able to finish The Magic Mountain, Magister Ludi, The Plumed Serpent, Orlando or Lord Jim. Holy books they are, ripe with metaphor and the musk of civilization. They belong in the world of deep and ponderous things. But the smell of literature sickens me. What I like is fun.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 (UPI) Heavy air pollution led the authorities tc issue health warnings for sections of the Los Angeles metropolitan area today, but the level of smog dropped from the exceptionally heavy pollution of yesterday.

title: Susan C. Knight Is Married
description: In Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester, Mass., yesterday, Susan Conway Knight, daughter of Capt. Richard H. Knight, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Knight of Virginia Beach, was married to Lewis Pickering Cabot, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Moors Cabot of Washington. The Rev. Rollin J. Fairbanks performed the ceremony.

title: GARDENING
description: THE best way to get through July and August as far as plant tending goes is to mulch. There are just too many demands on anyone's time. There are the essentials to contend with  the beach, golf course, boat, picnic, tennis court, jogging, biking.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: DR. GHOLAMHOSSEIN SA'EDI is Iran's most popular writer  except with the Government, which frequently bans the books, plays and movies that flow from his pen. He has been imprisoned and tortured, and some of the scars were visible when we talked to him recently. He is here on a visit arranged by the Freedom to Read Committee of the Association of American Publishers. Speaking through an interpreter, Dr. Sa'edi, a rumpled, plumpish man of 43, says Iranian writers endure constant, maddeningly arbitrary censorship. He described as a polycentric system, whereby Governmentcreated professional and trade groups ban works whose subject matter falls under their jurisdiction when the Government tells them to. Each new printing of a book must be approved, and the Government often will see what sort of impact a book has before banning it. A popular book may suddenly be found distasteful, and copies are swept from the bookstores. The Government is particularly sensitive about poetry  especially modern poetry, which obtuse censors cannot understand and so decide must be secret code.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: UNDONE BY ONE MORE TRY: Sparky Anderson, Reds manager, arguing call on a close play, left, with umpire, Dutch Rennert, during fifth inning of game against the !Wets Friday at Cincinnati. Anderson decided he had heard enough, center, but came back, right, for one last comment. It proved to be his undoing Rennert ejected him from the game. Joe Torre, Mets manager, was also ejectedhe argued that Anderson had been given to much time to argue. The Reds won, 63.

title: Soviet Launches a Satellite
description: MOSCOW, July 15 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today launched a new Molniya satellite into orbit around the Earth to help relay television broadcasts and telephone communications to outlying areas of the country, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: A Little Bit of Censorship
description: The spectacle of the mighty Soviet Union hounding the gnats of dissidence with clubs and cannon ought remind us that there is no such thing as a little bit of repression. As they showed again in the farcical trials and brutal sentencing of Anatoly Shcharansky and Aleksandr Ginzburg, the Russians no longer shoot their dissenters but merely cart them off to Siberia. As they will demonstrate in a further farce this week, they no longer censor the dispatches of foreign reporters but merely bring them to court on charges of slander. They no longer haul ordinary folks out of bed for telling a bad joke or composing unorthodox music but merely suppress all unapproved communication and terrorize people with threats of economic deprivation and social ostracism. A tyranny can be more or less tolerant; cannot cease to be a tyranny.

title: Jobs Program for 200 Is Ordered Canceled For Alleged Nepotism
description: A $2.5 million Federal project to provide jobs for the unemployed has been ordered terminated by the New York City Department of Employment following allegations that the nonprofit sponsoring agency's executive vice president had placed his son and daughter on the project's payroll.

title: Preserving Community Life
description: VLLAGES don't want to be suburbs, suburbs don't wart to be cities, and cities don't want to be wastelands. With these words, Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts recently expressed the feeling of many communities  in Connecticut and other states  about the need to steer growth and development in a way that preserves the quality of life in each community.

title: An ExD.A. Marches On
description: HENRY F. O'BRIEN is a long way from one of the most bizarre incidents in recent political and governmental history  a charge by a Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, that Mr. O'Brien, then the District Attorney of Suffolk, was guilty of criminal homosexuality. The charge followed Mr. O'Brien's accusation of coruption against the Commissioner.

title: Seymour N. Siegel, Radio Pioneer And ExHead of WNYC Stations
description: Seymour Nathaniel Siegel. intemationally known as an educational broadcasting pioneer and longtime major domo of New York City's Municipal Broadcasting System, died yesterday morning at the Columbia Presbyterian Neurological Institute in Manhattan. A resident of Lakeville, Conn., he would have been 70 years old later this month.

title: Carol Lefkowitz and Andrew Boas to Wed Next Month
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Lefkowitz of Middlebury, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carol Lefkowitz, to Andrew Mark Boas, son of Mr., and Mrs. Robert S. Boas of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Refusal to export Alaskan oil to Japan (Anthony J. Parisi's news article, July 4) is a deadweight loss to the United States. With exports there would be substantial savings in transport cost, on sea and on land; there would also be additional production of Alaskan and Californian oil at costs less than import prices.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Inflationary pressures and expectations throughout the American economy appear to be worsening, and the Carter Administration's game plan for dealing with them is simply not working. The lack of progress in achieving a number of objectives  on taxes, energy, jobs and prices  is the cause of the spreading malaise among consumers, investors. businessmen and economists.

title: DITERVIEW
description: PRINCETON AYEAR ago, when Dr. Joan Stern Girgus, then dean of the Division of Social Science at City College in New York, was aimed dean of the college at Princeton University, the conservative Concerned Alumni of Princeton cornplained that she appears to be another academic technocrat emerging from the quintessential New York bureaucracy.

title: State Still Hopeful On Offshore Oil
description: TRENTON RSPORTS of the demise of hope for oil potential in the Baltimore Canyon may be exaggerated.

title: Nobody Expects Miracles in Bonn
description: BONN  President Carter and the political leaders of Western Europe, Canada and Japan gather here today, amid inauspicious omens, for the nations fourth annual attempt to agree on a joint strategy for ending the world recession. All the participants want the talks to succeed. Yet. in recent days these leaders have shown themselves still deeply divided over the best way to tackle the world's economic difficulties and several have been deliberately playing down their expectations for the meeting.

title: At Home: Portrait of the Moral Heroine
description: EVERYONE has a theory about her. She's rigid; she's frigid; she's compulsive. In place of personality, she has a defense mechanism. She is the world's champion coper. She's a bore, a Renaissance woman, a saint, a peach.

title: Law School Graduate Blacklisted In 50's Is Finally Admitted to Bar
description: For 25 years. Arthur Greene waited and worried. As a student, he had been involved in leftwing causes, and he had been denied admission to the bar.

title: Editor Will Marry Mary Elizabeth Jewett
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Jewett Jr. of Ross, Calif. and Woods Hole, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Jewett, to Donald 0. Graul Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Graul of Montreal.

title: Susan Fox Is Bride Of Michael P. Jarvis
description: Susan Coutant Fox, daughter of Mrs. M. Warren Smith of New York and East Hampton, L. I., and the late Alvin Gibbs Fox, was married yesterday to Michael Phillip Jarvis, son of Mrs. Roger Gordon of Mission Viejo, Calif., and Kaye Jarvis of Federal Way, Wash. The Rev. Norman Stanton, assisted by the Rev. Frederick Schultz, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton.

title: W.T. Small Jr., Elaine Luchak Plan to Marry
description: Elaine Mary Luchak, an assistant vice president in the municipal bond department at the Bankers Trust Company, and W. Thomas Small Jr., a vice president in the same department, plan to be married in September in Princeton. N. J.

title: Miss Lanctot, J.P. Humes Jr. Plan to Marry
description: Suzanne Lanctot and J. Portner Humes Jr. plan to be married July 29 in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: 7TH ARMY PERFORMS KEY ROLE IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  The Seventh Army, which President Carter visited yesterday in West Germany, is the largest United States military entity and the one closest to the forces of the potential adversary, the Soviet Union.

title: The Mackey Bill:
description: BRICKTOWN WHEN she is not busy with creative writing or original pop lyrics, or involved in some sort of project for her three sons, Barbara Mackey ponders strategy to push S49, her bill in the Legislature. If the measure becomes law, it would give the police the power to demand blood or urine tests for injured or unconscious drivers suspected of being drunk or under the influence of narcotics.

title: Brave Dees
description: For all their vaunted efficiency, most of the spies the Nazis sent to Britain during World War 11 were amateurish duffers who were quickly caught and either executed or, increasingly, enlisted as double agents under the highly successful Double Cross System.

title: Cruel and Unusual Considerations for the Court
description: WASHINGTON  Since the issue is statesanctioned murder, it is hardly surprising that the Supreme Court of the United States approaches it gingerly. For the past six years, the Justices have been grappling, unhappily and discordantly, with the most painful punishment a government can levy against citizen  the death penalty. The Justices most recent attempt seems unlikely to bring the country much closer to an answer.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN making sizable patches on a plaster wall or ceiling, or on drywall where a considerable amount of patching plaster or spackling compound must be used, the doityourselves often have trouble making a patch blend in neatly with the rest of the surface.

title: A Hymn to Concrete, That Rock of Ages
description: There are concrete houses and concrete skyscrapers. Birdbaths are frequently concrete. Sidewalks and highways are often concrete. Picasso designed some sculpture in concrete. Every year engineering students promote the versatility of concrete by designing, building and racing concrete canoes.

title: Housing: Subsidies For Facelifts
description: THIS is not cosmetics, Terry Waivada, New Rochelle's administrator of loans and grants, says of her city's neighborhood rehabilitation program. We are not trying to restore historic homes, we are trying to stabilize housing.

title: An Asian Bank Challenges West
description: HONG KONG  From a granite fortess guarded by a pair of regal bronze lions, it controls 70 percent of Hong Kong's bank deposits. It also issues Hong Kong's currency, helps determine local interest rates and owns a block of the colony's most profitable shipping, aviation, real estate and newspaper businesses.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Napoleon's preoccupation with ancient Rome and Egypt and the trappings of royalty shaped the Empire style, a decorative arts movement that now seems ripe for revival.

title: ANTIQUES
description: IN every 17thcentury New England town, the meeting housechurch was the first community house built. The second was the local ordinary tavern or inn  contrary to English practice the terms were interchangeable here  built if not next door then just a few houses away.

title: Rochelle Arkush Is Betrothed.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Wiseman of Albany have announced the engagement of her daughter, Rochelle Arkush, to Michael Kassen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Kassen of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Miss Arkush and her fianc plan to be married in September. She also is a daughter of the late Samuel Arkush.

title: From a Resort to a Town for All Seasons
description: Early on hazy summer mornings in Madison, Conn.  a town they are calling the new Greenwich  a refreshing salty breeze drifts in across the cool sand toward the freshly painted, turnofthecentury white clapboard houses hugging the shoreline.

title: Topics
description: Boar Bites Man

title: New Haven Spotlights Some Coming Attractions
description: NEW HAVEN NEW HAVEN, its leaders say, is a city whose time has come. Economic development plans either under way or in the planning stage include a $40million hotel, office and restaurant complex on the New Haven harbor called Gateway Landing; what is described as the world's first offtrack betting theater, a teletrack in which 2,000 spectators will be able to gamble while watching live television transmission of thoroughbred and harness racing; the revitalization of the landmark Taft Hotel into downtown luxury apartments; a new $57million hospital; more parking; restoration of the Shubert Theater, and a new $11million Federal office complex.

title: Tom Petty and Heartbreakers In Rock Show at the Palladium
description: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, who were at the Palladium Friday night, don't fit comfortably into any of the stylistic niches invented by rock writers in their attempts to bring order out of chaos. They are too melodic and 50'sinfluenced to be called punks, too intense and jangly to be labeled poprock, too basic in conception to fit into either the jazzrock or artrock categories. Perhaps they are new wave, although that term is vague enough to be virtually meaningless.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Jets Camp Brings NickelandDime Days
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 15 Dreams of big money danced in the heads of the 98 rookies who opened the Jets training camp the other day. But first, there was the nickel and the dime.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN making sizable patches on a plaster wall or ceiling, or on drywall where a considerable amount of patching plaster or spackling compound must be used, the doityourselves often have trouble making a patch blend in neatly with the rest of the surface.

title: Gifts Fit for a Museum
description: IN the search for an unusal trinket, it is sometimes the most unsuspecting place that yields the most fascinating treasures. Museum shops are a good source, and while those in the major museums have international reputations, those in less renowed locations are often worthwhile in an entirely different way.ne LockwoodMathews Mansion Museum, at 295 West Avenue in Norwalk, stands as a tribute to what LeGrand accomplished in 18691868, when he imported artisans from Europe to create a vast grey stone house described as a blend of French chateau, Scottish manor house and Victorian fancy. The citizens of Norwalk saved this astonishing building, with its dazzling interiors, from the wrecker's ball by referendum in 1962 and it has been in the process of gradual restoration ever since.

title: ART VIEW
description: Of all the works of modernist art produced in this century, the one that has more clearly than any other attained the status of a universal political symbol, signifying the struggle of liberty against tyranny, is Picasso's Guernica. Painted in Paris in 1937 as an immediate response to the destruction of the Basque town for which the picture is named, Guernica was at once a passionate political statement and a cry from the heart. It has ever since been regarded as a painting with a special meaning, not only in Picasso's own copious and manysided oeuvre but in the public imagination of the world beyond arta painting that is a memorial to the suffering of the Spanish people in the civil war, and a symbol of the democracy that perished under the triumph of General Franco's Fascist forces.

title: Moscow Supports Young On His Prisoner Remark
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (Reuters)  The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today described a furor in Washington over recent controversial remarks by Andrew Young, chief delegate to the United Nations, as evidence of a Ku. Klux Klan mentality.

title: Copters Scour Coast for Pollution
description: SANDY HOOK ON July 3, 1976, Gene Geer, a skin diver, plunged one of the many shipwrecks off the New Jersey coast. He had been at the site before, but this was the first time that he saw evidence of the massive pollutionspawned fish kill that was dealing a serious economic blow to the state's shell and sportsfishing industries.

title: The New York Times /John Soto
description: BIRTHDAY FOR A CARROUSEL: Seth Budick was the first to ride one of the intricately carved horses of the Central Park Carrousel yesterday as it began its 70th year as an attraction in the park.

title: Disco Discontent in Rye
description: SOME Rye residents say they are suffering from a severe case of Tuesday night fever caused by a discotheque in the clubhouse of the cityowned Rye Golf Course. The onceaweek social event has become one of Westchester's most popular night spots but, according to the residents, it is disrupting the surrounding neighborhood.

title: Peking Called Willing To Negotiate Accord With Taiwan Regime
description: HONG KONG, July 15 (AP)  A top Chinese official told an American Congressional delegation that Peking does not rule out negotiating a solution to the Taiwan issue with the Taiwanese, the delegation's leader, Representative Lester Wolff, Democrat of New York, said today.

title: Jericho: Magnet for New Offices
description: JERICHO THE view north from the Long Island Expressway near Exit 40 is striking and unmistakable: In the midst of the greenery of a former sod farm, a large, dramatic white building, dominated by what appear to be the hulls of two boats. commands the skyline.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ANOTABLE absence at the Democratic State Convention Friday night and Saturday will be Joseph I. Lieberman, Senate Majority Leader, candidate for lieutenant governor and Orthodox Jew.

title: 17 More Quit Mexican Prisons
description: SAN DIEGO, July 15 (AP)  Federal officials say 17 more United States citizens who were held in Mexican jails have arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center under the prisonerexchange treaty with Mexico. Acting Warden Lowell Kincaid said yesterday that the arrival of the 17 prisoners, all male, brings to about 300 the total of such returnees since October. Most of them were serving time for drugrelated offenses, he said.

title: Tale of Persistence
description: Mrs. Mackey said, and a policeman on the scene so stated when he prepared to take him to a hospital and asked my husband and me to appear as witnesses.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Don't tell me you're busy, said Stanley, my film producer friend, because this can't wait. As it happened, I was busy. It was two hours before deadline and I still didn't have a lead paragraph, but Stanley didn't get where he is by hiding his light under a bushel. Without being asked, he took a chair and began, as usual, in the middle. I could tellfrom the luster of his tan and from the high shine on his Gucci loafers that he'd just arrived in town. He hadn't yet had time to fade. He was, as he is wont to put it, just laying over.

title: Sarah Chapman Riley Is Bride of Jon T. Roll
description: Sarah Chapman Riley, daughter of Mrs. William G. Mundy of Weston, Vt., and Dr. Edgar A. Riley of New York, was married in Simonsville, Vt., yesterday to Jon Tuxbury Roll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester J. Roll of Gran-tnam, N. H. The Rev. Jay Sprout, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at Red Top Farm, home of Mrs. Mundy's family, the Marshes.

title: Open Cabinet
description: Tif HEN I began to brood about my tummy being too fat, writes Richard Crossman in his third and concluding volume of The Diaries of a Cabinet Minister, and on the fact that this diary which I thought of as being enormously important to future historians will probably be regarded as the rather dull detailed history of the last days of the British widen regime.

title: Colleen Anne Paul Wed to John Quinn
description: Colleen Anne Paul of New York, an assistant manager in the corporate division of the Chemical Bank, was married yesterday to John Joseph Quinn, an assistant district attorney of New York County.

title: David Mason, Rock Singer, In Park Show
description: Make mellow, romantic albums with plenty of catchy songs and liquid guitar on them, and rock a little harder live. In a nutshell, that's the Rock Formula of the 70's, and Dave Mason and Pablo Cruise, who were at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park Friday night, followed it to the letter.

title: Wood, Field &_Stream.
description: ERROL, N. H.  Late one night, cold wind came out of the west and swept the sultry weather away; stars burned bright in the heavens and the Androscoggin, rushing by only a few feet away, lulled me to sleep.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: WHEN making sizable patches on a plaster wall or ceiling, or on drywall where a considerable amount of patching plaster or spackling compound must be used, the doityourselves often have trouble making patch blend in neatly with the rest of The surface.

title: She Runs the London Festival Ballet
description: It is just ten years since Beryl Grey, the famed English ballerina, took over the leadership of the London Festival Ballet. As if to celebrate that anniversary, the company will return to New York on Tuesday for a twoweek engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, its first American appearance since 1954.

title: Jane Kreamer Wed To Henry Meyer 3d
description: Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Kansas City, Mo., was the setting last night for the marriage of Jane Carlyle Kreamer and Henry Lewis Meyer 3d, who bothwhom graduated last month from the Haryard Graduate School of Business Administration. The Rev. Maurice Van Ackeren, president emeritus of Rockhurst College in Kansas City, performed the ceremony.

title: Before the Bell, Sparring at Bonn
description: The international economic meeting that began this morning in Bonn is supposed to produce at least the facade of earnest collaboration. But the unusually severe sniping before the gathering was ample demonstration of just how hard that will be.

title: Bridge: 3 to Vie For Title
description: THREE New Jersey bridge stars will be very close to winning a major national title in Toronto during the coming week. Eugene O'Neill, Merle Tom and Bill Pollack, together with three Westchester experts, will represent the Northeast in the quarterfinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN the roof of the Hartford Civic Center Coliseum caved in last winter, Jeanne Nelson of Darien was more unnerved than most downstate residents. Mrs. Nelson, the state Republican vice chairman, had reserved the Coliseum for the upcoming G.O. P. state convention.

title: 17 Blacks Massacred In Rhodesian Village; Guerrillas Are Blamed
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 15 (AP)  A military, spokesman said today that black nationalist guerri;las massacred 17 blacks last night in a village 100 miles north of here. Some of the victims were burned to death.

title: Editors Choice
description: COLLECTED POEMS, by Basil Bunting. (Oxford University Press, $10.95.) Poems 192475 by a neglected master.

title: The Ubiquitous Hair Dryer Everybody's Got One
description: When Steve Hope and his wife split up, she took the blow dryer, which put the 34yearold film editor in something of a quandary. I went through two months of dripping into my shirt collar before I broke down and bought my own. I had to admit it was no longer a luxury, but a necessity, like my toothbrush or razor.

title: Sdpport for the Japanese Cabinet Is at Record Low of.19.1 Percent
description: TOKYO, July 15 (Reuters)  Public support for Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda's Cabinet has declined to a record low of 19.1 percent; according to an opinion poll released today.

title: Nicklaus Takes 3d British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 15 It was a horse race, just as Tom Watson had figured. Except that the two golfers who wound up going headtohead for the 107th British Open championship today were Jack Nicklaus and Simon Owen. Yes, Simon Owen.

title: July 21: Deadline Or Dead End?
description: Women's athletics officially come of age on Friday. On that day the antisex discrimination law known as Title IX requires high schools and colleges to provide equal athletic opportunity to all students or risk the loss of continued Federal aid.

title: Carter Tells Young of Unhappiness At Comment on Political Prisoners
description: BONN, July 15  President Carter told Andrew Young today that he was very unhappy with controversial statements made by the United Nations delegate this week.

title: Nancy Strouss Wed To T.R. Casselman
description: Nancy Walton Strouss and Theodore Robert Casselman, both of New York, were married yesterday at the Plaza. The Rev. Lloyd G. Mair, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Greene Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. William Aldrich Greene of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Louisa Aldrich Greene, to Kevin McCall, director of facilities for the department of athletics at Harvard University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benton McCall 3d, also of Greenwich.

title: At Asparagus Beach, a Slow Change in the Mating Dance
description: AMAGANSETT, L. I.  Despite the socalled new freedom and honesty between the sexes, despite all the consciousnesses that supposedly have been raised to think of people as more than mere sex objects, the oldfashioned mating game still persists.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Twin Brooks K.C. 31st dog show. Caldwell College campus, Ryerson Avenue, Caldwell, N.J.; 1.151 dogs; 9 A.M.5 P.M.

title: Inspector Clouseau Strikes AgainAnd Again and Again
description: Telephone call for you, Inspector Clouseau, announces the butler. Ah, yes, says the determined little man. That will be for me. A scene from A Shot in the Dark

title: White House Groupie
description: ONCE, some years ago. I caught Gay Talese on television explaining why he had left the newspaper business to write books.
