He said he had done so because he noticed that the headlines on obituaries of newspaper reporters always went something like this  John Doe, Covered Yalta  and that it occurred to him that he did not want to die with nothing to his credit but the events he had covered.

title: The Economic Wind's Blowing Toward the Right For Now
description: What began as a Presidential drive for tax reform has turned into a revolt against taxes by middle and upper income groups. Public television, which a few seasons ago starred the liberal economist John Kenneth Galbraith, this year will offer economicsmadeeasy by the conservative Milton Friedman. And on campuses around the country, corporate executives, instead of being picketed, are teaching soughtafter courses on the freeenterprise system.

title: Carter and West German Leader Trim Demands for Parley's Sake
description: BONN, July 15President Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany have privately agreed to shelve their economic differences, official sources here say, in order to agree on a modest program for combating world recession at the economic summit meeting opening here tomorrow.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: VOLENDAM (HollandAmerica) Lett Bermuda July 14; due at S A. M. at 55tH Street.

title: PaperMaking Techniques Cause Popular Literature to Bite the Dust
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., July 15 (AP) With surprising regularity, students pull books from Harvard's vast library stacks and find nothing between the covers but dust.

title: TelevisionThisWeek
description: 10:30 A.M. (2) LOOK UP AND LIVE. The Family, the Future. A halfhour report on Costa Rica's successful population control program.

title: Maxine Goldenson Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Goldenson of New York and Mamaroneck, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maxine Goldenson of Los Angeles, to Peter A. Meyerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Meyerson of Hallandale. Fla.

title: An Approach to Peace
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  If negotiations between Egypt and Israel on the West Bank and Gaza are to get anywhere, the United States will have to contribute some fresh ideas and be ready to assume new responsibilities in the framework of a settlement.

title: Her Father Tells How the Family Coped
description: WHEN our daughter Beth became very ill in August 1975, we were not prepared for anything like cancer. (Is anyone ever prepared for cancer?) Within 24 hours of learning her diagnosis, my wife Gail and I were waiting for Beth to come down from the operating room. We didn't /mow whether she had cancer, but I think both of us felt it. I don't think we were really surprised when we were told that the surgeon had removed the tumor and that it was not benign.

title: Roots in Nutley: The Story of a House
description: IT WAS a rainy Sunday. The small red house was set far back on the street, almost hidden by old apple trees and a tall hedge of privet. We glimpsed a sturdy front door and an extraordinary large window that seemed to bend and disappear under the roof shingles.

title: New L.I. Office Complex Presents Striking Design
description: JERICHO, L.I.  The view north from the Long Island Expressway near Exit 40 is striking and unmistakable: In the midst of the greenery of a former sod farm, a large, white building, dominated by what appear to be the hulls of two boats, commands the skyline.

title: Laura G. Ingraham And Peter Justinius Wed in Connecticut
description: Laura Grosvenor Ingraham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sears Wilson Ingraham of Darien, Conn., and Peter Van Justinius, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan Oscar Justinius of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday in the garden of waveny in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Richard L. Rush of the First Congregational Church of Fairfield performed the ceremony.

title: Crown Heights Residents Block Leftist Protesters
description: Charging that their own plans for a parade were being upstaged, black residents of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday prevented a group of mostly white demonstrators from marching through the streets of the neighborhood to protest the death last month of black businessman while in police custodv.

title: Jane Berylson Is Fiancee Of Stephen E. Flechner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kermit J. Berylson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Berylson, to Stephen E. Flechner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Flechner of Lauderhill, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: And The Market Expands
description: State insurance commissions, previously among the fiercest opponents of captive insurance companies, increasingly are seeing it in their interest to attract this business.

title: Red Sox Top Twins; Carew Gets No. 2.000
description: BOSTON, July15 (AP)  Carl Yastrzemski's home run on the first pitch of the sixth inning helped Bill Lee to his 10th victory today as the Boston Red Sox snapped a three gamelosing streak with a 54 triumph over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Great Contradictions
description: THE almost simultaneous publication of the new English edition of Leo Tolstoy's letters, of the memoirs of his eldest daughter and of a detailed study of his fiction by a distinguished Dostoyevsky specialist testifies (if such testimony were needed) to our continued fascination with both Tolstoy the great writer and Tolstoy the historical phenomenon. His was the kind of personality that is best described by the French phrase, le monstre sacre, the sacred monster. With his intransigent moral maximalism and his lifelong conviction that he was the only person in the world with correct answers to all life's problems, Tolstoy easily could have qualified as the most unbearable of literary titans were it not for his endearing selfcontradictions and occasional selfrefutations. No one could ever refute Tolstoy's more outrageous pronouncements better than Tolstoy. If one delves enough into his voluminous writings, one is sure to find him propounding clearheaded arguments that overthrow the more dogmatic, simplistic or plainly wrongheaded attitudes that he himself expresses a few years earlier or later.

title: KissingerColby Briefings on C.I.A. Called Misleading by Senate Panel
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee has concluded, after a secret yearlong study. that Henry A. Kissinger and William E. Colby misled Congress about the extent of the Central Intelligence Agency's activities in the 1975 civil war in Angola, according to sources with firsthand knowledge.

title: King Wants to Inc. Giants Pact
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 15 Gordon King Inc., which the Giants No. 1 draft choice would like to call himself, has not as yet signed a National Football League contract. The result was that the star tackle from Stanford could not take a 12minute run, the only exercise today on the opening day of training camp.

title: U.S. Sailors Prepare for Baltic
description: When it comes to Olympic competition, American sailors have not exactly been threatening. There have been occasional flashes of success, such as Buddy Melges's 1972 gold medal in the Soling Class, but for the most part the laurels tend to be garnered by European sailors.

title: A Second Recall Notice Is Issued For FiveFoot Aluminum Ladders
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  A second recall notice involving 7,500 fivefoot household aluminum ladders sold by Sears Roebuck and Company has been issued by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Captive Insurers Slip Their Chains
description: The insurance industry calls them captives  companies set up by major United States corporations to insure their own special risks. They bask in taxfree Bermuda  an unlikely group to cause a stir in the international insurance market. But in the last year the captives have come to life. lhey nave begun to do some capturing of their own, selling insurance to companies unrelated to them and entering the sophisticated field of reinsurance, seeking Lloyd's of Londonstyle highrisk business.

title: Billy Martin's Liver Ailment
description: Up to now the primary plot of the Yankees soap opera has involved the continuous conflict of egos between George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin, but suddenly a medical crisis has surfaced. The volatile owner has offered the volatile manager an opportunity to resign for health reasons. George Steinbrenner identified a nagging virus that Billy Martin has been unable to shake all season. But his ailment might be much more serious. Billy Martin has told friends, I have a spot on my liver, and has been advised by physicians to stop drinking. True to his stubborness that he can't live with or without, Billy Martin has spurned that medical advice as well as George Steinbrenner's offer.

title: Catfish Hunter, a Candidate for the People
description: BRUNSWICK, Me.I've been voting ever since I was discharged from the Army Air Corps in 1945. As a survivor of 35 combat missions, I concluded the numbing experience might acquire some significance if I participated in the process I had risked so much to help protect.

title: FOOD
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE LINDA WASSERSTEIN is one of those perfectionist bakers who keep working on a recipe until they are thoroughly satisfied with the results, even if it means inventing a pan to 20 with it.

title: Ban on Bettor Services Upheld
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (Reuters)  The Illinois Supreme Court has ruled that the state has the right to outlaw messenger, services that accept wagers and take bets to the track for gamblers unable to get out themselves.

title: CHILDLESS COUPLE IS SUING DOCTOR
description: A dispute over an uncompleted attempt to produce a testtube baby here five years ago will pit a Florida couple against Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in a civil trial tomorrow in Manhattan Federal Court.

title: In Russia, a Good Citizen Is a Quiet One
description: MOSCOW  As the Soviet Union turned a deaf ear last week to cries of outrage in the West, and handed down heavy sentences against two prominent dissidents, an unresolved question hung over Moscow. It was the question of the future, the uncertainty of what these trials, and especially the treason conviction of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, would mean for the quality of political life in the Soviet Union.

title: Archbishop Andrey Dies at 86; Immigrated With Russian Church
description: Archbishop Andrey of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia died Wednesday at the Convent of Novo Diveyevo in Spring Valley, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Sara Watson Is Bride of Michael Stubbins
description: Sara Letitia Watson and Michael Hamilton Stubbins were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Frank Norwood Watson of White Plains. Mr. Stubbins is a son of Hugh A. Stubbins of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Diana Stubbins Stuart.

title: The Issues Abound, but So Do the Delays
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate convened one day last week at 8 A.M. to get an early start on not legislating. The point was to prevent a committee meeting, scheduled for 10 A.M. on Alaska lands legislation, from taking place. There were a couple of hours of long speeches, including one by an Alaska senator opposed to the lands bill, followed by a little real work, then a recess from 11:26 A.M. to 1:15 P.M.  a more leisurely lunch period than the cuisine of the senators dining room justifies.

title: Expos 8, Astros 0
description: MONTREAL, July 15 (AP)  Tony Perez drove in two runs with a firstinning double and lefthander Woodie Fryman hurled a sixhitter as Montreal easily defeated Houston tonight.

title: United Press International
description: GERALD FORD IS 65: Former President Gerald R. Ford and his wife, Betty, in Vail, Colo., late Friday, as they celebrated his birthday with surprise party.

title: Byrd Tells Carter Senate Will Pass Bill on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, said today that he had telephoned President Carter in West Germany to assure him that the Senate would approve the first part of his energy pro. gram on Tuesday.

title: CARTER ADDRESSES A TORN MEETING OF WEST BERLINERS
description: WEST BERLIN, July 15  President Carter stood before an audience of 1,000 Berliners here today and fielded questions for nearly an hour on everything from the security of this divided city to the size of his daughter's weekly allowance.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: A sail is a beautiful thing, but it exists not to be beautiful but to catch the wind; in fact, its beauty comes when the wind fills it. lot, but it is essentially inert. It rarely catches the play's wind; instead, Wilford Leach, the director and designer, has provided his own auxiliary motor.

title: Julie and Barbara Krekstein Will Be Brides
description: The engagements of Julie Sue and Barbara Ellen Krekstein have been announced by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Krekstein of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Julie Sue Krekstein plans to be married in September to Robert Craig Rosenberg. Her sister plans to be married next May to Jeffrey Robert Allen.

title: GARDENING
description: Arecent trip to the North Fork early on a Saturday morging was a refreshing experience. The roadsides were arrayed with colorful wildflowers nodding among the unmown grasses. White daisies and yarrow, blue vetch and, here and there, chicory and golden hawkweed caught one's attention. An occasional excavation for a new house by the beach was covered with pale yellow mustard, nature's way of healing the wound.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1.400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: MUSIC
description: GREENWICH I haven't had the space to tell you about it until now, but there was touching and affectionate happening last month in the auditorium of the Greenwich Library. It was a centennial tribute to Chester Edward Ide (18781944), a modest and therefore littleknown American composer who taught in the Greenwich schools for the last 15 years of his busy life.

title: Betsy Bentrup Wed To J. B. Armstrong
description: The marriage of Betsy Lenor Bentrep, daughter of Mrs. Gustave L. Bentrep of Austin and the late Mr. Bentrup, to James Dell Armstrong took place in Charlottesville, Va., yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Armstrong of New York.

title: Horse Council Gets A Dedicated Worker
description: The endless grind will end tomorrow for Georgine (Gigi) Winslett when she joins the staff of the American Horse Council.

title: Plastic Shields Tomatoes
description: CLOSTER LOCALLY grown tomatoes and corn are two staples of the summer roadside market. The earlier that harvesting begins, the more business that is generated.

title: Soviet, in Jailing a Dissident Gains 4 Others
description: MOSCOW, July 15  In jailing Anatoly B. Shcharaasky, the authorities have removed one dissident, but they have made dissidents of at least four other persons  his parents, his brother and his brother's wife  who were content and reasonably happy with their lives until the storm of injustice. as they see it. sweat over them.

title: DINING OUT
description: WALKING into The Sawpit as a newcomer is like entering a club of which you're not a member. There is a lively hubbub as the regulars tablehop, call to each other, exchange confidences with the waiters, and generally make themselves at home.me place is almost always crowded. Our first visit was on a Saturday night, so the backedup throng in the bar was understandable. But when we went the following Wednesday with almost similar results, we realized that The Sawpit was, for many, a very special place.

title: Passman Trial Set for Louisiana
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  Otto E. Passman, the former Democratic Congressman accused of bribery and tax evasion, will be tried in his home state of Louisiana rather than in Washington. Federal District Judge Barrington Parker yesterday granted a defense request to move the trial to Louisiana to spare Mr. Passman the trouble and expense of traveling to Washington. The court cannot shrug off the fact that the defendent is 78 years old and is beset by physical problems and ailments that would be a taxing and demanding experience in the best of circumstances, Judge Parker said.

title: Stalking the CopperyTailed Trogon
description: The cactus wren, officially honored as the state bird of Arizona, makes its home in arid areas of the southeastern states and parts of Mexico. It is readily distinguishable from the widely distributed house wren by its relatively large size, by white stripe over the eye, and by its song: which is described by ornithologists as unwrenlike, chortling, unmusical. Would you travel 2,500 mites to see this bird?

title: Green and White, and Read All Over
description: HARTSDALE THERE is a littleknown card in Westchester that puts nearly million books, records, films and other informational material almost at one's fingertips. It can give access to expensive art volumes, lareenrint books and hardtofindworks by a favorite mystery writer, as well as special collections on such varied topics as law, science, business, county data, Hudson Valley history and horseracing.

title: Baryshnikov and Balanchine: The Story Begins
description: YSARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. you cannot tell everything yet, but the union, at least for now, is working. The New York City Ballet is looking at Mikhail Baryshnikov; Mikhail Baryshnikov is looking at the New York City Ballet.

title: LEGACY OF TERROR
description: The lack of consistency in the United States policy toward Castro left a legacy that some experts believe finally came to include terrorist acts like the murder of Orlando Letelier. as the stories of Orlando Bosch. Orlando Garcia and Ricardo Morales illustrate. Trained by the Central Intelligence Agency in the early 1960's, when American policy toward Castro was very firm. these terrorists  with the support of Americanbased exile leaders like Ignacio Novo  later employed the tactics they had learned on behalf of other Latin American countries after United States policy toward Cuba softened.

title: Governor Hardens His Political Tactics
description: THERE is increasing evidence that the I Byrne administration has learned how to play hard ball during the early stages of Mr. Byrne's second term.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTPORT WHY does Westport have such monopoly on restaurants when certain nearby towns with greater populations are virtual culinary wastelands? The town support; two Mexican restaurants, several French, Italihn and Chinese restaurants, at least four seafood places, steak houses, and numerous other small boutiquelike establishments.

title: Rock's LowKey Pilgrims
description: IF one of those volcanic outdoor rock concerts erupted in the tranquil glades of northern Westchester, some of the 'ountry's biggest rock promoters might be among the first residents to grab their ears and lee. the area has become a mecca for the people who produce and promote much of the music listened to by American youth, but these pilgrims have come to escape the sounds of electric guitars, powerful amplifiers and screaming crowds.

title: Unified Job Program
description: WHITE PLAINS MANY black and Hispanic youths cannot obtain jobs, even in relatively good times, because of discrimination or because  even more so than in the case of their white coinneroarts their education, skills and location do not readily match available jobs, according to the Committee for Economic Development. A complication is the lack of coordination and communication among the agencies providing employment related services to youths, according to a spokesman of an intermediate council formed to combat the problem.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: AIN'T MISBEHAVIWThe Tony Awardwinning musical salute to Fats Waller, directed by Richard Maltby Jr. Choreographed by Arthur Feria. It has a first act that wilt knock your ears off and second that will come back for the rest of you. (Kerr) Longacre, 220 W. 48th St. (C165439)

title: POLITICS
description: WHITE PLAINS DEMOCRATS and Republicans in Westchester have been conducting highpowered campaigns to persuade voters to enroll in their party, but the ranks of the independents who refuse to join either seem to be swelling considerably faster.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Although many of America's multinational companies are household names overseas, their corporate success has often been marred by individual failure. Executives assigned to help run operations abroad sometimes do their work woefully, despite a splendid track record at home.

title: Bolivian Case Study
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  The first elections permitted by Bolivia's armed forces in 12 years illustrate the difficulty of shifting from military dictatorship to even the most limited kind of democracy in South America's authoritarian regimes. The military men who hold power in Urueuay. Argentina, Paraguay and Chile resent President Carter's campaign for human rights and political liberties. They are war with international Communism, they contend, and political parties and unions cannot be permitted to threaten national unity.

title: Close Relatives
description: MONKEY business, always attractive to the public, is now scientifically fashionable as well. Primatologists are busily studying monkeys, apes and our other immediate relatives.

title: Sarkis Agrees to Stave On
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 (UPI) President Elias Sarkis withdrew today his threat to resign, easing 10 days of tension in Beirut, where nearly 200 people have been killed in shooting between Syrian peacekeeping troops and Christian militia forces.

title: Comptroller's Audit Asserts 2 of City Parking Fines Go Unpaid
description: Because of deficient procedures in the Parking Violations Bureau and other agencies, nearly two out of three parking violators who receive summonses escape without paying them, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Margaret McGuinness Is Bride
description: Margaret McGuinness and John Pierce Borders Jr., graduates of St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., were married yesterday in the Saddle River Reformed Church in Upper Saddle River, N. J., by the Rev. John K. Highberger. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. McGuinness of Woodcliff Lake, N. J., and Mr. and Mrs. Borders of LaGrange, Ga., are the parents of the couple.The bride, whose father is a vice president of the Dexter Chemical Corporation in New York, will start studies in September at the Columbia University School of Nursing. Mr. Borders, whose father is a building contractor, works in the New York office of Milliken & Company, a textile concern.

title: PEOPLE
description: Three former executives of the Franklin National Bank, which collapsed in 1974 in the biggest bank failure in United States history, were indicted last week on Federal fraud charges. Harold V. Gleason, former chairman of the board of Franklin National, Paul Luftig, former president of the bank, and J. Michael Carter, a former senior vice president, were named as defendants in the indictmentwhich includes 19 counts of fraudalleging that the men falsified records to cover up the bank's huge losses, in attempting to obtain an extension on $35 million in loans from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: MovingA Lament
description: DEAR, old friends mean well when they say, We worry when you threaten to tear up roots at your age. They find it hard to accept the fact that our proposed move from Towaco, in Morris County, to New England is no idle threat.

title: Saturday Night Is Rodeo NightDeep in the Heart of New Jersey
description: Just head down U.S. 40 and you can't miss it, the locals say, and for once the phrase is apt. It is indeed difficult to overlook the 40foothigh fiberglass cowboy and steer at the entrance, the big Welcome Rodeo Fans banners and the signs announcing arrival at The Cow Capital of the First Frontier. If it's Saturday night, this must be Cowtown, the country's second oldest weekly rodeo, in Sharptown, N.J.

title: The Wrong Medicine
description: Here is a pretty kettle of fish; or maybe it's a can of worms:

title: Mr. Speaker Sits. For a TV Portrait
description: BOSTON Tacked along the periphery of a large productionschedule chart on the wall of Nancy Porter's office at WGBH, the Boston publictelevision station, are the quotations of Speaker Tip she got to know best:

title: Dodgers 2, Cardinals 1
description: ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP)  Ron Cey and Dusty Baker hit runscoring singles and Doug Rau, with relief help from Terry Forster, scattered six hits as Los Angeles prevailed. Rau (104) raised his career record against the Cardinals to 72, giving up only an unearned run in the sixth.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday criticized a twoyearold program to improve city management, saying the program had failed to take into account quality as well as quantity in measuring productivity by city agencies and workers.

title: Cosmos Defeat Fury, 30; 19th Victory in 24 Games
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15  The Cosmos scored two goals within three minutes in the second half tonight and went on to defeat the Philadelphia Fury, 30, in a North American Soccer League match that was played before 19,279 fans at Veterans Stadium.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Quit New Jobs On Board of Broadcast Company
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 15 (Reuters)  Two of the first blacks to be appointed to the board of governors of the staterun. Rhodesia Broadcasting Corporation have resigned after only five davs In a joint letter of resignation fhis week, Washington Sansole, an attorney, and the Rev. Charles Manyoba said they did not believe they could change the role of Rhodesian radio and television as proGovemment propaganda outlets.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WITHIN the vast contemporary literature that deals with broken marriages, there is one kind of heroine that exasperates me more than any other: the triumphantly efficient and successful career woman who singlehandedly educates a brood of adorable, perfectly adjusted children.

title: Realty News,
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is moving from the Sperry Rand Building at 1290 Avenue of the Americas to the former headquarters of Group Health Incorporated at 230 West 41 Street.

title: BEIUND THE BEST SELLERS
description: The rich are different. Their big worry is not how to make money but how to keep it  a lesson of welltodo life that Ken Follett has suddenly learned at the age of 29.

title: Gradations of Silliness
description: THROUGH the sturdy homespun of English fiction runs a single thread of silver silliness. It is a filament drawn from an art that may seem snobbish and arch but that in fact affects attitudes only for the sake of the imagination. For that reason it must not be regarded as satire, for the foolish, delicate creatures it pokes fun at have, alas, never existed save in the tented gossamer daydreams of a few writers. I'm thinking of a tradition that begins with Pope's Rape of the Lock and extends through Thomas Love Peacock, Oscar Wilde, Ronald Firbank and Henry Green and that ends, implausibly enough, in America with W. M. Spackman and his splendid, recently published An Armful of Warm Girl. The distinguishing characteristics of the style of sublime silliness are its atmosphere of innocent romance and gorgeous effects, its tight design and economy of expression played off against an almost total absence of content. There is also, usually, a coiled, edgy quality to the writing, as though the author were trying to transcribe a humor that eludes language.

title: CAMERA
description: There is a fascinating world waiting to be discovered by the adventuresome photographer who will take the time and trouble to look for it. It is a Lilliputian uni verse teeming with interesting colors; textures snd shapes, and all it takes to explore this world is a few simple camera accessories. Most camera lenses will focus as close as two or three feet, but the small universe we are interested in requires that we be able to focus our lenses in terms of inches, rather than feet.

title: Panov Is Seen With Berliners In His Spring
description: No better lesson in how a change in cast can transform one's view of a ballet was offered than on Friday night at the New York State Theater when. Valery Panov made his local debut in his own Berlin Opera Ballet production of The Rite of Spring and Gisla-dottir appeared for the first time as its heroine, the Chosen One.

title: Police Officials on Coast Deny Inspector Forged Zodiac Letters
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP)  Police officials have emphatically denied reports that Inspector Dave Toschi, who has investigated the Zodiac killer case for nine years, ever was suspected of forging the latest letters attributed to themurderer.

title: Miss Alvarez Captures U.S. 35er Grass Crown
description: Judy Alvarez of Tampa, Fla., the firstseeded player, defeated Charlene Hillebrand of San Pedro, Calif., 61, 63, and won the 35yearsandover title in the United States senior women's grass tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

title: Hollywood's New ideal of Masculinity
description: In what may be an emerging genre in the movies  the postfeminist romance  there appears character who expresses in his personality and relations with the heroine a new ideal of masculinity. He might be described as the emotionally competent hero. Alan Bates plays him in An Unmarried Woman; Paul Starr, assistant professor of sociology at Harvard, is the author of The Discarded Army: Veterans After Vietnam.

title: A Law That Aids Repairs
description: TWO years ago, the Smith family added an extension to their South Shore home in Brentwood to accommodate a new member. Everything appeared in order, and then recently the roof sprang a leak and the Smiths discovered that their contractor had gone out of business.

title: Bonnett Remembers His Road to Success
description: Breaking into the big leagues of auto racing is a lot like breaking into the big leagues of baseball. Almost everyone has to serve an apprenticeship in the minors. Then if you develop the necessary skills  and are able to take advantage of a break or two  you might make it.

title: Expectant Mother of Lab Embryo Is Evacuated After a Bomb Hoax
description: OLDHAM, England, July 15 (AP) The English woman who is expecting baby whose embryo derived from fertilization and culturing in a laboratory had to be evacuated from her hospital ward last night because of a bomb hoax, police said.

title: A Birder's Sojourn in Alaska
description: Some Alaskans swear that on at least one of the tour boats that cruise into the waters of Glacier Bay National Monument, many of the passengers do not bother to leave the bar to marvel at the turquoise icebergs and teeming marine life. Instead, as they order another round, they scan the sights on closedcircuit television.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: O n the evening of May 22 of this year a middleaged man collapsed and died in a subway station in the center of London. Such are the hazards and indignities of sudden death that it was quite some time before he was identified as Benedict Nicolson, editor since 1947 of what is by consent the best arthistorical journal in the world: the Burlington magazine.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony L. Lanese. Jr. ot Clittside Park. N.J. and Mr. Harold R. Donohue of N.Y.C. are happy to announce the engagement ot their (laughter, Diane Jaw!t to r.1r. Michael Steven Dorfaine 0! Pacific Palisades, California The wedding will take Place on September 16 In Cahlol hie Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weston of West Long Branch, N.J. are pleased to announce the engagement ot their daughter, Bonnie Lee to Steven Sobo. on of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Sobo of Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Princeton Women Settle In
description: PRINCETON THE 101 women who entered Princeton University in September 1969  the first class to include members of the opposite sex for all four undergraduate years  are establishing themselves in the traditional fields of Ivy League achievement, according to an informal survey taken at the first major reunion of the class, the Class of 1973.

title: The Region
description: Longawaited Federal loan guarantees for New York were worked out last week in a bill that will keep the city on a tight rein as it tries to stay out of bankruptcy and level its debt over the next four years.

title: Jennifer House Wed To Nigel Wilkinson
description: Jennifer Gardner House, who graduated in May from Smith College, was married yesterday to James Nigel Wilkinson, who expects to receive a degree in theoretical physics next year fromQueen MaryCollege of the University of. London. The ceremony was performed in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. Paul C. Weed.

title: Red Smith
description: The first thing that impresses one in meeting Martina Navratilova is her easy composure. The second is her charm. it is as though the volatile kid from Czechoslovakia who calls herself The Brat became a woman Friday afternoon, July 7, when she defeated Chris Evert for the Wimbledon singles championship. At 19 she was an accredited member of the tennis menagerie where it is not always possible to keep order with a whip and kitchen chair. If she didn't indulge in the obscenities and tantrums that distinguish some overpaid and unmannered performers, she could fly apart emotionally, she was capable of berating a line judge or dissolving in tears. At 21 she is a professional, with professional poise.

title: Links and Chains: Shcharansky Trial And Arms Talks
description: Dtente has always been an uneasy mixture of pragmatism and propaganda. Efforts by the United States and the Soviet Union to control (and preserve) their destructive power are matched by the determination to extend their influence further and further. Keeping the rivalry from undercutting cooperation has become increasingly difficult in recent months. Last week, it was impossible.

title: W.G. Soare to Wed Mary Ann McSoley
description: Mary Ann McSoley and Warren G. Soare were married yesterday in the garden of the Larchwood Inn in Wakefield, R.I. The Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev. Graham M. Patterson and the Rev. Jack S. Miller.

title: Youth Center to Rise From Ashes
description: A nautical education center for youngsters from Yorkville and Harlem was destroyed by a fire last week, but the chairman of the project has promised that will rise from the ashes.

title: Military Contingency Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  The Defense Department says it has a contingency plan to use the military to deliver the mail in case of a postal strike.

title: Elizabeth Gutmann Married
description: Elizabeth Kohner Gutmann and Harold Oshlag, both of New Rochelle, N. Y., were married last evening at Temple Israel of New Rochelle by Rabbi Amiel Wohl. The bride, widow of Harry K. Gutmann, an insurance agent, graduated from George Washington University in 1932, the year Mr. Oshlag graduated from Columbia University. He also has a law degree from St. John's University and heads his own insurance and, real estate business in New Rochelle. His first wife died. The late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kohner of Washington were the parents of the bride.

title: Marquez Himself
description: GABRIEL GARCIA MARQUEZ recently passed through New York on his way home to Mexico. He joked about the difficulties he faces whenever he comes to the United States. Like a number of other Latin American writers  Julio Cortazar and Carlos Fuentes among them  he is on a socalled blacklist generally reserved by the immigration authorities for those who belong to subversive organizations. This means he can enter the country only if he is invited to lecture at a university. With a smile, he said that the only organization in the whole world that he belongs to is the American Academy and nstitute of Arts and Letters, of which he is an honorary fellow, and that the only honorary degree he has ever received is from Columbia University. Yet in spite of these attachments and his general popularity in this country, he is subjected to special visa restrictions. Although he won't say so himself, he feels that this bizarre situation is an insult to writers everywhere. At the same time, it occasionally produces comic side effects. Because of his friendship with Gen. Omar Torrijos, he was made a member of the Panamanian delegation that visited Washington to sign the Panama Canal treaty. The official plane landed at Andrews Air Force Base, and Garcia Mdrquez, who is a short and stocky man, gestured in the manner of Charlie Chaplin to show how he felt when he found himself being welcomed by the trumpet salute of an Air Force band as he stepped off the plane into this topsecret military enclave.

title: The Day the LockerRoom Door Slammed Shut
description: IT was Memorial Day  how ironic, and yet how appropriate. The day of my disenfranchisement. For more years than I care to remember, I had convinced myself that I was merely biding my time, playing out the string, as it was. I told myself that I could see the proverbial lightattheendofthetunnel, and that I would (when the time came) bow out gracefully. Then suddenly, it was all over. Gone. (Poof!) Like that. I was out of a job.

title: They Make Jazz a Part of People's Lives
description: IN the beginning, when a group of North Shore residents hungry for good music founded the International Art of Jazz 19 years ago, the emphasis was strictly on art for art's sake. Now, hundreds of gigs later, jazz is flourishing on the Island, so alive and welt that when the I.A.J.

title: Carter, Received Politely, Touches No Emotional Chords
description: WEST BERLIN, July 15  The applause rose through the day and the crowds swelled. President Carter traveled across much of West Germany today, easily and cheerfully, but withal touching the emotional chord that American Presidents have often found an visits here since the end of World War II.

title: Group Seeks to Persuade Carter To Free Patricia Hearst From Jail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) committee that contends that Patricia Hearst was incorrectly jailed said had started a campaign to persuade President Carter to free the newspaper heiress from Federal prison.

title: Zukerman Adds Conducting to Fiddling
description: During a break at a recent recording session, Pinchas Zukerman leaned across the engineering console and quietly asked a member of the Guarneri Quartet about a fellow violinist, Shmuel Ashkenasi. I wonder if Ashkenasi is really any good, was the question. Very good, was the reply. The subject? Tennis. A few minutes later, after arranging something of a string players celebrity tennis tournament and discussing the dubious wisdom of the New York Yankees management, Mr. Zukerman and the Guarneris settled down to a Mendelssohn quintet, Mr. Zukerman playing an unobtrusive second viola part.

title: THE DESCENT FROM THE HEIGHTS
description: Truman Capote /KIS been famous as both a writer and salon celebrity since the publication, at age 23, of his first novel, Other Voices, Other Rooms. Capote had felt himself to be a spiritual orphan during his childhood. An Only Chaa, telt at age 4 with relatives by a mother who later committed suicide, Capote spent five years in Monroeville, Ala., then spent the rest of his childhood in New York City. During the years that followed, he courted critics with his pretty prose, and rich women with his ready ear. In 1959 he went to Ho/comb. Kan_ to begin work on what he would call the book of a lifetime, In Cold Blood, about the murder of the wholesome Middle Western Clutter family. His sympathy was stretched thin between Alvin Dewey, the head of the investigation, and small dark Perry Smith, one of the murderers. The Kansas experience was a high point in his literary life, but it was followed by the scandal that attended the publication of sections of his newest novel, Answered Prayers, and led to the emotional turmoil of his recent years.

title: Marijuana Over Tobacco, 3 to 1
description: BOULDER, Colo., July 15 (UPI)University of Colorado students who smoke prefer marijuana to tobacco, according to a recent survey. The survey, conducted by a university journalism class, found that marijuana smokers outnumbered cigarette smokers at the school by a ratio of almost 3 to 1. The class randomly selected 360 students and interviewed them by telephone last spring.

title: U.S. Weighing Response to Soviet Dissident Trials
description: BONN, July 15  The United States is studying various alternatives on how to react to the sentencing yesterday of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident. The preference seemed to be to mount a diplomatic effort to obtain his freedom or a reduction of his sentence.

title: The World
description: Score one for diplomacy in Africa. After a year of patient negotiations, five Western nations have secured agreement on a plan for independence and black majority rule in SouthWest Africa.

title: Lutheran Church in America Elects Its New President
description: CHICAGO; July 15  The Rev. Dr. James R. Crumley was elected president here today of the Lutheran Church in America. with 3.1 million members the third largest Protestant denomination in North America.

title: Not Yet Finished With Korea ate
description: After 18 months of investigating South Korea's bribery and influencepeddling on Capitol Hill, the House ethics committee has charged four members with violating House rules and exonerated the Speaker and majority whip with a polite chiding for poor judgment. Is that all there is?

title: CAREY IS CONFIDANT ON ANTICRIME PLANS
description: ROCHESTER, July 15  Governor Carev said today that he expected bipartisan negotiators in the Legislature to produce by Monday or Tuesday a package of bills to provide stiffer penalties for juvenile crime. The bills, he indicated, would be acceptable to him.

title: Correction
description: In the review of Point Blank by Sonny Grosso and Philip Rosenberg (July 2), Mr. Rosenberg was incorrectly identified as the author of the television screenplay Contract on Cherry Street. Mr. Rosenberg wrote the novel of that name, but was in no way connected with the television script, which was written by Edward Anhalt.

title: The Klansman Who Wore Many Hoods
description: There was never a doubt that Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. committed questionable acts as the Government's chief infiltrator of the Ku Klux Klan in the early 1960's. Last week there was evidence that some of his activities may also have been unconscionable.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Trade negotiators in Geneva reached a tentative agreement just in time to present it to the leaders of the seven Western powers who today convene the Bonn economic summit. Robert S. Strauss, the chief United States representative at the Geneva talks, said he hoped that the framework for understanding would form the basis of a new.international law governing trade, a pact that has eluded the negotiators since the socalled Tokyo round of trade talks began five years ago.  Latest word on Japan's exports: they swelled to $8.6 billion in June, the secondhighest monthly level and a 20.3 percent jump from their 1977 level. Almost $2.1 billion was destined for American shores, a 17.1 percent increase.

title: Nuclear Agency Studies Eruptions in Soil Where Thorium Is Buried
description: WASHINGTON, W.Va., July 15 (UPI) Each time a shovel bites into a patch of soil at the L.B. Foster Company plant here, the earth glows and explodes in a small volcanolike eruption.

title: New York Acts on TeenAge Pregnancy Problems
description: The New York State Department of Social Services has begun a new drive to deal with the problem of teenage pregnancies, including the expansion of services intended to prevent such pregnancies and of those that provide care and services to the thousands of pregnant teenagers and teenage mothers.

title: Miss Caulkins Takes Medley in Near Record
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., July 15 (UPI) Tracy Caulkins, a 15yearold swimming sensation from Nashville, Tenn., came within fivehundreths of a second of the pending world record in the 200meter individual medley last night.

title: Later to tht editor
description: Joseph Horowitz's excellent and timely article, The Sound of Russian Music in the West (June 11), brings to mind the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra's recent visit to the Soviet Union under the auspices of the State Department. All of us on that tour were extremely impressed with Soviet musicianship in general and, contrary to Mr. Horowitz, with the Russians sensitivity and elegance in the performance of such composers as Mozart. Music making seemed to help understanding between our two countries.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. The High Cost of Loving.

title: CHILDREN'S AUTHOR, JAY WILLMMS, AT 64
description: Jay Williams, a prolific writer, principally of historical novels and science fiction stories for children, died Wednesday on a visit to Britain. The 64yearold author also maintained a home in Redding, Conn.

title: Carol Schimmel to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Carol Joan Schimmel to Marc H. Launer has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Milton R. Schimmel of Longmeadow, Mass. Mr. Launer is a son of Helen G. Launer of Ellenville, N.Y., and the late Jack Launer. A wedding in late summer is planned.

title: Judges at Contest in Moscow Listened to the Piano Partners, Too
description: In much of the literature for violin and piano or for cello and piano the two instruments are equal partners. The importance of the pianist to the violinist or cellist cannot be calculated. This is something the jury in the Tchaikovsky competition realized. James Gemmell, Nathaniel Rosen's pianist in Moscow, remembers the jury announcing during the second round, We are listening to the pianists as well as the cellists. The result of this was the awarding of five special diplomas to the pianists in this group. Of the five so honored, Mr. Gemmel! was the only American. Three Russians and one Japanese were the others.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WINNING 22 awards, as Westchester did last week at the meeting in Atlanta of the National Association of Counties, is one thing; getting them home is another. On the last day of the conference, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello. called his executive assistant, Joyce Baumgarten, a member of the delegation, with a plaintiff request: Do you have any room in your suitcase?

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: CHARITY may begin at home, but for a lot of people it goes much farther. Described in terms ranging from nearsaints to perpetrators of a necessary evil, these individuals go about their business, often for no pay, with the zeal and concentration of the truest of true believers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE winners take office, and the losers teach. Raymond H. Bateman and Stephen B. Wiley, former members of the State Sen1 ate who lost last November, have signed up to be adjunct professors at the Eagleton Institute of Politics next spring.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: A look at some of the world's leading stock exchanges shows wide variations in performance during the first half of 1978. The strongest sustained price advance came in Tokyo, while the weakest trading was in London.

title: OVERHAUL IS URGED IN JOBLESS FIGURES
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Statistics Are No Substitute for Good Judgment, reads the plaque on Sar A. Levitan's office wall.

title: What's Going Up
description: The JerichoSyossetHicksvilleWoodbury area is the site of extensive construction activity, according to L.L. & I.L. Publishing of Jericho, publisher of the Long Island Real Estate News Letter. The activity includes the following projects:

title: PrinceFigueredo Final
description: BANGOR, Maine, July 15 (AP) Dean Prince of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Tony Figueredo of Miami each won two matchplay rounds yesterday to reach the final of the United States amateur publiclinks golf championship.

title: VIEWS VARY WIDELY OVER SOLAR HEATING
description: LOS ANGELES  Homeowners venturing into the new realm of solar heating may encounter either significant encouragement, discouragement or an inconclusive neutrality from their utility companies and lending institutions  depending on where they live.

title: Citation for Contempt Is Sought by Walinsky
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15  Adam waiincky, a New York City lawyer who is suing the Gay Activists Alliance and some of its members for $2.2 million in damages because of a raucous demonstration they allegedly staged at his Scarsdale home last August, has asked a State Supreme Court justice here to bold the defendants in contempt of court for continuing to harass him.

title: An Auspicious Year At Britain's Stratford
description: While the audience is still settling into its seats, a bearded. Scruffy, obstreperous young man, clenching a bottle of whisky, begins to shout and to create a disturbance in the aisle. A helpful female usher tries to break up the melee. The rascal shoves her aside, saying, No bloody woman is going to talk to me like that, and then climbs on stage, gets into a fistfight, and starts to destroy the elaborate scenery. This is the boisterous beginning of Michael Bogdanov's iconoclastic production of The Taming of the Shrew, the centerpiece of this summer's season at Stratford. Despite the theatricality of the staged altercation  and the fact that it has been well reported in the London press  it is handled with such ease, spontaneity and conviction by the actor Jonathan Pryce that it still takes some theatergoers by surprise. At the performance that I attended, two women in the front row were so unnerved by the disturbance that they scurried up the aisle to safety. A real usher led them back to their seats, hurriedly explaining that the performance was in progress.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Man of La Mancha, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Aug. 12). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50. (201) 4297662. WestminsterThm ter.

title: Janice Trebbi Is Engaged To Bruce Tilton Richards
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Trebbi of Trenton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Lorraine Trebbi, to Bruce Tilton Richards. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Prescott Langdon Richards of Cummaquid, Mass. The marriage will take place in the fall.

title: Queens Firefighter Dies
description: A 96yearold firefighter died of heart attack while fighting a brush fire in the College Point, Queens. It was the department's first onduty fatality in nearly a year.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on military procurement authorization bill, passed, 87 to 2, July 11.

title: Xerox on Trial: A Defeat, A Second Suit
description: The long antitrust fight between the Xerox Corporation and the SCM Corporation appeared to end in a split decision last Monday when a Federal jury found that Xerox had indeed maintained an illegal monopoly of plainpaper copying machines but ruled in such a way as to reduce sharply the amount of damages likely to be assessed. But the story didn't end there.

title: Hydrants Spark Greenwich Tax Suit
description: GREENWICH'S property tax rate this year is an attractive $25.50 per thousand dollars of assessed valuation, reportedly the lowest in the state except for Warren's $18.50. According to local officials, this financial miracle has been accomplished through the avoidance of bonded debt, the constant updating of realestate assessments, the broadening of the tax base through office construction  and a windfall from the thousands of wealthy residents who pay for their own roads, storm drains, street lighting, security, snow and leaf removal and, until now, fire hydrants.

title: Robert Edward Manganello Weds Phoebe Anne Milliken
description: Phoebe Anne Milliken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrish Hill Milliken of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church to Robert Edward Manganello, son of Mr: and Mrs. Samuel S. Manganello of Ellicott City, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold Bassage, who was assisted by the Rev. Vincent O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Satellite Is Launched in Mission To Probe Earth's Magnetic Field
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 15 (AP)  A Delta rocket lifted a satellite of the European Space Agency off its launch pad yesterday in a mission to probe Earth's magnetic field.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: To add another dimension to its current antique carousel exhibition, the MuseuminthePark at Eisenhower Park at East Meadow has set up a working merrygoround ride outside the building. Inside, a Baroquestyle carousel, complete with painted menagerie, fourseater chariot and classic jumping horses from the old HerschellSpillman grand carousel, is on display. A film describing the restoration of a similar vintage model now operating in Michigan and photographs and text panels detailing the origins of carousels from mantohorsetogaspower machines complete the exhibition. As an extra attraction, members of the Long Island Wood Carvers Association with experience in the restoration of antique carousels will demonstrate their craft today at 1 P.M. The museum, near Parking Field 6A, is open daily from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. and costs 25 cents to visit, with children under 5 admitted free. The fourminute outside ride is 35 cents. Proceeds go to the Friends of the Nassau County Museum, who eventually would like to reassemble the antique carrousel and make it a permanent Eisenhower Park movable feast.

title: Editor Who Brews Controversy
description: WESTHAMPTON AS David J. Willmott tells it, the moguls of American journalism did not exactly treat him like an equal when he attended the American Newspaper Publishers Convention some time ago. After all, his twiceweekly paper. Suffolk Life. is given away, hung on mailboxes or thrown, unbidden, onto front walks from Montauk to eastern Smithtown. But on the Island's East End, Suffolk Life and, most particularly, Mr. Willmott's irreverent and crusading attorials have become an influential force and a rallying point for causes like the abolition of the Suffolk County Legislature or the enactment of a Californiatype Proposition 13.

title: ART
description: WHITE PLAINS TO HEAR some Westchester residents tell it, Westchester County is the driest cultural desert, offering painfully little V in the visual arts. Such claims are ludicrous.

title: Lag in World Food Output Renews Fear of Famine
description: Percapita food production in most developing countries declined in 1977, according to figures made public by the World Food Council, the top United Nations agency monitoring the global food situation.

title: A Correction
description: A line was dropped in last week's article on volunteer firefighters. The full comment of Pat Bliss was that men need a night out with the boys, and some men get it by sitting in a bar. Some men probably join just to get out of the house once in a while, but now see how much time they put into training and fire prevention; I'm impressed with how professional they are. The article also said that there were no female volunteers in Westchester. Judith Bevans of Pound Ridge has been a member of the Pound Ridge department for five years.

title: Pilot Science Program for Disabled Students Opens
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  Nine young students sat in the warm lecture hall taking notes about the acidbase experiments they would be conducting in a few moments. Half watched the lecturer as he chalked points on the blackboard; the other half had their eyes riveted on the young signer who translated the words into hand language.

title: Rent Control, Suburban Style
description: The village of Dobbs Ferry on the east bank of the Hudson seven miles north of New York City has many distinctions. Among them are its spectacular river views, its handsome architecture, and its revolutionary war history. In later years, Diamond Jim Brady made legends at hotel parties here and Irving Berlin made music at his country home.

title: FISHING
description: FOR the angler in northern New Jersey waters, some of the finest fishing of the season is under way in Sandy Hook Bay as well as New York Bay. Good amounts of large weakfish have arrived, supplementing the numerous schools of bluefish.

title: CHESS
description: when Vlastimil Hort, the leading Czechoslovakian grandmaster, offered his wry advice that it is better to play the secondbest move in the opening, since everyone knowstoo well what to do about the best play, he wasn't overstating the case in the interest of wit. It is true that secondbest moves and what to do about them are soon forgotten.

title: The Disposal by Inge Is Staged
description: The question that kept troubling a spectator at the performance of William Inge's The Disposal, being shown at the Intar theater through Tuesday, is why any group, sufficiently interested in William Inge to thumb through his lesserknown works. would expose sun a feeble and inept piece to the scrutiny of an audience. Written not too long before his death in 1973, the play, once known as The Last Pad, is a measure of Inge's waning powers and his faulty judgment that he let such a piece of writing survive. The language is clichridden, the situations banal, the arguments simplistic. And the ending is so corny that it makes the death of Little Nell seem a passage out of Antonin Artaud.

title: THE MARKETS
description: A sharp  and surprising  rally on Friday sent the stock market briskly ahead last week to scatter some of the gloom clouds gathering recently over Wall Street. After the close of trading on Thursday, the Federal Reserve announced that the nation's basic money supply soared by nearly $5 billion in the latest week, which logically should have sent fears of tighter credit shuddering through the investment community.

title: TIE TROUBLE910011R
description: The pale gray Ford LTD speeds across the Mall, a genial elderly chauffeur at the wheel. To his right, in a seat normally left vacant in such circumstances or at least reserved for a lesser aide, sits the United States combined Special Trade Representative (with rahinetlevel Ambassadorial rank) and Special Counselor on Inflation. Robert S. Strauss, exuding selfconfidence and poise, has just turned in masterful performance on the subject of inflation for the Senate Banking Committee and is now in pursuit of Californiabound plane that will carry him to trade talks with a key Japanese official.

title: MY FIRST SEASON ON THE AISLE
description: The grass is as green around the Festival Theater in Stratford, Ontario, as it was a year ago. The swans are just as polished and cross, and the Canadians teeter upon the lawn in what seem to be the identical blue linen jackets and pale dresses with fur stoles. As for me, I am 23 years older, somewhat heavier, and much jumpier than in the summer of 1977.

title: O.A.U. DRAFT ASSAILS FOREIGN TROOP USE
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 15  African foreign ministers, meeting here to prepare for next week's Organization of African Unity summit conference, condemned foreign military bases and alliances with outside powers today.

title: A Film About Hope
description: WEST ORANGE AS the film opens, a young man is calmly driving a car down country road. The camera then follows him into a telephone laboratory, where he works as ianitor.

title: The big three of rock promoters Page 8
description: The big three of rock promoters Page 8

title: Evangelical Christian Movement Being Reshaped by Radical Wing
description: The evangelical Christian movement, a religious force of growing import in the United States, is being reshaped, largely as a result of the increasing influence of values and themes once associated with the youth counterculture of the 1960's.

title: The Longest Walk Was Designed to Raise Consciousness, Not Backlash
description: WASHINGTONAt Plymouth Rock in 1620, it has been said, the Pilgrims fell upon their knees, and then upon the Aborigines. The early centuries mythological, interethnic Thanksgivings and romances like that of John Rolfe and Pocahontas do not paper over the brutal treatment of the Indians by frontiersmen. The Indians contend that the same sort of treatment continues today, less violently, but with genocide still in mind.

title: Sutton Plans to Sue Umpire for Ejection
description: ST. LOUIS, July 15 (UPI)  Don Sutton, the Los Angeles Dodger pitcher who was ejected by Doug Harvey, umpire, for defacing the baseball in game last night with the St. Louis Cardinals, says he is filing suit against Harvey and the National League.

title: Miss Horvath, 12, Wins L. I. Women's Net Final
description: ROSLYN, L.I., July 15  Twelveyearold Kathy Horvath of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., continued to dominate the Eastern tennis scene today when she won the Long Island women's championship. The tall, longlegged youngster beat Kathy Dalton of Port Washington, 75, 60, in the final at the Tower Tennis Club.

title: 3 Brands of Vodka Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  A recall of three imported brands of vodka has been ordered because they contain excessive amounts of flavoring material. The recall was ordered yesterday by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which said that the liquors contained too much coumarin, an aromatic flavoring. The vodkas were produced in Poland, Austria and the Soviet Union. The recalled brands are Po!mos J.A. Baczewski and Sovetskaya.

title: Lizabeth Pope, Police Officer, Married To Greg Garton, Sergeant, in Wyoming
description: The marriage of Lizabeth Pope, a police officer in Laramie, Wyo., to Greg A. Garton, a sergeant in the Wheatland (Wyo.) Police Department, took place in Wheatland yesterday. The ceremony was performed in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. John J. Corrigan and the Rev. Sidney Hoadley, rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Wheatland.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures,are for the preceding week and latest available

title: Catholics Reassess Views on Spiritual Movements
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn are reevaluating some basic assumptions about their congregants as a result of a recent study taken by the diocese.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: Noel Perrin theorizes that regional or other breweries go out of business because of beer presently sold in cans and nonreturnable bottles. I am grateful to him for inviting comment on his theory. I am happy to oblige.

title: Egypt Rounds Up 400 Criminals
description: CAIRO, July 15 (Reuters)  The Egyp. tian police have recaptured 400 escaped prisoners and seized 3,500 guns in a big operation along the Upper Nile, the newspaper Al Gomhouria reported today. The paper said the weapons, made in Israel and India, had a value of $8 million. About 3,000 policemen took part in the 12day drive and stormed several villages. It was the first police raid in 18 years in the area, where the criminals bad spread terror, the paper said.

title: Donna C. Atanasio Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Atanasio of B rooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Christine Atanasio, to Frank A.D. Andrea 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrea Jr. of Old Brookville, L.1.

title: H.U.D. Admits Failure On Rural Areas Housing
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  In selfexamining report, the Department of Housing and Urban Development says it has failed in its responsibility to provide housing and community development assistance to rural areas.

title: 36,000 Vials of a Poison Ivy Drug Being Recalled as Overly Potent
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  About 36,000 vials of a poison ivy extract are being recalled because they are too potent and make problems worse for people suffering from the itchy skin irritation, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Poll Finds That Trial Judges Rate Lawyers as at Least Competent
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (Reuters) Federal and state judges rate the vast majority of trial lawyers who appear before them as being at least minimally competent, according to a survey.

title: Deaths
description: AVNERSidney H., beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Judith, Kenneth and Jeffrey, brother of Beatrice Shavit, Dorris Avner. today, 10:30am,Services Resnick and Buch binder Jetters Memorial Chapel, 188th St. and Hillside Ave., Hollis.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2): Face the Nation: Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader.

title: Trees and Shrubs Are Easy to Root When You Learn How
description: There was a time not so long ago when plant propagation was considered the exclusive domain of the professionals. The methods used were jealously guarded as trade secrets. Happily this condition no longer exists and there is an open exchange of information.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: In an Opinion Page article on June 18, Ann Bastian stated that social services should not be cut. She feels, that much of the tax burden should be shifted to corporations. If that were done, we would still pay those taxes in hidden way in the form of higher prices for products of the corporations. The real solution to the

title: Iacocca to Ford: What Did I Do Wrong?
description: When executives disagree with Henry Ford 2d, he likes to remind them whose name is on the front of the building where they all work. Last week this matter of nomenclature was brought to Lee A. lacocca's attention in particularly dramatic fashion when he was ousted as president of the Ford Motor Company.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 15 (Reuters)  Thailand and Cambodia agreed in principle today to try to end incidents along their border and to exchange ambassadors, said the Thai Foreign Minister, Uppadit Pachariyangkun.

title: It's Blueberry Time In the Pine Barrens
description: THE the most ideal spot in the world for blueberries, according to Duke Galletta, head of the Atlantic Blueberry Corporation, near Weymouth in the pine barrens of Atlantic County, is right in his own backyard. The proximity of the sea and the mixture of sand and peat in the savanna of the pine barrens is the combination that makes New Jersey the world's largest supplier of blueberries.

title: DINING OUT
description: Acomplicated but fortuitous flattire problem unexpectedly stranded us on Shelter Island for dinner. We had the pleasure of discovering La Terrasse, tucked into the waterfront of the sealevel section of Shelter Island Heights.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: ESTATES are very much in the news. The 1,600acre Rosenstiel property in Greenwich is under negotiation for a reputed $20million  the largest personal estate to come on the market in Fairfield County in years.

title: A Cape Cod ClamDigger's Scheme for Living Off the. Land
description: TRURO, MASS. When the Pilgrims first landed at Provincetown in the bleak fall of 1620, they stayed for only month before departing for the rocky coast at Plymouth, because they couldn't find enough to eat on Cape Cod.

title: Lessons in How to Film The Troubled Psyche
description: Capturing the disturbances of the mind on film poses tricky problems. Mental states are invisible; film is the medium of the visible image. In translating one into the other, it is easy to be overly explicit, clumsy or downright fanciful.

title: BRIDGE
description: Ambitions come in two varieties  sternly realistic and hopelessly remote. The latter category is symbolized by the small boy who wants to be President when he grows up.

title: Does SchoolTax Reform Really Work?
description: THE recent New York State Supreme Court ruling that the state's system of financing education is unconstitutional throws the Legislature into the middle of one of the most controversial and powerful educational developments of the 1970's: schoolfinance reform.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter held a town meeting in West Berlin, answering questions for nearly an hour on subjects ranging from West Berlin's security to the size of his daughter's weekly allowance. The polite audience of 1,000 Berliners seemed delighted by the candor of the President's replies and applauded when he pledged Whatever may be, Berlin stays free. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Headliners
description: C. Douglas Dillon has the power to make dead people keep their promises. Last week, Nassau County Surrogate John D. Bennett ruled that the estate of Joan Whitney Payson had pay the Metropolitan Museum of Art $1.5 million in fulfillment of a pledge she made in conversation with Mr. Dillon when he was president of the museum. No signed paper was produced to prove Mrs. Payson's intentions; Mr. Dillon testified to the conversation and the judge found for the museum.

title: Conception Takes A Brave New Form
description: Aldous Huxley cast his shadow. A baby conceived, not in the usual manner, but in a test tube, is about to be born in England, it was announced last week and the British went wild with excitement. Some thought it blessed; some thought it fearsome but simply as a scientific event it was a significant step toward greater understanding of the reproductive process.

title: Stiffer Regulations Being Sought For PostSecondary Education
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 15 Mounting concern over abuses and fraud in postsecondary education is forcing the states and accrediting associations, underprodding from the Federal Government, toward more stringent regulation of the nation's trade schools, colleges and universities.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: ISRAEL AND THE DEAD SEA SCROLLS, by Edmund Wilson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $5.95.) During the last 20 years of his life, the distinguished critic Edmund Wilson (18951972) became fascinated with the Hebrew language and with the ancient scrolls that had been found in caves near the Dead Sea. This volume brings together all his writing that resulted  his account of the scrolls discovery and his interpretation of their significance for the JudeoChristian tradition, his views on Israel and on modern Jewish literature. Leon Edel's foreword puts it all in focus.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Few calamities in New York can be attributed to happenstance. So when a series of explosions ripped through nearly two miles of sewers in the South Bronx last March 24, damaging an apartment building, shattering store windows and injuring 11 persons slightly, Mayor Koch empaneled an informal board of inquiry to find out the cause. There was speculation that someone had dumped fuel or cleaning fluid into a sewer.

title: Louisville Firemen Resume Picketing as Talks Fail
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 15 (UPI) Firemen returned to their picket, lines early today after a sevenhour round of contract talks failed to produce a contract settlement.

title: Moynihan Finds U.S. Aid to State Rose $7.7 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Federal payments to New York and to New Yorkers increased by $7.7 billion to a total of $34 billion in fiscal 1977, the largest gain of any of the 50 states, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said today.

title: An ExD.A. Marches On
description: HENRY F. O'BRIEN is a long way from one of the most bizarre incidents in recent political and governmental history  a charge by a Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, that Mr. O'Brien, then the District Attorney of Suffolk, was guilty of criminal homosexuality. The charge followed Mr. O'Brien's accusation of coruption against the Commissioner.

title: Keynes Retooled
description: GREENVALE, N.Y.  Not so 16 Ang ago there was talk of a New Economics, based on the teachings of John Maynard Keynes, the English economist. Today one hears complaints of the bankruptcy of modern economics and that Keynesian theory is dead or has become irrelevant. Both the previous euphoria and the subsequent disenchantment seem to involve some confusions about what Lord Keynes taught.

title: GARDENING
description: THE best way to get through July and August as far as plant tending goes is to mulch. There are just too many demands on anyone's time. There are the essentials to contend with  the beach, golf course, boat, picnic, tennis court, jogging, biking.

title: Ann Dunham Is Married To Michael A. Hartson
description: Ann Johnson Dunham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Putnam Dunham of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Alan Hartson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Louis Hartson of Keene, N. Y. The Rev. Robert 0. Lamitie performed the ceremony in St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church in Keene.

title: A Traditional Unit of Government Adjusts to Change
description: ATLANTA  The stereotype of the county official is a portly middleaged white male, a bit rustic and bereft of new ideas. There still are some of those around. But last week the National Association of Counties elected a black woman, Charlotte Williams, Commissioner of Genesee County, Mich., as its president, a sign of change in the most arcane and traditional layer of government in the complex Federal system. The county is the fastest changing governmental unit in the United States, Patricia R. Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, told some 4,000 delegates attending the association's annual convention.

title: Following Britain Down
description: PORTOFERRAIO, ItalyThe political analysts have been expecting Britain's Prime Minister, James Callaghan, to call a general election this fall, while the Labor Party can still take credit for pulling the country from the economic abyss of three years ago and before the expected new wave of inflation. His Government's achievements have been real enough, but the underlying economic situation remains dismal nevertheless.

title: Clare Schaffeld Sets Wedding in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry G. Schaffeld of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Clare Schaffeld, to Richard C. Fooshee, son of Mr. and Mrs. 1. H. Fooshee of Austin, Tex.

title: Louis Tutelian To Be a Bride
description: Louise May Tutelian, assistant Sunday editor of The Trenton Times, plans to be married Oct. 14 to Marc Jaime Morgenstern, associate producer of the New Jersey Nightly News, a joint production of WNET and New Jersey Public Television.

title: Polls Finds 58% Favor Rights Proposal
description: The American public supports ratitication of the proposed equal rights amendment by a margin of 58 to 31 percent but evenly divided on the question of whether to extend the time for passage, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I applaud Sidney Kramer's decision not to sell Richard Nixon's book in his bookstore [May 7]. To call it censorship, as Donald Hutter does, is inaccurate; there are plenty of places people can buy the book if they want it. Sidney Kramer is not a government; he is deciding nothing for other people, just for that portion of human activity into which he's putting his life, influence, and reputation:

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Annie Get Your Gun, starring Kathy Wheeler and Howard Lear. Tonight and Wednesday to next Sunday at 8:30 P.M. $5.50 to $7. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rtes. 6 and 118.6281169.

title: Legislature Has Gone Big Time, May Be Going Full Time
description: ALBANY  A few years ago, a former New York legislator was saying, the question was whether we would get out by St. Patrick's Day or Easter. Now, as those who returned to a balmy summer session last week would attest, the suggestion of a Memorial Day windup of the Legislature greeted by guffaws, and even a target date of July is good for a snicker.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15  Aisco Stables Sharp Belle won the 33d modem running of Monmouth Park's oldest stakes today, scoring a twolength victory in the $55,050 Monmouth Oaks on a muddy track. The filly returned $16.60, $7.20 and $4.60 for $2 across the board to her supporters in the crowd of 20,079.

title: Number of Measles Cases Down By More Than 50% This Year
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (AP)  The number of measles cases reported in the United States in the first six months of 1978 was less than half the number reported in the same period a year ago, the national Center for Disease Control said yesterday.

title: STATE'S FARMERS SET NEW CHEESE RECORD
description: ALBANY, July 12  For the second consecutive year. New York State towns, dairy farmers and processing plants combined in 1977 to produce a record amount of cheese, 407 million pounds, according to figures issued this week by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: ART
description: LINCROFT IS it possible that a show devoted to the plight of New Jersey animals that are listed as endangered species can be seen as an art show? Yes, it is, if it is like the exhibition at the Monmouth Museum.

title: Lining Up at the Starting Gate
description: HARTFORD THERE is a $25,000ayear parttime job available at the State Capitol next year, and it's real dream. No one expects you to do anything in particular, you get a big office, a little travel if you like, and there is no problem sneaking away for an afternoon of tennis or golf.

title: For World's Chess Title, It's Mr. Cool vs. Hothead
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines. July 15 The two men who will face each other across the chess board when the World Championship match begins here Tuesday have much in common. Each will be playing his first title match, each was born in the Soviet Union and each is a product of that country's nononsense system of turning out tough chess players  a system that accounts in good part for the Soviet Union's virtual monopoly on world champions.

title: Forest Hills Business Misses U.S. Open
description: They had quite a racket going, the children of Forest Hills, Queens, when the United States Open was in town. Distraught ticketholders driving up and down the private, residential streets were faced every few yards with the sign No Parking Any Time anu wow( succumb eventually to the children's offers of parking space in the driveways of their homes. The price $5 on weekdays and up to $10 for the Saturday and Sunday finals.

title: U.S. Trucking of Gas Perilous, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  A New England gas company has told the Government that it is unable to estimate the number of fatalities that might occur if one of its large liquefiedgas trucks crashed while traveling from Boston to Providence, R.I.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN most people decide to buy a pet, they stick to the common choicesdogs, cats, birds or fishbut there are those who have the need to possess a more exotic creature, like a python. And therein hangs a clue to the mystery of why eight Long Islanders have taken sick since the end of May.
