It is a story that has captured the interest of health detectives, including Suffolk Health Commissioner David Harris.

title: Primer on School Tax Reform
description: THE recent State Supreme Court ruling that the state's system of financing education is unconstitutional throws the Legislature into the middle of one of the most controversial and powerful educational developments of the 1970's: school finance reform.

title: TV VIEW
description: Trapped in the arrogance of television tampc.ring, when is enough enough? For Robert Radnitz the moment of detonation came a few weeks ago after watching a twopart presentation of his Where thelilies Bloom on CBS. Phoning this writer from his California office, Mr. Radnitz said he found his movie butchered and the result was horrendous. In fact, I have not seen Mr. Radnitz's film,either intact or chopped up, but his cry of outrage is shockingly familiar to anyone in contact with the broadcasting industry.

title: Ludmilla Schollar, Ballet Dancer; Taught Here and on the Coast
description: Ludmilla Schollar, a dance teacher and former member of the Maryinsky (now Kirov), Kirov and Diaghilev Ballets Busses, died Monday at the Marshall Hale Memorial Hospital in San Francisco. She was 90 years old.

title: Food
description: Until recently, the word Italian attached to food conjured up most American minds something, probably spaghetti, smothered tomato sauce. Fortunately. this notion is being dispelled as the delights of such things as pesto sauces and the endless variety of pastas are discovered. But still much overlooked in America are gnocchi  a kind of dumpling. and one of the great pleasures the northern Italian table. There is gnocchi Piedmontstyle. made with potatoes: gnocchi Romanstyle, made with semolina: and gnocchi antica (literally, oldfashioned gnocchi), made with flour and eggs. Here, the recipe for the most elegant of the antica variety of gnocchi  gnocchi alla parigina or (in French) gnocchi parisien.

title: Foreign Banks on the March
description: The growing presence of foreign banks in the United States has Congress, regulatory authorities and American bankers worried  for somewhat different reasons.

title: LETTERS
description: Harold Bloom's putative review of Poems of R. P. Blackmur (Feb. 5) is as good a comment on Mr. Bloom as we have. He sees criticism, and literature itself, as an example of power, of critical authority  being overturned. Thus it is not so much a matter of being grateful for a distinguished dead man's accomplishments as it is of disposing of him. Exclusively a critic himself, Mr. Bloom gives short shrift to this earlier critic's poetry. He regrets that Mr. Blackmur's poetry lacks the quality of his prose, is not dense and turbulent so that it might win its agon against the past and against contemporaries. Rather than dealing with the poetry, Mr. Bloom is happy to judge Mr. Blackmur's judgments, on Hart Crane and Wallace Stevens for instance, finding his not so altogether ludicrous statement on Crane that he represents every ignorance possible to talent when it has genius a case of defensive anxiety. Worst of all, Mr. Blackmur questioned Freud, one of Mr. Bloom's principal authorities in his continuing systembuilding. Little wonder Mr. Bloom is upset. Especially since he has in his own practice tended to make hysteria a norm. Accordingly, we are told, the absence of this, of Romantic violence, ruined Mr. Black.

title: New Specious Cash Sales Law Aids Homeowners in Suffolk Coun
description: Two years ago, the Smith family added an extension to their South Shore home in Brentwood to accommodate a new member. Everything appeared in order, and then recently the roof sprang a leak and the Smiths discovered that their contractor had gone out of business.

title: Suit Is Filed Over Whale Quota
description: ANCHORAGE, July 15 (AP)  Two Eskimo whalers and the mayor of the North Slope Borough have filed a class action suit in Federal court over the bowhead whale quota set by the International Whaling C.onimission. The suit seeks to prevent the United States Department of Commerce from enforcing the commission's quota for subsistence whalers. The suit also seeks to declare that the National Marine Fisheries Service's bowbead regulations have no legal authority over whale hunting.

title: France's Patchwork Left Shows Signs of Coming Unpatched
description: PARIS  The internal struggle that has shaken the French Communist Party since the left's election defeat last March has drawn attention from an even more serious dispute within the Socialist Party that threatens the leadership of Francois Mitterrand.

title: Problem High School in Brooklyn Put on Probation
description: Boys and Girls High School in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, plagued in recent years by violence and low academic performance, has become the first New York City public school ever put on probation and stands to lose its right to grant diplomas next year if it does not correct deficiencies by then.

title: Rose Gets Hit in 28th Consecutive Game Swan Hurt
description: CINCINNATI, July 15  Sparky Anderson studied the calendar on the wall of the Cincinnati Reds locker room, frowned like a man afraid of missing the boat and said: We're playing 25 percent our best level, sometimes 50 percent. At that rate, we can't win.

title: A Residency Law Invites Reprisal
description: THE County Board of Legislators is set to vote tomorrow on a proposal that would require county employees to reside in Westchester. This rule would create for Westchester its own version of the Berlin Wall. There is no need for county government to require its employees to state, Ich Bin Ein Westchesterite, when the sole criteria for obtaining and maintaining a job should be performance.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Hundreds of American Indians, joined here by several thousand supporters, today reached the goal of a fivemonth trek to protest proposed legislation that the Indians believe threatens their survival.

title: Midwest Goyern. ors Express Doubts on Tax Drive
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.. July 13The 17thannual meeting of the Midwestern Governor's Conference ended bore today withnost of the participants expressing serious doubts about the longrange value of. the property tax ?? now on ballots aeron the nation.

title: Jersey Earthquake Centered at Oakland
description: THE most powerful earthquake in New Jersey in 16 years rumbled through the Ramapo Fault earlier this month, rattling windows in the small towns along the New JerseyNew York border with the force of several thousand pounds of dynamite.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: British Grand Prix Formula 1 race, at Brands Hatch, England. (Television  Channel 2.4 P.M.)

title: Nastase, Genilaitis Gain Final
description: They traveled together from Wimbledon to New York. They flew to Las Vegas together for the World Team Tennis allstar match and came back yesterday on the same early morning plane to compete in the semifinals here.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The success of the California effort to reduce property taxes substantially by referendum has persuaded people around the country that it can happen to them, too. In town after town, state after state, politicians and consumer groups have moved toward reducing, or at least limiting, the taxes levied on property.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Ortnene or matatnion will control scale crawlers now; follow label dilutions. Last call to feed roses with a general garden fertilizer such as 5105 or 51010. Divide three or four yearold clumps of iris; trim foliage to onethird height and space rhizomes at least six inches apart in groups of three Use malathion or Sevin for lacebugs on pieris; be sure to spray undersides of leaves.

title: INVESTING
description: Along came Congress two years ago and changed the rules on the tax deductions allowed to the owners of vacation houses who rent out their units when they are not using them. The effect was to curb the practice of purchasing vacation units primarily for the purpose of building up tax losses with which to offset other income.

title: Japan's Travel Agents Seek Lure for Tourists While the Dollar Drops
description: TOKYO, July 15  Hoping to lure foreign tourists, a group of Japanese travel agents has proposed that the visitors be exempted from Japan's meal tax. The proposal is aimed at alleviating the financial strain on tourists, already beset by high food prices here and the recent decline in the value of the dollar against the yen.currently everyone is required to pay a 10 percent meal tax whenever a restaurant bill exceeds 2,000 yen a person, or about $9.80 at the current rate of exchange.

title: New Orleans Is Worried Over Symphony's Future
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 15  When New Orleans symphony audiences heard this week that their conductor, Leonard Slatkin, would be moving on to St. Louis the season after next, as rumors had been saying, they were depressed by the news but not more so than they've been all summer, because of another worry, over the future of the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony.

title: Warbler Population Declines 10%
description: M10, Mich., July 15  The population of the Kirtland's warbler has dropped 10 percent in the last year, but Government officials in charge of a special recovery program for the endangered bird are not discouraged.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Some laws can be bent and some can be broken. But one law that holds immutable sway is the First Commandment of the arts: He who pays the piper calls the tune. As it happens, the 12th Mostly Mozart Festival, which gets under way tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall, will be paying considerable attention to Schubert, in observance of the 150th anniversary of his death. And that juxtaposition of artists clearly illustrates the piper's law.

title: Carter Said to Approve Huge Arms Sale to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (Reuters)President Carter has approved the sale to Iran of nearly $600 million in weapons, including 31 Phantom fighterbombers, according to Government sources.

title: U.S. CONCEDES BIAS IN OLD ENERGY UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  The Government has acknowleged that there was a statistical disparity between salaries of female and male professionals at te? Energy Research and Development Administration from 1975 to 1977.

title: Rough Passages
description: ONCE upon a time a journalist named Gail Sheehy went to visit a Yale faculty member named Daniel Levinson. Dr. Levinson was engaged in a study of psychological growth and development during adulthood (a relatively unexplored area at that time) and was focusing on the midlife crisis in males in particular. Mrs. Sheehy had a proposition: She and Dr. Levinson could combine her skills as a writer and his as a researcher, and write a book together on this fascinating new work.

title: ART
description: BROOKVILLE IN the old days  the 1950's and 60's  a few prevailing styles, such as Abstract Expressionism, Pop and lyrical abstraction, dominated the art world. In the 70's, things have got much more complicated. Artists are no longer content to ex.. press themselves in a few stylistic ways. There are so many different styles being exhibited in museums and galleries these days that there seem to be as many styles as artists.

title: Notes: Keeping Tabs On the Casino Craze
description: The great casino craze, currently spreading like wildfire in the United States  and in Europe  is expected to gather even more momentum with the recent announcement that Resorts International in Atlantic City grossed $16 million in its first full month as the first legal gambling casino in this country outside Nevada.

title: GARDENING
description: THE best way to get through July and August as far as plant tending goes is to mulch. There are just too many demands on anyone's time. There are the essentials to contend with  the beach, golf course, boat, picnic, tennis court, jogging, biking.its tne weeds that seem to get out of hand now. No matter how carefully they are pulled up, they come back with as much or even more vigor than.before. The weeding cycle seems endless without a mulch. This magical layer of organic materials can solve almost all the problems if it's the right sort.

title: Letters: The Search For Secret Beaches
description: To the Editor: Every year when traveling through Spain, my family and I make a point of photographing ourselves on a deserted stretch of beach, just to record the fact that such places still exist. There is no need to seek out an island as Robert Packard did in his article, In Search of Solitude on the Mediterranean's Secret Beaches (Travel Section, June 18). The Spanish mainland still has hundreds of miles of virgin white beaches, and most are readily accessible by car, most notably on the Costa de la Luz, between the Straits of Gibraltar and Huelva.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: T he 250th anniversary of the birth of Robert Adam is being celebrated in England and Scotland this month, and during those twoandahalf centuries he has had his ups and downs.

title: Timothy Harr, Miss Crigler Are Married
description: Winfield Potter Crigler and Timothy Adams Harr, 1976 graduates of the University of Virginia School of Law, were married yesterday in Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Brian Crenshaw, pastor of the Buncombe Street United Method-ist Church, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Bothwell Crigler, parents of the bride, who is an associate with the Washington law firm of Williams & Jensen. The bridegroom, an associate with Covington & Burling, Washington lawyers, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Gottlieb Harr Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: A New Twist in Nastase Drama
description: Exit the Nastase, villain. Enter The Nastase, martyr. Under three months suspension from lucrative Grand Prix tennis tournaments, including the 1978 United States Open, hit with $5,000 fine by his peers, docked $7,000 for missing Wednesday's World Team Tennis match, past his peak and no longer considered in the top 10, the gifted Rumanian has given up seeking scorn for seeking sympathy.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: WHEN making sizable patches on a plaster wall or ceiling, or on drywall where a considerable amount of patching plaster or spackling compound must be used, the doityourselves often have trouble making a patch blend in neatly with the rest of the surface.

title: Yankees Beaten, 82
description: The New York Yankees and the Kansas City Royals, antagonists in the American League championship playoffs the last two seasons, met again at the Stadium last night, and the Royals won, 82, in the first game of a threegame series.

title: 3 Clubs Sponsor Math Baseball
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, Houston Astros and Atlanta Braves are cosponsoring a mathematical baseball league this season.

title: Last Week, More Inconclusive Talks
description: WASHINGTONAlmost nine months after President Carter announced that a new SovietAmerican agreement limiting strategic arms was within sight, Secretary of State Cyrus Vance traveled to Geneva last week for vet more arms talk. Both Mr.

title: Shows and Events
description: Thursday, Friday and Saturday Antiques show and sale, First Presbyterian Church, Main Stret, Sparta; Thursday and Friday, noon to 10 P.M.; Saturday, noon to 5:30 P.M. Twentythree dealers. The show is sponsored by United Presbyterian Women. Admission is $1.50. (201)7296197.

title: Central African Empire Replaces Prime Minister, Broadcast Says
description: PARIS. July 15 (AP)  Emperor JeanBedel Bokassa of the Central African Empire has replaced Prime Minister Ange Patasse with former Education Minister Henri Maldou, according to an official broadcast monitored here.

title: Educating The Parents
description: MUCH recent discussion has focused on the issue of educational malpractice. The frequency of court cases would indicate an increased awareness about learning problems and the lack of early identification and treatment.to Boulder, Colo., a new court case focusing attention upon another aspect of this problem, namely malparenting. A young man is now suing his parents for 4350,000 in damages that he claims were caused through emotional distress. This case (and another one in Los Angeles) illustrates that the growth and development of our young are not simply relegated to an institution; instead, they are shared by both school and parent.

title: EXOFFICER SOUGHT IN DRUG CASE SEIZED
description: ST.k.ot1FORD, Conn., July 15  A former police sergeant in the narcotics division here has been arrested in Georgia on charges that he sold heroin in New York City, Federal officials said here yesterday.

title: DINING OUT
description: FOR many New Jerseyans, New Hope (Pa.) the place on the other side where the grass is greener, the shops are more chic and the restaurants are classier. At the moment, three New Hope restaurants confirm the clich.

title: Tosca Sung at the Mall in Park
description: For a few hours on Thursday night, visitors to the Mall in Central Park could imagine that they were in a mediumsized Italian town enjoying an openair performance of Puccini's Tosca. The New York Grand Opera's staging of the work was the first of three productions the company has planned for the city's operagoers this summer. While the overall quality of this Tosca may have been strictly Italian provincial, at least it was free of charge and in the proper Puccinian spirit.

title: STAMPS
description: Two years to the day that Viking spacecraft landed on Mars in one of the crowning achievements of the space spectacular of the 70's, the United States is issuing new 10cent stamp to commemorate the success of the Viking Space Program that extended human observation to the surface of another planet.

title: The Rubells: A Family Dynasty in Tennis
description: The grandfather, a lean; wiry man, had his arm around the boy's shoulders as they walked toward the tennis court. He leaned down and whispered something in the boy's ear, patted him on the head and went to the sideline to await the start of the match.

title: Taking the Baby Along on Journeys in Europe: Plan, Pack, Nap
description: My son, Alexander, who is 19 months old, has been traveling regularly since he was a month old. He has made many trips in Italy, where I have lived for years, and to Austria, where I have friends and relatives. He has been each to England, West Germany and Yugoslavia and once to France and the United States.

title: FISHING
description: THE best variety of fishing around the Island this week is in Long Island Sound. Bluefish have invaded the western end of the Sound. Striped bass fishing has Picked up along the edges of the points, and along the bottom, blackfish and putties are available in good numbers. On the South Shore, fluke fishing is living up to the description of fluky. The fishing generally is slow there, although the imminent arrival of snappers  baby bluefish  should liven things up. Otherwise, the action is all offshore with bluefish and sharks.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ROSLYN IF you're looking for something simple and inexpensive, you may not find it in the village of Roslyn. Use the clock tower at the intersection of Main Street and Northern Boulevard as your point of reference, but forget about using this wellknown fixture as a timepiece, since it doesn't keep accurate time.

title: Nancy Aborn, Teacher, Bride of Kenneth Duffy
description: The marriage of Nancy Louise Aborn to Kenneth Charles Duffy took place yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Joel Baehr, a UnitarianUniversalist minister, performed the garden ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Aborn.

title: Glenna Wright Married
description: Glenna Wright and Robert A. Soriano were married yesterday in the Chapel of Syracuse University by the Rev. James Cesta, a Roman Catholic priest. Mr. and Mrs. William Wright of Syracuse and Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Soriano of Ocean Township, N.J., are the parents of the couple. The bride, a University of Mississippi graduate, is a teacher. tier husband, an alumnus of a Rutgers University and the University of. Syracuse Law School. is a clerk in the Brooklyn office of Federal Judge Mark A. Cost ;I nt ino of the Eastern Dist rict of N.

title: POSTAL NEGOTIATORS CONFIDENT OF PACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Postal unions and the management of the Postal Service met through the weekend here, with all parties expressing confidence that a new labor agreement could be reached by Thursday, when the current contract expires.

title: Tidbit, a Cocker Spaniel, Is on Top of Dog World
description: Kenilworth, Cape Cod, Staten Island, North Shore and Delaware County all these kennel club prefixes represent new bestinshow labels Q. Tabaka's Tidbit of Wynden, C.D.X, can affix to her traveling crates. Over the last five weekends the black cocker spaniel compiled five top awards and six sporting groups in an overall record reflecting 17 bests.

title: Home of the Unicorn
description: LET me confess to a bias in favor of the authentic traveler, as opposed to the tourist, whose most intense experience usually has to do with the shortcomings of his accommodations. The equipment of the authentic traveler comprises not credit cards, but a certain number of human qualities, such as stamina, patience, indifference to personal comfort, a gift for being at the same time detached and absorbed, a knack for ferreting out odd information and the ability to make the most of chance encounters.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ADOZEN youths enclosed in an outdoor rink are cpasing a nobounce streethockey ball. Wearing helmets, shin guards and gloves, they wield plastic sticks and shoot at an aluminum goal. Guarded by a goalie who is protected better than a knight in armor, this is organized street hockey as it exists today.

title: A Losing Proposition for Carter
description: President Carter hasn't had much personal financial success since taking office and turning his holdings over to a socalled blind trust.

title: Lowering the Boom On New Rent Increases
description: Late last month, a group of six men and two women sat down at a conference table in the small auditorium of Lower Manhattan building and, as several members of the public and news media looked on, quietly discussed the significance of several statisticsladen charts.

title: ANTIQUES
description: PARAMUS THE stockintrade at the shopping malls in Hackensack and Paramus is of the now world New styles, new furniture, new design or modern nostalgia. And this is probably rightly so.

title: Tighter Reins on Bankers
description: The notoriety of the Bert Lance banking scandal has done some good, according to Representative Fernand J. St. Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island. His bill, which would prohibit many of the practices engaged in by the ousted Budget Director, was unanimously approved last week by the House Committee on Banking, Currency and Urban Affairs, which he chairs.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: WITH resale prices and building costs rising at rapid pace, it is not uncommon today to see $100,000 price tags on homes that are lackluster in design and construction. The very word luxury, too, seems to have become devalued.

title: SPORTS
description: NORWALK JULY means summer, and summer means water, if you're one of the lucky ones within reach of a large lake or, even better, the Sound. But even those people not really near water manage to get there these days, and ally body of water on any hot summer day looks as if it's being swum, sailed, powered, fished, clammed, lobstered and waterskied to death.

title: Margaret T. Samek Is Fiancee of Richard J. Peyton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Samek of Valley Forge, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Theodora Samek, to Richard John Peyton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Peyton of Hackensack, N. J.

title: U.S. to Ease Job Hunt For People 55 and Older
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  It will be easier for older, lowincome persons to obtain parttime Federal jobs under new rules announced by the Labor Departmerit.

title: BRITAIN ASKS SHIFT OF MIDEAST TALKS; TERRORISM FEARED
description: BONN, July 15  Concerned by reports of possible terrorism, Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain asked the United States, Egypt and Israel today to cancel plans for a meeting of foreign ministers in London. He suggested that they find a site with better security, American nificialc said.

title: Computer Helps Albany Create Order From Chaos
description: ALBANY, July 15  One consequence al big government is that so many people do so many things that different people 3ften do the same things at the same time and don't even notice.

title: Pumps and Drainage Canals, Not the French Quarter and Jazz, Are Keeping Soggy New Orleans Alive
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP)1 Some folks say that if it weren't for the French Quarter this town would die. Truth is, water pumps and drainage canals, not Bourbon Street and jazz. keen it alive.

title: Byrd Doubts a Ratifying Of Arms Pact at Present
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that Soviet heavyhandedness in imprisoning dissidents had made it impossible for the Senate to ratify any new arms control agreement at this time.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The American legal system guarantees the right of citizens to a speedy trial before a jury of their peers. But who are the peers of corporate mammoths like Xerox, which nurtured and dominates the booming office copying machine market, and SCM, maker of typewriters and appliances, which wanted a piece of that market?

title: Misting Methods
description: july is the ideal month to propagate many woody plants from stem cuttings. have adapted the technique of mist propagation that was once the exclusive province of commercial greenhouse growers and it works suite well. Eauiament is now available to the hobbyist in a kit that makes no demands upon one's knowledge of plumbing or electricity.

title: Disease Should Be Itself
description: ILLNESS AS METAPHOR first appeared as three long essays in the New York Review of Books last January and February. The essays have been revised in a spirit of discretion. Wilhelm Reich's language is no longer described as having its own inimitable looniness'; now it has its own inimitable coherence. Laetrile is a dangerous nostrum rather than a quack cure. John Dean is not repotted as calling Watergate the cancer on the Presidency. The revised version has him explaining Watergate to Nixon: We have a cancer within  close to the Presidency  that's growing. Farright groups no longer have a paranoid view of the world'; now they have a politics of paranoia. All the textual changes I have come across serve the cause of moderation.

title: Biological, Ethical Questions About Laboratory Conception Are Great
description: If all goes well within the next two or three weeks, the first human fertilized within the artificial environment of a culture medium will be born at Oldham General Hospital, 190 miles outside of London. Heralded as the world's first testtube baby, the infant the product of the union of a sperm and an egg within the confines of a tiny laboratory dish containing special nutrient formula.

title: Janet Longstreth Nevius Fiancee of J. C. Wylie Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Foster Nevius of New York and Smoke Rise, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Longstreth Nevius, to James C. Wylie Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Calvin Wylie of Greensboro, N.C.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Changes. Starting tomorrow there will be a couple new faces over at Pocket Books, eldest of the paperback giants. One belongs to its new president  Ronald Busch, who has headed Ballantine Books, one of Pocket's chief competitors, for the last four and onehalf years. Mr. Busch succeeds Peter Mayer, who resigned suddenly a fortnight ago because he and Richard E. Snyder, president of Simon and Schuster, Pocket Books's parent company, have differing views on future directions in the publishing industry. Mr. Mayer stated that he would resume his work publishing after Labor Day. All of which suggests that Publishers Row has an interesting fall coming up.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: WILL the new Administration proposal to make. states full partners in efforts to revitalize cities be a boon to those hardhit Newarks across the country?

title: Portrait of Edward Gorey in brass, and detail of a katydid, by Philip Grausman, at the Washington Art Center
description: WASHINGTON DEPOT CHARLES BAUDELAIRE felt that the good portraitist must combine submissiveness with the power of divination, as well as the actor's talent for empathy. Portraiture may seem a modest genre, tie said, but it is, in fact, difficult to do and calls for an immense intelligence. Having, in effect, defined the art, the critic, who was reviewing the Salon of 1859, went on to say he could find but few examples to adduce.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: FIFTYTWO years ago, it was the toughest ticket in New Jersey: An openingnight seat at the Plaza Theater in Englewood for $1.10, which was a lot of money when orchestra seats were normally 40 cents.

title: Plainfield Track Runs a Winning Streak
description: PLAINFIELD EXCEPT for Sundays and holidays, the dogs here have not stopped running since Jan. 1, 1976, the date when a crowd of 16,000 attended the opening of the Plainfield Greyhound Park. In its 30 montns of operation, the tra,:k has turned over $29 million to Connecticut, more than any other parimutuel establishment in the state, according to Plainfield officials. It boasts an attractive physical plant, a loyal clientele, and a profitable and scandalfree operation.

title: Rivalries Undercut Political Ambitions in New Jersey
description: TRENTON  Nancy Muniz attracted some attention when she was sworn in as a member of the Perth Amboy City Council early this month, and it would have been strange if she hadn't. Although people of Hispanic background now make up about 10 percent of New Jersey's 7.1 million population, their share political power is still so small that she is a rarity.

title: Peterson Keeps Pole for British Grand Prix
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 15 (AP)  Sweden's Ronnie Peterson, in JPSLotus 79, shattered the Brands Hatch track record again today to take the pole position for tomorrow's British Grand Prix ahead of his teammate, Mario Andretti.

title: Big Towner Takes First In Roosevelt Feature
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 13  Taking command at the outset, Big Towner went on to capture the $50,000 second leg of the United States Pacing Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Is Retirement a Right of Passage?
description: JUNE was the season for weddings and commencements. A lot of people changed their status during June  with appropriate rites of passage that made children into adults, and individuals into couples.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: MEXICO CITY  Less than three years ago, during the election campaign of President Jose Lopez Portillo, a littleknown engineer and friend of the candidate called Jorge Diaz Serrano forcefully challenged Mexican oil officials who were warning that Mexico was running out of oil. It was really easier to show we had a lot of oil, he recalled, but they insisted we didn't.

title: What'sDoing on CAPE COD
description: TWO FACES  Cape Cod has two faces: beaches, ponds, pine woods and villages on winding lanes; and bustling resort towns with saltwater taffy, Remember Cape Cod Tshirts, rock music and traffic. Nowhere on the 70milelong strand that stretches from Buzzards Bay to Provincetown is this duality more evident than in MidCape. There, the boom town of Hyannis has two shopping malls for rainy days, and ice cream concessions, breakfast nooks and nightclubs line Main Street.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The third chief engraver of the Mint, Christian Gobrecht (17851844), designed eight of our regular coins which circulated for a total of 444 years. Yet although millions, he is chiefly remembered for a creation that was never adopted the Flying Eagle Dollar.

title: $2 Million in Olympic Lottery Goes to Five Upstate
description: Lorraine Corbett watched on television in her upstate New York home Friday as the first winning ticket was drawn in the $2 million Olympic lottery. The ticket, number 0640183, made Mrs. Corbett and four of her coworkers $2 million richer.

title: A Dream Fulfilled: Joe Yancey Relays
description: When David Scott of the Community Democratic Club of Harlem decided to conduct a track meet three months ago, he did not have a name for it and expected it to be just something for preteenagers to do on a Saturday afternoon.

description: BROOKFIELD  A Personal World, works by Leonore Tawney, through Sept. 4. Brookfield Craft Center, daily 2 to 5 P.M.

description: Nm of since the days of Jacqueline Kennedy's famous pillbox has there been such a todo about hats. After readytowear designers showed hats with almost everything in their 197879 fallwinter collections, women quickly got the message. Particularly young women who might never have worn a hat until now.

title: The Nation
description: After 18 months of sifting, the House ethics committee last week delivered itself of six absolutions, four formal complaints, two criticisms and one abstention in the matter of sitting Congressmen's conduct in the South Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe Loses StolenPaintings Lawsuit
description: In a case with potentially wide ramifications in the art world, Georgia 0. Keeffe, the painter, lost her court battle to regain possession of three small paintings of hers that were stolen 32 years ago.

title: 80 Japanese Arrested To Prevent Crime War
description: TOKYO, July 15 (Reuters)  The police arrested more than 80 people suspected of being gangsters today in an effort to prevent an underworld war of revenge following an attempt to assassinate a leader of organized crime in Japan.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: UNLESS you sail, the only way you can get into Long Beach is by one of three roads  the Meadowbrook Parkway from the east, the Atlantic Beach Bridge from the west or Long Beach Road from the north. Any way you take, once you reach the city, you are greeted by sign saying: Welcome to Long Beach  Home of the N.Y. Rangers.

title: A Fantasy: The Day TV Saved New York
description: Recent disclosures that the Los Angeles Olympic Committee is seeking financial aid to the tune of $50 million from the television industry in underwriting the 1984 Summer Games have veteran observers of New York's fiscal woes shaking their heads and wondering:

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Distractions at Belmont
description: To the Sports Editor: I used to be a thoroughbredracing fan, often enjoying a day at the races at Belmont Park. Unfortunately Belmont is no longer a park  it's a circus. Did you ever try to relax and read a racing form with dozens of unsupervised children running about, playing punchball, fighting, throwing a frisbee? I used to think a race track was a place where adults could go to play the horses. Instead, it is a playground. Children play on a trampoline provided for their amusement by the New York Racing Association. Youngsters openly smoke marijuana as they await the start of the rockandroll show that starts after the last race. On the Saturday I was in attendance (July 1) I couldn't hear the call of the last race over the television monitor because an employee of the N.Y.R.A. was calling out names of qualifiers of a twist contest over aloudspeaker.

title: House Panel Votes a Pay Ceiling Of $47,500 on Double Dippers
description: WASHINGTON. July 15 (UPI)  There are 34 persons on the Federal payroll who make more than $83,000 a year and 2,500 more who make almost $50,000 by adding Civil Service pay to their military pensions.

title: Shorter Marquez
description: THE Colombian Gabriel Garcia Marquez is the author of that great and astonishing fable of Latin American torpor, One Hundred Years of Solitude, a novel without equal in the literature of a suffering continent for its dazzling transcendence of all realism and its wonderfully black, mythopoeic humor. In Garcia Marquez's very imaginary country of Macondo there is no telling truth from rumor. The sloth, the credulity, the isolation, the feudalism, the casual brutality that are a running scandal in the backward parts of Latin America are all pointedly, sardonically exaggerated. Macondo has so many marvels it is not of our commonplace scientific world at all; nature doesn't function there with the regularity or impartiality it shows elsewhere, and time, if it moves at all, moves in circles. Garcia Marquez has borrowed, for a wholly topical and essentially political purpose, the secular nonsense of a Lost World, an anachronistic society at once INNOCENT ERENDIRA AND OTHER STORIES

title: Births
description: Peter and Virginia Joyfully armounce the birth of their son, Alexander Nikon on July 1st m Philadelphia. Proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. BuBerman of Wassenaar, The Netherlands and Darien. Ct. and Mr. and Mrs. Jacob C. Schein of Woodbridge, N.J.

description: Ron Guidry, on his relationship with Billy Martin, the Yankees manager: If you approach him right he's O.K. I avoid him altogether.

title: Beauty
description: The American beauty business is full of s'rprises. A stillcurrent industry legend has it that, as far as makeup is concerned, the products that sell best are those in bright colors (such as turquoise blue eye shadow), not the nowfashionable subtle, smoky brown shades. products have a faster useup time than others. A jar of night cream, for example, might be used up in 60 days and a woman will usually scrape the bottom of the jar. A nail enamel, on the other hand, may be used up in a month or it may sit on a dressing table while a woman buys another one. Mr. Gebb agrees with Revlon's idea that women will experiment with more shades in nail polishes, thus genrating more sales. A woman today is constantly looking for new color ideas.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: STRUGGLING rock musicians on the Island should gather inspiration from Blue Oyster Cult's performance tonight at the Jones Beach Theater. Because it was not long ago that Blue Oyster Cult, now one of the top draws on the rock concert circuit, was playing to uninterested audiences in Long Island bars. And it was not long ago that the same band, whose show now features a $250,000 laser light system, was living communally on the North Shore, subsisting on lasagna and Spanish rice.

description: T HE first comprehensive show h this country of art from Nubia, a black civilization that goes back to the fourth millennium B.C., will open Sept. 30 at the Brooklyn Museum.

description: NEWPORT, RI., July 16 (AP) Bernie Mitton of South Africa pulled off a 61, 36, 76 victory today over John James of Australia and won the $75,000 Hall of Fame championship.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams, who was severely criticized for some decisions early last year, appears likely to be one of the first members of the Carter Cabinet to depart, possibly by the end of the year, Government and industry sources here say.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 16 (AP)  The Rev. Willie Dicks carefully staged his own crucifixion in a city park to publicly express his disgust with unsafe streets and to plea for an end of crime.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The pastor of a church in a Chicago suburb has raised a delicate problem for the Carter Administration by inviting the Prime Minister of Rhodesia, Ian D. Smith, to participate in a religious conference July 29.

Each evening. network viewers now have a choice among CBS's Walter Cronkite, NBC's John Chancellor and David Brinkley, and something called World News Tonight.

The ceremony, was performed in the MarthaMary Chapel of the Wayside Inn in South Sudbury, Mass., by Rabbi Samuel Umen and the Rev. Henry Bowen, a Roman Catholic priest.

description: THE Flat Earth Society, Baseball Division, Sparky Anderson chief spokesman, is having a terrible time winning new recruits. Despite their fears, free agency has not ended the world as we knew it.

description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 16  Ecuadoreans voted today in a presidential election that starts a transition to constitutional government after six years of military rule.

description: PATERSON, July 16  Both major candidates for the United States Senate attended the dedication yesterday of nearly completed community college complex here, and Bill Bradley, the Democratic nominee, said later that he was looking forward to debating his opponent before the November election.

description: FREE ALL OVER At no trouble, except for transportation, musicminded New Yorkers can take in variety of tree concerts today and tonight.

title: Rutherford Offers Meadowlands Site for Art Center
description: RUTHERFORD, July 16  After more than a year of weighing proposals for the development of land it owns in the Hackensack Meadowlands, the Borough of Rutherford has decided that it wants at least 25 acres set aside for an arts and cultural center.

description: The marriage of Madelaine Blanche Manisoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Manuel Manisoff of New York, to George M. Wohlreich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Wohlreich of Bay Harbor Islands, Fla., took place yesterday in the BethEl Chapel of Temple EmanuEl. Senior Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Rabbi Joachim Prinz.

title: Dollar Steady in Tokyo Trading
description: TOKYO, Monday July 17 (AP)  The United States dollar opened steady today on the Tokyo foreignexchange market in quiet trading.

title: TRANQUILIZING HELD A FACTOR IN DEATHS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Heavy doses of tranquilizers given to patients at two of New York State's biggest mental institutions, both in Rockland County, were a contributing factor in the deaths of numerous patients, the county's Medical Examiner said yesterday.

description: Charging flimsy reconstruction work and other defects, a Congressman from the Bronx has called for a Federal investigation of two troubled housing projects in which nearly 60 old South Bronx apartment buildings were rehabilitated in recent years with Government aid.

title: Women Reject Krupsak Race To Back Carey
description: Striving for equality in politics, women politicians have generally been united in supporting major women candidates in recent elections. But that is not so in this year's statewide elections, in which two women are running for major Mimes  one.of them, the state's highest elected female official, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak.

title: 12 Pianists in Kennedy semifinals
description: WASHINGTON, July I6(AP)-Twelve semifinalists were announced today in the first Kennedy CenterRockefeller international competition for excellence in performance of American music.

Arthur Miller.

description: CHICAGO, July 16  Few people other than the families of Peter Saraceno and his fiance, Linda FrachalIa, thought that he would survive the automobile accident that left him in coma for two and a half months in 1976.

description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 16  Del Insko came to the qualifying trials for the estimated $325,000 MonticelloN.Y.C. OTB Classic IV with four horses today, and he made it to 1he final with three.

title: CARTER REAFFIRMS HIS PLEDGE TO CUT OIL IMPORTS OF U.S.
description: BONN, July 16  President Carter reaffirmed his commitment to cut United States dependence on imported oil and to strengthen the dollar at the opening of an economic summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized nations.

title: 700 MexicanAmericans Demonstrate in Texas Heat Over Alleged U.S. Reluctance to Prosecute in Deaths
description: PLAINVIEW, Tex., July 15  Hundreds of MexicanAmericans, many of them carrying placards and chanting.

title: Mickey Rivers: Enigma in a Slump
description: MICKEY RIVERS is still free spirit, and, like any free spirit, he resents adult authority, especially when the authority is the owner of the Yankees.

title: Philip Morris Debentures
description: Now that it has merged with the SevenUp Company, Philip Morris Inc. plans to enter the bond market tomorrow to raise $150 million in debentures to pay off shortterm loans it used in May to make its successful tender offer for the softdrink maker.

title: 2 Versions of Tax Break
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Capital gains are the profits made when someone sells capital assets, such as stocks or bonds, at a price greater than the one he paid for them, after holding them for a cerstain period. The seller already gets a tax break on these gains. The question that comes up again this week before the House Ways and Means Committee is how much more of a break ought to be offered as a spur to investment.

title: Vilas Triumphs
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 (AP)  Guillermo Vilas beat Jose Luis Clerc, 63, 76, 64, in a thrilling duel between two hardhitting Argentines in the final of the Swiss championship today.

title: 22 Hurt as Jet Is Buffeted
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP)  A Philadelphiabound Delta Airlines jumbo jet ran into severe turbulence today south of Richmond, and later 22 persons required medical treatment here. The plane, carrying 106 passengers and a crew of 10, landed without further incident at Philadelphia International Airport, according to Jim Ewing, a Delta spokesman, and was not itself damaged.

title: British Use Lottery For Offering
description: LONDON, July 16  Britain's hottest new stock in at least five years begins trading Tuesday, an offering that proves one can still start from scratch and become a millionaire here, where income tax can take 98 percent of a person's earnings.

title: Chinese Reopen University
description: TOKYO, July 16 (AP)  The Chinese People's University. closed in 1970 because of disruption by Lin Piao and the Gang of Four, has reopened and will enroll 1,700 students this autumn, Hsinhua, the official news agency, reported.

title: New York City' Judges give More Criminals
description: New York City judges imposed longer prison sentences on a larger proportion of defendants convicted of felonies last year than judges in the suburbs or in the rest of the state, a survey by The New York Times has found.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BASTAD, Sweden, July 16 (AP)Bjorn Borg, the Wimbledon champion, beat Jose Higueras, 61, 64, 62, to give Sweden a 32 victory over Spain today in the Davis Cup European Zone Group B semifinals. In the first singles match of the day, Manuel Orantes of Spain defeated Kjell Johansson, 64, 64, 75, to even the series.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 8:00 (7)Baseball: Minnesota Twins vs. Boston Red Sox.

title: Coast Representative Predicts Taxes Will Be Cut $20 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  Representative James E. Corman, Democrat of California, predicted today that. Congress would pass a $15 billion to $20 billion tax cut, including a $1 billion cut in the capital gains tax.

title: Outdoors: Eating Well on the Trail
description: FORTY years ago, the typical grub list for a backpacker or wilderness canoe traveler began  at least as far as I was concernedwith a chunk of slab bacon and a sack each of flour and corn meal.

title: G.S.A. Is Assailed for Bid Practices
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The General Services Administration is awarding a substantial number of construction con tracts without the competitive bidding process required by Federal contracting procedures, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One person was dead and two others were missing after a sailboat capsized on Lake Champlain. Clinton County sheriff's deputies and airrescue search teams from nearby Plattsburgh Air Force Base searched for the two missing persons, but they were hampered by heavy rainstorms.

title: Yarborough Wins Nashville Race
description: NASHVILLE, July 16 (AP)  Cale Yarborough scored his second consecutive victory on the Nashville Speedway last night as he won the $69,800 Nashville 420 Grand National race.

title: Inquiries Link Informer for F.B.I. To Major Klan Terrorism in '60's
description: ATLANTA, July 16  Renewed investigations into the activities of Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., the Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief paid informer in the Ku Klux Klan, have produced a portrait of Mr. Rowe as a man who loved violence and who could be linked to most major incidents of Klan terrorism that occurred in Alabama while he was on the bureau's oavroll.

title: Pope Criticizes Trials Of 3 Soviet Dissidents
description: ROME, July 16 (AP)  Pope Paul VI, adding his.voice to the broad protest in the West, spoke out today against the convictions of three Soviet dissidents, calling their alleged crimes ideological infractions and their sentences too severe.

title: Mike Mansfield, the Envoy, Is a Weary but Happy Man
description: TOKYO, July 15  Mike Mansfield, once a miner, is pleased to have left the wild winters of Montana behind. Mike Mansfield, once a marine, is glad to be living in the region where he served 57 years ago. Mike Mansfield. once the senate majority leader, is delighted to be away from Washington. After his first anniversary as a diplomat, Ambassador Mike Mansfield is at ease in his latest profession.

title: U.S., Israel and Egypt Shift the Site Of ideast Parley to British Castle
description: BONN, July 16  The United States, Egypt and Israel agreed today to move their foreign ministers meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday from a London hotel to a medieval castle about 45 miles from the capital because of the British Government's concern about possible terrorist attacks.

title: Defense Specialists Worried By Trend of Russian Efforts
description: Soviet and Cuban military and political gains in Africa, a Soviet nuclear and conventional buildup in Europe and the vulnerability of United States landbased nuclear weapons predicted for the early 1980's are contributing to disquiet among defense specialists in Con. gress and civilian experts.

title: Sporting Gear
description: There are many kinds of racquets in racquetball, one of the fastest growing sports these days. There are wood, aluminum and fiberglass models, and now RSI's metalplastic model is the first composite racquet on the market. The RSI racquets, designed by a mechanical eneineer from Massachusetts Institute of Technology, come in four types, depending on the style of play you prefer. The top of the line is the L4, featuring a rectangular.,frame slightly below average weight (270 grams) and above average length (18% inches). Other models feature lighter weights for mobility, teardrop shapes for balance, and heavier weights for power. From $35 to $43, with leather or rubber grips, at pro shops or direct from RSI, 9539 Town Park, Houston, Tex. 77036.

title: Dance Machine's Bravo Team at Durham Festival
description: DURHAM, N.C., July 16  It was three years ago that the American Dance Machine, a company founded by Lee Becker Theodore to preserve individ ual dance numbers from Broadway shows, appeared at the American Dance Festival in its first public peiformances.

title: Test Finds Deficiencies In Crime Laboratories.
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (upz) Many crime laboratories taking part in a nationwide test were unable to match blood samples, identify drugs or analyze other crime evidence correctly, according to Govermr.ent report released today.

title: Associated Press
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 16 (UPI)  Carlos Reutemann of Argentina, driving a Ferrari, took advantage of a mistake by Niki Lauda of Austria to win the British Grand Prix auto race by iust over a second today.

title: Croquet: For Families or for Real
description: GAMESTER, sportster, youngster, oldster, how does your croquet go? Through thin wire hoops or castiron wickets? On manicured lawns or grassy thickets? With a monogrammed mallet of hickory or ash, or a lacquered broomstick with Halloween dash?

title: Diplomacy Not Bluster
description: One of the most remarkable feats of American diplomacy in our time: That was what one veteran diplomat said of last week's agreement on a plan to bring the territory of SouthwestAfrica to Independence as Namibia. The compliment was not exaggerated.

title: Mindy Shangold Is Bride Of Craig Gordon, Lawyer
description: Mindy Joy Shangold, an occupational therapist with the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine in New York, and Richard Craig Gordon, a lawyer with the New York City Conciliation and Appeals Board, were married yesterday at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, L.I. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz of the Hillcrest Jewish Center performed the ceremony.

title: 30 Residents of Orange Continue Y.M.C.A. SitIn
description: ORANGE, July 16  Thirty residents, protesting what they term racially motivated cuts in financing for the black community, vowed today to continue a twoweek sitin at the executive offices of the branch of the Young Men's Christian Association here until officials of the Y.M.C.A. met with them to discuss the continuance of programs designed for the poor.

title: French Unearth a Roman Site
description: BOULOGNE, France, July 16 (Reuters)Workmen building an underground parking lot at Boulogne may have unearthed the ruins of the camp from which Julius Caesar invaded Britain in 55 B.C. Archeologists said a wall. 2 yards wide and 4 yards high, could be the remains of the fortified camp from which Caesar's fleet launched its invasion. The archeologists said they also found many Roman coins and pieces of pottery at the site.

title: O.J. Goes West, Running
description: O RENTHAL JAMES SIMPSON will be in Oakland today making three commercials. Last Tuesday he was in New York to present No. One Awards to high school athletes, and he went from there to convention in Wisconsin. When he is finished in Oakland he will have three days to find living quarters in or near San Francisco and move his belongings up from Los Angeles before checking into the San Francisco 49ers training camp San Jose, Cal. Obviously, O.J. Simpson is still running, through airports, through life.

title: Suspect Held in Slayings Of 2 Staten Island Girls
description: The body of a 17yearold Staten Island girl whose parents had reported her missing last Thursday was found in a shallow grave in a wooded area of Tottenville, S.I., yesterday, and a 31yearold shortorder cook was charged with her slaying as well as that of a 19yearold girl found strangled last May.

title: P.B.A. Session Ends; Protests Are Scheduled
description: New York City's latest bargaining session with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ended after nearly 10 hours at 4:40 A.M. yesterday, and are to resume at 2 P.M. today at the Office of Collective Bargaining, 250 Broadway.

title: Federally Sponsored Physicians Begin Work in City's Poverty Areas
description: Physicians from the National Health Service Corps began practicing medicine last week in some of New York City's most povertystricken neighborhoods, representing the urban vanguard of Federal publichealth program that earlier was concentrated in rural areas of the country.

title: Mrs.carner L.P.G.A. Victor
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, July 16 (AP) JoAnne Comer chipped to within 18 inches of the cup and made the putt for a par on the final hole today to win an $85,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Four HOHazard Danis in Jersey Found Defective by U.S. Inspectors
description: TRENTON; July 19  Four of the first high hazard dams inspected in New Jersey are deteriorating; state officials said today.

title: Grand Old Chilean Hotel Is on the Way to Oblivion
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  An auctioneer's gavel has begun the destruction of the Gran Hotel Crillon, one of South America's social landmarks.

title: TRANQUILIZING HELD A FACTOR IN DEATHS OF, MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Heavy doses of tranquilizers given to patients at two of New York State's biggest mental institutions, both in Rockland County, were a contributing factor in the deaths of numerous patients, the county's Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Judge Says Amway Fixed Price
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Amway Corporation, a company that was founded by two doortodoor salesmen in 1959 and became one of the largest directselling companies in the  world, illegally fixed prices, a Federal Trade Commission judge ruled in decision released today.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry Leads to the Arrest Of Man Linked to Whaling Plot
description: MIAMI, July 16 (UPI)  A man who the Federal Bureau of Investigation said was involved in a plot to blow up whaling ships has been arrested and charged with interstate transportation of explosives.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAX APPLE is the author of a wonderful collection of short stories, The Oranging of America, in which ZIP. A Novel of the Left and the Right. By Max Apple. 183 pages. Viking. $8.95.

title: The Women In the Shadow Of Miss Lopez
description: NANCY LOPEZ has attracted so much attention in the last four months that many of those who have just discovered women's golf are taking for granted that she will win the United States Golf Association's 26th annual women's open championship, which starts Thursday at the Country Club of Indianapolis. Nancnes.

title: SHCHARANSKY TRIAL BREAKS NEW GROUND
description: MOSCOW, July 16  A close examination of the evidence made public in last week's, treason trial of Anatoly B. Shcharansky indicates that the Government case was based on a condemnation of activities that for years were a normal part of the Jewish emigration movement's efforts to publicize its position, activities for which dozens of other dissidents have gone unpunished.

title: Introduction of 79 Autos Begins
description: DETROIT, July 16  The nation's major automobile manufacturers begin their 1979 modelyear introductions tomorrow when the Ford Motor Company shows its allnew subcompacts, the Mustang and the Capri.

title: Phils, Red Sox Continue Winning Ways
description: The two division leaders with the biggest leads, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Boston Red Sox, continued their winning ways yesterday, to the dismay of their pursuers. The Phillies did it with a 42victory over the Atlanta Braves and the Red Sox by sweeping the Minnesota Twine in a doubleheader. 53.32.

title: French Cycle Leader Is Banned for Fraud
description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 16The overall leader of the Tour de France bicycle endurance race, one of Europe's most popular sporting spectacles, was disqualified tonight for fraud in a doping test.

title: A Business Course for Entrepreneurial Women
description: Most women who go into business for themselves make terrible businessmen, but then, so do men.

title: Nicklaus Touch Is Still Golden
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 16 Jack Nicklaus had heard the questions with increased frequency at news conferences in recent years: Had he lost the golden touch, could he ever win another major Rolf championship?

title: A Horse Is a Horse, of Course, But How Many Are There?
description: GHENT, N.Y.  Ever since the first of June, Reba Curtis has been traversing the countryside of eastern New York State counting horses.

description: WHEN a company's management believes the company's assets are worth substantially more than the market price of its shares, what course should it follow when confronted with a merger bid that falls short of the claimed asset value?

description: To the Editor:

title: She Lands Desk Job And Becomes a Pilot
description: Karen Dillon wanted to succeed at Flying Tiger Line, the big freight and charter airline, so she studied shorthand at night. She had a business career in mind, and although she had private pilot's license, it never occurred to her to seek a flying job.

title: King Signs as Person
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 16  Gordon King, the Giants firstround draft choice, signed his first National Football League contract today as a person. not as a coroorat inn.

description: REMEMBERING LOST HOMELANDS: A fiercelooking Cossack marched clown Fifth Avenue and Croatian dancers gathered in Central Park as groups from 34 Communistdominated lands marked Captive Nations Week.

title: Jeanne Friedberg Is Married to Joseph Samet, a Lawyer
description: Jeanne Friedberg, a psychiatric social worker, was married yesterday to Joseph Samet, a lawyer with the New York law firm of Krause, Hirsch & Gross. Rabbi Walter Orenstein performed the ceremony at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J.

title: Quake in South Pennsylvania
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  An earthquake at 2:90 A.M. today in the Lancaster area of southeastern Pennsylvania registered about 3.0 on the Richter Scale, the United States Geological Survey reported today. A Survey spokesman described the tremor as minor.

title: Air Travelers Still Stranded
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)  Pan American Airways may have sold too many tickets for its bargainpriced flight between Amsterdam and Boston, the executive director of the Massachusetts Port Authority said Sunday.

title: Some Philadelphia Strikers Ordered Back to Work
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 16  A city judge issued temporary restraining orders today directing prison guards and court employees among the city's 19,600 striking employees hack to work.

title: The Woes of Fuller Employment
description: The spectacular decline in the unemployment rate in recent months to a fouryear low of 5.7 percent seems to have numbed the Carter Administration. The trouble is that the promised land of full employment has been reached too soon. Policies to counter the nation's soaring inflation are not yet forged. Success in one realm has become embarrassment in every other.

title: New York City's Judges Give More Criminals
description: New York City judges imposed longer prison sentences on a larger proportion of defendants convicted of felonies last year than judges in the suburbs or in the rest of the state, a survey by The New York Times has found.

title: How Previous Economic Meetings Have Fared
description: Leaders of the world's major industrial nations are meeting for the fourth time in four years to confront economic problems and propose solutions.

title: Gerulaitis Takes Final
description: Guess who won the first Forest Rills Invitation tournament yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club? None other than a club member, Vitas Gerulaitis. Gerulaitis; who will be 24 years old in 10 days, became the first. winner of the event with a quick and easy 62, 60 triumph over a wellmannered Ilie Nastase.

title: Motivating Women to Succeed
description: For women who agree with that point of view and have a spare $250 - Barbara Scher may be able to rectify that belief. Miss Scher is the creator and director of the Women's Success Teams, which run motivation seminars for women. W.S.T., one of a growing number of selfimprovement programs directed at women, claims to be different and, of course, more successful because it is based on team effort.

At right, a youngster found an exhibition of handcarved wooden toys irresistible at one of the booths set up ittleonta's Overpack Park. The fourday fair ended yesterday..

title: Dentists Not Reporting Child Abuse, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)  Dentists treating children who have been beaten on the heads or faces do not always recognize child abuse cases or report them to authorites as required by law, according to three Massachusetts doctors.

title: Brezhnev Said to Have Told Allies Moscow Will Help Fight Terrorism
description: BONN, July 16  The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, appears to have tacitly accepted the idea that the Soviet bloc should assist Western countries in combating terrorism, according to an authoritative source here.

title: Reds and Rose Hit Mets, 92
description: CINCINNATI, July 16 - Pete Rose batted safely in his 29th straight game today, set a major league record for switchhitters and helped the Cincinnati Reds overpower the New York Mets for the third day in a row, 92.

title: Frigitemp Ousts Chief Executive
description: The Frigi temp Corporation, in Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings, said yesterday that it had removed Gerald Lee as chairman and chief executive and had named two officers to succeed him as chief executive.

title: State Pension Fund Invests in Atlanta Project
description: Directors of the New York State employees pension fund have made a commitment to invest nearly $21 million in an Atlanta apparel mart being built to encourage garment manufacturing concerns to relocate in Georeia.

title: Quite. Remote From Greatness
description: FRANK ROBINSON, the great old outfielder, has been managing the Rochester Red Wings of the International League this year, in a season quite remote from greatness. At the AllStar intermission, the Red wings were seventh, 15 games out of first place. On some occasions Robinson had been forced to use a first baseman to pitch. That's not a comical situation, he says. The other night, after two infield errors cost the Wings a game, Robinson closed the door to the clubhouse. Outside, you missed the words, but you could hear his tone. Displeasure rose to staccato bursts of anger.

title: Wire, an English Rock Band, Visits
description: WIRE, the latest in a succession of English punk rock tends to visit the United States, was at CBGB over the weekend, playing. raw, forceful miniatures that seemed to owe a great deal to the influence of the Ramones. That influence was apparent in the brevity of the songs, many of which were under two minutes; in the use of insistent, hammering slogans for lyrics; in the satirically naive cast of some of the more developed lyrics; and in the occasional variations on the counting offone! two! three! four! with which the Ramones begin nearly every number.

title: Harvester Talk With Soviet Off
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (UPI)  International Harvester announced it had suspended business talks with the Soviet Union until the Kremlin's case against a Harvester employee was concluded.

title: ADAMS RESIGNATION IS SAID TO BE LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams, who was severely criticized for some decisions early last year, appears likely to be one of the first members of the Carter Cabinet to depart, possibly by the end of the year, Government and industry sources here say.

title: Soviet Fencer Wins
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, July 16 (AP) - Valentina Sidorova of the Soviet Union won the women's foil title at the 39th world fencing championships last night. It was the second consecuuve title for the 19yearo1d Russian. Second was Katarina Raczowa of Czechoslovakia and West Germany's Cornelia Hanisch finished third.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuters) About 200 Indian elders, chiefs and spiritual leaders prayed today in an encampment in Maryland that their Longest Walk protest would succeed. About 2,000 participants in the protest remained at the camp in a Federal park on the outskirts of Washington.Los Angeles Is Expected To Get Smog Respite Today

description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx, 8 P.M. (RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

description: LOS ANGELES, July 16  The Bubble Wars officially begin here tomorrow. Poland Water, a natural mineral water that comes from Maine, not Eastern Europe, is taking on Perrier, the elegant, bestselling French prince of imported waters  by means of a fourweek radio and television blitz.

The participants said that they were optimistic that they would be able to announce a plan for restoring prosperity to the world when their meeting ends today. [Page 1, Column 6.]

description: Billie Jehn King's latest injury, this time to her heel, must have the New York Apples wondering about their future. description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The United States and Israel yesterday reached a new civilaviation agreement designed to expand lowcost air travel between the two countries, the State Department announced.

description: Two recent felony cases were cited by prosecutors as typical examples of the longer prison sentences now faced by defendants in the city's criminalcourt system.

title: Barbara Appelbaum Bride of Charles Rosen
description: Barbara Anne Appelbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Appelbaum of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles Morris Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rbsen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi Harold S. Silver performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Israel.

title: Calm Reigns in Beirut For First Time in July
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16  For the first time in two weeks all fighting appeared to have stopped here today, a development seen as a positive effect of the announcement last night by President Elias Sarkis that he had decided not to resign.

title: 5 More Die in Spanish Explosion
description: MADRID, July 16 (AP)  The Health Ministry said today that five more persons died overnight from injuries suffered in the explosion that devastated a campsite near Tarragona on Spain's Mediterranean coast last week, raising the death toll to 150.

title: R. Walter Riehlman, 78, Former Representative
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla.,July 16 (AP)  R. Walter Riehlman, who represented the Syracuse, N.Y., area in Congress for 18 years, died today of a respiratory disease. He was 78 years old.

description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 16  The overall leader of the Tour de France bicycle endurance race, one of Europe's most popular sporting spectacles, was disqualified tonight for fraud in a doping test.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  Government experts believe that at least one of every 10 cars designed to use leadfree gasoline is being run on less expensive leaded gasoline and polluting the air in the process.

title: CARTER REAFFIRMS HIS PLEDGE TO CUT OIL IMPORTS OF U.S.
description: BONN, July 16  President Carter reaffirmed his commitment to cut United States dependence on imported oil and to strengthen the dollar at the opening of an economic summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized nations.

title: Designers Talk About the. Shape. of Things to Come
description: Seventh Avenue is tooling up for a major fashion change. This time it is not the length of hemlines or the pantsversusskirt question that are exercising designers. For the first time in years it is the shape of clothes themselves that is under revision.

title: Fed Clue On Rates Is Awaited
description: Interest rates have been steadily climbing for more than a year, and the obvious question is how much higher the climb will go.

title: Inquiries Link Informer for F.B.I. To Major Klan Terrorism in 60's
description: ATLANTA, July 16  Renewed investigations into the activities of Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., the Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief paid informer in the Ku Klux Klan, have produced a portrait of Mr. Rowe as a man who loved violence and who could be linked to most major incidents of Klan terrorism that occurred in Alabama while he was on the bureau's payroll.

title: Jazz/Funk: Olu Dara, Trumpeter
description: THE jazz avantgardists who work downtown tend to, combine and recombine in perpetually shifting grouPings. Anyone whololloWs the music regularly learns to expect a certain style or at least a certain quality from each of the musicians'who habitually works a::Sgroup. leader. But there are other musicians working downtown who contribute original and substantial work no matter what the context, and one learns to anticipate. an interesting experience whenever their presence is announced.

title: F.B.I. DATA NETWORK POSES PRIVACY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  A Congressional report has concluded that a computerized information network that the Federal Bureau of Investigation wants to expand poses farreaching questions about individual privacy and the power of the Federal Government.

description: BLACKBUSHE,, England, July 16 (AP) -- The singer Bob Dylan drew an estimated 200,000 fans. a World War II airbase in southern England for a daylong openair concert billed as The Picnic at Blackbushe.

description: THE three ballerinas who dance Juliet in the London Festival Ballet staging of Romeo and Juliet that opens here Tuesday are three very different persons and artists: an intense and sturdy Yorkshire woman, an introspective Italian, a cosmopolitan American with a tendency to giggle.

description: VICTORY is at hand for proponents of capital gains tax reduction. title: Plant in Houston Area Explodes
description: HOUSTON, July 16 (UPI)  A dynamite storage plant in an uninhabited section of the city exploded last night, shattering windows more than a mile away across the San Jacinto River. No injuries were reported. The explosion occurred at a plant owned by the N. L. Baroid Company.

title: Farth Markets In City Luring Eager Patrons
description: At 8 A.M. one day last week, Irene Hall got out of her nurse's uniform and into her street clothes, left Bellevue Hospital, where she had been on duty since mid, night, and boarded a subway train for Brooklyn, where she lives. But instead of going straight home, she stopped off at large, gravelpaved parking lot to renew acquaintance with William Merriman Jr. of North Canaan, Conn.; Dorothy Slade of Rest Spring, N.C.; Alvina Frey and her schnauzer, Gus; of Mahwah, N.J., and Bob Engle of Highland, N.Y., among others.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Senator Herman E. Talmadge wrote to the Federal Highway Administration in 1966 seeking approval for construction of an interchange for Interstate 75 in Georgia on land he later acquired, an aide acknowledged today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of precious metals futures declined moderately yesterday as prudent traders awaited the communiqu at the end of the economic summit meeting in Bonn. Although the report of the twoday conference produced no surprises, to say the least, it did tend to firm the dollar in overseas money markets.

title: Mr. Nixon's Revenge
description: Remember when highway billboards used to urge passing motorists to Impeach Earl Warren? In the interests of civility, it must be hoped that no such dubious importunings will arise against Warren Burger and the present Supreme Court. Nevertheless, the Burger Court does begin to look more and more like Richard Nixon's Revenge; although the four justices he appointed do not always vote as a bloc, Mr. Nixon left a powerful legacythe Court's conservative nucleus, direction and Chief Justice.

description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Businesses increased their inventories by a relatively weak 0.8 percent in May compared with a month earlier, while their sales were also tapering off, the Commerce Denartment said today.
