title: Jascalevich Defense Challenges Finding of Curare in One Patient
description: HACKENSACK, July 17  The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought to show today that one of the alleged victims could not have been poisoned with curare because his symptoms lasted too long for the rapidacting muscle relaxing drug to have been involved.

title: NEW YORK UNVEILS A BIG CASH BALANCE
description: New York City had a cash balance on July 1, the start of the current fiscal year, of nearly $1 billion, almost twice as much money as had been previously projected, city officials said yesterday.

title: Way Is Cleared to Get Abortion Clinic Records
description: WASHINGTON July 17 (AP)  Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan cleared the way today for the state of Texas and a woman with a malpractice suit against an abortion clinic to obtain records of other patients who suffered abortion complications.

title: Providence Mayor Is Under Fire
description: PROVIDENCE, July 14  The rumors about the popular 36yearold Mayor of this city have been whispered about for months, but nobody would talk about them publicly or put them into print.

title: DEFENSE DEPT.FINDS BAKKE CASE IMPACT TO BE ONLY MODEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The Defense Department, the Government's largest single employer, has tentatively concluded that the Supreme Court's decisions in the Allan P. Bakke case may alter some affirmative action programs but that the rulings will not substantially affect the department's equal opportunity efforts.

title: R.F.K. Tournament Stays at Forest. Hills
description: The West Side Tennis Club may have lost the United States Open, but another annual glamour event, the Robert F. Kennedy procelebrity tournament, will remain at the Forest Hills site at least one more year.

title: SALE OF STEEL PIER SET IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 17  Resorts International, owner here of the nation's only legalized gambling casino outside Nevada, announced today that it had purchased the Steel Pier, the famed Boardwalk landmark since 1898, for $5.7 million.

title: Cello: Rosen Repeats Prize Program
description: WHATEVER the reasons that prompted the Soviet Union to award gold medals to two Americans in the Tchaikovsky Competition on July 4  the first time an American musician has won a first prize since Van Cliburn's victory 20 years ago  no shadow should be allowed to fall over Nathaniel Rosen's blossoming career. The 30yearold cellist's talent was put brilliantly on record at his debut in Alice Tully Hall last season, and it was affirmed Sunday night at the Temple University Music Festival in Ambler, Pa., where Mr. Rosen performed with the Pittsburgh Symphony.

title: Dance: Septa Driver Offers On Doing at Festival
description: DURHAM. N.C., July 17  The American Dance Festival continues. to he a proving ground for creative young talents. Last night, usually reserved for its more experimental series, the organization oresented a oroeram of new and old works by Senta Driver, a moderndance choreographer whose brainy but physical pieces were seen as part of the festival's past Emerging Generation presentations.

title: Seattle Aquarium Pulls Crowds With Its Displays That Educate
description: SEATTLE  There are no killer whales kissing pretty girls, no dolphins doing double flips or seals balancing beachballs. But to learn something about what lives in the oceans, lakes and streams, Pier 59 in Seattle's Waterfront Park  the home of the nation's newest aquarium  is the place to come.

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Of Bank Fraud
description: A former Chase Manhattan bank official and a Westchester businessman were accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of having conspired to misapply $3.5 million in bank funds.

title: Air Passengers Increase 16.3%
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) America's airlines, heading for a record year of passenger traffic, carried 16.3 percent more travelers in the first six months of 1978 than they did in the same period last year, the Air Transport Association reported today.

title: Washington Journal
description: ALITTLE BOY from Michigan emerged from the elevator at the tip of the Washington Monument here the other day and whooped with joy at what he spied below.

title: Fire Disables Oil and Gas Tanker
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 17 (UPI)  A 650foot oil and gasoline tanker wallowed adrift in the Florida Straits 40 miles off Key West today after an engine room fire that injured a crewman and knocked out all power aboard. The injured crewman was treated for smoke inhalacion at Fishermen's hospital at Marathon. The tanker was identified as the Mount Explorer, registered at Texas City, Tex..

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TICKETS AND TUT Two free events today in Greenwich Village, an evening concert and a morning slide show on the Treasures of Tutankhamen, mark the start of the 21st season of one of the city's oldest summerconcert series, the Washington Square Music Festival.

title: Protest Over Layoffs Grows At Greystone
description: PARSIPPANY, July 17 (AP) Nurses at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital were joined by other hospital workers today in a continuing protest over staff cutbacks.

title: Oldest Book Club Is 100
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y. ACENTURY ago, in August 1878, what is now the oldest continuing book club was started in the United States with a highflown aim: Education, once the peculiar privilege of the few, must in our best earthly estate become the valued possession of the many.

title: Frontiers of Science
description: ONE WOULD hardly expect relationship between sea otters, crustaceans and aboriginal Aleuts to cast light on the mysterious extinctions of giant mammals at the end of the last ice age. scientists nave reached some conclusions in that line, however, after studying the heaps of, refuse left by early inhabitants of the remote Aleutian Islands.

title: Arrest of Wyoming Mining Town's Top Police Official Fuels Controversy Over Charges of Corruption
description: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., July 17 (AP) The arrest of the top police official here in the death by shooting of an undercover policeman has added fire to the controversy over allegations of vice and corruption in this rough mining town.

title: WITH UNITY ELUSIVE, O.A.U. MEETS TODAY
description: KHARTOUM, the SUDAN, July 17 The Organization of African Unity opens its annual conference of heads of state here tomorrow, at a time when Africa's problems have never seemed more awesome and its unity more elusive.

title: Concert: Mostly Mozart Opens
description: ONE of New York's indispensable summertime ornaments, Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival, went on display once more last night at Avery Fisher Hall. And for this 12th season. the festival decided to lead from strength, not only stacking the opening program entirely with Mozart masterpieces, but also bringing on three soloists whose credentials as Mozarteans could not be doubted. Pinchas Zuckerman conducted the Festival Orchestra and contributed the violin obbligato in two arias by Judith Blegen, and provided Emanuel Ax with clairvoyant orchestral support in the Piano Concerto No. 22 in Eflat (K. 982). Before the concert, the violinist and conductor led a prelude program, and he topped off his busy evening by conducting the Linz Symphony.

title: CurareData Hearing Is Ordered
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ordered a reporter for The New York Times yesterday to appear in court today for a hearing on whether he should be required to go to New Jersey and comply with a subpoena demanding that his news file on Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich be submitted to the judge presiding at the surgeon's murder trial in Hackensack.

title: Profit Up Sharply at Two Banks
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the fourth largest,reported yesterday operating earnings gains of 27.1 percent and 19.8 percent, respectively, for the second fiscal quarter.

title: E.P.A. Is Investigating Fish Kill At Nuclear Power Plant at Salem
description: TRENTON, July 17The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had assigned a biologist to patrol the Delaware River to gather more, information about a fish kill, at the water intake pumps of a nuclear generating sta. tion in Salem.

title: Califano Says Quarter of Elderly In Nation Are Poor or Near Poo
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that a quarter of America's elderly were poor or near poor and urged a re thinking of national policies on retirement, work, income support and health care.

title: News Summary
description: Moves to combat unemployment without rekindling inflation were announced yesterday by the leaders of the seven leading industrialized nations at the end of their summit meeting in Bonn. All seven, including President Carter, praised the results of their fourth annual economic conference. The key commitments were from the United States to strengthen the dollar by saving oil and fighting inflation, from Japan to import more and export less and from West Germany to prime its economy to spur world economic growth. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Deaths
description: SCHNURSidnev, dearly beloved husband of Dorothy (Thurman). adored father of Joan Goodman. devoted grandfather of Robert Goodman. Services Tuesday. 17:45 PM, at The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 56 Die as Cairo Bus Falls in Nile
description: CAIRO, July 17 (AP)  A city bus filled with soldiers and workers swerved to miss a truck, smashed through a retaining wall and plunged into the Nile River today, killing at least 56 passengers, the police reported. At least 11 passengers survived.

title: Court Order Overturned, Then Substituted in Louisville Firemen's Strike
description: An order directing Louisville's 600 union firefighters to end a strike that has closed all but eight of the city's 23 fire stations was overturned on a technicality yesterday and substituted by another court order.

title: New State Prison Appointee
description: ALBANY, July. 17  In the spitandpolish annals of law enforcement, the appointment of Richard D. Hongisto as New York State's Commissioner of Correctional Services could best be characterized as unlikely.

title: Lobby Group Files Suit To Prevent Postal Strike
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  With major issues still unsettled in Postal Service union negotiations, a public interest group filed suit today to prevent workers from staging a nationwide strike if they do not get a contract by midnight Thursday.

title: 2 SOUGHT IN SLAYING OF 6 IN OKLAHOMA
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 17 (AP) The police were seeking at least two gunmen today who held up a steak restaurant at last night at closing time, herded six employees into a freezer and killed them one by one with a bullet through the head, leaving their bodies in a heap. Four of the dead were teenagers.

title: Death
description: HANERFELDSam. Beloved husband of Miriam. Dear brother of Fay Hoffman, Sylvia Kuna, Louis. Irving and Hyman. Services Tuesday, 10:30 A.M. at Gutterman's Lincoln Square Chapel Broadway at 66th Street.

title: Antiques Expand Daeschler's Vistas
description: Robert Daeschler is one of the many men who said, When I turn 50, I would do what I wanted to do. But he is also one of the few who actually did it. On his 50th birthday four years ago, he bid adieu to his job as an investment counselor at Eppler & Company in New Jersey and took up seriously with his hobby  the antique business.

title: Around the Nation
description: DALLAS, July 17 (AP)  Nineteen deaths have been attributed to a heat wave that has roasted North Texas for more than two weeks. Another 16 persons in the DallasFort Worth area have been hospitalized for treatment of heat stroke symptoms.

title: E.P.A. Is Invesingating Fish Kill At Nuclear Power Plant at Salem
description: TRENTON, July 17  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had assigned a. biologist, to patrol the Delaware River to gather more information about a fish kill at the water intake pumps of a nuclear generating station in Salem.Mr. Cahill said there was no expectation that Public Service could reduce by, any large amount the water it used to cool the reactor.

title: Stokoag. Fkins? Net Up Sharply
description: Two major. Wall Street brokerage firmX, the E.. F. Hutton Group and Paine WebbefInc.; yesterday reported sharply increased net income and revenues for their mostrecent fiscal guarters. The gains were attributed largely to the recent surge in trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cooperation but Caution
description: BONN, July 17  Leaders of the indus: trialized nations hope that the outcome of this year's Bonn summit meeting will keep the flame of international economic cooperation burning, even if it also shows they have now lowered their expectations about what these annual meetings can achieve.

title: Shakeup Aids Mexican Steel
description: MEXICO CITY, July 16  A huge shakeup of Mexico's state steel industry four months ago has resulted in increased output and higher productivity, although American fears that the industry will soon join other foreign producers competing for the United States market seem premature. in the early 1970's, United States producers in the Southwest frequently charged Mexican dumping of steel.

title: Ecuador Voting Is Led By,StandIn for a Man Disqualified by Junta
description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 17  The presidential candidate of a populist party that Ecuador's military rulers had sought to discourage ran far ahead of five rivals in the elections held yesterday, but he apparently fell considerably short of the ma jority needed to avoid a runoff.

title: Deaths
description: NOVIKHerman on Jul 15, 1978. Husband of Claire Novik. Father of Alice Silverstein, Richard Novik and Jane Adam. Grandfather of Adam Silverstein and Taaron Silverstein. Service were held at the North Nassau Chapel, Great Neck, New York on July 11th.

title: Ballet: Berliners Close Season With Giselle
description: THE Berlin Opera Ballet closed its debut season in New York over the weekend with a number of new dancers appearing in old roles. Standing ovations seemed to be the order of the/day and, while most of them were for Valery and

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on July 11 erroneously attributed to Governor. Carey a statement made by Msgr. Myles Bourke at funeral services in Manhattan for a slain 13yearold boy. The statement, referring to the boy's parents, Leo and Elizabeth McEvoy, was I have learned more from them than from many readings and talks, for I have seen in them a spirit of Christianity, which is, unfortunately, rare.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on July 11 erroneously attributed to Governor Carey a statement made by Msgr. Myles Bourke at funeral services in Manhattan for slain 13yearold boy. The statement, referring to the boy's parents, Leo and Elizabeth McEvoy, was I have learned more from them than from many readings and talks, for I have seen in them a spirit of Christianity, which is, unfortunately, rare.

title: 20 Food Places Called Violators Of New York City's Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 20 food businesses for failing a health code inspection. Five others were listed as having corrected violations, and one was reopened. The businesses were listed as follows:

title: Stocks Mixed
description: Despite some encouraging news from the sevennation economic summit conference in Bonn the stock market only managed to close mixed yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Diversity Advocate Heads New Broadcast Agency
description: Henry is an idealist who is not rigid in his ideas, an intellectual who has no problem admitting he was wrong, an associate of Henry Geller, head of the new National Telecommunications and Information Administration, said. sne added, The best thing about him is that there is no veneer; what you see is what you get.

title: News Summary
description: Moves to combat unemployment without rekindling inflation were announced yesterday by the leaders of the seven leading industrialized nations at the end of their summit meeting in Bonn. All seven, including President Carter, praised the results of their fourth annual economic conference. The key commitments were from the United States to strengthen the dollar by saving oil and fighting inflation, from Japan to import more and export less and from West Germany to prime its economy to spur world economic growth. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: APPOINTMENT VEXES CONNECTICUT PANEL
description: HARTFORD, July 17  The State Commission on Human Rights has accused the Connecticut State Police Commissioner of ordering the appointment of local politician's son to the police academy after he had been screened out as a candidate by examiners.

title: The Crime Bill Caper
description: The main feature of Governor Hugh L. Carey's crime package is, to put it bluntly, a fraud. The Governor proposed that a new category of violent crimes be created  violent felony oitenses, namely murder, manslaughter, rape, kidnapping, arson, robbery, assault and certain degrees of burglary. These offenses would have higher mandatory minimum and maximum sentences than now exist. Persons committing a second violent felony offense would also be dealt with more harshly. A thirdtime violent offender would get a mandatory life sentence.

title: U.S. and 6 Allies to Cut Air Links To Countries Sheltering Hijackers
description: BONN, July 17  Leaders of the world's major nonCommunist industrial nations, attending the economic summit meeting here, resolved today to act jointly to suspend air traffic to and from countries that failed to turn over hijackers and hijacked aircraft quickly.

title: For Needham: No Snow Job
description: Soon after James J. Needham resigned under pressure in 1976 as the first fulltime chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, he was quoted as saying that I do miss the excitement of being at the nerve center of the New York Stock Exchange, but I'm not sitting around watching the snow fall.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: VAN NUYS, Calif. July 17 (UPI) American Jet Industries announced today that it had worked out an agreement in principle for the purchase of the Grumman American Aviation Corporation, Savannah, Ga., for $32 million and $20.5 million in preferred stock to be issued.

title: A New Backlash
description: WASHINGTONThere is a spectre haunting America. The spectre of big government.

title: Olinkraft, Texas Eastern Back Merger
description: In a transaction estimated to value $460 million, the Texas Eastern Corporation, holding company for one of the nation's largest natural gas transmission operations, and Olinkraft Inc., a Louisianabased pulp and paper company, announced yesterday that their boards had agreed to merge.

title: Winners of $2 Million Come to City to Collect
description: The winners of the $2 million first prize in the Olympic lottery, five workers in a upstate New York school who had chipped in $2 each to buy a $10 ticket, collected checks for $16,000 each yesterday. It was the largest guaranteed lottery prize ever awarded in the United States.

title: 7 INDUSTRIAL NATIONS PLEDGE TO SPUR JOBS, CURB INFLATION; U.S. READY TO CUT OIL IMPORTS
description: BONN, July 17  Leaders of the largest industrial democracies agreed today on a modest package of moves to help combat worldwide unemployment without rekindline inflation.

title: DEFENSE DEPT FINDS BAKKE CASE IMPACT TO BE ONLY MODEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Defense Department, the Government's largest single employer, has tentatively concluded that the Supreme Court's decisions in the Allan P. Bakke case may alter some affirmative action programs but that the rulings Will not substantially affect the department's equal opportunity efforts.

title: New York Regents Impose Probation on 2d School
description: The New York State Board of Regents has placed a second public high school on probation as part of a new effort to enforce state education standards more strictly.

title: Bill Drafted On Bank Takeovers
description: The New York State Banking Department, moving swiftly to curtail foreign takeovers said to be facing at leagt two major unidentified comniercial banks, has quietly drafted new banking legislation to block such takeovers without state authority.

title: Father Monitors Heart Of Laboratory Baby
description: MANCHESTER, England, July 17 (UPI)  John Brown, the expectant father, listened today to the heartbeat of the world's first baby conceived outside the mother's womb and said everything is going very well.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Western leaders agreed on a package of measures to combat unemployment without rekindling inflation. The key commitments at the summit meeting in Bonn were for the United States to conserve oil and fight inflation, for Japan to buy more and sell less abroad and for West Germany to stimulate economic growth. President Carter and other heads of state hailed the pact, but specific commitments in most cases went no further than proposals discussed in preparatory meetings over the last few months. [Page A1.]

title: A Good Compromise on Privacy
description: It's too bad that a piece of legislation as basic to a free society as the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978 has to be thought of as radical, but given recent experience, it is just that  and should therefore be applauded. The bill would protect individuals against tuirestricted prowling through bank and creditcard records by Federal agencies. It would, with certain exemptions that are still being debated, require notification of anyone whose records the authorities want to see. And the person could object.

title: S.E.C. Curb On Lykes, LTV Stock
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended yesterday through July 26 trading in stock of the LTV Corporation and the Lykes Corporation.

title: Deter Preparing to Take a Giant Step Up
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 17  The Giants began today that grueling training camp ordeal known as the twoadays and there was Gary Jeter. directing traffic.

title: Zaire and Angola to Reopen Rails
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 17 (AP) Zaire and Angola have ended a meeting of reconciliation by agreeing to reopen the Benguela railroad that was once the lifeline of Zairian copper exports, a joint communiqu said today.

title: Bank Earnings for Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Belgian Cyclist Confused
description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 17 Near tears, Michel Pollentier told a confused story here today as he tried to explain his disqualification as the overall leader of the Tour de France bicycle endurance race.

title: Cleveland's Dismissed Police Chief Named Corrections Head by Carey
description: ALBANY, July 17  Governor Carey today announced the appointment of Richard Hongisto, who was dismissed as Police Chief in Cleveland earlier this year, as New York's Commissioner of Correctional Services. and said Mr. Hongisto would take over the duties immediately, with or without Senate confirmation.

title: Social Security Changes Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, today proposed amendments to last year's Soda) Security tax increases. The Talmadge bill would reduce future Social Security tax rates, allow the taxes to be deductible on income tax returns, limit excessive costofliving increases in benefits and bring members of Congress and other Federal employees into the system.

title: U.S. and 6 Allies to Cut Air Links To Countries Sheltering Hijackers
description: BONN, July 17  Leaders of the world's major nonCommunist industrial nations, attending the economic summit meeting here, resolved today to act jointly to suspend,air traffic to and from countries that failed to turn over hijackers and hijacked aircraft quickly.

title: Chess Title Match Opens With a Musical Blunder
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 17A Philippine military band made the first blunder of the world chess championship match today, playing the wrong music at the opening ceremonies. It was something of a victory for Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger, who has been waging psychological warfare since the $550,000 match with the champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, was announced.

title: NeWest New York Commercial Sex Enterprise Is Opened on 53d St.
description: A brandnew sex supermarket is competing for customers with its 53d Street neighbor, the Citicorp Center's Market, and neighboring businesses are worried.

title: South African Hints at Conflict in U.N. Over Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 South Africa's chief delegate hinted today that a new accord on independence for SouthWest Africa could be jeopordized if the Security Council tried to decide the status of Walvis Bay, the territory's only deepwater port.

title: Change Set In Auditing Standards
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants announced yesterday a major restructuring of its operations for setting auditing standards. The move, which had been expected, was made in response to recent Government criticism of accounting audits.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Government Bond Prices Rise In Quiet Trading
description: An upswing in prices of some government bonds continued despite quiet trading yesterday as some traders took a more positive view of recent monetary statistics, including the recently announced huge increases in the money supply.

title: AirTraffic Union Fined $100,000 for Slowdown
description: A Federal judge ordered the airtraffic controllers union yesterday to pay $100,000 in fines for violating a 1970 court injunction by slowing down flights on four days in May and June of this year.

title: Black Rhodesian Launches Drive To Induce U.S. to End Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  On most of his visits to this country in recent years, Bishop Abel Muzorewa urged the United States to enforce the economic sanctions invoked by the United Nations Security Council against Rhodesia's white minority Government.

title: 2 Charge ealous Doctor Killed TestTube Baby
description: Lawyers for a Florida couple who had sought to produce a testtube baby five years ago charged in court yesterday that a:physician at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center had deliberately destroyed a laboratoryfertilized embryo because of poor relations between him and the physician who initiated the vroiect.

title: Cambodian Assails Vietnam, Embarrassing Thais
description: BANGKOK, July 17  Deputy Prime Minister leng Sary of Cambodia declared today that the Cambodian people, army and Communist Party had heavily crushed the Viettiamese enemy, annexationists and swallowers of territories. in a notable breach of diplomatic etiquette, the Cambodian leader, who is in charge of foreign affairs, used a news conference at the end of an official visit to Thailand as a platform for Cambodia's propaganda campaign against its former ally.

title: Investment Bank Deal Discussed
description: Credit Suisse, the large Swiss bank, said yesterday that it was negotiating with First Boston Inc., the New York securities firm, for First Boston to acquire a share in Credit Suisse White Weld, the European investment banking organization. The two firms said they were also discussing the possibility of Credit Suisse taking a stake in First Boston.

title: New Eyeglass Rule in Effect
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPO) A new rule requiring that persons undergoing cye tests be given copies of their eyeglass prescriptions is now in effect, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The rule was Issued by the agency last month but was not put into effect because of a court appea) by the American Optometric Association. The asency said that the stay won by the association was lifted last week by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, and the nee waS now in effect.

title: Ad Slogans Tell Businessmen Grass Is (or Isn't) Greener Elsewhere; Zoned for SUCCESS
description: Cities, states and regions around the country are bombarding businessmen with enticing slogans and advertisements, in an escalating tugofwar for companies, with their jobs and payrolls. Using millions of tax dollars as well as private business contributions, they have turned increasingly to advertising professionals to tell companies, in effect:

title: Adams Says He. Has No Thought Of Leaving Transportation Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams denied at noon news conference today that he was looking for an opportunity to leave the Carter Administration.

title: Cooperation but Caution
description: BONN, July 17 Leaders of the industrialized nations hope that the outcome of this year's Bonn summit meeting will keep the flame of international economic cooperation burning, even if it also shows they have now lowered their expectations about what these annual meetings can achieve.

title: United Press International
description: FORCED AT SECOND: Bob Beal of Braves sliding into second base on Sunday as Ted Sizemore of Phillies threw to first on an attempted double play. On the play, Atlanta's Glenn Hubbard scored the Braves second run. The Phillies won. 42.

title: Iacocca Relieved Of Duties at Ford
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 17  Lee A. Iacocca, who resigned last week under pressure as president and chief operating officer of the Ford Motor Company, effective Oct. 15, has been relieved of virtually all management responsibilities within the company, it was disclosed today.

title: Ambitious Casino Plans Outlined by Silverberg
description: I want to prove that not only big companies can raise capital and develop casinos. I will prove that a small company with young and ambitious individuals can build one of the largest and most productive casinos in the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ElderBeerman Stores Corporation, a Middle Western chain of department stores, announced that Barry Miller has resigned as president and chief merchandising officer to become owner of GiddingJenny, a Cincinnatibased women's specialty store previously owned by Genesco. Max Gutman, chairman and chief executive, and Charles Waldron, vice chairman, will assume Mr. Miller's duties until a successor is named.

title: Writers See Tony Snub
description: Stephen Sondheim, the songwriter who is the president of the 2,700member Dramatists Guild, has criticized the June 4 telecast of the 1978 Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards presentations and has threatened to advise guild members to withhold any and all support of future presentations unless the format of the telecast is changed.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Community Arts (13)Captioned ABC News

title: POLITICAL ADVISERS GAIN FOREIGN ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17President Carter is increasingly involving his political and domestic advisers in the formulation of foreign policy, which he views as inextricably tied to political and domestic concerns, according to senior White House aides.

title: Philip Morris Profit Up
description: The secondquarter profit of Philip Morris Inc. rose 22.5 percent to $109.3 million, or $1.74 a share, on a 25.8 percent revenue rise to $1.67 billion, the company reported yesterday. It was the first quarter in which earnings had ever exceeded $100 million. In the yearearlier quarter the nation's secondlargest cigarette producer (its brands include Marlboro, Benson & Hedges, Parliament and Virginia Slims) had net income of $85.1 million, or $1.42 a share.

title: Many Black Policemen Feel They're Between Two Guns..

title: Illegal Flow of Haitians to Florida Coasts Rising
description: MIAMI, July 17  Thirtythree Haitians landed today on Key Biscayne, the latest arrivals in the tide of illegal immigration from the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.

title: and a Black Police Chief May Be in the Middle Most of All
description: The man most responsible for the police investigation into the death of a Crown Heights civic leader, Arthur Miller, is William R. Bracey, assistant chief of Brooklyn North.

title: Bridge:
description: The focal point of today's meeting in Toronto of the directors of the American Contract Bridge League will be the KatzCohen affair.

title: Soccer Express Rushes to Title
description: The Cosmos lead the North American Soccer League in attendance, goals and points, but the Detroit Express, an expansion team, has become the first team to clinch a division title.

title: OLD TEXT IS LINKED TO 1054 SUPERNOVA
description: When a minor star in the sky suddenly burst into an unusually brilliant super. nova on July 4, 1054, Chinese astronomers saw it and made detailed records. So did their contemporaries in Japan: it has been suggested that certain Indian rock etchings in the American Southwest also depict the event.

title: Business Records
description: MELVIN THOMAS, 29 Cortlandt St., Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Liabilities, 54,443; assets, 6550.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE three novellas that make up The Hill of Evil Counsel are set in a suburb of Jerusalem called Tel Arta. It is peopled mostly by refugees; the backyards are littered with packing cases and other debris of their flight.

title: Text of Declaration at the Bonn Summit
description: The heads of state and Government of Canada, the Federal Republic of Germany, France, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the United States of America met in Bonn on 16th and 17th July 1978. The European Cornmunity was represented by the president of the European Council and by the president of the European Commission for discussion of matters within the community's competence.

title: An Inquiry Is Ordered on Claims Of Overdrugging Mental Patients
description: The New York State Commissioners of Mental Health and Mental. Retardation yesterday ordered a special state investigation into allegations by the Rockland County Medical Examiner that the heavy use of tranquilizers in two state mental hospitals in the county had contributed to many patient deaths.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN the owner of 100 shares of General Motors goes to his neighborhood banker planning to offer the stock as collateral for a loan to pay college tuition, the banker will eagerly agree to advance money  and at a rate well below that charged for a typical consumer loan.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: MONDALE MEETS WITH DISSIDENT'S WIFE: The Vice President welcoming Avital Shcharansky to the White House. Mrs. Shcharansky, whose husband, Anatoly, was sentenced in Moscow to 13 years imprisonment treason, wished to thankGovemment officials who voiced support for him.

title: Opera: Coloradans Sing Handel Xerxes
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 17  The operas of Handel are not exactly repertory fare la any of the world's opera houses. Take Xerxes, or Serse, to use the Italian title, the opera that Handel composed in 1738 and that contains the celebrated Largo. It has had some student and concerthall presentations, but as far as anybody knows, there has never been a professionally staged performance in the United States.

title: 3 Night Club Bouncers in Jersey Are Accused in a Fatal Beating
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., July 17 (UPI) Three men charged in the beating death of a young Middletown Township, N.J., man, have been released on $10,000 bail pending a hearing later this month.

title: Roosevelt Memorial: Finally, a Plan Is Set
description: AFTER 18 years of proposals and rejections, a plan for a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt has finally been presented to Congress by the Federally appointed Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission. Designed by the landscape architect Lawrence Halprin, the memorial departs from the rigid monumental concepts of earlier plans, creating a 12acre environment on the Tidal Basin in Washington, with works by four contemporary sculptors evoking the life and times of the 32d President.

title: Deaths
description: COHALANRev. Patrick J. The Quarter Century Club of the New York Athletic Club records with sorrow the passing of a valued member elected in 1926 and extends its deepest sympathy to his bereaved family.

title: J.A.L. Installing Beds
description: TOKYO, July 17 (Reuters)  Japan Air Lines announced it would introduce sleeping accommodations next month in its Boeing 747's. Five beds. senarated by curtains, are being installed in the upperdeck lounges of the airline's jumbo jets for firstclass passengers. The service is scheduled to begin on transPacific routes starting Aug. and on polar flights to Europe on Oct. 1. The extra cost for a bed will be $120 from Los Angeles or San Francisco to Tokyo.

title: TraCkImprovements Begun by the L.LR.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road began trackimprovement work yesterday ori two of the most troubled parts of its system, the Oyster Bay branch and th SneonktoMontauk line.

title: Scotch Exports Rise
description: LONDON, July 17 (UPI)  Britain's exports of Scotch whisky rose during the first five months of 1978, industry spokesmen said today. Volume rose 13.6 percent from the yearearlier level to 40.1 million gallons, while the value of shipments rose 23.5 percent to $442.32 million. The United States, the biggest market for Scotch in the fivemonth period, took 19.37 million gallons (up 25.6 percent) worth $133 million (up 26.5 percent).

title: Deaths
description: FOGELAiattle, beloved wife of the late Abraham L. Devoted mother of Alvin,adored grandmother of Michael and Jeffrey. Greatgrandmother of Jennifer and Joshua. Services Tuesday 10:COAM at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel Long Beach Road at Greystone, Rockville Centre,LI.

description: 69 A.M. WKCR. String Quartet No. I, Tippett ; Trio No. 4, 13avicchi; Trio for Flute, Cello and Piano, Rorem; Variations on an Old Russian Chant, Duke; String Quartet Music, Sculthorpe.

title: Pennsylvania Acts to Ferret Out Medical Malpractice
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 17A dozen specially trained medical investigators, including former nurses, policemen and military paramedics, fanned out across Pennsylvania today as the state opened a new program to rid medicine of malpracticine nhvsicians.

title: Fyodor D. Kulakov, 60, Is Dead; Viewed as a Brezhnev Successor
description: MOSCOW, July 17  The Soviet Government announced today the death of Fyodor Davydovich Kulakov, who at the age of 60 was one of the youngest members of the 14member ruling Politburo and was regarded as a possible successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.

title: Yemen People's Council Chooses Saleh to Take Over as President
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 (AP) Yemen's People's Council elected Col. Ali Abdullah Saleh as President today, the Saudi press agency reported from Sana, the Yemeni capital.

title: Rabbi Says He Expects New Shcharansky Talks
description: A New York State rabbi said today that he expected new negotiations for an exchange of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a convicted Soviet dissident, for two Soviet citizens who face espionage charges in the United States.

title: Taxes &
description: Arecent Supreme Court decision has significantly enlarged the ability of the Internal Revenue Service to obtain the financial records of taxpayers under investigation, even if the inquiries eventually lead to criminal prosecution.

title: More Pain for Those Choosing Abortion
description: The opponents of abortion are bringing two more measures into the House of Representatives this week which treat women who choose legal abortion as a group apart, undeserving of the equal protection of the Federal laws. One measure, the pregnancy disability bill, would amend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to protect pregnant women against discrimination in employment  except those who have abortions. The second would forbid the United States Commission on Civil Rights from considering abortion issues on the ground that abortion is not a matter of civil rights. The very proposal of the first measure contradicts the premise of the second.

title: Famous Last Words at the Kremlin
description: The Soviet Government has distributed a morbidly engrossing anatomy of treason to justify its most brutal persecution of a recent dissenter  Anatoly Shcharansky. The trouble began, it tells its people, when he decided long ago to leave his homeland for the West. There is no mention that the West is Israel, and there is no mention that the world would never have heard of him had he been allowed to leave. The pivotal lie in the mountain of lies on which this case rests is to be that he was not content to leave:

title: No Damage in Reactor Leak
description: ATHENS, Ala., July 17 (UPI)  An accidental discharge of radioactive waste into the Tennessee River from a Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant reactor has produced no measurable change in the river water, according to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., July 17 (AP)  Jeb Allen of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Denny Savage of Mission Viejo, Calif., won championships today in the raindelayed final of the National Hot Rod Association's ninth annual Summernational drag races at Raceway Park.

title: United Technologies Profits at Record
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported record quarterly profits and sales for the three months ended June 30. Profits were up 13 percent for the Quarter.

title: More Women Become Surgeons, Though Barriers Fall Slowly
description: Bonna Coulter's reply at the time was a crisp, That's the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard!. She went on to become not only a doctor but also a surgeon, which even today is a rare choke for women. Perhaps the most Be tried to persuade me that in the respansible, duties of relieving ills which the flesh is heir to, it is approiriate that man be the physician, and woman the ntirse.

title: Fussing With New York's Realty Tax
description: The referendum that cut back California's taxing powers  Proposition 13  was only the latest in a long series of condemnations of real estate taxes. New York's courts had already ruled that assessment practices are unfair throughout the state and that all real property must be valued according to market price. Some apartment house tenants have also insisted that New York's laws be changed so they can deduct a portion of their rents on Federal income tax returns. Turning to both issues, the Legislature has passed stopgap help on one and a complex law full of uncertainties on the other.

title: It's TentPitching Time on the Summer Party Circuit
description: At Nelson Rockefeller's 70th birthday party, given recently by his wife, Happy, at their estate in Pocantico Hills; N.Y., dinner was served in an elaborate, brightly colored tent.

title: Privileges for Diplomats in U.S. Stir Resentment and May Be Curbed
description: The special privileges that' are enjoyed by foreign diplomats assigned to the United States  such as immunity from prosecution and penaltyfree parking are being scrutinized by Congress and by local lawenforcement authorities.

title: 7 INDUSTRIAL NATIONS PLEDGE TO SPUR JOBS, CURB INFLATION; U.S. READY TO CUT OIL IMPORTS
description: BONN, July 17 Leaders of the largest industrial democracies agreed today on a modest package of moves to help combat worldwide unemployment without rekindling inflation.

title: Shero Starts Ranger Renovation
description: Fred Shero continued his efforts yesterday to create a New York Ranger team that still exists more in his mind than it ever did on the ice.

title: NUNN FEARS GENEVA WILL PROVE COSTLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Senator Sam Nunn said today that the Carter Administration might soon be required to undertake huge expenditures to protect American missiles from attack by the Soviet Union because negotiators have failed to solve this potential problem in arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Racing Canceled at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 17  Calling the racing surface unsafe, jockeys at Monmouth Park refused to continue riding after the second race today and forced the cancellation of the balance of the thorouehbred proeram.

title: Brushfire on Coast Contained
description: PALMDALE, Calif., July 17 (UPI) Firefighters worked for five hours yesterday before containing a 500acre brushfire in the Angeles National Forest and stayed through the night to make sure the blaze did not flare up again. More than 200 Forest Service and county firefigthers, using five helicopters and four air tankers, battled the blaze in Texas Canyon, 20 miles southeast of Palmdale. There were no injuries, and no structures were burned.

title: Soviet Downs Iranian Helicopter After It Strays, Killing the Crew
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 17 (Reuters)  Soviet air defense forces shot down an Iranian army helicopter, killing the crew, when it strayed across the border last month, it was announced here today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Federal Judge George Barlow refused yesterday to suppress taperecorded evidence to be used in the gambling trial of State Senator William V. Musto, Democrat of Union City, and four others, including three police officials.

title: Alligator Blocks Cars Before He's Lassoed
description: MISSOURI CITY, Tex., July 17 (UPI)  A 14foot alligator, apparently looking for a cool wet spot, settled down in the middle of a street, blocked traffic and snapped at several onlookers early today before he was lassoed and hauled away in a cattle trailer to the Brazos River.

title: Hunter Knocked Out; Yanks Lose 51 Lead
description: With Catfish Hunter starting for the first time since May 9 and Reggie Jackson batting fourth for the first time since June 28, the Yankees tried to regain some degree of normalcy last nieht at Yankee Stadium.

title: Soviet Jews in Israel voice Concern over Kin Left Behind
description: REHOVOTH, Israel  Yevgeny V. Levich looks, healthier and huskier than when he emerged from a year's stretch in a military labor camp in the Soviet Arctic four years ago.

title: Construction: Doubt Voiced
description: The resurgence of severe inflation in general and in construction in particular and an impending decline in residential building has placed the construction industry in a critical position as it enters the second half, the 1978 edition of Dodge/Sweet's Construction Outlook maintained yesterday.

title: Real Places
description: NORTHPORT WHAT a strange shadowrich sight the customers make WW from inside the drivein milk store; as they clutch purse and steering wheel, gear stick and clinking bottles, and sit idling, taking on food and handing over money, then sliding away from this tollbooth of a store like internalambustion torsos from a pit stop.

title: Jascalevich Defense Challenges Finding of Curare in One Patient
description: HACKENSACK, July 17  The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought to show today that one of the alleged victims could not have been poisoned with curare because his symptoms lasted too long for the rapidacting muscle relaxing drug to have been involved.

title: Rains More Difficult for Allen
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July 17  In the leafy Spanishstyle courtyard outside, the weather was warm and sunny, as it almost always is here. And in his gardenapartment suite at Cal State, Fullerton, where the Los Angeles Rams train, the new and old coach, George Allen, talked about how this warm, sunny weather was perhaps his team's most formidable foe in its crusade to win the Super Bowl for the first time. In this weather, he said, it's more difficult to drive people. Away from this weather, when the Rams have traveled to Arctic regions in the National Football League playoffs, they have had a history of losing. Other teams lose their cool. But the Rams lose their warm. Even in the mud of a California rainstorm last year. pro football's beachbovs felt betrayed as they were eliminated by the Minnesota Vikings, 147, in a playoff opener. That loss prompted the departure of Chuck Knox to the Buffalo Bills and the return of George Allen after an interim of seven seasons with the Washington Redskins.

title: Foreign Aid Measure, Cut by Billion, Is Still in Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Carter Administration's $8.9 billion foreign aid program, already cut by more than a billion dollars in the House Appropriations Committee, is in danger of further deep cuts, a variety of prohibitions on aid to certain countries and possibly even defeat in the House.He said Representative Clarence E. Miller, Republican of Ohio, who regularly proposes acrosstheboard cuts in appropriations bills, had agreed not to offer one on foreign aid if the Long amendment carried. An aide to Mr. Miller confirmed It doesn't look too good, said the House Majority leader, James C. Wright Jr. of Texas.

title: TWO HOUSE LEADERS BACK GAINSTAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee are planning a tactical move tomorrow that would give a strong push to tax legislation President Carter has labeled unacceptable and a windfall to millionaires.

title: Cleveland's Dismissed Police Chief Named Corrections Head by Carey
description: ALBANY, July 17  Governor Carey today announced the appointment of Riciard Hongisto, who was dismissed as Police Chief in Cleveland earlier this year, as New York's Commissioner of Correctional Services, and said Mr. Hongisto would take over the duties immediately, with or without Senate confirmation.

title: Illinois Governor Says He Will Veto Measure To Cut Property Tax
description: CHICAGO, July 17  Gov. James R. Thompson announced here today that he would veto farreaching legislation to provide property tax relief that has been embraced by his Democratic opponent, State Comptroller Michael J. Bakalis.

description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Atlantic City Being Overwhelmed By Homeless Seeking Casino Jobs
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 17  This seashore resort is being, inundated with homeless people including entire families and runaway youths, whose hopes of getting casinorelated jobs did not Materialize.

title: Just a Short Walk From Capitol, Indian Rally Draws 1 Lawmaker,
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Nearly 1,000 American Indians and their supporters in a nineday protest demonstration here against Red backlash in legislative proposals, marched to the steps of the United States Capitol today.

title: World News Briefs
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 17 (Reuters)President Spyros Kyprianou dismissed his chief negotiator in peace talks with Turkish Cypriots today, accusing him of blind ambition and tragic mistakes.

title: AMPHETAMINE RING IS RAIDED BY POLICE
description: NEWARK, July 17  The seizure of an illegal drug factory in Winslow Township and the arrest of two men on charges of manufacturing illegal amphetamines were announced here today by Robert J. Del Tufo, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Protest Over Layoffs Grows At Greystone
description: PARSIPPANY, July 17 (AP) Nurses at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital were joined by other hospital workers today in a continuing protest over staff cutbacks.

title: TV: Contrasting Profiles of Mr. Speaker and diSuvero, the Artist
description: ACHANCE study in intriguing contrasts is available tonight on Channel 13, with two documentaries, one about a master politician, the other profiling an artist. Mr. Speaker: A Portrait of Tip O'Neill is being shown at 9 o'clock. North Star: Mark diSuvero is on at 11:35.

title: Fatah Says Iraq Seized Gun Plant
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17Al Fatah, the largest group in the Palestine guerrilla movement, disclosed today that it had an arms plant and a facility for making naval vessels in Iraq, and that the Iraqi Government had seized both.

title: AMPHETAMINE RING IS RAIDED BY POLICE
description: NEWARK, July 17  The seizure of an illegal drug factory in Winslow Township and the arrest of two men on charges of manufacturing illegal amphetamines were announced here today by Robert J. Del Tufo, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Economic Scene
description: GBASSROOTS lobbying, including advocacy advertising, by large corporations, is a subject of growing national concern and debate. The last decade has witnessed an upsurge in corporate use of mass media to publicize viewpoints on major public policy issues that corporate management considers vital to its interests. Estimates place expenditures for corporate communication  to the public at large and to such special segments as employees and shareholders  in excess of $1 billion a year.

title: CurareData Hearing Is Ordered
description: Acting Justice Harold J. Rothwax set the hearing for 2 P.M. in the Criminal Court Building at 100 Centre Street in Manhattan, and directed that the reporter, M. A. Farber, be present. Eugene Scheiman, an attorney for The Times, gave assurances that Mr. Farber would appear voluntarily.

title: Dodgers Defeat Cubs On Smith's Clout, 43
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (AP)  Reggie Smith's second home run of the game, an eighthinning shot off Rick Reuschel, snapped a tie and carried the Los Angeles Dodgersid a 43 Victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Schreyer Is Named Merrill Lynch Head
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the largest brokerage house in the United States, yesterday named a new president, William A. Schreyer, the man responsible for overseeing the recent merger of White Weld into Merrill Lynch.

title: Gomez, Leading Rider At Calder, Dies After Spill
description: MIAMI, July 17 (AP)  George G omen, an apprentice jockey who was the leading rider at Miami's Calder Race Course, died yesterday from injuries he received in a spill nearly two months ago. He was 28 years old. Comez had been at Jackson Memorial Hospital since the fall on May 19. The cause of death was not determined, pending an autopsy, according to the Dade County medical examiner's office.The jockey had broken four ribs and punctured a lung in the twohorse spill. Complications developed. Gomez set a Calder record during the 1977 spring meeting by riding six winners on one program, including five in a row. He set a track record with 63 victories during that meeting and broke that record with 80 victories in the fall meeting.

title: U.S. Envoy to Swiss Drums Up Sales and Raises Hackles
description: BERN  In a mimeographed newsletter To My Pen Pals at home and abroad, Marvin L. Warner, United States Ambassador to Switzerland and a newcomer to international diplomacy, declared recently, We are not the largest embassy in the world and we are not the smallest; we just want to be the best.

title: and a Black Police Chief May Be in the Middle Most of All
description: The man most responsible for the police investigation into the death of a Crown Heights civic leader, Arthur Miller, is William R Bracey, assistant chief of Brooklyn North.

Addis, loving greatgrandmother of Anne & Elizabeth Goldhammer, Dawn &. Jesse A. Addis. Services Tues, 2:30 P.M. Schwartz Bros. Forest Park Chapels", Queens Blvd & 76 Rd. Forest Hills.

title: Steel Output Off 2% in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended July 15 fell 2 percent to 2.58 million tons from 2.63 million tons produced a week earlier, according to the Iron and Steel institute.

title: Minnesota Town Flooded Again
description: AUSTIN, Minn., July 17 (AP)  About 50 families were being evacuated from lowlying sections of Austin today as the southern Minnesota city contended with its second flood in less than two weeks. Many of the people being evacuated as the Cedar River and tributary streams overflowed their banks were the same people who had to flee their homes during the flood of July 6 and 7.

title: TWO HOUSE LEADERS BACK GAINSTAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON. July 17  The leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee are planning a tactical move tomorrow that would give a strong push to tax legislation President Carter has labeled unacceptable and a windfall to millionaires.

title: SALE OF STEEL PIER SET IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 17  Resorts International, owner here of the nation's only legalized gambling casino outside Nevada; announced today that it had purchased the Steel Pier, the famed Boardwalk landmark since 1898, for $5.7 million.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar gained against leading world currencies in moderate New York trading yesterday as President Carter and leaders of six other nations concluded an international summit meeting with an agreement on tactics they hope will speed world economic growth.

title: Chrysler N.V. In 5Year Loan
description: Chrysler Financial Overseas Capital N.V. has signed for a $100 million, fiveyear loan backed by the Chrysler Financial Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Ciuros Checking Prison Security By Making Unannounced Raids
description: New York City's Correction Commissioner, William Ciuros Jr., reported yesterday that he had been making unannounced visits to the city prisons and that a 4 A. M. inspection last Friday at Rikers Island had found every corrrection officer very alert and challenging him and his accompanying team of 10.

title: Barrett Appointed Deputy Chief Of Department of Investigation
description: Brian Barrett, chief of a trial bureau in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, has been appointed deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Investigation; Commissioner Stanley N. Lupkin announced yesterday.

title: Advertising
description: MEDIA'S idea that they can continue to charge advertisers as much as the traffic will bear, may  it just may  have become passe, says Media Decisions magazine.

title: Letters
description: The Times was among the first to discern the nascent SovietChinese schisin. As long as 15 years ago (July 30, 1963), I congratulated The Times on a series of perceptive editorials on the split and its potential significance for American foreign policy and world peace. In one of these editorials (July 24, 1963) you concluded that an ultimate world community living in peace will have to include both Russia and China. Had our nation followed your advice in time and sought to lower the Bamboo Curtain as well as the Iron Curtain, we might have averted the disastrous Far Eastern policy which culminated in Vietnam. Now, 15 years later, as we belatedly strive to overcome our calamitous purblindness, The Times ironically retreats to a posture of warning against Playing the Chinese Card (editorials June 22 and June 30).

title: Illegal Flow of Haitians to Florida Coasts Rising
description: MIAMI, July 17  Thirtythree Haitians landed today on Key Biscayne, the latest arrivals in the tide of illegal immigration from the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Money Rates
description: MONDAY, JULY 17, 1978 (AP)

title: Braves Set Back Mets, 30; 4th New York Loss in Row
description: ATLANTA, July 17  Joe Torre, the Mets manager who was trying to figure out a way to stretch his pitching staff over three doubleheaders in the next four days, got a Solid performance from Nino Espinosa and Dale Murray tonight in the first game of a twin bill against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Afifa, With Shoemaker, Captures Coast Handicap
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 17 (AP) Afifa, a lightweighted long shot ridden by Bill Shoemaker, ran away with the $133,300 Vanity Handicap before 32,432 fans at Hollywood Park yesterday. Taisez Vous, the highweighted favorite, dropped back in the stretch and finished fifth.

title: Spain Buys 4 DC9's
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold four extendedrange DC9's to Ayiaco, the Spanish airline, for $40 million. The planes, scheduled for delivery in the last quarter of 1979, will be built at McDonnell Douglas's plant in Long Beach, Calif. The company said the jets would be equipped with two extra fuel tanks and highperformance Pratt & Whitney engines to give them a range in excess of 2,000 statute miles. Aviaco plans to use them on routes between European cities and the Canary Islands.

title: Toshiba Builds U.S. TV Plant
description: TOKYO, July 17 (Reuters)  The Toshiba Corporation said today that it was building a factory in Nashville, which later this year would begin producing 150,000 to 200,000 color television sets a month for the United States market.

description: ASIALINER (Seatrain). Rotterdam August 3. Jeddah 17, Dammam 25. Bandar Shahs:our 27. Kuwait 29 and Sharjah 31; sails from Weehawken, New Jersey. AUSTRAL PILOT (Farrell). Monrovia July 28. title: OPEC, Ending Meeting, Silent on Dollar Moves
description: LONDON, July 17 (UPI)  A threeday committee meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss the continued use of the falling dollar as the standard for buying and selling oil ended today with no official statement and no indication of any decision.

title: Notes on People
description: ACCORDING to Representative Margaret Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, when the House Judiciary Committee votes today on proposals to extend the deadline for action on the proposed equal rights amendment, many members will have heard from Betty and Gerald R. Ford, who favor an extension. Mrs. Heckler said that, although Mrs. Ford has been confined to bed, undergoing physical therapy for arthritis, she has been telephoning wavering Congressmen, urging them to support an extension of the March. 22, 1979, deadline. I understand Gerald Ford also has made phone calls and has become personally involved, Mrs. Heckler said.

title: Vance, Dayan and Kamel in Britain for Mideast Talks Starting Today
description: LONDON, July 17  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel arrived tonight at a heavily guarded medieval castle outside London for a twoday meeting aimed at seeking an end to the impasse in the Middle East.

title: PHILIP J. GREENSPAN
description: Philip J. Greenspan, the founder of a lampmanufacturing concern bearing his name, died Sunday of cancer at the De Witt Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: New York WASP
description: In New York everyone belongs to a minority group. This gives you pride in your roots and encourages you to feel everybody else is picking on you, which is one of the basic pleasures of the New York experience.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: MONDALE MEETS WITH DISSIDENT'S WIFE: The Vice President welcoming Avital Shcharansky to the White House. Mrs. Shcharansky, whose husband, Anatoly, was sentenced hi Moscow to 13 years imprisonment for treason, wished to thank Government officials who voiced support for him.

title: Insurance Man With Teamster Tie Accused of $6.8 Million Tax Fraud
description: An insurance promoter with reputed ties to organized crime was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of embezzling $1.2 million from Teamster Union funds and evading $6.8 million in income taxes in one of the largest taxevasion cases in history.

title: New MassTransit Plan Released By Albany to Meet Clean Air. Act
description: A transportation improvement proposal released without fanfare by New York State this month promises increased rushhour subway service, faster Long Island Rail Road and Conrail service and better bus service for New York City and suburbs.

title: Andrus, in Alaska Visit, Rules Out Trims in Land Bill
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  After a weeklong tour of Alaska, Cecil D. Andrus, the Secretary of the Interior, says he remains convinced that there should be no trimming of the Administration's proposal that 92.5 million acres more of Federal land in the state - about onefourth of its area - should be put into national parks and other specially protected preserves.

title: Dr. ROBERT R. ERGANG
description: Dr. Robert R. Ergang, a retired professor of history and economics at New York University, died Sunday in St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 700 Boulevard East, Weehawken, N.J.

title: New York Weighs the Cost
description: New York City's bid to hold the 1984 Summer Olympics, rejected in favor of Los Angeles last fall, may be revived if city and state officials can find away to bring the Games here without any significant outlay of municipal funds.

title: Firemen End Strike
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18 (AP) Striking firefighters voted overwhelmingly today to accept a new contract and immediately began returning to work, ending a fiveday walkout that left this city of 400,000 with reduced fire protection.

title: Questions on Fate of Bader Field Stall Atlantic City's Master Plan
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 18  The drafting of this resort's master plan for development as a casino city has been stalled by the problem of what to do with Bader Field, Atlantic City's 144acre intown airport for small planes.

title: Soviet Judge Rules U.S. Reporters Libeled TV and Orders Retraction
description: MOSCOW, July 18  A Soviet court ruled today that two American correspondents had libeled Soviet television employees. The reporters were ordered to publish retractions, either in the Soviet or in the American press, and to pay the equivalent of $1,647 each in court costs.

title: INFORMER IS BACKED ON WITNESS DISPUTE

description: WASHINGTON, July 18  President Carter's beleaguered energy bill took a step forward today when the Senate gave its final approval to a coal-conversion measure by a 92-to-6 vote.

description: LONDON, July 18 (AP)  Derek Humphry, a journalist who admitted having helped his Cancerstrikeri wife to kill her. self three years ago, will not bp prosecuted, a spokesman for Ahe Director of Public Prosecutions said today.

The final communique paid homage to familiar goals - inflationfree growth, reduced dependence on imported oil, more balanced trade accounts, less abrupt shifts in exchange rates. The real test will come in translating these goals into results.

title: NEW CHIEF CHOSEN FOR BOSTON SCHOOLS
description: BOSTON, July 18  The Boston School Committee today named Robert C. Wood, former president of the University of Massachusetts, as superintendent of the city's schools. This marks the first time since 1912 that the top post has gone to person from outside the school system.

title: Soviet Appellate Court Upholds Orlov Sentence
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters)  A Soviet court today rejected an appeal by Yuri F. Orlov, leader of a rights group, against his sentence for antiSoviet agitation and propaganda, his wife said.

title: Screen: Goldie Hawn in 'Foul Play':Jumping Hybrid
description: COUNTLESS attacks are made on Goldie Hawn's life during the course of "Foul Play," but she is clearly not in any real danger. When a midget tries to menace her, for instance, she simply picks up a broom and chases him around her apartment, eventually knocking him out a window. Later, feeling sorry about the incident, she goes to visit the poor traumatized midget in a hospital, and behaves so sweetly and contritely that she gives him an even worse scare.In another scene, when a thug makes the mistake of catching Miss Hawn by surprise, she greets him with the most adorably indignant little shriek the movies have witnessed in years. Miss Hawn often looks frightened, as befits the complicated suspense plot of "Foul Play," but she even more often looks tremulously furious, and that's her secret weapon. Gloria, the librarian Miss Hawn plays here, may be so disarmingly dense she can't spot trouble brewing on the horizon, but once it arrives she's never too out-to-lunch to lose her temper. And her anger, imbued with all the quivering, outraged self-righteousness Miss Hawn can muster, is enough to make the most hardened villain or moviegoer melt.If Miss Hawn does a wide-eyed deadpan through most of the film, her costar, Chevy Chase, is correspondingly cool. "Enjoy your dinner, there's nothing to worry about," says Mr. Chase's detective character reassuringly, having just crashed his car through the front window of a restaurant. "Be careful, it's very slippery here," he warns Miss Hawn, as he escorts her to the houseboat that serves as his lair. No one familiar with Mr. Chase's career on television's "Saturday Night Live" need wonder which of them is about to fall into the drink.Miss Hawn and Mr. Chase meet very early in the film, looking bright and funny and all set to make beautiful music together. Accordingly, it's quite a surprise when "Foul Play" turns out to be more like a thriller than a comedy, and when neither performer is given much opportunity to cut loose. "Foul Play" is a slick, attractive, enjoyable movie with all the earmarks of a hit. But as "House Calls" did a few months ago, it starts out promising genuine wit and originality only to fall back on more familiar tactics after a half-hour or so. If either film had a less winning opening, perhaps it wouldn't leave a vague aftertaste of disappointment.Colin Higgins, who wrote and directed "Foul Play," has aimed for the same kind of thriller-comedy-romance hybrid he attempted in writing "Silver Streak," and this time he's much more successful. Parts of the film, like a few aerial shots at the beginning, that mean to recall Hitchcock do, and there are enough good scares to keep things jumping. Still, Mr. Higgins isn't a facile enough juggler to keep the film's diverse elements from colliding at times. The finale, with two lovers flanked by two corpses, surrounded by the cast of "The Mikado" and cheered on by a religious leader, is bewildering at the very least.Mr. Higgins's penchant for mixing visual elegance with coarse gags is equally ill-advised, especially because it makes him work the gags so hard. Dudley Moore, as a swinging single Miss Hawn unwittingly picks up in a bar, would have been a great deal funnier had Mr. Higgins decorated his bachelor pad with only half the sex-aid devices in the world, instead of all of them. Indeed, the soundtrack from "Saturday Night Fever," which Mr. Moore slaps on the turntable the moment Miss Hawn walks in, would probably have been enough. Here and elsewhere, Mr. Higgins would have done well to demonstrate more confidence in both his actors and his audience."Foul Play" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because it contains several innocent love scenes and a modicum of violence.

title: Culture as History
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.A new way of seeing American politics is emerging among historians. For generations they described political history as the product of economic forces. that is, class conflict and geographic factors. Now they see cultural politics at work: Irishmen against Englishmen, Chicanos against WASPs, moralists against free thinkers, blacks against white.s, Catholics against Protestants, teetotallers against drinkers, and Yankees against white Southerners. Ethnic identity, religion, styles of life - these figure prominently in the newer histories, and they give us a strikingly new picture of the American past. Ideology appears in a fresh perspective, arising from conflicts almost tribal in nature, and often centuries old, between different kinds of peoples.

title: Carter, Reacting to Trials in Soviet, Will Control OilTechnology Sales

He filed the bill after a conversation with Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal. who again registered the Administration's displeasure with the legislation.

title: The Best Commercial Brands
description: THOSE of us who are too busy, too lazy, too impatient or too whatever to make our own ice cream will have to begin by admitting defeat: The sad truth is that although there is a good deal of excellent commercial ice cream available in the city, not even the best offers the mellow, creamy freshness of the homemade variety. That is true whether one makes ice cream by the French or Neapolitan method (based on the cooked egg custard sauce, creme Anglaise) or by the American method, which consists merely of whipping and freezing pure heavy sweet cream with sugar and flavorings and which may include egg yolks. (The version that includes flour is hardly worth making, traditional though it may be.)

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: OVER a period of time I have heard numerous readers lament: But some of your recipes are so l-o-n-g. The fact is that, with certain exceptions, the length of a recipe isn't necessarily related to the cooking time. The recipe for the principal dish on this page is a case in point. It consists of nine steps. If you read carefully, however, you will note that the first four steps are nothing morathan telling you to trim and cut carrots and asparagus in a certain way and to cook them quickly in boiling water. Nothing complicated there.

title: LAST OF FREE TESTS ON THYROID OFFERED

title: Morality Is Back in Town . . .Perhaps
description: IT is sad, but I think accurate, to say that most people spend their lives consciously or unconsciously trying to get in synch with life itself. Of course, let us all genuflect before creative tension, but harmony is what we're striving for, the relief of synchronization. If only we could match the music, get the entire exercise class flinging its limbs in the same direction, catch up with the rest of the Ice Capettes, the pinch between the ideal and the actual, to quote the philosopher William James, would dissolve.

title: Costa Rica Bars Vesco Bid
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 18 (Reuters)  The Costa Rican naturalization board today rejected a request from Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, now traveling abroad, for Costa Rican citizenship. Observers said the decision meant that there was virtually no chance that Mr. Vesco would be allowed to return here to his mansion. The rejection cited as reasons Mr. Vesco's intervention in local politics, and public opposition to his request. He fled the United States in 1972 to avoid charges he looted about $224 million from Investors Overseas Sexvices, the mutual fund.

title: 2 Florida Pilots Swim to Safety
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., July 18 (AP) Two Navy pilots swam to safety today after ditching their T34C trainer aircraft in Santa Rosa Sound, 15 miles east of here, the authorities reported. An instructor and a student pilot brought the plane down about onequarter mile offshore after an engine malfunctioned, a Navy spokesman said. The plane landed in about four feet of water.

title: Pink Panther Tries Revenge in 5th Film:For the Pun of It
description: "THE REVENGE of the pink Panther," the fifth in the series of Inspector Clouzot comedies by Blake Edwards, the writer and director, and Peter Sellers, the star, drives a wooden stake through the heart of reason.If you have the Clouzot habit, as I have, there's very little that Mr. Edwards and Mr. Sellers could do that would make you find the movie disappointing, or not up to their own standards, or slow in spots, or, unfortunately, not as much fun as "The Pink Panther Strikes Again," "The Return of the Pink Panther," "A Shot in the Dark" or "The Pink Panther."Such comments are pointless when one has come to the realization that the "Panther" films are not separate entities but one continuing, effervescent saga about man (Inspector Clouzot) and his deficiencies.Clouzot rides (walks, stumbles, falls, trips) again in "The Revenge of the Pink Panther," which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters, and which provides Clouzot with all sorts of marvelously transparent excuses for physical bungling and for interfering with the progress of what he calls "loowa" and order.Once more on hand to complement and support Mr. Sellers are Burt Kwouk as Cato, his reliably unreliable, karate-chopping manservant, and the inestimably funny Herbert Lom as Chief Inspector Dreyfus, Clouzot's former superior who's been driven mad by Clouzot's internationally acclaimed triumphs.Robert Webber plays it more or less straight as Clouzot's latest archenemy, an American business tycoon who deals in heroin. Most important of all, Dyan Cannon is around to play what might be called a flawed femme fatale, a person who, like Clouzot, has a tendency to bend  successfully  all the laws of nature. They are most winning sleuths, especially when, disguised as Chinese coolies, they register at a fancy Hong Kong hotel as Mr. and Mrs. Low Key.Horrendous puns, slapstick gags and disguises are the material of the comedy that, for no particular purpose that I can think of, has Clouzot, at one point and another, masquerade as a woman, a peg-legged sailor who carries an inflatable rubber parrot on his shoulder, and as Toulouse-Lautrec, a masquerade that prompts someone to say in admiration, "Now you can work both the Left Bank and Montmartre in anonymity!""The Revenge of the Pink Panther," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains one or two suggestive sequences that will go over the head of anyone less than three feet tall and 9 years of age.
