title: Film: Tatum O'Neal
description: "INTERNATIONAL VELVET," Bryan Forbes's sequel to Clarence Brown's classic 1944 film, "National Velvet," is a racking experience for any reasonably self-possessed adult, continuously pulling the viewer between a sneer and a tear.The film, which opens today at the Guild and other theaters, exploits without shame, wit or subtlety our sympathy for misunderstood children, for animals, for pluck, progress, perseverance and, especially, for against-all-odds success.The photography is so lyrical you may feel airsick by the end, while the soundtrack score by Francis Lai should be labeled with a skull and crossbones. After listening to this music for more than two hours, you get an idea of what it would have been like to be in Pompeii that fatal day had Vesuvius been full of butterscotch instead of lava.Yet "International Velvet" has more than its share of moments, almost all of them centering on the performance of the eerily talented, immensely appealing Tatum O'Neal, who was 14 years old when the film was made and, for the purposes of Mr. Forbes's fiction, ages (if that's the right word) from 10 to 18 in the course of the movie. She just may be a superlative actress. It's not easy to tell yet, though she seems to possess the sort of infinitely adaptable personality that film directors dream of. Her face, still in process of being formed, reflects degrees of feeling that transform the child into someone beyond identifiable age. She's unique.The movie is something else. Mr. Forbes's screenplay picks up the character played by Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" about 25 years later (though the movie is very fast and loose with time), when the girl, now played by Nanette Newman (Mrs. Bryan Forbes), becomes the guardian of her orphaned niece, Sarah Brown (Miss O'Neal).The niece, a very large 10-year-old who's been raised in Arizona, arrives in England with a chip on her shoulder that can be removed only by an obsessive interest in horses and by the love and understanding of her aunt and Christopher Plummer, the writer Miss Newman lives with.Whereas Velvet won her nickname by winning the Grand National steeplechase as a girl, Sarah becomes International Velvet by being the youngest member of the British Olympic riding team.As domestic drama, "International Velvet" is facetious and coy and just about unbearable. Miss Newman and Mr. Plummer have silly roles that they play with a kind of provincial sophistication, which may be what the director wanted (since nothing in this film is uncalculated). As a movie about a girl, her horse and the big race. "International Velvet" sneaks up on you in unexpectedly moving ways.The steeplechase sequences are superb and the film has a first-class performance by Anthony Hopkins as the tough, no-nonsense trainer of the Olympic riding team. Mr. Hopkins is an actor of such crisp intelligence that he seems to be in a movie completely removed from the sentimental romantic drama inhabited by Miss Newman and Mr. Plummer. It's to Miss O'Neal's credit that she moves from one to the other not only without visible strain but with (dare I say womanly?) ease.

title: Ice Cream: There's Nothing Like Homemade
description: IT would seem that nothing could be less Chinese than ice cream. And yet there are legends that Marco Polo returned to Italy from his travels in the 14th century with tales of Orientals reclining on embroidered cushions, dabbing at dishes of ice brought from the mountains on camel back, and flavored with exotic fruits. Frozen desserts in the form of water ices were thus  according to that exotic account  established in Italy. The idea was spread to France through the Medicis, accord- ing to the same source, and French chefs took their usual giant step forward and replaced water ices with ice cream. Thence the idea traveled as a court secret to England and eventually, in colonial times, to America.

title: Fire Hits Nashville Arts Center
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19 (UPI) Fire broke out yesterday in the $13 million Tennessee Performing Arts Center that is under construction in downtown Nashville, but 20 construction workers were rescued from above the sixth floor, and no injuries were reported. Initial reports indicated a welder's torch had set fire to some pitch. Ten workers were injured at the project last month when an elevator failed, and one worker was killed in a fall earlier this year.

description: The EastWest talks on Mutual and Balanced Force Reductions in Europe recessed in Vienna yesterday still deadlocked after five years of largely futile negotiations.

title: An Extended Deadline Offered to Los Angeles
description: GENEVA, July 19  The International Olympic Committee said today that its president, Lord Killanin, had offered to extend until Aug. 21 ihe deadline for reaching a satisfactory agreement with Los Angeles on holding the 1989 Summer Games.

title: Notes on People
description: IN an effort to stop a mass exodus of the population from the area around Salonika, Greece, Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis flew there yesterday. He hoped to calm residents who believed that a major earthquake would coincide with tonight's full moon. Fears that such an earthquake would occur were based on the fact that a strong tremor on June 20, a day before the last full moon, killed about 50 people and injured many more in Salonika, in the north of Greece. In recent days, as rumors spread that there would be another quake when the moon was full again, thousands left the city and many of those remaining were sleeping in parks and other open spaces. Mr. Caramanlis hoped to demonstrate that there was nothing to fear with the coming of a full moon. Meanwhile, Government seismologists also sought to assure the populace that there was no connection between full moons and earthquakes.

title: Air Force Says New Missiles May Need Area the. Size of Connecticut
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Air Force has concluded that a proposed mobile missile system for the 1980's will need an area about the size of Connecticut, or 4,000 to 6,500 square miles.

description: Music

title: 2 Found Dead in Gulf of Mexico
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 19 (UPI)  Two South Carolina men were found dead on fishing boat in the Gulf of Mexico today and a third was taken to a hospital after inhaling poisonous fumes, the Coast Guard said. The men were aboard the Swashbuckler, a 68foot fishing and shrimp boat out of Bayour La Batre, Ala. The Coast Guard said that the cause of the accident was under investigation.

title: Maryland Names James
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., July 19 (UPI)  Carl James, executive director of the Sugar Bowl, was nominated today by the athletic committee of the University of Maryland board of regents to be the school's next athletic director. The full board is expected to approve his appointment.

description: The American Can Company, a leading manufacturer of metal containers and packaging products, reported yesterday that strong performances by its consumer products, sewing pattern and recorded music and tape divisions had lifted secondquarter earnings 12 percent to $30 million, or $1.52 a share, on an 11 percent sales rise to $980.4 million.

title: CREDIT MARKETS OneYear Treasury Bills Get Lackluster Response
description: An upswing in Government securities prices and a decline in yields that began a few days ago continued yesterday morning, but many issues gave up their gains in the afternoon and closed lower.

title: 3D TENTATIVE PACT WITH P.B.A. REACHED AS CITY EASES STAND

title: House Votes to Set One Ceiling On Immigration to United States
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  The House voted yesterday to set one worldwide ceiling on immigration to the United States, replacing the current, separate ceilings for the Eastern and Western hemispheres.

title: Wyoming Officer's Widow Says Incriminating Data Were Stolen
description: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., July 19 (AP) Documents gathered by an undercover policeman who was investigating allegations of corruption here were stolen from his home the day he was shot, his widow said yesterday.

title: Facing Soviet Reality
description: When the Soviet Union behaves as it has in these last weeks, we are revolted. To convict a dissident of treason because he talked to a foreign correspondent, to send someone away for years because he wanted to emigrate. and hung a banner out his window these are the acts of men who are in the deepest sense uncivilized.

title: More Japanese Imports Urged

description: TOKYO, July 19  The latest Japanese trade surplus figures pushed the yen higher against the dollar today. The dollar fell to 201.95 yen at the close from 202.15 yesterday with the Bank of, Japan intervening on a small scale to support the United States currency.

title: Bolivian Court Annuls Presidential Election, Calls for a New Vote
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 19 (AP)  The National Election Court annulled Bolivia's July 9 presidential election tonight and called for another election within 180 days.

title: EDWARD J. GALLAGHER

Grasso, by announcing that she would not pick her running mates but would leave the choice to the 1,357 delegates at the state convention beginning this Friday, has created in the last few days what House Speaker James J. Kennelly calls the most complex political mosaic in the state's history.

description: An 84-year-old man and his elderly wife were both reported in satisfactory condition in separate hospitals yesterday after they were severly beaten and robbed in their Bronx apartment Tuesday afternoon.

title: Husband Held in Stabbing Death
description: HOWELL, N.J., July 19 (UPI) Monmouth County man was arrested early today and charged with stabbing his wife to death and wounding his moth- er-in-iaw during a domestic quarrel at their Howell Township home, authorities said. The man, George Terlizzese was arrested at 1:30 :A.M. and held pending a hearing on charges of murder, atrocious assault, two counts of assault and battery with a dangerous weapon and assault with intent to kill.

title: Rock: Carlene Carter, From Country
description: BEFORE Carlene Carter can be accepted on her own terms, she has to be explained. As every review or article about her has dutifully mentioned, she is the daughter of June Carter Cash. the step- daughter or Jonnny Cash, and the granddaughter of Maybelle Carter. She is touring with the Rumour, an English band that is best known as backing group for the hew wave rocker Graham Parker and, while there is plenty of country in her presentation, there is also plenty of hardcore rockan-roll.

The increases apply to all orders received beginning today and to all shipments made after Aug. 4.

title: Disks: Religious Music From English Chorales
description: ALTHOUGH Gustav Hoist's The Hymn of Jesus may sound conservative today, its appearance in 1920 marked breakthrough in English religious choral music. One listener has been quoted as saying, long after the pre- miere: To those,of us who were young then, this very new music came first as a shock, then as a revelation. And when the composer's music in this vein reached the American consciousness a decade later, it made the same kind of impact. In its rhythmic and harmonic freedom, in its color and sensuousness, it had a strangeness and beauty that affected those who heard it for the first time.

title: Xerox Penalty To SCM Is Cut
description: HARTFORD, July 19  The maximum amount of damages that the SCM Corporation can obtain in its antitrust suit against the Xerox Corporation was reduced today to $114 million from $225 million.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 19, 1978

title: Rose Extends His Streak To 32 With Bunt in Ninth
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP)Pete Rose extended his hitting streak to 32 games with a twoout bunt single in the ninth inning tonight and Ken Henderson's threerun homer in the seventh and George Foster's grand slam in the eighth led the Cincinnati Reds to a 72 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Paraguayan Links Chilean General to Letelier Case
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 19 Paraguay's chief of military intelligence has given United States investigators sworn evidence, including a copy of a coded message, linking Gen. Mantel Contreras SepUlveda, the former chief of Chile's secret police, to the assassination of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, in Washington.

title: Theater: Little Angels
description: IT WILL be fall before Louis La Russo 2d's play Knockout reaches Broadway. In the meantime he has sent us a twoact drama, Momma's Little Angels, which opened at the Quaigh Theater last night. It is a play with classical lineaments. Parallels to Greek tragedies suggest themselves. And although it is marked  and marred in spots by maudlin passages and others that are melodramatic and not altogether convincing, the play's undeniable strengths and passion come through.

title: Hungary Suspends 2
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 19 (UPI)  The Hungarian soccer federation suspended two star players for one year today for their misbehavior at last month's World Cup in Argentina. Tibor Nyilasi and Andras Toeroecsik had been expelled in the cup match with Argentina in Buenos Aires.

title: J.C. Penney Slips Into Fashion
description: Sophisticated shoppers have traditionally regarded J.C. Penney & Company as a place where suburbanites and smalltown residents bought such utilitarian items as sheets, towels and children's clothes. But even such shoppers pranced off to other stores to buy more glamorous apparel for themselves.

title: Kodak Net Rises 41.9% In Quarter
description: ROCHESTER, July 19 (AP)  The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest maker of photographic supplies, reported today record earnings and profits for the second Quarter.

title: House Kills Bill to Aid Coal Slurry Pipelines
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The House today killed a coal slurry pipeline bill aimed at providing competition for railroads In hauling coal to utilities

title: Reggie's World: Above It All
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 19 Just as Reggie Jackson above taking orders, his home is above the clouds. His address, ironically, is 22 Yankee Hill, and far below puffs gray cotton shaded the city streets. But where his elegant home is perched on a woody cliff overlooking San Francisco Bay, a golden sunset sparkled through the big glass win- dows. Inside a man was seen moving around, but when he answered the bell, it was not the suspended slugger. He's not here, said Everett Moss, who described himself as Reggie Jackson's friend. He's down near San Diego with some friends. They must be old friends, because Reggie Jackson does not have many new friends. Nobody is sympathizing with him now. In other crises, his declarations at least were

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday an agreement with Holiday Inns Inc. under which Hertz Rent-ACar service would be made available through installations at more than 1,500 Holiday Inns in the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: VANCE REPORTS CAIN AT TALKS IN BRITAIN; WILL CO TO MIDEAST
description: HOLLINGBOURNE, England, July 19  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that although major differences remained between Egypt and Israel, his twoday meeting with their Foreign Ministers had produced enough results to justify his flying to the Middle East in about two weeks for more exchanees.

title: AntiSomoza Strike Halts Most Business in Managua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 19 Nicaragua's increasingly militant opposition called a 24hour nationwide work stoppage today as part of a new offensive aimed at forcing the resignation of President Anastasio Somoza Debavle.

title: Inland Steel Up 14.8%
description: Operations of the Inland Steel Company in the second quarter resulted in a 14.8 percent increase in earnings to $45.7 million, or $2.23 a share, on record sales of $837.5 million, the company re- ported yesterday. The Republic Steel Corporation, the fourth largest in the industry, reported on Tuesday a 41.4 percent profit gain. Inland, sixth ranking in the field, said it expected steel mill operating levels to be close to capacity during the second half with annual shipments expected to reach the 1974 record of 6.1 million tons.

title: Tax Inquiry At Anheuser
description: ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP)  A Federal grand jury here is investigating former competitive trade practices of AnheuserBusch Inc. for possible tax violations, the company said today.

title: State Considers Appeal Of FlagPledge Ruling
description: TRENTON, July 19 (AP)  State legal officials were considering yesterday whether to appeal a Federal court ruling declaring unconstitutional a New Jersey statute compelling school students to stand during the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: NEW &
description: AnneMarie Schiro

title: 3 Tests of a FirstRate Actor
description: Walter Kerr

title: Carter News Session at 8 Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  President Carter, in a bid for 30 minutes of prime television time and an increase in his sagging public opinion ratings, has scheduled his next news conference for 8 P.M. tomorrow.

title: 3D TENTATIVE PACT WITH P.B.A. REACHED AS CITY EASES STAND
description: A new tentative agreement between New York City and its police officers union was announced yesterday after Mayor Koch withdrew two key proposals  efforts to write into the contract a curb on sickleave abuses and more flexibility in working shifts.

title: Father Hogan Enters Stakes
description: The nomination, of Father Hogan for Saturday's $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap finally was accepted at Belmont Park yesterday11 days late.

title: Weather Receives a New Format
description: Beginning today the weather forecasts and records in The New York Times will be presented in a new format with specialized material prep fired by Dr. Bob Harris from data provided by government agencies.

title: Consulate of Jamaica Seeks to. Aid the Crew Still Aboard America
description: The Jamaican Consulate General in New York asked its Government yesterday to intervene with the island's American Embassy to guarantee rettirn passage for 100 crew members aboard the cruise ship America, which has'been plagued with problems since she made her first cruise on July 1.

title: Carter's Aide, Linked to Issuing False Prescription, Takes Leave
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Dr. Peter G. Bourne, President Carter's principal adviser on drugs and narcotics, acknowledged today that a prescription for a powerful sedative that he had written and intended for one of his staff members had been made out for a fictitiouS person. Late today, he announced that he had been granted an indefinite leave of absence with pay from his White House post.

title: Chances of Postal Walkouts Rise As Prospects for a Settlement Dim
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The prospects for an orderly conclusion of postal negotiations dimmed today as the contract expiration at midnight tomorrow drew near, raising the possibility of disrupted mail service Friday.

title: Auto Union Head Protests Role Of Business, Quits Carter Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The president of the United Automobile Workers union, Douglas A. Fraser, resigned today from President Carter's Labor-Management Group, charging that the nation's business community was waging a onesided class war.

title: From Barns To Brownstones
description: WHEN Henry Snyder first took up the brush and palette, he was helping his father farm a thousandacre spread in the rural South. Between chores he learned to paint, and, not surprisingly, his subjects were the constants of his environment: cows, mules, haystacks, cornfields and cotton patches.

title: U.S. AIDE DENIES BAN ON EMBRYO TESTING
description: A staff member of the National Institutes of Health testified yesterday that the institutes had never had a general ban against experimentation with testtube fertilization.

title: Books of The Times
description: ASTRANGER arrives one day in St. Adrienne, La. He is frail, gawky, unkempt and dissipated. He says his name is Robert, Robert X. He. is from Chicago.

title: Barclays Bank Agrees To Buy American Credit
description: Barclays Bank International Ltd., which operates banks in New York and California with combined assets of $1 billion, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase the American Credit Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., for about $191 million.

title: Attorneys for Mandel Optimistic After Appeals Panel Hears Case
description: ABINGDON, Va., July 19  Lawyers for former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and his five codefendants, convicted last year of mail fraud in a bribery scheme and sentenced to up to four years in prison, received what they called an encouraging reception here today from a panel of three Federal appeals judges.

title: VANCE REPORTS GAIN AT TALKS IN BRITAIN; WILL CO TO MIDEAST
description: HOLLINGBOURNE, England, July 19  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that although major differenceS remained between Egypt and Israel, his twoday .meeting with their Foreign Ministers had produced enough results to justify his flying to the Middle East in about two weeks for more exchanges.

title: U.S. to Dedicate Wind Generator
description: CLEVELAND, July 19 (UPI) A large wind turbine generator, the Federal Government's second such unit, is to be dedicated Friday at Culebra, a small island about 50 miles east of San Juan, P.R. The

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, July 19,1978

title: Braniff Profit Advances 15%
description: The Braniff International Corportion, which owns Braniff Airways, sixth largest of United States flag international air carriers, reported a 15 percent increase in secondquarter earnings to $11.2 million, or 56 cents a share, on a 22.9 percent rise in operating revenues to $236 million.

title: Mystery Theater Goes to WNEW
description: Mystery Theater, the nightly series of radio dramas, will switch its New York base front WORAM, where it has played the last 4 years, to WNEWAM starting Monday evening. The broadcasts have been scheduled from 8:05 to 9 P.M. seven nights a week.

title: Gasoline Sets Record Output
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that gasoline production reached record highs in the week ending July 14, with daily production at 7.7 million barrels, against 7.2 million barrels produced daily a week earlier.

title: Dance: Premiere at Pillow
description: THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival started its third week of summer dance on Tliesday with a typically eclectic bit of programming. Ballet was represented by a pair of young dancers from American Ballet Theater in two Classical pas de deux. Our own roots were represented by a suite of dances choreographed by Ted Shawn, the founder of the Jacob's Pillow school and theater complex 46 years ago and a formative figure in American modern dance. And Rachel Lampert and Dancers were on hand to represent a newer generation, nearly sabotaging the program with Miss Lampert's delectable but corruscating wit.

title: Mostly Mozart:Bonell Offers:TWo..Guitat Solos
description: AS THE Mostly Moiiit Festival grows older, it ventures farther and farther afield from Mozart himself. On Tuesday night, in only the second event of this 1978 installment of the the now tradi- tional summer festival presented at Avery Fisher Hall, the venturing extended to late 19thcentury Spain with music for guitar composed: by Francisco Tarrega andIsaac Albeniz.

title: 4,000 Spaniards Honor Franco
description: MADRID, July 19 (UPI) About 4,000 Spaniards made a pilgrimage to the grave of Francisco. Franco, in the Valley of the Fallen, 12 miles northwest of Madrid, yesterday to mark the 42d anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War.

title: Sound
description: Hans Fantel

title: About New York
description: Feeding them is one thing. The drivers, very considerate men who are reformed exconvicts, have to move fast in delivering the hundreds of hot meals to the old people who are slotted about the worn apartment blocks of the West Bronx.

title: Milacron Suit Settled
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. said that the Kearney & Trecker Corporation had agreed to pay Milacron $2.05 million to settle longstanding tool changer patent litigation with Milacron. The payment, Milacron said, represents attorney fees and expenses incurred by Milacron in defense of the action, filed in 1965.

title: Albany Legislature Votes Package Of Stiff Youth and Adult Penalties
description: ALBANY, July 19  The Legislature today approved a tough compromise package increasing penalties for serious crimes by adults and juveniles, despite bitter criticism from a handful of liberal legislators who said the measure provided severe punishment for crime but ignored its prevention.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Smith Booed By Whites On Black Rhodesia Role
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 19 (AP)  An allwhite audience booed and heckled Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tonight when he said he had agreed to bring blacks into the Government because it was the best deal that could be expected after six years of guerrilla war.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: Yamaha Bikes to Be Recalled
description: TOKYO, July 19 (UPI)  Yamaha Motor Company said yesterday that it would recall about 27,900 smallsized motorbikes of two models for repair of a defective brake system. The company said that the vehicles, Yamaha Sport RD 50 and 50 SP, were produced between March and June of this year.

title: MedtcalExpenses Pilot Program Receives Final Passage in Albany
description: ALBANY, July 19  The Assembly gave final passage late last night to a bill establishing an experimental pilot program that extends insurance against extraordinary medical expenses to all New Yorkers. But the plan was immediately attacked by New York City officials as a fiscal balloon that would expose the city to millions of dollars in increased medical costs.

title: Apples Vanquish Loves For 6th Time in Season
description: The New York Apples remained unbeaten against the Indiana Loves, scoring their sixth World Team Tennis victory of the season over the visitors before 2,918 fans Tuesday night at the Felt Forum. The score was 2823.

title: Aussie Sailing Victor
description: SANDHAMN, Sweden, July 19 (AP)  Frank Tolhurst of Australia, in Arunga III, scored his third straight victory in five races of the world 5.5Meter sailing championship today.

title: TV: I Want It a Documen tary on Life in Marin County
description: TONIGHT at 10, NBC News offers a tour of the Golden Ghetto of Marin County in California. The suburb of San Francisco is predominantly white, wealthy and, according to this documentary, disturbed. The county's indefatigably trendy residents are discovering that the pot at the end of the overachieving rainbow contains little more than the next fad promising total happiness.

title: The Editorial Notebook An Encouraging Breeze at the Summit
description: What seems most important about the sevennation summit is that it is still there. Despite countless arguments, the leaders of the industrial democracies are meeting yearly to coordinate economic policy. They are developing effective machinery to follow up their pledges and prepare the next encounter. The process is as significant as the substance.

title: Vanishing Broker Pleads Guilty
description: James W. Doyle, a former smalltown Minnesota stockbroker, came to the end of a long road on Tuesday, one that began in 1976 and included stops in Las Vegas, San Francisco. Costa Rica ana ranama. For Mr. Doyle, who had been charged with fleeing the country with $2.1 million in securities and cash, pleaded guilty to reduced charges in a Federal courtroom after a plea bargaining agreement was reached with the United States Attorney there.

title: Notes From a Losing Office
description: For a fleeting moment, let us mix the unmixable, in the way that life mixes up things before lawyers and editorial writers apply their artifice of clarity.

title: `Blue Laws
description: TRENTON, July 19  Although New Jersey's restrictions on Sunday sales in of the state's 21 counties were upheld yesterday by the State Supreme Court, the blue laws, which have plagued merchants since 1704, may be doomed.

title: POLICY ON RETARDED IS PRAISED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey praised Westchester County's facilities for the mentally retarded yesterday in one of numerous appearances that took him from Brooklyn to Ossinine.

title: About New York
description: Feeding them is one thing. The drivers, very considerate men who are reformed exconvicts, have to move fast in delivering the hundreds of hot meals to the old people who are slotted about the worn apartment blocks of the West Bronx.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Associated Press
description: INDIAN PROTEST CONTINUES: A member of the group of American Indians who marched across the country Washington, demonstrating on Tuesday. The Indians ended their protest of civil rights abuses yesterday.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Bill. to Spur Investment Delights Levitt of Amex
description: Yesterday was a special day for Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, and well it might have been. For it was the day that a measure he has sought almost since the day he assumed his Amex position at the beginning of January was introduced as a bill in Congress.

title: Jackson's Differences
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 19 Fred Stanley, for one, does not think the suspension of Reggie Jackson will help to solve or even alleviate the Yankees multifaceted problems. In fact, the shortstop said today, more likely it will just add to their mushrooming list of problems and contribute another farcical shade to their deteriorating image.

title: H.E.W. to Intensify Drive to Find Fathers of Children on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The Government announced plans today to intensify efforts to track down the missing fathers of children on welfare and make the parent pay child support.

title: Inland Steel Up 14.8%
description: Operations of the Inland Steel Company in the second ,quarter resulted in a 14.8 percent increase in, earnings to $45.7 million, or, $2.23 a share, on record sales of $837.5 million, the company reported yesterday. The Republic Steel Corporation, the fourth largest in the industry, reported on .Tuesday a 41.4 percent profit gain.

title: EARNINGS Honeywell, Sperry Rand Profits Rise
description: Two leading computer companiesHoneywell Inc. and the Sperry Rand Corporation, announced yesterday improved secondquarter earnings. Honeywell's earnings rose 48.6 percent, while Sperry Rand's gained 20.5 percent.

title: United Press International
description: KULAKOV BURIED IN MOSCOW: Politburo members carry urn with ashes of their colleague, Fyodor D. Kulakov, for burial in the Kremlin wall. From- left: Kirill T. Mazurov, Andrei P. Kirilenko, Andrei A. Gromyko and

title: An Indian Media Play
description: WASHINGTON  The spectacle of the American Indians participating in The Longest Walk  a spiritual journey to protest certain anti-Indian bills introduced in Congress  illustrates once again the frightening ability of the news media to shape the presentation of issues by special interest groups and the perception of those issues by the public.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Can you tell me the best method for stripping down to the bare wood an old wing table with spindle legs? It is presently coated with a dark stain and probably a varnish and a wax. S.S.S., New York City.

title: Continental Group To Expand Mill
description: A $138 million costreduction, modernization and expansion of its Hopewell, Va., kraft mill has been approved by the board of the Continental Group.

title: 12 Arrested Off Florida COast
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., July 19 (UPI) United States Customs inspectors arrested 12 men here yesterday after intercepting two 50foot lobster boats laden with marijuana. Seven of the men, arrested aboard the two vessels, were charged with possession of marijuana with intent to distribute. Five others, found in bushes along the shore, were also taken into custody.

title: News Parley on TV
description: The three television networks and their local stations  Channels 2, 4 and 7  have scheduled live telecasts at 8 o'clock tonight for President Carter's news conference. The following radio stations have also scheduled a live broadcast: WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA and WNYCAM.

title: Savings Bank Net Outflow
description: The country's savings banks had a net deposit outflow in June, contrary to what some in the industry had expected. The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks put the net deposit outflow last month at $75 million, with total deposits of $1.48 billion. The banks had a net deposit inflow of $97 million in May. The association said the introduction of sixmonth moneymarket certificates in the industry had failed to reverse the weak deposit experience of savings banks.

title: SPECIES LEGISLATION IS BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The Senate voted today to permit exemptions under the Endangered Species Act, a law that caused construction to be halted on multimillion dollar dam because it ,threatened the survival of a fish species.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Guilty Plea In Foreign Bribe Case
description: The United Brands Company pleaded guilty yesterday to a criminal charge of conspiracy to pay a $2.5 million bribe to a high official in Honduras.

title: Broadway Maintenance Files for Reorganization
description: The Broadway Maintenance Corporation, frequently involved in controversy in the 25 years thatit held a monopoly on streetlight maintenance in Manhattan and the Bronx, yesterday-filed for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy law in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The company listed assets of $13 million and liabilities of $13 million:

title: MedicalExpenses Pilot Program Receives Final Passage in Albany
description: ALBANY, July 19  The Assembly gave final passage late last night to a bill establishing an experimental pilot program that extends insurance against extraordinary medical expenses to all New Yorkers. But the plan was immediately attacked by New York City officials as fiscal balloon that would expose the city to millions of dollars in increased medical costs.

title: Plan for a Review of 1984 Finances
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19  Representatives of this city and the International Olympic Committee agreed today to one last meeting in Europe some time next month to decide whether Los Angeles would be the host of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games.

title: To an Energy Policy, Slowly
description: The contrast between President Carter's bold pledges on energy at the Bonn summit and Congress's modest progress on energy legislation is striking. Mr. Carter promised the allies that the United States will have in place by the end of the year an energy program to cut oil imports by 2.5 million barrels a day by 1985. Yet his backers in the Senate were able to give him only a small token of progress.

title: 8 Restaurants Cited for Violating The New York City Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited eight restaurants for Health Code violations and listed six that had corrected earlier violations. The restaurants were:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Gerber Block Held Legal
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 19 (UPI)  A Federal judge ruled today that the Gerber Products Company had not violated securities law by blocking a takeover attempt by Anderson, Clayton & Company of Rouston.

title: Egyptians Urging U.S. To Step In With Plans For Accord in Mideast
description: CAIRO, July 19An oftmade Egyptian suggestion that it is up to the United States to step in with its own proposal for a Middle East settlement was made again today by officials and private citizens alike as the Middle East talks ended inconclusively in Britain.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Senate Panel Approves Industrial Parks Plan

title: Managers Prove to Be Discreet
description: With all the furor that the Reggie Jackson suspension has set off, the handful of major league managers reached yesterday were suprisingly closedmouthed about the situation.

title: XRays Seen as Possible Method To Detect Legionnaires
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 19 (UPI) Chest Xrays can provide evidence indicating the possible presence of the legionnaires disease in a patient, a University of Vermont researcher said yesterday.

title: Casinos
description: RENO, Nev., July 19  William F. Harrah's will, which will dispose of an estate of more than $137 million, was filed for probate in the Washoe County Courthouse here today. It divided the estate between his widow and two adopted sons.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: `JESTER'S JESTER, is the title of a multicolored porcelain sculpture Cybis to be presented by Governor Byrne to Bob Hope, the comedian.. Mr. Hope will be the guest of honor today at a ceremony marking his 75th birthday and the opening of a twoday engagement at the Garden State Arts Center.

title: South African Crime Statistics Portray a Violent Society
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 19  When Mceliva Dladla died late last month, the event was reported in one paragraph in The Post, the newspaper that covers Soweto. The inner said that Mr. Diadla had been resting on his bed in a migrant workers hostel when two other black men approached him in the semi-darkness and rained a series of blows on him with a blunt ax. The 35-year-old Zulu died instantly.

title: Settling a Contract in the Streets
description: Despite all manner of tough talk against the demonstrations, provocations and mob censorship New. York City's police union, Mayor Koch appears have surrendered on two issues that only a few days ago he considered crucial features of a new contract. The Mayor vowed to protect public order, yet in the end he yielded to unacceptable conduct and outrageous threats. The experience will haunt the community for many years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Express International Corporation, Stamford, Conn., a leading air freight transportation company, has elected Siegfried Kratzer vice presidentexecutive sales.

title: 4 U.S. Oil Companies, With Official Support, Start Talks With China
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Four American oil companies, with government encouragement, have entered into talks with Peking to establish offshore drilling operations, according to officials.

title: An Active Interest in Art
description: On a daycamp tour to City Hall Park from East Harlem, youngsters found George Sugarman's sculpture Yellow Ascending, more than just pleasing to the eye. They climbed and slid as they explored the aluminum structure.

title: Kamov and Korchnoi Put Off Second Game
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 19The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and his challenger, Viktor Korchnoi, took a day off today in their title match.

title: Letters
description: That Move to the Farm

title: Du Pont Net Rises 18.2%; Kodak Up
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's leading chemical concern, reported an 18.2 percent rise in secondquarter earnings yesterday. Others in the industry had mixed results.

title: Various Corporations Report Their Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: Forperiods as snown. (N) mapcotes stock Is listed on the New York Stock Excharige, (A) the American Stock .Exchange and (0) over-thecounter:-

title: Building Suppliers Profits Gain
description: Producers of building products and materials reported a 25 percent yeartoyear earnings gain in the initial 1978 quarter, according to the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: Morristown Is Enlisting Aid of Wise Counsel
description: MORRISTOWN, July 20 (UPI)  In the fight to wipe out the town's rat population, Morristown officials are learning to respect  or at least put up with the finicky life style of owls.

title: 14 in Korea Feared Drowned
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 20 (Reuters)  Fourteen schoolchildren, 13 girls and a boy, were feared drowned today when the small motorboat in which they were going to school capsized in a river near the city of Taejon, the local police said. The skipper and three boys swam to safety.

title: Wildlife Unit Corrects A Report on Air Quality
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  The National Wildlife Federation says that its recent report listing air quality in 20 cities is misleading.

title: McDonald's to Stop 2 Advertising Claims.
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20 (UPI) The city attorney's office has ordered the McDonald's Corporation hamburger chain to stop advertising fresh orange juice that had been frozen and maple syrup, which contained too little true syrup to justify such a label.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: The Fed's latest tightening of monetary policy came as it reported a decline of $2 billion in the nation's basic money supply.

title: EXMAYOR WHELAN IS GRANTED PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  The Federal Parole Commission today granted parole, effective Aug. 15, to former Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and former City Council President Thomas M. Flaherty, each serving 15year prison terms for extortion and bribery while in office.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Labor

title: Study Finds Most Men Unaware Happy Wives Have Sex Problems
description: BOSTON, July 20 (AP)  When a man has a sexual problem, his wife probably knows about it, but the man rarely recognizes his wife's problems, according to a published study of 100 happily married couples.

title: Connors Routs Alexander In Washington by 61, 60
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Jimmy Connors, the topseeded player, won 11 straight games to defeat John Alexander, 61, 60, tonight in the thirdround of the $175,000 Washington tennis tournament. Connors needed only 50 minutes to oust the veteran Australian and advance to the quarterfinals.

title: $15 BilliOn Cut in Federal Budget For 1980 Is Favored by President
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter has approved budget guidelines that would require $15 billion in cuts in planned spending programs in the fiscal year 1980, senior Administration officials disclosed today.

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING NO FURTHER ACTION OVER SOVIET TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter, deploring the recent conviction of Soviet dissidents, said tonight that he had not embarked on a vendetta against the Soviet Union and planned no further retaliatory action against Moscow at this time.

title: 1.5 Million Bottles of Vitamins . Are Recalled Under Court Order
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  A Federal judge has ordered the recall of 1.5 million bottles of One A Day vitamins because many adults are unable to put the childproof caps on properly, it was reported today.

title: Chicago Suburb Is Vatican of Evangelicals
description: WHEATON, Ill.  Just as country musicians flock to Nashville's Music Row and Manhattan's Madison Avenue is synonymous with the advertising industry, so this pleasant Chicago suburb is gaining a reputation as the Vatican of Evangelicals.

title: Soviet Charges U.S. Connivance In Violence at New York Offices
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 (AP)  The Soviet Union accused the United States today of what it called virtual connivance in harassment of Soviet offices in New York, including death threats and a bomb blast.

title: Details Listed On New Pact For Policemen
description: Following are some provisions of the twoyear contract approved by the delegate assembly of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association:

title: Art People
description: No one at the Museum of Modern Art is saying very much about last week's court ruling that would curb the Modern's plans to build a 42story apartment tower atop the museum as part of its longrange expansion plans.

title: Federal Reserve Raises Its Funds Rate Target
description: Credit analysts reported yesterday that the Federal Reserve had raised its target for the Federal Funds rate  the money market's key interest rate  to at least 7% percent and possibly 8 percent from 73A percent.

title: P.B.A.'s Delegate Assembly Votes To Endorse 2- Year Pact With City
description: The delegate assembly of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which had twice previously rejected new contract agreements with New York City, endorsed the latest pact yesterday. The vote was 227 to 104, with 24 members not voting.

title: Pianist and Quartet in Lyndhurst Limelight
description: Michel Block, pianist, and the Golden Chordsmen, a barbershop quartet, will be featured tomorrow night at the fourth concert of the Summer of Music on the Hudson Festival at Lyndhurst, in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mr. Block will be accompanied by the County Symphony, with Ronald Ondrejka, guest conductor.

title: HERMAN B. LERMER
description: Herman B, Lermer, who retired in 1968 as the owner and operator of Lermer Plastics of Garwood, N.J., died Tuesday in Exeter (N.H.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Rye, N.H.

title: W.R. Grace & Company
description: W. R. Grace & Company announced that secondquarter earnings rose 5.7 percent to $51.5 million, or $1.34 a share, from $48.7 million, or $1.26 a share,in the similar three months last year. Sales in the period rose to $1.12 billion from a restated $1.06 billion in the corresoondina auarter in 1977.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Cash prices of precious metals continued to occupy the spotlight yesterday, causing futures prices to rise.

title: F.C.C. to Take Aotion Against CBS
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday said it would impose a shortterm, license on one of the stations owned by CBS  whichever one of the five networkowned stations next comes up for renewal  as punishment for improprieties with a series of CBSTV tennis: matches. This is the first time the agency has censured a network by applying a sanction against one of the parent's stations.

title: Adm. Jackson R. Tate, 79, Dieg; Got Russians to Free Daughter
description: ORANGE PAIN, Fla., July 20 (AP) Rear Adm. Jackson R. Tate, retired, whose daughter by a Russian screen actress was allowed to leave S the Soviet Union after a personal appeal to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has died of cancer. He was 79 years old.

title: Two Trail on 70's; Miss Lopez at 71
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 20  The 33d United States Women's Open golf championship that started today is supposed to be the one Nancy Lopez wins to complete a story book rookie year as a professional golfer.

title: Pietro Montana, at 88, A Painter and Sculptor
description: Pietro Montana, a painter and an awardwinning sculptor who was at one time sculptor in residence at Fordham University, died July 6 in Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Bayville, L.I., and Rome, where he was buried.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, July 20 (Reuters) Chinese border guards have refused to allow hundreds of people of Chinese origin across a bridge from Vietnam, the Vietnam News Agency said today.

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING NO FURTHER ACTION OVER SOVIET TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter, deploring the recent conviction of Soviet dissidents, said tonight that he had not embarked on a vendetta against the Soviet Union and planned no further retaliatory action against Moscow at this time.

title: Frazier Transfers to Missouri
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., July 20 ('UM) Ricky Frazier, a St. Louis University basketball standout who was the 1978 Metro Conference freshman of the year, has transferred to the University of Missouri. Bill Callahan, the Missouri sports information director, said yesterday that the 6-foot-6-inch forward from Charleston, Mo.. would be on academic probation for the fall semester. Frazier led St. Louis in scoring with an average of 13.7 points a game.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets for H.M.S. Pinafore tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. range from $7 to $17.50; tomorrow at 2 P.M., $5.50 to $15.50. They may be purchased at the New York State Theater box office, Lincoln Center. Information: 8774727.

title: Beaths
description: GINGOLDRoslyn, beloved wife of Charles, devoted mother of Dr. Jeffrey and Mrs. Fredda Greenberg, adoring grandmother of Jordan, loving daughter of Sol Kleinman anddarling sister of Gilbert. Passed away July 20th after a long illness. Services Sunday, July 23, at 10AM at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck (opposite RR station). Please omit flowers. Shiva to be observed at 11 Brokaw Lane, Great Neck, N. Y.

title: Nets
description: Negotiations to sell the New Jersey Nets went on all day yesterday, but parties close to the meetings described the deal as being just barely alive.

title: Ford Envelops Company in Tight Security Net
description: The following article is based on reporting by Agis Salpukas and Jo Thomas, and was written by Miss Thomas.

title: Swimmers Synchronize Ballet With Gymnastics
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., July 20  The girls who were backstroking to Swan Lake in the state university pool here this afternoon are not destined for Jones Beach Theater or a Florida water show. Synchronized swimming is serious business for the 500 competitors in the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor championships, which run here through Saturday.

title: Advertising
description: ONE of the biggest food brokers in the New York area, concerned about supermarket sales declines, has taken an unusual step  it has organized a huge advertising, couponing, sweepstakes promotion for its clients products.

title: Carter's Top Drug Adviser Resigns In Conflict Over False Prescription
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Dr. Peter G. Bourne, the target of a police investigation focusing on his prescription of a powerful sedative for a White House em ployee, resigned today as President Carter's principal adviser on drugs and narcotics.

title: Two Atlantans Accused of Trying To Block Union Chief's Indictment
description: A Federal grand, jury is investigating the possibility that two wellconnected Atlanta lawyers attempted to use highlevel Washington contacts to obstruct justice and block the indictment of Joseph P. Tonelli, who was charged Wednesday along with four others of embezzling $360,000 from the United Paperworkers International Union, of which he is president.

title: Broadway
description: WINGS, the Arthur Kopit play that received rave notices when it opened this spring at the Yale Reportory Theater and again during its recent twoweek standing-room-only visit to the Public Theater, will open on Broadway on Sept. 9 at the Lyceum.Theater.

title: An Uncanny Impersonator
description: Watch out! David Frye's back in town and he's brought Anwar elSadat, Menachem Begin and Lillian, Jimmy and Billy Carter with him.

title: State CampaignDisclosure Rule Is Held Invalid by Federal Judge
description: An electionlaw provision requiring organizations that campaign on political issues to disclose information about their contributions and expenditures was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal DistriceCourt judge in Manhattan.

title: Times Units Name Officer
description: Richard H. Gottlieb has been named executive vice president of the Cambridge Book Company and of Electronic Publishing Inc., it was an-

title: Sada, Calling U.S. Help Essenticil, Awaits Vance for Talk on Mideast
description: CAIRO, July 20  President Anwar elSadat said today that he was waiting for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to,arrive here for talks to explore the next move toward negotiating a Middle East settlement.

title: The Editorial Notebook China Behind the Wall Posters
description: No twentiethcentury despotism has been without its admirers in this country. Visitors have returned from Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Russia, even Idi Amin's Uganda, with reports of millenial advances. If a properly inclined journalist or movie actress could get into Cambodia today and get out again, we would doubtless be treated to descriptions of new wonders of social organization.

title: L.I. Museum Celebrates Yankee Art
description: THE PRECISIONIST PAINTERS, 191649 is the title of an exhibition that has just opened at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, L. I., and will be on view there through Aug. 20. Subtitled Interpretations of a Mechanical Age, it is the work of two young people: Katherine Lochridge, who has just taken over the directorship of the museum, and Susan Fillin Yeh, who has worked hard and long on the subject and contributes the catalogue essay. Between them, they bring fresh eyes and a contagious enthusiasm to a movement of fundamental importance to the history of American painting.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Have you seen the constellation Scorpius or the Corona Borealis lately? They're in the summer sky, along with lots of other bright lights that will be pointed out tonight at 8:30 at the Greenburgh Nature Center in Scarsdale, N.Y. Kenneth Savary, director of the Hudson River Museum's Planetarium, and members of his staff will talk about Wonders of the Summer Sky. The program will start with a slide show and discussion. Then, everyone will go outside to view the wonders through reflecting and refracting telescopes. Admission is $1. From New York City, take the Major Deegan Expressway to Exit 5; go north on Central Avenue and turn right on Dromore Road. Information: (914) 7233470. Rain date next Friday.

title: U.S. Raises Imported Steel Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The Treasury Department raised by 4.4 percent today the minimum price for which imported steel can be sold in theUnited States.

title: The State Without a TV Station
description: New Jersey has been a state without a commercial television station in the convenient VHF range of Channels 213 since 1961. The license to operate in Newark on Channel 13 was transferred that year from a commercial station, then losing $3 million annually, to a nonprofit corporation, which has blossomed into WNET, the public station that viewers know today. Although it is nominally still a Newark outlet, with certain obligations to its city and state, the station's larger mission has been from the beginning to offer an alternative to commercial television for the entire New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut metropolitan area.

title: Green's 65 Leads Nicklaus by Shot
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 20  For what the PGA Tour officially labels a designated tournament  that is, a command performance that requires all the leading players to appear  the opening round of the 16th Philadelphia Classic turned out to be a bit of an awkward anticlmax today.

title: Senate Votes Urban Housing Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The Senate, 81 to 3, today approved a $31.8 bil, lion Federal housing bill that expands the number of cities eligible for a $400 million economic assistance program by including some prosperous cities in the Sun Belt.

title: Korman, Aide to Trager, Named To Replace Him as U.S. Attorney
description: President Carter yesterday announced the nomination of Edward R. Korman to replace David G. Trager as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, covering Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: Dissident in the Ukraine Is Given 10 Years
description: MOSCOW, July 20 (Reuters)  A Ukrainian member of a humanrights watchdog group was sentenced today to 10 years hard labor and five more years in internal exile for antiSoviet agitation and propaganda, dissident sources said.

title: TaxExempt Institutions Asked For Voluntary Payments to City
description: Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy announced yesterday that they had asked hospitals, universities and other owners of more than 2,300 parcels of taxexempt real estate to make  voluntary payments to New York City in lieu of the property taxes that they are exempt from paying.

title: Woody Allen Shoots Scene at Elaine's
description: Woody Allen's newest film began shooting in New York on Monday, little more than two weeks before the premiere on Aug.2 of his Interiors. The first scenes of the new film, which is untitled, were shot at Elaine's, Second Avenue and 88th Street, which for years has been the otherwise reclusive Mr. Allen's favorite hangout.

title: Brown and Jarvis Devise Coast Ren tRelief Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Howard Jarvis, the advocate of tax cutting, worked out a voluntary rentrelief plan with the state's landlords today in a bid to head off legislation on rentcontrol in California.

title: Star Wars Back With An Ad Blitz
description: Since its release on May 25, 1977, the motion picture Star Wars has grossed more than $221 million at the box office, more than any other film in history. Nevertheless, the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has un- leashed an unusual multimilliondollar publicity blitz on behalf of the film, and only a hermit is likely to miss being exposed to it.

title: P.B.A.'s Delegate Assembly Votes To Endorse 2- Year Pact With City
description: The delegate assembly of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which had twice previously rejected new contract agreements with New York City, endorsed the latest pact yesterday. The vote was 227 to 104, with 24 members not voting.

title: Chad, at O.A.U., Seeks Withdrawal of Libyans
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 20 (Reuters)  The President of Chad called on members of the Organization of African Unity today to demand the withdrawal of Libyan troops and their allies from his country.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: President Carter would be an unwelcome campaigner in some New Jersey districts because he has been ineffective and has not delivered on promises, Bill Bradley, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, said in New York yesterday.

title: Job Offer to Professor Is Dropped
description: The nomination of a Marxist associate professor at New York University to head the department of government and pblitics at the University of Maryland was withdrawn yesterday, stirring further controversy over a proposed appointment that had become a major issue in the Maryland gubernatorial camopaign.

title: The Bitter Pension Pill
description: Matthew M. Lind, executive director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation  the agency that guarantees basic pension benefits for around 33 million workers belonging to about 80,000 private pension plans  had some strong words for American buSinessmen yesterday.

title: John C. Sheppard, 64, Painter Of Western Oils and Watercolors.
description: RENO, July 20 (AP)  John Craig Sheppard, an artist whose westerntheme oils and watercolors won international recognition, died yesterday of cancer. He would have been 65 years old Saturday.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads for the latest week totaled an estimated 17.1 billion tonmiles, 7.6 percent above the cone- sponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 958,654 cars, 2.5 percent above last year.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday. July 20,1978

title: Jackion Target Of Chambliss's Criticism, Too
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 20 When Reggie Jackson returns to the Yankees Sunday  and he plans to return, a close friend reports= all he has to do is put on his uniform and go out and play. No apologies needed. It will be that simple. So says Manager Billy Martin.

title: Son Replaces Father
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 20 (AP)  David Morris, vice president of Saratoga Raceway, has been named president. He replaces his father, Er nest B. Morris, who becomes chairman . of the board of directors, a post that had been vacant for several years.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 20  Players arriving here today for the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals were greeted with some major news about a controversy.

title: A House of Little Shame
description: Why should a majority of the House of Representatives turn down public subsidization of the reelection campaigns of its members? Because duly designated opponents would also qualify for the subsidies and because all contestants would then be held to a total spending limit. For all the complaining in Congress about the financial burdens of running for office, the sad fact remains that incumbents prefer no limitation and no subsidy for themselves if their opponents are similarly denied.

title: A Gem Amid Diamonds Marks His 95th Birthday
description: Lazare Kaplan came to New York in 1914 on vacation from Belgium and his job as a diamond cutter. But the onset of World War I prevented his return to Europe  I had nothing to go back to, he noted and so he was forced to get started again in the New World.

title: Columbia Ousts Its Presiden
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, in a further sign of continuing management turmoil, said late yesterday that it had replaced Alan J. Hirschfield as president.

title: Screen: Son of 'Sgt. Pepper':Many Forms Involved
description: IS IT A film? Is it a record album? Is it a poster, or a T-shirt, or a specially embossed frisbee? "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" is the ultimate multimedia mishmash, so diversified that it doesn't fully exist in any one medium at all. This isn't a movie, it's a business deal set to music.There are three brief sequences good enough to put the rest of the picture to shame. Steve Martin, cackling his completely unhinged rendition of "Maxwell's Silver Hammer," is a reminder that the film is otherwise humorless. Billy Preston, doing a flashy, rousing dance to the tune of "Get Back," makes the other hoofers look sadly two-left-feet. And Aerosmith, singing a piercing rock version of "Come Together," bring a taste of the 60's to a movie dead-set on both exploiting and soft-pedaling that era.The point behind turning Peter Frampton and the Bee Gees into the Beatlesque band of the title was, presumably, to lure both young rock fans and members of the rocking chair set. But the plan has its drawbacks.However much of a fan rave Mr. Frampton may be, he's a musician, not a movie star, and even a plot that merely requires him to look sad, peppy or joyful from time to time is more than he can manage.In the role of Mr. Frampton's brother, Paul Nicholas, the actor who played nasty Cousin Kevin in "Tommy," provides a particularly unhelpful contrast, since he is every bit as lively as the singer is stiff. Still, Mr. Frampton looks like Marlon Brando beside the even more wooden Brothers Gibb.Even if the Bee Gees aren't natural-born cutups, their principal job here is to perform a number of Beatles songs, mostly from the title album and "Abbey Road."This sounds as if it ought to be child's play, in view of arrangements and production by George Martin (who worked with the Beatles in the first place), and considering the uncanny way the Bee Gees first rose to popularity by perfecting a Beatlish sound. However, the brothers have since risen to even greater popularity doing something different, so different that their newest fans may be dismayed to find not a whit of disco in the movie's soundtrack. And their Beatle numbers vary dramatically in quality, depending upon the nature of the particular song."Nowhere Man" suits them beautifully, for instance. But a less pretty number requiring zest and a strong lead singer  such as the title song, or "With a Little Help From My Friends," both sung with Mr. Frampton  merely makes them sound short on character. The Bee Gees's special gift for elaborate musical teamwork is often undercut by songs that cry out for individual personalities. Accordingly, Robin Gibb's bluesy solo on "Oh! Darling" is a sweet and surprising exception.The musical numbers are strung together so mindlessly that the movie has the feel of an interminable variety show. Characters are named, invented or introduced to one another simply to provide excuses for the various songs.This reaches a pinnacle of idiocy when a character named Strawberry Fields (Sandy Farina) sings "Strawberry Fields Forever" to her beau, Billy Shears (Mr. Frampton), who has been knocked unconscious. "Living is easy with eyes closed/Misunderstanding all you see," Strawberry sings, prettily but for absolutely no good reason. Even worse, when the screenplay has Strawberry killed (temporarily) so that a few sad songs can be sung, Mr. Frampton is obliged to croon "Golden Slumbers" to a woman in a see-through coffin.The movie may have been conceived in a spirit of merriment, but watching it feels like playing shuffleboard at the absolute insistence of a bossy shipboard social director. When whimsy gets to be this overbearing, it simply isn't whimsy any more."Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). Its most risque moments, having to do with the morals and drug habits of people in the record business, are among its few funny ones.

title: HOSPITAL RATE LAW IS SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, July 20  A new hospital ratesetting plan  designed to relieve New Jersey urban areas from paying the $30 million-a-year hospital bills of indigents from tax funds  was signed into law today by Governor Byrne, who called it the nation's best such system.

title: Notes on People
description: In keeping with a tradition that began in 1912, Rosalynn Carter yesterday presented her inaugural ball gown to the Smithsonian Institution. The blue chiffon gown received attention at President Carter's inauguration in January 1977 because it wasn't new: Designed by Nary Matise, it was the same dress that Mrs. Carter wore for the inauguration of her husband as Governor of Georgia in 1971, and it is the first in the Smithsonian's collection of First Ladies gowns to have been worn for two inaugurals. S. Dillon Rip. ley, secretary of the institution, said: This marvelous unbroken collection has become a popular symbol of the history of our country. It is a mirror of the tremendous interest the American people have in the First Lady. Mrs. Carter's gown will be displayed on a mannequin, which will also have her gold slippers and gold leather evening bag she used at the inaugural balls.

title: Will of J. D. Rockefeller 3d Lists Wife and Charity as Beneficiaries
description: WHITE PLAINS, JulY 20  The will of John D. Rockefeller 3d was filed today in Surrogate Court in Westchester County, naming his wife. Blanchette, and charity as the primary beneficiaries of his estate, whose worth has been estimated at $100 million.

title: 29Hit Outburst by Mets Sweeps Astros by 74, 54
description: The New York Mets carried on yesterday unlike they have been carrying on all season. They won their first doubleheader of the year, amassed a twogame total of 29 hits and benefited from fine relief pitching in sweeping Houston at Shea Stadium.

title: U.S. DENIAL OF LOAN ANGERS ARGENTINES
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 20 A decision by the United States ExportImport Bank to withhold a $270 million loan from Argentina because of human rights violations produced an angry reaction today from Argentine officials and American businessmen here.

title: Bluefish and Sea Trout Give Anglers the Action
description: As one might expect at this time of year along the East Coast from New Jersey to Cape Cod, bluefish are the species providing most of the action for light tackle marine anelers.

title: Chamber of Commerce Files Suit Challenging U.S. Election Laws
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The United States Chamber of Commerce charged in Federal District Court today that Congressional limits on political fundraising were unconstitutionally violating corporations rights to free speech and association.

title: Israeli Relives 3 Years at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 Chaim Herzog, who conducted a vigorous but often lonely defense of Israel here for three years, is giving up diplomacy and returning home.

title: Associated Press
description: FIRE DESTROYS HISTORIC HOTEL: The scene early yesterday as firemen from 10 communities tried to control the blaze at the 94-year-old Avon Inn on Ocean Avenue in Avon, N.J. The unoccupied I20room hotel was a complete loss.

title: MurderProsecution Law Is Voided
description: TRENTON, July 20(AP)  A commonlaw rule that blocks prosecution for murder in New Jersey unless the victim dies within a year and a day of the attack was abolished today by the State Supreme Court.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The United States Treasury said yesterday it auctioned $3.254 billion of twoyear notes at a record average yield of 8.61 percent  up from 8.25 percent at its June auction.

title: New York City HighRise Fire Law Is Reinstated by Appellate Division
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday reversed a lowercourt ruling and reinstated all provisions of Local Law 5, the fire law for highrise office buildings that landlords contend would cost hundreds of millions of dollars to implement.

title: U.S. Sees No Test of Wills
description: WASHINGTON, July20 (UPI)  President Carter is being kept informed of developments in the Moscow incident, thich is not being characterized as a test of wills between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Head of Major Party In Puerto Rico Says He Won't Seek Post
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 20 (UPI)The Popular Democratic Party was stunned yesterday by a surprise radio announcement from former Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon that he would not accept the antistatehood party's presidency at its July 25 convention after serving for 10 Years.

title: Nuclear Power for Seoul
description: SEOUL, Sbuth Korea, July 20 (UPI)  President Park Chung Hee dedicated South Korea's first nuclear power plant today at Kori, 205 miles. southeast of Seoul. The 587,000kilowatt plant was guilt by the Westinghouse Electric International Company.

title: HENRY KIRK GREER
description: Henry Kirk Greer, a corporaiion lawyer and a member of the United States Olythpic ComMittee from 1931, to 1960, died yesterday in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He was 78 years old and lived, in Dennis, Mass. He had formerly lived in New York City and in Rye, N.Y.

title: Body of an East Side Doorman Found in Apartment Basement
description: An East Side doorman was found stabbed to death early this morning in the basement of the apartment building where he worked.

title: Transit Strike Cripples the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) A wildcat strike virtually shut down the capital's mass transit system today, causing enormous traffic jams as half a million commuters took to their cars in an area already hit by a fullscale pollution alert.

title: Albany Putting Aside A Program to Improve John Brown Site
description: ALBANY, July 20 (AP)  A plan to build a visitors center and parking lot outside Lake Placid at the farm, and gravesite of John Brown, the abolitionist, has been dropped by the state.

title: Reinsurance Exchange Established in State
description: ALBANY, July 20  Governor Carey signed a bill today establishing a reinsurance exchange in New York State and creating a free trade zone to exempt large and unusual insurance contracts from state regulation and taxation.

title: Auctions
description: FAR more than postage stamps went under the hammer Tuesday at Harmers of New York, 6 West 98th Street. ITS a departure for this auction house, which specializes in stamp sales, the last sale of its 197778 season also dispersed old post office memorabilia and a score of vintage mailboxes and vending machines. The occasion was the sale of the philatelic paraphernalia of the late Dr. Rendell Rhoades, a collector and historian of Ohio postal issues. There were postal counters in glorious golden oak, which brought moderate prices ($320 to $800), and a score of mailboxes, which cost far less than new ones (from $13 to $65). Ten of the boxes were purchased by the Smithsonian Institution. The star of the day proved to be a stampvending machine produced shortly after World War I by the U.S. Automatic Vending Company, an elaborate cast iron and glass affair, as outmoded today as the stamps it spewed. The Smithsonian it for $1,000.

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: Thought: Manacled
description: The psychological traumas of a person incarcerated, brutally tortured, then released, hardly heal. I knew a bookseller who had been frequently arrested. He was a man stricken by fear. He spoke with the minimum amount of words.

title: Fight Over Ocean County Plan to Bury Sludge Portends Statewide Issue
description: TOMS RIVER, July 20A plan to bury sewerage sludge near a residential area in this Ocean County community is encountering bitter local opposition, and the controversy is viewed here as a precursor of similar battles to be fought in New Jersey as problems of sludge disposal mount.

title: Restaurants
description: IT is not often that one comes across a Chinese restaurant with a menu that reflects a fairly strict commitment to the food of one particular region of China. Whether the featured cuisine is Hunanese, Fukienese or Szechwanese, the manage- ment generally reels compelled to add such trademark Cantonese appetizers as egg roll, roast pork, spareribs, and egg drop and wonton soup, in order to appeal to the mass audience that would not consider a Chinese meal complete without those touches.

title: Yugoslavia, Sued, Bans Towaway
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  The spider and the clamp, two of life's small but persistent irritations in this Balkan capital, are finished.

title: Stage: Connecticut Whoopee
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn.  There is such pleasure in the first act of the Goodspeed Opera House revival of the 1928 musical Whoopee that the thought occurs: Why not perform it twice?

title: A South African Black Dies, Possibly Tortured
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 20 (AP)  A black South African, convicted of theft, has died in police custody, and a black doctor said he appeared to have been the victim of systematic torture.

title: Smaller Cut Backed on Gains Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The Carter Administration, trying to avoid major defeat in the House Ways and Means Committee, delivered another attack today against a substantial reduction in the capital gains tax. It said that such a law would allow some Americans to escape all taxation.

title: DoctorDefends His Procedures In Test Tube Baby
description: A gynecologist involved in the 1973 attempt of a Florida couple to produce the world's first test tube baby said in court yesterday that he did not submit to all available approvals governing work in human experimentation because he did not consider the procedure  although never before successful in humans  to be an experiment.

title: Ballet: A Juliet For Nureyev
description: ELISABETTA TERABUST, the second of the London Festival Ballet's three ballerinas, took over the role of Juliet on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Rudolf Nurevev's new orodue. tion of Romeo and Juliet does not give its Juliets much chance to shine technically. This is a ravishingly pretty Renaissance pageant, with the emphasis on the male protagonists. Mr. Nureyev has worked in some tellingand touchingdramatic effects, namely in Mercutio's death scene, performed outstandingly by Nicholas Johnson on Wednesday, and in the characterizations of Tybalt and Paris.

title: The New York Times /Paul Hosef roe
description: COLOMBIAN INDEPENDENCE DAY was celebrated yesterday as members of the Association of Colombian Professionals gathered for ceremony the statue of Simon Bolivar in Central Park. Luis Fernando Botero, center, Colombian representative to the United Nations, addressed the group.

title: American Credit's 20Point Rise Fails to Sustain Early Dow Rally
description: American Credit, the latest target in the corporate takeover boom, soared more than 20 points yesterday, while the momentum of the general market's recent earnings rally faltered late in the session.

title: MITCHELL RECEIVES PAROLE IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  John N. Mitchell was granted a parole today, effective Jan. 19. He will have served 19 months of his one-to-four-year sentence for Watergate crimes, including five months he spent on medical furlough.

title: CIVIL SERVICE UNION LOSES VOTE APPEAL
description: ALBANY, July 20  A hearing officer of the state's Public Employment Relations Board today upheld a disputed union election in which the Civil Service Employees Association lost the state's 45,000 professional, scientific and technical employees to a rival union, the Public Employees Federation.

title: Is Metrics U.S.A. Just a Silly Little Millimeter Away?
description: If Scotch comes in liters, film in millimeters, drugs in grams and cubic centimeters and some temperature reports in Celsius, can the metric packaging of milk, bread and butter and other common food products be far behind?

title: PeresHussein Meeting Is Vetoed
description: TEL AVIV, July 20  Prime Minister Begin has refused to authorize a meeting in London between the Israeli opposition leader, Shimon Peres, and King Hussein of Jordan, sources in Parliament said today.

title: Dresser's Jousts With U.S.
description: DALLAS  Executives of Dresser Industries like to portray their engineering company as a modernday, corporate David waging a moral and legal war with the new Goliath, the Federal Government.

title: Touring. Brooklyn's Gold Coast
description: Our elite were not the Astors or Vanderbilts, John Muir began. He was talking about Brooklyn, where the rich and powerful of the late 19th century made their mark with the little things in life  hot dogs, chewing gum, baking powder and Bon Ami cleanser.

title: Texts of Letter to Carter and Statement by Bourne
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Following are the texts of Dr. Peter G. Bourne's letter of resignation today to President Carter, and the statement by Dr. Bourne asking a leave of absence as the President's adviser on drug abuse problems:

title: Dance: Baryshmkov Jewels
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.Mikhail Barystmikov has yet to be allowed to perform in all the jewels with the New York City Ballet.

title: Is Metrics U.S.A. Just a Silly Little Millimeter Away?
description: If Scotch comes in liters, film in millimeters, drugs in grams and cubic centimeters and some temperature reports in Celsius, can the metric packaging of milk, bread and butter and other common food products be far behind?

title: Savoyard Patter Man Does It With Urbanity, Humanity and a Little Inanity
