description: In admiral's hat and monocle, black coat embroidered in gold, John Reed, principal comedian of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, will cross the stage of the New York State Theater tonight and give a most enlightening account of his career.

title: Phyllis Wagner's New Job Is Hard Which Suits Her Fine
description: Give Phyllis Wagner an inch and she'll give it back. Mrs. Wagner doesn't think small. That was why she absolutely couldn't say no when Harold L. Fisher, chairman of the MetropolitanTransportation Authority, asked her to take on the chairmanship of the Authority's esthetics committee. After all; the subways alone have 231 miles of rails and 461 stations. That's big, even in Mrs. Wagner's book.

title: Ryunoshin Kusumi, an Executive Of Japanese News Organizations
description: TOKYO, July 20 (AP)  Ryunoshin Kusumi, chairman of the northern Japanese newspaper Too Nippo and vice chairman of the Kyodo News Service, died today of liver insufficiency, according to St. Luke's Hospital here. He was 69 year old.

title: Around the Nation
description: .COKORD,, Mass., July 20 (AP). Thirtysix black students bused from Boston to this historic suburb have quit the predominantly white high school, contending that white students boasting in the senior yearbook of Ku Klux Klan connections threatened them if they returned in September.

title: For Children
description: MANHATTAN ISLAND CRUISE, a 35mile, 3hour trip around Manhattan, with views of the World Trade Center, the Statue of Liberty, the Palisades of New Jersey. and other sights, aboard cruisers of the Circle Line Sightseeing Yachts Inc.. scheduled from 9:45 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Cruisers leave from Pier 83 at the foot of West 43d Street. Children, (under 12), S3; adults, SA: Advance res&vations are needed for children's groups. r.11C1.111N1

title: Lack of Evidence Cited In Case Against a Mayor
description: MILWAUKEE, July 19 (UPI)  No charges were filed against Vincent Cianci Jr., now Mayor of Providence, R.I., in an alleged 1966 rape here because there was not enough evidence of a crime, Gerald Boyle, the assistant district attorney, said Wednesday.

title: Pop Music: Bebop at Michael's Pub
description: JAZZ at Michael's Pub usually has its roots in the swing era or earlier. This week and next, the East 55th Street restaurant is harboring a different sound  a band that draws its inspiration from the bebop period. It is the first New York appearance of the Steve Wolfe Quintet and Nancy King, the singer, whose home base is Eugene, Ore.

title: South Africa's Penal System, Descended From C.alvinism Falls Hardest on Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 20  About once a month, the Pretoria Central Prison, a dingy redbrick structure on the outskirts of South Africa's administrative capital, is the scene of a gruesome ritual: the execution by hanging, in swift succession, of groups of men convicted of rape or murder.

title: Seiko Will Market New Thin Watch in U.S.
description: A man's watch with a quartz movement as thin as a dime and an outer case no larger than a quarter was introduced here yesterday by the Seiko Time Corporation, which says it is the world's largest watch manufacturer.

title: The New York Times/Neal Baena
description: TRADITIONAL RETREAT FROM THE HEAT: In the timehonored way tenement dwellers, a woman sat on the fire escape outside her apartment West 48th Street yesterday to seek a cool breeze as the temperature soared into the 90's. More hot weather is forecast for today.

title: Inquiry Questions Rafshoon Tie
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The chairman of a House investigating body asserted today that close cooperation between a Government agency and a maritime industry trade association to influence public opinion raised questions of legality and propriety.

title: 2d Game of Chess Title Match Ends, Like the First, in a Draw
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 20 Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, did no better today on his turn with the white pieces than the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi, had done.

title: Transcript of President's News. Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Good evening, everybody. Before I answer questions, I'd like to make one brief comment. Dr. Peter Bourne, out of consideration for my Administration, has submitted his resignation this afternoon, which I have accepted with regret. Dr. Bourne is a close friend of mine and my family; he's an able and dedicated public servant. Because of this unfortunate occurrence, he has left the Government.

title: Trade Ruling On Clothespins
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  A Government trade agency ruled today that China was disrupting American industries with its exports of wooden clothespins.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Falls 2.9 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined 2.9 million shares to 36.7 million shares in the month ended July 14. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 32.3 million shares.

title: Letters,
description: To the Editor: The Times of July 6 carried a story of a 76-year-old Texas man who filed for divorce of his wife of 49 years. He took this action in order to qualify his wife for Medicaid and thus'enable her to continue receiving needed care in a nursing home.

title: Classic Fall Fashions: Attractive, Safe and Enduring
description: A doublebreasted navy blue blazer by Ralph Lauren was a sellout at Lord & Taylor earlier this month. Its price was $322.

title: Books: The Buzz Bomb And the Typewriter
description: THE barbarians were at the gate. The question was not the survival of literary life but of life itself. Only long afterward can a book such as Under Siege: Literary Life in London, 193945 allow us to see through the prism of perspective without looking for the buzz bombs overhead.

title: Market Place
description: AMERICAN SNACKS INC. has been climbing steadily on the over-the-counter market recently and reached a high of 8 bid Wednesday and again yesterday.

title: U. S. IS SAID TO FEAR TIME IS RUNNING OUT IN MIDEAST EFFORTS
description: LONDON, July 20 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has decided on another major effort to break the negotiating stalemate in the Middle East because of concern that time is running out and also a feeling that opportunities will never be greater, American officials said today.

title: Westchester's CETA Chief Quits
description: MUTE PLAINS, July 20  Keith Drake, the director of Westchester County's troubled Office of Employment and Training, resigned today as County Executive Alfred B. DelBello ordered major changes in the administration of the $32 million Drogram.

title: The Assoclatreti Press
description: HEAT WAVE CONTINUES:Martin Brown inspecting damaged corn on his farm near Dallas, Ter., as temperatures reached over 100 degrees there the 19th consecutive day yesterday.It has not rained in the area since June 7.

title: Israeli Relives 3 Years at U.N.
description: >UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20Chaim Herzog, who conducted a vigorous but often lonely defense of Israel here for three years, is giving up diplomacy and returning home.

title: Teddy Ball Game on the Miramachi River
description: BLACKVILLE, NEW BRUNSWICK, July 20  In the morning, curls of vapor rose from the wrinkled suface of the Home Pool, and from Ted Williams's porch were seen blobs of foam from the rapids up at Tom Boyd's floating swiftly toward the sea. This camp, set in a grove of white birch on the lofty south of the Miramachi River, has been the summer home of baseball's last .400 hitter for 13 of the 17 years since he struck his last blow for the Boston Red Sox  and drove the ball screaming out of Fenway Park. (More than a little reluctantly, he suffered a threeyear interruption in his pursuit of the Atlantic salmon to manage the Washington Senators, then he gave one more season to the team as the Texas Rangers before returning to the life he loves best.)

title: Neither Rain, Sleet Nor Strike
description: As businesses all over America make final their contingency plans for operating in the event of a strike of Postal Service employees, one small business in New York, with a particular relationship to the postal function, knew exactly what it would do if such an emergency arose.

title: 6 Held in Bellevue Ratket Case
description: A multimilliondollar loan-sharking and narcotics racket operating out of the basement mortuary at Bellevue Hospital was broken up yesterday, the city's Investigation Commissioner said, with the arrest and indictment of six hospital employees.

title: Kirby Plans Plywood Plant
description: Kirby Forest Industries, the treefarming and forest products manufacturing subsidiary of Santa Fe Industries, said it planned to build a plywood plant and sawmill near Cleveland, Tex., that would cost more than $20 million.

title: Books of The Times
description: ETHEL, with her big breasts and her reddishgolden hair, has many problems. People keep calline her kitten. She is an

title: A State Bill Would Help Families Exposed to DES, a Suspected Carcinogen
description: With unanimous votes in both the State Senate and the Assembly, the New York State Legislature passed a bill this week that would find, screen and help people who have been exposed to diethylstilbestrol, the synthetic estrogen hormone commonly known as DES.

title: Publishing: The Expatriate Life
description: WHEN Clifford Irving was reached by telephone last week at his remote home on the central Mexican plateau, the man who almost fooled the world with his false Howard Hughes autobiography was just back from a refreshing horseback ride.

title: Liberty's Sentry Can't Sleep
description: WASHINGTONOne of the sturdiest chestnuts of political rhetoric is that eternal vigilance is the price of liberty. This grand old epigram is quoted with equal effect by Presidents seeking higher defense budgets, F.B.I. directors organizing witchhunts and civil libertarians.

title: Harvard Accuses C.I.A. Of Ignoring School Rules; WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Derek Bok, the president of Harvard, charged today that the Central Intelligence Agency planned to circumvent university rules blocking the use of professors and students from the covert gathering of intelligence.
description: Appearing before the Senate Intelligence Committee, he said that Harvard had drafted rules to block its students, faculty and administrators from the covert recruiting of likely candidates for the Federal agency and from engaging in operational activities for it.

title: Brat178
description: RTHURFrancesca, beloved daughter of Mrand Mrs. Budd Arthur of Chicago, and Mrs. Joan Arthur of Ridgewood, N.J. Cherished granddaugther of Mrs. Burt Arthur of Chicago. Services Friday 1:30PM The Riverside 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Screen: 'Buddy Holly Story':Tale of Rock Star
description: THERE are a lot of actors in "The Buddy Holly Story"  some of them very nice  but the movie is really a one-man show. It's Gary Busey's galvanizing solo performance that gives meaning to an otherwise shapeless and bland feature-length film about the American rock-and-roll star who was killed in a plane crash in 1959.The film, which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, was made with the cooperation of Holly's widow, Maria Elena Holly, and may be a demonstration of why keepers of the flame are not the best people to have around when you're making a movie"The Buddy Holly Story" has a story of sorts, but it's a B-picture plot with all of the crises and villains discreetly removed, about the virtually unimpeded rise to the top, within three years, of a nice, gawky kid from Lubbock, Tex., who could express himself only through his music.Buddy Holly was not Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. What he expresses are not the contradictory impulses of a society of rare sophistication, but the pounding lusts and comic heartbreaks of people who have trouble dealing with any gratification not instant.It may be argued that the film, written by Robert Gittler and directed by Steve Rash, reflects the essential simplicity of Holly's music, but that, I think, is to confuse simplicity with lack of technique, which is the manner of the film. Holly's music  including the dozen songs ("That'll Be the Day," "Well Alright," "Every Day," among others) that are reprised in the movie  is not especially complex but it expresses a kind of youthful vitality that has nothing much to do with the conventions of dopey movie making.Which brings us to Mr. Busey, who's already been seen in "The Last American Hero," "Thunderbolt and Light-foot" and, most recently, in "Straight Time," as Dustin Hoffman's junkie pal. Mr. Busey, tall and slightly awkward, a fellow whose teeth appear to have been grown and not styled, has the look of middle America all over him. He's also capable of making articulate a character who remains inarticulate except in his music. He's not only an actor who possesses a center of gravity  of intelligence  but he's also a pop musician (professional name: Teddy Jack Eddy) who understands the mysterious (to the rest of us) transformation that takes place during a performance.Don Stroud and Charles Martin Smith ("American Grafitti") are effective and functional as Buddy Holly's two hometown pals who accompany him to stardom. Maria Richwine plays the Puerto Rican girl he marries, Gloria Irricari is her skeptical, watchful aunt (who doesn't trust musicians), and Paul Mooney, Gilbert Melgar and George Simonelli show up as some of the other rock stars (Sam Cooke, Richie Valens and Dion) whose careers crossed that of Holly.Although "The Buddy Holly Story" can't be classified as a musical, it's a movie that comes alive only during the musical sequences, and these sequences, featuring Mr. Busey's transformed country-boy, are so good, so full of energy, they turn the material that frames them into wood."The Buddy Holly Story," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language.

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 21,1978 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee  10:30 A.M. And 3 P.M.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WI NET's Lost and Found series of old films, produced in collaboration with the Museum of Modern Art, continues tomorrow at 10 P.M. with the silent version of Eugene O'Neill's Anna Christie. Made in 1923, the film, starring Blanche Sweet, was produced by Thomas Ince and directed by John Griffith Ray. A copy with Russian subtitles was found in Yugoslav archives and restored to the proximity of its original form.

title: BrownForman Has Comfort Option
description: The BrbwnForman Distillers Corporation said it had acquired an option for $10 million to buy in 1979 for an additional $80 million cash all the outstanding common shares of the Southern Comfort Corporation, a liquor company, and its associated companies.

description: Music

title: TaxExempt Institutions Asked For Voluntary Payments to City
description: Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy announced yesterday that they had asked hospitals, universities and other owners of more than 2,300 parcels of taxexempt real estate to make voluntary payments to New York City in lieu of the property taxes that they are exempt from paying.

title: News Summary
description: Urging better relations with Moscow, President Carter said he had not embarked on a vendetta against the Soviet Union and planned no further retaliation on the issue of Soviet dissidents. Speaking at an evening news conference, Mr. Carter, who had barred a computer sale to Moscow over the issue, deplored the recent convictions of dissidents in the Soviet Union, but stressed that he would like to see an improvment in SovietAmerican relations. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Summer Stock Thriving In Metropolitan Area
description: IT used to seem that every seaside town had its own little summer playhouse where, lobsterred and sleepy with sun, you could doze pleasurably through faded comedies and energetic song. A good many of those little tneaters nave become parking lots and restaurants, but summer theater is not dead. University and community theater groups are singing, dancing and acting their hearts out for audiences that are by no means made up of relatives and friends.

title: Saudi Deal Expected With CRS
description: Gaith R. Pharaon, the Saudi businessman who on Wednesday made a bid to acquire the Hyatt international Corporation, operator of a chain of international hotels, is close to acquiring 20 percent control of CRS Design Associates, a Houston architectural and design firm with extensive business in the Middle East, CRS disclosed yesterday.

title: $ 15 Billion Cut in Federal Budget For 1980 Is Favored by President
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter has approved budget guidelines that would require $15 billion in cuts in planned spending programs in the fiscal year 1980, senior Administration officials disclosed today.

title: U. S. IS SAID TO FEAR TIME IS RUNNING OUT IN MIDEAST EFFORTS
description: LONDON, July 20  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has decided on another major effort to break the negotiating stalemate in the Middle East because of concern that time is running out and also a feeling that opportunities will never be greater, American officials said today.

title: Foreign Investments In U.S. Rise
description: The number of foreign investments in manufacturing in the United States reached a high of 101 in the second quarter of this year, the Conference Board reported today.

title: The Pop Life
description: PETER,GABRIEL, whose second solo album was recently released by Atlantic, has the potential to become a pivotal figure in rock. He spent five years or so as lead singer and tactical commander for Genesis, so his credentials are very much in order as far as the huge American audience for English artrock Is concerned.

description: Incoming

title: BaaderMeinhof Suspect Is Seized
description: A 27-year-old West German woman whom Federal Bureau of Investigation agents suspect is a member of the notorious BaaderMeinhof urban terrorist gang, was arrested as she was crossing into the United States from Canada on foot last Sunday, bureau officials said yesterday.

title: An Adviser Who Quit Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Those or us from Georgia, Dr. Peter Geoffry Bourne observed not long ago, have a kind of longevity that is secure.

title: Private Agency Planned To Fight Child Abuse
description: TRENTON, July 20  The setting up of a private agency to fight child abuse in New Jersey, with the help of a $35,000 grant from the Johnson & Johnson Company of New Brunswick, was announced today.

title: Associated Press
description: SLIGHT DISAGREEMENT: Brewers'Charlie Moore, center, is restrained by a teammate, Lary Sorenson, as argues with Umpire Rich Garcia over call allowing George Scott of Red Sox to score seventhinning run at waukee Wednesday. While Moore argued, Boston's Butch Hobson also scored. Boston went to defeat Brewers,

title: Candidates
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak shook a few hundred hands on Nassau Street and in City Hall Park yesterday, turned almost every answer into a criticism of Governor Carey's asserted management failings, and insisted that  despite some political conceptions to the contrary  her own campaign was being managed just the way she wanted it to be.

title: Mdjor Amoco Gas Find Reported in Wyoming
description: A major natural gas discovery in the Overthrust Belt of southwestern Wyoming was announced yesterday by the Amoco Production Company, the domestic exploration and production subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: AUSTRALIA WILL SELL URANIUM TO FINLAND
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 20  Australia, estimated to have a fifth of the nonComunist world's known uranium deposits, moved today toward becoming a major world supplier by sigiging its first safeguards agreement with an importing country.

title: About Real Estate
description: Large midblock and throughblock sites are seldom available for redevelopment on side streets of Manhattan's residential areas. But such sites are desirable beCause of their distance from the traffic and noise of the avenues. Also they afford more exposures and a design opportunity to control views of rear yards or to do away with them altogether.

title: The Slippery AntiCrime Dollar
description: President Carter's critics in Congress complain that he has been slow to learn the facts of political life, but his new plan to reorganize the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration (L.E.A.A.) suggests that he is learning fast. His plan would tinker in useful ways with that muchmaligned agency yet avoid another Congressional confrontation by not demanding its overhaul or abolition. Drastic reorganization has been advocated by many critics, including a Presidential candidate named Carter. But with L.E.A.A. funds flowing to virtually every Congressional district, there was no hope for anything so farreaching.

title: China to Buy Japanese TV Plant
description: TOKYO, July 20 (Reuters)  Two Japanese concerns, Hitachi Ltd. and the Toshiba Corporation, have reached a broad agreement with Peking's National Technical Import Corporation to export to China a color television manufacturing plant valued at $150 million. Toshiba said today.

title: Japanese Buddhists Hold a Summer Festival
description: For Japanese Buddhists the Obon festival is the highlight of midsummer. It is a time to remember ancestors and reflect on the goodness of charity, and it is a time to dance, to sing and to set lanterns afloat on river and sea. New York's Obon celebration will be held tomorrow evening from 5:30 to 8.0clock on the Riverside Park Mall at Riverside Drive at 103d Street, and everyone is welcome to join the festivities.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Art: About Art, Parodies, at Whitney
description: EVERY work of art derives to some extent from antecedent works of art, and is therefore in some sense a comment on its artistic sources. Where other compelling interests  a commanding religious vision say or a orofound erotic obsession  dominate the creation of art, the element of selfconscious art comment tends to be instrumental and oblique, a means rather than an end. Ours, however, is a period in which art has been stripped  at times, indeed, stripped bare  of these outside interests. For many contemporary artists, the only compelling subject for a work of art is art itself, and so the making of art about art is now a thriving enterprise.

title: Postal Negotiators Continue Talks In Effort to Avert Walkouts Today
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  A break in the deadlock between the United States Postal Service and the unions representing 570,000 of its employees occurred here late tonight, brightening the outlook for an agreement that could avert service disruptions tomorrow.

title: Businessman in Italy Is Shot in the Legs
description: ROME, July 20 (AP)  Extremists shot a businessman in the legs near Turin during the night and set off bombs that injured a policeman in Rome and caused extensive damage here and in Milan, the Police said.

Speaking at an evening news conference, Mr. Carter, who had barred a computer sale to Moscow over the issue, deplored the recent convictions of dissidents in the Soviet Union, but stressed that he would like to see an improvment in SovietAmerican relations. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: KOCH IS OVERRULED ON WAGE DEFERRALS
description: New York City's Office of Collective Bargaining ruled against Mayor Koch yesterday and held that the city remained obligated to repay the money that city workers gave up three years ago when a wage increase was deferred.

title: Metropolitan Postal Officials Fear Effects of Strike
description: Phillip Seligman was fielding several telephone calls from colleagues all at once at midday yesterday. He was clearly exasperated, and the heavy humidity in his office wasn't helping any. Yes, yes, he said to one caller, it looks pretty bad, right now. No contract, no work.

title: At the Movies
description: FELT better about this movie than anything I've been involved in for years, and then this had to happen, James Brolin was saying the other day as he wiggled the toes of his heavily bandaged left foot. In the scene I'm desperately chasing a car down the drive in Central Park. My daughter is in it. She's been kidnapped. I was really going all out when my foot hit something. I lost my balance, I fell, and I heard something pop.

title: Lawyer for Terrorists May Hold Key to Compromise on Basque Separatist Movement
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 17  It used to be said that if Francisco Franco ever wanted to find a lasting solution to the problem of Basque separatism, he would have to travel to this northeastern coastal resort and knock on the door of Juan Maria Bandres.

title: Officials Advise Postal Patrons
description: Postal Service officials said yesterday that plans were still being worked out for what customers should do in the event of a strike by postal employees.

title: Pop Music: Emmylou Harris And Asleep at the Wheel in Park
description: IT is no slight to Emmylou Harris, who was the headliner at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park Wednesday night, to say that her opening act, Asleep at the Wheel, stole the show. Miss Harris does what she does extremely well; her live performances are, lovely, but they are relatively restrained. Asleep at the Wheel is a show band that has never come across adequately on records. The group must be seen to be believed.

title: Clout Before Justice
description: America has entered the age of the corporate Goliath: A giant electronics firm forces one of its suppliers to the wall and then forces a complete takeover; .a bank uses other services to subsidize its creditcard business into market dominance so that small operators cannot compete. Yet the modern David  whether individual company or private citizen  is still very much alive, often able to dazzle a lumbering opponent by marketing his smallness as being synonymous with being better.

title: Meadowlands Plans Rich Races
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 20  Joe DeFrank, racing secretary at the Meadowlands Race Track, revealed plans today for an $800,000 race next year, a milliondollar race in 1980 and a $2million race a year later.

title: FUNDS ARE CUT OFF FOR WORK PROJECT
description: New York City's Bbard of Estimate voted 20 to 2 last night to cut off funds for the Puerto Rican Community Development Project, a jobtraining program that had been accused of mismanagement and financial irregularities and had once been a base for former City Councilman RamonVelez.

title: Events and Openings
description: H.M.S. PINAFORE, written by W.S. Gilbert; composed by Arthur Sullivan; directed by Leonard Osborn; musical director, Royston Nash. D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, at the New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: United Press International
description: ON VISIT TO DENMARK: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany stepping off yacht after pleasure trip around Faaborg Harbor. He was in Denmark for talks with Prime Minister Acker Jorgensen.

title: Economic Scene
description: AFTER several lean years and a particularly trying first quarter in 1978, when the long coal strike and the severe winter took a heavy toll on profits, the American steel industry is making a comeback. Significantly, most of the rebound reflects the strength of domestic demand for steel, not the Government's efforts to curb steel imports, the maior effects of which are still to be seen.

title: Export Aid Is Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  A Presidential study group plans to submit to President Carter shortly an export promotion proposal intended to increase American sales abroad by $10 billion to $15 billion over five years, according to Administration officials.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City and New Jersey police arrested three men and recovered about $2 million in negotiable securities that had been stolen from the sate of a Wall Street brokerage last Oct. 10.

title: Keystone Center
description: A distribution center for steel and aluminum tubular products will be built on a 50acre tract in the Santa Fe Industrial Park, southwest of Chicago, by the Keystone Tubular Service Corporation. With headquarters in Butler, Pa., Keystone, a subsidiary of the Marmon Group, also operates service centers under its own name in 10 major cities nationally. The center is to be completed in midsummer next year.

title: Debut for Irish Flutist
description: James Galway, the Irish flutist who has won critical acclaim and an enormous following in northern Europe, makes his New York City debut at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall tonight. He says he would not mind if people in the audience ate chickens.

title: Trombonist Comes Home
description: Ten years ago, Bob Brookmeyer, the valve trombonist, was a leading light of the New York jazz establishment playing five nights a week in the ochestra of the Mery Griffin television show, a charter member, then arranger for the Thad JonesMel Lewis band and playing intermittently with a combo he had formed in 1961 with Clark Terry. Despite this, he moved to Los Angeles and seemingly disappeared from jazz until he brought a quartet into Hopper's, 452 Avenue of the Americas, near 11th Street, where he will be playing tonight and tomorrow night at 9:30 P.M., 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: All three performances start at 8 P.M., but will be preceded by preconcerts from 7 to 7:30. Tickets, at $5.75, are available at the Avery Fisher Hall box office, Lincoln Center, 8742424.

title: 2 Antifraud Measures Rescinded by Macy's
description: Macy's New York has dropped two controversial elements of an antifraud program  requiring photographs of customers who seek cash refunds and names and addresses of cash-customers  the chain has informed the New York State Attorney General's office.

title: U.S. Embassy in Moscow Protests .After Policeman Tries to Bar Diplomat
description: MOSCOW, July 20  A Soviet police guard entered the grounds of the United States Embassy today, seized an American diplomat from behind and tore his jacket while attempting to stop him from entering the embassy building.

title: Harmony Amid Discord
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 20The Organization of African Unity, meeting here, is like a John Cage symphony and a Mozart sonata:being played simultaneously  under the sharpedged polemics and obvious discord, there are subtler movements or harmony and reconciliation.

title: KOCH OPPOSES PLEAS FOR HOUSING RELIEF
description: Mayor Koch yesterday opposed requests for financial relief made by about 15 MitchellLama apartment developments. He said that the fiscally troubled city could not afford the revenue losses that would be involved. but despite his administration's effort - which began successfully  to bring the issue to a vote by the Board of Estimate, the matter was postponed until another public hearing could be held Sept. 15.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest independent telephone system, reported yesterday an 11 percent increase in consolidated net income in the second quarter, reflecting a 14 percent rise in revenues and sales.

title: Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's secondlargest chemical manufacturer behind E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, announced yesterday a 4 percent increase in secondquarter earnings to $106.8 million, or $1.65 a share, from $102.6 million, or $1.62 a share in the 1977 quarter.

title: Commodore's Trophy Won by Klein a 2d Time
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 Bruce Klein of Sea Cliff, L.L, Yacht Club yesterday became only the second doublewinner of the Commodore's Trophy since the award for the outstanding junior skipper of Larchmont Race Week was established in 1957.

title: Israel Exempts Religious Women
description: TEL AVIV, July 20After bitter wrangling and a 12hour filibuster, the Israeli Parliament adopted legislation early today making it easier for women to avoid conscription into the defense forces by citing religious objections. The vote was 54 to 45.

title: Carter's Top Drug Adviser Resigns In Conflict Over False Prescription
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Dr. Peter G. Bourne, the target of a police investigation focusing on his prescription of a powerful sedative for a White House employee, resigned today as President Carter's principal adviser on drugs and narcotics.

title: Black Caucus Supports Indians
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  Indian protest leaders today received support from the Congressional Black Caucus and from Hispanic Congressmen in their fight against 11 bills that they consider to be antiIndian.

title: Associated Press
description: CONGRATULATIONS were in order as Pete Rose of the Reds, right, was greeted by teammate, Ken Grif fey, after Rose hit safely in his 33d straight game last night at Philadelphia. Phillies catcher is Bob Boone. Page A19.

title: Postal Negotiators Continue Talks In Effort to Avert Walkouts Today
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, July 21  A break in the deadlock between the United States Postal Service and the unions representing 570,000 of its employees occurred here late last night, brightening the outlook for an agreement that could avert service disruptions today.

title: Beaths
description: SCHILLERMollie. Beloved wife of the late Max, devoted mother of Florence Sherman, loving grandmother of Jay and Stephanie, Scott, Jolie, and Terri. Adorihg greatgrandmother of Michael. Service Friday, 12 noon, at The Riverside, 179 St. and Grand Concourse, Bronx, N.Y.

description: Morning

title: Strike in Italy Hurts Tourists
description: ROME, July 20 (UPI)  Thousands of tourists throughout Italy were left without hotel and restaurant services today when 700,000 workers staged their third 24hour strike this month. The strike by workers in hotels, restaurants and campgrounds was called to protest dismissals and to demand a single contract for various job categories.

title: Crafts, Canoes, Sea Lore To Come to Freeport
description: Three outdoor event are scheduled this weekend in Freeport, L.I.

title: Fans 8 Twins, Yanks Gain 2d Shutout in Row
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 20 Ron Guidry, the skinny Cajun who has been battling a bout of midseason blahs, pitched against Minnesota tonight with an extra day's rest and looked strong enough to beat back a swamp full of allieators.

title: FALSE PRESCRIBING OF DRUGS ASSESSED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Leaders in medicine, psychiatry and pharmacy, along with practicing doctors and druggists, agreed almost without exception today that the use of pseudonymns in writing drug prescriptions was both out of the ordinary and unethical. But there were widespread indications that it was indeed done, particularly for patients prominent in public life.

title: The Powell Test
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The Supreme Court's celebrated Bakke decision was not a sharp legal or constitutional setback for affirmative action programs, but since it was widely misperceived as outlawing quotas and reverse discrimination, the decision did make the public climate for affirmative action more difficult.

title: Statements by Bourne Open Flood of Queries On Capital Drug Use
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The White House was put on the defensive today as the abrupt resignation of President Carter's principal narcotics adviser prompted a flood of inquiries about drug use by members of the White House staff.

title: U.S. Senate Rivals in Jersey. Assail Carter on Mideast
description: NEWARK, July 21  The two major candidates for the United States Senate from New Jersey criticized President' Carter's Middle East policies in a debate today before Jewish leaders.

title: Earth Sciences Pact
description: Earth Sciences Inc., a mineral exploration and development company, said that it was in the final stages of negotiating a 20year agreement to supply two electric utilities with about 2 million pounds of uranium oxide from its planned uranium production facility in Calgary, Alberta. The company said that at current prices the uranium was worth $85 million. The company said that negotiations with a major bank for financing the $10 million production facility were at an advanced stage. Earth Sciences did not identify the two electric utilities or the bank with which it is negotiating.

title: World Oil Use Up in Quarter
description: PARIS, July 21 (UPI)  Oil consumption in the industrial world climbed 3.4 percent in the first quarter of 1978 from the similar period last yearto a total of 448.6 million tonsdespite pledges to cut back, a major economic organization reported today.

title: Begin 's Fitness to Remain in Office Is Under Challenge by Labor Party
description: TEL AVIV, July 21 (AP)  A political storm has erupted in Israel over how to proceed in faltering peace negotiations with Egypt, and the opposition Labor Party has begun to question Prime Minister Menachem Begin's physical and mental fitness to remain in office.

title: WRTNIn the Astaire Style
description: If William O'Shaughnessy hadn't turned on the radio in his Buffalo hotel room a few years ago, his own Westchester County radio station might not today be one of the most talked about radio stations in the metropolitan area.

title: Your Money
description: JUST how good an investment are the new sixmonth savings certificates offered by commercial banks and such thrift institutions as mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations?

title: AGREEMENT REACHED WITH POSTAL UNIONS ON 3YEAR CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The United States Postal Service and the postal unions reached tentative agreement early today on a threeyear contract, and union officials said prospects were good for ratification by union members.

title: Books of The Times Inside the Eye's News
description: Way back in early radio times, when the older and better established National Broadcasting Company had a corner on massappeal entertainment programming, William S. Paley, AIR TIME. The Inside Story of CBS News. By Gary Paul Gates. 428 oases. Harper & Row. 512.95. founder of the Columbia Broadcasting System, determined that his network would make its mark on the then uncharted sphere of electronic journalism.

title: Mets Rout Braves for 4th in Row
description: The Mets had a chance to win a fourth straight game for the fifth time this season last night. For the first time, they succeeded, walloping the Atlanta Braves, 123, their largest outpouring of runs in one game for more than two years.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 22, 1978

title: Prices Jump In Silver
description: Touched off by new weakness in the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets, silver futures prices rose sharply yesterday in vigorous early morning trading.

title: Pushcart War Simmers in Melting Pot
description: Hot dogs are getting a run for the money in New York City. In the melting pot of the nation, shish kebab, felafel, quiche Lorraine and Oriental concoctions are being dished out by street vendors  illegally in most places  for sidewalk snackers who say they are becoming gourmets.

title: U.F:T. Accord on Pay Is Questioned by City In Light of Guidelines
description: New York City officials are questioning whether the cost of the recently negotiated contract with the United Federation of Teachers will exceed the city's guidelines for union contracts. But both the union and the school board insist that the package is consistent with the city's financial guidelines and will be approved by the Emergency Financial Control Board, which must pass on all such agreements.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED WITH POSTAL UNIONS ON 3YEAR CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The United States Postal Service and the postal unions reached tentative agreement early today on a threeyear contract, and union officials said prospects were good for ratification by union members.

title: Newest Thing in Salon Decor? The Look of Spaceship Elegance
description: The new Gerard Bollei salon in the Galleria building is so hushedgray elegant, one woman said she felt she should have had her hair done before she arrived there. The decor, down to the calla lilies in big, glass bowls, is clearly expensive, the Music discreet. Approaching the reception desk hidden in a pavilion of softly gleaming metal, surrounded by gray draperies, charcoal velvet sofas and steelgray carpeting, one feels as though one had come for an audience, rather than a wash and set.

title: No Summit for Elvis
description: In his declining years Elvis Presley began worrying about what the Beatles and the Rolling Stones were doing to America. He asked for a conference with J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Dominica to Be Independent
description: LONDON, July 21 (Reuters)  An order giving the Caribbean island of Dominica full independence was approved without a vote today by the House of Commons. The island, which currently has associated status with Britain, is to become independent on Nov. 3.

title: Police Harassment of Daily News Drivers Reported
description: Incidents of police officers harassing deliverytruck drivers of The Daily News have been reported, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said last night, and he directed department commanders to investigate thoroughly and take immediate disciplinary action where warranted.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The percentage increase in the operating earnings of Citicorp for the second quarter was listed erroneously in Business Day on Wednesday. The correct figure is 27.2 percent.

title: T.I. Introduces SweepHand Watch
description: Texas Instruments Inc., which in just three years has emerged as the world's leading manufacturer of digital watches, is now going after the market for analog watches, which use hands instead of numbers to display time.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 22, 1978

title: Bank Sees No Plans to Foreclose On Exchange International Loan
description: CHICAGO, July 21  The First National Bank of Chicago said today that it had no immediate plans to foreclose on a $10 million loan to the Exchange International Corporation, the holding company for the Exchange National Bank of Chicago.

title: Hottest Day This Year Prompts City Water Watch
description: Sweltering through the hottest day of the year, youngsters opened hundreds of fire hydrants on igneous streets throughout New York City yesterday, causing a sharp drop in water pressure in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn and prompting the Department of Water Resources to declare a firststage water watch.

title: Florida Utility Plans Coal Power Plant
description: The Florida Power and Light Com. pany said its directoth had approved the spending of $170 million for initial work on its first coalfueled generating plant. It will be a 730meeawatt unit and is expected to be completed in the mid1980's at a cost of $830 million.

title: Byrne Foresees No Proposition 13
description: TRENTON, July 21- Governor Byrne in an informal deskside chat with report ers, said today that he believed that any fears of a possible Proposition 13type tax revolt in New Jersey were unrealistic.

title: Post Joins With Times and News In Setting Deadline for Pressmen
description: The New York Post joined The New York Times and The Daily News yesterday in setting an Aug. 8 deadline for a new contract with Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2.

title: Riders Cope as Transit Strike in Capital Continues
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The capital's bus and subway system remained at a standstill for a second day today as drivers and mechanics defied a court order and the urgings of their own union officials to end their wildcat strike.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES TO DISCIPLINE POLICE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 21 The South African police, facing widespread censure for the spate of deaths among blacks in custody, announced today that disciplinary steps were to be taken against three members of the security branch in Port Elizabeth. The unit has been involved in the deaths of three blacks in the last 19 months, including Stephen Biko, the country's foremost young black leader.

title: Court Bars 2 ExNew Yorkers From Vying With Indians in Santa
description: SANTA FE., N.M., July 20  Wheri they were schoolteachers in New York few years ago, Paul and Sara Livingston spent many of their Sunday afternoons on the sidewalk in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art selling the quilts and other handicrafts that Mrs. Livingston turned out as a hobby.

title: Vermont Reports First 78 Death In 7 Legionnaires
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 21 (AP) The state Health Department today confirmed Vermont's first death this year from legionnaires disease.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: TRACE OF OIL OR GAS IS FOUND OFF JERSEY
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it had turned up traces of oil or gas under the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Strike Compounds St. Joe Zinc's Woes
description: SYRACUSE, July 21  Striking miners at the St. Joe Zinc Company, the nation's largest zinc producer, have not moved a rock in a month and a half. But a St. Joe smelter in Balmat, N.Y., that produces 17 percent of all domestic zinc is still operating, processing imported zinc ore the company can buy more cheaply than ore its own men mine.

title: Candidates
description: It was candidates corner at 14th Street and First Avenue early yesterday morn. ing. Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak, candidate for Governor, stood next to the subway entrance on the northeast corner, while 10 yards away, Carter Burden, Democratic candidate for Congress snook nanas with passersby, and yet another several yards down the block Allard K. Lowenstein handed out his own leaflets. All three candidates were clearly eager to catch the commuters rushing to work between 7:45 and 9 A.M.

title: Philadelphia Workers Accept a Pact With Layoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21  Philadelphia's 19,500 unionized civilian employes, including 4,000 sanitation men who have let rotting garbage pile up on the streets here for eight days, voted approval today of a strike settlement that would offset the cost of a major pay increase by laying off hundreds and perhaps thousands of municipal workers.

title: A New Juliet By Londoners At the Met
description: Eva Evdokimova, a dancer unfamiliar in New York until last year, but almost a regular since her guest appearances with the American Ballet Theater and her recent performances with the Berlin Opera Ballet, made her local debut as Juliet in the London Festival Ballet's Romeo and Juliet on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: POLES STILL COPING WITH WIDE SCARCITY
description: WARSAW  It is summer now in Warsaw, and Poland has managed to pull through another winter and even another spring.

title: Pathologist at Jascalevich Trial Ties 3 Patients
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21  The pathologist who coordinated the exhumation of the bodies and their examination for curare testified today at the murder trial of Dr, Mario E. Jascalevich that three of the deaths had been caused by curare noisonine.

title: Catholics Are Taking Over in Londonderry
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland Derry has been the Irish Jerusalem, sacred, disputed ground, for nearly 900 years.

title: Commonwealth Oil Aides Are Approved
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said a Federal bankruptcy judge in San Antonio had approved the selection of a reorganization management team headed by C. Howard Hardesty Jr., former vice chairman of the Continental Oil Company, to, help the ailing company regain financial , strength.

title: Cairo's Aide Differs With Vance On Outlook for New Israel Talks
description: LONDON, July 21 (Reuters)  Egypt's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel, said today that he did not share Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's stated optimism that there would be more EgvotianIsraeli talks.

title: Rose Hits In No. 34, Reds Win
description: MONTREAL, July 21 (UPI)  Pete Rose singled on the first pitch of the game, extending his hitting streak to 34 games, and the Cincinnati Reds went on to collect 14 hits and rout the Montreal Exnos. 103. For the Reds rookie righthander, Mike LaCoss, the outburst resulted in a victory in his major league debut.

title: In a Hot City, Neatness Is on the Rise
description: On the streets of New York these hot summer days, neatness counts.

title: 3 SOUGHT FOR AIDING A GERMAN TERRORIST
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police were searching yesterday for two men and a woman who are believed to have helped a 27-year-old West German terrorist enter the United States illegally from Canada on Sunday.

title: Notes on People
description: Muggings on Congressmen continued in Washington, with Representative Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois, the latest victim. The 55-year-old Representative returned to his town house near the Capitol, after playing softball with other Congressmen, early yesterday morning. The police said that as he got out of his car behind the house he was attacked by at least two young men, who severely beat him and escaped with his wallet and watch. Representative Michel, the House minority whip, was given firstaid treatment at a nearby hospital and transferred to Bethesda Naval Hospital, where he was reported in satisfactory condition. A spokesman said that he suffered from a cut on the tongue, cuts of the face and swelling of the eyes. Last week Senator Robert Morgan, Democrat of North Carolina, was robbed of $300 while windowshopping near a bookstore by three youths who threatened to beat him. Several other members of Congress, including Democratic Senators John C. Stennis of Mississippi and William Proxmire of Wisconsin, have also been victims of muggers.

title: Pathologist at Doctor's Trial Links 3 Deaths to Curare
description: HACKENSACK, July 21 The pathologist who coordinated the exhumation of the bodies and their examination for curare testified today at the murder trial of Dr, Mario E. Jascalevich that three of the deaths had been caused by curare poisoning.

title: Various Corporations Disclose Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Latest Quarter
Westchester Savings And Dime To Merge
description: The Westchester County Savings and Loan Association and the Dime Savings Bank of New York announced that they had agreed in principle to merge. Under the agreement, the Westchester orgamzation would Decome the Westchester regional division of the Dime. But existing savings accounts of individuals and the mortgage loan accounts of Westchester Savings will not be affected by the merger.

title: Verdict Mixed In Reid Trial
description: The trial of Robert H. Reid, a former vice president of the American Stock Exchange, declared itself hopelessly deadlocked yesterday on nine counts of perjury against Mr. Reid and acquitted him of eight other perjury counts after more than three days of deliberation.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company is seeking to replace 10,900 possibly defective and potentially dangerous transformers that provide the electric current for the dial lights on some Trimline and Princess phones.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ACCENT ON YOUTH More creative work by young artists has moved into local galleries in the wake of the recent display in New York of winning art pieces in Scholastic magazine's annual competition. Two new exhibitions are at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 79 West 53d Street, a few doors west of the Museum of Modern Art, and New York University's 80 Washington Square East Galleries.

title: Deathas
description: GODWINFrances L. On July 19, 1978, after a long illness. Daughter of the late Ann and Bernard Leavitt. Served in France in W.W.II for the American Red Cross and U.N. R.R.A. Services were held Friday at The Riverside 76 and Amsterdam Ave.

title: United Press International
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21  A man who was shot and killed as he drew gun on the police has been identified as a struggling New York mystery writer who decided to rob banks as research for his next book. His unfinished manuscript predicted that the bizarre plan might lead to his death, the police said.

title: Economy's 7.4% Growth Below Goal
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The nation's economic growth was less than had been expected and the rate of inflation in the second quarter wasabove the Administration's forecasts, according to a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.

title: Stratford Head Quits Festival
description: Robin Phillips, artistic director of the Stratford, Ontario, Shakespearean Festival, has submitted his resignation, to become effective in November, the festival's administration has announced.

title: Raft Talks to Resume
description: ROANOKE, Va., July 21 (AP)  The Norfolk & Western Railway said today that it would renew negotiations in Washington tomorrow with the railway clerks union in an effort to end a strike that has idled 20,000 N.&W. workers since July 10.

title: I.T.T. Britain Award
description: A British unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has been awarded contracts for two largecapacity undersea telephone cable systems. They will connect Britain with Spain and the Netherlands. The contracts for the two systems, totaling about $45 million, have been awarded to the submarine systems division of I.T.T.'s Standard Telephones and Cables Ltd.

title: Postal Workers at Big Facility in Jersey Stage Walkout Over Settlement
description: Operations at the country's biggest parcel-post facility, in Jersey City, came to a standstill yesterday as hundreds of postal workers walked off of the job to protest the tentative wage settlement that their national leaders reached earlier in the clay with the Postal Service in Washington.

title: Forego's Absence A Handicap
description: For the first time in five years Forego will be missing from the prestigious Brooklyn Handicap when the 91yearold fixture is run at Belmont Park today. The 8-year-old gelding was retired recently and will not be competing.

title: The White Elephant Called Woodhull
description: While Brooklyn's Woodhull Hospital was being built, it was customarily referred to in city press releases as a dream hospital, the first municipal hospital to offer onebed rooms to most patients. The city planned to give the prospective clientele of Woodhull. mosey poor, all the luxuries of private patients in other hospitals. No loud voice asked how a financially burdened city could afford to give such care.

title: British Weigh Decision On New Airliners
description: The British Government is nearing an informal end-of-the-month target date on a decision that will have critical impact on the future of its aerosnace industry.

title: Assocures Prees
description: DAMAGE TO BOSTON LANDMARK IS AVERTED: Water from firemen's hoses splashing against the Old North Church Thursday night as the building next door burned down. By soaking its root, firemen prevented flying embers from damaging the church, from which news of the British advance on Lexington and Concord was semaphored to Paul Revere in 1775. Longfellow's poem described the lamp code: One, if by land, and two, if by sea.

title: Beth Daniel: The Next Nancy Lopez
description: In another time, Beth Daniel might have eased into the realm of women's golf without much advance notice. Or much advance pressure. But this is the time of Nancy Lopez and so Beth Daniel already is being touted as the next Nancy Lopez  a billing that not fair. But not surprising. Beth Daniel twice has won the tournament that Nancy Lopez never won, the United States Women's Amateur; in her 1975 triumph as an 18-year-old she eliminated Nancy

title: GENERAL AND AIDE ARE KILLED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, July 21 (AP)  Terrorists believed to be leftwing extremists stepped out of a stolen taxi and shot to death an army general and his aide today.

title: Reagan Denies ExAide Spoke for Him on China
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Ronald Reagan said today that he remained opposed to recognition of China by the United States, no matter what some of his political aides have been saying.

title: Owens Corning Profit Up 11.1%
description: With fiberglass continuing in demand for insulation, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation reported an 11.1 earnings rise on a 26.6 percent sales gain in the second quarter. The nation's largest maker of fiberglass products said, however, that earnings were adversely affected by a continuing strike that began on June 1 at its Newark, Ohio, insulation plant. About 2,500 hourly employees represented by three unions are involved in the compensation battle.

title: Nicklaus, 130, Leads Way Despite Plan to Cut Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21  When Jack Nicklaus takes the lead in a tournament by tying and breaking records, as he did today with a 64 for 130 in the second round of the Philadelphia Classic, it's hohum time.

title: Transplanting of Fish Is Viewed as Successful
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 21 (UPI)  David Freeman, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said yesterday there was growing evidence that a colony of snail darters, the tiny, endangered fish that has held up completion of the $116 million Tellico Dam, has been successfully Vann:panted.

title: Briton, 25, Pleads Guilty in Effort To Smuggle Out an East German
description: EAST BERLIN, July 21 (Reuters) Colin Semple, a 25-year-old Briton, pleaded guilty today to charges of trying to smuggle an East German out of the country. He is to be sentenced on Monday and could get five years in jail.

title: Seaboard Bids Southern Pacific Divest 885,000 Shares of Stock
description: Seaboard Coastline Industries, owner of the Family Lines railway system, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to order the Southern Pacific Company to divest itself of 885.000 shares of Seaboard stock.

title: Tight End Tallies, Snares Long Pass
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 Cracking heads, clawing and pulling, then shaking hands and hugging like old friends saying goodbye, the Jet and Giant rookies (and some regulars) staged their annual scrimmage today.

title: Changes Expected in Telecast By Satellite of the Royal Ballet
description: Rudolf Nureyev is expected to replace the previously announced Gene Kelly as host for WNEWTV's satellite broadcast of The Royal Ballet Salutes the U.S.A. tonight. The program, which was to have been telecast from Covent Garden, London, is expected to be replaced by an alternate program that includes the ballets Elite Syncopations, Symphonic Variations, Facade, Grosse Fuge and The Maids, all performed by the Royal Ballet.

title: F.A.L.N. Bomb Suspect Indicted
description: A 28-year-old reputed member of the F.A.L.N., a terrorist group seeking independence for Puerto Rico, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in New York yesterday for possession of firearms and explosives.

title: Letter: On School Financing
description: New York, July 14, 1978

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: KOCH BACKS CON ED ON LOWRATE PLAN
description: In an effort to save an estimated 50,000 manufacturing jobs in New York City, the Koch administration has joined the Consolidated Edison Company in seeking approval for specially reduced electric rates for heavy power users who are being forced to leave the city or close down because of current high rates charged by the utility.

title: Deathas
description: NEFFMelvin A. 76, of 128 Pine Top Trail, Bethlehem, Pa, retired Bethlehem Steel Corp Mining Aide, died Wednesday at Allentown Sacred Heart Hospital Center. He was the husband of Elizabeth Gould Neff. Surviving with his wife are a son James L. of New York City, a brother Edward of Williamsport Pa and two grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at 11AM on Saturday at the Cathedral Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Pushcart War Simmers in Melting Pot
description: Hot dogs are getting a run for the money in New York City. In the melting pot of the nation, shish kebab, felafel, quiche Lorraine and Oriental concoctions are being dished out by street vendors  illegally in most places  for sidewalk snackers who say they are becoming gourmets.

title: Brazilian Dance at Clark Festival
description: The Clark Center Dance Festival swung into its third week with performances by Capoeiras of Bahia. Inside the City University Graduate Center Mall on Wednesday, it was standing room only. Outside, passersby clustered at the eages or the openended, streetlevel theater, drawn by the pulsing drums of the Brazilianinfluenced ethnic dance company. It was a peculiarly appropriate response, for the festival is a down-to-earth little celebration of dance that seems to spring up from the city streets themselves, and in Capoeiras, the Clark Center had a real winner.

title: Defensive Veterans Watch and Worry
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 Three Giants players huddled together beyond the end zone without the goalpost, trying to make themselves inconspicuous during the scrimmage today between the area's two National Football League franchises, the Jets and the Giantc

title: African Group Avoids a Deep Split By Skirting Issue of Outside Forces
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Saturday, July 22  The Organization of African Unity approached the end of its conference of heads of state here early today after three days of quarrelsome debate, tentative peace efforts and highsounding calls for nonalignment  with no consensus in sight on what to do about foreign military intervention.

title: Overcharges Laid to Amoco
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reuters) The Energy Department said today that the Amoco Production Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, might have overcharged crude oil customers by $11.6 million over a 40month period. The de- partment served the company with notice of probable violation of pricing regulations and gave it 10 days to respond.

title: GERALD W. BRACE, 76, NEW ENGLAND MITER
description: Gerald Warner Brace, a former professor of English at Boston University and a writer who explored many aspects of New England life, from lobster fishing to romance under campus elms, died of cancer Thursday in Blue. Hill, Me:Mr. Brace, wno mane his home in Belmont, Mass., and spent his summers in Maine, was 76 years old.

title: Society in Jersey Gets Models of Inventions
description: NEWARK, July 21 (AP)  Twentysix inventions, all made by New Jerseyans, have been acquired in model form by the New Jersey Historical Society.

title: Wage Policy Tightened In Britain
description: LONDON, July 21  The Government announced today a wageincrease guideline of 5 percent in the next 12 months in an effort to consolidate Britain's dramatic gains against inflation.

title: Civiletti Rejects Request On Dallas Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  MexicanAmerican leaders met with Deputy Assistant Attorney Benjamin A. Civiletti for four hours today but failed to presuade him to reverse the Justice Depart- menus decision against prosecuting a former Dallas police officer in the shooting death of a 12-year-old Chicano boy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The percentage increase in the operating earnings of Citicorp for the second quarter was listed erroneously in Business Day on Wednesday. The correct figure is 27.2 percent.

title: Jersey Pillow Company Fined
description: The Hollander Home Fashions Corpo. ration of Newark has been fined $7,500 and suspended from operating in New York State for stuffing unwashed chicken feathers in pillows, the latest in a string of violations. Mario Cuomo, the New York Secretary of State, said yesterday that the company was fined $2,500 last year for similar practices.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: CasinoHotel Planned

title: Navy to Test Asbestos Effects
description: NORFOLK, Va., July 20 (UPI)  The Navy plans to begin testing its ship maintenance and constuction crews for effects from exposure to asbestos, an indestructible insulator and known carcinogen. A Navy spokesman said Thursday that as part of the program, the Navy would expand examinations of civilian workers at its eight shipyards across the nation, Lieut. Connie Haney, the spokesman, said.

title: Ax, Harrell and the Zukerrnans Play at Mostly Mozart Festival
description: If it had not been for Emanuel Ax's poised performance of one of Mozart's grayest and most emotioncharged piano sonatas, Thursday night's Mostly Mozart program would have been pure helium. It was one of those lighter- thanair concerts that on paper can appear potentially charming but, in the event, turn out to be hard to concentrate on. It seemed a shame to bring on such artists as Pinchas Zukerman, Eugenia Zukerman and Lynn Harrell, and set them to noodling over pieces rescued from the attic of the chambermusic literature.

title: Maj. Gen. Charles Lanham Dies; A Soldier Model for Hemingway
description: Maj. Gen. Charles Truman (Buck) Lanham, whom Ernest Hemingway called the finest and bravest and most intelligent regimental commander I have ever known, died Thursday night of cancer at his home, in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 76 years old.

title: Witco Extends Offer
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation announced that it would extend until 4 P.M., Wichita, Kan., time, on Aug. 10 its cash tender offer to purchase all of the issued and outstanding shares of Southwest PetroChem Inc. for $12.50 a share. When the offer was oriEinally made on July 10,.it was conditioned on Witco's purchase of not less than 984, 000 Southwest shares. This condition has been satisfied, Witco said, and the offer is no longer conditioned on any minimum number of shares being tendered.

title: Gynecologist's Letter Challenges Couple in Test Tube Baby
description: A New York gynecologist who had assisted a Florida couple who are suing Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center for allegedly destroying their test tube baby indicated in a 1973 letter that what he had helped create might not have been an embryo at all, but only a mass of human eggs and ovarian fluid, according to testimony in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: U.S. Open Court Spurs Talk of Livelier Matches
description: The odds on Bjorn Borg to win the United States Open tennis championship lengthened earlier this week when the first completed court at the tournament's new home in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park was tested by players.

title: Patrick R. Christian, Planner, And Joan B. Mueller Are Wed
description: Joan Bulkley Mueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Swan Mueller Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday morning to Patrick Reid Christian, son of Mr. and Mrs. N.M. Christian of Radford. Va.

title: Marcia Weinstein Bride Of Dr. Richard Steinbrook
description: Marcia Lois Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman H. Weinstein of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard Alan Steinbrook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Steinbrook of Philadelphia. Rabbi David W. Gordon, assisted by Cantor Morris Romalis, performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center.

title: David Johansen and New Group at the Bottom Line
description: If David Johansen was not such a shameless Mick Jagger imitator, his new album and new group would be the most exciting thing to happen to'rock this year. But then, if Mr. Johansen and the group had not imbibed so much of the spirit of the early Rolling Stones, they would not be half as captivating as they are.

title: ;Senate Votes, 711, to Back FixedFee Health Plans
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The Senate today approved, 71 to 1, a compromise bill to support health maintenance organizations but put brakes on plans by the Carter Administration to expand such programs.

title: GoldMine Stocks Glitter As General Market Dips
description: Goldmining issues moved ahead sharply on Wall Street yesterday, reflecting higher bullion prices abroad along with weakness in the United States dollar in foreigncurrency dealings.

title: Koch, County Leaders Lobby for Welfare Bill
description: Mayor Koch joined with county executives from various parts of New York State yesterday to begin lobbying for passage by Congress of a bill that would relieve all local jurisdictions of a substantial portion of their welfare expenditures.

title: Letters
description: New York, July 13,1978

title: Di Suvero Scrap Sculpture Is Presented to the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  A large work made from gird'rs, a ship's bowplates, a buoy and other pieces of scrap metal by Mark di Suvero, the sculptor, was formally presented to the eaeral Government by the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden here Wednesday.
