description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  By some accounts it all started June 9, when a termite inspector looking for the Finley home at 1 Foxhall Road knocked instead on the door of the Daly home at 2

title: Cash Prices
description: FRI DAY, JULY 21, 1978

title: Lopez, 2 Others Tie For Lead
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 21  Nancy Lopez displayed an uncharacteristic but very human trait today. She got anus, and showed it.

title: 3 Young Persons Killed, 2 Injured In Car Accident on Staten Island
description: Three young persons were killed and two others were seriously injured in a car crash early yesterday in the Mariner's Harbor section of Staten Island.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Labor

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Bliss and Citation Prepare Tie
description: Bliss & Laughlin Industries, a leading producer of coldrolled steel bars, announced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the Citation Companies for about $28 million in cash on the basis of $17 a share.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES TO DISCIPLINE POLICE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 21 The South African police, facing widespread censure for the spate of deaths among blacks in custody, announced today that disciplinary steps were to be taken against three members of the se- curity branch in Port Elizabeth. The unit has been involved in the deaths of three blacks in the last 19 months, including Stephen Biko, the country's foremost young black leader.

title: Grand Central Is More Than a Building
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding the landmark status of Grand Central Terminal was a happy ending to a decade of litigation and uncertainty. But the assurance that New York will keep its handsome Beaux Arts monument only emphasizes the need to revitalize the Grand Central neighborhood.

title: 2 U.S. Senate Candidates Assail Carter on Mideast
description: NEWARK, July 21  The two major candidates for the United States Senate from New Jersey criticized President Carter's Middle East policies in a debate today before Jewish leaders.

title: McHenry Sees Namibia Pact as Aid in Solving Other African Problems
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 The American diplomat who was instrumental in negotiating the new agreement for the independence of SouthWest Africa thinks of that accord as a fragile souffl. The negotiator, Donald F. McHenry, adds, Good food has to be consumed while hot.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, JULY 21  A group of players from Westchester and New Jersey were in confident mood today in the semifinal stage of the grand national team championship.

title: Alleged Rape by Freed Inmate, 17, Intensifies Criticism of State Aide
description: The director of New York State's Division for Youth came under attack yesterday as two Family Court judges and the chairman of the State Senate Committee on Crime and Corrections sharply criticized the release of a youth of 17 who, while on furlough from a minimum-security facility, allegedly raped, robbed and tried to electrocute a 63-year-old woman.

title: Coast Jury Absolves Vokswagen Of Liability in 75 Accident Case
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., July 21 (AP)  Volkswagen of America Inc. has been absolved of liability in the case of a 29-year-old man who was paralyzed from the waist down when his 1972 Porsche 914 flipped over.

title: American Utility. Tie To Lord Abbett Set
description: American Utility Shares Inc. and Lord Abbett Income Fund Inc. said stockholders of each company had approved the merger of American Utility into Lord Abbett Income and that all necessary regulatory approvals for the previously announced merger had been obtained.

title: A Beach Cure That Works in Mysterious Ways and Lasts Forever
description: Morning Instructions.

title: Scarsdale's Retarded Get a New Home, A Mixed Welcome
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  By some accounts it all started June 9, when a termite inspector looking for the Finley home at 1 Foxhall Road knocked instead on the door of the Daly home at 2 Foxhall Road. The termite inspector worked for New York State, and it was from him that residents of this quiet, verdant enclave in Scarsdale's Heathcote section first learned that the Finleys home would soon become a residence for eight mentally retarded people who had been living in large institutions.

title: Environmental Rules Mess
description: Debate has raged over the economic impact of our national environmental improvement program. But the debate has failed to deal with the real and unspoken fears of the private sector concerning the Environmental Protection Agency's regulatory programs. And the problems associated with its approach to cleaning up the environment are more likely to prevent environmental cleanup and cause economic decline than any of the scare stories one hears about factory shutdowns and job loss.

title: Those Deductible Pleasures Of Summer
description: The pleasures of summer  occupying a cottage in the country, inviting guests for a barbecue on the patio, sending the children to day camp, even using a lawn mower  may all be transformed into tax breaks at the time of income reckoning next spring.

title: Wide Marijuana and Cocaine Use Reported Among Professionals
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The use of marijuana and other illicit substances, particularly cocaine, is so widespread among welleducated young professional people with highpressure jobs that it is increasingly difficult to find any who have not at least tried them.

title: Connecticut Democrats Convene Amid Disputes on Nominations
description: HARTFORD, July 21  The Democratic State Convention, meeting for the first time in 32 years without the late John M. Bailey calling the shots, convened tonight, facing unaccustomed fights over the renomination of Gov, Ella T. Grasso and the choice of at least two other statewide candidates.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  A plan to reorganize the Government's border inspection operations this year has been shelved by President Carter, White House sources say.

title: White House, in Reversal, Opposes Colorado Dam
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The Carter Administration reversed itself today and announced its opposition to the politically sensitive Narrows Dam project on the South Platte River in Colorado.

title: Plundering of Treasury Seen in Lobbying Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, today accused officials of the Maritime Administration of plundering the United States Treasurythy creating, administering and working closely with a maritime industry trade association.

title: Alleged Rape by Freed Inmate, 17, Intensifies Criticism of State Aide
description: The director of New York State's Divi sion for Youth came under attack yester. day as two Family Court judges and (tit chairman of the State Senate Committee on Crime and Corrections sharply criti cized the release of a youth of 17 who, while on furlough from a minimumse curity facility, allegedly raped, robbed and tried to electrocute a 63-year-old woman.

title: Court Bars N.E.A. Checkoff Plan for Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  A Federal district judge has ordered the National Education Association to stop its practice of deducting political contributions automatically from the paychecks of its 1.8 million members, subject to later refund to those who protest.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, July 21  The Cambodian Government, in a note to the United Nations published today, has rejected charges of mass violations of human rights by assuring that it does not murder, but pursues a noble and virtuous goal by serving the people on the basis of just policies.

title: Cyprus and the Senate
description: The Senate is about to vote on whether to continue the limitations on arms sales to Turkey. They were imposed after Ankara used Americansupplied weapons to occupy twofifths of Cyprus in 1974, in violation of Congressional prohibition. We have argued in the past that the limits should be kept until Turkey indicates will withdraw its forces. We still think so.

title: Year's Hottest Day Spurs New York Water Watch
description: Sweltering through the hottest day of the year, youngsters opened hundreds of fire hydrants on igneous streets throughout New York City yesterday, causing a sharp drop in water pressure in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn and prompting the Department of Water Resources to declare a firststage water watch.

title: More Magazine Ends Its Publication to Join Journal at Columbia
description: More magazine, the monthly journalism review founded in 1971, announced yesterday that it was suspending publication and would be merged into the Columbia Journalism Review.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENHelen W. on July 21, 1978 wife of the late William, mother of James W. Allen also survived by three grandchildren and one oreat grandchild. Funeral from the Doyle B. Shatter Inc Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy at Northern Blvd, Little Neck on Mon at 10:30AM. Services at the Zion Episcopal Church Douglaston at 11AM. Interment Zion Churchyard. Visiting Sun 2S & 71Cpm

title: Carey Asks Alternatives For New Anticrime Law
description: BUFFALO, July 21 (AP)  The state's recently passed anticrime legislation must be supplemented by laws creating alternatives for crimeprone youth, Governor Carey said today on a campaignstyle swing through Buffalo.

title: Internal Chaos Grips a Major Party In Puerto Rico After Head Resigns
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 21  The resignation of former Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon as president of the Popular Democratic Party has left what was once Puerto Rico's most powerful organization in chaos.

title: A Rash of Municipal Strikes Foretells Harder Bargaining
description: The rash of strikes by municipal workers and the threat of walkouts by postal workers are a signal of harder times coming in public employee bargaining.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: Experts at OPEC Want Dollar Replaced by Basket
description: KUWAIT, July 21 (UPI)  A committee of economic experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has agreed that the United States dollar should be replaced by a basket of currencies in computing oil prices, OPEC's chairman said today.

title: TRACE OF OIL OR GAS IS FOUND OFF JERSEY
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it had turned up traces of oil or gas in the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey.

title: Statements by Bourne Open Flood of Queries On Capital Drug Use
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The White House was put on the defensive today as the abrupt resignation of President Carter's principal narcotics adviser prompted a flood of inquiries about drug use by members of the White House staff.

title: Jazz Pianism By Alexander At the Carlyle
description: Twenty years ago, the jazz landscape was dotted with pianists who used strong sense of the dramatic to frame their jazz talents. The most successful was Erroll Garner. but there was also Ahmad Jamal, who made provocative use of the rhythmic tension of silence, and Ramsey Lewis, who was exploring the devices that eventually gave him brief period with a pop following.

title: Theater: Singer's Teibele, Wry Tale of Student's Love
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 21  The sad and delicate irony of an Isaac Bashevis Singer short story has been captured briefly and then flooded out in its staging at the Guthrie Theater here.TM BELE AND HER DEMON by.I saac Bashevis Singer and Eve Friedman. Directed by Stephen Kanee; music composed by Richard Peaslee; setting and costumes by Desmond Helley; lighting by Duane Schuler; ccnductor, Dick Whltbeck; stage manager, Mary Hunter. Presented by the Guthrie Theater. At Minneapolis.

title: Democratic Officials In Cleveland Support Effort to Oust Mayor
description: CLEVELAND, July 21  Leaders of the Cleveland Democratic Party voted overwhelmingly last night to support an effort to oust Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich from office.

title: Fed's Open Market Committee Votes Increase in M1 Growth
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy and is composed of governors and presidents of regional banks in the Federal Reserve system, has voted 9 to 2 to raise shortrun targets for growth in the nation's money supply.

title: An Arab Who Serves as a Bridge
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 21 President Gaafar alNimeiry, the new chairman of the Organization of African Unity, is known in his homeland as a man with baraka  a word whose English translation, charmed life.

title: Effort to Save Skylab To Go on but Official Believes It Is Doomed
description: HOUSTON, July 21 (UPI)  Although the head of the Johnson Space Center believes that the Skylab space laboratory is probably doomed to a fiery death in Earth's atmosphere, the space apencv's administrator, Robert Frosch, said today that engineers would continue to try to save it.

title: Voldano Erupts on Soviet Island
description: TOKYO, July 21 (Reuters)  A volcano on Kunasbir Island off Hokkaido, one of four formerly Japanese islands now held by the Soviet Union, was seen erupting today for the first time in five years.

title: Yanks Win 3d in Row, 74
description: CHICAGO, July 21  Sparky Lyle, who apparently took himself out of the Reggie Jackson game last Monday night saying I'm no longrelief man, entered tonight's game with Chicago as a longrelief man.

title: G.O.P. TOLD TO BACK TAX CUTS FOR POOR
description: DETROIT, July 21  The leader of the nation's oldest civil rights organization today read the Republican Party a political price list for its campaign to win more black votes, saying that the cost would include support of tax relief for the poor and Federal fullemployment legislation as well as rejection of the Proposition 13 mentality.

title: RAILROADS CONFIRM PACT WITH 4 UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The' nation's railroads formally announced today that they had tentatively settled with .four unions on new contracts with wage packages that could exceed 35 percent over three years.

title: Colts Trade Chester To Raiders for Siani
description: BALTIMORE, July 21 (UPI)  The Baltimore Colts today traded Raymond Chester, a tight end who has played in the National Football League for nine seasons, to the Oakland Raiders for a wide receiver, Mike Siani.

title: Coast Smog Cuts Output
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21  Until this week, smog in the Los Angeles area was the sort of material for comedians that potholes are in New York City. But now, with the worst conditions in seven years, smog is no laughing matter, particularly for business, which stands to lose $5 million a day in lost production.

title: About New York
description: The case of the vanishing joke received barely a nod of recognition, and no laughs, in a report earlier this week that dealt with Salesmen's Awareness Day, an occasion designed to bring the sample case of drummer problems to the public eye.

title: S.E.C., After 10 Years of Debate, Clears Way for a Utility Merger
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  After more than 10 years of deliberation, the Securities and Exchange Commission gave tentative approval today to the offer by the American Electric Power Company to acquire the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company.

title: Standard Brands Plans Joint Pact
description: Standard Brands Inc. announced that it planned to enter into a joint agreement with Convenience Foods Ltd. of Hong Kong to produce dimsum, a food that is customarily served in Chinese restaurants during the day as a main course or as an appetizer in the evenings.

title: Jersey Indians Bow, 21
description: JERSEY CITY, July 21  Bob Tufts, the East'rn League's top pitcher, tossed a fourhitter for his 13th victory as the Waterbury Giants defeated the Jersey City Indians, 21, last night.

title: Phyllis R. Craig, Editor, Bride of William Wheelan
description: Phyllis Rose Craig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Craig of Jacksonville, Fla., and William Hubbard Wheelan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Wheelan of Rock Island, Ill., were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in the Municioal Bui!dine.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: F.T.C. Charges G.M. Arid Ford In Car Rental Ad Allowances
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged yesterday that, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company had granted discriminatory advertising allowances to vehicle renting and leasing companies that purchase their cars and trucks.

title: A Rash of Municipal Strikes Foretells Harder Bargaining
description: The rash of strikes by municipal workers and the threat of walkouts by postal workers are a signal of harder times coming in public employee bargaining.

title: Wistful Longings for Those Fits in Print in All the News
description: The pride that The New York Times displayed on July 3d in describing its total conversion to cold type was tempered somewhat by the wistfulness expressed by its Linotype operators and makeup printers, who had long struggled with molten lead to achieve sense of Craftsmanship in getting copy into mint.

title: Barbara H. Gross To Be Wed Sept. 10
description: Barbara Hope Gross, an account executive at Dorf /Muller Jordan Herrick, a New York public relations company, plans to be married Sept. 10 to Kenneth Stave Goodkind, a graduate ofthe University of Pennsylvania Law School.

title: SADAT CALLS BEGIN THE ONLY OBSTACLE TO MIDEAST ACCORD
description: CAIRO, July 22  President Anwar elSadat declared today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was the only obstacle to peace in the Middle East.

title: Last Week, Two American Correspondents Were Convicted of Libel for Writing Stories Like Their Colleagues Do Every
description: MOSCOW  For all their history, since long before the Bolshevik revolution, Russians have looked upon the Western world with a neurotic mixture of envy and suspicion. They have suffered the agyances of European and then American societies with an admiration and a distaste so strong in their conflicting impacts that no foreigner, even today, can predict whether he will be met in Russia by the warmest flood of hospitality he has ever known, or by the crudest bullying he could ever imagine.

title: Appellate Court Fights Backlog
description: TRENTON

title: INTERVIEW Political Crusader
description: MORE and more women are becoming involved in politics these days, not in the roles of the Ella T. Grassos, the Mary Anne Krupsaks or the Helen B. Meyners, but as counterparts or aides of the David Garths and the Gerald Rafshoons, the campaign strategists.

title: ANTIQUES Prizes of an Early Collector
description: AN antiques lover's dream would be to find an unknown cache of objects gathered long before there was any profit to be made in faking old furniture. Any- one wishing to indulge in such a fancy can do so by visiting the summer exhibition, Furniture From the Wheelock Collection, at the Clinton Academy in East Hampton.

title: Eugenia Ulasewicz Wed To Robert F. Labbancz
description: Eugenia Marie Ulasewicz, daughter Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Ulasewicz of Pittsburgh, and Robert F. Labbancz, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Labbancz TotStamford, Conn., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. EdWard J. McLaughlin at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic ChUrch in Upper St. Clair, Pa.

title: HONE CLINIC How to Reunite a Broken Soap Dish With Ceramic Tile
description: ONE of the most frustrating repair problems a homeowner or apartment dweller can face is when a soap dish or similar accessory breaks off on a ceramictile wall of a bathroom or shower enclo- sure. This repair often seems to require the services of a professional tile contractor, and very often it is almost impossible to match the color of the tile if and when you can find a new soap dish of the same size and style.

title: Deirdre Stall Is Engaged To Alan Barry Osofskv
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour R. Stall of poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Stall, to Alan Barry Osofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Osofsky of N'ew York, Shelter Island LI., and Boca Raton. Fla.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Menachem Begin, Prime Minster of Israel.

title: Atlantic City: Hedging the Bet on Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: What Price for the West Bank?
description: The central question now put to Israel is starkly simple: Will it rule out further settlement and annexation of territory in the West Bank in return for a full peace with Egypt, the negotiation of new borders with Jordan and West Bank Palestinians, and a definition its continuing security requirements beyond those borders? Having brought President Sadat to the offer of such a deal, the United States need make no apology for pressing hard for a clear Israeli answer.

title: Mower Mishaps: A Clear Pattern
description: AHOMEOWNER took it into his head to trim the top of the hedges with a power lawnmower and was hoisting up the heavy machine when he caught his hand in the rotary blade and ampu- tated one of his fingers. Another man, mowing his backyard, stopped to adjust the wheel of his lawnmower without bothering to shut off the machine and lost an index finger. And a young man who was backing up a mower to trim around a tree ran the machine over his left foot, severely injuring several toes.

title: The Cultural Retreat of the 70's
description: In his new collection of essays, Gore Vidal tells of a conversation he had with Tennessee Williams a year or two ago. When Williams confessed, I slept through the 60's, Vidal responded, You didn't miss a thing. Then, in a mire sober afterthought, Vidal said, But if you missed the 60's, God knows what you are going to do with the 70's.

title: James Galway, a Popular Flutist From Ireland, Performs Mozart
description: James Galway, who made his New York debut at Friday night's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall, is a short, bearded Irishman with ruddy cheeks and dancing eyes. He was once the principal flutist of the Berlin Philharmonic, but quit in 1965 to pursue a solo career.

title: DISPUTES EMBARRASS DALLAS'S EDUCATORS
description: DALLAS, July 22  In two days this week, the Dallas Independent School District was forced to disclose that half its new teachers had failed a competency test and was told that School Board members could have been guilty of criminal violations of Texas statutes in their interviews with candidates for the school superintendent's lob.

title: Jazz and Classical Musicians Interact At Woodstock
description: Most summer music festivals, like Tanglewood or the Newport Jazz Festival, specialize in one type of music or another. But at the Creative Music Studio in Woodstock, where a threeday festival is now in progress, one can expect an eclectic mixture of musical styles.

title: Memphis Club May Shift to New York
description: Gull and Western is in the final stages of completing a deal to purchase the Memphis Rogues with the intention of moving the North American Soccer League franchise to New York.

title: Houston's FaceChanging Building Boom May Be Abating
description: HOUSTON, July 22  Above the clink of glasses and the steady murmur of a festive crowd, LM. Pei, the architect, was describing one of his newest creations, a 70story skyscraper, more than 900 feet high, called El Paso Tower. When it opens two years from now in downtown Houston, the arresting, fivesided structure of granite and glass will probably be the tallest building in the country outside New York and Chicago.

title: WHITES IN RHODESIA SHAKEN BY SCANDAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 22  The disclosure that highranking Rhodesian officials participated in a multimilliondollar plan to divert large amounts from a secret armsbuying fund into private Swiss bank accounts has shaken morale among the country's white minority as few events since the rebellion against Britain 13 years ago.

But more important than the specific commitments, most of which were already in the works, were the economicconticat realities anti perceptions that permeated the final communiqu. title: Versatile jazz Group Shines in Montauk
description: DESPITE the publicity that women jazz musicians have received in the last year, it is easy to be caught off guard by the intensity and versatility of the Mary Kaye/Nadine Jansen Quartet.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Baldrigu of Woodbury., Conn., and Claunch, N.M., have ahnoUnc_ed the engagement of their daughter, Megan Brewster Baldrige, to Craig W. Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner A. Murray of Woodbury and Jeffersonville, Vt. A wedding next spring is planned.

description: BASEBALL.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE pay raises that Newark City Council members voted themselves and Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson on July 12  retroactive to July 1  are creating a backlash in the State Legislature, because Newark is dependent on the Legislature for survival.

title: Gains Tax Cut Gathers Momentum
description: The Administration continued its struggle last week to head off what it considers unacceptable cuts in the capital gains tax despite strong support for such legislation in both the Senate and the House.

title: White House Planning No Inquiry Into Drug Use by Members of Staff
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  With leaders in both parties assessing the political impact of Dr. Peter G. Bourne's resignation as President Carter's chief adviser on narcotics, a White House spokesman said today that there were noplans to investigate the use of illicit drugs among staff members there.

title: Jersey City Fire RazesBuilding
description: JERSEY CITY, July 21 (AP)  One apartment building collapsed and two others were heavily damaged yesterday when a fire erupted in the residential Greenville area, Battalion Chief Vernon Nacion said. The fire forced the evacuation of 14 families.

description: FUNERAL FOR SLAIN SPANISH OFFICERS: The widow of Lieut. Col. Juan Perez Rodriguez is comforted in Madrid at services for slain officer and Brig. Gen. Juan Sanchez Ramos, who were killed in their car Friday. Spanish authorities received a note from Basque separatists claiming responsibility.

title: John Daniel Cole to Wed Hilary L. Platt in the Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. William V. Platt of Nobe Sound, Fla. and Siasconset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Lester Platt, to John Daniel Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Daniel Cole of Buffalo. A fall wedding is planned in Siasconset on Nantucket Island.

description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 22  Out on the patio, palm trees filtered the glow of sunset. In the pastel elegance of the Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel, the beautiful people paraded to their tables for drink before dinner. Sitting near the door, Joe Namath was gazing at blonde walking by when a grev-

title: IRONWORKERS AGREE TO SETTLE BIAS SUIT
description: A civil rights suit has resulted in an agreement to establish a goal of 24 percent nonwhite membership by the end of five years in Local 580 of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Ironworkers.

title: The Elements That Make Jack Nicklaus the Golfer He
description: Jack Nicklaus smokes as much as two packs of cigarettes a day, but he never lights 11D on the golf course.

title: Karen Simpson, a Teacher, Bride
description: At All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J., yesterday, Karen Nichols Simpson was married to Robert Eldon Harvey by Suffragan Bishop G. P. Mellick Belshaw of the Diocese of New Jersey.

title: The Nation
description: In Summary

title: From the Korean Truce, One of History's Great Lessons
description: TWENTYFIVE years ago this week, on July 27, 1953, an American soldier named Harrison strode into a wooden building at a wide place in the road called Panmunjom. There he signed his name to a document he had helped to negotiate, a truce agreement calling for a ceasefire in the Korean War.

title: Felix Rohatyn, a Star in the city's Bankruptcy Drama, Is About to Leave the Spotlight
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, who engineered New York City's financial rescue and who has engineered some of the major business deals of the last two decades, is about to leave the public spotlight and is wrestling with the problem of what to do for an encore.

title: Boat Carrying Haitian Refugees To Florida Capsizes and 10 Die
description: FREEPORT, the Bahamas, July 22 (UPI)  A boat carrying 28 Haitian refugees heading for Florida was hit by storm and capsized this week, and at leak 10 of them drowned, Bahamian authorities have reported.

title: Regional Cooperation Is Just One of Many Noble Ideals
description: Truckers take the shortest route the way water seeks its own level, so when New York outlawed heavy rigs on a section of Route 9W last March, the stream of 18wheelers simply cut a new channel around the blockage. Right through the peaceful towns of Bergen County, N.J., just across the border.

title: Program Testing Support Or Scapegoat?
description: On almost any weekday, at about 4 o'clock in the afternoon, some 15 or 20 people selected at random from the streets of midtown Manhattan are herded into elevators in CBS's Black Rock headquarters on Sixth Avenue and led to a screening room. There, seated around a large conference table with a homey TV set at one end, they are shown a program that no one aside from a few CBS executives  has ever seen before. They record their moment-to-moment reactions by pressing two buttons: a green one in their right hand to indicate the parts they like, a red one in their left for the others. After the show is over, they fill out a questionnaire, which asks in detail what they thought of the story, characters and so forth. They are then sent on their way with a hearty thankyou and a CBS ballpoint pen for their trouble.

title: H.M.S. Pinafore
description: Since H.M.S. Pinafore was the first fulllength Gilbert and Sullivan operetta to achieve a triumphant worldwide success, exactly a been ago this year, it would have been unthinkable for the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company to omit this perennial favorite from the repertory of its current United States tour. So, sure enough, Pinafore turned up Friday night at the State Theater, its melodic appeal and barbed, satire intact and untarnished by age.

title: STEPHEN R. JEWSBURY
description: MIAMI, July 22 (AP)  Stephen R. Jewsbury, a communications staff member of The Associated Press before he retired in 1972, died here yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Dave Parker, after the Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder placed first in the voting of the National League general managers for the league's best allround player: Basically, I think they're telling the truth.

title: FISHING The Sound: Jammed With Fish
description: IN the last few years, fishing in Long Island Sound has played second fiddle to the established fishing grounds in the Atlantic Ocean from Shark's Ledge to the Cholera 13 anks. But with a strong run of bluefish and weakfish, anglers in the Sound are now singing a new tune.

title: Philip Francis Petronis Marries Anne L. Bennett

title: At Home: Portrait of a 20thCentury Moral Heroine

title: Connors Advances To Final
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Jimmy Connors, in 104degree heat, defeated Spain's Jose Higueras; 76, 62, today and reached the final of the $175,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament. It is his first event since he lost in the Wimbledon final to Bjorn Borg.

title: U.S. Terpsichore Brings the Classics to Stamford
description: CRITICS have been puzzling over U.S. Terpsichore since the little ballet company came into existence three years ago. To start with, there was that rakish name. Then there was the matter of a relatively small ensemble performing the classics on the most tenuous of shoestring budgets.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: EDMUND WILSON didn't give a damn who killed Roger Ackroyd, and mystery buffs have been having at him ever since, even bringing back his ghost to argue with him. Jacques Barzun is such a one. In Murder Ink, that sprightly collection of odds and ends dedicated to the mystery reader and brought together last year by Dilys Winn, Dr. Barzun repeated the point he had developed in an essay in The Mystery Writer's Art, edited by Francis M. Nevins Jr. Wilson, said Dr. Barzun, had been aiming at the wrong target in dismissing virtually all mystery fiction as trash.

title: The Editor
description: To people in the world of books he was a major figure, a kind of hero, writes A. Scott Berg the Scribner editor Maxwell Perkins; and many Scribner authors agreed. Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings, later a Pulitzer Prize winner for The Yearling, wrote her editor in 1936 at the height of his achievement, When all of us are done for, the chances are that literary history will find you the greatest  certainly the wisest  of us all. No mean claim wpen all of us included Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Thomas Wolfe, Ring Lardner, Allen Tate, Edmund Wilson. Perkins inspired nearly filial devotion in his authors, enough to create a legend. There Is nothing so important, he once wrote Wolfe, as a book can be, and everyone knew he believed that.

title: GARDENING Wild Flowers Enhance Summer
description: SEVERAL summerblooming native wild flowers make themselves at home in my garden. In July, the culver's root thrusts its panicled snowy spikes of bloom aloft, as if old Neptune himself were raising flowery tridents from behind my ohlox. Although not many wild plants flower so late as this, or do well in sunshine and part shade, culver's root does both.

title: Wagon Show Goes On as Horse Lies Dying

We do, however, have a town pool, and into these two summer months we crowd a whole year's worth of democratic living; that is, we practice knowing and loving our neighbors. The loving does take practice.

They are home from col- iege, ana tney are miming um IllUM swim upstream to the waters where they were spawned. They won't stay long, most of them, but they will drop by to see the old folks at home, to empty the icebox in a flurry of appetite, to pay grudging courtesy calls to the friends of their folks who want to show them off.

title: For a Special Market
description: FIRST we had the Cat in Art, the Dog in Art, the Horse in Art. Now, inevitably it would seem, we have The Nude Male, an illustrated study of the unclad masculine body in art. Just as other books isolate special categories of subject matter from the general history of art are designed to appeal to an audience more interested in that particular subject than in art itself, so The Nude Male addresses itself to a specialized constituency. In this case, the public is the growing audience (and lucrative market) for material designed to express and satisfy the newly emergent feminist and homosexual points of view.

It was a landmark event in the economic and political history of this small nation, one of South America's poorest and politically most unstable countries.

title: DINING OUT Uneven Excellence

By August of that year, my mailbag was full of complaints about the food and the service. Here is a rereview, after recent dinners in late June and July. The excellence is there, but you cannot rely on it.

title: New Massacre Last Week
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  Faced with a guerrilla war that is growing in violence and in scope, even Ian D. Smith, once the symbol of white minority survival and denial black aspirations, seems to be running out of schemes and losing heart. I think it is clear to everyone that as far as the ceasefire is concerned, it's in the hands of my black colleagues, the Rhodesian Prime Minister said last week. There is little I can do.

To others it was a call to compromise, adjust and adapt in order to maintain something of the rural character of the 39-square-mile, northern Westchester community. These contrasting strains reverberating last week in the Bedford Town Hall were the beginning of what promises to be an extended coda to a bitter, fiveyear legal battle between the town and neighboring Mount Kisco over annexation and development of 225 acres of Bedford land for condominiums.

Another Canadian critic, Penelope Doob, admires the company's remarkable generosity of spirit.

title: Wheelock's Bonak
description: JOHN HALL WHEELOCK, the poet who died this year at the age of 91, lived for many years in East Hampton. This month, the Clinton Academy in East Hampton put on view selected pieces of furniture (see Antiques column on opposite page) from the collection of the poet's father, William Efner Wheelock.

title: Success Straining Standby Flights
description: Flying standby has become the new wave of travel across the North Atlantic, but what started out as a cheap, slightly inconvenient way to travel between New York and London has turned into a highly uncertain mode of transportation, one that threatens to smudge the image of the airlines.

title: Cover: Photographs by Helen Levitt and Marl: Cohen / Picture credits, Page
description: One of the most striking developments in the recent history of the visual arts in this country has been the elevation of photography to an exalted new status. In popular journalism it has be- come a commonplace to speak 01 the photography explosion, and in professional photographic circles there is an emphatic new sense of pride, opportunity and achievement as the old barriers separating photography from the

title: Notes: Liner's Owners Remain Optimisti6c
description: The liner America is now standing idle, her planned series of summer cruises suspended as a result of the difficulties with plumbing and other aspects of refurbishing that plagued her first two voyages after her return fo New York in June. But her owners remain hopeful that the 38-year-old ship will in time be able to resume her career as a cruise vessel.

title: Deaths
description: TAYLORSeth. We shared our lives and though part of us dies with him, he will be with us forever.

title: GARDENING Ferreting Out the Foe of Squash
description: HOW nice it would be if gardentending could be all flowers and vegetables without any worry. But at this time of year no gardener can go too far down the path without needing some challenge. Another insect, you say?

title: Future of Playland Park Weighed
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 20  Members of Westchester's Board of Legislators and other county officials trudged over Playland's beaches, inspected its rides and other attractions and toured its 80acre lake in a motorboat on this hot, humid day as part of their effort to determine the future development of the 270acre amusement park on Long Island Sound here.

title: Costs and Imports Hurt Philippine Film Industry
description: MANILA, July 22 (Reuters)  The Philippine film industry has run into hard times and could be facing collapse because of competition from a flood of foreign films and increasing production costs.

title: Hadley Mack, E. R. Stroh 3d, Are Married
description: Hadley Mack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilber Hadley Mack of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Edwin Ralph Stroh 3d, son of Jane Malcomson Stroh and Mr. Stroh Jr., also of Grosse Pointe Farms, were married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert McGregor performed the ceremony.

title: Meat for the Table
description: BLACKVILLE, New Brunswick, July 22  As surely as Muhammad Ali had a battle plan against Leon Sninks. the salmon had a plan. Human traits are seldom assigned to other creatures in this space, but the fish's tactics left no doubt about what was in his mind/Obviously, he realized that his adversary wasn't Ted

title: Christiane Citron, Lawyer, Will Be Bride Of David Anson Clive Moore in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Harmon Noble of Pasadena, Calif., and Essex, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Noble's daughter, Christiane Hyde Citron, to David Anson Clive Moore, son of Lady Campbell of Hartley Wintney of England, and Nassau, the Bahamas, and William C. Moore of Washington. Miss Citron also is daughter of Casper Henry Citron of New York and North Salem, N.Y.

title: The Walker's Route To London Expertise
description: If you want to know London better, if you want to learn some things about the world's most cosmopolitan city that most people who spend their lives there never learn, I. cannot think of a better investment of a couple of hours and 80 pence (about $1.50) than one of the strolls organized by a company called London Walks.

title: Economic Summit Signals Bonn's New Diplomatic Clout
description: BONN  The outcome of last week's Western economic conference has been widely, and accurately, portrayed as a personal victory for its host, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. But his victory has a significance extending far beyond the economic sphere. It is another sign that 30 years after losing World War II, West Germany is finally acquiring the diplomatic muscle to match its economic strength.

title: HOME CLINIC How to Reunite a Broken Soap Dish With Ceramic Tile
description: ONE of the most frustrating repair problems a homeowner or apartment dweller can face is when a soap dish or similar accessory breaks off on a ceramictile wall of a bathroom or shower enclosure. This repair often seems to require the services of a professional tile contractor, and very often it is almost impossible to match the color of the tile and when you can find a new soap dish of the same size and style.

title: Notebook: Poisons Common in Cycling
description: PARIS, July 22  As the sun was going down over the glaciers of Alpe d'Huez last Sunday, a rider in the Tour de France ,bicycle race was relaxing before dinner and talking about his plans for Monday, a day off.

title: ART
description: BETHEL

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: BRIDGE TOURNAMENT ENDS ITS LONG TREK
description: TORONTO, July 22  The world's biggest bridge competition reached its climax here today, with 10 players out of an original entry of 90,000 still in contention fora ma ior national chamoionshin.

title: Ann H. Ridegly Is Wed to John Schwoerer
description: The Presbyterian Church of Remsenburg, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ann Hodges Ridgely, daughter of Mrs. Ann Franklin Ridgely of Cockeysville, Md., and James Hodges Ridgely of Ruxton, Md. to John Gerald Schwoerer. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Schwoerer of Phoenix, Md.

title: Odette C. King Is Married
description: Odette Chantal King, an area representative for the Easter Seal Society, and John Evans Benda of Purdys Station, N. Y., a tennis professional, plan o be married in October. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Oliver of Yorktown Heights, N. Y., uncle and aunt of the bride-to-be, who is the daughter of Broadus H. King Jr. of Alexandria, Va. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Benda of Miami are the parents of the prospective bridegroom,

title: Floods in Northeastern India Are Reported to Leave 60 Dead
description: NEW DELHI, July 22 (Reuters) More than two million people have been affected by floods in northeastern India, the United News of India news agency reported today.

title: Around the Nation
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 22 Civil Service investigators have determined that examinations for the Dayton Police Department were given to minority applicants in 1974 and 1975, a time in which the city was actively involved in minority recruitment.

title: Comptrollers Say Their Reports Have Helped Cut Welfare Fraud
description: What happens to auditors recommendations? With some pride, the New York State and City Comptrollers are crediting their reports with sparking important gains in the city's Human Resources Administration to fight fraud and waste.

title: 2 Children Die in Jersey Fire
description: PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., July 22 (UPI)  Two children died today and three other persons were injured in a 1:30 A.M. fire chat swept their home in this Warren 1County community. The dead children were identified as Theodore Klotz, 11 years old, and Rose Sebring. 12. The owner or the home, George Klotz.. was reported in fair condition, while his wife, Bonnie, and their 9 yearold son, Sam, were treated for minor bUrns and released.

title: The Politics of Emergency
description: YONKERS

title: Goldie Hawn Has the Last Laugh: She's Buried Her Ding-a-Ling Image
description: Goldie Hawn was stopping In New York on her way to Rome, where she'll star in a film with Giancarlo Gia!Mini. In a couple of hours she would be at Calvin Klein's showroom choosing clothes for the role  designer clothes, not the thriftshop bargains she used to buy. She's grown up now, no longer the daffy, wideeyed waif of television's LaughIn, the one who was usually described as a delectable sweet  a bonbon, perhaps, or a lollypop.

title: Foreign Observers and Familiar Features
description: LOOKING at 19thcentury pictures of New York, it is always surprise to find outflow much of the scenery is still recognizable. Perhaps this is a matter of the better region's bone structure, the longer it survives. Still, the state has a romantic quality not wholly attributable to its geology and it is visible even in the transition from Connecticut to Westchester County.

title: Grand and Otherwise
description: THE cover of Prof. Hamish F. G. Swanston's In Defence of Opera is an elegant color photograph of Boris Christoff in the theatrical coronation robes of Boris Godunov, but Moussorgsky's opera about that 16thcentury Czar is not even mentioned in passing in the text of the book. The text fulfills the title in exactly the same way.

title: Realty News
description: Ann Taylor Inc, a 46store chain of women's wear apparel, is moving on. 57th Street.

title: A Fire in the Office
description: An electrical fire put most of the team offices in darkness. I can't look at the films, complained Michaels, so I don't know if anyone who's in the training room is there because he got hit or because he's lazy.

title: Rhodesia Reports 39 Blacks Slain, Says Military Killed 106 Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 22Military headquarters here said today that black nationalist guerrillas of the Patriotic Front alliance had killed 39 black civilians in a war zone southeast of Salisbury two weeks ago.

title: Dr. Roberto ArezziBoza Is Fiance of Miss Cushing
description: Margaret C. Cushing of Boston, a travel agent, and Dr. Roberto ArezziBoza of Florence, Italy, an ophthalmologist, plan to be married in October in Beverly Farms, Mass., where Mr. and Mrs. George M. Cushing of Beverly Farms, parents of the bride-to-be, have announced the engagement.

title: DINING OUT A Swiss Touch, With a Few Holes
description: WHEN we heard last year that the owner of Gipfel's had taken over part ownership of Tappan Hill, we looked forward to the rejuvenation of that Westchester landmark. For years, a dinner at Tappan Hill had marked the celebration of a birthday, an anniversary, or a graduation for many a Westchester family. It was, too, the setting for many an important date, with dancing in the entry rotunda under the skylight of a twostory ceiling.

title: CALENDAR
description: Today: Southern Connecticut Bottle Flea Market. Lake Quassapaug Park, Route 64, Middlebury. 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: Fashion Paris Preview
description: Starting tomorrow, the 1978 fall and winter couture collections will be shown in Paris. And as can be seen in these sketches, made exclu- sively for The New York Times Magazine by four top French couturiers  the new broadshouldered, slim silhouette will continue to be the favored look in Paris. Although the haute couture collections are not startlingly provocative, they are always interesting to observe. Yves Saint Laurent (who started the bigshoulder movement) will continue to emphasize sleeves and shoulders and he promises sexy dresses with accessories full of humor. Marc Bohan for Dior is doing wide shoulders, too, and, tired of his beige and white palette of previous seasons, he will be deep into black, brilliant colors and glamour. Hubert de Givenchy, using the most luxurious fabrics, will show elegant cocktail and short evening dresses. Emanuel Ungaro describes his upcoming collection, full of unexpected fabric and color combinations, as clothes for strong, willful ladies who want to make dramatic entrances.

title: A Legend Instead of President
description: WHAT is the genius of this book? Irving Bartlett, a professor of history at Carnegie-Mellon University, really means it when he says, I began my research, trying to explain why so many of Webster's contemporaries, even those who hated him the most, thought he was so great.

title: Jewelry Salesman Guilty
description: NEWARK, July 21 (AP)  Jewelry stolen from the home of former Hackensack Deputy Mayor Kazmier Wysocki that later turned up at an antique show has led to the conviction of Edwin Fuchs, 48 years old, a Maplewood, N.J., jewelry salesman. He faces up to seven years in prison and $2,000 fine for receiving stolen property.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING For Auction, Old House Made New
description: PEEKSKILL will show off some of its handiwork Saturday when it is to auction off a 19thcentury Gothic house on the Hudson. The city bought and restored the house as part of its downtown renovation program and was the first local government in 10 metropolitan counties to go into the restoration business with Federal money, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. If the auction is successful, Peekskill expects to continue the program.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Cricket: For Some
description: KENNEDY VENKERSAMMY hurled the small red ball at a group of adversaries 22 yards away and it bounced deviously in front of them. The projectile, traveling at up to 90 miles an hour and popping up in front of the players eyes, would have made most men duck, but not these. They stood up to it. To do otherwise just wouldn't have been cricket.

title: Biologist Experiments With Raising Crabs Under Artificial Light
description: PRINCESS ANNE, Md., July 22  A marine biologist in this quiet East Shore town is trying to fool crabs: The purpose of his experiment is to grow crabs commercially, much as millions of chickens are produced in this region, under artificial light that encourages 24hour growth.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Act to Bur Rivalry in Bid to Promote Total Long Island Tourism and Development
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  Taking a cue from New York State's successful advertising campaign, the newly formed Long Island Tourism Commission is singing, 1 love New York but I'm delirious about Long Island, in the hopes of sharing the I imelight. .

title: F.T.C. Opens an Inquiry On Lwenbrau Formula
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commission said today that competitors of Lowenbrau beer should be allowed to question in television commercials and other advertising whether the beer is still the same as the original German brew.

title: CAREY'S YOUTH AIDE ASSAILED BY DURYEA
description: The director of the New York State Division for Youth was attacked by Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea and defended by Governor Carey yesterday for his handling of juvenile criminals, including a 17-year-old youth who, while on furlough from a maximumsecurity facility, allegedly raped, robbed and tried to electrocute a 63-year-old woman.

title: ART VIEW
description: With the deaths of Harold Rosenberg (on July 11) and Thomas B. Hess (on July 13), the New York art world is suddenly a significantly smaller and less interesting place. In the official positions they lately occupied  Mr. Rosenbere was the art critic of The New Yorker, of course, and Mr. Hess the new curator of 20thcentury art at the Metropolitan Museum' they will undoubtedly have able successors in due course. Yet in the larger roles they played in shaping the climate of criticism and opinion in New York in the past three decades  for Mr. Hess had been for many years an influential editor and critic for Art News magazine  they can never be replaced. With their passing, an entire era in the intellectual history of the New York School has all but come to an end.

title: Nasty and Bold Breaks Record
description: Forego, the threetime winner of the Brooklyn Handicap, had his day at Belmont Park yesterday. But it was not for being the winner of the 90th running of the orestiRious 1 1 /2mile event.

title: How to Complain Successfully: A Fact Sheet on Health
description: OF all the complaints processed by government agencies, health problems are generally agreed to be more difficult to assess, mainly because of the interpretations required in medical diagnoses and treatment. In addition, professional groups kept, until recently, a tight hold on their role as arbiter for medical standards and disputes. But times are changing, and patients and health services clients are beginning to arm themselves with information.

title: DelBello Set to Defer Con Ed Takeover Vote
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: A Third Game,. A Third Draw In Title Match
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 22 Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger, pressed the champion, Anatoly Karpov, nearly to the end of their third worldtitle chess game in the Baguio Covention Center tonight, but his attack, the sharpest so far, fizzled into draw. All three encounters between Karpov, 27 years old, of the Soviet Union and Korchnoi, 47, have finished in draws.

title: GermanFrench Art Links in Paris Show
description: PARIS, June 22  In the turbulent history of love and hate across the Rhine, the first three decades of this century marked an intense cultural crosspollination between France and GenPany. This relationship  sometimes affectionate, sometimes hostile  is the subject of a sprawling, vigorous exhibition that opened here last week at the Centre National d'Art et de Culture Georges Pompidou.

title: A Program That's Nutritiously Educational
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Huggle Duggle Wins at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 22 (AP) Huggle Duggle was the victor today in the $39,025 Eatontown Handicap at Monmouth Park, beating All Bix by 21/2 lengths in the 1 1-16-mile turf race. Navajo Princess was third.

title: Quintessential Housing Of the Past: Tenements
description: If there is one kind of building that characterizes New York, it is the tenement house. You find them throughout Manhattan  not just in neighborhoods like the Lower East Side but in Greenwich Village and the Upper East Side as well  and they fill block after block in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Survival Courses Lure Many to Tests of Endurance
description: BOULDER, Utah, July 19  Terri Ferons has quit her job as a title insurance clerk in San Diego and plans to work in a coal mine in Utah this fall. She is 19 years old and wishes that she had a luxury van with a sunset painted on the side, but she is saving her money for college.

description: Today

title: Steamtown May Move From Vermont in Fall
description: BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., July 22 (AP)  Officials at Steamtown U.S.A. say the tourist attraction probably will leave Vermont this fall.

title: Denise Nesson Is Engaged

Goldwasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goldwasser of Westbury, L. I. The prospective bridegroom, a graduate of Ohio State University, is in the controller's division of Salomon Bros., investment bankers.

description: Today

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING A Look at Homes of the Future
description: RECENTLY, representatives from nearly a dozen of the state's leading housing-development companies gathered to ponder the future of housing in New Jersey.

title: Marie Banich, Tufts 78, Bride of James Gleason
description: Marie T. Banich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Banich of Union, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to James T. Gleason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Gleason of Watch Hill, R.I.

title: TV VIEW
description: Several times a year I draw back and point out that the British imports seen here represent the very best of a lot that, on the average, is no better, and perhaps even worse, than the general run of American television. However, for a variety of reasons, the relatively small collection of British highs are considerably higher than our own  in ambition, imagination, integrity and execution. American television is simply incapable, as currently constituted, of producing a series on the level of Frederick Raphael's The Glittering Prizes (seen here recently on Channel 13). One obvious reason is that British programming executives actually have considerable experience in programming. Their American counterparts are too often refugees from sales or research departments. Another reason is that the British system maintains at least a modicum of a commitment to quality material, to the concept of occasionally giving the audience what it may need instead of constantly feeding it what it presumably wants.

title: CRIME
description: Linda J. LaRosa and Barry Tannenbaum have collaborated on THE RANDOM FACTOR (Doubleday, $8.95), and in a way the book is a throwback to the wondrously artificial, complicated mysteries of the 1940's. The identity of the murderers four well-to-do, aging former soldiers who are playing a game for thrills  is known from the beginning. Each of them soon attempts to outdo the others, to score points. The tension is in the way the New York City police, aided by a criminologist, track down the culprits.

title: South Africa Is Preparing for a Hostile, 2000Mile Border
description: PRETORIA, South Africa After more than 30 years dispute at the United Nations and the World Court and 11 years of guerrilla war, SouthWest Africa seems likely shed its white rulers and become the independent state of Namibia sometime next year.

title: As Democrats Meet, a Fiscal Reckoning Draws Nigh
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut's economy has improved recently, and as a result life has become a little easier for elected officials who face hard financial choices after the November election.

title: STAMPS
description: The 25th anniversary of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth H, now the third longest reigning queen in British history, has been marked by Great Britain with a set Of four special commemoratives. The issues depict symbols of royalty associated with the pomp and circumstance that no one in the world does better than the British.

title: A Portfolio of Souvenirs From the Roadside West
description: Souvenirs, writes Richard Anseldi, are things you select that are very personal reminders of your experiences. They are much more than the objects themselves. They recall times, places, people and events you choose to remember and cherish. They are also illusions, for they are symbols that recreate your interpretation of reality.

title: BRIDGE
description: If all those present at the world championships in New Orleans last month had been polled and asked to select the best players and the most popular players, it is very likely that four young men from Brazil would have emerged at the head of both lists. They are Gabriel Chagas, a director of a group of trading companies; PedroPaul Assumpcao, the director of an ithporting and exporting company; Gabino Cintra, an I.B.M. executive, and Marcelo Branco, a government employee. All are from Rio de Janeiro, and all are in their early 30's.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Proxy Rule Revision
description: Since the early 1970's, when corporate bribery and questionable payments became a burning issue, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been wrestling with the problem of corporate governance  seeking more checks and balances on management and making companies more accountable to their shareholders. Last week it issued the first of its proposals, a wideranging revision of proxy rules.

title: MARY LORD, 73, DIES; HELD POST AT U.N.
description: Mary Stinson Pillsbury Lord, a former United States representative to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, died Friday at her apartment at 425 East 58th Street. She was 73 years old and also lived in Stamford. Conn.

title: Rachel Hadas Bride Of George Edwards
description: Rachel Hadas, daughter of Mrs. Moses Hadas of New York and the late Mr. Hadas, was married at noon yestarday to George Edwards, son of Mrs. Arthur Edwards of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Arthur Edwards.

title: Katheryn C. Patterson, Lawyer, Fiancee of Thomas Kempner Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Parsons Patterson of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Patterson's daughter, Katheryn Clews Patterson, to Thomas Lenox Kempner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kempner of New York and Purchase, N.Y.

title: The Region
description: When the ship seems to be sinking, only the very bold care to apply for the post of Captain. During Benjamin Ward's three years as New York State Corrections Commissioner, prison overcrowding grew while segments of public and politicians clamored for more imprisonment, and many both inside and outside the Department of Corrections lost faith in its power to correct anything.

description: Archery

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY Beach Haven: The Joy of Crowds
description: WHENEVER it is known that we have a house in Beach Haven at the New Jersey shore, someone always says, Lucky dogs  you have those weekends in September. June and September  those are tne montns that everyone longs for. Then the beach is something shared with spindly legged gulls; and the nights are so quiet that you can hear the ocean's surf as you fall asleep. In September, the water is warmer than ever, and no lifeguard whistles you to swim between the narrow flags; and the sunlight, which is softer than its summer's glare, makes everything lovelier  the house fronts, the twilight haze, the tranquil bay.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklit and Fremont Streets)  Man of La Mancha, in an Actor's Caf Theater production Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Aug. 12). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, 2.5044.50. (201) 4297662. West. minster. Theater.

title: Y'KNOW WHAT I'M SAYING?
description: For those with a taste for the freshest in cliches  who take their bromides with Perrier and lime, and feel the need to make sense out of nonce words  here is the Third Annual Vogue Word Watch, a guide to those currently in phrases that make up our transienttalk.

title: Chiang Ching Offers Dances In Clark Series
description: The fourth annual Clark Center Dance Festival continued Friday night with a performance by the Chiang Ching Dance Company at the City University Graduate Center Mall. This is an unusual company because it combines Chinese subject matter with Western modern dance.

title: U.S. Rugby Club Is Invited to Play in the Soviet Union
description: After a year and a half of laying the groundwork, a Boston club has won approval as the first American rugby team invited to play in the Soviet Unioh.

title: Pearson Approaches the $2 Million Mark
description: Next Sunday's 500mile stock car race at Pocono (Pa.) International Raceway could be a milestone race for both David Pearson and Richard Petty.

title: Movie People
description: MOST of what passes for film criticism is still an exchange of more or less decorous warwhoops, and most of it is intended directly for recycling as advertisement or cocktailparty fodder. This is especially so in America  why, one can- . not be sure. But perhaps the making and exhibiting of a personal taste has remained, from Henri James's day to our own, one of the special trials by which we measure solidity of character; to acquire a taste is art ordeal, to have acquired one is a distinction; and we are too proud of our new acquisition, and too wary of being found out, ever to shut up and think. So we are disabled from saying anything really intelligent  we have no trouble being charming and clever  about the works of art that we know best, which are movies. At any rate, whatever it is we do when we talk and write about movies, the French critic Andre Bazin does something different:

title: Ferris Says F.C.C. Will Not Act As Censor of Controversial Issues
description: Charles D. Ferris, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said Friday that he would consider it a tragedy if the Supreme Court's recent decision on the use of indecent language on television and radio were to become a reason for broadcasters to avoid controversy.

description: 1COLLECTION MUSEUM OF MODERN ART (TOP) GILMAN FOUNDATION FUND

title: Mary L. Cooke, Teacher, Bride of Richard T. Opie
description: Mary Lauren Cooke, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Lawrence H. Cooke of Monticello, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Thomas ()pie of Boston, son of Guy Ware Opie of Santa Clara, Calif., and the late Helen McCrudden Opie.

title: The Many Games of Chance
description: NOW that it has become legal for the state to exploit its weakest citizens through an official numbers game, called the lottery, and its more affluent citizens through casinos, we ought to think about the role of gambling in our lives.

title: Outdoor Sculpture That Cooperates With Nature
description: OLD WESTBURY IN the past, outdoor sculpture was generally an object for conspicuous exhibition. Its presence was emphasized, often flamboyantly, by: means of pedestals that made seem more grandiose than it was and by artistic gestures that were exuberantly dramatic. The site chosen for the sculpture was frequently of strategic importance, usually an eminence or noticeable spot dominating its environment. Surrounding trees and gardens played a secondary role to the work, as if man's creation had triumphed over nature.

title: How the System Works
description: John Doe, who lives in Brooklyn, receives a Visa card from Bankers Trust Company. While on vacation in California, he buys a shirt for $28  the average bank credit card sale  and charges it to his card.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: For Dr. George A. Sheehan, life began not at 40 but at 45  when he started playing. Not the playing around of the frustrated middleaged man, but the sport that earned him a collection of silver medals in college running. Now, almost 15 years older and much happi er, he stands firm in his explanation of1 his rebirth: To know running is to know) llife.

title: Susan Rich Tharaud Is Bride Lawrence Michael Quater
description: Susan Rich Tharaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Tharaud of San Erancisco, was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Lawrence Michael Quater, a certified public accountant with the San Francisco accounting firm of Wolf & Company. The Rev. Erwin D. Reddekopp of the San Francisco Church of the New Jerusalem 6erformed the ceremony.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee
description: JUGGLING ACT: Bruce Boisclair of the Mets stealing second base as Braves Jerry Royster bobbled the ball in the first inning last night at Shea Stadium.

title: CORRECTION
description: Today's Arts & Leisure Guide lists the Michael Bennett Musical as running at the Public Theater. The show is only in rehearsal at the theater.

title: Correction:
description: A typographical error in The Private World of Truman Capote, by Anne Taylor Fleming (July 9), altered the meaning of a quotalion from Jack Dunphy about his life with Capote. The passage should have read: We're proud of our past, a terrific past we've held on to and don't talk about. We traveled all over the world and stayed young for a very long time.

title: Ohio Teamsters Group Backs Ouster of Mayor
description: CLEVELAND, July 22  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich received another setback today in his fight to avoid recall when the political action arm of the Ohio Conference of Teamsters announced its support of the recall movement.

title: A Fresh Air Child, Now 30, Returns to Settle in His Friendly Town
description: Until he was almost 7 years old, vacations for Orlando Vasquez went about as far as the fire escape outside his railroad flat on the Lower East. Side or the open hydrants on the street below.

title: Veal for All Seasons
description: Food

title: Greenwich Recalls Lore of the Islands
description: GREENWICH AS summer ripens, more and more weekend sailors will ply the waters of the Sound and carry on the tradition of legend, gossip and hearsay that make up the mythology of Greenwich's offshore islands.

title: The Odyssey of Two British Rockers
description: Robert Fripp and Brian Eno are alive, well, working industriously and based in New York. Thisnews may not seem important to a rock fan whose taste is defined by Andy Gibb and John Travolta. But, in fact, it's very important-both for what it should mean to the rock and even serious music scenes here, and for what it tells us about the whole fascinating interchange between London and New York Music over the past decade.

title: Folksiness Is Gary Busey's Film Career
description: I know just how this here story's gonna start, said Gary Busey, who did. There was Gary Busey, sitting in the SherryNetherland Hotel eatire about 200 olives and throwin pits every which way, with no regard forthe feelings of the cleanin staff, until it looked like Easter up there.  Easter? Well. don't these pits look like littl6 bitty Easter eggs? Back home I'd say they looked like somethin else, but Eguess we have to make a few concessions, seemn as we're here in New York City.

title: GARDENING Ferreting Out the Foe of Squash
description: HOW nice it would be if gardentending could be all flowers and vegetables without any worry. But at this time of year no gardener can go too far down the path without needing some challenge. Another insect, you say?

title: Dog Show on Coast Sets an Entry Record
description: For the sixth consecutive year, Santa Barbara ranks as the nation's largest dog show. This year's golden anniversary event, set for next Sunday, is ex- petted to exceed all previous shows with an entry of 4,650. The 1977 total was 4,488 and the previous high was in 1975 with 4,649.

title: An American Vision
description: IT'S easy enough to be condescending toward James Michener, and over the years many reviewers have been exactly that. His long, plodding novels are high on sincerity, low on literary merit. The history he serves in such massive helpings tends to arrive at the table halfbaked. And his extraordinary commercial success arouses envy and outrage among more certifiably serious writers who struggle from novel to novel with no particular hope of a decent audience, not to mention a decent income.

title: Gomez Junior Victor
description: ST. LOUIS, July 22 (UPI)  Unseeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador eliminated seventhseeded. Mike DeFranco of Gainesville, Fla., 63, 36, 75, in the semifinals of the St. Louis junior invitation tennis tournament yesterday.

title: Editors
description: ILLNESS AS METAPHOR, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $5.95.) A powerful attack on the attitudes we adopt toward sickness in out writing and thinking.

title: Study Projects Low Risk From Radioactive Cargoes in Urban Areas
description: Shipping radioactive materials through densely populated cities such as New York presents nearnegligible risks to the public, according to a comprehensive Governmeiitsponsored study that will be presented tomorrow to a panel of experts and to the public.

description: THERE seems to be a feeling among Americans that learning cricket would be as hard as learning nuclear physics. This p untrue. Even neophytes can get into the swing of the game by watching or a while, and because matches can go on for days (in Westchester the matches are relatively short, six hours Or so), there is plenty of time to learn the fine points. But there are certain things to be aware of, especially if you

title: Sharon D. Greene Is Engaged To Alan Kornstein, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Greene of Highland Park, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Donna Greene, to Alan F. Kornstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Hornstein of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: U.S. MassTransit Grants Found To Benefit New York Area Most
description: As the Federal Urban Mass Transit Administration celebrates its 10th anniversary this month, a survey of its grants for the building and refurbishing of subways, buses and commuter rail lines shows that the New York tristate region has benefited far more financially than any other area in the nation from the agency's existence.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE The InterestRate. Debate
description: For a brief period last week, it appeared that the investment world was inclined to ignore some of the current cosmic economic issues  inflation, monetary policy, the dollar's weakness, the cautious tone of the Bonn summit  heeding only recent economic statistics and the latest corporate data.

title: Remembrances of Things Beastly
description: Upon request, Chris Miller (Dartmouth 63, Alpha Delta Phi fraternity), Harold Ramis (Washington University 66; Zeta Beta Tau), and Doug Kenney (Harvard 68, Spee Club) will obligingly recite their favorite selections from the mythsteeped oral history of Guffawingly Funny, Unprintably Impolite Things That College Fraternity Boys Have, On Occasion, Purportedly Done. Messrs. Miller, Ramis and Kenney know a bit about this subject because (a) they have been there, and (b) they cowrote the screenplay of Animal House, the new film comedy opening July 28, which is brought to you by the same people who, each month, bring you the National Lampoon magazine.

title: Religious Networks Blossom
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. In a clearing amid 195 treelined acres here, two 30foot dish antennas look toward the heavens. They are the satellite earth stations of the Christian Broadcasting Network, an organization that has wed religious conviction and modern technology to fashion a communications network whose programs can now reach millions of people around the world.

title: Giants Drop 13, Greet 32
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y:, July 22 On hellogoodbye day at the Giants training camp, 32 veterans reported and 13 players were the victims of the first, and probably biggest, squad cut of the summer.

description: One of the major problems in reviving thirties comedy, says director Tom Moore, is the decision on where or what to cut. Plays of that time were overlong  heavy with exposition  with three, sometimes four intermissions. But with this play only three lines were dropped. It's a meticulously constructed comedy. It's impossible to cut. Something you think

description: WASHINGTON. July 22 (UPI)  The amount of wastes dumped off United States coasts dropped 12 percent in 1977, the Environmental Protection Agency has reported.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 22 (AP) Fund raisers are finding that running often pays better than passing the hat.
