description: CREPES are fun, a theme to be deliciously varied. Given the. single, paperthin pancake, how many fillings can one dream up to make a snack, a dessert, a meal? On the Island there are well over 100, at creperies in seven locations.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: YOU certainly bring one hell of a class of clients, Hume Cronyn said to his friend, Jack Mitchell, a realtor, as the two lie handcuffed and locked in the basement of the actor's Pound Ridge home a few weeks ago. Upstairs woman who had posed as a prospective buyer and her architect colleague were moving paintings, sculpture and lother art works into a box that, Mr. Cronyn recalled, they would never have been able to lift out of the house. They never had the chance.

title: Talmadge Asserts Paper Is Trying to Destroy Him
description: ATLANTA, July 22 (AP)  Senator Herman Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, issued a 1,700word letter today ac= cusing the Atlanta JournalConstitution of trying to destroy him.

title: I Accept the Universe
description: THE 19thcentury career of Margaret Fuller supplies persuasive evidence for absolutely opposed interpretations. In her late 30's the American writer who had sustained herself by intellectual talk and platonic friendship began a liaison with an Italian man by whom she bore a son. Did she thereby surmount her frustrated femininity to reveal woman's ultimate dependence on man and child as a means to wholeness? Or did she attest the richness of her feminism, rejecting the partial self-expres-

title: THE MARKETS Dow Dips in a Seesaw Week
description: A week ago, the stock market raced ahead with a rally that added 27 points to the Dow Jones industrial average. But last week the momentum ran out and the Dow stumbled, finishing at 833.42 with a loss of 6.41 points.

title: School's Out, but Not the Principal
description: SH000L'S out for the summer. It's the time of year when many parents face with trepidation the prospect of having their offspring home all day, the time of year when many school administrators face with trepidation that old chestnut of question: What are you going to do all summer?

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: DogShow Aplomb: Advice for Novice Travelers
description: When it was the preserve of the moneyed elite, dog showing was a ather esoteric pastime. Although it is still far from plebeian, its popularity as aparticipant and spectator sport has increased dramatically in recent decades. About 1,700 wellattended shows are held annually in the United States, and many of the most colorful events during place outdoors in the Northeast during the summer and early autumn. they offer an opportunity to combine easy weekend traveling with the fun even for the uninitiated  of watching purebred canines compete against each other.

title: CHINA STRENGTHENS ITS TIES WITH JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 20  A new era appears to be opening up in China's economic relations with Japan. The two major Oriental, powers, which remained at arm's length for nearly 29 years after the 1949 revolution in China, are planning a mass of joint industrial projects.

title: The Center of the Community
description: There arc nine and sixty ways of constructing tribal lays.  Rudyard Kipling once observed, and every single one of them is right. A most novel, supremely right way pf reconstructing the American people's story was conceived by Phyllis Lambert. an architect, who persuaded the Joseph E. Seagram Company to underwrite a project that would study the courthouse as a symbolic center of community life and as o. reflection of the attitudes and aspirations of each generation from colonial times to the present. The outcome may be seen in Court House, edited by Richard Pare (Horizon Press; cloth, $35, paper. $18.95).

title: $144,000 Jewel Theft Reported at Hilton Show
description: About $144,000 in gems were stolen yesterday from a jewelry exhibition in the New York Hilton Hotel at 53d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, according to the police.

title: A Film Producer Takes On a Chiller
description: A lot of people today make motion pictures without knowing anything about making motion pictures, said Elliot, Geisinger. What they do know about is deal making. They feel they can go out and hire those people that do have the knowledge. And I don't happen to agree with that.

title: The Blurb and I
description: THE word blurb is said to have been coined in 1907 by the humorist Gelett Burgess, as the Oxford English Dictionary says, in a comic book jacket embellished with a drawing of a pulchritudinous young lady whom he facetiously dubbed Miss Belinda Blurb. The dictionary goes on to quote Mr. Burgess: ... fulsome praise; a sound like a publisher. The word has a nice, wet ring to it and has become more a part of the language than Burgess's other coinages, bromide and goop.

title: Anna S. Hurry Married To Prof. Stanley Frame
description: Anna Stoddard Hurry of Cold Spring Harbor, L. L, widow of Renwick Washington Hurry and daughter of Mrs. Francis R. Stoddard of New York, and the late Mr. Stoddard, was married yesterday afternoon to Stdnley Turner Frame, a widower of Plandome Manor. L.I. He is a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Frame of Rockland, Mass.

title: Mets Win By 2 to 0; 5 in Row
description: It's called putting it together. When the other team scores five runs, you score seven. When it's a 20 game, you get the pitching. When the game's on the line, your fielder comes up with the big catch.

title: Brigid A. Holleran Married To Michael Stephen Smith
description: The marriage of Brigid Ann Holleran to Michael Stephen Smith took place yesterday in St. Mary's Chapel in Exton, Pa. The couple are graduates of School of Arts and Sciences of Cornell University.

description: Alan J. Hirschfield, president of Columbia Pictures Industries, was ousted last week, just three weeks after David Begelman, a former Columbia executive, was fined $5,000 and put on probation for taking $40,000 from the company in forged checks.

description: INVESTING Two Paths Toward Municipal Bonds

title: The Case For Nuclear Power
description: IN an age when the folk singer John Denver is treated as an expert on nuclear power, it's no wonder people get confused by the debate over this important issue. After all, scientists disagree about vitamin and saccharin, so it isn't surprising that they can't agree about nuclear power.

title: Philanthropy, the Business of the Not-So-Idle Rich
description: Philanthropy has always carried an aura of wealth and dogoodism, an image as a plaything of the idle rich, said John D. Rockefeller 3d in an interview some months ago. But it is not too late to straighten out the idea.

title: Traffic Judge Is Indicted Over Alleged Kickbacks
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP)Judge Louis Vignola, President Judge of City Traffic Court, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of racketeering, income tax evasion and accepting money and gifts from writservers who worked for him.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 22  Jack Nicklaus's threeshot lead melted in today's 96degree heat  it was one of those threetowel days  as Bruce Lietzke was shooting a 66 and taking the lead in the third round of the 16th Philadelphia Classic.

title: NEW CHIEF IN BOLIVIA CITES LEFTIST THREAT
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 (AP)  Gen. Juan Pereda Asban, who deposed President Hugo Banzer Suarez with a oneday rebellion, says he had to take control of the country to prevent the rise of leftist extremism.

title: Oregon Measure Limiting Taies Is Approved for November Ballot
description: SALEM, Ore., July 21 (AP)  Secretary of State Norma Paulus today approved a measure on property tax limits for Oregon's November ballot.

title: Farmers
description: CHICAGO  Combines have reaped the winter wheat in Kansas and other major states to the south and are now sweeping through the Nebraska fields. Another week of good weather will complete most of the work. And there is every indication of a dramatic turnaround in the fortunes of the Farm Belt. Just a few months ago their big tractors were rumbling through the streets of Washington, and other cities as farmers angrily protested the squeeze on their incomes. Now, everything seems to be coming up roses. Good weather has helped. But the farmers are also helping themselves, encouraged by new Government programs to store record quantities of their crops, waiting for the right price until well after the harvest.

title: Workers
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 22  A Federal judge here is considering a case in which the General Motors Corporation, arguing for the privacy rights of Its employees, has resisted the efforts of a Federal occupational health agency to subpoena em ployee medical records without the worker's consent.

title: The New York Times/Karen Eberhardt
description: Richard C. Squires with the tools of his trade. Page

title: Page T.Phelps Will Be a Bride
description: Anne Stewart Phelps of Farmington, Conn., and Gordon Stuart Phelps of West Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Page Taft Phelps, to Paul Anderson Ingraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Ingraham of Winchester, Mass.

title: Headliners
description: Joseph P. Tonelli, president of the 300,000member United Paperworkers International Union, seems to know something about giving advice. He needs it now. Mr. Tonelli has been member of the Federal Social Security Advisory Board, the Air Quality Advisory Board, the Advisory Committee for Trade Negotiations. Since 1973 he has been a member of the New York State Racing Commission, also an advisory board. Last week, a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted Mr. Tonelli for a number of illadvised actions, chiefly embezzling $360,000 from his union. In addition, the indictment charges Mr. Tonelli with spending $50,000 of union funds to pay two Atlanta lawyers to try to block the indictment. One of the lawyers, Irwin W. Stolz Jr., was appointed to the Georgia Court of Appeals by Jimmy Carter when he was Governor, but denies any impropriety. The other, W. Homer Drake Jr., is said to be a close friend of Attorney General Griffin B. Bell. If there was any impropriety it did not succeed, but an attorney for the Organized Crime Strike Force has confirmed that Mr. Stolz and Mr. Drake are also targets of the grand jury.

title: CAMERA
description: The home movie maker can, with careful planning, take everything aloes for vacation needs to meet most emergencies without weighing themself down. Here are some pointers. Pack camera gear separately from clothes in a rugged, pliable, expandable carryon bag such as a back pack or EuropeaQ schoolbag so that your camera will be easily accessible.

title: Patient Royals Wait for Hurdle
description: Clint Hurdle is so young he still remembers and can relate to the books his parents read to him before he learned to read books and hit baseballs he orobablv learned to hit first.

title: U.S. Does Not Plan Ties To Angola Despite Bid
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  The United States has no plans to establish diplomatic relations with the Marxist Government of Angola despite an overture from the Angolan President, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: FuelSaving Focus On Newer Offices
description: A recent analysis of New York City's office buildings has indicated that more significant savings in energy consumption can be achieved in postWorld.War II construction than in older properties.

title: N. J. Campbell Jr. Who Retired From the Board of Exxon, at 63
description: Nicholas J. Campbell jr., a former director of the Down Corporation, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Mount Vernon Hospital. Mr. Campbell, who lived in Crestwood, N.Y., was 63 years old.

title: Capital Transit Strike Continues
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  Attornery for striking transit workers and the Washington Metropolitan Transit Authority were ordered today to come up with a plan to speed arbitration of the pay dispute that led to the wildcat walkout.

title: New Donleavy Novel Due
description: J.P. Donleavy's next novel, Schultz, which is about an American producer living in London, is scheduled for next spring by Delacorte as a Seymour Lawrence book. Dell: Will publish a paperback edition of an earlier Donleavy novel, The Destinities of Darcy Dancer, in October.

title: Thomas Hooper 3d Weds Miss Boykins
description: Diane Marian Boykins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis L. Boykins of Rahway, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Harrison Hooper 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hooper Jr. of WinstonSalem, N.C. The Rev. James W. Ealey performed the ceremony at the Second Baptist Church.

title: In the Manner of Balzac
description: MOST writers have to face moments of despair, and, as his letters show, John O'Hara frequently suffered from lack of confidence in his work. Sometimes his doubts took the form of an exaggerated belief in the importance of his writing. To Harold Ross of The New Yorker he once wrote, I have decided to reject your rejection of this piece and to give you another chance to read it over again. A few years later, he sent an aggressive oneliner to Katharine Angell White, also of The New Yorker, which read: My pieces don't run second.

title: Samoyed Is Top Dog At Putnam
description: CARMEL, N.Y., July 22  Joan Scovin has nine Samoyed champions and has been involved with the breed for 15 years, but today one of her dogs

title: Battered Shore: Official Neglect?
description: TWELVE separate bills, more than 20 printed pages, $85 million in proposed expenditures and no action. This is the record compiled by the recently concluded session of the New Jersey Legislature on the repair, restoration and reconstruction of the stormbattered New Jersey seashore.

title: There's a Hunger to Own Land, Any Land, However Remote
description: Whoever heard of bidding on an island off the coast of Maine, on 320 acres in upstate New York, or on a building lot in Ocala, Fla., all sightunseen and while seated in the luxurious Corrinthian Suite of the New York Sheraton Hotel?

title: Borg in Swedish Final
description: BASTAAD, Sweden, July 22 (AP) A tired Bjorn Borg, breezed into the final of the Swedish open tennis tournament today, beating Spain's Antonio Munoz, 64, 61.

title: Alydar 13=Length Winner
description: CHICAGO, July 22. Alydar scored 13length victor:'n the Arlington Classic today in:what his trainer described as a conditioning; exercise to prepare for an Aug. 19 rematch against Affirmed at Saratoga.

title: POLITICS Clamorous Protest At Close Range
description: ALFRED B. DELBELLO, Westchester's County Executive, seems to be getting as much flak from his fellow Democrats these days as he is from the Republicans.

title: Hank Williams Jr. Sings of Identity at the Lone Star
description: Hank Williams Jr., who was at the Lone Star Cafe on Wednesday and Thursday, sings about a single subject. As one might guess, the subject is his own identity. As the only son of Hank Williams, the most talented, influential, charismatic and starcrossed singer and songwriter in the history of country music, Hank Williams Jr. has a lot to live up to.

title: DIVIDED DEMOCRATS ENDORSE GOV. GRASSO FOR A SECOND TERM
description: HARTFORD, July 22  A bitterly divided Democratic state convention endorsed Gov. Ella T. Grasso for a second term today, but also gave enough votes to her opponent, Lieut. Gov. Robert K. Killian, to force a statewide primary election Sept. 12.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: China's leaders tell us that art cannot be divorced from politics, and they have sent us the Performing Arts Company of the People's Republic of China, which has just left New York, to prove their point. Any attempt to appraise this ensemble of four distinct groups  musicians, ballet dancers, ethnic dancers and performers of the Peking Opera  on purely artistic grounds falls short of the complete picture.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel. oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available

title: Oil Slick off Chicago Dispersed
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI)  High waves churned by two thunderstorms have dispersed most of a 36mile oil slick on Lake Michigan about 1,000 feet off Chicago's lakefront. After the slick was discovered yesterday, an investigator of the Metropolitan Sanitary District took samples of the material and reported that the slick may have come from the bilges of a ship. A Coast Guard spokesman said he suspected that the slick was caused by an oceangoing vessel pumping her bilges illegally.

title: A Time for Politics
description: LEE VEST, the chairman of a recent Republican nominating convention in New Canaan, was taken aback when G.O.P. headquarters sent down rules on how to select a candidate for the State House. They included instructions on when delegates could demonstrate for the candidates of their choice.

title: Sweden's 'Company Doctor'
description: SPOTLIGHT Sweden's Company Doctor

title: Aimee May Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard May have announced the engagement of their daughter, Aimee May, to Mark Gomberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Gomberg. The future bride, the professisonal representative coordinator for Sony Corporation of America, is a graduate of the State University of New York at New Paltz. Her fianc, a graduate of Brooklyn College, is an administrator in a corporate banking center of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Both families live in Brooklyn.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It's not easy to resist it. The Swarm, this year's funniest if only bigbudget groupjeopardy movie, stars people like Olivia de Havilland, Henry Fonda, Richard Widmark, Fred MacMurray and Michael Caine. It's about a swarm of African killer bees who, in the space of 24 hours, terrorize a large part of the American Southwest. The bees attack picnickers at their peanut-butter sandwiches, then helicopters, and, for an encore, the personnel at an underground missile silo. They cause the explosion of an atomic power plant, whose failsafe system hasn't been programmed for killer bees (which results in the death of 32,000 people in one town alone) and, for a climax, threaten the complete destruction of Houston.

title: POLITICS Monitor
description: IT is virtually a political tradition in New York City that the City Comptroller keep a close watch over the shoulder of the Mayor and not hesitate to publicly criticize mayoral fiscal shortcomings.

title: Joanne Bosche Wed To David J. Ehrlich, City Ballet Official
description: Joanne Bosche, an assistant treasuier with the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Dayid Jay Ehrlich, director of special events for the New York City Ballet, were married yesterday in Rutherford, Calif. The Rev. Richard Fabian, an. Episcopal priest of San Francisco, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents, Virginia Volkmann Bosche and John Bosche, both of Oakland, Calif.

title: Births Jelin
description: Dr. & Mrs. Abraham Jelin (nee Malone Aipren) are happy to announce the birth of Sandra Eve's brother Eric Bradley, on July 13,1978.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: As deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget during the Nixon Administration, Frederic V. Malek gained a reputation as a hatchet man, ruthlessly cutting his way through the Civil Service thicket. Washington's Hidden Tragedy suggests that this label was at best simplistic; for here Mr. Malek appears as a thoughtful veteran of the bu. reaucratic wars, genuinely disturbed at the inability of administrations to get the government to do what it's supposed to do.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: This year's Red Book has a new look and more readable type face inside. For anyone who doesn't know, it is, more formally, A Guide Book of United States Coins, by Richard S. Yeoman, in its 32nd appearance, edited by Kenneth Bressett. It is a brief history of American coinage, early American coins and tokens, early mint issues, regular mint issues, private state and territorial gold, silver and gold commemoratives, and proofs. These are illustrated and priced.

title: Cornelia Loughran And Fred Heather, Lawyer, Are Wed
description: Cornelia Ann Loughran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Loughran of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Fred Doenges Heather, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Fred H. Heather of Avalon, N.J., were married yesterday in Scarsdale.

title: 90 Nuclear Protesters Are Fined For Trespassing at Power Plant
description: ST. HELENS, Ore., July 22 (AP) Ninety members of the Trojan Decommissioning Alliance, a group opposed to the Trojan nuclear power plant, were fined $155 each and received 30day suspended jail sentences.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS L.I. Symphony's New Man on Podium
description: BECOMING a conductor may be the least practical aspiration a musician can have. Unlike budding violinists or pianists, budding conductors can't buy an instrument aria practice at will, or accumulate concert experience by giving recitals in small, inexpensive halls. Instead, it is the instrument that hires the conductor, and even then opportunities to rehearse and perform can be few and far between.

title: Renoir Painting Taken From Gallery in Turin
description: TURIN, Italy, July 22 (AP)  A French Impressionist painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir, valued at $111,000, has been stolen from the Modern Art Gallery here, the police reported today.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Education Funds Urged For Handicapped Children

title: Universities in. South and West Gaining in Ratio of Ph.D.'s Granted
description: The universities in the Northeast, which have long been dominant in turning out the nation's Ph.D.'s, are gradually losing ground to younger institutions in the South and the West, according to a report by the National Research Council.

title: Homes Tailored to Troubled Youths
description: RUN away? Not me! Peter exclaimed. I'm not that stupid. How am I going to live? I'm only 12 years old. I'm too young to get a job or an apartment. The cops would be looking all over for me and I'd get caught easily.

title: POINT OF VIEW Don't Count on Employment Contracts
description: For many key people in business, happiness is an employment contract. In its simplest form it is a job security blanket which provides an executive with a measure of immunity from being severed from the payroll without good and sufficient reason.

title: Caverlee Cary Wed To Samuel H. Otter
description: Caverlee Sturges Cary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sturges Flagler Cary of New York, and Samuel Henry Otter, son of Mr. and Mrs.Robert David Otter, also of New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the Friends Meeting House in Haverford. Pa.

title: Arizona's Navajo and Hopi Country: Nations Within a Nation
description: The paved, lonesome, exciting highway that dips and winds through the heart of the Arizona section of the Navajo Indian Reservation is probably designated in your book of road maps as Arizona State Highway 264. Not so to the Navajo Indians. On their mapyou can get one by writing to the tourist department of the Navajo Tribal Government at Window Rock, Ariz. 86515it is Navajo Route 3 and is marked by the tribe's own road symbol, a drawing of an arrowhead. A gesture of pride. For the Navajos are, they insist, a Nation Within a Nation, part of the United States yet separate and distinct, with rights of selfdetermination.

title: RollsRoyce Exempted From Rules on Mileage
description: A RollsRoyce is not the car to buy one is worried about gas mileage, but the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has determined that the British luxury automobile should be exempted from American mileage requirements.

title: LowFlying Bids Seen After Feast on Berries
description: PERRYVILLE, R.I., July 22 (UPI)  Local farmers and motorists say flocks of birds haVe been flying across Route 1 with the grace of a sailor who has spent his shore leave in a bar.

title: A Modest Success
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The vote of Grenada finally brought into being this week an InterAmerican Court of Human Rights that has been nine years in winning hemisphere approval. A day or so later, Argentina learned that the United States ExportImport Bank had turned down a $270million loan for electrical equipment for a hydroelectric project on the upper Parana River. And in the same week, a Bolivian election was annulled by a court, only to be followed by military coup.

title: Meredith Sargeant Wed To Douglas Harrington
description: Meredith Nicholls Sargeant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sargeant of Ruxton, Md., was married yesterday to Douglas Sanford Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Harrington of Belleaire Beach, Fla.

title: World News Briefs
description: U.S. and British Army Pilots Pulled Out of Soviet Contest WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)  The United States and Britain announced today that they had pulled their military teams out of the world helicopter championships in the Soviet Union because of the recent trials of Soviet dissidents.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONThe President says 90 percent Americas lawyers are devoted to protecting the comfortable insulations of privilege. The Chief Justice says half lack the skill to try a serious case, and a recent poll by the American Bar Association shows that 91 percent of the lawyers surveyed agree with him. Nobody seems to like lawyers much these days, so it is scarcely surprising that the country's 168 law schools, which are turning out 30,000 lawyers a year, have themselves become objects of scrutiny.

title: HOME CLINIC How to Reunite a Broken Soap Dish With Cermic Tile
description: ONE of the most frustrating repair problems a homeowner or apartment dweller can face is when a soap dish or similar accessory breaks off on a ceramictile wall of a bathroom or shower enclosure. This repair often seems to require the services of a professional tile contractor, and very often it is almost impossible to match the color of the tile if and when you can find a new soap dish of the same size and style.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I read with great interest the article titled ItalianAmericans in Politics: It's Our Turn  in the July 2 issue of Westchester Weekly. I think it necessary for the purpose of a more accurate press that I advise you that I am extremely proud of my Irish-ItalianAmerican heritage.

title: Betty Jauvits to Be Wed
description: Betty Jauvtis of Bayside, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Diane P. Jauvtis, to Michael J. Mand, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley yfand of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Rushing for Judgments
description: Whenever a Federal agency issues a major decision or regulation that is subject to court review, there is, quite literally, a race to the courthouse. Lawyers for industry, unions and consumer groups, plus squadrons of paralegal aides, deploy themselves in the courts their choice to file an appeal before their opponents file in the courts of their choice. It is a spectacle that ought to make judges blush.

title: Deaths

title: CRISIS FOR RUSSIA'S DISSIDENTS
description: On the day of his arrest, Anatoly Shcharansky was in a rather cheerful mood. It was his way of facing adversity. He could find a twist of humor in the baldest outrage, and through several years or open aissent he had brought a fine, ironic wit to his confrontations with Soviet authorities, enough to turn the most offensive official behavior into an educational experience.

title: Jane Hunt Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hunt of KinneIon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Hunt, to William Charles Brackett, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. C. Brackett of Itasca, Ill. Miss Hunt and her fiance are graduates of the University, of New Hampshire.

title: F.B.I. Questions 2 in Illegal Entry of West German Terrorist Suspect
description: Two of the three persons who were being sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the illegal entry into the United States from Canada of a suspected West German terrorist last Sunday have been found and questioned, an F.B.I. spokesman said yesterday, and no charges were immediately brought against them.

description: THERE are still two years to go before the 1980 Olympic Games crown Bruce Jenner's successor as the world decathlon champion, and Mark Lineweaver, native of Northport, hopes he will move one step closer to the Olympics on Friday.

title: Glories of the Past in Mystic
description: MYSTIC

title: .LIRA RIDERS GLUM ON SERVICE OUTLOOK
description: It has not been a time that railroad officials want .to remember: July, weather predominantly sunny and warm, and yet the odds were that the commuters of the Long Island Rail Road were late on eight out of 10 trips to and from New York City during the week of July 9.

title: K.O.'d by the I.R.S.
description: Joe Louis after knocking out Max Schmeling, June 22, 1938.

title: New York City's CriminalJustice System Prepares for the Next Blackout
description: Auxiliary generators to keep the lights on in New York City's jails. Stockpiles of riot gear for the police. Transportation to get defense lawyers to the courthouses. If there's another blackout, the criminaljustice system is ready.

title: World Is the Stage For AliSpinks Fight
description: As far as Top Rank Inc. is concerned, the Battle of New Orleans between Leon Spinks and Muhammad All will be won in places like Japan, Britain and Venezuela.

title: Easy on the Salad Bar, Dieters Are Cautioned
description: DURHAM, N.H. (UPI)  Salad bars are not always good for the waistline, nutritionist at the University of New Hampshire has warned.

title: A Massachusetts Village Recalls A Bitter Night
description: Throughout the 1940's, a display of prints depicting early explorers hung in the Northern Indiana Historical Society Museum. In one etching, Pre Marquette stood dramatically in a canoe on the St. Joseph River, while on the bank, from behind massive oak and elm, Indians spied on his progress.

title: Contracts Without Contacts
description: THE time to reform the State Public Works Department's method of selecting architects and engineers for state projects apparently has come. The charge, by Daniel MacKinnon, recently fired as Commissioner of Administrative Services, that certain architects and engineers had received preferential treatment in obtaining state work has been wellpublicized. Further, there is evidence of great interest in this matter by design professionals, politicians and the public.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: HERE LIES AMERICA, by Nancy Eills and Parker Hayden. (Hawthorn, $6.95.) To the countless ways of tracing our national heritage, this volume adds another  the tombstones of celebrities. The 70 per- sonages represented here with fullpage photographs of their graves and spirited sketches of their lives and deaths include writers (viz., Melville, Margaret Mitchell), tycoons (J. P. Morgan, Hetty Green), performers (Houdini, Tallulah Bankhead), sinners (Lizzie Borden) and legends (Casey Jones).

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING Builders Fear Rise in Cost of New Houses
description: CONCERN is mounting among builders in the state that the high cost of financing  as much as 10 percent at most banks for a construction or land loan  plus increasingly vociferous neighborhood and conservationist challenges to the desirability of using certain categories of land for housing, may force the price of a new house to increase by at least 15 to 20 percent by next spring.

title: In Bristol, A Civics Lesson
description: BRISTOL THE Republican convention in Bristol to . nominate a candidate for the State Senate looked like it was going to be a good fight, a glimpse of oldfashioned ward politics in a manufacturing town.

title: Sex, Torah, Revolution
description: IN his 74 years, Isaac Bashevis Singer, rabbi'sson from Warsaw who immigrated to. America in 1935, has been a prolific writer: journalist, memoirist, children's storyteller and novelist. His books, written in Yiddish and serialized in The Jewish Daily Forward, have become popular in translation here. The sociology of this popularity is itself an interesting, if separate, subject. For me, a cheder boy in a Sholem Aleichem Bund school, his short stories in the Kinder  Journal, or Children's Magazine, were required reading, along with those of Sholem Aleichem (the master), Isaac Peretz, Israel J. Singer (the writer's brother) and others. These writers felt a dual commitment, trying to transmit a dying language and culture to young people and trying to create literature. These simultaneous passions sometimes nourished their work, sometimes confused it. In his newest novel, Shosha, new for the Englishspeaking audience (it was first published in Yiddish, in serial form, in The Forward in 1979), many Singers appear in one way or another  the journalist, the rabbi's son, the children's writer, the European refugee.

title: Fascinating Works By TeenAge Mozart
description: The music of Mozart is fortunately always with us, particularly so during these summer months with the annual Mostly Mozart Festival in full swing at Avery Fisher Hall. Nor is there ever any ttlearth of new Mozart recordings for nome listening. Along with fresh performances of the familiar concertos, operas, chamber music and symphonies, the latest crop of disks explores some surprising rarities, ambitious yet astonishingly assured products of his early teens.

title: Colleges Should Recognize It's Time to Pay the Players
description: As I read Jim Cefalo's five recent articles on these pages describing his exploits at Penn State, I kept reminding myself that football on this huge campus operates as altruistically as any bigtime college sports program one is likely to find.

title: Nancy Lopez Trailing by 6 As Miss Stacy Leads Open
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 22  Hollis Stacy, the defending champion, took the lead by one stroke after three rounds of the United States women's open golf championship today. Nancy Lopez, the people's choice, fell so far back she apparently lied lost any chance to take the title that will be decided tomorrow.

title: Laos Backs Vietnam in Dispute Despite Chinese Troops in North
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22  The Laotian Government, which had been gradually shifting from apparent neutrality to lowkey support of Vietnam in its disputes with Cambodia and China, has ranged itself fully on the Vietnamese side in a strong declaration followed by an editorial in the Communist Party newspaper.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Plans a Lobby Effort On Affirmative Action Programs
description: DETROIT, July 22  The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today that it would lead a major lobbying effort in which every member of Congress and the Cabinet would be pressed on the importance of continuing affirmative action programs.

description: ALMOST TOO HOT TO BE FESTIVE: As 14th Street merchants prepared for Feast of Santiago Apostol, a man rested atop unfinished stall, above, and John Oliveira sat on block of ice against the heat, which reached 91 degrees.

title: Owners of Dogs Face Orders to Clean Up
description: In nine days, dog owners throughout New York City  as well as in Buffalowill be required to clean up after their pets or face the possibility of fines of as much as $100. On that day, Aug. 1, the canine waste law takes effect, and yesterday Mayor Koch announced that he had directed the Departments of Police, Sanitation, Health, and Air Resources, and the Housing Authority Police to take it seriously.

description: 1. Vote on conference report on coalutilization bill, passed, 92 to 6, July 18.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 23  Hollis Stacy refused to back off from the pressure today as she sank a fourfoot downhill putt on the 72d and final hole and won the United States Women's Open championship by one stroke. Thus, she successfully defended the title she won a year ago.

title: Special State Prosecutor Reports Fewer Convictions for Last Year
description: Twentyfive civilians and criminal-justice officials pleaded guilty to criminal charges brought by the office of John F. Keenan, the Special State Prosecutor, in the last 12 months, compared with 67 the year before, his second annual report says.

description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I.  For cen; turies, men have gone fishing to get away from life's travails and once in a while the wife. The wife, also known as a fishing widow, traditionally cooked the man's catch and listened to his everlasting fish stories. Here and there a wife would smile and think, The truth is not in him.

description: DETROIT, July 23  The problem was familiar: engine trouble, $1,000 worth of it. And the 1977 Ford Grenada had registered 13,000 miles. In other words, its warranty had iust exoired.

description: HONG KONG, July 2 (Reuters)-- Vietnam has agreed to open talks with China on the mass exodus of Chinese refugees across the Vietnamese border, the Hanoi radio reported today.

description: LA PAZ, Bolivia. July 23  The installation by the Bolivian armed forces of a new military president, disregarding the invalidation of his election by a national electoral court because of fraud, is a setback for President Carters advocacy of democracy in Latin America.

description: JERUSALEM, July 23  The Israeli Cabinet refused today a request by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that Israel make a conciliatory gesture by returning the Sinai Desert town of El Arish and historic Mount Sinai to Egyptian administration.

title: Renewing Ties With Vietnam
description: WASHINGTONNow that the United States is out of Vietnam, it is time to get back in. On Sept. 14 the United States trade embargo against that country, issued by executive order in 1975. expires. forcing Presi- dent Carter.either to renew or cancel it. For practical strategic and moral reasons it is an ideal opportunity for the President to break with his prede- cessors and allow trade. It would be the beginning of a sane and civilized United StatesVietnamese relation- ship.

description: JERUSALEM, July 23 An increasingly fractious and bitter political fight between Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing Likud bloc and the opposition Labor Party continued unabated today.

description: COLLINGSWOOD, N.J.,July 23 Scoring a record 234 points, the New York Athletic Club won five races today in the 102d national rowing championships on the Cooper River, overshadowin2 collees and other clubs.

title: MiddleClass Revolt Pays Off for Queens Youths
description: At the end of this week, a group of teenagers from middleincome families in Community School District 26 in Queens will get their first paychecks from a summerjob program involving gardening at city golf courses, doing clerical tasks at school offices and working with handicapped children. The jobs  paid for by the Federal Government  are not unusual for urban youngsters, but they represent the fruits of a revolution that began last winter in the middleclass district, which includes Bayside, Little Neck and Douglaston:

title: EDWIN LEE TERRY RAY
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 23 (UPI)  Edwin Lee Terry Ray, a real estate developer and onetime actor, was found drowned in his swimming pool yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Commodities

title: Soviet Objects to U.S. Missile Plan, Complicating Talks on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Carter Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union had objected to an American plan for deploying mobile, intercontintential missiles. They said the move had injected a new complication into the Administration's search for a strategic arms agreement this year with Moscow.

title: U.S. Exoresses Regret
description: WASHINGTON, July 2.3  The United States expressed regret yesterday at the events in Bolivia that brought nullification of the presidential election results and the apparent seizure of power by General Pereda.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: Senator Argues Against Seeking Redress for JapaneseAmericans
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 23 (AP) Senator S.I. Hayakawa says the forced relocation of JapaneseAmericans during World War II was perfectly understandable and done for their own safety. Moves to seek restitution would only rekindle resentments, he said.

title: Around the Nation
description: REIDSVILLE, Ga., July 23 (AP) Two inmates and a guard who was taken hostage were stabbed to death today in a riot at the racially troubled Georgia State Prison, the authorities said.

title: Finding Wealth in Newark
description: The City Council of Newark  needy, struggling Newark  has raised Mayor Gibson's salary from $38,588 to $52,500, making him the fifth highestpaid mayor in the nation. It is to be an instant raise, supple- mentea by the previous $12,000 expense allowance. It compares with a top pay of $38,000 for mayors of cities of comparable size. Newark has more than its share of problems, it is true; but now it has one more.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Why didn't Harold Solomon enter this year's Wimbledon tennis tournament?

title: 78's Top Temperatures Bring Water Emergency
description: The hottest temperatures of the yearwith simmering midafternoon readings in the midto upper 90's  baked the New York metropolitan area yesterday, forcing the city to declare a- waterpressure emergency as youngsters opened fire hydrants on steaming city streets and sending hundreds of thousands of people to windswept coastal beaches.

title: Opening Doors to the Indochinese
description: The Carter Administration has recently taken two important steps toward fulfilling the nation's obligation to the refugees from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. It will admit 25,000 more refugees before next May under the President's parole authority. raisins to 197,000 the total number authorized to enter the United States since the fall of Saigon in 1975. To date, 164,000 have arrived. In addition, the State Department has declared that refugees plucked from boats at sea by Americanowned vessels will be admitted to the United States if they find no other sanctuary. The purpose is to set an example that might end the cruel refusal of many ships  in violation of law and decency  to pick up Vietnamese boat people because no one will receive them ashore.

title: Mary Ellen Paskey, Teacher, Married to James P. Roberts
description: Mary Ellen Paskey, daughter of Paul J. Paskey of Roselle, N.J., and the late Dorothea Neis Paskey, was married yesterday to James Peter Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Roberts of Lin- den, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Cantor David Benedict at the Chanticler in Millburn, N.J.

title: Officials Charge Resort Employers Are Exploiting Seasonal Workers
description: Unscrupulous New Jersey resort employers from Asbury Park to Cape May are clipping $2 million a year from the paychecks of 300,000 high school and college students who take seasonal jobs, according to state officials.

title: 17 Teenagers Devote the Summer to Good Deeds
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 23  While others can be found at the beach, visiting friends or just hanging around, 17 teenagers from throughout the state are spending the summer helping the less fortunateand they are even paying for the opportunity.

title: Public Workers Fear Tax Revolt May Increase Private Contracting
description: Public employee leaders fear that, in reaction to taxpayer revolts, local governments may turn more and more to contracting with private businesses for public services.

description: A brother in a Roman Catholic order who was shot and robbed of $60 in proceeds from a church bingo night in Hammonton remained in critical condition yesterday at Kessler Memorial Hospital.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTE LEAVES PARTY SPLIT
description: HARTFORD, July 23  The Democratic state convention, which adjourned early today, left the Connecticut party facing a rare primary fight for Governor and possibly one for Lieutenant Governor as well.

description: Well, somebody's baseball streak ended yesterday: The New York Mets got four hits and nothing else as they dropped a 30 decision to the Atlanta Braves and ended their winning streak at five games.

description: ALBANY, July 21Cross two publicspirited laws such as the new Lobbying Regulation Act and the Freedom of Information Act and what do you get? One of the state's hottest political campaign con trihution lists.

title: Fell Rides J.O. Tobin To Victory
description: To the surprise of few in the crowd of 29,350 watching the proceedings in 95degree temperatures, George A. Pope Jr.'s favored J.O. Tobin was the winner of the $43,250 Tom Fool Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: VANCE CALLS TRIALS IN SOVIET A SETBACK
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that recent actions by the Soviet Union against dissidents had caused a setback in SovietAmerican relations, but he said the Car ter Administration was determined to continue to speak out on human riehts.

description: Two major team championships were decided here Saturday night, and Chicago had a part in both.

title: Property Tax Is Hot Issue in Illinois Contest for Governor
description: CHICAGO, July 23  At delicatessens and ball parks, on street corners and especially on television, the candidates for governor in Illinois have suddenly made property taxes and. limits.on government spending the hottest issue in their race.

description: The President's Commission on Mental Health spent a year of hard work, enlisted hundreds of experts, and had the personal interest of President and Mrs. Carter. Its final report issued in April, produced a flurry of clippings ana excites meetings of professional groups, since then there has been silence.

title: Anglican Bishops, at British Talks, Are Cautioned on the Spiritual Life
description: CANTERBUR Y, England, July 23 The Archbishop of Canterbury, Donald Coggan, opened the Lambeth Conference today by speaking out against those bishops whose spiritual life has died and criticizing what he called a common image of the modern bishop as a kind of sunerexecutive.

title: America's Amateurs Get a Festival
description: AMATEUR athletes in 26 sports will converge on Colorado Springs and neighboring towns this week for the first National Sports Festival, whose success or failure could figure prominently in the future development of America's amateursports movement.

title: California Landlords, Fearing Controls, Start Freezing or Reducing Rents,

The fire, which investigators said was intentionally set Friday, burned along Highway 71 toward the resort area of Lake Elsinore.

title: $24,000 QUESTIONED IN TALMADGE AUDIT

title: John V. Lang, Active in Rowing As an Official and a Referee, 77
description: TEANECK, N.J., July 23  John V. Lang, a rowing official and referee, died at Holy Name Hospital yesterday of cancer. He was 77 years old.

description: EVA Evdokimova's local debut in London Festival Ballet's very special production of Giselle with Rudolf Nureyev , at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday night gave us another outstanding performance of the 19thcentury Romantic classic.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23  All afternoon it looked like one of those typical Jack Nicklaus blitzes, but then Oil Morgan put up a gutsy challenge, with birdies on the 15th and 16th holes, while Nicklaus was scoring a bogey on the 17th.

title: Scoring Goals Is His Cup of Tea
description: THE man most responsible for the creation of yet another rivalry between New York and Boston is Mike Flanagan, a 25yearold curlyhaired Englishman of Irish parents who plays center forward for the New England Tea Men, soccer's surprising expansion club.

title: Cosmos Triumph, Gain Division Title
description: SEATTLE, July 23 (AP)  New York's Vladislav Bogicevic scored early, but a shot that bounded off a Seattle defender's back in the second half gave the Cosmos a 21 victory today over the Sounders. The victory clinched the North American Soccer League Eastern Divigion title for the Cosmos.

title: Mariana Memories
description: HICKSVILLE, N.Y.  On Tinian Island, part of our new Mariana Islands commonwealth, lies an abandoned airfield. Thirtyfour years ago today, I walked across it with Marine infantry in battle. Later the atomic bombers took off from it, bringing Tinian to the world's notice.

title: Rose's Streak Reaches 36 As Reds Win
description: Pete Rose, closing daily on the National League record, extended his hitting streak to 36 games yesterday in Montreal when he led off the sixth inning with a single off Steve Rogers, the Expos starter. Rogers was the pitcher who surrendered Rose's 3,000th career hit earlier this season.

title: Owner Stunned By Manager's Outburst
description: CHICAGO, July 23 Reggie Jackson returned to the Yankees today, but the fragile peace that was expected to exist between him and manager Billy Martin was shattered just after the game when Martin erupted in a volatile verbal attack on Jackson and George Steinbrenner.

description: Anderson, Clayton & Company, a major food processor, announced yesterday that it was making a cash tender offer for all the shares of Southwestern Group Financial Inc., the second largest savings and loan holding company in Texas.

title: Painting Is Stolen From Museum In Milan While Visitors Pass By
description: MILAN, Italy, July 23 (Reuters) -Thieves stole a 19thcentury painting from its frame in Milan's Modern Art Museum today while visitors were passing. through and 14 attendants were on duty.

title: The Good Doubles Partner Knows His Place
description: IHAD a friend who used to bring her baby to the tennis courts every Tuesday and Thursday morning, days the mother played doubles. As far as anyone knew, the baby suffered only one unusual side effect from her early exposure to tennis.

title: Happy Lady Victor in Rich Pace
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 23 Happy Lady easily won the $333,238 Monticello N.Y.C.OTB Classic IV today at Monticello Raceway. The 3yearold filly pacer, the favorite, left the gate from the No. 2 post on top.

title: Cornucopia Wins In Polo, 1211
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 23  Frank Mortimer scored six goals and helped the Cornucopia polo team of Long Island to beat Country Road Farms of Virginia, 1211, today in the openine round of tne President's Cup at Bethpage State Park.

title: Study Finds Caesarean Not Always Necessary
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI)  Almost half of 526 pregnant women who have given birth by Caesarean section had safe vaginal deliveries in a trial labor study at the Robert B. Green Hospital in San Antonio.

title: 6 Firemen Hurt as Blaze Wrecks Historic San Francisco Building
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 (AP)  A fire rated out of control through a pre1906 earthquake waterfront building for more than three hours early today, destroying the interior of the threestory structure and injuring six firefighters.

title: Abu Dhabi Signs Gas Deal
description: ABU DHABI, July 23 (Reuters) Abu Dhabi and three foreign oil companies today signed agreements for a $1.6 billion project to collect, process and export natural gas from the Persian Gulf emirate's onshore oilfields, the official Emirates news aeencv renorted.

title: Soviet Dissident's Odyssey: From a Defiant Georgian Nationalist to a Broken Penitent
description: MOSCOW, July 23  Behind a Soviet court's decision last week to order two American correspondents to retract articles they wrote about a wellknown dissident there lies another story, perhaps even more interesting to Soviet citizens.

description: Bette Klegon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Klegon of Southfield, Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Gary F. Halby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Halby of New York.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: Billy Graham Plans Bible Center
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 23 (UPI) Billy Graham, the evangelist, unveiled architect's plans for a laymen's Bible training center. Mr. Graham said yesterday that the center, to be built four miles west of Asheville on 1,374 acres near the Great Smoky Mountains, will be for people of all ages and races who desire to learn the Bible.

title: Crosby Stills, Nash. Sitg
description: GROWING older does not have to bring on an identity crisis for rock performers. Many words have been spent arguing the pros and cons of this proposition, and some people actually seem to be concerned about it, but the truth of the matter is, plenty of rockers have aged gracefully and plenty of swing and pop performers from the prerock period look mighty silly still going through the motions.

description: Morning

title: Women Fasting to Lose Weight But Using Liquid Proteins Less
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) - Use of the liquid protein diet, implicated in several deaths, has dropped sharply since the Government warned against it, but more women are resorting to total fasting to lose weight, a national survey shows_

title: Carter Aides List Bills for Priority In Final Weeks of Congress Session
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 With the second session of'the 95th Congress threefourths finished and an Oct. 7 adjournment goal drawing near, the outlook is dubious for a number of President Carter's major legislative proposals.

title: Communists Attack Thai Base
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 (Reuters)  About 300 Communist guerrillas attacked a base in northeastern Thailand yesterday, killing five of its 35 soldiers and wounding 16 others, the police said today. The guerrillas lost 11 men before ther Thais drove them back with air support.

title: Caldwell May Head Ford
description: DETROIT, July 23 (AP) - Philip Caldwell, deputy chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, will replace the ousted Lee A. Iacocca as president of the nation's No. 2 automaker, The Detroit News reported today.

title: Public Workers Fear Tax Revolt May Increase Private Contracting
description: Public employee leaders fear that, in reaction to taxpayer revolts, local governments may turn more and more to contracting with private businesses for public services.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23  Fresh fighting broke out today between Syrian troops and Christian militiamen in a hillside suburb of this Lebanese capital not far from the presidential palace.

description: BENTON, Mo., July 23 (AP)  Two men have been arrested and charged with kidnapping nine workers they had hired in Chicago to pick tomatoes.

title: Dorothy Donovan, 59, Wife of Time Inc. Editor
description: Dorothy Hannon Donovan, the wife of Hedley Donovan, the editor in chief of all Time Inc. publications, died yesterday of cancer at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Sands Point. L.L. and in New York City.

title: Hinault Coasts to Victory
description: PARIS, July 23  Coasting the last few yards across the final finish line, Bernard Hinault of France won the Tour de France bicycle race here today by nearly four minutes after more than 108 hours of racing.

title: Issue and Debate Trade and Foreign Policy: Will Export Controls Influence Moscow?
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  President Carter's decision last week to cancel the sale of a computer and impose controls on the export of oil technology to the Soviet Union has touched off a controversy over whether trade curbs should be used as a diplomatic tool.

title: Retailers Find Early fall Buying
description: Although; the summer season is  barely half over, the nation's retailers are enjoying g widespread and early business in :f merchandise as consumers attempt to beat price increases expected later and also take advantage of new fashion'offerings.

title: Jackson Is Back but Uneasy
description: CHICAGO. July 23  A television cameraman, trying to create a path for his camera where there was none, repeatedly shoved a reporter standing next to Reggie Jackson and barked at him to stoop down.

title: Henry Longhurst, 69, Conveyed Literary Style in Golf Telecasts
description: LONDON, July 23 (AP)  Henry Longhurst, the British golf commentator and writer, has died at his Sussex home after a long battle against cancer, his family announced today. He was 69 years old.

title: Designers Who Use Fabric as the Key to Innovation
description: When the refurbished S'fari shop opens next month on the fourth floor of Bonwit Teller, it will highlight the work of innovative designers who have not yet entered the mainstream. It will be geared to women who are adventuroUs about tneir ciotnes, can't want to look like everybody else, and dare to be dif- ferent.

title: Tagamet: SmithKline's Aid For Earnin s
description: Tagamet, the SmithKline Corporation's new treatment for ulcers and related gastric disorders, is providing a sharp lift for the big pharmaceutical company's earnings. It also is being cited as an example of how a drug can make its way quickly through the Government's regulatory maze.

title: Connecticut and U.S. Differ on Newspaper Search
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  In the wake of the United States Supreme Court ruling that newspapers may be searched for evi- dence of a crime without warning, Federal and state officials in Connecticut have adopted strikingly different guide- lines governing such searches. .

title: State Senate to Act on Death Penalty and Penal Code
description: TRENTON, July 23  The State Senate will interupt its summer recess Thursday, and is expected to give final passage to a new state criminal code and to a bill that would restore the death penalty in New Jersey for firstdecree murder.

title: Consumer Board, in Study, Finds Abuse Among Technical Schools
description: Dozens of vocational schools have been accused by the New York State Consume! Protection Board of leaping greedily into a badly regulated flow of Federal and state tuition assistance, enrolling many unqualified students for hasty and expensive training for occupations in which there are few onenines.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: After Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. retired as chief of naval operations in 1979, he ran for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from Virginia and wrote a book about his experiences, On Watch. Last year, having decided not to run for public office again and anxious to enter the business world  but nothing to do with the militaryindustrial complex  he became associated with a small company, American Medical. Buildings, as president and chief executive officer.

title: Soviet Objects to U.S. Missile Plan, Complicating Talks on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Carter Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union had objected to an American plan for deploying mobile, intercontintential missiles. They said the move had injected a new complication into the Administration's search for a strategic arms agreement this year with Moscow.

title: Jean DuncanClark Tomlinson, ExTimes Bureau's Library Aide
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Jean DuncanClark Tomlinson, a former library assistant in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, died yesterday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., after a heart attack. She was 69 years old.

title: Burger Urges Congress to Act to Create judgeships
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called on Congress today to act on stalled legislation that would create new Federal judgeships, saying that the shortage of judicial manpower is now reaching crisis proportions.

title: Outdoors: Swordfishing the Gulf Stream
description: MIAMI

title: 2 Recruits' Deaths Leave Soldiers Shaken
description: FORT JACKSON, S.C., July 21  At noon, the helmeted recruits break for lunch in the pulsing sun. They sit in the shade of the Southern pines and oaks, crarIline their weanons and sinoine water.

title: CARTER FACES TESTS ON FOREIGN POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Carter Administration faces two critical tests of its foreign policy this week as it tries to persuade the Senate to vote for repeal of the embargo on military assistance to Turkey but to maintain economic sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: For Holding Firm on Rhodesia
description: American policy in Rhodesia has hung for a year on the slender hope that there would yet come a moment in that country's bloody civil war when all the parties would rather talk than fight. This week, Congressional critics of that approach will make a major effort to force a change. They are tragically misguid- ed their prescription is likely only to prolong the war and to assure that whatever black regime eventually comes to power will be militantly antiAmerican in a country from which whites have fled, its infrastructure destroyed.

title: Koch Vows Stern Policy on Dogs
description: The way to enforce the law requiring dog owners to clean up after their pets is to make examples of a number of pea. ple, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abitibi Paper Company, Toronto, has named C. Harry Rosier to the new position of vice chairman, and Robert C. Gimlin to president.

title: JERSEY TRAILER LIFE GETS A TRIPLE
description: FREEHOLD  A retired couple from Riverdale in the Bronx recently purchased the first triplewidth mobile home in New Jersey and possibly the first in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: TV: Networks to Stress News Over Entertainment
description: After the most turbulent television season in history, in which the administrations of NBC and CBS were toppled by their failures in the audienceratings contests, the three television networks. appear determined to take a new approach to the forthcoming season.

title: Borg Captures Swedish Open
description: BASTAAD, Sweden, July 23 (AP) Bjorn Borg, looking forward to a vacation, trounced Corrado Barazzutti of Italy, 61, 62, today and captured the Swedish open tennis championship for the secona time tiarazzutti won the event last year, but has had no luck against Borg in their meetings.

description: TONIGHT

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23  Arthur Knapp Jr., of the host club, who first sailed in Larchmont Race Week in 1920 and has not missed participating in many others since, won a prize yesterday which has eluded him since it was established more than 30 years ago.

title: Treasury Plans Wide Financing
description: About 750, people a day trooped down to the Fedetal Reserve Bank of New York duringlthe first four days of last week, mostly to buy United States Treasury, securities, and on two days, the Federal Reserve had to open its gymnasium on the 14th floor to handle the crowd.

title: Two Holding Hostages In Quebec Jail Give Up
description: SAINTE ANNE DES PLAINES, Quebec, July 23 (AP)  Two convicted murderers who held four hostages for more than 70 hours at Archambault Prison surrendered quietly today after the prison authorities agreed to transfer them to another jail.

description: Herbert A. Allen, president of Allen & Company, picked up the phone the other day and called a friend.

title: Chess Match Ends Its 1st Week In a Tie Karpov 0, Korchnoi 0
description: BAGUIO, The Philippines, July 23 The first week of the world-championship chess match between titleholder Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and his challenger, Viktor Korchnoi, a Russian defector, resulted in a standoff, with all three games drawn here in the Baguio Convention Center.

description: For periods as shown. ( N ) indicafes stock Is listed on the New York Stock E xchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

description: HERMANHelen beloved wife of Samuel M. on July 23, 1978. Services Tuesday 11 AM at the Westchester Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 West Broad St. Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Cairo Athletes to Shun 5 Nations
description: CAIRO. July 24  Egypt declared today that its athletes would no longer compete in sports events held in any of the rejectionist Arab countries after political animosities spilled over into the sports arena at the African Games in Algeria.

title: The Times in the Dock
description: The Times has been fined severely and our colleague, M. A. Farber, has been ordered to jail indefinitely for refusing to reveal to a New Jersey court the confidential sources of news reports. These punishments for contempt of court are so great as to intimidate the most prosperous publishers and most courageous reporters. And the costs of contesting these sen tences can be borne only by the most sturdy and affluent. So even vindication for The Times would not erase the damage that has been done to enterprising journalism. Anything less than vindication, we feel certain, will cripple every newspaper's ability to search out the news the community should prize the most.

title: Israel Says It Would Discuss Status Of West Bank and Gaza in 5 Years
description: JERUSALEM, July 24  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Parliament today that Israel would undertake to discuss the sovereignty of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in five years if the Arabs meanwhile accepted the Israeli peace plan granting the inhabitants partial autonomy.

title: Deaths
description: FLANAGAN  Deirdre, beloved daughter of Helen (nee McCaffrey) and Edward J., devoted sister of Ellen and Kevin, loving granddaughter of Eleanor McCaffrey, loving niece of Ann O'Dwyer (nee McCaffrey) and Terry O'Dwyer. Funeral Mass Thursday, St. Joseph's Church in Garden City, 10AM. Reposing at Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave, Garden City. Visiting 2 to 5, 7 to 9.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: THE OLD VILLAGE GREEN In today's secondweek program of the annual Washington Square Music Festival, the spotlight falls on Jose Contreras, the young conductor from the Dominican Republic who led Scott Jonlin's Treemonisha on Broadway; the soprano Susan Reed and the Richard Morse Mime Company. At 8 P.M. Mr. Contreras leads the Festival Orchestra in a program of Handel and Hayden, as Miss Reed renders the folk collection, Songs of the Avergne.

title: The NeW York Times/Jack Manning
description: ZOO SHEEP GET SUMMER SHEARING: Just as the heatwave broke a bit, the black sheep of the Central Park Zoo got sheared down to his summer crew cut as zoo personnel did summer sprucing up of animals and cages.

title: Dollar Falls Below Rate Of 200 Yen
description: TOKYO, July 24  The rate of exchange for the United States dollar plunged today below the psychologically significant barrier of 200 yen for the first time since World War II.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSAvon F. Jr. July 23, 1978 ol Mt. Kisco, New York. Husband of Helen. Father of James Donald, Pe. ter Marshall and Jet trey Thomas Adams. Brother of Katharine McCali and Margaret Gillespie. Services private.

title: Dr. Burns, Dean of Fun
description: THERE ARE certain things that one always says about comedians when they reach the age of 82 and are still working, but they do not easily come to mind when you meet George Burns, eating, frugally, at the Friars Club during a New York weekend that included seeing the premiere of movie he's in and discussions of another book he's writing.

title: Miss Hearst Terms Jailers No Better Than S.L.A.
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP)  Patricia Hearst says that she feels she is becoming a professional prisoner and wishes her jailers would not keep telling me this is such a nice place  like I'm lucky to be here.

title: ARTIST PRESENTS U.S. WITH NEW PAINTING
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Peter Max, the artist, illustrator and muralist, presented a painting of the Statue of Liberty to the nation on Independence Day to coincide with the placement of welcoming signs on the Canadian and Mexican borders.

title: Howser's Yankees Lose, 52
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24  Dick Howser, the 5foot9inch managerial bridge between Billy Martin,and Bob Lemon, began tonight's game with Kansas City the way Martin had begun more and more games in the final weeks of his Yankee tenure  without Reggie Jackson in the lineup.

title: News Summary
description: Israel will discuss sovereignty of the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip in five years if the Arabs in the interim accept an Israeli peace plan granting the Palestinians there partial autonomy, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Parliament. The chamber, voting 68 to 37, tacitly endorsed the slight policy shift. Mr. Dayan said that the undertaking did not permit the Government to reach a decision on sovereignty, but he added without explanation: This problem is also soluble. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Gas Rig Blast in Gulf Kills 2
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  An explosion at a natural gas drilling platform 120 miles out in the Gulf of Mexico killed two workers and injured another critically today, the United States Geological Survey reported. The agency said in a statement. that the accident occurred when workers on the Aminoil U.S.A. Inc. rig were running drill pipe back into well and the hydraulic clutch exploded. The statement said there was no fire after the explosion and that The dead and injured were not identified.

title: World News Briefs
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, July 24 (AP)  A West German Supreme Court judge issued an arrest warrant today for Kristina Katherina Berster, an alleged terrorist who was arrested when she crossed from Canada into the United States last week.

title: The New York Times/ Teresa Zabala
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Rosalynn Carter conceded today that her husband, the President, has an image problem. But she said she does not think that the public's perception of him is accurate.

title: Indiana Standard
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's sixth largest petroleum company, reported that secondquarter net income hid risen to $282.7 million, or $1.94 a share, from $277.3 million, or $1.89 a share, a year ago. Revenues rose to $4.1 billion from $3.5 billion. Foreignexchange translations added $3.2 million to the quarter's results. A year earlier there were losses of $4 million.

title: United Press International
description: SWIMMER'S SIGH OF RELIEF: George Kauffman, 45, leaving the water Keansburg after 12hour, 16mile swim from the Battery off Manhattan. Mr. Kauffman, who began marathon swimming five years ago, was motivated to make swim for charity by the death of his parents to cancer.

title: CITY PENSION FUNDS AGREE TO PURCHASE $1 BILLION IN BONDS
description: A labor consultant to the municipal employees pension funds said yesterday that the funds would make $1 billion in longterm loans to New York City if Congress enacted legislation that would let them.

title: Implants of Monkeys May Explain Success With Human Embryo
description: LONDON, July 24  A surprising discovery in the experimental transplantation of 35 monkey embryos, reported this month by a British researcher, may explain the success of,Drs. Robert G. Edwards and Patrick C. Steptoe in implanting a human embryo. That embryo has developed into a fetus with an audible heartbeat, and The baby is expected to be born in the next few weeks.

title: IRVING D. GOULD
description: Dr. Irving D. Gould, chief of the arthritis clinic at the former Beth David Hospital, died Sunday at his home in Lake Mahopac, N.Y. after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: 17 Food Places Called Violators Of New York City's Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 17 restaurants for violating the Health Code, and listed four that had corrected earlier violations. The restaurants listed are:

title: The New York Times/ Neal Boenz
description: Governor Carey yesterday abandoned his plan to save the MitchellLama middleincome housing program through subsidies to tenants and limited rent in creases. He said he would send the Legislature a new plan to rescue financially ailing projects individually and would insist that the Legislature enact the plan when it returns on Aug. 8.

title: Sylvan L. Joseph, Regional Head Of U.S. Price Office in 1940's, 80
description: Sylvan L. Joseph, who during World War II served as the regional director of the Office of Price Administration in New York City, died Friday at Doctors Hospital. Mr. Joseph, who lived in Manhattan, had observed his 80th birthday last Thursday..

title: Resignation Ends Stormy Union
description: In a turbulent life now in its 51st year, perhaps the most traumatic events experienced by Billy Martin have been two departures from the New York Yankees, 21 years apart.

title: Perseid Meteor Shower Scheduled for August
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  Sky watchers may be treated to some drama this month with the Perseid meteor shower, culminating on Aug. 12. If the sky is clear and there are few artificial light sources nearby, it should be a fine display.

title: NEW BOLIVIAN CHIEF INSTALS A CABINET
description: LAPAZ, Bolivia, July 24  Gen. Juan Pereda Asbun, who assumed the presidency of Bolivia on Friday with the support of military units, swore in a largely civilian Cabinet today. Meanwhile, opposition sources reported the arrest of at least 100 labor and student leaders and some human riehts activists.

title: Atlantic City Gambling Bringing Rise in Bus and Airline Services
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 24  The booming casino business is resulting in new longdistance bus and airline service to Atlantic City.

title: PHYSICIAN TESTIFIES ON TESTTUBE BABY
description: A gynecologist testified yesterday that there was less danger of chromosome abnormality in a laboratoryfertilized fetus than in a pregnancy conceived in conventional fashion.

title: Crimes by Women Found on Rise, With Fraud Favored Over. Violence
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Women are approaching equality with men in crime, but they favor embezzling, fraud or forgery over violence, a Governmentfinanced study reported today.

title: There Are Voices That Talk for Blacks in Crown Heights
description: These are beautiful homes, Fletcher Graves said as he drove slowly along President Street in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section, past rows of elegant and wellmaintained houses on the broad, treelined street. The black people who own them are very proud of them  they represent the essence of their life's struggle. Mr. Graves works for the Community Relations Service of the Denartment of Justice: and he is one of a hoit of communityrelations experts who are devoting a great deal of their time and attention thiSsummer to that tense neighborhood, attempting not only to avert violence but also to work out a lasting and peaceful relationship between the blacks and the Hasidic Jews, who are locked in a struggle for both turf and power.

title: Associated Press
description: The first long heat wave of the summer surrendered to an almost springlike day across the New York metropolitan area yesterday as the city canceled a waterpressure emergency brought on by gushing fire hydrants and the state began'investigating a Queens nursing home where airconditioning broke down and 18 elderly residents felled by heat had to be evacuated Sunday night.

title: In Sweep of Markets, 11 Violations Found Over Posting of Prices
description: Led by Commissioner Bruce C. Ratner, New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday conducted a unitpricing sweep of 23 supermarkets. Eleven were found to be violating the priceposting law, which requires food markets to list prices per quantity in specified product catagories so that consumers can compare value in different brands.

title: BUSINESS
description: New York pension funds will make $1 billion in longterm loans to the city if Congress enacts legislation enabling them to do so, said Jack Bigel, consultant to the funds. The loans would be a major element in moving the city's fiscal plan toward completion. [A1.]

title: U.S. Reviewing Relations
description: WASHINGTON, July 24(AP)  The State Department said today that the Administration would withhold judgment about the future of United States relations with Bolivia pending a clarification of the new Government's intentions.

title: This Year's Trade Deficit Expected to Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters) Government officials said today that the United States trade deficit this year would probably set another record but that the monthly deficits should become smaller from now on.

title: NEW YORK LEADER URGES MAIL STRIKE
description: The president of the New YorkMetro Area Postal Workers Union recommended to the union's 23,000 members last night that they strike in protest against the tentative contract, agreed upon last week with the United States Postal Service.

title: Air Force General Who Seized Power in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 24  Gen. Juan Pereda ASblin, who took over Bolivia's presidency on Friday with the support.of rightwing military men and civilians, is known among his friends as scalded milk because of a tendency for his temper to boil over. Many here believe that his temper may have led him to accept the advice of his militantly antiCommunist backers to seize the presidency after the Electoral Court annulled the results of the election July 9 that he claims to have won.

title: 3 More of Wilrnirigton 10 Freed
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 24 (UPI) Three more members of the Wilmington 10 will be paroled this week and the civil rights group's leader will be granted a study release, the North Carolina Paroles Commission announced today.

title: Networks Ditching Diction for Realism
description: THE network staff announcer, that august figure chosen for his ability to speak an English that was regionally untraceable and as anonymously dignified as a Federal courthouse, is now an endangered species. His unaccented accent set a standard of speech that was welcomed by national centralists but is now as unimportant as an unheard New York r in the egalitarian present.

title: The. Furor Surrounding Begin: He Fights Harder and Doesn't Budge
description: JERUSALEM, July 24  Thirteen months ago, when Menachem Begin assumed the post of Prime Minister, he urged his colleagues in Parliament as well as the Israeli people to grant the new Government moral credit at least for the tirst year of Its tenure.

title: Carter Orders White House Staff To Follow Drug Laws or Resign
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  President Carter, responding to reports of drug use by White House employees, warned his staff today to obey the drug laws even if they disagreed with them or to seek employment elsewhere.

title: Ammonia Leak in Norfolk
description: NORFOLK, Va., July 24 (AP) Several blocks of downtown Norfolk were evacuated and 10 firemen suffered minor injuries today when ammonia leaked from the refrigeration system at a brewery. A workman at the Champale Products Corporation also was taken to hospital. Homes and businesses near the the plant were evacuated for about an hour.

title: News Summary
description: Israel will discuss sovereignty of the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip in five years if the Arabs in the interim accept an Israeli peace plan granting the Palestinians there partial autonomy, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Parliament. The chamber, voting 68 to 37, tacitly endorsed the slight policy shift. Mr. Dayan said that the undertaking did not permit the Government to reach a decision on sovereignty, but he added without explanation: This problem is also soluble. [Page 1, Columns 12.)

title: JOB RULE IN QUEBEC AROUSES OPPOSITION
