description: OTTAWA, July 24  A new regulation in Quebec that reserves most construction jobs in the province for residents of Quebec has aroused opposition from Canadian federalists and thousands of workers in building trades who have been accustomed to crossing provincial borders for employment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in The Times Saturday incorrectly stated the first name of an assistant attorney general in New Mexico. She is Jill Z. Cooper.

title: CLASSACTION STATUS DENIED IN ATOM SUIT
description: NEWARK, July 24  The Army Department acknowledged today in Federal District Court that soldiers had been ordered to witness nuclear bomb tests, but the judge dismissed a motion that a $13 million damage suit by a former Army corporal from River Edge, N.J., who is suffering from cancer, be broadened to class action to include all alleged victims of such Army orders.

title: Helping Wives Adjust to the Corporate Move
description: DENVER  A new wrinkle is troubling corporateland. When Worldwide. Wicket says to a promising young executive, Joe, it's time for you to move to (Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Keokuk or Kotzebue), Joe is often saying no.

title: Computer. Sciences Gets Saudi Contract
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation announced that the Saudi Arabian Ministry of the Interior had selected to negotiate a contract to provide a nationwide computer information system.

title: DELAWARE DISTRICTS LOSE BUSING APPEAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24  The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upheld today a lower court's order that Wilmington, Del., and its Newcastle County suburbs alleviate segregation by busing students to one another's districts in September.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of gold futures dropped $2.50 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday as the demand for the metal surged in foreign markets. At the final pricefixing in London, for example, gold closed at $195.20 an ounce, up $3.45 on the day. The spot July Comex quote was $193.40, off $2.50.

title: Real Places
description: YONKERS WE'RE here at Carvel College with John and. Barbara O'Malley.who are graduating in uniforms white as the vanilla We are toasting them with pink champagne and listening to Tom Carvel's terrible voice.

title: White House to Submit MeasUre On Land Claims of Maine Indians
description: BOSTON, July 21 (UPI)  The White House says it will submit legislation this week to settle Maine Indian land claims against general landowners, but the bill will not include claims against the state and 19 large landowners.

title: Steel Output Climbs by 0.2%
description: Steel production for the week ended July 22 rose to 2.59 million tons, up 0.2 percent from the week before, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The industry produced 2.58 million tons the week before.

title: CLASSACTION STATUS DENIED IN ATOM SUIT
description: NEWARK, July 24  The Army Department acknowledged today in Federal District Court that soldiers had been ordered to witness nuclear bomb tests, but the judge dismissed a,motion that a $13 million damage suit by a former Army corporal from River Edge, N.J., who is suffering from cancer, be broadened to a class action to include all alleged victims of such Army orders.

title: Polaroid Stock Up By 3 Points
description: The Polaroid Corporation was the star of Wall Street yesterday as it moved ahead nearly 3 points on the strength of an enthusiastic brokeragehouse recommendation. The overall stock market, meanwhile, sagged under the weight of worries touched off by. renewed weakness of the American dollar in foreigncurrency dealings.

title: Shield Laws, Journalists and the Courts
description: In 1972, the United States Supreme Court, in a major press ruling, held that reporter who had witnessed a crime had the same obligation as anyone else to appear before a grand jury and answer questions. However, Justice Byron R. White, who wrote the majority opinion, reminded news organizations that they were free to ask their state legislatures to pass laws or to strengthen existing laws that would protect reporters from being required to testify or to hand over their notes in legal proceedings.

title: California Town Turns From Wine to Culture
description: LOS GATOS, Calif., July 24 (AP) -The Los Gatos Annual WineTasting Festival has gone on the wagon. This year it's the Los Gatos Culture Festival, and anyone caught even sipping Chablis will be fined $35.

title: Israel Says It Would Discuss Status Of West Bank and Gaza in 5 Years
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Patliament today that Israel would undertake to discuss the sovereignty of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in five years if the Arabs meanwhile accepted the Israeli peace plan granting the inhabitants partial autonomy.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Medical Consumerism (13)Captioned ABC News (R)

title: Text of Shield Law In Force in Jersey
description: Subject to rule 37, a person engaged on, engaged in, connected with, or employed by news media for the purpose of gathering, procuring, transmitting, compiling, editing or disseminating news for the general public or on whose behalf news is so gathered, procured, transmitted, compiled; edited or disseminated has a privilege to refuse to disclose, in any legal or quasilegal proceeding or before any investigative body, including, but not limited to any court, grand jury, petit jury, administrative agency, the Legislature or legislative committee or elsewhere a. The source, author, means, agency or person from or through whom any information was procured, obtained, supplied, furnished, gathered, transmitted, compiled, edited, disseminated or delivered; and b. Any news or information obtained in the course of pursuing his professional activities whether or not it is disseminated.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in The Times Saturday incorrectly stated the first name of an assistant attorney general in New Mexico. She is Jill Z. Cooper.

title: And Far From Paris, Donny and Marie's Show
description: Donny and Marie Osmond, the brotherandsister singing team almost always described as wholesome, came to New York yesterday to introduce their first fashion collection for young people. It contained no short skirts, bare midriffs or tight pants.

title: $2.1 Billion OilMining Venture Set For Canada
description: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta, July 24 (AP)  In just one Canadian province, there are an estimated 300 billion barrels of oil, enough to supply Canada for 500 years or the United States for 43 years. And experts now are developing ways to mine the precious fuel.

title: Committee on Attica Revolt Cites Rockefeller Role
description: BUFFALO, July 24 (AP)  A committee seeking the release of a prisoner convicted in the Attica prison uprising has charged that a grand jury investigation of the revolt was halted when former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller was in the process of becomingVice President.

title: 2 Medicaid Services Face Carey Veto as Too Costly
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he intended to veto a bill to restore Medicaid payments for podiatry and chiropractic services because it was too costly, even though the veto would foreclose the wider use of other optional Medicaid services he favors, such as occupational therapy, speech pathology and private nurses.

title: EARNINGS
description: ST. PAUL, July 24 (AP)  The Minneth:)ta Mining and Manufacturing Company reported today a 31.9 percent profit rise in the second quarter to a record $143.1 million, or $1.23 a share, from $108.5 million, or 94 cents a share, a year ago.

title: NEW YORK POSTMEN TAKING STRIKE VOTE
description: The executive council of the postal union for the New York area, whose members have shut down a bulk mail facility in Jersey City with a wildcat walkout, authorized a strike vote last night by the 26,000 union members in the metropolitan area.

title: 2 Dance Troupes From West to Visit
description: Two dance troupes from west of the Mississippi, the Albuquerque Dance Theater and the San Francisco Ballet, will appear in New York next month and later this year.

title: City Aids 89 Arts Groups
description: Grants totaling $141,026 have been given to 89 nonprofit cultural organizations throughout the city by the city's Cultural Affairs Department, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Economic Scene
description: PRICES rise because costs go up  so runs one classic explanation of inflation. But today's version has a new punch line. Extra payments have been added to the basic costs of labor and materials through regulations for environmental protection, worker safety and other social programs.

title: Cairo Building Collapse Kills 24
description: CAIRO, July 24 (Reuters)  Twentyfour people were killed and 15 injured today when an apartment building collapsed in Cairo's Sharabeya district. Interior Minister Mohammed Nabawi Ismail supervised rescue operations. Occupants of three neighboring buildings were evacuated whpn cracks appeared following the collapse.

title: Japan's Auto Output Soars
description: TOKYO, July 24 (UPI)  Japan's production of fourwheeled vehicles reached 840,706 units in June, the secondhighest level on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. The association said this brougnt output for the JanuaryJuno period of this year to 4,617,345 units, a record high for any sixmonth period and 12.2 percent higher than the corresponding period of last year. The previous monthly record of 898,567 was set in March this year.

title: Angola Said to Airlift Nkomo Men
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 24 (Reuters) Diplomatic souces here said today that Angolan civil aircraft had airlifted up to 2,000 Rhodesian nationalist guerrillas to Zambian bases from training camps in Angola over the last month. It was not clear whether the airlift was part of freth military buildup by guerrillas loyal to Joshua Nkomo, which is based in Zambia.

title: $1 Billion Food Complex Is Planned for Raritan Arsenal Site in Jersey
description: A newly formed realestate management corporation disclosed plans yesterday to build a $1 billion international fooddistribution center on the site of the old Raritan Arsenal in Edison, N.J.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: THERE was really nothing new in the figures Treasury Secretary Joseph W. Barr was citing about millionaires who do not pay taxes. Among a host of liberal tax reformers, Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois had focused repeatedly on this exception to tax equity. It was January 1969, and the public was showing resentment about higher taxes particularly a surtax to raise money for expenses of the Vietnam War.

title: Setting the Rules for Jai Alai
description: While New Jersey is still learning to deal with casino gambling in Atlantic City, proposals are being made to introduce jai alai into the slat e. In November. volets will decide, Dy means of a constitutional amendment, whether to allow jai alai frontons to start operating  along with the parimutuel betting that has become a part of the fastmoving games. Some communities hope for muchneeded revenue from the Mate'cut of the fronton action. But even with the prospect of helping failing resorts and ailing cities, the proposal flawed.

title: United Press International
description: SWIMMER'S SIGH OF RELIEF: George Kauffman, 45, leaving the water at Keansburg, N.J., after 12hour, 16mile swim from the Battery off Manhattan. Mr. Kauffman, who began marathon swimming five years ago, was motivated to make swim for charity by the death of his parents to cancer.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: Governor Carey yesterday abandoned his plan to save the MitchellLama middleincome housing program through subsidies to tenants and limited rent increases. He said he would send the Legislature a new plan to rescue financially ailing projects individually and would insist that the Legislature enact the plan when it returns on Aug. 8.

title: Another Night at The Opera
description: As usual, fiery temperaments, were flaring among members of the New York Yankees Opera Company. The decision of the scrappy little maestro, Billy Martin, to present La Traviata that night had irritated many of the company's stars, most of whom preferred to do Wagnerian opera because it kept them on stage longer than the Italian works.

title: Implants of Monkeys May Explain Success With Human Embryo
description: LONDON, July 24  A surprising dis covery in the experimental transplantation of 35 monkey embryos, reported this month by a British researcher, may explain the success of Drs. Robert G. Edwards and Patrick C. Steptoe in implanting a human embryo. That embryo has developed into a fetus with an audible heartbeat, and the baby is expected to be born in the next few weeks.

title: Letter: On Cyprus
description: To the Editor:

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Running counter to the general upward sweep in interest rates this month, yields on threemonth Treasury bills dropped sharply yesterday in a decline that was largely an indirect result of the dollar's weakness in currency trading.

title: Nyiregyhazi Recordings To Be Distributed by CBS
description: Recordings by the Hungarianborn pianist Erwin Nyiregyhazi will be distributed on a commercial basis by CBS Records under the terms of a contract signed with the International Piano Archives.

title: Another Pulp Plant Struck
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 24 (UPI) Another West Coast pulp and paper mill was struck today, bringing to 7,000 the number of workers idled at 19 plants. Pickets from the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers appeated at A.M. at the Newberg plant of the Publishers Paper Company. Its other Oregon was struck last Friday.

title: Philip Morris Names Three to Top Posts
description: A series of promotions, effective Nov. 1, to the three senior management positions at Philip Morris Inc. were announced yesterday by the tobacco (Marlboro, Benson and Hedges, Virginia Slims, Parliament), beer (Miller) and softdrink (7Up) company.

title: Notes on People
description: SOUTH DAKOTA'S new Governor, Harvey Woliman, was sworn in yesterday and said he was determined to tackle several issues even though he'll have only six months in office. Mr. Woll man, who was Lieutenant Governor, automatically succeeded Richard F. Knien. who was to be sworn in today at the White House as Ambassador to Singapore. Mr. Wollman must leave office Jan. 6, as he narrowly lost the Democratic primary for Governor last month and is prevented by state law from seeking the office as an independent. I realize my input will be very, very limited, Mr. Wollman,said on taking office. My goal is to at least establish some direction on issues now left dangling and hope my successor finds my initiative was good enough to build on. He promised to concentrate on the state's water resources, which pose one of its most serious problems.

title: Egyptian Officials Are Awaiting Next Offer by Israelis
description: CAIRO, July 24  Egypt said today that it was waiting.for a sign,of Israeli good faith before agreeing to new talks.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICTCHRISTINA GIVENS. 1635 E. 174 St, the Bronx. Liabil ities. $5,520: assets. none.

title: Theater: The Big Apple Circus
description: IN one sunny tent the Big Apple Circus of New York demonstrates the theater's own fortunate economy of scale.

title: Associated Press
description: COLLISION IN LEFT: Bill Russell and Dusty Baker of the Dodgers slamming into each other in the first inning of Sunday's game with the Cardinals at Los Angeles. Baker held on to the soft fly hit by Gary Templeton for the out, but both players were sufficiently shaken up to be removed from the contest. St. Louis won, 20.

title: CITY PENSION FUNDS AGREE TO PURCHASE $1 BILLION IN BONDS
description: A labor consultant to the municipal employees pension funds said yesterday that the funds would make $1 billion in longterm loans to New York City if Congress enacted legislation that would let them.

title: France Lifts Trade Surplus
description: PARIS, July 24 (Reuters)  France increased its trade surplus to the equivalent of about $100 million last month from $35 million in May, the Foreign Trade Ministry said today. Exports fell to $6.4 billion in June from $6.5 billion in Max, while June imports cost $6.3 billion, frsaid.

title: Gold Price Soars Abroad
description: LONDON, July 24 (AP)  The price of gold soared today as the dollar plunged on world money markets.

title: Some Towns Are Finding Ways Of Recycling Themselves
description: The sun is shining on Iron River, Mich. And if the residents of the former mining town have their way, the sun's rays may play a role in turning the community's failing economy around. warm two years, me town or MOO people plans to grow much of its own produce, even in wihter, when 30below days are frequent in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. With 25 acres of communal gardens for use in the summer and a huge solar greenhouse for yearround use, Iron River hopes to become a model for the Middle West, fighting inflation and unemployment with an oldfashioned, communal approach that rewards selfsufficiency and inventiveness.

title: Bhutto's Daughter One of Staunchest Supporters at Appeal Hearing
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 29One of the most interested. spectators these days at the Supreme Court hearing on the murder conspiracy charge against former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto is a 25yearold Harvard graduatehis daughter, Benazir.

title: Chilean leaders after the 1973 takeover were, from left, Gen. Cesar Mendoza, Gen. Gustavo Leigh, Gen. Augusto Pinochet and Adm. Jose Merino
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. July 24 (AP)  The Chilean military junta today ousted member who had urged a speedier return to civilian rule. It was the first change in the junta since the rightwing generals overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens five years ago.

title: Christian Book Sales Boom at Con vention
description: DENVER The Christian Booksellers Association, which is doing landoffice business these days, recently wound up a fourday convention here that showed that the thriving industry would probably set more records next year. Industry officials called the meeting the best convention, in terms of sales, that they have had.

title: F.D.U. Names Joganow Coach
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J. July 24  Viktor Joganow was named the women's basketball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University today, replacing Pat Waite. In three years as coach at Passaic Valley High School, the 29yearold Joganow compiled a 6313 wonlost record.

title: Advertising
description: AS fate would have it, Harvey Dreyer, president of Chalek & Dreyer, who helped introduce Tic Tac, the Italian minimint candy, to America, is now prepared to do the same for Jintan Mints, a Japanese minimint. Tai Morishita, chairman of Morishita Jintan, the manufacturer. was in town yesterday to give the campaign his considerable support. He is, you see, a member of his country's Parliament, as well as head of a leading manufacturing company in the pharmaceutical and confections business.

title: Bombs Explode in 2 Greek Cities
description: ATHENS, July 24 (AP)  Twelve time bombs exploded today in Athens and Piraeus, the adjacent port city, on the fourth anniversary of the collapse of the Greek military dictatorship. The police said no one was hurt and there was no significant damage. They said they did not know who had planted the bombs...

title: Democrats in the West Express Concern at Republicans' Ascent
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 24 (AP)Western Democrats are worried about the ascent of the Republican Party in their region and say they need more money from the party and responsiveness from the White House to stop it.

title: The Talk of Stockholm
description: STOCKHOLM A FOREIGNER newly arrived in Sweden sometimes feels as if he has intruded upon a society that considers itself a thing apart from the rest of the world.

title: Bratini
description: SCHWARTZMiltonThe Board of Directors of the Jewish Reconstructionist Foundation and of the Reconstructionist Federation of Congregalions & Fellowships, mourn the passing of the beloved father of Carole Kessner, secretary of. the Recoilstructionist Federation. To her and the bereaved family we. extend our sincere condolences.

title: Police Guard Is Taken Off Horne Of Crown Heights Hasidic Rabbi
description: A police patrol car that had been stationed since April in front of the Crown Heights home of Rabbi Menachem Schneerson, leader of the worldwide Lubavitcher Hasidic movement, was removed yesterday despite the opposition of Hasidic leaders. Instead, a car will monitor 61 houses of worship in the troubled Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: West Bank Calm Hides Simmerin Resentment of Israel
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccupied West Bank  The graying Palestinian peasant selfconsciously smoothed her embroidered black dress with workroughened hands, apologized for her lack of education and in simple Arabic talked about her 28yearold son, held for five months in a Ramallah jail.

title: South Africa Threatening to Oppose Namibia Accord
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 South Africa, accusing Western negotiators of bad faith, is threatening to oppose the accord reached last week that would end the guerrilla war in SouthWest Africa and would give the territory independence as the black nation of Namibia.

title: The New York Times / Don Hogan Charles
description: CLEVELAND  The change started coming to Ohio City just as Mary and John Trisco were about to give up.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WKCR. Cello Concerto, Herbert; Plano Concertos Nos. and 2; Sonata Tragica, Macdowell.

title: Martin Resigns
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24  Billy Martin, a tempestuous street fighter who had been dismissed from three previous major league managerial jobs, tearfully resigned today from the one managerial job that he always yearned for the one with the Yankees.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24 (Reuters)  The Royal Dutch Shell Group has canceled a $1.2 billion agreement it had signed with the Indonesian Government in 1975 for the exploitation of coal deposits in south Sumatra, Adnan Kusuma, the director of the state coal company, PN Tambang Batubara, reported today.

title: Deaths
description: MERKUSPeter J., Jr. In Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, on July 22nd, 1978, beloved husband of the late Mary R. Merkus, devoted father of Peter Roe Merkus, and Pamela M. Tighe. Retired VicePresident, Manufacturing, Shell Oil Company. Services to be held MittlebergGerber Funeral Home, 23 West Lockwood, Webster Grove, Missouri. In lieu of flowers, contributions maybe made to The American Cancer Society, N.Y., N.Y.

title: Law Store on Coast Offers LowCost Aid In Prepared Packages
description: LOS ANGELES (Reuters)  Californians can now buy the law in packets.

title: Psychiatrists Challenge Charges In Tranquilizer Case in Rockland
description: The Rockland County Medical Examiner, who earlier this month charged that heavy doses of tranquilizers had contributed to patient deaths at two of the state's largest mental institutions, was attacked yesterday by psychiatrists and institution personnnel who challenged his findings.

title: Government of Britain Loses Vote in Commons
description: LONDON, Tuesday, July 25, (Reuters) The Labor Government suffered a serious defeat in Parliament early today in the first of three important votes this week.

title: F.D.A. Would Regulate Medical Device Makers
description: WASHINGTON. July 24 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration, in an effort to prevent recalls, has issued tentative regulations on the manufacture of medical devices, it was announced today.

title: Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART: Chamber music. Avery Fisher Hall, Untoln Center, 8.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 24  All the indications are that the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which began here three days ago and continue through Sunday, will be the world's biggestever tournament.

title: Florida Power: Mature Growth
description: MIAMI  The Florida Power and Light Company used to be a growth utility. Typically, sales jumped 13 percent a year. So did earnings.

title: Billy Martin's Battlefields
description: Billy Martin's heroes in a turbulent light are Casey Stengel, who preceded him as a manager and an exmanager of the New York Yankees, and a halfdozen generals in the Civil War, starting with U.S. Grant and Philip Sheridan, who preceded him as tenants of the nation's battlefields.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: The presence of foreign banks in the United States has increased dramatically in recent years. In the last few months alone, three major banks Marine Midland, the National Bank of North America and Union Bancorp  have become tne objects of toreign takeover attempts. One result of such activities is legislation, pending in Congress, designed to strengthen the power of regulatory authorities over foreign banking interests here.

title: Rose Hits in 37th Game in Row, Tying Mark, as Reds Beat Mets
description: Sports fans who love to say they were there when something important happened got their wish at Shea Stadium last night, thanks to Pete Rose.

title: Exxon Reports 21.7% Earnings Rise
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum enterprise, reported yesterday a 21.7 percent jump in secondquarter net income.

title: 40 Drown in Indian Flood
description: NEW DELHI, July 24 (Reuters)Forty people drowned today when a boat crossing the floodswollen Rapti River capsized near the north Indian district of Deoria in the state of Uttar Pradesh, the news agency Press Trust of India reported.

title: Bennett's Meetings With Iacocca
description: Why was the advice of George F. Bennett sought by Lee A. Iacocca last month when the president of the Ford Motor Company found himself falling into disfavor with Henry Ford 2d, the chairman and chief executive officer?

title: Alvin Ailey Dance Troupe Will Give Six Revivals
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will celebrate its 20th anniversary with six revivals during its season at City Center, from Nov. 29 through Dec. 17. Dances scheduled are Flowers, Kinetic Molpai, The Beloved, Congo Tango Palace, Toccata and Reflections in D.

title: Gambling on China
description: If playing the Chinese card were a kind of parlor game played in an academic seminar or in a military simulation, one could dismiss it as an innocuous pastime that may sharpen the minds of political and military experts but would have no relevance for actual policies. If playing the Chinese card becomes, at the very least implicitly, the official policy of the United States, one must subject its assumptions, advantages, and risks to critical scrutiny.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CONCORDIA LAGO (Condordia I. Tenerife Aug.2. Las Palmas 3,Barcelona 8. Genoa 9, Naples I I, Limassol 15. Beirut 16, Lattakia 17 and Piraeus 19; sails from Port Newark, N. J.

title: Lemon Is Classified As a Disciplinarian
description: Bob Lemon, who was named manager of the Yankees yesterday in the wake of Billy Martin's resignation, was classified as a disciplinarian yesterday by the man who counts most George Steinbrenner, the team's owner.

title: Government Moves to Cut Links Of Businesses to Biased Clubs
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs is expected to propose rules forbidding companies that do business with the GoverOment to pay for their employees' membership in clubs that discriminate on the basis of sex, race or relielon.

title: Abourezk In Filibuster On Gas Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, began a filibuster,today against a bill that would remove price controls from natural gas and thus further imperiled President Carter's already troubled energy legislation.

title: The Melting Pot's Mexican Roots
description: WASHINGTONFor two years have been living with people on both sides of the Mexican border investigating the illegal immigrants who are entering this country.

title: Washington Subways Run Again, But Bus Drivers Are Still on Strike
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  There was the beginning of a break today in the weather and in the wildcat public transit strike that has plagued the capital for the last five days.

title: TV: America Alive Makes Debut on NBC
description: NBC's new weekday series America Alive made its debut at high noon yesterday and, to judge from the first installment, it appears to be a light souffl of entertainment entirely suited to the sultry weather.

title: Some Towns Are Finding Ways Of Recycling Themselves
description: The sun is shining on Iron River, Mich. And if the residents of the former mining town have their way, the sun's rays may play a role in turning the community's failing economy around.

title: Jersey Judge Jails Times Reporter For Refusal to Yield Notes, in Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 24  A reporter for The New York Times was sent to jail today and the Times Company was heavily fined after both were convicted of contempt of court for refusing to obey a court order to turn over the reporter's confidential notes for possible use in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich.

title: Mahoney Named Manhattan Coach
description: Brian Mahoney, an assistant basketball coach at St. John's and a former professional basketball player, has been named head coach at Manhattan College. The announcement was made yesterday by Manhattan's athletic director, Ken Norton. No terms were disclosed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Repeal of the mandatory binding arbitration provision of the state's Taylor Law as it applies to police departments has been recommended by officials of the Town of Hempstead in Nassau County, L.I., and five of its large incorporated villages.

title: Western Talks on Hijacking Curb Will Be Held in Bonn Next Week
description: BONN, July 24 (Reuters)  An international meeting to. design measures to combat aerial hijacking will take place here on Aug. 1 and 2, the West German Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Statements by Farber and The New York Times
description: I would like to explain to the Court, and to the public, why I am refusing to surrender my reporter's file on the case of Dr. Mario E. JaScaleyich. As serious as this matter is, and as highly technical as are the legal arguments, my position is not all that complicated. Following are the texts of statements issued today by M. A. Farber of The New York Times, by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger,. the publisher, and by Seymour Topping, the managing. editor,- on the New Jersey contemptofcourt conviction of The Times and Mr. Farber: What is at issue here is not Dr. Jascalevich's right to a fair trial ; he has access to the same people that I interviewed, and more. Nor is the issue my right to place myself above or outside the law. I have no such right, and seek none. The issue, I believe, is the right of the public to be informed through its press, in accordance with the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.

title: Fragments Said to Be Easter Island Statues Eyes
description: A Chilean museum official, analyzing bits of old stone and coral found recently on Easter Island, which belongs to Chile, has concluded that the centuriesold stone figures of beetlebrewed human beings that dot the island originally had huge inlaid eyes with red pupils, a New York museum official reported yesterday.

title: Rhodesian Forces and Guerrillas Clash in 2 Salisbury Townships
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 24 (Reuters)  Black nationalists. and security forces have fought gun battles in the vicinity of this capital city for the first time in six years of guerrilla warfare, the police said today.

title: State Court Backs Water Company on Assessment
description: TRENTON, July 24  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 4 to 3 today that land at the bottom of a reservoir in Old Tappan should be assessed at the original purchase price of $670 an acre instead of the present market value, which could fall between $2,200 and $2,800.

title: 2 Paperworker Officials Enter NotGuilty Pleas
description: JosephIP. Tonelli, the president of the 300,000member United Paperworkers International Union, and Henry Segal, the union's secretarytreasurer, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges of racketeering and embezzling $360,000 in union funds.

title: Brushing Up the Urban Landscape on West 48th Street
description: West 48th Street, with its burnedout houses and burntout street people, seems an unlikely place to find colorful doorways, gated patios and windows graced with hanging plants. Yet there they are, standing out incongruously on five adjacent buildings on the rubblestrewn block between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

title: Exceller Triumphs In Rich Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) Exceller, the solid favorite, capped a brilliant season today with a comeback victory in the $164,100 Sunset Handicap on the final day of Hollywood Park's meeting.

title: Market Place
description: MALLINCKRODT CHEMICAL, whose shares sold at 37 times earnings in 1973, has been an institutional favorite for much of the last decade. The company's popularity stems from its lead. ership in such specialty chemicals as barium sulphate  the socalled atomic cocktail used with Xrays to discover ulcers  acetaminophen, the raw material for the nonaspirin painkiller, Tylenol, and a wide variety of other drugrelated chemicals.

title: Variable Mortgage Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates federally chartered Savings and :loan associations, today approved a proposal that would enable these institutions to offer four types of variablerate mortgage.

title: 2 East Germans Climb Over Wall In the Disguise of Border Guards
description: WEST BERLIN, July 24 (Reuters)Two East German medical students have fled to the West by climbing over the Berlin wall disguised as border guards, the West Berlin government said today.

title: Slow Growth Pushed in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, July 24  West Germany made clear today that it expected other European countries joining its proposed European currency stabilization plan to adopt conservatively inclined policies that would tend to lower economic growth, as well as inflation.

title: Halting The System
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter denied, earlier this year, recommendation from the International Trade Commission for tariff relief for the steelfastener industry, only about 20,000 workers in six states, most of them in Ohio, would have been direedy affected.

title: Andre Previn Cancels Boston Symphony Date
description: Andre Previn, suddenly indisposed in England, will not appear with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood Friday and Saturday, a spokesman for the Symphony said.

title: 2 Brothers Accused Of Shooting Cleric
description: Two brothers were being held in lieu of $100,000 and $50,000 bail after being charged in the shooting and robbing of a Roman Catholic brother delivering Bingo receipts in Hammonton.

title: Spending Dollars in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 24  The middleaged American woman was wandering around the streets of central Tokyo near the Karasumori shrine carrying a heavy laundry bag and looking puzzled.

title: Jersey Judge Jails Times Reporter For Refusal to Yield Notes in Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 24  A reporter for The New York Times was sent to jail today and the Times Company was heavily fined after both were convicted of contempt of court for refusing to obey a court order to turn over the reporter's confidential notes for possible use in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich.

title: The New York Times/ Marilynn K. Yee
description: On a field where he was once booed as a bully, Pete Rose basked in a threeminute standing ovation last night in Shea Stadium when he tied the National League record by hitting in his 37th straight game.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A cloud band across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys is shifting eastward with showers moving towards the Atlantic States. Convective clouds producing powerful thunder, storms are in and along the Gulf of Mexico. A weak weather disturbance over the Southwest shows up as spiraling clouds. Another unsettled weather system seems headed into the upper MidWest.

title: Cases Against Reporters Increase
description: Contemptofcourt proceedings against journalists refusing to disclose their sources are a fairly new phenomenon that multiplied in the 1970's despite laws adopted in many states to protect a reporter's confidential information.

title: Exxon to Drill Deeper In Baltimore Canyon
description: HOUSTON, July 24  In a development read in some quarters as a discouraging sign for oil prospects in the Atlantic, the Exxon Company U.S.A. said today that it was drilling beyond an original target depth of 14,000 feet at its first exploratory well off the New Jersey coast.

title: Firestone Tests Showed Tire Danger, Paper Says
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 24 (AP)  The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company discovered serious problems with some of its steelbelted radial tires in tests three years ago but did not report the findings to the Government, according to a published report.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: EVEN from the author of such fine first novel as Her Mothers, A Weave of Women is an astonishment. E.M. Broner seeks nothing less than to achieve, in a kind of epic poem, a recapitulation of the rhythms of female consciousness.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City. (Television  Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: 29 in Gaza Held on Sabotage
description: TEL AVIV, July 24 (Reuters)  Israeli security forces have arrested 29 Arabs in the Gaza Strip suspected of belonging to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, an announcement today said. The suspects were said to have planned sabotage activity in Israel and the occupied territories.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A.M. and P.M.

title: The New York Times
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 24  The judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich refused today to grant delay sought by the defense, which said that to proceed it must,have documents from the New York Times reporter who went to jail today rather than turn over those documents.

title: United Press International
description: THUNDERSTORM'S AFTERMATH: A barn roof and a porch swing littered the lawn of a farm in Brady's Bend, Pa., after a thunderstorm and severe winds ripped through the Upper Allegheny River Valley yesterday.

title: U.S. Cites Mexican Fishing Boat
description: SAN DIEGO, July 24 (UPI)  The United States Coast Guard detained Mexican fishing boat for almost 10 hours and then released it after citing it for fishing in American waters. The boat was stopped Saturday about a halfmile north of the United StatesMexican border and inside the 200mile territorial limit.

title: Scottish Labor Dispute Ties Up 3 of 4 British Polaris Submarines
description: LONDON, July 24  Dock workers seeking pay increases have immobilized three of Britain's four Polaris submarines.

title: U.S. Says Sing Sing Freed Narcotics Dealer by. Mistake
description: A major narcotics dealer serving a 12 year sentence walked out of prison and escaped as a result of an administrative error at the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., according to a Federal complaint disclosed yesterday.

title: Treasury Bills
description: (000 omitted in Toner figures)

title: Rangers Murdoch Banned
description: Don Murdoch, the 21yearold right wing for the New York Rangers, has been suspended for at least 90 games next season by the National Hockey League and fined $500.

title: Anticrime Bill Signed Without Any Fanfare
description: Governor Carey's office announced today that Mr. Carey had signed the omnibus anticrime bill stiffening penalties for adults convicted of violent crimes, limiting pleabargaining and allowing juveniles accused of certain types of violent crimes to be tried in the adult criminalcourt system.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Brushing Up the Urban Landscape on West 48th Street
description: West 48th Street, with its burnedout houses and burntout street people, seems an unlikely place to find colorful doorways, gated patios and windows graced with hanging plants. Yet there they are, standing out incongruously on five adjacent buildings on the rubblestrewn block between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, July 24 (AP)  The Wimbledon champion, Martina Navratilova, denied she was AWOL on yesterday from the Boston Lobsters of World Team Tennis and insisted that she is injured.

title: Martin Resigns
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24  Billy Martin, a tempestuous street fighter who. had been dismissed from three previous major league managerial jobs, tearfully resigned today from the one managerial job that he always yearned for  the one with the Yankees.

title: Choreography Festival Infused With Energy
description: ALL that it takes to make a festival is festivity. That point was proved Sunday night by the dancers who held what they called A Choreographers Festival at Columbia University Teachers College. The events took place on a cramped, little stage no bigger than a postage stamp. Yet the dancers energy made the evening festive.

title: Carter Orders White House Staff To Follow Drug Laws or Resign
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  President Carter, responding to reports of drug use by White House employees, warned his staff today to obey the drug laws even if they disagreed with them or to seek employment elsewhere.

title: Atlantic Richfield
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, which ranks among the eight largest domestic oil companies, reported a 10.3 percent rise in secondquarter net income to a record $210.9 million, or $1.73 a share, from $191.2 million, or $1.57 share, in the 1977 quarter.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Henry Charts Course for Pacific
description: Charles J. Henry, who last week was named president of the Pacific Stock Exchange by a unanimous vote of the board of governors, knows precisely what his first priority will be in the months ahead.

title: No Need for a Nuclear Carrier
description: The Administration's effort to head off construction of a fifth nuclear supercarrier, costing $2.9 billion, has been rebuffed so far in Congress. After the House voted full speed ahead, the Senate passed a socalled compromise resolution calling for a halt in bigcarrier construction  after just one more. The resolution has limited value, for any future Congress is free to insist on still more of the monster ships. So the extravagance has been authorized but it may still be denied an appropriation and it ought to be.

title: Associated Press
description: A fireman hosing down the smoldering wreckage of the prison laundry at Pontiac, Ill., State Penitentiary after weekend riot that left three guards dead.

title: Actor Has a Close Call During Movie Robbery
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 (Reuters) A filmmaking venture by five youths nearly ended in tragedy last night when Salt LakeCity police officers, thinking a staged armed robbery was the real thing, fired a shot at one of them. The bullet narrowly missed.

title: Frontiers of Science
description: SOMEWHERE on the face of the earth, perhaps in a Brazilian jungle or on a Cambodian mountainside, or maybe by the banks of the Congo River, a nondescript little plant may be growing, synthesizing in its leaves a substance that can cure cancer or prevent heart attacks.

title: Accord Ends Strike Threat at 4 State Mental Hospitals
description: TRENTON, July 24  A strike by employees that had been threatened for, tomorrow at four state psychiatric hospitals was called off tonight.

title: TRW Profit at Record
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP)  TRW Inc., a maker of automotive parts, such as valves, pistons and cylinder sleeves and aircraft parts, such as fuel pumps and jet propulsion equipment, reported a 10.4 percent rise in secondquarter profits to a record $46.9 million, or $1.48 a share, from $42.5 million, or $1.33 a share, in the yearearlier period. Sales rose to $956.3 million from $825.6 million in the 1977 period. Ruben F. Mettler, chairman of the bpard, said the results came after losses of $4.9 million in the second quarter related to the closing of a wire and cable plant. He said the closing would improve profits for the rest of the year and result in a substantial yeartoyear profit improvement in 1979.

title: British Oil Tax at Issue
description: LONDON, July 24  A dispute over taxation of North Sea oil profits came to light here today amid unconfirmed reports that the British Government intends to raise the basic rate of its petroleum revenue tax from the present 45 percent to 60 percent.

title: !St. Louis Sheriff, Though Convicted, Stays in Race
description: ST. LOUIS, July 21 Despite a conviction on Federal charges of corruption in office and income tax evasion, Civil Sheriff Benjamin L. Goins has refused to resign or to scuttle his bid to unseat Representative William Clay in Missouri's Democratic primary election Au2.8. ine 51yearold sheriff said he would I not give in to mounting,pressure for his resignation because I feel that I am innocent and the verdict is under appeal. The longtime political nemesis of Representative Clay said he believed that the Federal indictment leading to his conviction was politically.motivated, although he refused to say by whom and for what purpose.

title: Deaths
description: CAMPBELLNicholas J., Jr. The Administration, Faculty and Staff of Elizabeth Scion College mourn the loss of our esteemed Trustee, and beloved friend and expresses deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Associated Press
description: The first long heat wave of the summer surrendered to an almost springlike day across the New York metropolitan area yesterday, and the state began investigating a Queens nursing home where airconditioning broke down and 18 elderly residents felled by heat had to be evacuated Sunday night.

title: 2 Union Aides Charge Conrail Mismanagement
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Spokesmen for two unions told a Congressional committee today that poor management at Conrail was costing taxpayeis millions of dollars a year in additional subsidies for the railroad.

title: Lafayette To Be Sold
description: The Lafayette Radio Electronics Corporation, one of the nations's larg est retailers and wholesalers of electronic products, announced yesterday that it planned to sell its business for $16 million in cash to a corporation being formed by Gibbons, Green & Rice Ltd., a New York investmentbanking house.

title: ATLANTIC CITY PLAN FOR CASINO OPPOSED
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 29  Mayor Joseph Lazarow said today that unless suitable housing could be found for the people who would be displaced  and I cannot see where that could be  he would lead opposition to two recently announced casino projects in Chelsea, the downtown area of the resort.

title: Shearson's Profits Surge
description: Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage and investment banking firms, announced yesterday that its profits for the foruth fiscal quarter ended June 30 more than tripled to a record $6'.45 million, or $1.44 a share, from $1.88 million, or 52 cents a share, in the similqr period a year earlier.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) L Artificial sweeteners in moderate amounts  those taken bymost of the'people who use them  do not increase the risk of bladder cancer, a major study indicates.

title: Avon Products Up 28.8%
description: Avon Products, the doortodoor marketer of household products, reported a 28.8 percent profit rise for the second quarter to $48.8 million, or 84 cents a share, from $37.9 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed to $462.18 million from $360.42 million. David W. Mitchell, the company chairman, attributed the gain to an increase in the sales force.

title: United Press International
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24  Thirteen months ago Phil Rizzuto was playing golf with Billy Martin in Detroit while the manager's fate was being decided at the Pontchartrain Hotel. That time Martin survived.

title: Gerulaitis, in Top Form, Sparks Apples' 2725 Victory Over Nets
description: Vitas Gerulaitis overwhemed two New Orleans Nets and led the New York Apples to a 2725 overtime victory last night at the Felt Forum.

title: Paris Couture Opens With Bow to the Past
description: PARIS, July 24  There's a brilliant moment midway in the Christian Dior fall couture show when a mannequin emerges in a short red dress and black suede gloves. She has a gold bracelet over one of her gloves and she carries her hands extended in a decadesold mannequin pose. Her pinky is not quite extended, but it might as well be.

title: Consultant in the Overmyer Case Pleads Guilty to Charge of Fraud
description: A business consultant pleaded guilty yesterday to bankruptcy fraud involving $10,000 in the case of the D. H. Overmyer Company, whose owner has complained that the company was looted of millions of dollars.

title: The New York Times/George Tames
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House of Representatives gave final passage today to the compromise bill providing New York City with $1.65 billion in Federal loan guarantees. The vote was 244 to 157.

title: 2 OF WILMINGTON 10 GO FREE ON PAROLE
description: WILMINGTON, N.C., July 25 (UPI) Two of the Wilmington 10 defendants, James McKoy and Willie Earl yereen, were paroled today after two and a,half years behind bars and asserted their innocence, vowing to work for the freedom of the members of the group still in prison.

title: Report by a Missouri Man Suggests Plotters Sought Murder of Dr. King
description: ST. LOUIS, July 25  A 46yearold man here has told the House assassintion committee that in late 1966 or early 1967 he turned down an offer of $50,000 to arrange the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Economic Rein Urged On the U.S.
description: PARIS, July 25  President Carter should accept a sharp reduction in economic growth in the United States next year and a possible rise in unemployment as necessary to reduce inflation and strengthen the weakened dollar, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report on the American economy that was released today.

title: Gilbert J. Gibbs Jr., 39, Coached Lacrosse Team
description: Gilbert J. Gibbs Jr., director of physical education at Montclair High School and acclaimed locally for his coaching of the school's state champion lacrosse team, died of cancer Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. He was 39 years old.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON OILSEARCH BILL
description: WASHINGTON, JUly 25  A SenateHouse conference committee reached agreement today on legislation to regulate and control the search for oil and natural gas in the seas of the outer continental shelf.

title: Associated Press
description: Associated Press

title: Troisgros in America
description: EAST HAMPTON. L.I. AS Jean Troisgros, with understandable enthusiasm, plunged his salad fork into his first course  a plate of salad greens tossed withtruffles  it did smack of sudden poetic justice. After all, few mornings ago this typewriter delivered itself of the thought that salads served as a first course is an enormously unsophisticated and childish concept.

title: Court Rules Law Firm in Conflict
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled late today that the big law firm of Kirkland &Ellis had engaged in a conflict of interest in a huge uranium antitrust case.

title: Jersey Acts to Bar Use 01362 Slot Machines That Skimp on Payoff
description: TRENTON, July 25  A deputy New Jersey state attorney general asked the Casino Control Commission today to bar 362 of the 1,051 slot machines in Resorts international's Atlantic City casino until they were adiusted to Day out more.

title: Market Place
description: MARGIN debt has been scaling new peaks monthly and, capped by the largest increase since March 1976, set still another record midJune at $11.9 billion. Dangerously high? Perhaps.

title: K Mart to Revise Australia Venture
description: The K Mart Corporation said it had agreed in principle with G. J. Coles & Company of Australia to restructure their joint venture, K Mart (Australia) Ltd., which operates 36 K Mart stores in Australia.

title: United Press International
description: ON HOLIDAY:Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, being visited at his Crimean retreat by Erich Honecker, the German leader. Mr. Brezhnev usually spends the summer on the Black Sea.

title: Andreas a Man in the Spotlight
description: Dwayne O. Andreas, a secretive, freewheeling Minnesota businessman, trades soybeans, buys banks and finances politicians  all with apparently equal zest. His political and financial powers are said to be considerable, and they are clearly enhanced by his ability to remain out of the public eye:

title: PAUL L. PEYTON
description: Paul L. Peyton, a retired lawyer and director of Avon Products Inc., died Sunday at his home In Bronxville, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived at 1 Sturgis Road.

title: Workers Management Role on Bumpy Course in Europe
description: STOCKHOLM  When Sweden put into effect a law requiring management to negotiate with employees before making any important change in working or employment conditions, Ulla Christiansson thought it was a good idea.

title: Stadium Echoes With Mixed Feelings
description: YanXee Stadium, the noose that Martin left, was empty at noon yesterday. Suddenly, as in a surreal movie, the organ began playing the famous charge! strains.

title: Exceller Triumphs In Rich Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (AP)  Exceller, the solid favorite, capped a brilliant season yesterday with a comeback victory in the $164,100 Sunset Handicap on the final day of Hollywood Park's meeting.

title: Backlogs in Bulk Mail Result From Walkouts
description: The United States Postal Service. said yesterday that although bulkmail deliveries at the Jersey City and San Francisco facilities had been affectedby walkouts, the job actions had had no effect on firstclass letter traffic.

title: Egypt Dismisses Israel 's  Proposal On West Bank Talks After 5 Years
description: CAIRO, July 25  Egypt today dis: missed Israel's offer to discuss, after five years, the sovereignty of the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip as nothing new, and Cairo looked to the United States to soften Israel's stand.

title: Giants Eying Jim Clack For Key Center Position
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 25  It all starts with the center, which why Jim Clack is probably the most closely watched player at the Giants training camp. Jim Clack is probably the Giants starting center this season.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II Cunard Left Southampton July 22; due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Aide to Carter Cancels Miss Costanza's Time On a Television Show
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  The scheduled appearance of Margaret Costanza, a Presidential aide, on ABC's Good Morning America television program today was abruptly canceled by Gerald Rafshoon, assistant to the President for communications.

title: Rockefeller to Sell Copies of Art
description: Former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday announced that he would pay royalties to the creators of works of art he planned to reproduce and sell.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON OILSEARCH BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  A SenateHouse conference committee reached agreement today on legislation to regulate and control the search for oil and natural gas in the seas of the outer continental shelf.

title: A Gathering of Sweeps
description: The temptation toreport that a pack of chimney sweeps swept, or flue; into town yesterday is overwhelming, but it will be resisted.

title: Powell Orders Officials in Texas To Delay Execution of Murderei
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the United States Supreme Court told the Texas authorities today to postpone setung an execution aate tor a murderer condemned in the 1975 beating death of college student in Dallas.

title: 38 Workers Dismissed For Supporting Others In San Antonio Strike
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 25 (AP)  City Manager Tom Huebner, who has already dismissed more than 140 striking sanitation men, discharged 38 dog catchers and airport maintenance workers today for walking off their jobs in support of the sanitation workers.

title: Recipe CorreCtion
description: In an article on macrobiotics in The Living Section of July 19, a recipe for East/West Tempura batter contained a typographical error. The correct amount of beer or sparkling water is onethird cup.

title: Police Arrest Suspect in Hijacking
description: A securities messenger was arrested yesterday in connection with the hijacking of a station wagon containing $5 million in negotiable securities belonging to a Wall Streetbased company for which he allegedly worked, the police said.

title: Mitchell Fines Reach $2,000 in Colt Boycott
description: BALTIMORE, July 25 (AP)  Lydell Mitchell's fines mounted to $2,000 today as he continued his boycott of the Baltimore Colts training camp. The Colts have levied a $500aday fine against Mitchell, a running back, for every day he refuses to attend practice as the result of a contract dispute with the National Football League team.

title: Deaths
description: SHAFFERJoseph,. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Jean Beth Willis and Simon Peter. Cherished grandfather of Debra, Jill and Merlin Joshua. Dear brother of Miriam Bodlan. Services at  BoulevardPark West, 1901 Flatbush Ave., (at Ave. L), Brooklyn, today at 10 a.m.

title: HAROLD JOHNSTON
description: Harold Johnston, former chairman of the board of Belding Heminway Company Inc., a manufacturer of textiles and thread, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Johnston, who lived in Greenwich, was 83 years old.

title: Gerulaitis Triumphs; Apples Win
description: When two eras meet, the result is usually World Team Tennis at its most exciting. For one set, at least, the big difference in age doesn't mean that much, such as last night at the Felt Forum when 23yearold Vitas Gerulaitis of the Apples faced 39yearold Rod Laver of the San Diego Friars.

title: Doctor Calls Woman In Tube Baby Trial Unable to Try Agair
description: The 1973 attempt by Doris Del Zio at producing a laboratoryfertilized  baby was her last chance to attempt such procedure, her physician testified in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 25  The biggestever life master pair championships approached its climax at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here this afternoon, with 60 pairs in contention for top honors.

title: Town Hall to Shut Its Doors This Week After 57 Years
description: Town Hall, the 43d Street concert hall with a long history of virtuoso performances and some of the best acoustics in the city, will close this week after 57 years. a victim of competition from Lincoin Center, conditions in the Times Square neighborhood, and operating deficits that its owner, New York University, could not continue to make up.

title: ComputerSale Bar Irks Sperry
description: President Carter's decision last week to cancel the sale of a Sperry. Rand 1100 series computer to the Soviet Union was based on misinformation, J. Paul Lyet, chairman and chief executive officer of Sperry, charged yesterday.

title: Jilted California Accountant Sues His Date for $38 in Expenses
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25  Tom Horsley had his day in court here last night, trying to force Alyn Chesslet to pay for his time and expenses incurred for a date she did not keep early this year.

title: BROTHER CH RYSOSTOM
description: Brother Chrysostom Basil (Martin T.) Connell, associate professor emeritus of biology at Manhattan College in the Bronx, died Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers following a short illness. He was 79 years old.

title: The New York Times/John Sotomayor
description: OUT OF WORK AND OUT OF MONEY: Crew members of the America, the ship that offered the illfated Cruise to Nowhere, picketing the vessel. Venture Cruises, their employer, put The liner in dry dock after passenger complaints and offered to provide foreign crewmen with air fare home. Some those crewmen complain that the company owes them both wages and the cost of their fare to New York; most of them come from Caribbean countries.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Is there a great difference between longgrain rice and shortgrain rice? Should rice be salted when cooking?

title: Best Buys
description: A SECOND consecutive weekly decline in the cost of feeding family of four in New York City was announced yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART:Festival Orchestra, Avery Fisher Hall, 8.

title: The New York Times/George Tames
description: SPEAKING ON PROPOSITION 13: Representative Millicent Fenwick giving her views on the effects of California 's new propertytax law on other states at a House banking subcommittee hearing in Washington yesterday.

title: Scarlet Skipper Wins Trot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 25  Sonam stormed through the stretch of Meadowlands mile track tonight and most of the 21,500 fans on hand clucked knowingly and said He's got it! He's got it!

title: EARNINGS
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday a 12.2 percent earnings increase for the second quarter. That rise, however, did not keep pace with the company 's revenue gain of 16 percent to a record.

title: Sunken Treasure Beckons Divers Outside Harbor
description: BRIELLE, N.J.  Somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean; out beyond the shallow depths at Sandy Hook and buried beneath tons of sand and silt, are the rotted timbers and greenmottled ballast rocks of the Lizzie D, a rumrunner that sank in 1922 midway between New Jersey and Long Island 's Jones Inlet.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25  Syrian troops today resumed their shelling of Christian positions at the hillside town of Al Hadath, four miles east of here, shattering a 24hour lull.

title: JOHN R. SCHOEMER
description: John R. Schoemer, from 1944 to 1959 managing director of the National Builders Hardware Association in New York, died Saturday in a nursing home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 94 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor.

title: Grumman Jet Sale
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, disclosed that it had completed the last of its F1.1 fighter jet sales to Iran and said that it might lay off 500 to 000 emplOyees.

title: Chess Game a Draw But Not on YOgurt Issue
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 25  Viktor Korchfini once again muffled the guns of the world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, today, bringing the fourth game of their title match here to another draw and reinforcing expectations of a long, close match.

title: Dividends
description: X 5 for 4 wilt, pay date unannounced.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Nobody ever called me an elitist and walked away undamaged. And I am weary of writers like William Manchester who think of the losers in our society as dross [OpEd July 15]. In any competitive system, as in sports or war, there are winners and losers, and the winners are not always the sort of people you would like to go to the movies with.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: TOKYO, July 25  The dollar, having dropped below the 200yen level for the first time in postwar history, yesterday, continued its plunge in the foreign exchange market today, dropping by a not her:1.00 yen to close at 195.50.

title: Soviet Mail Restrictions Described by U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  The Soviet Union is interfering with some mail from Amgricans to dissidents and wouldbe emigrants, representatives of the Postal Service and the State Department told Congress today.

title: NEW ITALIAN TERROR SEEMINGLY RANDOM
description: ROME, July 25  Italy has been plagued in recent weeks by a rapidly increasing number of terrorist attacks that follow no discernible pattern and cannot be traced to any known terrorist organization such as the Red Brigades.

title: Panel Backs. Anthony Coin
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  House subcommittee voted today, 6 to to authorize a new $1 coin bearing the image of the suffragette Susan B. Anthony. The action was a rebuff to the Treasury Department, which contended that would be more appropriate to use the symbolic Miss Liberty on the coin, thus honoring all women rather than just one. The Banking Committee is expected to consider the bill before Congress recesses Aug. 18.

title: Minority Group Leaves Government in Portugal
description: LISBON, July 25 (AP)  The minority group in Prime Minister Mario Soares's Government walked out today and President Antonio Ramalho Eanes said, he would ask his military advisers whether he should dismiss the Prime Minister:

title: West German Prison Bombed
description: HANOVER, West Germany, July 25 (AP)  A bomb blew a threefootwide hole in the wall of a 300yearold prison in Celle, north of here, that had recently been fortified to house terrorists, the state Justice Ministry reported today. No one was injured in the blast last night, spokesman said, and no escapes were renorted.

title: MARY E.W. RISTEAU
description: FOREST HILL, Md. July 25 (Al') Mary E.W. Risteau, the first woman to serve in the Maryland Legislature, dipd yesterday at her Harford County farm. She was 88. The former schoolteacher and farmer was elected to the House of Delegates in 1921. Alter two terms there, she became the first woman elected to Maryland's Senate, in 1934.

title: An Eng lishman Faces Jail for Dogs Right to Litter
description: LONDON, July 25  Frank Clifford of Burnley is England's newest hero. He is preparing to go to iail for his doe.

title: Five Partners of Rainess Join Main Lafrentz Firm
description: Five key partners of the public accounting firm of Clarence Rainess & Company have joined the international accounting firm of Main Lafrentz & Company in a move that industry observers said could signal the demise of the Rainess partnership.

title: The Complicity of Silence: A License for Criminals
description: You can see them running through most,any crowd. They crow, a gleeful song  they've just made a hit and know they'll never be caught. They're home free  no one knows who they are, where they come from,,or where they're going. But their time is coming, oh yes.

title: Babcock Award
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company announced that it had received contract. awards totaling $109.4 million from the Department of Energy. The orders inchide work for the Navy's nuclear propulsion program. The. company is a wholly owned subsidiary of J. Ray McDermott & Company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified Yigal Allon as former Prime Minister of Israel. Mr. Allon was Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Former Teamster Head Sentenced in Camden
description: CAMDEN, July 25 (UPI)  The former president of Local 918 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Garfield was given a threeyear suspended sentence and fined $7,500 today for accepting illegal payments from trucking companies.

title: Dow Up by 7.97 to 839.57 As Polaroid Leads Rally
description: Propelled by gains in airline and glamour favorites, the stock market rose sharply yesterday in the final hour of steppedup trading. It was a session that snatched victory from the jaws of seeming defeat  countering nearrecord gold prices, a new postwar low in the dollar against the Japanese yen and fears of rising interest rates that had rippled through Wall Street.

title: Attorney General Primary Fight RaisesDemocratic Party Interest
description: The choice of a majority of the politicians at the Democratic State Convention for Attorney General of New York State, Robert Abrams, campaigned yesterday as the independent Democrat.

title: In Search of the Elusive Oatcake
description: THOSE who have glimpsed the Scottish oatcake can never forget it. Flat, coarse, graybeige, pitted like the moon's bleak surface, this triumph of Calvinist cuisine tests the Scotsman's grit and separates the men from the laddies.

title: United Press International
description: KANSAS CITY, July 25  Bob LeMon, vowing he has no plans to make radical changes, directed, his first game as Yankee manager tonight and did what any rightthinking manager, new or old, would do  he started Ron Guidry against the Kansas City Royalp.

title: Woman Gives Birth to Baby Conceived Outside the Body
description: LONDON, Wednesday, July 26  The first authenticated birth of a baby conceived in laboratory glassware and then placed in the uterus of an otherwise infertile mother occurred last night, apparently without complications.

title: Personal Health
description: VARIOUS studies in recent years indicate that all the above are false. There are perhaps more myths about ulcers than about any other common chronic disease. Much of the misinformation is because the experts themselves are unsure of how or why ulcers.

title: A Gathering of Sweeps
description: The temptation to report that a pack of chimney sweeps swept, or flue, into town yesterday is overwhelming, but it will be resisted.

title: National Van Lines Is Sued by I.C.C.
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission sued National Van Lines today, charging the company with 2,769 late pickups and deliveries in a sevenmonth period in 1977.

title: Vietnam Reports a Troop Buildup For Action Against Aggressors
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25 (AP)  Vietnam has inducted more than 350,000 men and women into its armed forces for defending and building the motherland. the Vietnam radio reported today. The broadcast from Hanoi said the recruits would be sent to border areas to defend the country's territorial integrity against foreign aggressors and also to construction sites.

title: Bolivians, Thankful for the Calm, Accept Latest Coup With a Shrug
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 25  The posters along the main thoroughfares of this cool mountain capital exhort the people, Think about yourself, think about Bolivia, vote for Juan Pereda!

title: Plums: From the Sweet to the Tart
description: IN his classic work, The Plums of NeW York, published in 1911, the horticultuiist. Ulysses Prentiss Hedrick, said, Of all the stone fruits, plums furnish the greatest diversity of kinds. Varieties to the number of 2,000, from 15 species, are now or have been under cultivation.

title: Compulsive Shopping: The BuyNowandBuyLater Syndtbme
description: It's something I do if 1 am bored or depressed, said the young woman in muted, slightly strained voice. I do it when there is on emotional emptiness in my life, when I feel I've been deprived of something.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE FOR ALLBucky Pizzarelli, the jaziguitarist, holds forth this afternoon from 4:30 to 6 in the Music for a City Evening series. The place is Rockefeller Center's McGrawHill Park, between 98th and 99th Streets, west of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: For the Kitchen, Some New Cook 's  Tools
description: No matter how many thousands of kitchen gadgets there are, there always seems to be room for a few more  variations, refinements or innovations aimed at. rendering the cook's task lighter with more efficient results. Here are a few candidates that are new or have only recently caught our eye.

title: NEW YORK ENDORSES GATEWAY PROPOSAL
description: New York City gave qualified endorsement yesterday to a National Park Service proposal to develop the 26,000acre Gateway National Recreation Area, urging that the 20year, $300 million project include expanded recreational activities, improved transportation and greater community participation.

title: Topics
description: New York 's Mayor Koch and Council President Bellamy have announced a plan to request voluntary payments from institutions like Rockefeller University and Mount Sinai Hospital to make up for the real estate taxes they do not have to pay. Having long supported a review of tax exemption, we wish them luck. But if there 's one thing that taxes are not, it 's voluntary.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified Yigal Allon as former Prime Minister of Israel. Mr. Allon was Deputy Prime Minister.

title: POSTAL SERVICE SAYS ITS WORKERS RETURN
description: The United States Postal Service reported yesterday that workers in New Jersey and California who had illegally stayed away from their jobs in protest against a tentative wage contract were returning to work in large numbers. The agency also said it would continue dismissing employees who did not show up for duty.

title: TV: Funny Business, 2 Hours of Film Clips
description: ONE of the more tantalizing big television programs of the summer is Funny Business, a twohour program of film clips of many of the funniest scenes ever played before a camera that will be seen tonight at 8 o'clock on CBSTV.

title: U.S. Study Finds Soviet Superior in Strategic Arms
description: The Soviet Union has attained or moving toward superiority in 10 of 13 strategic nuclear forces and weapon systems, according to a report sponsored by the Defense Nuclear Aeencv.

title: The Tax Reform Trap
description: WASHINGTON  These are dangerous times for the taxpayer. Revolts don 't always succeed. They often fail, and in the process of being put down, the taxpayer can come out a net loser.

title: Chicago Starts Home Bonds
description: Chicago, venturing into the singlefamily mortgage loan business, will sell $100 million of taxexempt bonds today to raise money to make loans to home buyers at 8 percent  well below the going rate.

title: A New Leader Is Chosen by Party Opposing Puerto Rican Statehood
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 25  The procommonwealth Popular Democratic Party today chose a new leader, Senator Miguel Hernandez Anosto. But the question of who will be the party's candidate for Governor in the 1980 election, when the island's status is expected to be major issue, was left undecided.

title: Optimistic Lemon Takes Yanks Helm
description: KANSAS CITY, July 25  About a year ago, Manager Bob Lemon of the Chicago White Sox looked at the Yankees and said: I can't wait to get the newspaper each moniing to read about the latest episode of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.  Today Manager Bob Lemon looked at the Yankees and saw that he was directing the cast of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.

title: Railroad Policy Of I.C.C. Hit
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  In an unusual move, the Federal Railroad Administration lashed out today at a sister agency, the Interstate Commerce Commission, charging that its policies for distributing rail cars was detrimental to railroad companies profits.

title: Gets 3 Blows As Reds Lose To Mets, 92
description: Pete Rose broke one of baseball's most glamorous records last night in Shea Stadium when he,lined a single to left field in his second time at bat and stretched his hitting streak to 38 pamec.

title: Jury Acquits Seven in Obscenity Case in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP)  A jury in Federal District Court that acquitted seven persons of obscenity charges wrote the judge a message saying. that the jurors did not believe the average person was capable of having a shameful interest in sex.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial DiscriMination  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SENATE ACTS TO LIFT ARMS BAN ON TURKS, BUT ADDS WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The Senate voted today to repeal the 42monthold embargo on American military assistance for Turkey but tried to link any future aid for that country to progress on a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus problem.

title: Mine Union Chief Temporarily Blocks Ouster Bid
description: DENVER, July 25 , The embattled leadership of the United Mine Workers convened a tightly secured session of the coal union's 24man executive board here today.

title: The New York Times/George Tames
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House of Representatives gave final passage today to the compromise bill providing New York City with $1.65 billion in Federal loan guarantees. The vote was 244 to 157.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 3yearold boy found wandering alone on Northern Boulevard in Queens was returned home safely three hours later after the police found someone who recognized him.

title: Books of The Times
description: IWISH I could work up some real enthusiasm for these two disasterthrillers. After all, I owe them something for taking part of my mind off the heat for a day or. so  which is probably just the sort of thing their authors intended them to do.

title: Surgery for Cards End
description: ST. LOUIS, July 25 (UPI)  J.V Cain. starting tight end of the St. Louis Cardinals, will undergo surgery Thursday for a torn Achilles tendon and will be out of action indefinitely. the football team said today. Cain, a fiveyear veteran, tore the tendon while running a puss pattern during practice last night at the training camp in St. Charles.

title: Frank Gilloon, Manager Of NewsPhoto Agencies
description: Frank J. Gilloon, sales manager of Wide World Photos for 24 years before its owner, The New York Times, closed the agency, and national sales manager of International News Photos for 20 years. died Sunday in Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, LI., of cancer. He was years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: Girl, 14, Stabbed in Rape Attempt
description: TRENTON, July 18 (UPI)  A 14yearold girl, stabbed more than 10 times in the abdomen during an apparent rape attempt, was saved by two motorvehicle inspectors yesterday in Pemberton Township.

title: Eating on the Trail: You Don't Have to Leave Good Food Behind
description: AFTER backpackers trek for miles in the wilderness, feeling the senses keen and reawakened, they often face dampening meal of freezedried or vacuumpacked food. This sort of food is convenient, of course, requiring simply the addition of water. It passes baSIC criteria: nuitritional value, light weight, ease of preparation. Many backpackers find it satisfactory, or perhaps they regard such fare as an inescapable trial of trailblazing.

title: Bridgeport Brass
description: The Bridgeport Brass Company, a division of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, announced an increase in the price of all brass mill products except free cutting brass rod alloys, effective yesterday. This will reflect an increase in the price of copper to 64 cents a pound from 63 cents.

title: Marathon Reports Encouraging Find
