description: Marathon Petroleum Indonesia Ltd. announced that an offshore Indonesian exploratory well drilled by the company and its associates had penetrated several sands with encouraging oil and gas potential.

title: Distribution of Article Criticizing the L.I.R.R Is Approved by Court
description: The Long Island Rail Road, which has often left leaflets on the seats of its trains to explain its problems to its frustrated riders, was ordered by a State Supreme Court iustice yesterday to let a State Senate candidate distriliute a newspaper story critical of the railroad.

title: Business Records
description: DONALD M. LEVINE, 203 W. 86 St., N.Y. Liabilities, $92,518; assets, 55,375.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Taxes would be waived on capital gains resulting from inflation under a proposal unexpectedly approved by. the House Ways and Means Committee. The vote introduced a new element of confusion into the murky legislative situation surrounding the capital gains issue. [Page A1].

title: Honesty Can Be Ageless
description: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y.  All of a sudden, I was approaching my 65th birthday, so one Friday morning early in June, I went over to the Social Security Administration office in Mineola, L.I., to apply for Medicare. And learned I don 't really exist, not officially anyhow.

title: Deaths
description: ANTMANAnn, beloved sister of Ruth Jacobs, Pearl Jaffe, and the late Bernard M tchell and Roslyn. Funeral at Norman L. Jef ler Corn. munity Chapels, 4620 Fort Hamilton Pkwy, Bklyn, Wednesday 1PM.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: AMUSEMENT AMERICANSTYLE:The Shah of Iran 's 8yearold daughter, Leila, taking part in a potatosack race during visit to the Capital Children 's Museum in Washington. Also in. the race is Iran 's Ambassador, Ardeshir Zahedi. Two of the Shah 's children were ending a monthlong tour of the U.S.

title: Henry Fenn, a Specialist On Speaking of Chinese
description: Henry Cdurtenay Fenn, noted authority on the Chinese spoken language, died Saturday in the Medical Center of Kendal at Longwood in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 84 years old and lived in Kennett Sauare.

title: The New York Times/ Edward Hausner
description: CAUGHT ON A TRASH CAN: A rented car driven by Karen Faehner along Eighth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan yesterday rests on trash can after! freak accident. Basket had been set into large pothole, but car wheel righted and vehicle was subsequently stuck in midair.

title: Four Assassinated in Nicaragua; Slayings. Are Linked to Rightists
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25 (Reuters)  Three students and a lawyer were shot to death by civilians last night and this morning, apparently for political reasons, the police said.

title: News Summary
description: The arms embargo against Turkey would be repealed under a vote by the Senate, which also sought to link any future American military aid to that country to progress on a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus problem. The vote on the conditional lifting of the embargo was 57 to 42. It came on an amendment to the $2.9 billion international security assistance bill. The amendment was proposed by Senator George McGovern. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Economists, U.S. at Odds Over Full Employment
description: Jeffrey M. Perloff and Michael. L. Wachter, the two young University of Pennsylvania economists whose study was cited in yesterday's Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development report on the American economy, were surprised and delighted that their analytical work on potential output was being used as source material by that highly regarded group of Western industrial nations.

title: The New York Times/D.Gorton
description: The Cincinnati Kid was early. He got to Shea Stadium about 4 P.M. yesterday, more than four hours before game time.

title: Krantz on Shopping
description: The thrill was in the trying on, in thetuying. The moment after she had acquired something new, it became meaningless to her; therefore, each time she went out looking for something to purchase, it was the same need that drove her.

title: M. G. Peroukhin Dies; Among Soviet Leaders Ousted by Khrushchev
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (Reuters)  Mikhail Georglyevich Pervukhin, a member of the ruling Politburo from 1952 until he was ousted by Nikita S. Khrushchev five years later, has died at the age of 73, the Communist daily Pravda said today.

title: Jersey Indians Triumph On a Homer by Moore. 54
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn., July 25  Kelvin Moore snapped a 44 tie with a home run in the sixth inning, giving Mike Norris and the Jersey Indians a 54 victory over the West Haven Yankees last night.

title: Careers
description: ANEW PROGRAM sponsored by the New York State Education Department aims to put holders of doctorate degrees in such fields as Byzantine art, archeology and classics to work in business.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: What would you give for something cool and sparkly? If you're a cheapskate, get a fizzy drink from the refrigerator. If you have lots of money, not too many years, and think unobtrusive is the name of a new toothpaste, take a gander at a vest that looks like shimmering cobweb, now on display at Bonwit Teller. The word cobweb is used advisedly; there are vast expanses of absolutely nothing between the swirly chains of rhinestones. The vest is probably meant to be worn with something underneath it, but then again, maybe it isn't. Whatever is meant to be doesn't much matter anyway, because anyone who would spend $1,000 on this frippery undoubtedly wants to be noticed, and assuredly will be granted their wish. Bonwit's, not being reckless, offers the vest to order only, but it's something to think of if you want to perk up that basic black dress. Oh yes, the jewelry department is the place to look.

title: Billy Joins the Passing Show
description: Soon after George M. Steinbrenner 3d bought control the Yankees, Mike Burke, president of the club, resigned. Then Ralph Houk, the manager. resigned. Then. Lee MacPhail, president and general manager, resigned. Then Bob Fishel, vice president, resigned. Then Fishel'ssuccessor, Marty Appel, and the club's attorney, Joe Garagiola Jr., resigned. Then Gabe Paul, president and general manager, resigned. Now Billy Martin, the manager, has resigned.

title: Schlesinger Plans Visit At Invitation of Chinese
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger has accepted an invitation to go to China in the next few months to discuss cooperative efforts in energy development, Administration officials said today.

title: RollCall Vote on New York's Bill
description: WASHINGTON (AP),  Following the rollcall Vote by which the House approved, 244 to 157, a Federal guarantee of up to $1.65 billion in New York City municipal bonds. A 'yes vote is a vote for the guarantee. A no vote is a vote against. An xxx denotes members not voting.

title: Hartford Mayor Says He Vetoed Ban on Bias Against Homosexuals
description: HARTFORD, July 25  An ordinagce passed by the City Council last night making Hartford one of the 32 cities in the country with a ban on discrimination against homosexuals was vetoed today, accordine to Mayor George Athanson.

title: Sunken Treasure Beckons Divers Outside Harbor
description: BRIELLE, N.J.  Somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean, out beyond the shallow depths at Sandy Hook and buried beneath tons of sand and silt, are the rotted timbers and greenmottled ballast rocks of the Lizzie D, a rumrunner that sank in 1922 midway between New Jersey and Long Island's Jones Inlet.

title: The New York Times/Chester Jr.
description: ONE WAY TO LEAVE MANHATTAN: A bicycle rider pedaling over the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday as temperatures dropped into a more comfortable range from the weekend, and fluffy clouds dotted the sky.

title: Roll Call Vote to Repeal Arms Embargo on Turks
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  . Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate adopted On amendment today lifting an embargo on arms shipments to Turbpv.

title: 2 Policemen Sent to Jail For Withholding Names
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 25 (UPI)  Diktrict Judge Frank Marullo has sent two police officers to jail for 72 hours for refusing to disclose, the name of a confidential source.

title: Ehrlichman Sues Government
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  John D. Ehrlichman sued the Federal Govern: ment, today for the return of personal property seized in 1973 when he resigned as a top aide to President Nixon. In a complaint filed in Federal District Court, he said that he has had no meaningful access to his private property since then and asserts that he is entitled to its return. Three months ago, Mr. Ehrlichman completed an 18month prison term for his role in the Watergate coverup and the burglary of the office of a California psychiatrist.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ACAB driver friend of mine, writes Devereaux Carson, told me he was sitting in diner where all the cabbies congregate when a fellow driver sat down and recounted this story.

title: REPORTER IS DENIED AN APPEAL SPEEDUP
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25  The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today by a 5to.1 vote to speed the usually long appellate process and hear appeals now by the New York Times Company and Times reporter, M. A. Farber, of their contemptofcourt convictions that were handed down yesterday.

title: Senate Votes to Extend Meal Program for Aged
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  The Senate approved yesterday a $2 billion, twoyear extension of a program for elderly Americans that includes more meals for shutins and parttime jobs for those who need employment.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN.Images for Orchestra, Gigues, Debussy; Trumpet Concerto, Albinoni; Concerto Quattro in A minor, ToreIli; 11 Viaggio a Reims Overture, Rossini; Overture in F, Tchaikovsky.

title: Skylab Is Maneuvered Into a
description: HOUSTON;July 25 (AP)  Flight controllers maneuvered the. 84ton Skylab satellite today into, a position, aimed. at prolonging its orbit, and eivineers were cautiously oathnistic afterwaid.

title: Boarding Home Owner Accused Of Taking Social Security Checks
description: TRENTON, July 25 (UPI)  Theresa Raziano, owner of a boarding home in East Orange, N.J., has been indicted on charges of stealing Social Security checks worth $6,610 from a resident and also cashing checks of more than $1,000 belonging to another.

title: Notes on People
description: INa ringing defense of Ambassador Andrew Young, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday that recent criticism of the United States representative to the United Nations was a continuation of the attacks that were made on her husband. Coretta Scott King said in Atlanta, It appears to me that the Andy Young affair has brought all the racists out of the closet. For those of us involved in the struggle for human rights it should come as no surprise that our opponents and those who oppose giving blacks and other minorities an equal opportunity should surface to criticize those who are doing their best to promote full human rights everywhere. Mrs. King referred to the controversy stirred by Mr. Young's recent remarks that there were hundreds, perhaps thousands, of political prisoners in the United States. Mr. Young was an associate of Dr. King.

title: Reforming the Informing Business
description: Informers are universally despised  and universally employed. Even when they help solve serious crimes, we grant them no honor; they too much resemble the criminals they trap. Yet we demand and require their services to defend us against crime and subversion. The F.B.I. alone uses 2,800 informers, paying many of them piecework Tor the intormation delivered. William Webster, the very civilized F.B.I. Director, told Congress recently that despite a tradition against snitching the informant is the, with a capital T, The most effective tool in law enforcement today  state, local or Federal..

title: Alleged Breaches Studied at Citibank
description: Citibank, the largest commercial bank in New York, said yesterday that its outside counsel and auditors were conducting a study into the possibility it might, have violated the foreignexchange and tax laws of some of the foreign countries in which it does business.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Trading in precious metals futures yesterday was somewhat more nervous than usual because of the guessing about the nation's balance of trade for June, which are to be released today, and because of several bouts of profit taking provoked by lower gold prices in London.

title: Civil Service Commission Endorses a Plan to Abolish Most of Job Preferences Now Given to War Veterans
description: TRENTON, July 25  In a major proposed revision of hiring and dismissal procedures, the New Jersey Civil Service Commission approved today a plan to run the state government with highly paid senior career executives while abolishing most of the job and promotion preferences to war veterans.

title: Yanks New Unpretentious Quiet Man
description: In the always gossipy and often backbiting society of professional baseball, Bob Lemon holds a distinction almost as rare as his status as a member of the Hall of Fame: no one has a bad word to say about him.

title: Miss Onassis Wedding Rumored
description: ATHENS, July 25 (UPI)  Christina Onassis, daughter of the late shipowner Aristotle Onassis, will marry a Soviet shipping official within a week, a close family friend said today.

title: $300 Million Gateway Park Plan Gets Qualified City Hall Support
description: New York City gave qualified endorsement yesterday to a National Park Service proposal to develop the 26,000acre Gateway National Recreation Area, uraing that the 20year, $300 million project include expanded recreational activities, improved transportation and greater community participation.

title: Skipper Goes Under With a Beer
description: FUNCHAL, Madeira, July 25 (Reuters)  H. Vesprhein, the Norwegian captain of a whaler that capsized as it was trying to pull aboard a giant whale, went down with his ship while quaffinga beer, survivors said today. The 42 members of the crew of the 543ton factory ship Tonna, registered in the Netherlands Antilles, were picked up by a Greek freighter 220 miles off the Portuguese coast. The crew members said they had implored the captain to abandon ship but he refused.

title: Showplace Mosque Planned on East Side
description: Led by the major Arab oil exporters, a coalition of Islamic countries will finance a project to build the city's first mosque on Manhattan's East Side. Although other buildings in the city are used as Islamic houses of worship, the domed, granite shrine will be the first designed for that purpose.

title: 2 IN HOUSE ASK TALK WITH KOREA LEADER
description: WASHINGTON, July 25, (AP)  Thomas P. O'Neill, the Speaker of the House, said today that House members were asking South Korea's President, Park Chung Hee, for a meeting to discuss their request for a former Ambassador's testimony On alleged influencebuying.

title: Taiwan Balloons Stray Into India
description: NEW DELHI, July 25 (Reuters)  Two balloons carrying leaflets calling for a revolt in China strayed into India from Taiwan earlier this month, Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai said today. The balloons, which he said also contained pieces of toffee and towels, landed two weeks ago in a village in Madhya Pradesh state.

title: In the South, Catfish Business Is Purring
description: But on a recent sunaay afternoon, as the villagers were paying homage to its catfish, the supply was running short.

title: It 's  a Healthy Girl
description: LONDON, Wednesday, July 26  The first authenticated birth of a baby conceived in laboratory glassware and then placed in the uterus of an otherwise infertile mother occurred last night, apparently without complic.ations.

title: Deaths
description: LEAVINSamuel B. Died of a heart attack on Jul 17 In Cannes, France. He is survived by his wife. Gertrude, his daughter, Valerie & his son, Paul. A memorial service will be held at a later date for family & friends.

title: Paris Comes to Locust Valley
description: LOCUST VALLEY, N.Y., July 25  Someone allowed as how a lot of women in this area still like pink, green, little Givenchy collars and prim buttondown coats. A lot of them also like flower prints and Diane Von Furstenberg designs. So what.

title: Technology
description: FOR all its pervasiveness, the standard, gardenvariety telephone has been completely overlooked by the technological revolution of the last quartercentury. In the home it does not even rate the status of an appliance. It is still, except for the addition of pushbutton dialing a decade ago, the same old instrument used by generations of callers.

title: Tito in Warning On Role of Cuba In African Strife
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25  President Tito warned countries professing nonalignment today against letting their disputes, especially in Africa, develop into EastWest power struggles throueh involvement of outside forces.

title: Questioning U.S. Antitrust Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  John H. Shenefield, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, has outlined in a confidential memorandum a strategy for attacking in the courts certain pricing practices of socalled sharedmonopoly industries.

title: Embryo Storage Is Studied
description: LONDON; Wednesday, July 26  The freezing and storing of embryos, already routine with cattle, could provide an infertile woman with a whole family of children after a single eggharvesting procedure, according to the two doctors who brought such a patient to the successful delivery of a baby girl late last night.

title: Somoza and His Foes Both Looking to U.S. for Aid
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 20  I don't think the United States would have the nerve to ask me to resign, President Anastasio Somoza Debayle said in an interview. No. I don't think so. If they ask me to resign, the implications would be tremendous.

title: Citicorp Cuts Size Of Offering
description: Citicorp's offering of floatingrate notes scheduled for sale today was reduced in size late yesterday to $200 million from $250 million and was priced to yield 9 percent initially.

title: Factory Orders in June Down for Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  New factory orders for durable goods, a sign of future business trends, declined for the first time in five months during June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Philadelphia Law Upset
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP)  Judge Charles P. Mirarchi of Common Pleas Court today declared the city's antiobscenity law unconstitutional on the ground that it was vague and indefinite.

title: U.S. Budget Chief Seeks $5 Billion More in Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  President Carter 's budget director said today an additional $5 billion should be trimmed from next year 's proposed budget. He suggested an acrosstheboard spending cut as one way to accomplish the goal.

title: The New York Times/Harvey L. Bilker
description: Animals are a big part of traditional country fairs, and the attractions at the Ocean County Fair are no exception. Above, Janette Taege did some trick maneuvers during a musical sacks horse race. At right, Paul Griming carries sheep to animal competition. Fair runs through Thursday at Rockefeller Park, Lakewood.

title: Did Mobil's Ad Sway WNET?
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation last week stoked up the issue of corporate influences in public broadcasting by purchasing an advertisement in The New York Times that appeared to criticize the scheduling of a program series by WNETTV in New York that Mobil had supported.

title: Carey Gains Support From Badillo
description: Governor Carey held a news conference yesterday morning to accept the support of Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo of New York City for his reelection camr aien and another in the afternoon to accept $10 million from the Federal Government for New York State energy programs.

title: The Catfish, And How To Cook It
description: It has been called the Sweete.se meat you ever will eat, and it's not meat at all, it's catfish. Long regarded as major gastronomic jewel of the South, this meanlooking, sharprayed creature is on it's way to national stardom. Commercial and sport fisheries are discovering its unusual attributes and considerable advance publicity from staunch Southerners is convincing the rest of the nation that catfish is at least worth a try.

title: Growing Number of Young People Strive for Internships at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Gordon Strachan, an aide in the Nixon White House, advised pnce in the height of the Watergate scandals that young people stay away from a career in public service.

title: Amdahl In Accord On Credit Line
description: The Amdahl Corporation announced that it had entered into an agreement in principle to establish a multicurrency $100 million line of credit with an international consortium of banks.

title: WJA, Xcor In Fight for JaiAlai
description: A battle for control of World JaiAlai Inc., the operator of jai alai arenas, emerged yesterday with gambling commissions in two states playing key role in the outcome.

title: F.D.U. Names Joganow Coach
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J. July 25  Viktor Joganow was named the women's basketball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University yesterday, replacing Pat Waite. In three seasons as coach at Passaic Valley High School, the 29yearold Joganow compiled a 6313 wonlost record.

title: Nureyey Dances Nifinsky Role
description: SCHEHERAZADE. Just the name of this stage extravaganza conjures up images of Baslav Nijinsky shooting out across the stage like a panther from a cage. At least that is how eyewitness accounts had it in 1910.

title: Emil Blasberg of Lord & Taylor; Designed Its Window Displays
description: Emil A. Blasberg, director of merchandise presentation for Lord & Taylor in New York,, died Monday at the Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 40 years old and lived at 19 East 88th Street.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: PROBABLY nothing in my childhood impressed me more than the years served as an apprentice at the then fashionable Restaurant Drouant Paris. But of the things I remember, most vivid is the insistence of the ecutive chef that a daily  and earlyhour  visit to the market (invariably Les Halles) was imperative to a good kitchen.

title: Kennedy Center Asks Congress To Waive Interest on Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The trustees of the John F. Kennedy Cenier for the Performing Arts, facing a financial squeeze, yesterday asked Congress to pass legislation waiving millions of dollars in bonding interest owed to the Treasury for financing part of the center's construction.

title: Auto Sales Up by 5% for the Middle 10 Days of July
description: DETROIT, July 25  Auto sales increased by 5 percent in the middle 10 days of July, but the General Motors Corporation, the industry giant, was the only company to report a sales increase.

title: Books: Rorem's Diary
description: NED ROREM'S newest installment in his continuing diary is hardly the absolute gift he calls it. For a good deal of its length, it is a tired document, marked by petty carpings, weary aphorisms and futile resentments. For the first time, readers will sense the effort behind what Mr. Rorem himself refers to as the precious archness of his prose. In places, an elaborateness in the writing disguises a poverty of substance.

title: 2 ACED DIE IN HOME; STATE INVESTIGATING
description: Two patients of the Fairview Nursing Home in Forest. Hills, Queens, died Monday, and the special state prosecutor for the nursinghome industry yesterday began an investigation to see if an airconadioning failure during the recent heat wave contributed to the deaths.

title: Sugar Imported From Europe Given Special Tariff by Treasury
description: WASHINGTON. July 25 (AP)  The Treasury Department moved quickly today to place special tariffs on sugar imported from Europe.

title: Head of Patrick House Drug Program Facing Removal
description: JERSEY CITY, July 25  The City Council today resumed its investigation of the Patrick House drugrehabilitation program, the largest in the state, as the New Jersey Health Department prepared to take control of the program away from its founder and executive director, the Rev. Francis E. Schiller.

title: JAPAN'S STAFF CHIEF IS FORCED TO RESIGN
description: TOKYO, July 25  Gen. Hiroomi Kurisu, chairman of the Joint Staff Council, was dismissed today for having said that the Japanese armed forces might act on their own in case of a surprise attack.

title: U.S. Again Cancels Trip By Delegation to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reuters)  The Carter Administration said today that it had canceled the visit of another highlevel delegation to Moscow in response to the trials of Soviet dissidents and action against American correspondents.

title: U.S. Checking Cars for Stalling
description: DETROIT, July 25 (AP)  The Federal Government is checking 470,000 1977 model Oldsmobiles, Pontiacs and Buicks with V6 engines because of complaints that the cars are suhiper to Atsal ing. uovernment spokesmen say that there have been nine minor accidents that may have been related to the alleged stalling. No serious injuries were reported.

title: Real Estate
description: IN the last few years, there has been a considerable shifting of ownership of important midtown office buildings, and new investors have increasingly sought older properties that can be upgraded.

title: Delay Is Again Denied by Judge in Jascalevich Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25  Today, for the second time in two days,the judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich denied a defense request to delay the trial until documents could be obtained from the New York Times reporter whose investigation and articles were instrumental in bringing about the murder indictments.

title: Deaths
description: JOSEPHSylvan Lehman, age 80, on July 21, husband OrMildred Aaron, father of Betty Ann Halperin and Sylvan L, Jr.. grandfather of Amy Sara Halperin, Jonathan Joseph Halperin, Ellen Nancy Joseph and Carol Klee Joseph. Private funeral has been held. Fremont, Ohio papers please copy.

title: The New York Times/D.00mo
description: PETE ROSE SETS NEW BATTING RECORD: Reds Pete Rose connecting. for a single his second time at bat against Nets at Shea Stadium last night set new National League record of hitting in 38 consecutive games. Page 135.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne said a bill pending in Congress would give New Jersey an additional $13.7 million for social services. Mr. Byrne said that figure included $6.8 million for day care related programs.

title: Players Fail to Support Murdoch on Suspension
description: TORONTO, July 25The National HockeY League Players Association, at a meeting here today, failed to support Don Murdoch, the New York Ranner wing wno receives a suspension of at least 40 games without pay yesterday. The suspension by the league president, John Ziegler, stemmed from Murdoch's conviction three months agd on charges of possession of 4.8 grams of cocaine, an illegal drug. Murdoch had pleaded guilty in Chitario provincial court and was fined $400:

title: Wine Talk
description: BORDEAUX, FRANCE DAY after day, the gray clouds roll in from the sea and across vineyards that extend out from this city in all directions for 30 miles. From time to time, the sun breaks through and the cool days turn hot and muggy.

title: James Earl Ray: A Decade in the Public Mind
description: From the time of the assassination of the Dr. Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. 10 years ago until this month, when the way was cleared for him to go public on Capitol Hill. James Earl Ray never allowed the public to put him out of mind for long.

title: Stanislaw Krzyczkowski, at 79, A Former Director of I.A.T.A.
description: Stanislaw Krzyczkowski, who was the first technical director of the 1 Sternational Air Transport Association, died in Montreal Monday after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

title: City, Citing Economic Upswing, to Take Closer Look At Midtown Commercial Buildings Tax Abatements
description: New York City's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board will take harder look at applications for propertytax abatements on commercial buildings in Midtown Manhattan. Peter J. Solomon, Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development, said yesterday.

title: Rono Wins Steeplechase, Leading a Kenyan Sweep
description: ALGIERS, July 25 (AP)  Henry Rono had littlecompetition today in leading a Kenyan sweep of the first three places in the 3,000meter steeplechase at the Afrinan nanipc.

title: Tito in Warning On Role of Cuba In African Strife
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25  President Tito warned countries professing nonalignment today against letting their disputes, especially in Africa, develop into EastWest power struggles through involvement of outside forces.

title: Eschenbach and Mozart
description: THE sight of a pianist serving as a parttime conductor in 18thcentury concertos always conveys at least some sense of the ridiculous to a modernday audience. We know, of course, that Mozart and his contemporaries led their own works from the keyboard, and that much music of the period is neither rhythmically nor orchestrally complex enough to require a separate conductor.

title: West Presses Accord For Namibia at U.N. In Spite of New Snags
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25  The new Western accord for a peace settlement and independence for SouthWest Africa came under further attack today from South Africa, but also from the nationalist forces waging guerrilla war in the territory.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Airwick Industries,a wholly owned subsidiary of the CibaGeigy Corporation, has named Jay Berry chief executive officer.

title: 2 Missing Czechs Dead in lanan
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, July 25 (Reuters)  Two bodies assumed to be those of a Czechoslovak man and his wife missing for nearly two years have been found on Mount Fuji, the police reported today. The counle. Stanislav and l4anna Fejkl, disappeared while trying to climb the 12,389foot peak.

title: Heading for Adventure at Ford
description: I had a fine job at Du Pont. I couldn't have had a better job for the rest of my life, said Harlan L.T. Wendell, the 53yearold former director of public affairs for the big chemical corporation. So why did he chuck this post at the peak of his career and go over to the Ford Motor Company last month to assume the title of executive director of a newly created communication policy and planning staff?

title: New York City Is Getting Funds For 10,000 Summer Youth Jobs
description: New York City will get $2.1 million more in Federal funds to hire an additional 10,000 more youths this summer, Representative Fred W. Richmond, secretary of the New York State Congressional delegation, has annnounced.

title: Delay in Carter Border Plan Laid To Unions and Hispanics' Fears
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  Opposition by unions, fears among Hispanic groups and Congressional complaints of heavy work load are responsible for new delay in President Carter's plan to create a new Border Management Servira.

title: Private Lives
description: WE are about 20 minutes east of Heraklion, on the northern coast of Crete, in whitewashed bungalow with a veranda at which the Mediterranean laps, a kilometer or two away from an island populated entirely by goats. The stars show off. By the light of the Big Dipper, the female children play backgammon and the male child reads Zorba the Greek. The female adult is across the road, buying a bag peaches and a bottle of wine. The male adult is deep into ouzo and rhansodizing.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, waiting to see how the Treasury decides today to refinance $7.6 billion of notes that will mature Aug. 15; held their ground yesterday. In the afternoon, two recently marketed issues of corporate bonds were freed to trade, and they stayed close to their initial prices.

title: News Summary
description: The arms embargo against Turkey would be repealed under a vote by the Senate, which also sought to link any future American military aid to that country to progress on a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus problem. The vote on the conditional lifting of the embargo was 57 to 42. It came on an amendment to the $2.9 billion international security assistance bill. The amendment was proposed by Senator George McGovern. [Page 1, Column 6].

title: Army Recruiters Ousted For Enlisting Dropouts
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 25 (UPI)  Seven Army recruiters in Michigan have been relieved of duty for knowingly enlisting a dozen high school dropouts with bogus diplomas, an Army spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Steel Earnings Rebound
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the industry leader, announced yesterday a sharp rebound in earnings  a 53.7 percent rise  for the second quarter, giving support to expectations that the quarter will be one of the most profitable since the industry went into a slump three years ago. In addition, Armco, the No. 5 company, reported a 71 percent rise.

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTON THE honeymoon is obviously over for G. William Miller after a blissful four months as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Now the test looms on how he will get along with the Administration, Congress, the financial world, the international Bankers and the public.

title: Report by a Missouri Man Suggests Plotters Sought Murder of Dr. King
description: ST. LOUIS, July 25  A 46yearold man here has, told the House assassination committee that in late 1966 or early 1967 he turned down an offer of $50,000 to arrange the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin. Luther King Jr.

title: Associated Press
description: TWO HURT IN AIR MISHAP: A North Central Airlines passenger plane lies in a corn field after crashlanding ontakeoff from Kalamazoo, Mich. airport. Most of the 43 passengers and crewmen walked away; two were hospitalized.

title: Paris Fashion: Craziness, Then the Calm
description: PARIS, July 25  Andr Courreges and Emanuel Ungaro seem to be competing for the European rights to do the clothes for road companies of The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.

title: Soviet Rejects Appeal by Begun
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (Reuters)  A Moscow court rejected an appeal by a Jewish activist, losif Begun, today against the carrying out of his sentence of three years' internal exile on charges of violating internal passport laws, Jewish sources here said.

title: House Panel Proposes Tax Waiver On InflationCaused Capital Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House Ways and Means Committee unexpectedly approved a proposal today to waive taxes on capital gains resulting from inflation.

title: NEW LAIN RESTRICTS DELINQUENTS VISITS
description: ALBANY, July 25  A bill that would severely restrict home visits by juvenile delinquents in state custody has been signed by Governor Carey, his office announced today.

title: REPORTER IS DENIED AN APPEAL SPEEDUP
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25  The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today by a 5to1 vote to speed the usually long appellate process and hear appeals now by the New York Times Company and Times reporter, M. A. Farber, of their contemptofcourt convictions that were handed down yesterday.

title: Washington Transit Service Restored
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  Bus and subway service in Washington returned to near normal for tonight's rush hour,after a sixday strike, and in Detroit, negotiators for the city and the sanitation union conferred all day today to avert strike threatened for tomorrow over forced overtime.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The Government announced today that it was relaxing the requirements for school districts to obtain $34.7 million in Federal desegregation aid.

title: Berkey Reaches Accord on Loans
description: Berkey Photo Inc. said that it had concluded a restructured agreement with its lending banks with respect to its $35.2 million of debt, of which $31.5 million is long term and $3.7 million is short term.

title: Chancellor Orders School Board To Reinstate Its Superintendent
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday ordered Community School Board 5 in Central Harlem to reinstate William Hall immediately as its Community District superintendent. Mr. Hall was summarily aismissea by a majority of tlp local board last week.

title: Advertising
description: ONE of the more successful television advertising campaigns around  the one about people who listen to E. F. Hutton & Company  is going to get a major print test beginning Friday.

title: Man Told to Explain Why He Can't Give Marrow to Ill Cousin
description: PITTSBURGH, July 25 (UPI)  judge today ordered a man to file a written explanation why he should not be forced to donate some of his potentially lifesaving bone marrow to a criticallY ill cousin.

title: SENATE ACTS TO LIFT ARMS BAN ON TURKS, BUT ADDS WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The Senate voted today to repeal the 42monthold embargo on American military assistance for Turkey but tried to link any future aid for that country to progress on a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus problem.

title: Uniroyal Chemical To Build in Brazil
description: The Uniroyal Chemical Company announced plans to build a multimilliondollar plant in Rio Claro, Brazil. Edward J. Geise, vice presidentinternational operations, said the new plant would manufacture a broad range of antioxidants, including Naugard Q, Naugard SP, Aminox and Octamine.

title: The New York Times/ Eeward Hausner
description: FINDING BEAUTY IN THE SOUTH BRONX: Mayor Koch commending residents of Dawson Street for rehabilitation of homes during walking tour through area yes terday. The Mayor commented, If we are going to save the nouses we have to have private ownership. Earlier, he dedicated flower garden in park on Longwood Avenue.

title: William H. Cowley, 79; Was Stanford Professol
description: William H. Cowley, the David Jacks professor of higher education at Stanford University from 1945 until his retirement in 1968, died Sunday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: Consolidated Edison's Earnings Slide 15.1%
description: Secondquarter earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York fell 15.1 percent from the comparable period of 1977, the company reported yesterday, to $51.6 million, or 65 cents a share, from $60.8 million, or 81 cents a share. Revenues rose to $688 million from $682.24 million a year earlier.

title: Postal Workers Dislike the job 's  Monotony
description: CHICAGO, July 25  Sweepsweep goes a metal arm passing in front of Mrs. Clorinda Sykes 's face.

title: China Is Target Of Import Curb
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The International Trade Commission recommended to President Carter today that he impose import quotas for three years on wooden clothespins produced in China, the first such sanctions against a Communist nation.

title: A Losing Tumult Over Capital Gains
description: It is symptomatic of a national confusion of purpose that Congress has decided to focus the.debate over national tax policy on the capital gains tax. Such preoccupation tends to prevent a clear discussion of the alternatives on how best to cut taxes while combating inflation and stimulating investment. And it has left Washington arguing over shaky computer studies about the nation 's stake in any major reduction of capital gains taxes.

title: Ban Sought on 362 Slot Machines In Casino Until They Pay Better
description: TRENTON, July 25  A deputy state attorney general asked the Casino Control Commission today to bar. 362 of the 1,051 slot machines in Resorts International's Atlantic City casino until they were adjusted to pay out more than they do now.

title: Canadian Pilot Killed in Germany
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, July 25 (Reuters) . A Canadian Air Force pilot was killed today when his Starfighter crashed into the woods near the town of Kiikelsau, halfway between here and Wilrzburg, the poliCe reported. The pilot, who was not immediately identified, had been on a training flight.

title: Maj, Gen. Alden R. Crawford, 77; Headed a GuidedMissile Section
description: Maj. Gen. Alden R. Crawford, formerly of the United States Air Force, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Northport. L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Dayan Briefs Staff on Change
description: JERUSALEM, July 25  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan briefed members of his staff today on a slight change in Israel's stand regarding the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, aimed at easing some of the strain that has developed between Israel and the United States.

title: House Panel Proposes Tax Waiver On InflationCaused Capital Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House Ways and Means Committee unexpectedly improved a proposal today to waive taxes on capital gains resulting from inflation.

title: `Showplace Mosque Planned on East Side
description: Led by the major Arab oil exporters, a coalition of Islamic countries will finance a project to build the city 's first mosque on Manhattan 's East Side. Although other buildings in the city are used as Islamic houses of worship, the domed, granite shrine will be the first designed for that purpose.

title: Inc New York Times/Jim Simpson
description: FESTIVAL IN HOBOKEN: Parishioners of St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Hoboken carrying a 600pound, lifesize statue of the church's patron saint during the saint's feast day yesterday. The procession was accompanied an outdoor festival featuring music, rides and Italian food.

title: MAX GREEDY
description: DENVER, July 26 (AP)  Max Greedy, a retired news editor of The Rocky Mountain News and an organizer of the Newspaper Guild, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack at Colorado General Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: A New Production Company
description: A new theatrical production company, MPM Enterprises, has been formed by Arthur Penn, the director; Martin Manulis, the producer and director, and Priscilla Morgan, formerly of the William Morris Agency. The three, whose office is at 1860 Broadway, are now reading manuscripts and talking to authors about possible productions, Miss Morgan said.

title: Early Insertion of Embryo Into Womb Is Linked to Successful Gestation
description: LONDON, July 26  Scientists applauded, English churchmen nodded qualified approval and the British press turned somersaults today to welcome the world's first baby born from an egg fertilized in a laboratory.

title: Lawsuit by Dissidents To Block Transit Pact Rejected in U.S. Court
description: An attempt by dissident transit workers to overturn their union's new contract agreement with the New York City Transit Authority was rejected yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Early Insertion of Embryo Into Womb Is Linked to Successful Gestation
description: LONDON, July 26  Scientists applauded, English churchmen nodded a qualified approval and the British press turned somersaults today to welcome the world's first baby born from an egg fertilized in a laboratory.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: THE Medal of Freedom was presented by President Carter yesterday to Arthur J. Goldberg for distinguished service as a Cabinet officer, Supreme Court Justice and chief delegate to the United Nations. Mr. Carter praised Mr. Goldberg, who helped draft United Nations Resolution 242, a 1967 directive calling for an Israeli withdrawal from Arab territory in return for peace. Mr. Carter called the resolution the unshakable basis for ultimate agreement in the Middle East. Last week President Anwar elSadat of Egypt put much of the blame for continued Israeli occupation of Arab lands on Mr. Goldberg's shoulders, but Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said that the timing of yesterday's award, the highest given to a civilian, had nothing to do with the Egyptian President's criticism of Mr. Goldberg as a Zionist. Mr. Goldberg, who is 69 years old, has served as Secretary of Labor and is a onetime Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. He will soon retire from his latest Government job, as an ambassador at large at the Belgrade conference on human rights.

title: Associated Press
description: MOSCOW, July 26  The wife of a prominent Jewish activist received a suspended prisoncamp sentence today for her part in unfurling a banner from an apartment balcony declaring, Let us out to our son in Israel.

title: 161 INSPECTORS HIRED BY KOCH TO COMBAT AGENCY CORRUPTION
description: Mayor Koch hired 161 new inspectors yesterday for an overseer program meant to root out corruption and incompetence in 30 New York City agencies.

title: Folk: Susan Reed Sings of Auvergne
description: THE Washington Square Music Festival held annually in the park at the lower end of Fifth Avenue has now completed twofifths of its 1978 fiveconcert schedule, but it hasn't appeared outdoors yet. The first event was held according to plan at Grace Church. The second, presented on Tuesday night, was transferred to Eisner and Lubin Auditorium by a threat of rain that never materialized.

title: Hers
description: ACCORDING to people who claim to be psychic, spiritual forces, like tides and winds, converge at Hawaii. We attract refugee lamas from Tibet, and kahunas, people with special knowledge, still work here. Some kahunas say they see tree spirits fly from branch to branch; the various winds and rains are spirits too; sharks and rocks have spirits. If ancestors and sages travel on supernatural errands between China and the Americas, they must land here in transit, nothing but ocean for thousands of miles around. In the old days, though, they probably stopped more often, before the sandalwood trees were cut down.

title: 5 Counts Cut In Gerard Case
description: MINEOLA, L.I. July 26 A Nassau County Court judge today dismissed five of 11 counts of an indictment against Dr. Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian charged with switching the race horses Cinzano and Lebon in a betting coup.

title: Califano Asks Medical Specialist's To Urge Public to Get Flu Shots
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today appealed to medical specialists to help him rebuild public confidence in flu immunization, which was shattered by the swine flu fiasco in 1976.

title: The Times Sets Dividend
description: The board of directors of The New York Times Company yesterday declared a regular quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock; payable Sept. 26 to holders of record Sept. 8. A regular. nmirterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 percent cumulative prior preference stock was also declared, payable Oct. 2 to shareholders of record Sept. 8. The company's Class A common stock is traded on the American Stock Exchange under the:symbol NYT.A.

title: Trade Gap Of U.S. Cut 50% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Department of Commerce reported today that the nation's trade deficit had been sliced in half in June, a development that brought quick expressions of pleasure from spokesmen for the Carter Administration.

title: Carey Planning to Appoint Black To State Financial Control Board
description: Governor Carey will appoint Gilroye A. Griffin Jr., a vice president at CBS Inc., as a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board, aides to the Governor said yesterday. Mr. Griffin would be the first black member named to the board since it was created in 1975.

title: How Bank Allegedly Hid Profits
description: Court papers filed Monday by a dismissed officer of Citibank charge that New York City's largest commercial bank employed two sets of books in order to minimize its foreignexchange earnings in Europe and shift the profits to its taxhaven branch in the Bahamas.

title: Ethiopia Claims First Big Victory in Eritrea in 3 Years
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26  Ethiopia says that its troops have gained their first major victory over Eritrean rebels in three years, with the recapture of the important supply town of Tessenei close to the Sudanese border.

title: 2 Champion Chess Duelists Use Seconds, and Thirds, Too
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 26 Their names and faces are not well known. They labor behind the scenes. They are there to blame if things go wrong, but they get none of the glory if they go right. They must be peptalkers, excusemakers, game analysts, alter egos, devil's advocates and, in the throes of crisis, tireless and trusted friends.

title: Bloom Insists He ack Out of Battk
description: The accent is modified Brooklyn. The centerpiece of the campaign is a New Dealstyle, pump priming program. The prefered style of politics is old fashioned  the politics of loyalty and of friendhelpingfriend. For the reformers and their works, there is disdain; for feminists a auick dismissal.

title: 161 INSPECTORS HIRED BY KOCH TO COMBAT AGENCY CORRUPTION
description: Mayor Koch hired 161 new inspectors yesterday for an overseer program meant to root out corruption and incompetence in 30 New York City agenCies.

title: Economic Scene
description: ONE byproduct of Proposition 13 and its aftermath may be a reconsideration of some general principles of taxation. Most of the drastic measures proposed  a cap on spending, circuit breakers for property taxes, limiting total tax revenues to some percentage of total income  lead readily to such questions as What is a good tax? What should taxes accomplish? and Who should pay taxes?

title: Koch Appoints a Group To Ease City's Tensions
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the formation of a 93member committee of religious and community leaders to ease racial, religious and ethnic tensions throughout the city.

title: U.S. to Tighten Computer Security to Halt Abuses
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Carter Administration will move next week to tighten security over the Federal Government's farflung network of computers to protect individual privacy and to prevent fraud and misuse.

title: Dr. Mary C. Henderson Named Theater Curator
description: Dr. Mary C. Henderson, associate curator of the Museum of the City of New York, has been named curator of the theater collection, succeeding Theodore H. Fetter, who will be a consultant.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Senator Challenges 2 Byrne Appointments
description: TRENTON, July 26  Senatorial courtesy, the unwritten rule that allows state senators to block gubernatorial appointments from the senators home counties, will be invoked in a new dispute between Governor Byrne and member of his nartv.

title: Justice Dept. Supports Detroit Police Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  In its first official interpretation of the Supreme Court's Bakke'decision, the Justice Department has urged approval of an affirmative action program that sets strict. numerical quotas for the promotion of blacks in the Detroit police department.

title: Court Bars Cutting Off AutoPolicy Laggards
description: TRENTON, July 26 (UPI)  In decision expected to aid many New Jersey drivers, the Supreme Court ruled today that autoinsurance companies must cover residents whose policies are canceled for failure to pay nremium installment.

title: Ford Profit Rises 1.8%, Sales, 22.7%
description: DETROIT, July 26  The Ford Motor Company reported today that secondquarter profits had surpassed last year's secondquarter record by scant 1.8 percent.

title: POSTAL EMPLOYEES RETURNING TO JOBS
description: Postal workers in New Jersey and California who began a wildcat strike last weekend in protest to a tentative contract were returning to their jobs in increasing numbers yesterday. But leaders of the American Postal Workers Union in New Jersey said the action did not represent change in attitude, Instead, the local union officials said they were urging their members to go back to work because they felt they could more effectively organize opposition to the tentative agreement from within the postal facilities.

title: Egyptians Order Israel's Mission To Leave Today
description: JERUSALEM, July 26  Prime. Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that Israel had been ordered by Egypt to withdraw, by tomorrow, its military mission based in Egypt since January.

title: The U.N. TODAY
description: Committee on the elimination of racial discrimination  10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: SENATE VOTE ANGERS GREECE AND CYPRUS
description: Anger in Cyprus and Greece and mixed reaction in Turkey were the responses to the United States Senate's decision to lift a threeyear arms emharm against the Turks.

title: Associated Press
description: STATE'S NEWEST MILLIONAIRE: Cathy Jones, facing camera at center, being hugged by members of her family in Oceanport yesterday after she won first prize in the Lucky Horoscope Lottery. Miss Jones, a 20yearold Trenton factory worker, will receive $1,000 a week for life, or at least $1 million.

title: Bus Driver Says He May Appeal
description: The Staten Island bus driver who refused to take out a bus that had a rearview mirror on only the left side because he considered it unsafe says he may appeal the recommendation of a referee for a written reprimand on his personnel record. The June 5 action of the driver, James A. Kerrigan of Stapleton, resulted in his emergence as a kind of hero to several thousand Staten Island commuters.

title: Prosecutor Set to Rest Case Today In Murder Trial of Dr. Jascalevich
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 26  The prosecution's 56th and final witness in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich completed testimony today, and the state prepared to rest its case.

title: New Paper for Visitors in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP)  A new Englishlanguage newspaper called Moscow News International appeared in the Soviet capital this week. The eightpage paper is being published twice a week by the editorial board of Moscow News, which already publishes a weekly in English.

title: Carey Acts to Expand Suffolk Referendums
description: ALBANY, July 26  Governor Carey has signed into law a bill that could make Suffolk the first county in the state where voters could initiate their own laws through public referendums, the Governor's office announced today.

title: Scientists and Sages
description: The number of general conclusions one can come to about the universe, or about any significant part of it, is usually limited, and the various sages of the world, past and present, have (with their eyes closed and their intuitions working) come up with every one of them.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ROCKDALE. The Growth of an American Village in the Early Industrial Revolution: An account of the coming of the machines, the making of a new way of life in the mill hamlets, the triumph of evangelical capitalists over socialists and infidels, and the transformation of the workers into Christian soldiers in a cottonmanufacturing district in Pennsylvania in the years before and during the Civil War. By Anthony F.C. Wallace. Technical drawings by Robert Howard. Illustrated. 553 pages. Knopf. $17.50.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: MY TRICK: These card players in.the small park on CresCent Avenue and Adam's Place in the Bronx seemed oblivious to. the World passing around them. The weather remained cool yesterday, with intermittent sunshine.

title: A State Justice Outlaws Westchester Rent Rules
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 26 (UPI) State Supreme Court justice has ruled tharthe 197778 Westchester County rent guidelines violated state law.

title: Tour Company Ailing
description: The Nptionwide Leisure Corporation, one of the country's largest vacation tour operators, is in financial difficulty and is expected soon to take steps to reorganize, possibly under the Federal bankruptcy statutes, according to authoritative trade sources.

title: The New York Times/ David Strick
description: LOS ANGELES  The nation's largest supermarket chain, Safeway Stores, has entered the catalogue business with 18 household items priced competitively with the catalogue giants.

title: Justice Dept. Supports Detroit Police Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  In its first official interpretation of the Supreme Court's Bakke decision, the Justice Department has urged approval of an affirmative action program that sets strict numerical quotas for the promotion of blacks in the Detroit police department. The Court's decision last month did not require public agencies to be colorblind, the department argued, and did not disturb previous rulings that required such agencies to take positive steps to remedy the effects of past discrimination.

title: Business Records
description: L STE NA WARREN, 770 Riverside Drive, N.Y ??? $2.031: assets. none

title: Chinaglia Sets Mark as Cosmos Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 26  The Cosmos rolled to their 23d victory of the season at Giants Stadium tonight and moved into a strong position of accumulating the mostpoints in the North American Soccer League.

title: NEW &
description: Stained glass is beautiful and romantic and can change the atmosphere of a room as the light coming through the colored glass changes from bright soft. But stained glass can be costly. So Pat and Debbie Ward of Canterbury Panes are doing handleaded Lucite that looks like stained glass. It's not only less expensive than glass but also lighter weight. They will design to order windows, panels, shower doors, ceilings, headboards, lighting fixtures  anything that would be made in stained glass. They will use pale or bright colors, Art Nouveau modern designs; they're young and willing. Prices are $10 to $20 a square foot. Estimates are free. Call 8777910.

title: A Gardener Heeds The. Call of the Soil
description: WHEN I was small, dreamed of large things: magic carpets, personal press conferences, an invitation to have my feet immortalized in the cement outside Grauman's Chinese Theater. These things did not materialize. When I grew up, I continued to dream of large things: a change of circumstances, absolution for sins, the chance to be in a room full of people where everybody understood exactly what everybody else was saying. These things, for the most part, did not materialize either.

title: Associated Press
description: A Londoner looking at a photo of newly born Louise Brown on the front page of The Daily Mail

title: Sound
description: THIS writer can't resist casting himself in the role of a White House correspondent, and having just got word about what stereo components are shortly to be installed in the Presidential quarters, let me go to press.

title: Order Barring Reporters From Jurors Overturned
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI)  An order barring reporters from talking to jurors after the Seattle trial of two selfstyled revolutionaries was overturned today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH 11 (Cunard). Left Southampton July 22, due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Cable TV Franchise For Queens Gains
description: After several years of negotiations, public hearings and procedural delays, the city Bureau of Franchises has recommended a 20year franchise contract for a cabletelevision system to serve Queens.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 27, 1978 Repeal of economic sanctions against Rhodesia was rejected by the Senate. However, it adopted a compromise provision that, in effect, would require President Carter to lift the sanctions, but only after he had determined that Rhodesian Government had been established by free elections under impartial international observation and that it had committed itself to negotiate with rebels. [Page I, Column 6.]

title: Grounding the Air Cartel for Good
description: The International Air Transport Association (I.A.T.A.), the airfare cartel, recently opened the door a crack to competition. It will no longer require airlines lo participate in collective ratesetting to enjoy its essential housekeeping and clearinghouse services. The decision is less an endorsement of competition than a reluctant admission of division among carriers flying the Atlantic. It does not guarantee that fares will henceforth be determined in the marketplace; most airlines remain deeply suspicious of free enterprise. The task of putting an end to I.A.T.A.'s pricefixing for once and all is still up to the United States Government.

title: Realistic Touch Haunts Beer Ad
description: MILWAUKEE, July 26 (UPI) The Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee has a television commercial on its hands that might be a touch too realistic.

title: Bethlehem Steel Net Rose 143.7%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel company, yesterday reported that its earnings for the second quarter rose 193.7 percent to $84.8 million, or $1.95 a share, from $34.8 million, or 80 cents a share, for the comparable period in 1977.

title: CURBS ON RHODESIA UPHELD BY SENATE, BUT CONDITIONALLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Senate rejected a move to repeal economic sanctions against Rhodesia today, but then decisively adopted a compromise measure setting conditions under which the President could be required to lift the sanctions in the future.

title: Schultze Rejects Slainmifig Money. Brakes
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Carter Administration flatly rejected today foreign advice that the fiscal and monetary brakes be slammed on harder in the United. States to enhance progress against inflation.

title: All of the South Changing Planes at Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, July 26  I don't know where I'm going when I die, most Southern air travelers have said at one time or another, but one thing is sure: I'll change planes at Atlanta.

title: Judge Upholds Transplant Denial
description: PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP)  The cousin of a dying man whose diseased bone marrow will not produce blood cells cannot be required to submit to a transplant, a judge ruled today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday incorrectly identified the site of a smelter of the St. Joe Zinc Company. The site is Monaca, Pa.

title: Increase Is Criticized
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.,July 25  The Suffolk County Legislature voted today to grant pay increases costing $1.25 million a year to 400 deputy sheriffs and correctional officers.

title: Events Today
description: MONTEITH AND RAND, comedy team. At the Theater East, 211 East 60th Street, 7.

title: Trash Trucks Escorted in Strike
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 26 (AP) Policemen escorted, garbage trucks on their rounds here today to protect newly hired sanitation workers against violence by more than 175 dog catchers, airport maintenance workers and sanitation workers dismissed in a strike.

title: Karpov Is Rising to New Heights In Defense of World Chess Title
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 26 (Reuters)  The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, still struggling to prove his superiority over Viktor Korchnoi after four drawn games, decided today he must take a new look at the match  from a raised chair.

title: The New York Times/John Grossman
description: HOUSTON, July 26  Rising out of the green, treeless coastal plain in the distant haze, they look like rockets poised for flight. In fact, they are modern creations of another sort: the characteristic towers of a gleaming new petrochemiccal plant, owned by the Amoco Chemical Company, on Chocolate Bayou, 28 miles south of Houston.

title: South Korea Is Assured On US. Defense Role
description: SAN DIEGO, July 26  Defense Secretary Harold Brown assured the South Korean Government today that the Carter Administration was committed to the security and wellbeing of the Republic of Korea and that the approaching withdrawal of American combat troops would be carried out only if the military situation warranted.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS DIFFER ON IMPLANT
description: Roman Catholic leaders criticized all forms of artificial insemination yesterday, but many Jewish, Moslem and Protestant figures endorsed a laboratoryinduced conception so long as both husband and wife were the parents of the child.

title: Doctors Isolate a Human Gene, Allowing BirthDefect Detection
description: BOSTON, July 26  For the first time, doctors have been able to identify a single gene among the millions in a human cell and can now see whether an unborn baby is missing certain parts of its genetic blueprint, a team of researchers reported today.

title: Taxpayers in Protest
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 26  A taxpayer's suit challenging the part of the state's Taylor Law that requires mandatory binding arbitration in negotiations with policemen and firemen was started today by the Taxpayers Union of Long Island.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart
description: LOOKING in on Mostly Mozart's preconcert recital on Tuesday night, a professionally serious visitor could only be impressed by the cool, relaxed atmosphere that pervaded Avery Fisher Hall. Most of the main floor was populated  there is no reserved seating for these preludes  and the auaience struck one as somewhat more attentive and musically sophisticated than the larger gathering for the formal program later in the night. In any event, the earlybird bargain hunters happened upon a particularly pleasant event. The German pianist Christoph Eschenbach began with two Schubert Impromptus (No. 3 in Gflat and No. 4 in Aflat), which he held to a rather small scale, stressing their intimacy.

title: Doctors to a Baby Who Made Medical History
description: LONDON, July 26  The two men whose skill and ingenuity have achieved the first known birth of a baby conceived outside the body of a woman are acknowledged pioneers in their highly specialized fields.

title: Dance: Thematic Salute
description: CAROL JOY is a soprano and Lucinda Ransom is a dancer. But Tuesday evening at the City University Graduate Center Mall they did more than sing and dance. Their Salute to the AfricanAmerican Wonhan, an offering of the Clark Center Dance Festival. inenrnn.

title: Utke's Mysterious Departure
description: When Sunkist Growers, the country's largest agricultural cooperative, with 7,500 members, announced last Thursday that Roy Utke, its president, had resigned for personal reasons, some eyebrows were raised in the business community. Mr. Utke, 57 years old, had been head of the citrus producers organization for seven years, but had recently come under attack from some of his members because, of his Far Eastern marketing policies.

title: GainsTax Cut Is Stressed by Long
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Senator Russell B. Long, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, predicted today that his committee will recommend a large cut in the tax rates on capital gains.

title: Mine Union Leaders Quash a Bid To Remove Miller From Presidency
description: DENVER, July 26  Top officials of the United Mine Workers voted overwhelmingly today to quash on technical grounds a rankandfile drive to force recall election of Arnold R. Miller, the controversial U.M.W. president who was elected to a second fiveyear term last June.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday incorrectly identified the site of smelter of the St. Joe zinc Company. The site is Monaca, Pa.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Will Borrow $7 Billion Next Week
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it would borrow $2.6 billion of additional cash next week to help finance the Federal Government's deficit as sells notes and bonds to refinance $4.38 billion of publicly held securities that will come due Aug. 15.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Communications Commission heard clashing arguments yesterday whether WNET, the public television station, is ignoring its home town, Newark.

title: A Wright Revival
description: THE moment a workman comes in here, he takes one look around and says, Oh, this house is one of his, isn't it? Then he groans and lets you know how much more work it's going to mean for him, said Jeannette Fields, sitting the living room of her 77yearold house.

title: Clark Streak Ends at 26 As Giants: Lose to Cards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) Silvio Martinez of the St. Louis Cardinals beat the San Francisco Giants, 21, with; a twohitter today and stopped Jack Clark's hitting streak at 26 games.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters Do Not a Lobby Make
description: After vanishing in committee for two months, the lobby disclosure bill that has already passed the House is suddenly reborn in the Senate. The Governmental Affairs Committee is now preparing a draft of the measure that would strengthen the requirements for annual registration and quarterly reports from major lobbying groups. Given the recent examples of unseemly mtluencepeddling and corrupt contact between lobbyists and legislators, the more known about organized counseling the better.

title: World News Briefs
description: LISBON, July 26 (Reuters)  Portugal's outgoing Foreign Minister, Vitor Machado, said today that he was confident a solution would be found to the nation's political crisis, which arose when his conservative party left the governing coalition with the Socialist Party of Prime Minister Mario Soares.

title: Dance: Two Premieres At the Jacob's Pillow
description: LEE, Mass. IT is so natural to think of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival as an internationally known series of summerlong performances that sometimes one loses sight of the fact that it is a learning institution as well.

title: A.T &T. Critical of Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company took issue today with provisions in a House bill that call for the divestiture of its Western Electric subsidiary and that might jeopardize the company's national telephone switching network in the name of competition.

title: The New York Times/ Pascal Ilinous
description: THE most important piece of furniture in Francois Catroux's office on the stylish Faubourg St. Honore is the telephone. And next to it sits a battery of antacid preparations and headache remediespart of the everyday equipment of an interior designer with a foot on either side of the Atlantic.

title: Justice Finessed
description: LOS ANGELES  In this space last week, I railed at the way the House ethics committee  given media respectability by sacred cowboy Leon Jaworski  failed to get the testimony of the former South Korean Ambassador Kim Dong Jo and thereby let a dozen senior Congressional felons go free. Embarrassed, the House has shown new interest in Mr. Kim.

title: CHANGE IS GRANTED IN MEADOWS ZONING
description: SECAUCUS, July 26  The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission approved !today a zoning change within the 32squaremile Meadowlands district that would permit development of part of a 700acre tract formerly designated for marshland preservation.

title: CURBS ON RHOETA UPHELD BY SENATE, BUT CONDITIONALLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Senate rejected a move to repeal economic sanctions against Rhodesia today, but then decisively adopted a compromise measure setting conditions under which the President could be required to lift the sanctions in the future.

title: Exxon Chemical Switches Office
description: The Exxon Chemical Company announced that it had dropped its plans to relocate its headquarters staff of 130 employees from New York City to proposed new building in Fairfield, Conn., and would move instead to leased facilities in Darien. Conn.

title: Bolivian Says Elections Could. Be Held in 1980 If Reforms Are Made
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 26  Gen. Juan Pereda Asbfin, Bolivia's new President, said today that he would be prepared to hold new general elections in 18 months if the electoral law and registry of voters could be reformed in time.

title: Vilas Seeded First
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 26 Guillermo Vilas, who will be seeking his second straight success here, was seeded No. 1 today for next week's $75,000 tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. The tournament runs July 31 to Aug. 6.

title: Fernandez and Escalera Victors in Garden Bouts
description: Alfredo Escalera of Puerto Rico did the expected, but Vilomar Fernandez did the unexpected and completely surprised Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua last night in 10round lightweight fights at Madison Square Garden.

title: Experts Say the LaborLaw Bill Is Still Alive but Not at All Well
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The bitterly contested legislation to revise the national labor law is still alive, but only, according to Congressional experts, by grace of artificial life support systems.

title: Arts Festival Slated at Ancient Luxor
description: Byron Janis, the pianist, Dizzy Gillespie and his jazz group and actors from the Yale Repertory Theater are among the Western performers who will appear Oct. 15 to Oct. 20 at an international festival at Luxor. The town is an archeological site beside the Nile in southern Egypt.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Precious metals futures prices reacted sharply yesterday to the smaller than expected national trade deficit for last month, which was given as $1.6 billion. The trade had expected a duplication of last May's deficit of $2.2 billion.

title: Italian Reds Will Continue Pact With Government
description: ROME, July 26  The leadership of the Italian Communist Party decided today to continue its de facto alliance with the ruling Christian Democrats and other nonMarxist parties despite expressions of criticism from the party's rank and file.

title: Carey Signs a Measure Abolishing New York Board of Water Supply
description: ALBANY, July 26  Governor. Carey today signed a bill abolishing the New York City Board of Water Supply, which had been criticized for years as a political patronage dumping ground by mayors, legislators and good government groups who found themselves Powerless to end it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: It is provident that former White House drug abuse fighter Dr. Peter G. Bourne has been hoist with his own petard. Had Dr. Bourne dutifully given his administrative assistance, Ellen J. Metsky, a properly completed prescription with her own name on it, and had she personlly had it filled, she would still enjoy anonymity  or would she?

title: Martin Is Still Their Man, Fans Chant
description: With Billy Martin gone as their manager and Reggie Jackson sitting on the bench as the heavy, the Yankees returned to a divided house last night.

title: Former Nazi Entitled To Keep Citizenship, Judge in Florida Rules
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 26 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that Feodor Fedorenko could keep the United States citizenship he won by concealing his past as a guard at Treblinka, the Nazi death camp.

title: CASINO IS REBUFFED IN SLOT MACHINE BID
description: TRENTON, July 26 Resorts International suffered its first major setback at the hands of the state's Casino Control Commission today when it had to withdraw an application for 305 more slot machines for its Atlantic City casino.

title: E.P.A. Scores Bids to Cut Cost of Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that attempts by President Carter's antiinflation team to influence the cost of regulations were sometimes made too late and with too little understanding of laws meant to protect publie health.

title: British Aid Venture In Microelectronics
description: LONDON, July 26  In a crash program to establish a microelectronics industry in Britain, the Government has teamed up with American technical pioneers to create a new company that is expected to challenge the world leaders by the early 1980's.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 26  For the first time in the history of the game, the life master pair championship, which has been contested for almost half a century, has been won by a pair of women players.

title: Associated Press
description: ACTIVIST FREED: Marlya Slepak in Moscow after she received a suspended sentence. Page A3.

title: Suspect in Policeman's Slaying Will Undergo Psychiatric Tests
description: GREEN RIVER, Wyo., July 26 (AP) Ed Cantrell, the suspended Rock Springs Public Safety Director charged with murdering an undercover narcotics agent, was committed yesterday to the state Mental Hospital for observation.

title: Panel to Visit Vietnam to Unite American Fathers With Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that a fivemember commission would soon visit Vietnam to arrange for the reunion of several children separated from their American fathers after the 1975 Communist takeover.

title: Vermont Jazz Festival Planned for Weekend
description: The Third Annual Vermont Jazz Festival will be held, rain or shine, this weekend at Killington Mountain, the operators of the festival have announced.

title: Yanks Win on Piniella Hit
description: Lou Piniella, who played for Bob Lemon in Kansas City and has predicted positive results under Billy Martin's replacement, got his old and new manager off to a positive Yankee Stadium start last night.

title: Siamese Twins Are Separated
description: DALLAS, July 26 (UPI)  Officials at Parkland Hospital today announced the separation of Siamese twins by surgery. Officials said that the 6weekold twin girls were joined at the chest, stomach and pelvis. The operation began at 7:30 A.M. and lasted several hours.

title: ROBERT H. TURTLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Robert H. Turtle, a lawyer and Government advisor on medical and behavioral research, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home here. He was 40 years old.

title: Clamours, Airlines Fuel Stocks
description: Glamour stocks and airlines issues continued to power the market higher yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead through a chart resistance level. Trading volume was heavy from the opening bell. Favorable earnings reports and dividend increases by large companies played their part in a favorable equity environment.

title: I Bomb to London Tories Defused
description: LONDON, July 26 (Reuters)  The police defused a parcel bomb delivered today to the London headquarters of the opposition Conservative Party. About 100 people were evacuated from the building while policemen dealt with the bomb, wrapped in brown paper. No group was reported to have claimed responsibiliy.

title: Cohen Group Reaches Agreement to Purchase Nets
description: A nineman group represented by Alan N. Cohen, former president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, agreed in principle yesterday to buy the financially troubled New Jersey Nets.

title: Misleading Advertising On Drugs Laid to Searle
