description: G. D. Searle & Company has been accused by the Food and Drug Administration of misleading advertising for its two most important drugs, Aldactone and Aldactazide, it was disclosed yes. terday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar continued to plummet to new lows against the Japanese yen, but gained against European currencies on foreign exchange markets Wednesday, as news of the lowest monthly United States trade deficit in more than a year was announced.

title: Senate. Voting Today On Loan Guarantees
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Senate put off until tomorrow a vote on the compromise bill for loan guarantees for New York City. It is expected to be enacted when it reaches the floor.

title: Jet Turns Back After Takeoff
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) Pan American World Airways jumbo jet carrying 333 passengers to London lost power in an engine on takeoff and had to dump about 100,000 pounds of jet fuel before it turned around and landed safely at San Francisco International Airport. No passengers were hurt, officials said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In our entrance hall there are some lovely old octagonalshaped clay tiles that havO been accumulating wax, grime and city goo since 1909. Is there any way we can pink theiti6 their original pale pink and red color, and is there a sealer for these porous Mrs. J. P.:C.,. New York City. I assume that by now youhaVe A. tried scrubbing with a strong detergent, but if you haven't, that is the first step. Then try a cornMercial wax removing solution. A final, more drastic step would be washing with a muriatic acid solution, but I would try that in a small corner first. You can buy the acid in paint and hardware stores, then mix it with two to three parts of water in a glass or plastic container, Wear rubber gloves and use a fiber brush to scrub the acid on. Let stand on the surface for about three minutes, then flush off with plain water. If you are satisfied, you can apply a penetrating stOne sealer after the tiles are dry. These scalers are also sold in paint stores, as well as by stone dealers.

title: Woman Seeks $300,000 Over Arrest as a Prostitute
description: A 25yearold woman filed a $300,000 damage suit against New York State and City officials in Federal District Court yesterday charging false arrest, assault and a subsequent coverup attempt by two plainclothes policemen who she says arrested her for prostitution as she walked home from a movie shortly after midnight on July 11 and dragged her through the street by her hair.

title: At Your Service: Finding a Woodcarver
description: THEIR 27thfloor condominium had a spectacular view of the Hudson River, but it wasn't enough for Hubert and Ruth Clapp. They felt the 40foot expanse of glass, together with flat white walls, lacked warmth, charm, a craftsman's touch.

title: Citibank Is Studied By S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the overseas transactions of Citibank, the nation's largest international banker, according to Government officials familiar with the study.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HERE AND THERE Russell Procope, for three deades a saxophonist with Duke Ellington, and most recently with Broadway's Ain't Misbehavin', leads his own quintet at 9 o'clock tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe (6669160), Broadway and 114th Street; no cover or minimum tab.

title: 2 Champion Chess Duelists Use Seconds, and Thirds, Too
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 26 Their names and faces are not well known. They labor behind the scenes. They are there to blame if things go wrong, but they get none of the glory if they go right. They must be peptalkers, excusemakers, game analysts, alter egos, devil's advocates and, in the throes of crisis, tireless and trusted friends.

title: Jazz: Richmond leads M ngus Quintet
description: ALTHOUGH Chlrles Mingus is no longer leading his quintet since his recent stroke  his group has remained together and is playing his music. Under the leadership of Dannie Richmond, who was Mr. Mingus's drummer for most of the last 20 years, the musicians who were with Mr. Mingus until his illnes  Jack Walrath on trumpet, Ricky Ford on tenor saxophone, Bob Neloms, pianist, and Mr. Richmondare playing Mr. Mingus's music at the Village Vanguard through Saturday, with Eddie Gomez taking Mr. Mingus's place on bass.

title: A State Justice Outlaws Westchester Rent Rules
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 26 (UPI)  A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the 197778 Westchester County rent guidelines violated state law.

title: The Porn Blight Spreads
description: The sex supermarket that opened recently across from one of New York City's delights, the Citicorp Center's Market, would be distasteful in any location, but its shabby quality is heightened by its purposeful proximity to the elegant Citicorp complex. This Cluster of shops and open spaces is an oasis where the urban rambler can browse, have a cup of coffee or enjoy five minutes of quiet, alone but not lonely.

title: Egyptians Order Israel's Mission To Leave Today
description: JERUSALEM, July 26 Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that Israel had been ordered by Egypt to withdraw, by tomorrow, its military mission based in Egypt since January.

title: Saudi Oil Exports Up
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia. July 26 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia's exports of crude oil in June rose slightly more than 3 percent to an average of 6.94 million barrels a day compared with May, the official Saudi Press Agency said today. Average daily exports in May were 6.72 million barrels.

title: Group Will Propose Amendment To Curb Spending and Taxation
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  A group of noted economists, former Government officials and business executives announced today that they intended to draft a constitutional amendment to limit spending and taxation powers of local, state and Federal governments.

title: REPORT ON DR. KING MISFILED, F.B.I. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  information concerning an alleged plot to assassinate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. remained unchecked for five years because an agent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's St. Louis field office disregarded a basic regulation concerning the dissemination of criminal information, bureau officials acknowledged today.

title: Right of Way Yielded To Swarming Mayflies
description: PORTAGE, Wis., July 26 (AP) Newly hatched mayflies swarmed onto a bridge over the Wisconsin River, forcing it to be temporarily closed while crews used a roadgrading machine to clear the insects away.

title: Industry into Orbit
description: WASHINGTON  People don't realize the potential of the dawning industrial space age. Like the wagon trains and railroads of the past, the space shuttle will open a new highway to prosperity. Economic development of space by private industry is about to begin.

title: Founder of MCA Is Pioneer of Year
description: Dr. Jules C. Stein, the 82yearold. founder of Music Corporation of America (MCA), who forsook a medical career to assume leadership of the company, has been named 1978 Pioneer of the Year, by the Foundation of the Motion Picture Pinneers.

title: Copper Up At Asarco
description: A major copper producer, Asarco Inc. announced yesterday that it was increasing the price on copper cathodes, the industry's basic product, by a cent to 65 cents a pound, continuing the rebound of severely depressed copper prices that began about a month ago.

title: Police Officer, Slain in West, Buried on L.I.
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y., July 26 Michael A. Rosa once told his sister Sonia that he would never live to be 30 years old. Today, at 29, he was buried here at the Long Island National Cemetery, the victim of a shooting on July 15 in corruptionplagued Rock Springs, Wyo., where he was working as an undercover policeman.

title: Beaths
description: HOFFMANBenlaminOn July 24, 1978. Beloved husband of Elaine; adored lather of David, Robert & Jam es; devoted son of Paula and the late Joseph B.; loving brother of Richard D. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 2.5 & 710pm. Service Thursday, 11:30am.

title: Leader of Democrats Says Carter Is Facing A Challenge in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  John C. White, the Democratic national chairman, said today that President Carter's renomination would be challenged in 1980 by an issueoriented candidate but not by a major figure in the party.

title: State Held Culpable for Problems Troubling Many Boarding Homes
description: TRENTON, July 26  A State Senator and a top state health official acknowledged today that New Jersey was at least partly responsible for the scandalous conditions at boarding homes in the state. To suggest that anyone else other than ourselves has been responsible, is copping out, said State Senator Anthony Scardino, the Lyndhurst Democrat, who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Institutions, Health and Welfare. Mr. Scardino's remarks came today during hearings by the committee, which is writing a bill to cover boarding homes.

title: Simon Estes Cheered at Bayreuth
description: BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 26 (AP)  SimonEstes, the American singer, won acclaim last night in The Flying Dutchman at the opening of the 1978 Bayreuth Festival. He was the first black male.to sing a lead role at the shrine of Wagnerian opera.

title: Beaths
description: MURPHYHugh J. On July 26, 1978 of Manhasset L.I. Beloved husband of the late Mary (nee Hinch) devoted father of Mary Marcantonio, brother of Alice Cornelius and Mary Murphy, loved brotherInlaw of Catherine Hinch. Friends may call at Fairchild Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, L.I., Thursday & Friday 3.5, 79PM. Mass of Christian burial. Saturday 9:30AM at St Mary R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donation to St Francis Hospital of Roslyn would be appreciated:

title: Saint Laurent Brings Back Luxury and Old Lace
description: PARIS, July 26 From the time the very first model put her foot on thelong runway, the excitement kept mounting at the Intercontinental Hotel this morning as Yves Saint Laurent showed his fall couture collection. This was  the show everyone had been waiting forpeople had even pulled themselves away from dinner parties early so they would be in shape for it. The Saint Laurent groupies in the front row, in their white tailored suit jackets from his last collection, awaited his decision on what they would wear the next time.

title: 2 Air Force Planes Collide in Air While in Exercise
description: DELTA, Utah, July 26 (UPI)  Two Air Force planes collided in midair in a combat exercise but both pilots escaped injury, military officials said.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: GOLDBERG GETS FREEDOM AWARD: Arthur Goldberg speaking at White House yesterday after President Carter awarded him the Medal of Freedom, nation's highest civilian award. Also present were Mrs. Goldberg; his daughter, Barbara Goldberg Cramer; her three sons, and Secretary. of State Cyrus R. Vance. Page C2.

title: REPORTER AND TIMES PREPARE U.S. APPEAL
description: Lawyers for The New York Times Company and a Times reporter, M. A. Farber, were drawing up. legal papers yesterday to submit to the United States Supreme Court. They are asking for stay that would allow Mr. Farber to remain out of jail during an appeal of contemptofcourt citations that were imposed in New Jersey on Monday against the Mr. Farber and The Times.

title: Disks: Contemporary Compositions
description: ATENDENCY among many people who think they do not like contemporary music is to lump it together, as if all examples derived from one mass of sound, and reject all of it indiscriminately. Tell them a piece of music was written in, say, the last 25 years, and they'll tell you to take it away. This is a GENE. GUTCHE: Icarus, Rochester PhilharMonic Orchestra, David Zinman conducting; VINCENT PERSICHETTI: The Hollow Men, R. Ted Parker on trumpet, and the Philharmonic Virtuosi of New York, Robert Karrenin conducting; Turnabout TV 34705.

title: AboutNewYork
description: The longest driveviay in whbt we call, for want of any more terse word of summary, the metropolitan area, lies under water, and it must be constantly swept. It is not a vanity, operation to show the neighbors that we can keep up with them -- it is a matter of trade and commerce of the sort that made the city into a city froni the forest primeval. In winter, the Coast; Guard sweeps the ice from the waterways; in other seasons, the Army Corps of Engineers vacuums the bottom.

title: New York City Announces Moves To Halt Illegal Conversion of Lofts
description: New York City officials announced plans yesterday to prevent further illegal conversions of factory buildings to residential use and to bring into compliance with fire, health and safety codes the 1,000 structures that have already been illegally converted.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Medical Consumerism (13)Captioned ABC News (R)

title: Oil Companies Report Mixed Profits
description: Continuing the pattern of varied secondquarter results for the petroleum industry, a group of major oil companies reported mixed earnings yesterday. They including: the Mobil Corporation, up 20.9 percent; the Standard Oil Company of California, down 6.9 percent; the Shell Oil Company, up 2.3 percent; the Gulf Oil Corporation, down 19.0 percent, and the Continental Oil Company, up 31.6 percent.

title: Quinn to Coach Flyers Farm
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) Pat Quinn, an assistant coach with the Philadelphia Flyers last season, was named today as hedd coach of the Maine Mariners, their top farm club in the American Hockey League. Quinn, 35 years old, was signed to a oneyear contract, succeeding the new Flyers coach, Bob McCamrhon.

title: Elraths
description: ABRAMSONJoseph L. MD. Age 79. July 26th. Beloved husband of Rose, Devoted father of Donald 8. William Loving brother of Pauline and Dave. Proud grandfather of Cindy, Tobi, Andrea and Sharon. After a long lllness in Miami Beach, Florida.

title: New York City Announces Moves To Halt Illegal Conversion of Lofts
description: New York City officials announced plans yesterday to prevent further illegal conversions of factory buildings to residential use and to bring into compliance with fire, health and safety codes the 1,000 structures that have already been illegally converted.

title: Advertising
description: HAVING completed its complex agencyselection process, the Army Recruiting Command announced yesterday its agency for the coming fiscal year  N.W. Ayer ABH International, which has been doing the job since 1967. There are two oneyear options to renew.

title: Miss Krupsak Renews Carey Attack
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said yesterday that Governor Carey had announced his change in plans for MitchellLama proj6cts on Monday because he knew that she was planning her own announcement.

title: The City Dog: For Better or Worse?
description: ONE of the graver issues facing the New York City dweller these days, even when a canine pet is not part of the household, is how the presence of approximately 1,100,000 dogs here affects what is still known in some boroughs as the quality of life. Apparently dogs have had enough of a qualitatively adverse effect that, as of Aug. 1, a state ordinance will require the dog owner to clean up his dog's act.

title: Jets Are Hoping to Rise With a Ground Attack
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 26  The lethal combination of the poorest running attack and the worst pass defense in the American Football Conference tells the impatient Jet fans why their heroes posted a 311 wonlost record last season.

title: Home Beat
description: THEIR pieces are always new, always one of a kind. Which is exhausting for them, fun for us, and terribly nice for the 90's.jolly colors. The most expensive piece Great Expectations has ever sold was a Varney grandfather clock for $3,000.

title: Vance Arrives as U.N. Prepares to Consider West's Namibia Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance came here today hoping to ease the way for Security Council acceptance of the Western plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa.

title: Lax Control of Casino Conceded by Jersey Official
description: TRENTON, July 26 Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of the state's Casino Control Commission, today acknowledged that there had been shortcomings in the en: forcement of casino regulations as a consequence of efforts to get the state's first casino opened in Atlantic City as quickly as possible.

title: Dan Horn Easy Winner On Grass at Monmouth
description: OCEAN PORT, N.J., July 26  Colonial Farm's Dan Horn, carrying the highest weight of his career  127 pounds  won the $26,675 Lincroft Handicap for New Jerseybreds on the grass at Monmouth Park today.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY. JULY 26. 1978

title: 2 HELIVOT GUILTY IN MALCOLM X CASE
description: Thomas Hagan, one of three men serving life sentences for the murder of Malcolm X in 1965, has signed an affidavit in which he denies the two others are guilty and names four other men from New Jersey who he alleges were his real accomplices.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, July 26  The Westinghouse Electric Company, embroiled in a major antitrust case, said today that it would dismiss a Chicago law firm representing the company rather than drop charges against three oil concerns involVed in the case.

title: Life on a Streak With Pete Rose
description: Pete Rose started hitting on June 14 in Cincinnati, and kept hitting in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Houston, Cincinnati again, Philadelphia, Montreal and New York. He eveh hit in San Diego in the AllStar Game, though Joe DiMaggio could have told him that didn't count. And when he streaked out town last night with the Cincinnati Reds, he observed with appreciation:

title: Study Finds Traditional Opinion On Welfare Incentives May Err
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP)  A federally financed study by University of Pennsylvania researchers concludes that traditional economic incentives are not the answer to improving the lot of welfare families.

title: Market Place
description: THROUGHOUT the nation, there have been legal challenges to the property tax method financing public schools, on the basis that the system results in better schools for wealthier districts. But so far, only New Jersey has acted to radically change the financing methods of local schools.

title: Oil Spilled After Barge Collision Endangers Wildlife in Louisiana
description: FORKED ISLAND, La., July 26 (UPI)  Two barges filled with oil and carbon black collided today on the Intracoastal Waterway, closing a sevenmile section of the muchtraveled canal and posing a pollution threat to nearby wildlife refuges.

title: Doctors Success in Conception in the Laboratory Intensifies the Debate Over Reproductive Control
description: LONDON, July 26  The first authenticated birth of a baby conceived in a laboratory, an event that comes on the heels of other developments in reproductive control, has intensified debate among scientists that touches such issues as the sanctity of life.

title: Newspapers Comment on the Farber Case
description: Newspapers around the country ran editorials yesterday on the case of The New York. Times and its reporter M. A, Farber, who was fined and sentenced to jail Monday for refusing to turn over his notes and other material to the defense in the New Jersey murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich. Mr. Farber's investigation into 13 allegedly suspicious deaths in a New Jersey hospital in the mid1960's led to a reopening of the case; Dr. Jascalevich is now standing trial for five of those deaths.

title: McDonnell Douglas Drops Suit Against the Times and a Writer
description: ST. LOUIS, July 26 (UPI)  McDonnell Douglas Corporation has dropped a $25 million lawsuit against The New York Times and a book reviewer.

title: British TestTube Baby Unrelated to Del Zio Case
description: Noting the birth in Britain yesterday of the first confirmed human testtube baby, a judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan cautioned the jury hearing Doris Del Zio's $1.5 million damage suit that the event had no bearing on her case.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  President Carter, described by an aide as outraged, has asked the Attorney General's office to join the investigation of fraud and abuse in the General Services Administration, which is estimated to be costing the Government $90 million a year, the White House announced oday.

title: Ballet: Augustyn and Miss Kain in Swan Lake
description: THE National Ballet of Canada, which has visited New York every summer since 1973, returned last night for a rather brief season through Monday at the New York State Theater.

title: Money Rates
description: Dealer'sComoaper: Eurodollar rates:

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Rhodesia Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate approved a proposal today to allow the lifting of economic sanctions against Rhodesia if progress is made toward a freely elected government.

title: Rosenhaus and His Influence at Columbia
description: In the talk among knowledgeable memberg of the motion picture industry about last week's removal of. Alan J. Hirschfield as; president and chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures Industries, one name tended to be mentioned as a key if not the key in the board's decisionmaking. That name was Matthew B. Rosenhaus, chairman of the J.B. Williams subsidiary of Nabisco Inc. and a Columbia director for more than 10 years.

title: Those Explosive Grain Elevators
description: The nation's grain elevators accept grain for storage and weigh it, blend it, clean it, fumigate it and dry it. Each step in the process raises clouds of highly explosive dust. All it takes to detonate the grain dust is a spark from a machine or a cigarette. In little more than a week last December, explosions at four grain elevators in Louisiana, Texas, Illinois and Mississippi killed more than 50 persons and sent 50 others to the hospital.

title: Doctors Success in Conception in the Laboratory Intensifies the Debate Over Reproductive Control
description: LONDON, July 26  The first authenti-cated birth of a baby conceived in a laboratory, an event that comes on the heels of other developments in reproductive control, has intensified debate among scientists that touches such issues as the sanctity of life.

title: Connecticut Senate Leader Quits Contest for Lieutenant Governor
description: HARTFORD, July 26 (AP)  Joseph Lieberman, majority leader of the Connecticut Senate, said today that he would not challenge William O'Neill in a September primary election for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

title: On the Waterfront, Auction of Spanish Antiques
description: KEVIN AND LYNDA CUNNINGHAM bought four oak shovels and a pitchfork for their barn in Ancram, N.Y. Therese Coburn picked up four incredibly large and ornate pine and walnut banisters from a palace in Valencia, Spain, for the new deck on her Cobble Hill home. And Phil Zweig snatched up a rustic, 18thcentury walnut chair tor $20, to replace my old metal ones from Alexander's.

title: Building Off For Quarter
description: After 12 quarters of steady growth, the construction industry recorded its first siginificant decline in the first quarter of this year, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McGi,v Hill, which monitors construction activities across the nation.

title: Disneylncubating New Artists
description: LOS ANGELES THE BLACK CAULDRON Walt Disney's $15 million animated film scheduled for 1980  is four years behind schedule. It will not be completed until Christmas, 1984, because the new crop of young animators the studio has spent six years acquiring are not yet compe. tent to handle its complexities. The Black Cauldron, which is based on Lloyd Alexander's interpretations of medieval Welsh mythology, will be r& placed in 1980 by a simpler and easier movie about animal friendship, The. Fox and the Hound.

title: News Summary
description: Repeal of economic sanctions against Rhodesia was rejected by the Senate. However, it adopted a compromise provision that, in effect, would require President Carter to lift the sanctions, but only after he had determined that a Rhodesian Government had been established by free elections under impartial international observation and that it had committed itself to negotiate with rebels. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Rose Hits And Mets Win, 123
description: With Tommy Holmes's modern National League record safely behind him, all Pete Rose had to do yesterday was extend his league markand that is just what he did at Shea Stadium, with a fifthinning double that was one of the two Cincinnati highlights in the Reds 123 loss to the New York Mets.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Despite drugindustry assertions, physicians and pharmacists are not subject to increased liability under New York State's new genericdrugs substitution law, the Office of Legislative Oversight and Analysis contends.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE of the easiest ways to build an attractive, durable patio or backyard walk is to assemble it of prefabricated modular wood squares, or blocks, which can be fitted together to form a paved surface of almost any size.

title: For Pine Barrens on L.I., Pristine Park or Project?
description: WESTHAMPTON, L.I.  Warm, dry wind swept over the forest, a curious forest of pine trees no more than six feet in height and even smaller oaks with shiny green leaves. A prairie warbler was singing up.the scale nearby as Dr. Steven Englebright, a geologist on the staff of the State University Center at Stony Brook, stretched his arm out toward the landscape.

title: Cattle Herds in U.S. Dip
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The nation's cattle population has declined to the lowest level in six years, continuing a trend that indicates consumers will have to pay even more for their beef by the end of the year.

title: For Pine Barrens on L.I., Pristine Park or Project?
description: WESTHAMPTON, L.I.  Warm, dry wind swept over the forest, a curious forest of pine trees no more than six feet in height and even smaller oaks with shiny green leaves. A prairie warbler was singing up the scale nearby as Dr. Steven Englebright, a geologist on the staff of the State University Center at Stony Brook, stretched his arm out toward the landscape.

title: Danish Lawyer, With a Bow to Proposition 13, Battles Income Tax
description: COPENHAGEN  Howard Jarvis, during his successful campaign this spring to slash California property taxes by twothirds, mentioned another unconventional crusader against big government, a Dane named Moaens Glistrun.

title: Merc Names a General In Futures Trading War
description: Domestid financial futures  including such categories as Treasury bills, Treasury notes and similar vehicles are widely envisioned as a major new growth market in futures trading.

title: Doctors Isolate a Human Gene, Allowing BirthDefect Detection
description: BOSTON, July 26  For the first time, doctors have been able to identify a single gene among the millions in a human cell and can now see whether an unborn baby is missing certain parts of its genetic blueprint, a team of researchers reported today.

title: N.H.L. Postpones Action On Islander Refinancing.
description: TORONTO, July 26  The National Hockey League's Board of Governors postponed decisions today on approval of the New York Islanders refinancing plan and of Arthur Imperatore's bid to buv the Colorado Rockies.

title: Various Corporations List Sales. and Earnings Results for the Latest Quarter.
description: IRREGULAR

description: PARIS

title: Doctor Doubts Ethics In Case of British Baby
description: The attempt to conceive a child outside the body, as in the recent British experiment that yielded a live birth two days ago, was probably unethical, a leading authority on the ethics of biomedical research said yesterday. But, he added, now that it has been demonstrated that an apparently healthy child can be produced that way, further attempts would appear to be ethical.

title: Design Notebook
description: CONT.RARY to popular belief and enduring clichs, Irish art and design is not limited to Celtic masterpieces or Waterford glass. The first image has been magnificently reinforced by the superb show of Irish art treasures that has been touring American musuems  not without mixed feelings about their absence in Dublin  with its dazzling displays of golden torques, brooches and  buckles and such legendary marvels as the Cooks of Kells and Durrow.

title: Rhodesians Schedule Switch of Government
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 26 (Reuters)  Rhodesia's transitional Government outlined its planned schedule today, for holding universalsuffrage elections and for the promised accession to blackmaioritv rule.

title: EARNINGS General Foods Profits Up 12% in Recent Period
description: Aided by a recovery in its coffee business, the General Foods Corporation reported a 12 percent increase in net income yesterday for its first fiscal quarter ended July 1.

title: Missing Patient, 65, Rescued by Helicopter
description: BOONTON, July 26  A 85yearold Parsippany man missing from a nursing home today became the first person to be rescued by the Air Rescue Medical Evacuation Unit of the New Jersey State Police. He was spotted crawling in a swampy area near Lincoln Park, picked up by helicopter and brought to the Riverside Hospital here. coin Park Nursing Home, an intemediary care facility, had been reported missing yesterday afternoon. He could not be found after a search of the building and grounds of the institution by the Lincoln Park Police and by bloodhounds from the Morris County Canine Unit.

title: A Mother Leads Crusade in Mexico for Political Amnesty
description: MEXICO CITY, July 26  For two years after her son disappeared following his arrest, Rosario Ibarra de Piedra trekked around Mexico visiting police chiefs, politicians and even the President in the hope that the 21yearold medical student would be presented in public alive. I don't know why, but I really had faith in our legal system, she said.

title: G.S.A. Head Asks Aide to Resign
description: WASHINGTON. July 27 (UPI)  The head of the General Services Administration, with President Carter's permission, today requested the resignation. of the secondranking official at the corruptionplagued agency.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Central Park seems to, be Joseph Papp's summertime muse, inspiring one new project after another. This time, it's jazz at the Delacorte Theater, where Mr. Papp's production of All's Weli That Ends Well is also playing. Tonight at midnight, the jazz pianistCecil Taylor will give a free recital of his own music: Ticket distribution will begin at 10 P.M. at the theater box office, near Central Park West and 81st Street. Those who want to make the evening a doubleheader can pick up jazz tickets when Shakespeare ends. And for those concerned about being in the park so late at night, a spokesman has these reassuring words: We've worked it out with the police. Information: 5355630.

title: Howard Estabrook, Won Oscar For Cimarron Screenplay, at 94
description: Howard Estabrook, a Hollywood screenwriter who won an Academy Award for the screenplay of the 1931 western Cimarron, died July 16 in Woodland Hills, a Los Angeles suburb, after a long illness. He,was 94 years old.

title: Paris Couture Collections End With a Salute to Tradition
description: PARIS, July 27  Alix Grs brought the fall couture showings to an amiable conclusion today in her traditional way. It was particularly appropriate for the quintessential couturiere to have the last word at a time when the couture is struggling to be born again.

title: Deepening of Newark Bay Urged
description: NEWARK, July 27  A statewide organization of business, industry and and transportation groups urged quick approval today of a proposal by the Army Corps of Engineers to deepen and widen navigation channels in the Kill Van Kull and Newark Bay to enable large oceangoing vessels to use Port Newark and the Elizabeth Port Authority Marine Terminal.

title: G.M. Profits Climb 1% In Quarter
description: DETROIT, July 27. The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest automobile manufacturer, today reported a 0.8 percent increase in,itssecondquarter profits. But G.M.'s net income of $1.11 billion; or $3.86 a share. was sufficient to set another record second quarter for the company.

title: Anatomy of Murder in a Wyoming Town
description: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., July 27 While almost half the state of Wyoming is at the Frontier Days celebration in Cheyenne, pretending that the West is still wild and woolly, Rock Springs is living out the legend.

title: Deal Links Investment Bankers
description: First Boston Inc. and Credit SuisseWhite Weld said yesterday they had agreed to the acquisition by First Boston of the White Weld interests in the European venture and the acquisition by the European company of an interest in First Boston Inc.

title: Canada Lifts Bank Rate
description: OTTAWA, July 27 (AP)  The Bank of Canada has announced an increase in its lending rate to 9 percent from 8 percent. Gerald Bouey, the bank governor, said United States interest rates had moved up significantly in recent months and it was important to keep Canadian interest rates in line with international trends. The central bank's lending rate, which governs interest charges on its rare cash advances to chartered banks, is primarily a signal to the financial community by Federal money managers. The 9 percent rate became effective yesterday.

title: Women's Sea Duty Curb Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Federal District Judge John J. Si rica declared unconstitutional today a Federal law that prohibits Navy women from serving at sea on other than transport and hospital ships.

title: Loss of Banks Concerns Fed
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The Federal Reserve's control over the nation's money supply may deteriorate if banks keep withdrawing as members, the Fed's chairman, G. William Miller, said today.

title: Sirica Rejects Statute Barring Navy Women From Some Sea Duty
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Federal District Judge John J. Sirica declared unconstitutional today a Federal law that prohibits Navy women from serving at sea on other than transport and hospital ships.

title: Various Corporations List Sales and Earnings Results for the Latest Quarter
description: For period$ a$ shown. (N) indi cafe$ stock i$ listed on the New York Stock Exchance,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Toward the end of his attack on the July 10 OpEd page upon the physicist who believes that the universe is pointless because it. is destined to die, Archibald MacLeish enlisted W. B. Yeats as an ally and promptly trampled him in the zeal of the final charge.

title: U.S. to Guarantee Loans for Puerto Rico Car Plant
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The Agriculture and Commerce Departments will guarantee $40 million in loans to a company being formed by John Z. DeLorean, a former General Motors executive who plans to build $96 million carmaking plant in Puerto Rico, it was announced today.

title: The New Tort Times/Neal Boenzi
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 27  Governor Carey and Perry B. Duryea, the Republican nominee for his job, jabbed sharply at each other in backtoback appearances at a labor convention here in the north country today.

title: The Soldiers of Fortune
description: WESTPORT, Conn.The old paymaster is dead, Col. Michael (Mad Mike) Hoare recently lamented. He was referring to the Central Intelligence Agency, which.is presently out of the mercenary recruitment business. Nevertheless Colonel Hoare, the reputed king of the mercenaries, is standing by at his headquarters in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Books: Infancy of U.S. Photography
description: Photography in America: The Formative Years, 18391900. By William Welling. Crowell. $29.95.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Association of American Railroads today estimated freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week at 17 billion tonmiles, up 6 percent from year before. Carloadings were up 1.1 percent to 458,764 cars. The American Trucking Associations reported that intercity truck tonnage rose 4.5 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Lockheed Corporation announced yesterday that its LockheedCalifornia unit had joined Avions Marcel DassaultBreguet Aviation of France and Dornier G.m.b.H. of West Germany, builders of the Alpha jet trainer, to enter the Alpha jet in the United States Navy's future competition for an advanced training system.

title: Chinaglia Has Title Competition
description: Giorgio Chinaglia has reached the 30goal mark, but with Mike Flanagan of New England around, that total will not be enough to win the goalscoring title of the North American Soccer League.

title: New Face: David Huffman Ex-Terrific Liar Gives Honesty a Boost in Film
description: IN the movie F.I.S.T. Abe Belkin is the union's conscience, gentle, sweetfaced boy who becomes tormented over the union's involvement with organized crime. Years later, the stubborn idealist will lose his life as a result of his commitment to decency and truth.

title: Upstate, a Festival for People With Hillbilly Souls
description: The third. annual Berkshire Mountains Bluegrass Festival, which starts at noon today in Hillsdale, N.Y., and continues until darkness falls on Sunday, is a celebration not only of bluegrass music and the life style of the rural South, but also of the unswerving determination of a devotee of bluegrass and the Southern life style named Nancy Talbott.

title: Restaurants
description: AMONG the many requests we get for restaurant recommendations, one of the most frepuent is for an attractive dining place. where one can enjoy really good seafood at moderate prices. Until now that has been a tough request to fill because the best of the city's fish restaurants are enormously expensive and the fey:, decent, moderately priced alternatives are jammed and, generally, somewhat tacky. But now that request has a far more satisfactory response in the Jane Street Seafood Cafe on the northwest corner of Jane and Hudson Streets in Greenwich Village.

title: CAREY SEEKS TO BAR NEW POWER PLANTS USING NUCLEAR FUEL
description: ALBANY, July 27  Governor Carey's administration will seek to bar construe:. tion of any future nuclear power plants in New York State because of a lack of capacity to handle radioactive waste, the State Energy Commissioner said today.

title: Local Leaders in Top Postal Union Reject Contract but Call for a Vote
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Local leaders of the nation's largest postal union voted to reject the tentative contract with the United States Postal Service here today but decided to send the agreement to its general membership for a final decision.

title: Stage: Comedy Duo At Theater East
description: JOHN MONTEITH and Suzanne Rand, who opened the lighthearted show bearing their name at Theater East last night, don't make it easy for themselves. They play in a rather austere space, bare  except for a couple of director's chairs  of scenery, props:

title: U.S. Reduces Beirut Embassy. Staff And Advises Americans to Leave
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The United States has advised Americans living in Lebanon to leave the country and has begun to reduce its embassy staff in Bei- nit, State Department officials said today. Both actions, they said, are a response to a deteriorating security situation in Lebanon.

title: Las Vegas Concern Details Risks In Plans for Atlantic City Casinos
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27  In a stock offering for a New Jersey subsidiary, Caesars World has outlined substantial risks that it says it faces in trying to open a casino in Atlantic City.

title: Art: Jim Dine Etchings at the Modern
description: SUMMER art exhibitions are, like summer menus, supposed to be light brit nourishing. Appropriately, the Museum of Modern Art is offering more than 100 of Jim Dine's etchings of the last 17 years.

title: All's Fair in Middletown At Big Farming Show
description: The 138yearold Orange County Fair, which begins today in Middletown, N.Y., and continues through next week, is a festival of competitions and entertainment within the traditional framework of a major agricultural exhibition.

title: Snepp's Lawyer Calls U.S. Unfair
description: WASHINGTON. July 27  A lawyer for Frank W. Snepp 3d, the former Central Intelligence Agency official who was found by a Federal District Court to have violated his secrecy oath with the agency, said today that the Justice Department was being patently unfair to Mr. Snepp in seeking an immediate payment of money damages that would bankrupt him.

title: Britain Expels Five Iraqis, Citing Recent Terrorism
description: LONDON, July 27  Five members of the Iraqi diplomatic staff in London have been ordered to leave Britain within week, the Foreign Office said today. A spokesman said the British acted because of increasing concern at the threat posed by terrorist activities in, London, particularly against Arab targets.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 27  One starstudded New. York team is likely to have tough struggle today in the third round of the Spingold knockout championship at the American Contract Bridge'0;League's Summer Nationals.

title: The Options. Boom: A Bumpy Road. To Maturity
description: Five years after the dazzling start of exchangetraded options, the options market has grown far beyond most people's expectations, although much of the glitter appears to have faded. What is left is a fastmaturing part of the financial marketplace.

title: A Threat to Judicial Independence
description: Quietly, the Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill, misnamed the Judicial Tenure Act, that would permit Federal judges to be disciplined or removed from office without impeachment. It would severely restrict the life tenure long associated with an independent Federal judiciary. Even if constitutional, the bill is nevertheless an unwise threat to the judiciary for no apparent need.

title: Music: Ronny Whyte
description: BARRING a distinctive vocal style, virtually the only way singing pianist can set himself apart from the dozens of other singing pianists who can be heard in cocktail lounges and restaurants around town is by developing a repertory of songs that is not only different from but also more interesting than that of his competitors. This is not easy because, as a song writer once said of men, a good song is hard to find, tooparticularly a good song that has not already been found by a number of other equally songhungry singers.

title: The New York Times/ July 28. 1978
description: AREA A  Fishing for blues continues to be excellent, according to Captain Andy's at Margate, N.J. The principal area is off 28Mile Wreck. Tuna and dolphin also have appeared and are being taken by trolling with red and white cedar plugs or red and white feathers. In the evening, blues have been caught off the Atlantic City Lobster Pots about 14 miles outside of Great Egg Inlet. At Point Pleasant the blues are really good', according to reports from Ken's Landing. They are being caught off the BA Buoy near Sea Bright by chumming from the party boats.

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTON TOWARD the end of the communiqu issued last week after the economic summit meeting in Bonn, there appeared a fairly bland paragraph that may lead to one of the meeting's most significant achievements as far as the United States is concerned. That, at least, is the hope of Frank A. Weil, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

title: Exxon Facility Ruined in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27  An avalanche in the high Chilean Andes has destroyed the ore processing facilities of La Disputada copper mine, owned by Exxon Minerals, with loss of production estimated at a year. The mine, about 35 miles from here, produces most of the ore for La Disputada's annual production of 35,000 tons of refined copper.

title: Vain Hopes Remain This For Admirer Who Sued
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27  With quotes from Quintilian, Lord Byron and California's antiheart balm statutes, a judge ruled today that a jilted accountant had no cause to sue woman who did not keep dinner and theater date with him earlier this year.

title: A Party to Celebrate Its Debut at the Ballet
description: James Kudelka will be all over the stage of the New York State Theater tonight and Saturday helping to swell the ranks in Sir Frederick Ashton's La Fille Mal Gardee and, as a character with a past, helping the plot along in A Party. If the 22yearold dancer looks somewhat distracted in the role of.

title: Market Place
description: CAN the Johnson Products Company, the largest publicly held company that is blackcontrolled, overcome the tide of competition in the personal care industry? Perhaps it is too scan to tell, but this producer of personal grooming aids for consumers appears to be making headway in its quest to recapture the dominant position it held only for years ago.

title: Norway's Oil Output Surges
description: OSLO, July 27 (Reuters)  Norway's 1978 offshore production of crude oil and natural gas could more than double to more than 30 million metric tons from 19 million last year, according to a survey by the oil directorate published today.

title: Notes on People
description: Those two bald heads gleaming in the midday sun at City Hall Plaza yesterday belonged to Mayor Koch and Yul Brynner. The Mayor gave the actor the city's highest civic award, the Bronze Medallion, for his efforts in behalf of the I Love New York advertising campaign. In return Mr. Brynner sang A Puzzlement from The King and I, in which he is starring on Broadway. To entertain the Mayor and a crowd of lunchtime spectators, Mr. Brynner brought along his costar, Constance Towers, and other cast members, including seven of the 14 children who play the offspring of the King of Siam. Mr. Brynner, who appears barechested and barefoot in the play, wore a dark doublebreasted suit at the award ceremony.

title: 3 Quakes Reported in Alaska
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 (UPI) Three minor earthquakes in less than three hours shook the populated Badger Road area on the outskirts of Fairbanks today. No damage was reported. The first tremor, measuring 3.9 on the Richter scale, was felt at 5:19 A.M. It was followed at 6:51 A.M. by a tremor measuring 3.6 and at 8:11 A.M. by one measuring 3.7.

title: Halting the System: II
description: WASHINGTON  Chairman John C. White of the Democratic National Committee has warned Democratic candidates to stop taking cheap shots at President Carter, and also predicted that Mr. Carter will be opposed for renomination in 1980, probably by an issuesoriented candidate.

title: Jaworski Says Inquiry Into Korean Lobbying Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Leon Jawprski said tonight that his investigation into the Korean influencebuying scandal was finished and that he was quitting as special counsel to the House ethics committee.

title: S.E.C. Asks Salary Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed that more corporate executives disclose how much they are paid in salaries and perquisites, but not in specific detail.

title: Dance: The Changes Age Brings to 3 Classics
description: THOUGH styles and scandals come and go, choreographic craftsmanship may cause certain ballets to live on. It was no wonder, then, that the London Festival Ballet's Wednesday matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House included Michel Fokine's Scheherazade of 1910 and Spectre de la Rose of 1911 and August Bournonville's Conservatoire of 1849. All three works are sturdily constructed.

title: New School Chief Seen as a Sign of Peace in Boston
description: In the first few years of this decade Boston, with its rich history as the cradle both of the American Revolution and of the abolitionist movement, became in the eyes of civil rights forces the epicenter of hardball racial politics. The irony was not lost on some Southerners, who pointed with glee at the city's desegregation trauma, nor on some Bostonians, who were deeply embarrassed by the negative image of their city that was flashed around the globe.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, July 27 (UPI)  Immunizing patients with bee venom instead of the bees crushed bodies can better prevent serious and sometimes fatal sting reactions in the more than one million Americans who are hypersensitive to bee stings, a team of researchers said today.

title: Entertainment, Events
description: NATIONAL LAMPOON'S ANIMAL HOUSE, directed by John Landis; starring John Belushi and Tim Matheson. at the Beekman, Sutton, Murray HIII, 86th Street East, Astor Plaza and other theeten.

title: PennDixie Explains Trading Reports
description: PennDixie Industries announced that, transactions in its common stock that were recently reported in the New York Stock Exchange's composite transactions tables in the financial press represented trades in the overthecounter market or on regional exchanges rather than transactions on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Knicks Await Ruling by O'Brien On Status of Webster's Contract
description: The Knicks attempt to sign Marvin Webster is in a holding pattern, awaiting a ruling by Lawrence O'Brien, the National Basketball Association commissioner, to determine whether the Seattle SuperSonic center is a free agent.

title: Jackson Returns, Turns Jeers Into Cheers
description: The orangelettered bedsheet at Yankee Stadium read, Bunt, Reggie, but Reggie Jackson ignored the sarcasm yesterday as he trotted out to right field for his first game in 10 days.

title: U.N. COUNCIL BACKS NAMIBIAN FREEDOM AND RETURN OF PORT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 The Security Council today endorsed the Western plan for ending guerrilla war in SouthWest Africa and leading the territory to independence as the new black African state of Namibia at the earliest possible date.

title: New York Officer Held in Holdup
description: A New York Zity policeman was arrested in his station house yesterday on charges that he robbed an Orange'County, N.Y., bank of $1,700 on his day off.

title: Willem van Ottertoo; Dutch Conductor, 70
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, July 27 (Reuters)  The Dutch conductor Willem van Otterloo, who led The. Hague PhillUirmonic for 23 years and later moved to Australia, was killed today in a traffic accident near here.

title: Main Breaks, Inundating Bushwick Neighborhood
description: The New York Times/ Fred R. ConradAnne Norris of Brooklyn was startled out of sleep by a strange sound at 4:30 yesterday morning. She rushed to a secondfloor window of her graceful, clapboard Bushwick house and rubbed her eyes in disbelief: A great river of water was roaring down the street.

title: ARABS MEET TO END RIFT ON SADAT LINE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 Egypt and hardline Arab countries moved today to calm a violent dispute over President Anwar elSadat's peace gestures to Israel. The move came amid signs that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance might have trouble in his effort to arrange EgyptianIsraeli talks next month.

title: Senate Votes New York Aid Bill; Carter Expected to Sign It in City
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Even its severest financial critic proclaimed I do love New York as the Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill to provide the city with. $1.65 billion in Federal loan guarantees.

title: H.E.W. to Limit Medicare Fees For Lab Tests and Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare, in a move to cut welfare medical costs, will limit payments for laboratory services and medical equipment to the lowest locally available prices.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 number of the nonaligned nations that are meeting here called today for Cuban disengagement from Africa.

title: DOCTOR'S RESEARCH CITED IN BABY CASE
description: The lawyer for an embryologist who assisted Doris Del Zio in an attempt to have a baby in 1973 suggested yesterday in court that his client's work was was highly valued by ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center until his growing fame in sexdetermination and other prenatal research caused his departmental superior to discredit him.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONJoseph L., M.D. The Brooklyn Alumni Club of the Phi Lambda Kappa fraternity and the Medical Students Aid Society records with deep sorrow the passing of frater Joseph Abramson, M.D. He was a founder of the Brooklyn Alum. ni Club and a guiding light to its members during his years of dedicated service. Our heartfelt symPathles are extended to his wife, Rose, and sons, Donald and William.

title: CAREY SEEKS TO BAR NEW POWER PLANTS USING NUCLEAR FUEL
description: ALBANY, July 27  Governor Carey's administration will seek to bar construction of any future nuclear power plants in New York State because of a lack of capacity to handle radioactive waste, the State Energy Commissioner said today.

title: Senate Backs Incentives to Hospitals Cutting Services
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The Senate today approved a program under which the Federal Government would offer financial incentives to hospitals that closed down unneeded services.

title: Rose,Returns Home, Eyes 2 More Streaks
description: Pete Rose is back in Cincinnati after a day off yesterday, and he has a chance today to match two more of baseball's longest hitting streaks when the Reds play Philadelphia in a twilightnight doubleheader.

title: World's Attention Fails to Stir El Arish, Small Sinai Town in Grip of July Torpor
description: EL ARISH, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, July 25  For nearly two weeks, use in Israel of the word gesture has been in reference to this unprepossessing desert town in a summer torpor that can make even camels sluggish.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: ON television or film the songwritrspele,whuonsless ey are enacted, usually show up in the crawl, the list of credits of those who have made this show possible.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Much to the surprise of traders and analysts, gold showed a sharp rise yesterday toward the close of trading after holding steady in the morning.

title: Brown Asserts Seoul Is Menaced by North; Vows Support by U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, July 27  Defense Secretary Harold Brown and South Korean defense officials said today that the military threat to South Korea was serious, and that the United States would provide prompt and effective support to the Seoul Government in the event of an attack from the North.

title: ARABS MEET TO END RIFT ON SADAT LINE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27Egypt and hardline Arab countries moved today to calni a violent dispute over President Anwar elSadat's peace gestures to Israel. The move came amid signs that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance might have trouble in his effort to arrange EgyptianIsraeli talks next month.

description: Jimmy Jemail, the Inquiring Fotographer of The Daily News for 52 years, died Wednesday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 1025 Fifth Avenue.

title: O.E.C.D. Wants Pledges Implemented
description: PARIS, July 27  Prompt and full implementation of the promises of economic expansion made by Western industrial nations at their Summit meeting in Bonn two weeks ago will be necessary if these nations are to avoid slipping back into recession next year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN ETHNIC. AT LARGE. A Memoir of America in the Thirties and Forties. By Jerre Mangione. 378 pages: Illustrated. Putnam. $12.50.

title: REALTORS ASSESSING CITY'S LOFTS POLICY
description: Realestate people and those involved in converting industrial lofts to apartments yesterday predicted widely varying financial effects on many such buildings if New York City enforced a newly announced program to bring illegally converted structures into compliance with fire, health and safety laws.

title: Screen: 'Animal House':Daffy Deltas
description: IT'S Rush Week of 1962 at Faber College, where "Knowledge Is Good" was the founder's most memorable witticism. The classiest fraternity on campus  the one to which the editor of the Daily Bavarian belongs  is wowing potential pledges with an elaborate show of gentility and a pianist who can play "Tammy." But right next door, at the eyesore that is the Delta House, something a little less civilized is going on.The Deltas are the kind of guys who bash beer cans against their foreheads, wheel their dates home in shopping carts and think they know the words to "Louie, Louie," which they will sing in off-key unison at less than the slightest provocation. Needless to say, they will not be having a very good year. The brother who racks up a 1.2 grade point average will be the brightest of the bunch, and the house Romeo will be reduced to gearing his visits to a nearby girls' school to the obituary notices. Pretending to be the grieving fianc of a dead coed is evidently a successful, if pitiable, gambit."National Lampoon's Animal House" is by no means one long howl, but it's often very funny, with gags that are effective in a dependable, all-purpose way. The movie works hard to supply something for the broadest possible audience, instead of aiming only at the viewer who'd like to watch John Belushi  as the Delta who knows the fewest words of more than one syllableeating Jell-O with his fingers."Animal House" is too cheerfully sleazy to be termed tame, but the film makers have been smart enough to leaven each gross-out with an element of innocent fun. Even the action-packed finale amounts to nothing more dangerous than the spectacle of all heck breaking loose.Except for Mr. Belushi, who mugs like crazy and spills a wide variety of substances all over himself, the actors tend to be as clean-cut and dopey as the movie's setting. Tim Matheson is a particularly self-congratulatory Joe College who whistles "Peter and the Wolf" as he loiters in a women's dorm; Stephen Furst does some very successful scene-stealing as the house blimp.And Thomas Hulce is appropriately dim playing the first guy in the frat to be offered a reefer, by the obligatory hyper-hip English professor (Donald Sutherland, in a throwaway role). "O.K., so that means our whole solar system could be one tiny atom in the fingernail of some other giant being," Mr. Hulce postulates, while under the influence. Then he breaks out in uncontrollable giggles.At its best, in moments like this, the movie isn't strictly satirical, because it doesn't need to be. The film makers have simply supplied the appropriate panty-girdles, crew-neck sweaters, frat-house initiation rites and rituals of the toga party, and let all that idiocy speak  very eloquently, and with a lot of comic fervorfor itself.

title: Marketing the Weather for Profit
description: Everybody talks about the weather, but Raymond Mayer is one man who does something about it.

title: Bolivia's Coup, Washington's Dilemma
description: A military coup in Bolivia last week was the sequel to a fraudulent election. Both demonstrate the limits on humanrights diplomacy in the Americas. If the Carter Administration fails to respond to the events in Bolivia, it can hardly expect its rhetoric to be taken seriously by authoritarian regimes. Yet it must avoid excessive involvement in the politics of sovereign countries.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker Tappan, a Hamlet Time Almost Forgot
description: THERE is a town that time has almost forgotten less. than 20 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, a town not just steeped in colonial history, but also. one that has never truly cast off the 18th century. It is a place to walk down narrow, twisting lanes and imagine, while passing houses several hundred years old, the clatter of horsedrawn wagons and the chatter of colonial townsfolk as they went about their daily business.

title: Hatfield Quizzes a Carter Nominee on Income Reports
description: WASHINGTON July 27 Apparent efforts by Republicans to embarrass President Carter and Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, over nominations to the Federal Election Commission broke into the open today on Capitol Hill.

title: Guide to Outdoor Music Close to Home
description: MAHLER songs in a sylvan theater in Westchester, Gershwin in a park on Long Island, a Shostakovich piano concerto in the remnants of a farm village in New Jersey, avantgarde music in a sleek Manhattan garden. It all adds up to summer music outofdoors in and around New York.

title: New DriveIn Downtown
description: A drivein movie theater is opening tonight in Lower Manhattan, with parkinglot wall for a screen and the Brooklyn Bridge as a backdrop. And according to one of the entrepreneurs, the downtown branch of the Whitney Museum, this drivein is Manhattan's first.

title: 65 Safe in Iran Airliner Crash
description: Teheran, Iran. July 27 (UPI)  An Iran Air Boeing 727 jetliner with a jammed landing gear made a crash landing at Teheran Airport early today, but none of the 65 people aboard was injured.

title: Publishin Of Women Poets, Zuleika Dobson' and Life on the Vistula
description: IN 1962, Willis Barnstone, a translator and poet, who has been nominated for the Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, did rendering of the complete poems of Sappho for Doubleday & Company. It seemed to him at the time that the whole field of poetry by women had been insufficiently explored.

title: Arab Interests Make a Bid for Commonwealth Oil
description: In the first formal offer by Arab interests for a refinery serving the American market, the Arabian Seaoil Corporation has submitted a proposal to acquire a stake in the distressed Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, it was announced yesterday. Corco's chief facility is a large refinery and petrochemical complex in Penueles, Puerto Rico.

title: Money Supply's Decline. Rallies Credit Markets
description: The nation's money supply unexpectedly droppped sharply in the week ended July 19  M1 shrank by $2.8 billion and M2 fell by $1.7 billion  and the bond market responded by staging a strong lateafternoon rally yesterday. Interest rates moved down more forcefully than they have in months.

title: At the Movies
description: SHE doesn't feel terrific because of her notices in Heaven Can Wait and Revenge of the Pink Panther, Dyan Cannon was saying the other day. The notices were good because she felt terrific and it showed in her performances. She's feeling equally upbeat, she said, about a madefortelevision film that will be shown this fall. It is a biography of Sally Stanford, the famous San Francisco madam who is presently the vicemayor  that is, deputy to the chief executive  of Sausalito, just across the Golden Gate Bridge.

description: The recent national revolt against escalating taxes should come as little surprise to New Yorkers. While Californians expressed their anger over property taxes through Proposition 13, a study of the past decade reveals that New Yorkers have been leadin,g the nation not only in all state and local taxes but also in tax growth.

title: Broderick Crawford Plays Himself in New Movie
description: Broderick. Crawford, the actor, will play himself in the film, A Little Romance: Mr. Crawford, Sir Laurence Olivier, Arthur Hill, Sally Kellerman and two 13yearolds, Diane Lane and Thelo Bernard, will all act in the movie produced by Yves RoussetRouard and directed by George Roy Hill.

description: WHITE PLAINS, July 27  Richard James Herrin, convicted last month of reduced charge of manslaughter hi the death of Bonnie Joan Garland, was sentenced today to a term of from eight and third years to 25 years in prison  the greatest penalty allowed under New York State law.

description: LISBON, July 27 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Mario Soares said tonight that he had been dismissed by President Antonio Ramalho Eanes and would not be asked to form a new Cabinet.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27  With quotes from Quintilian, Lord Byron and California's antiheart balm statutes, a judge ruled today that a jilted accountant had no cause to sue a woman who did not keep a dinner and theater date with him earlier this year.

description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Carter Administration's top priority in its package of urban proposals, a $1 billion program to provide fiscal aid to distressed cities and towns, has run into deep trouble in Congress.

description: A young black man from the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn was cleared of burglary charges yesterday after two Hasidic Jews came forward to say he was not the man they had seen running from the scene of the crime.

description: CINCINNATI, July 27 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit today reaffirmed its earlier support of busing in Dayton public schools.

description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A.M. and P.M.

description: ALBANY, July 27  A bill to protect tenants in rental apartments that are converting to caoperatives or condominiums in New York City's suburbs has been approved by Governor Carey, his Office announced today.

description: 74 A.M. WNCN. Piano Sonata No. 15, Haydn; KonzertstUck in F, Weber; Pavane, Faure; Romance in F, Beethoven; ConcertEtude No. 1, Tausig.

description: Members of the Police Department's Bomb Section carting two pipe bombs found yesterday in the Manhattan Towers apartment building on West 42d Street to a truck for disposal. At left, onlookers applaud officers efforts.
