description: HARTFORD, July 27  A Republican candidate for Governor, Lewis B. Rome, withdrew from the race today and handed the party's nomination to Representative Ronald A. Sarasin, the Republican frontrunner.

title: Benson Ford, 59, Dies
description: DETROIT, July 27  Benson Ford, a grandson of the automobile pioneer Henry Ford and a vice president and director of. the Ford. Motor Company, died early today of an apparent heart attack aboard his yacht, which was docked in the Cheboygan River in Michigan. He was 59 years old.

title: 5 Ohio State Games G0 To Pay TV
description: ABCTV and the Warner Cable Corporation have reached an agreement out of court to permit. the cable company to offer five Ohio State University games on its paytelevision system in Columbus, Ohio, next fall. ABC has described the agreement as a twoyear experiment to measure The impact of live cable coverage on attendance at the football stadium.

title: Avis in the Driver's Seat?
description: The contest for the hearts and minds of the world's carrental customers took a new twist this week when Colin M. Marshall, president of Avis, said that his company had finally reached the nirvana of becoming No. 1 in worldwide vehicle rental and leasing.

title: Herrin Given Maximum Jail Term In Bludgeoning Death in Scarsdale
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 27  Richard James Herrin, convicted last month of reduced charge of manslaughter in the death of Bonnie Joan Garland, was sentenced today to a term of from eight and third years to 25 years in prison  the greatest penalty allowed under New York State law.

title: Screen: 'Driver' Takes a Rocky Road:No Names, Please!
description: HE drives getaway cars, so he's called The Driver. The man who's obsessed with catching The Driver is a member of the police force. He's called The Detective. The young woman who's hired by The Driver to be his alibi when The Detective attempts to frame The Driver is called The Player, probably because when we first see her she's in a gambling casino, playing five-card stud.There are a lot of other people in "The Driver" (hereafter referred to as The Movie), including phantoms with names like The Connection, Red Plainclothesman, Gold Plainclothesman, Glasses, Teeth and The Kid.The movie, which opens today at neighborhood theaters, was written and directed by Walter Hill, who once wrote and directed a good movie, "Hard Times," with Charles Bronson. This one is not good. It is Awful Movie. It is Pretentious Movie. It is Silly Movie. It talks just like this.According to the program notes, Mr. Hill thinks he is getting at "the muscle, the sinew, the tissue, the very nerve center of a getaway driver." It doesn't work, though. By stripping away the individual idiosyncracies, Mr. Hill simply lays bare The Clich, and The Clich is Horrendous, if sometimes horrendously funny.Ryan O'Neal plays The Driver, who is supposed to be to getaway driving what Matisse was to scissors and colored paper. Not so. The Driver always does too much. He's too fancy. He's to getaway driving what Edgar Guest was to poetry. He doesn't know when to stop. Truly.He couldn't put his car into a parking lot without attracting the attention of the sleepiest traffic cop. All those screaming accelerations, those two-wheel turns and those brake-slammings have less to do with effective getting away than with random self-expresssion. Having no role to act, Mr. O'Neal seems bewildered.As The Detective, Bruce Dern snarls a lot, more or less repeating the rabbit-toothed psychotic he played in "Black Sunday" and "Coming Home," an unreliable fellow full of distress and possibly an upset stomach. Isabel Adjani, in her first (and possibly last) American film (Hollywood doesn't like a loser) is The Player, a beautiful young woman who means to be mysterious but more often may remind you of the trick-turning Barnard girls in Woody Allen's classic sketch, "The Whore of Mensa."She wears her mouth turned down at both ends and generally affects the world-weary manner of a jaded complit student who's been through it all  Cather, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Dos Passos, Irwin Shaw and Harold Robbins.For a movie in which there are so many chases. The Movie is singularly unexciting and uninvolving, though it does have its laughs.I'm fascinated by Mr. Hill's way of emphasizing the peak emotional moment in a scene by having one character talk intently to the back of another character's head. And he must mean us to break up when Miss Adjani, trying to sneak into a busy railroad station to fetch a satchel full of stolen loot, appears wearing a black costume of such arresting style she'd stop the music at Studio 54.Ronee Blakely, nominated for an Oscar after her fine performance in "Nashville," appears to no particular purpose in the throwaway role of The Connection, The Driver's business agent. She's not great.

title: Blaze Damages Bowery Church Erected in 1799
description: Fire swept through New York City's historic St. Mark'sintheBowery Episcopal Church at Second Avenue and 10th Street yesterday, sending the roof crashing 50 feet to the floor of the main sanctuary and destroying nine of the 179yearold landmark's 23 stainedglass windows.

title: Tax Cut in 1979 Of $16.3 Billion Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The House Ways and Means Committee tonight approved a $16.3 billion tax cut to take effect in 1979, including tax reductions for individuals averaging 5.7 percent.

title: Girl, 9, Is Killed and Her Sister,8, Hurt in 5Story Fall from Window
description: A 9yearold girl was killed and her 8yearold sister was injured critically last night when they fell together out of a fifth floor apartment window on the Upper West Side, apparently accidentally, the police said.

title: Gulf to Pay $42 Million On Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The White House, the Energy Department and the Gulf Oil Company announced today that the company had agreed to pay $42.2 million in alleged overcharges to the Treasury or to customers if they can be found.

title: Cherry Exports to Japan
description: Oregon's cherry growers this year, for the first time ever, will join the list of United States exporters to Japan, industry sources said. The fruit growers in the Hood River Valley are preparing for shipment this month more than 10,000 20pound boxes of Bing and Lambert cherries to Japan. Japanese importers believe there will be a heavy demand for the Americanproduced fruit because of their sweet taste. Cherries grown in Japan are mildly tart.

title: A Scientist's Lave Story: Research on Passion and Beyond
description: Love is the strange bewilderrneptFor millenniums, poets have rhapsodized over it, lovers have suffered over it, and parents have blustered about it. Nobody, however, has ever claimed completely to understand it. What is this thing called love? wonders the song, and at one time or another, surely every individual has asked the same bemused question.

title: United Press International
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 27 The United States Olympic Committee is committed to Israel's participation in the 1980 Moscow Olympics, Robert J. Kane. the U.S.O.C. president, said today.

title: Main Breaks, Inundating Bush wick Neighborhood
description: Anne Norris of Brooklyn was startled out of sleep by a strange sound at 4:30 yesterday morning. She rushed to a secondfloor window of her graceful, clapboard Bushwick house and rubbed her eyes in disbelief: A great river of water was roaring down the street. It was like the Mississippi, Mrs. Norris later recalled.

title: For Children
description: THE VALLEY RAILROAD, with Its 1010 cars. carries passengers from the Old Essex Station Corinecticut, to Chester, a 10mile trip through the countryside. A leisurely one or.twotour cruise up the ma lestIc Connecticut River may be added aboard the Sliver Star, a riverboat at the Deep River Station. At the centuryold Essex Depot. there 15 a restaurant and gift shop, and nearby, the old seaport town of Essex Village. Train trip: children, under 12, 51.50; adults, $3. Onehour train ride and cruise: children, $3.25; adults, $5.50 Twohour train ride and cruise: children. 54.23; adults, S6.75. For a timetable, call (203) 7670103.

title: Walvis Bay: African Port in a Storm of Controversy
description: WALVIS BAY, South Africa, July 27 Nicholas ClaaSsen rested his forearms on the levers of his forklift, and looked out across the choppy waters of this contested pOrt.

title: Women Protesting Use Of Federal Funds in Suit
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Some women's organizations are protesting the use of Federal money to help the state of Missouri pay for a lawsuit challenging boycott by supporters of the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Associated Press
description: GARBAGE PILED UP in San Antonio, Tex., where sanitation workers are on strike. The walkout was triggered by city's dismissal of 191 garbage collectors who refused to work unless their wage demands were granted.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Louis J. Nicastro, a 50yearold financial executive, knows what it is like in the world of corporate infighting. Mr. Nicastro, who was president of the Seeburg Corporation in the mid1960's, sold his interest in the jukebox manufacturer to the Commonwealth United Corporation, and within a brief time, left that company after struggles in the boardroom with the chief executive officer.

title: Dance at Westbeth
description: SnowTunnels and Other Visions, an abstractdance program choreographed by Sandra Stewart, will be performed the next two weekends at the Cunningham StudioWestbeth, 463 West Street (between Bank and Bethune Streets). Performances tonight and tomorrow are at 9:30 P.M. Tickets are $3.50 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Reservations: 6916500.

title: McKnight Estate To Offer 3M Shares
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced it had been informed by representatives of the estate of William L. McKnight, former chairman of the company, that the estate was planning to sell approximately 2.25 million shares of common stock in a secondary public offering.

title: More Walking Tours Afoot on Sunday
description: At 2 P.M. on Sunday, three walking tours sponsored by the Municipal Art Society will leave from various points around the city.

title: News Summary
description: The United Nations Security Council endorsed a Western plan for ending guerrilla war in SouthWest Afrjca and leading it to independence as the new black African state of Namibia at the earliest possible date. The Council approved the independence resolution, 13 to 0, with the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia abstaining. In a second resolution, the Council unanimously supported steps to insure the early reintegration of the port of Walvis Bay into Namibia. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: New Face: Susan Stevens Finding Herself As a Mexican Nun
description: SOR JUANA INEZ DE LA CRUZ was a 17thcentury Mexican nun. Susan Stevens, a 20thcentury New Yorker, has never been to Mexico, much less in a convent. But Miss Stevens has been drawing appreciative audiences to the theater of the Women's Interart Center on West 52d Street with her portrayal of the gifted Juana: poet, musician, theologian, mathematician and playwright.

title: Snug Harbor Arts Center Names Executive Director
description: Culminating a nationwide search begun last August, Dr. Michael T. Sheehan has been appointed the first executive director of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, Thomas Schleier, president of the center's board, announced.

title: Penal Code Revision Easing Curbs on Sex Passed in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 27  The State Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a new penal code for New Jersey that, among other provisions, eliminates penalties for sexual conduct between consenting adults. The vote was 24 to 14.

title: 2 Children Die in Missouri Fire
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 27 (UPI) twoalarm fire destroyed a fourstory apartment building last night, killing two children and forcing the evacuation of about 20 other residents. Inspectors said that arson was not suspected in the fire, which apparently started in the secondfloor apartment that Anthony M. Johnson, 5 years old, and his 9monthold brother, Kenneth, shared with their mother, Linda Johnson. The inspectors said that Mrs. Johnson was not home at the time of the fire.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALGIERS, Algeria, July 27 (UPI) The executive committee of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa today gave a vote of no confidence to Nigeria's decision to boycott the Commonwealth Games, a committee member said.

title: 35 Firemen Felled in 14th St. Fire
description: Thirtyfive firemen suffered smoke inhalation yesterday in a blaze in the basement of a John's Bargain Store on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Times Earnings at Peaks
description: The New York Times Company reported record earnings yesterday for the seCond quarter and the first half of 1978.

title: The Case of the Marxist Professor
description: The University of Maryland's president, John Toll, says his refusal to name a Marxist as chairman of the government department at the College Park campus was based on the nominee's lack of qualifications. But the facts of the case appear to tell a different story.

title: OldTime Yachts Sail to Mystic Festival
description: Like stately dowagers gathering for a meeting of the clan, oldtime yachts began easing into the Mystic Seaport in Connecticut today for the Third Annual Antique and Classic Boat Rendezvous.

title: Astros Beat Mets, 83, On 2Hitter
description: HOUSTON, July 27  The Mets arrived in this city of oil tycoons last night gushing with enthusiasm after having completed their most successful homestand of the season. But the Astros quickly stemmed the flow of confidence tonight with a threerun first inning in the Astrodome that paved the way for an 83 Houston victory. on J.R. Richard's twohitter.

title: Korchnoi Holds the Edge in Fifth Chess Title Game
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 27 A breakthrough may be in the making in the world chess championship match between the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and Viktor Korchnoi, the Russian defector who is challenging him.

title: Conceiving the Inconceivable
description: In his 1932 novel, Brave New World, Aldous Huxley envisaged a future in which sex and procreation would be entirely separate, a future in which people would be massproduced in hatcheries and conditioning centers. We are still, fortunately, very far from such a world; only very recently have scientists been able to identify one specific gene the one that directs the production of hemoglobin  from among the millions of genes that constitute the blueprint for each human being. But a landmark has now been passed with the birth of a normal baby conceived outside human body. Probably not since the invention of nuclear weapons has a scientific advance been received with such mixed feelings.

title: OilImport Dip Expected to Aid Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The decline in United States oil imports will continue for the remainder of this year and contribute to a lower trade deficit and a stronger dollar, Treasury Under Secretary Anthony M. Solomon said today.

title: Hancock, Nelson Tied At 64 in Hartford Golf
description: WETHERSFIELD. Conn., July 27 (AP)  Rod Funseth's course recordtying 29 on the front nine could not withstand the charge of two young golfers, Phil Hancock and Larry Nelson, at the $210,030 Greater Hartford open today.

title: Tax Cut in 1979 Of $16.3 Billion Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The House Ways and Means Committee tonight approved a $16.3 billion tax cut to take effect in 1979, including tax reductions for individuals averaging 5.7 percent.

title: Business Records
description: ANNIE BRIGGI NS, also known as Annie Williams, 2420 Lawrence Ave., the Bronx. Liabilities. 31,438; assets, none.

title: Stanley Phillips extile Executive
description: Stanley Phillips, Who was president of the Cannon Mills Company for 22 years,; died on Sunday in Montclair, N.J., where he had lived for many years. He was 82 years old.

title: The New York Times/ Paul Hosefris
description: It is one of the oldest museums and one of the newest. It has no stairs, but it is three stories high. It is finished, but doesn't look it. And It helps make child an adult and adult a child. What is it?

title: Sullivan, Option Trading Pioneer, Planning to Leave C.B.O.E.
description: CHICAGO, July 27Joseph W. Sullivan, the man who pioneered exchangetraded stock options, said today that he planned to resign within a year as president of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the nation's chief options market.

title: Concorde Loss for British Line
description: LONDON, July 27  British Airways disclosed in its annual report today that in its last fiscal year it lost nearly as much on its supersonic Concorde as it earned on its total operations. The Government is being asked to shoulder some of the burden.

title: Art People
description: THE good news this week is that at long last one of our great East Coast museums has got itself a woman director. Boston didn't do it. The Met didn't do it. The National Gallery in Washington never even thought of it. But as of Monday last the Philadelphia Museum of Art has a woman director in the person of Jean Sutherland Bones.

title: About Real Estate
description: There's nothing like looking for an apartment to provide a realestate developer with market wisdom.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, announced yesterday that he had vetoed a bill approved Tuesday by the County Legislature to raise the pay of more than 400 sheriff's deputies and correctional officers. He said that the raises were approved at a time when the county treasury can least stand it, and that the Legislature's action ignored existing labor contracts.

title: Robert Shaw Bringing In Another Top Choir
description: The sopranos of the Westminster Choir made their soaring entry in Brahms's Nnie, and the other voices joined in in turn, filling acampus chapel with a wonderful sound Out with most unusual words.

title: Major Lenders Pledge $2.55 Billion for New York
description: The principal parties to New York City's fouryear financing plan gave conditional commitments yesterday to lend the city $2.55 billion, a major step in the city's effort to get longterm loans and put its financial affairs in order.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Harzfeld's Inc., Kansas Citybased operating company of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., has named Ann Stegner president.

title: Prosecution Rests in Curare Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 27  The state rested its case at 3:30 this afternoon in the fivemonthold trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich after strenuous final arguments before Judge William J. Arnold on what evidence would be admitted.

title: Antiques in Garden City
description: About 31 dealers in antique books and furniture will display tDeir merchandise in a fair this weekend at the Roosevelt Field Mall, Garden City, L.T. Original copies of Charles Dickens's .Pickwick Papers will be among the rarities offered. Hours are 10 A.M. to P.M. today and tomorrow and noon to P.M. on Sunday. Admission is free. Information: (516) 6811118.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: TOKYO, July 27  The dollar plunged today to a another postwar low in the secondheaviest trading on record on the Tokyo currency market. It was the fourth consecutive day of declines here for the American currency.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The case of M. A. Farber, the New York Times, reporter who has been convicted of contempt of court for refusing to turn over his notes in connection with a New Jersey murder trial, is the latest in a series of court disions around the country involving, the newsgathering process. They involve the increasingly troublesome question of whether news organization is protected by the First Amendment and state shield laws from turning over notes or other material amassed during the course of news gathering.

title: EARNINGS
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a leading oilfield services company, increased secondquarter. profits by 24.5 percent and revenues by, 21.1 percent in the same period,, according to the company's semiannual report released yesterday. Net income for the quarter was record $131.6 million, or $1.55 a share, up from $105.7 million, or $1.23 a share, for the similar three months a year before.

title: WALVIS BAY IS CRITICAL ISSUE South Africa Assails the West for Urging Turnover and Warns Independence Is in Doubt
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 The Security Council today endorsed the Western plan for ending guerrilla war in SouthWest Africa and leading the territory to independence as the new black African state of Namibia at the earliest possible date.

title: Don King and Garden Join to. Promote Boxing.
description: EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 27 Sarah Schwartz of Bronxville, sitting in a lounge chair on the terrace of the Lake Isle Country Club, was an unwilling witness to boxing history today when Madison Square Garden formally announced that it had entered a copromotion agreement with Don King, the man who bills himself as the world's greatest promoter.

title: Blaze Damages Bowery Church Erected in 1799
description: Fire swept through New York City's historic St. Mark'sintheBowery Episcopal Church at Second Avenue. and 10th Street yesterday, sending the roof crashing 50 feet to the floor of the main sapctuary and destroying nine of the 179yearold landmark's 23 stainedglass windows.

title: The Pop Life
description: JOHN McLAUGHLIN, the English guitarist whose Mahavistinu Orchestra spearheaded the jazzrock fusion of the early 1970's, brings his new electric band to the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park on Monday night for its first New York appearance. The concert, which begins at 6:30 in the park's Wollman Amphitheater, with the English group Brand X as the opening act, promises to be an auspicious occasion. This is Mr. McLaughlin's first electric band and his first chance to reclaim a broad rock audience in several years. The band's instrumentation is identical to that of the Mahavishnu Orchestra, which was probably the most influential jazzbased group of this decade, but it features a renowned Indian violinist, L. Shankar, who divides his time between working in this country and playing Indian elassical music at home. It also incorportes Indian scales, rhytImi patterns and styles of melodic decoration into electric music in a manner that the Mahavishnu Orchestra only hinted at.

title: House Committee Backs Nuclear Aircraft Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The House Appropriations Committee approved a $119.4 billion defense spending bill today after voting by the narrowest possible margin to buy a nuclear aircraft carrier opposed by the Carter Administration.

title: Moscow, Starved for Society Gossip, Relishes a Bit
description: MOSCOW, July 27  The trouble with a classless society such as the Soviet Union is that the upper class keeps its affairs so secret that even juicy gossip remains the private preserve of the privileged elite. This summer, though, rumors about high society have become a bit more democratized, and everyone is entitled to gossip about Christina Onassis, the 27yearold daughter of the late Aristotle Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate.

title: State Senate Panel Adopts a Bill Requiring Seniors In High School to Meet State Standards in 3 Fields
description: TRENTON, July 27  Concerned by tests showing a decline in student achievement, the Senate Education Committee cleared a bill today that would require high school seniors to meet state standards in reading, writing and mathematics before receiving diplomas.

title: Spanish Police Report A Roundup of Leftists
description: MADRID, July 27 (Reuters)  The Spanish police say they have rounded up members of a leftwing guerrilla cell suspected of involvement in three killings, including the murder of the director general prisons in March.

title: Texts of Resolutions on Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27  Following are the texts of the two resolutions on SouthWest Africa adopted today by the Security Council:

title: Business and the Law
description: DAVID W. EWING, a teacher at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, has been called the guru of a new movement, and his book, Freedom Inside the Organization, has been called a manifesto for employees seeking civil liberties at work.

title: Whitney Gathers Drawings Harvest
description: WHAT is a drawing is just about the most difficult question to answer these days. From 20thCentury American Drawings: Five Years of Acquisitions at the Whitney Museum one might take it to be anything from a razorcut relief, five or six layers in depth,, to an assemblage of fingerprints. And that's only a beginning. Distant now is the day when Ingres could speak of drawing as the integrity of art and Degas could say, Just make lines, my dear fellow, lines, and plepty of them, to a young painter who came to him for advice.

title: Advertising
description: IN, 1977, wDen magazines were in general profiting greatly from the rising disenchantment with television rates, Parade, the Sunday newspaper supplement, had rather a flat year. Thomas H. Ferguson, president and new chief executive of what could well be the world's largest weekly print medium, blames free standing inserts for the results.

title: Priest Who Barred Bingo Is Removed From Parish Office
description: TRENTON, July 27(AP)  A 63yearold Roman Catholic priest who abolished bingo games, dismantled church clubs and dropped some religious services, was dismissed from his suburban parish today.; At Center of Controversy

title: Simply A Shift In Bolivia
description: WASHINGTON  BoliVians often ref& to their government as el gobierno deiwto, sardonic comment on Chronic political instability in which their governments come and go like the,Changing of the guard The recent coup detal by former Air Force General Juan Pereda Asbun, resembles theyebellion that installed his immediate predecessor, Hugo Banzer. in 1971. Both started their respective coups in the city of Santa Cruz and both claimed to be saving the nation from International Communism.

title: 13,648 See Apples Beaten, 2621
description: It's not who wins or loses in World Team Tennis, but how many people attend the match. There were smiles on the faces of most W.T.T. officials last night at Madison Square Garden, not because the Apples won  they didn't but because 13,648 fans showed up.

title: 5,000 Signatures Filed in Protest on Raises in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 27  More than 5,000 signatures were filed with the Newark City Clerk today by a citizens group seeking to rescind the substantial salary increases voted that the City Council voted for itself, the Mayor and other high city officials on July 12.

title: A.P. Sued Over Photos of Baby
description: The parent company of The London Daily Mail, which paid the parents of the world's first baby conceived outside the body nearly $600,000 for the exclusive rights to their story, yesterday sued The Associated Press for alleged Infringement of copyright for transmit ting pictures of the infant that had been published by The Mail.

title: New York Regents Set New Standards for High School Graduation
description: ALBANY, July 27  With the approval of new minimum competency tests today. the New York State Board of Regents has adopted statewide one of the most rigorous standards for high school graduation in the nation.

description: Frank W. Luerssen, who became executive vice president of the Inland Steel Company two months ago, has been elected president of the company, the nation's sixthlargest steel corporation.

description: RIP TORN, who always seems to play the strangest of characters, will play one bearing a suspicious resemblance to the late Howard Hughes in a production of Sam Shepard's Seduced opening late this fall at the American Place Theater, Ill West 46th Street.

title: Black Policemen Gain in Detroit
description: DETROIT, July 27  Coleman A. Young campaigned hard and and strong five years ago to become the first black Mayor of this key industrial city, stressing improvement of the black presence of the city's predominantly white police force. A city that had a black population of 50 percent, he argued, should have police force reflecting that.

title: Auctions
description: RICHARD BOURNE is boasting these days about an impressive find that will go under the hammer at his whaling auction in Hyannis, Mass., next week. The auctioneer found a mid19thcentury painting of the New Bedford whaler Trident in a previously unknown collection not far from New Bedford. A lively rendering, it depicts the Trident under full sail, a whale chasein the foreground and a second whaler possibly the Charles W. Morgan bearing down from the right. The presale estimate on this oil, painted by Carl Justus Barmen Fedeler in 1846, is $20,000 to $30,000, and it will be sold late Tuesday at the end of the tvioday auction. Of the dozen other stars in the marine art and artifacts sale are two compelling seascapes by Benjamin Russell (estimated to fetch, at most, $20,000 and $25,000). A highlight of the ship's gear up for sale is a hefty bell from the American liner Leviathan with the ship's name and New York 1923 embellishing the surface. Mr. Bourne expects it will sell, at the outside, for $1,000.

title: Screen: 'Big Wednesday' Gets Caught in Some Rough Surf:Buddyhood of Surfing
description: IT wasn't very long ago that John Milius's expensive, ambitious "Big Wednesday" was one of the more widely touted movies on the horizon, so what's it doing sneaking into Flagship theaters for only a weeklong run? The honorable thing, that's what. "Big Wednesday" isn't even a tiny fraction of what it was once cracked up to be.The surprise is not that Mr. Milius has made such a resoundingly awful film, but rather that he's made a bland one. Mr. Milius's reputation, after all, rests at least as heavily on his well-publicized walk-softly-and-carry-an-elephantgun world view as it does on his several screenplays and his direction of "Dillinger" and "The Wind and the Lion." So one might have supposed that "Big Wednesday," his epic about surfing and buddyhood, would have boasted at least enough trigger-happy machismo to make it controversial.True, "radical" is something of a dirty word in the screenplay Mr. Milius co-wrote with Dennis Aaberg. And Jan-Michael Vincent, as one of the three legendary surfers a narrator describes as "the big names, the kings, our own royalty," has a strident hippie-baiting scene during the segment of the film that's set in 1968. Mr. Vincent, outraged to find that his favorite hangout now serves organic food instead of cheeseburgers, and that a waiter in a butterfly-patterned undershirt keeps calling him "brother," douses the incense on his table with water and cautions the waiter to turn down the music.This, plus a scene that shows the three surfers quietly watching the Watts riots on television, is about as much of a nod "Big Wednesday" cares to give the real world.But it's not just the film's rapt attention to wave patterns that makes it so emphatically all wet. Mr. Milius's three adventurers, whom we watch over the course of 12 years and still never get to know, have an unbecoming horror of growing up, not just of growing old. "It's really different here," gushes a girl from Chicago who is just becoming initiated to the glories of beach life in L.A. "Back home, being young was just something you'd do until you grew up. Here . . . it's everything!"Being young means different things to our three respective heroes. For Leroy (Gary Busey), it's a chance to experience the joys of painting his torso with what looks like barbecue sauce and then trying to crawl into an oven. For Jack (William Katt), it's going to Vietnam for three years and then coming home expecting an old girlfriend to be a current girlfriend, even though he hasn't kept in close enough touch with her to find out she's now married. For Matt (Mr. Vincent), it means saying everying he needs to say through very careful flexing of the neck and the nostrils.For all of them, being young means acquiring a kind of oral history of wavesmanship from a senior surfer named Bear. Bear tells his biggest, saddest story at a party early in the film, after everyone has finished pouring beer on everyone else's head. He tells his much too solemn audience about a time when "the water was hittin' the cliffs and splashin' 100 feet high  it was like the end of the world." A surfer disappeared that day, and "they never found his body  they just found little pieces of his board."The movie often seems even more uneventful than material like this need make it, and Mr. Milius's attention to his actors focuses more closely on their pectorals than on their performances. He encourages such stiffness in his players that Barbara Hale, for instance, is quite unconvincing as Mr. Katt's mother. This is a faux pas of no mean eminence; after all, Miss Hale actually is Mr. Katt's mother.The score for the film includes a number of hit songs from the early 60's, which makes the absence of any "surf music" of that period worth noting. Surely the Beach Boys or Jan and Dean were just as deeply in love with the sport as Mr. Milius, and for them, too, it had connotations of masculine daring. However, it also had a spirit of fun. And there's no room for real levity or pleasure in Mr. Milius's grim, dispirited and too often incoherent scheme of things."Big Wednesday" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") apparently because its characters pranks tend to be violent, and their language slightly rough.

title: When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen.
description: When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen.

title: Caffreys Singing in Jersey
description: The Caffrey Family, a bluegrass group, will perform Sunday at 8 P.M. at the old red mill in Clinton Historical Museum Village, 56 Main Street, Clinton, N.J. Tickets are $3 ($2 for the elderly and $1.50 for those younger than 12). Listeners should bring chairs or blankets. The rain date is Sunday. Information: (201) 7344101 or (201) 7354104.

title: Higher Nets and Payouts Keep Stocks Moving Up
description: A combination of favorable earnings reports and dividend increases helped. keep the stock market moving ahead yesterday on heavy volume. In the glamour sector, computer and oilservice stocks ranked among the best performers.

title: WouldBe Parents Are Seeking Help From Doctors of British Baby
description: LONDON, July 27  The gynecologist and the physiologist who brought about the first human birth from an egg fertilized in a laboratory are receiving requests for help from other childless couples all over the world.

title: Associated Press
description: ILLEGAL MOVIE TAPES SEIZED: An F.B.I. agent loading cartons containing more than 600 videotape cassettes of major motion pictures into a van for shipment to Newark yesterday. The tapes were seized in a raid on a videotape company in Burlington on Wednesday. Valued at about $14 million, the tapes were master copies copyrighted movies and meant to be sold to persons possessing videotape machines for use on television sets.

title: A Pair of StarCross'd Promoters
description: Promoters Don Montague King and Teddy Capulet Brenner were joined in the holy bonds of expediency yesterday with Sonny Werblin in the role of Friar Laurence. It was solemn occasion accompanied by feasting, drinking, golf, tennis and swimming at the Lake Isle Country Club in Eastchester. As top honcho at Madison Square Garden, Werblin announced that Don King was joining the Garden as copromoter of boxing. There was, however, a minimum of hugging and kissing between King, who once tried and failed get Teddy Brenner's job, and Brenner, who continues as president of Madison Square Garden boxing. In any other business would seem a curious union, but in the fight racket unlikely alliances are formed and dissolved from week to week.

title: Japanese Auto Exports Up
description: TOKYO, July 27 (Reuters)  Japanese auto exports to the United States in the first six months this year rose 31.5 percent to just over one million units, the Automobile Manufacturers.

title: Ballet and Guitar at Heckscher Park
description: Dance and music will come this weekend to Heckscher Park, Prime Avenue and Route 25A, in Huntington, L.I.

title: Productivity Rose In Second Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)Productivity inched up in the second quarter at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 0.1 percent, the Labor Department said today.

title: The Senate's Two Votes on Forein Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Carter Administration won two important foreign policy victories in the Senate this week, but it did not shake the will of the Senate to state, and to try to put into effect, its own view of what American foreign policy ought to be.

title: A FundRaising Drive Is Planned to Rebuild FireDamaged Church
description: Architects and officials of St. Mark'sintheBowery Episcopal Church asserted yesterday that the 179yearold Manhattan landmark was structurally sound, despite the heavy damage caused by Thursday's threealarm fire, and said RESTORATION BELIEVED POSSIBLE: Stephen Facey, administrator of St. Mark'sintheBowery Church, in fireravaged interior yesterday. Page 21.efforts would be made to raise from $500,000 to $1 million fora restoration.

title: Atherton in Cairo for New Talks
description: JERUSALEM, July 28  Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the United States special envoy for the Middle East, left Jerusalem for Cairo this afternoon in an effort to get a new round of peace talks started.

title: High U.S. Aide, O'Neill Protg, Is Dismissed, Setting Off Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Despite the strenuous objections of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., a close friend and protg of the Speaker was formally dismissed today from the secondranking job in the problemridden General Services Administration.

title: Miss Onassis To Wed, Settle In 2Room Flat
description: ATHENS, July 28 Christina Onassis, determined to prove to her fellow shipowners and the rest of the world that she is serious about her impending marriage on Tuesday to a former Soviet shipping official, will spend most of the first six months of their married life in Moscow, according to close friends of the heiress here.

title: 3 Pull Ahead in Kansas Republican Senate Primary
description: ATCHISON, Kans., July 26  Kansas Republicans, facing a serious threat of losing a Senate seat for the first time since 1932, still have confident, if largely unknown, candidates who are backing their ambitions with their bankbooks.

title: June Price Index Up in New York
description: Soaring food and housing costs helped push up the Consumer Price Index for New Yorkarea residents eighttenths of 1 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 2 Koreas Maintain Delicate Balance in Shared Area
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 28  Specialist 4 Daney Dayley from southern Idaho, a United States Army volunteer who serves as a United Nations guard here, was explaining to a group of tourists how Panmunjom functions these days.

title: Danish Schools Promote Windmill Power
description: ULFBORG, Denmark  One of the world's largest windmills has risen on the moors facing the North Sea in a remote corner of Denmark because its builders, as one of them said this week, wanted to demonstrate that we could do something positive and, not just keep saying no.

title: Gold Soars Above $200 in Europe, Reflecting Dollar's New Weakness
description: LONDON, July 28  The price of gold soared above $200 an ounce for the first time on European bullion markets in heavy trading today, reflecting renewed weakness of the United States dollar in world currency markets.

title: Children's Hour Staged At the Berkshire Festival
description: STOCKBRMGE, Mass.  Time has been eating away at the logical underpinnings of Lillian Hellman's The Children's Hour. There is still emotional power in it, but not enough to still the squeak of restless improbabilities.

title: AroundtheNation
description: Labor Troubles Sirumerini In Two Southern Cities

title: Miss Onassis To Wed, Settle In 2Room Flat
description: ATHENS, July 28  Christina Onassis, determined to prove to her fellow shipowners and the rest of the world that she is serious about her impending marriage on Tuesday to a former Soviet shipping official, will spend most of the firstsix months of their married life in Moscow, according to close friends of the heiress here.

title: Books of The Times Portrait of a Born Actress
description: In 1903, a 15yearold Cockney, by her own description a raving lump of a girl, was indentured to a milliner and for the next nine years led an unambitious, lowermiddleclass London life  except for the fact that in the evenings she participated in amateur theatricals. At the age of 24, she played Beatrice in excerpts from Much Ado About Nothing. That performance, Bryan Forbes writes, might have slipped into oblivion had not William Poel been present in the audience. Mr. Poel was a director and a passionate innovator in the theater, and the milliner was a born actress named Edith Evans.

title: Your Money
description: EVERY summer the same scene occurs: Millions of tourists line: up in banks around the country to buy travelers checks for their vacstions.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP)  The United States Steel Corporation today announced the closing of its Central Furnaces plant effective Sept. 30, saying that a combination of market losses, increasing costs and additional expenditures for pollution controls made further operations unfeasible.

title: Phone Customers Face Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, July 28 (AP)  New York Telephone's six million customers are going to receive another rate increase this one adding at least another 28 cents to the minimum monthly bill and increasing charges overall 3.76 percent.

title: Of 20 Nations, Only U.S. Showed 77 Jobless Drop
description: GENEVA, July 28  The United States was the only nation of 20 that were surveyed by the International Labor Organization where the number of unemployed actually decreased in 1977, although all of them recorded greater number of people at work.

title: Carey Dismisses President, Naming a Grumman Aide to the Job
description: Robert K. Pattison was dismissed yesterday as president of the Long Island Rail Road, which was described by an aide to Governor Carey as in hideous shape  something commuters have long been saying.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Minnesota Tivins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P. M. OldTimers Day festivities, 1:15 P. M. (Telvision Channel 11;1:15. RadioWINS,)

title: Deaths
description: APPELBAUMRuth, On July 27, 1978. Wife of Percy Max. Daughter of Lena Geller. Sister of Harold and Milton Geller. Mother of Faith, Ben, and Kirk. Grandmother of Rebekah and Kalista. She was a woman. The family will beet home Sunday afternoon, July 30.

title: The New York Times/ Edward Hausner
description: A Federal judge in Newark issued temporary injunction late yesterday forbidding the strike vote that had been set for Monday by the New York Metropolitan Area chapter of the American Postal Workers Union.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.9% FOR MONTH, CONTINUING A CLIMB
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Consumer prices continued to climb in June, sending the annual rate of inflation well above 10 percent for the second quarter of the year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Soviet Sets Off Nuclear Device
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, July 28 (AP) The Soviet Union set off an underground nuclear explosion in the Semipalatinsk testing area in western Siberia early today, the seismological institute here reportedit was the sixth explosion registered in the area this year.

title: Louisville Mayor Won't Quit Over an Embarrassin Trip
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 (AP)Mayor William Stansbury, who was out of town with an assistant when fire. fighters here went on, strike and who then admitted to lying about his whereabouts, is resisting suggestions from Gov. Julian Carroll, city aldermen and some members of the public that he resign.

title: LEGISLATURE PLANS BLUE LAW REVERSAL
description: TRENTON, July 28  State Senate leaders said today that another special session had been scheduled for Aug. 14 to vote on a bill that would reverse legislation passed last night repealing New Jersey's blue laws. which restrict Sunday sales in 10 of the state's 21 counties. The blue laws were repealed as part of a new criminal code that cleared the Legislature last night.

title: Vorster Responds Defiantly to U.N. Over Walvis Bay
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, July 28  Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa declared today that his Government would not be dictated to by the United Nations over the disputed port of Walvis Bay. Early reintegration of the port into SouthWest Attica, when becomes the independent black nation of Namibia, was demanded by a Security Council resolution yesterday.

title: Korchnoi Blunders His Big Chance, and 5th Game Goes On Again
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 28 Viktor Korchnoi muffed a golden opportunity tonight to break the string of draws in his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov.

title: Excerpts of Application for Stay and White's Order
description: The instant proceeding is an adjunct to a New Jersey criminal prosecution, New Jersey v. Jascalevich, Indictment No. S49676. This proceeding involves the attempted wholesale invasion of reporter's and a newspaper's investigative files  containing source and confidential materials. It also involves the certainty of immediate incarceration and heavy imposition of financial penalties for petitioners, who to this day have not been afforded a hearing by any court on their claims under the First and 14th Amendments or on their claims of statutory protection of newspersons' rights under various state shield laws.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AVENUE LULLABY Those:Sun day night concerts continue to draw nostalgia buffs to Gregory's, the jazz lair on First Avenue at 63d Street, as tribute is accorded such composers as George Gershwin, Cole Porter,.Harold Arlen, Jimmy Van Heusen and Vihdent Youmans. The tunesmith being honored tomorrow wilt be Harry:Warren, whOse melodies set to Al Dubin's lyrics made moirie tistory at Wqrne'r from 42d Street'? through the cavalcode of Busby.Berkeley musicals, with such hits as Lullaby. of Broadway, I Only Have Eyes for You, By a Waterfall and Shanghai Lil. Later, Mr: Warren, teamed with Johnny Mercer for the famed  Atcheson, Topeka and the,Santa Fe from The Harvey Girls

title: Chevette Price Increased $90
description: DETROIT, July 28 (UPI)  The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation announced today $90 increase in the sticker price of its popular subcompact Chevette  the fourth such price rise since January.

title: About New York Lincoln Center's Outdoor Gala
description: The first production almost every evening at Lincoln Center starts a bit after 6 P.M. when the sun dips, as does at this time of year, behind the southeast corner the Metropolitan Opera House. At that point, the open, spacious plaza becomes the stage for an improvisational outdoor spectacle with a cast of perambulating thousands (hundreds are also sitting) drinking in the fascinating variety of itself before disappearing abruptly into the three theaters that are the backdrop for one of the most eyecatching and festive gathering places in the city.

title: 3 Prominent Midtown Hotels Sold; 2 May Be Turned Into Apartments
description: In a complicated flip transaction, the Loews Corporation has sold three prominent midtown hotels  the Barclay, which will be refurbished, and the Biltmore and the Roosevelt, one or both of which may be converted to apartments.

title: Cambodian Defends 75 Closing Of Nation to Prevent a Civil War
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28 Cambodia's Foreign Minister, leng Sary, said today that the closing of his country and evacuation of Phnom Penh after the Communists took over in 1975 had been necessary because otherwise we would have had a civil war.

title: Mr. Fraser's Walkout
description: Douglas Fraser, the leader of the auto workers union, is not class warrior or man of wild temperament. He is one of the nation's most enlightened labor figures, a disciple of Walter Reuther, who has sought serve the needs of both his country and union. It is more than unfortunate, therefore, that he has abruptly bolted from the LaborManagement Group, the unofficial meeting ground of prominent union and business leaders concerned about their mutual interests in social and economic issues.

title: Lummis Is Upheld as Hughes Estate Administrator
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 28 (AP)The right of William R. Lummis to be administrator of Howard R. Hughes's estate in Delaware has been upheld by the Delaware Sunreme Court.

title: Farber and Times Win Stays in U.S. and Jersey Courts
description: The reporter. for The New York Times who had been ordered to jail until he turned over his notes for possible use in New Jersey murder trial won stays yesterday from both the New Jersey Supreme Court and Associate Justice Byron R. White of the United States Supreme Court. The stays will allow the reporter, M. A. Farber, to remain free at least until noon Tuesday pending further action by Justice White.

title: Congressional Estimates of Tax Cuts
description: Here is what Congressional tax experts estimate the Federal income tax cut would be for typical taxpayers, at various income levels, under the bill which the House Ways and Means Committee approved Thursday. The table is computed taxpayers with deductible personal expenses of 23 percent of their income.

title: Seven Presidents Park To Get U.S.Financing.
description: TRENTON, July 28 (AP)  A $4.6 million park project in Long Branch commemorating seven Presidents who vacationed in the Monmouth County cornmunity won approval today for Federal and state aid, the State Department of Environmental Protection said.

title: Architect of Tax Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Representative James Robert Jones, the conservative Oklahoma Democrat whose name is fixed to the compromise taxreduction bill appl;pved last night by the House Ways and Means Committee, expresses surprise that the measure bears that label. I've only been a member of that committee for four years and, while I've tried to play apart in accomplishing certain legislative goals, I've felt the credit for them should go to those who had the prominence to get them through, he said.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE Bell System is considering the use of a new coding process to automate the production and printing of the yellow pages in telephone directories. The method can economically store illuqtrations such as line drawings as well as pages of type for reproduction or transmission.

title: Gold Soars Above $200 in Europe, Reflecting Dollar's New Weakness
description: LONDON, July 28  The price of gold soared above $200 an ounce for the first time on European bullion markets in heavy trading today, reflecting renewed weakness of the United States dollar in world currency markets.

title: Chicken Was King of the Contest
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It was drumsticks at 20 paces and no chickening out, as eight men and 43 women squared off against one another to compete for $20.000 inprizes at the 30th annual National Chicken Cooking Contest held here earlier this week. The contest is one of the nation's oldest and largest cooking competitions, second perhaps only to the muchballyhooed Pillsbury bakeoff.

title: Deaths
description: KETCHAmBenlamin Graham. On July 27, 1978 of Floral Park. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Eleanore Robb of Randolph, N.J. and Suzanne Bornstein of Tokyo, Japan. Fond brother of Eleanore Harrison of Norwalk, Conn. Also sur, vived by eight grandchildren. Friends may call 25 and 710 p.m. at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at RR Plaza) Floral Park, L.I. Religious service Sunday 8 MM., Rev. James D. Webster officiating. Funeral Mon. day 10:30 a.m. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: C.A.B. Backs El Al Bid For Discount Fares
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved an application by El Al Airlines to provide discount fares for travel between NeW York and Tel Aviv that are 50 percent below normal economy fares.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: TOKYO, July 28  The Bank of Japan, intervening in the Tokyo foreignexchange market today, reportedly bought $200 million to support the ailing American dollar. The dollar ended at 192.10 yen, down fromyesterday's close of 193.50.

title: Carey Signs Bill Raising Sentences For Pimps and Prostitutes Patrons
description: ALBANY, July 28  A bill subjecting prostitutes clients to the same penalties as prostitutes and allowing a pimp to be convicted solely on a prostitute's testimony has been signed by Governor Carey, his office announced today.

title: Four. Gunmen Steal Reels of ilm About $2 Million Brink's Robbery
description: BOSTON, July 28  Three armed men handcuffed four film editors in the offices of the Brink's Productions Film Company here today, the police said, and escaped with 13 reels of valuable footage of a movie about the famous 1950 robbery of the Brink's Security Company.

title: Bill Protecting Rights of Inmates Of Institutions Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The House today passed a bill that would give new human rights protection to inmates of institutions and would cut down on some of their grievances that reach the courts.

title: Painters' Fish House Begins to Rise Again
description: ROCKPORT, Mass., July 28 (AP)The old fish house that became so well known to painters that it was called Motif No. 1 will return to the Rockport waterfront. Work crews began restoration yesterday on the foundation of the structure, which was destroyed by a blizzard last February.

title: Senate, Citing Rights Violations, Bans Most Trade With Uganda
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The Senate voted today to prohibit the import A goods from Uganda because of humanrights violations, including what it said was genocide committed by the regime of Idi Amin.

title: JOHN N. KELLEY
description: John N. Kelley, who retired in 1958 as director of transportation and refrigeration engineering for the United Fruit Company, died Wednesday in St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: New U.S. Study of Children's TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Federal Communications Commission  has decided to investigate children's television programming for the first time since 1974 to see if the industry has improved its performance.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that the Wyoming State Supreme Court had named statewide grand jury to investigate allegations of corruption in Rock Springs, Wyo. Gov. Ed Herschler ordered the creation of the grand jury, whose members were named by a state district court judge.

title: Shipping Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Lett Bermuda July27; due 8 A.M. at W. 55thStreet.

title: Fertility Experts Warn Against Raising Hopes
description: In the wake of the birth of the world's first infant conceived outside its mother's womb, leading gynecologists in this area are cautioning infertile couples not to invest too much hope in the new procedure until more is known about it.

title: News Summary
description: South Africa's Prime Minister said his country would not be dictated to by the United Nations over the disputed port of Walvis Bay, which the Security. Council wants integrated into the new state of Namibia, now known as SouthWest Africa. The statement by John Vorster did not say whether South Africa would reject the Security Council call for blackmajority rule in the territory because of the resolution on Walvis Bay, the terrotory's only deepwater port. [Page 3, Columns 46.]

title: Learning to Love, to Work and to Look Out for Number One
description: WABAN. MassIn the beginning, when I first took to my room in an effort to survive as a freelance writer, argued constantly with Sigmund Freud. He kept pressing me to write more,. claiming the most important goals. were leiben und arbeiten. To loge and work. I'd gently remind him that this isn't exactly the old country, where a few hysterics from Zurich could help launch an immortal career. This is America, I'd tell him, where love eludes many, unemployment aboundi, and the only thing of enduring value is The Newlywed Game:

title: United Press International
description: LISBON, July 28 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Mario Soares said today that his Cabinet would continue to run the country, even though he still believed the group should have ceased to function following his dismissal.

title: United Press International
description: CELEBRATION IN CUBA: Fidel Castro raising youth festival torch at ceremony in Santiago marking 25th anniversary of Moncada raid. On July 1953, he and his brother, Ratil, at left, led group of insurgents in attack Army barracks at Moncada; attack failed and Fidel was captured. Freed two years later, he began guerrilla war against Gen. Fulgencio Batista's dictatorship that brought him to power in 1959. July 26 is now a national holiday.

title: Lemon Brings a LowKey Approach to Yankees
description: The game is over, the showers have been taken, and now Al Rosen is trying to get the attention of casually dressed employee who has just reached the Dresslounge bar at Yankee Stadium.

title: CLASH OF PHYSICIANS DESCRIBED AT TRIAL
description: Describing a verbal clash between strongwilled physicians while a disputed laboratory culture rested on a desk between them, Dr. Landrum B. Shettles yesterday told in Federal District Court in Manhattan how he learned that his chief of gynecology five years ago halted a spermegg mixture intended to result in the the world's first human being conceived outside a woman's body.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Greenwich Village landlord was reindicted yesterday on a charge of seconddegree murder in the shooting death of a deaf 13yearold boy.

title: Overseas Airways Closing
description: The board of directors of Overseas National Airways Inc., which owns two DC1030CF aircraft and expects delivery of a third in September. has approved plans to sell the company's assets and liquidate, ceasing operations in September. The company has agreements to sell two of the aircraft, and Edward Dry, chairman, said that because of the gains from the sale, the shareholders ought to receive more than the fully diluted book value.

title: Boeing Charged By S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the Boeing Company, the world's largest manufactor of commercial jetliners, of failing to dis close at least $52 million in question able foreign payments.

title: Dow Posts Gain of 5.72; I.B.M. Rises
description: The stock market shrugged off bad news yesterday about gold prices abroad and consumer prices at home to keep, its rally moving impressively ahead. Trading volume. for a Fridaybefore a summer weekend, was surprisingly heavy and lent authority to the advance.

title: Bill to Cut Takeout Is Signed
description: We are the great racing sfate of the nation, and we want, to keep it that way, Governor Carey said yesterday as he signed into law the legislation reducing the takeout on parimutuel betting in New York State from 17 percent to 14 percent.

title: Carey Signs Bill Raising Sentences For Pimps and Prostitutes Patrons
description: ALBANY, July 28  A bill subjecting prostitutes clients to the same penalties as prostitutes and allowing a pimp to be convicted solely on a prostitute's testimony has been signed by Governor Carey, his office announced today.

title: KEEPING COOL: A South American tapir beating the heat by taking a dip at the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange
description: KEEPING COOL: A South American tapir beating the heat by taking a dip at the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 28 (AP)  Moniticello Raceway, claiming itwas subject to an illegal boycott by horsmen seeking to organize at the track, said today that it would halt racing on Taesday.

title: Women an Issue at Anglican Talk
description: CANTERBURY, England, July 28  A report suggesting that the Roman Catholic policy of excluding women from the priesthood could be reversed was being studied today by Anglican bishops attending the Lambeth Conference. However, Roman Catholic sources at the session denied that any change in policy.was in view.

title: A :New Soviet Threat to Europe Spurs U.S. Decision. on Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The United States Govenimerit is nearing a critical decision over whether to develop a new generation of nucleararmed missiles to deploy in Western Europe in the 1980's. Officials say such a step would constitute a basic shift in strategy.

title: KOCH APPROVES ACT FORCING RESIDENCY ON NEW EMPLOYEES
description: Over objections by the Patrolmen's Benevolent,Association, Mayor Koch fulfilled a major campaign promise yesterday and signed a bill requiring city employees hired after Nov. 1 to reside in the city.

title: KOCH APPROVES ACT FORCING RESIDENCY ON NEW EMPLOYEES
description: Over objections by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Mayor Koch fulfilled a major campaign promise yesterday and signed a bill requiring city employees hired after Nov. 1 to reside in the city.

title: United Press International
description: SCORES HURT IN OAS LEAK:Virefighters trying to plutleak of hydiogen chlotitagai esaaPing from a railroa car in Jackiomiille, Fla. Xiteast 34 people were injured and about 1,500 others were forced to Hee their homes.

title: Farewell to Arms, and All That
description: Is Sex Necessary? E.B. White and James Thurber once asked. The fivepound, 12ounce answer, delivered by a British obstetrician in London Wednesday is. No.

title: Notes on People
description: Avital Shcharansky, wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, has canceled the remaining part of her North American tour to gain support for her husband. She became ill with fatigue several days ago and decided Thursday to return to her home in Jerusalem to rest. She boarded a plane for Israel in Chicago. Lord Pollack, a spokesman for Chicago Action for Soviet Jewry, said, Her schedule could fell a trained athlete. Mrs. Shcharansky, who visited New York, Washington and Los Angeles, had been scheduled to fly to Canada to continue her tour for her husband.

title: People In Sports
description: Dave Gavin of Providence College will coach the United States Olympic basketball team in the 1980 Games in Moscow. Gavin, coach at Providence for the last nine years, was the unanimous choice of the 22member American Basketball Association Games Committee, meeting this week in Colorado. Springs. Frankly, I'm overwhelmed, Gavitt. said Thursday. I think I'm aware of the pressure involved, but the honor far outweighs the pressure. The AOyearold Gavitt succeeds Dean Smith of North Carolina, who coached the goldmedal winning team in 1976.Carl Yastrzemsld, captain of the slumping Boston Red Sox, was admitted Thursday to New England Rehabilitation Center for a back ailment that could keep him sidelined for 10 days. It's a defect in two small bones that we are going to try to cure with hot packs, medication and bed rest, said Dr. Arthur Pappas, Boston's team physician. The 38yearold Tastrzemski said he felt a twinge during batting practice before Thursday night's game with the Rangers. I should have gotten right out of the cage and told Zim [Manager Don Zimmer] that I couldn't play, said Yastrzemski.But with the team not doing very well, I didn't want to be out of the lineup. Meanwhile, Zimmer received a contract yesterday to manage the team through the 1979 season. The Red Sox have lost eight, of nine games.Continuing to sign underage junior hockey players, John Bassett, owner'of the Birmingham Bulls in the World Hockey Association, signed 18yearold Michel Goulet of the Quebec Remparts. Both the W.H.A. and the National Hockey League have understandings with the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association not to sign youngsters until the calendar year of their 20th birthdays.  The Cosmos have postponed until next Thursday their news conference to announce the signing of Johann Cruyff, the Dutch soccer star, for postseason exhibition games. Cruyff ; according to a Cosmos spokesman, is in Spain suffering from food

title: Killings of 2 Puerto Rican Activists Revive Tensions
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 28  Charges of political terrorism and police harassment, relatively infrequent here since series of bombings in the late 1960's, came to the fore again this week with the killings of two young supporters of independence for Puerto Rico.

title: $490.4 Billion Budget Limit Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Representative Robert N. Giaimo of Connecticut, the chairman of  the House Budget Committee, recommended today that Federal spending in the fiscal year 1979 be limited to $490.4 billion, or $8.4 billion below the $498.8 billion expenditure proposed earlier by Congress.

title: Kennedy Assails Carter on Health
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Senator Edward M. Kennedy today denounced President Carter's national health insurance policy and said that he intended to take the issue to the people and introduce his own legislation.

title: Procope Plays Musical Salute Of Ellingtonia
description: Russell Procope, one of the latterday veterans of the DukeEllington Orchestra, played alto saxophone and clarinet, in the Ellington band for 29 years, from 1945 until the Duke died in 1974: He left the band when, Mr. ton died because, he said, the only reason he joined was to play with, the Duke. Before his three decades with Mr. Ellington, Mr. Procope was a key member of the John Kirby Sextet from 1938 until 1945.

title: Beaths
description: GAYNORWilliam Morgan. Beloved husband of Anne (nee White). Re posing at Frank E. Campbell, Ma. dison Avenue at 81st St. Friday 2-: and 7.9PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM at Church of St. Ignatius Loyo la, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: Various Corporations List Sales and Earnings for Latest Quarter KEYSTONE PORTL CEMENT (0)
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Carters Fly to Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., July 28 (AP)President and Mrs. Carter flew today to the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains for the weekend. Mr. Carter was expected to return to Washington on Sunday.

title: The New York Times/ Ed Grazda
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28 There is a new short program and a fresh freeskating routine, with musical emphasis on rock rather than classical. The warmun sweater also is new, handmade by her mother. But the two changes that may signal an Olympic gold medal for Linda Fratiannein 1980 involve her tonsils and nose.

title: Edward Gorey Writing Scenario for a Ballet
description: Edward Gorey, whose furry creatures grace New Yorker magazine cartoons and who won a Tony award this year for his costume designs for Dracula, is writing the scenario for new ballet, Fete Diverse, to be performed by the Eglevsky Ballet Company next fall.

title: DNATest Curbs May Be Eased
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The National Institutes of Health, in light of new knowledge about the potential risks and benefits of gene research, proposed today to ease regulations governing DNA experiments for which it provides funds.

title: Letters
description: The American Convention on Human Rights entered into force on July 18. The United States is not among the 11 member states of the Organization of American States which to date have ratified this treaty. President Carter signed the American Convention on June 1, 1977, and submitted it to the Senate for advice and consent to ratification on Feb. 23, 1978. The Senate has not as yet scheduled hearings on the convention.

title: $37 Billion Military Bill Agreed on by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON. July 28 (UPI) HouseSenate conferees agreed today on a $36.9 billion military proturement bill that includes $210 million for cruise missiles and $1.9 billion for a nuclear carrier that President Carter opposes as too costly.

title: About New York: Lincoln Center's Outdoor Gala
description: The first production almost every evening at Lincoln Center starts a bit after 6 P.M. when the sun dips, as it does at this time of year, behind the southeast corner of the Metropolitan Opera House. At that Point the open spacious plaza becomes the stage for an improvisational outdoor spectacle with a cast of perambulating thousands (hundreds are also sitting) drinking in the fascinating variety of itself before disappearing abruptly into the three theaters that are the backdrop for one of the most eyecatching and festive gathering places in the city.

title: Citibank Disputes ExOfficer
description: Citibank struck back yesterday at a discharged officer who has alleged in a $14 million  lawsuit against the bank that he was wrongfully dismissed for voicing concern that the bank was, violating the tax and foreign exchange laws of some European countries.

title: Boston Opera Will Offer Tippet's New Ice Break
description: The Opera Company of Boston has scheduled the American premiere of Michael Tippet's The Ice Break as well as the Boston premieres of Tchaikovsky's Mazeppa and de Falla's La Vida Breve.

title: As Rhodesian War Intensifies, Whites Resume Their Exodus
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 28 (Reu ters)  The exodus of whites from Rhodesia appears to be gathering speed again after a slowdown earlier this year.

title: Why Costs Rise Faster Than Buildings
description: The uses of adversity are neither sweet nor instructive for leaders of the construction industry's teamsters and operating engineers in the New York metropolitan region. Both unions are vital; the engineers operate heavy machinery like bulldozers and cranes, and run the hoists inside buildings under construction; the teamsters deliver most materials to construction sites. For years, their leaders, along with spokesmen for other local building trades unions, have lamented the decline in work that has idled as many as 75 percent of their members. Now, as a boomlet of longdeferred projects has put some craftsmen back to work, the engineer and teamster leaders are doing their best to keep the recovery as brief and incomplete as possible.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.9% FOR MONTH, CONTINUING A CLIMB
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Consumer prices continued to climb in June, sending the annual rate of inflation well above 10 percent for the second quarter of the year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that the Wyoming State Supreme Court had named statewide grand jury to investigate allegations of corruption in Rock Springs, Wyo. Gov. Ed Herschler ordered the creation of the grand. jury, whose members were named by a state district court judge.

title: Cruise Missiles Succeed in Test
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile flew several hundred miles over the Nevada desert today in a test flight, the Pentagon announced. Last Tuesday, in a different kind of test, two of the $1.7 million missiles fell into the Pacific Ocean in full view of Defense Secretary Harold Brown.

title: Japanese Wire Sales Studied
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Acting on a complaint from 17 American companies, the Treasury today began an antidumping investigation of stainless steel round wire imports from Japan.

title: Jersey Casino Operator Facing a Fine for Violations
description: TRENTON, July 28  A member of the Casino Control Commission today found Resorts International guilty of violating state regulations for casino operation and recommended that the commission fine the company $195,000.

title: Navy Settlement With Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  The Navy announced today a final settlement of $62 million on claims of $159.8 million by the Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company of Seattle for construction of 12 frigates and amphibious shies.

title: U. S. Project to Improve Port Area Unexpectedly Opposed at Hearing
description: BAYONNE, July 28  The Federal Government's plan for deepening and improving the channels in the Kill van Kull and Newark Bay to encourage oceangoing maritime traffic in the New YorkNew Jersey port area ran into strong and unexpected opposition at a public hearing here today.

title: News Summary
description: South Africa's Prime Minister said his country would not be dictated to by the United Nations over the disputed port of Walvis Bay, which the Security Council wants integrated into the new state of Namibia, now known as SouthWest Africa. The statement by John Vorster did not say whether South Africa would reject the Security Council call for blackmajority rule in the territory because of the resolution on Walvis Bay, the terrotory's only deepwater port. [Page 3, Columns 46.]

title: Long Jump to Robinson, But Goal Still is 28 Feet
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28 Arnie Robinson gambled and lost in his bid for a 28foot long jump today, but Bob Roggy dangled from a goal post and then fired the javelin 288 feet 11/2 inches in the start of track and field competition at the National Sports Festival.

title: EARNINGS Texaco Net Falls 33.4%; Record Profits for Aetna
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's secondlargest oil company, yesterday reported a 33.4 percent drop in secondquarter profits, reflecting lower production of crude oil here and abroad, and larger foreign currency losses.

title: A Balancing Act on Secrecy
description: The many abuses of the security system can no longer be tolerated, said the President. Fundamental to our way of life is the belief that when information which properly belongs to the public is systematically withheld by those in power, the people soon become ignorant of their own affairs, distrustful of those who Manage them and  eventually  incapable of determining their own destinies.

title: Years With japarcese Potters Shape a Couple's Life
description: In 1970 it was not unusual for young couples, disillusioned by the Vietnam war and intent on making a statement, to sell everything they owned and set off, undaunted, forparts unknown. When Craig and LauratRoberts did just that, they couldn't have known that during the next six years they would willingly relinquish their hardwon individuality, learn to stifle.emotion, ignore economic wellbeing andthreaten future careers, all for the sake of a ceramic cup.

title: Postal Pact Loses in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, July 28  Members of Branch 84 of the National Association of Letter Carriers voted unanimously last night to reject a proposed contract for postal workers. Frank Gut, president of the local, said workers would not walk out unless the national headquarters sanctioned the action, but we will honor picket lines if other unions decide to walk out. About 2,000 letter carriers in the area are union members.

description: HARTFORD, July 28  State Republi cans tonight nominated Representative Ronald A. Sarasin as the party's candidate for Governor and Lewis B. Rome as Lieutenant Governor by acclamation in show of harmony that starkly contrasted with the Democratic Convention last weekend.

title: Charles J. Symington, 95, Dead; Former Steel Company Chairman
description: Charles J Symington, who retired 20 years ago as board chairman of SymingtonWayne Corporation in New York, manufacturers of steel and other products, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 95 years old and lived at 325 East 72d Street.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28 Cuba vehemently defended itself, today against growing criticism by nonaligned countries of its militant foreign policy, implying that the critics had sold out to reactionary Dowers.

description: LISBON, July 28 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Mario Soares said today that his Cabinet would continue to run the country, even though he still believed the group should have ceased to function following his dismissal.

description: TOKYO, July 28  Recent reinforcement of Soviet naval forces in the Far East has intensified the confrontation between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. in the area according to a Japanese Goveenmeht report approVed by the Cabinet here today.

title: Blumenthal Praises Bill On Tax Cut

Michael Bluinenthat today praised as steps in the right direction two capital gains tax provisions. including a maior benefit for homeowners, that the House Ways and Means Committee wrote into a $16 billion taxcut bill it approved last night.

title: Ethiopia Says It Lifts Long Siege of Asmara By the Eritrean Rebels
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 28 (Reuters) The official Ethiopian press agency said today that Government forces had broken the 10month siege of Asmara, the province capital of Eritrea. The report, if true, would represent a major victory against Eritrean secessionists.

title: Stimulus, Tax Cuts Announced in Bonn
description: BONN, July 28  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt announced today a program of business stimulants and tax relief in. tended to fulfill the commitments he made to leaders of six other industrialized nations at the Bonn economic summit meeting in midJuly, but business leaders expressed reservations on how much growth the package would foster late next year.

title: Scientist Asserts Chemical Used In Herbicide Causes Miscarriage
description: BEAVERTON, Ore., July 28 (AP)  A scientist has reported that most pregnant itiesa monkeys given the chemical dioxin in a controlled experiment suffered miscarriages.

title: Anaconda Plans to Link Price of Cooper to Cornex

title: Don Redlich company Dances in Durham

It seems very much a company of good friends.

title: Willie Nile Sings Rock and Folk
description: Willie Nile, who is at Kenny's Castaways on Bleecker Street through tomorrow night, is an original. Stumbling upon him, as the writer did on Tuesday night. can be auite an exnerience, the kind that makes the daily grind worthwhile. For not only is Mr. Nile original, but also, on the concededly sketchy basis of, just one show, he would seem to be the most gifted songwriter to emerge from the New York folk scene in some while.

Apparently it had been Chiang Ching, the wife of Chairman Mao. who had an- provea it. President Nixon had made his famous visit, and there were indications of rapprochement in the air.
