Because many Government structures are on land that was once a swamp, they are tested periodically to see if they are sinking. The Washington Monument is expected to sink out of sight by the year 113053.

title: Nature on View At Audubon Parks
description: 0F THE 64 wildlife preserves in the National Audubon Society's sanctuary system, four are in Connecticut. Two. in Greenwich and Sharon, are among the few Audubon sanctuaries nationwide that have been developed as public centers. They are open yearround to hikers and children, who enjoy participatory displays on nature, particularly when the woods seem inviting on a hot summer day. The other Connecticut sanctuaries, in Guilford and Sharon, are more fragile and protective of the species that live there, so public access is severly limited.

title: Black Admiral Is Nominated

Gravely Jr., the highestranking black in the American military, to become director of the Defense Communications Agency. Admiral Gravely, 56 years old, commands the Third Fleet in the Eastern Pacific. He will replace Lieut. Gen. Lee M. Paschall of the Air Force, who is retiring.

title: Alicia de Larrocha Performs 2 Concertos by Mozart
description: Listening to Alicia de Larrocha play Mozart in the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, one could not help wondering why more concert pianists have not learned from the example of this petite Spanish virtuoso. Undaunted by the 20thcentury penchant for, brute strengtItand flashy razzledazzle at the keyboard, she patiently cultivated the qualities appropriate to her physique and temperament  clarity of articulation, subtlety of tone color and rhythmic flexibility and ended with acclaim as one of the great performing artists of the world. International success did not come to her early, but once it came, it was, apparently, for keeps.

title: IN BRIEF
description: A strong showing by General Motors pushed midJuly newcar sales 5 percent ahead of last year's pace. In the 10day reporting period, the No. 1 auto maker posted an 18.5 percent advance in sales, though it acknowledged that an incentive program in effect this year helped boost deliveries. At Ford, Chrysler and American Motors, sales dipped below last year's levels. New factory orders for durable goods fell 2.9percent in the month of June, according to the Commerce Department. It was the largest drop recorded by the volatile measurement of business spending since January.... The Labor Department announced that productivity inched upward in the United States by onetenth of a percent in the second quarter. That follows a down- ward revised 4.7 percent decline in the first three months of 1978. The department also noted that major collective settlements reached in the first half of the year provided an average firstyear wage hike of 8 percent.

Anxious and feeling terribly ambivalent about the whole thing.

title: A Medical Digest For the Peripatetic

I was thinking of my lower intestinal tract, he said. That was step one of a dismal vacation that might have been saved by a little forethought.

title: Yonkers Still. Strains for Fiscal Freedom

The $153 million budget included an authori- Zation to sell municipal oonas to pay 4.5 million back salaries awarded by the courts to teachers dismissed in the financial crisis of 1975, but if the city is unable to market the bonds, the budget could once again show a deficit, and that would keep the control board around.

title: Another GoRound In Sheriff Debate

title: A Classic Conflict of Constitutional Guarantees
description: The collision between the press and the courts in the Farber case falls in two areas of controversy about the First Amendment. One is a novel variation on the fair-trial/free-press conflict. The right of the press to publish or broadcast, to gather information, or to have access to judicial proceedings often may nose a danger to an accused's right to a dignified trial by an impartial jury. But in the Farber case, the question is whether a reporter must turn over raw investigative materials to a defendant. An impartial jury is not the concern, but rather the right under the Sixth Amendment to have compulsory process to obtain evidence.

description: New York City abounds in contrasts, incongruities and ambiguities. Order stands next to chaos, rundown tenements next to snooty highrise towers. Art galleries and apartment lofts find space between manufacturing plants.

title: HERRIN IS ASSIGNED TO OSSINING PRISON
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 28  Richard J. Herrin, sentenced this week to eight to 25 years in prison in the hammer-bludgeoning death of Bonnie Joan Garland, was sent to Ossining Correctional Facility yesterday and is scheduled to go to the Clinton Correctional Facility.

title: The Manhattan Apartment Hunt: An Ordeal Not for the Faint of Heart
description: Looking for an apartment in Manhattan, you have always had two choices: Go above your price range and get what you want, or stick to your price and settle for less.

title: E.A. Neal 3d to Wed Kathleen McKeon
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. McKeon of Auburn, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Marie McKeon, to Edmond Anthony Neal 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal Jr. of Southbridge, Mass.

title: Prisoner Serving a Life Sentence At Attica Earns Master's Degree
description: ATTICA, N.Y., July 27  Last month, his graduate program complete, a 40yearold Attica inmate was awarded a master's degree in psychological counseling from Goddard College in Plainfield, Vt., and corrections officials said they believed he is the first inmate in state cor-

title: Chinese Samizdat
description: THE EXECUTION OF MAYOR YIN

title: Growing Number of Thoroughbred Foals Being Bred on L.I. as a Result of New Law
description: MUTTONTOWN, L.I.  She looked around the corral as if to take measure of the other foals, lowered her head slightly and sped out across the field stretching her thinly ankled legs.

title: McNally: If a Play Goes Well...
description: EAST HAMPTON

title: Ralph F. Gates
description: Ralph F. Gates, former Governor of Indiana who served one term from 1945 to 1949, died Friday in Whitley County Hospital in Columbia City, Ind. He was 85 vears old.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It was Jake's idea to holiday in picturesque old Quidicattick during the Festival of the Lobsters. I tagged along because I had a crush on Brett, which bored her. Lobsters bored her, too. You're almost as boring as lobsters, dear, she told me.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Comptroller Harrison 3. Goldin yesterday said that there were 'serious weaknesses in services in New York City's 131 seniorcitizen centers. He cited, in particular, what he said was the centers failure to provide meaningful educational, cultural and social programs and the frequent serving of meals in unsanitary environments.

title: J. David Sampson Weds Carol A. Jasen in Buffalo
description: Carol Ann Jasen, daughter of Senior Associate Judge Matthew J. Jasen of the New York State Court of Appeals and the late Anastasia Gawinski Jasen, was married yesterday to J. David Sampson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Sampson of Hamburg. N.Y.

title: POLITICS Who's In Charge Here?
description: HARTFORD

title: ANTIQUESYankee Spirit at Glastonbury Show
description: GLASTONBURY

title: CAMERA
description: Though we think of 19th century photo equipment as slow and ponderous, by about 1870 there were dry plates ('film to the photographers of the time) fast enough to allow shutter speeds of 1/50 sec. Street scenes could be recorded in which only half the people and passing horsedrawn vehicles were blurred. Many landscape pictures of the 19th and early 20th centuries include the charm of blurred moving subjects, especially water which coalesces into soft decorative patterns.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Cost of Aiding Victims Called Low After Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  A national program to compensate victims of violent crime could cost about $261 million a year, according to a Federal study. Cost of Aiding Victims Called Low After Study

title: Brisco Is Victor In Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 29  Brisco Hanover moved one mile closer to the Hambletonian tonight. With a stakes and trackrecord performance at Roosevelt Raceway, the 2-year-old star of 1977 captured the Dexter Cup trot at a surprising return of $22.60.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: CHICAGO  Clayton K. Yeutter took the reins at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange early this month at a dramatic moment for both the exchange and the futures trading industry.

title: POLITICS A Contrast in Style
description: NASSAU COUNTY residents obviously wanted a political change last November and now, seven months into the administration of County Executive Francis T. Purcell, it is clear they got a major change in style, at any rate. Changes in substance from the administration of Ralph G. Caso remain to be seen.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: For all its dependence on numbers, few disciplines are so profoundly emck tional as economics, with its talk of business confidence, consumer psychology and investor moods. And no area of economics is so subject to sudden shifts of sentiment as the for- eign exchange markets, where rumor and speculation can send currency values shooting up or down in minutes,: and psychological barriers can halt the moves just as quickly.

title: Gaucho Five Spreads Good Will to Israel
description: Kenneth Gary remembers that he was not very fond of the religion studies he had to take at the Holy Name Catholic School on Manhattan's West 97th Street as a youngster. But how was he to know that he would get a chance to play basketball in the Holy Land some day.

title: Friends of the Consumer
description: AN insurance company executive had his car repaired twice in the same month for a malfunctioning alternator. An elderly widow stopped eating potatoes because her local supermarket sold them only in large quantities. A newly married couple waited until spring for a furniture delivery promised in October. A schoolteacher noticed her yearold kitchen floor had already begun to split and crack.

title: Cheyenne Reliving Past in Frontier Days
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 29- In Cheyenne, they are winding up the 82d Annual tomorrow, and if you are from Wyoming you don't have to ask, the 82d annual what?

title: DINING OUT The More Spanish, the Better
description: As its name implies, Le Petit Madrid in Westbury is a restaurant that is Spanish but not exclusively so. Even though the menu depicts Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, it peppered with French ?? Continental specialties as we as several ??ly Spanish ones.

title: Fear Rules in E1 Salvador as Political Foes Turn Violent
description: SAN SALVADOR  After a wave of kidnappings by leftists, the wealthy businessmen and farmers in El Salvador are living in fear, many venturing out of their homes and offices only with armed bodyguards and in bulletproof cars. Some have sent their families out of the country for safety.

title: Food Chopping, Slicing, Mincing, Dicing
description: The home kitchen in America has emerged with a dizzying suddenness as the most sophisticated on earth. In countless thousands of dwellings there are dazzling arrays of cop- per utensils hanging from overhead racks; food processors TM and professional ranges proliferate. Yet home cooks, whom I have observed in kitchens from Maine to California, share the same glaring deficiencies  the proper utensils for chopping, cut: ting and slicing foods and the proper skills in handling these tools.

title: U.S. Requires Insulation Tests
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission has required that cellulose insulation sold to the general public pass flammability and corrosiveness tests. The requirement, announced yesterday, applies to insulation made after Sept. 8. Cellulose insulation consists mainly of ground paper treated with flameretardant chemicals.

title: July Turns to August, and Racing Thoughts Turn to Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 Alydar, the colt that plays Avis to Affirmed's Hertz, was taking his ease in Stall 16 of Barn 3 in the bosky glade called Clare Court. Under the shedrow, stabIenands worked to make order out of a litter of gear vanned up from Belmont = tack boxes painted in the red and blue of Calumet Farm, folded trundle beds, feed buckets, wardrobe trunks, bundles of sweetsmelling hay.

title: Dance, Drink and Ignore
description: With professional athletes getting busted for cocaine and Olympians accused of everything from hormone popping to blood doping, it's generally assumed that athletics are a hotbed of drug abuse. I'd guess the percentage of athletes heavily involved is about the same as for the rest of the population, no more or less depraved than housewives hooked on mother's little helpers and the truckers who swallow bennies like jelly beans.

title: Chinese Travel Costs Add Up to a Mystery
description: The price of the tours that Pan American is conducting to China this summer ranges from $2,661 to $2,986. The bill breaks down to $1,366 for roundtrip economy air fare from New York and $1.295 for the land portion, double, $1,620 for singles. The tour provides 10 days in China with all expenses paid, three nights in Tokyo with breakfast and one meal and two nights in Hong Kong with breakfast and one dinner.

title: Pentagon Calls Atrocious
description: WASHINGTON  How many soldiers, sailors and airmen are chasing the dragon?

title: Editors
description: ILLNESS AS METAPHOR, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $5.95.) A powerful attack on the attitudes we adopt toward sickness in our writing and thinking.

title: Carter Describes Major Worries
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Complaining that there was a horrible mess in the Federal bureaucracy, President Carter said in remarks released today that his most frustrating problem was the effort to persuade Congress to adopt his Civil Service reform program.

title: Queensboro Bridge Market Plan Blocked by Assembly Committee
description: , A State Assembly committee has blocked a proposal to build a $2 million market under the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge, although the project had been approved by the Board of Estimate and the City Council. -

title: FILM VIEW
description: VINCENT CANBY

title: BRIDGE
description: A 40year hoodoo ended in New Orleans last month when the world women's team championship was won by the United States. When this event was first played in Budapest in 1937, there were five American women, but as two of them were involved in the Open Team championship, played concurrently, the remaining three had to recruit a tourist with rather unfortunate results.

title: Prison and the Czars
description: WASHINGTONThe lot of political prisoners in Russia is better today than it was under Stalin and worse than it was under the Czars.

title: SPORTS A WouldBe Boston Celtic
description: BLOOMFIELD

description: PRINCETON

title: New Rochelle College Offers Degrees With a Union Label
description: In one of the string of classrooms, Artur Vilankulu, wearing a bright greenpatterned dashiki, stood before a blackboard and a family tree of the peoples of Africa and spoke to a dozen students about the political traditions of the Zulu.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PROFESSOR OF DESIRE, by Philip Roth. (Bantam, $2.50.) The odyssey of David Kepesh, professor of comparative literature and accomplished womanizer. A thoughtful, even gentle novel about the paradox of male desire, that lacerating sexual passion which may lead to happiness but cannot survive it, was Vance Bourjaily's appraisal in this Book Review. A veteran of the hardcover bestseller lists.

title: Europe's HighRisk Challenge
description: It is not the platitudinous Bonn summit of the leaders of the industrial nations that now dominates discussion on three continents but the Bremen summit European leaders that preceded it. Economists and political strategists are just beginning to evaluate the importance of the Common Market gathering at which Germany and France unveiled an ambitious plan to tie together the European Community's exchange rates and to back this union with a new international fund.

title: Poems That Mean
description: TREAD THE DARK

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Corporate Moves Fuel Growth
description: THE American Dream of upward mobility has not been lost on at least one segment of the homebuying public  the corporate nomads who pick up and move from one part of the country to another for a better job in their company, or a new job in a different company in the process, transferees not only move up in housing quality for themselves, but they also exert a subtle influence on home values in the areas they choose.

title: The New York Times/Lou Manna
description: Morton and Penny Binn on their PenMor Thoroughbred Farms in Muttontown, L.I., with a young colt

title: Free Trips Work Wonders in Sales
description: Each year, as the deadline approaches, Jack Danzis feels the pressure mounting. You get to the last week, he says, and it's like overtime in a ball game. They send literature to your wife, urging her to push your husband. This year they sent a book on Rome to the house, to let her know what the trip would be like.

title: 2 Held in Detroit Heroin Seizure
description: DETROIT, July 29 (AP)  Two California men have been charged here in connection with the seizure of heroin valued by police at $8 million. Bonds totaling $1.5 million each have been set for Anotonio V. Torres, 39, of Redwood City, and Manuel Rivera, 37, of Huntingtbn, who were arraigned yesterday!!

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Western Perspectives of China

title: TaxCut Group, Meeting in St. Louis, Plans Strategy
description: ST. LOUIS, July 29  A National Tax Limitation Conference, hoping to capitalize on the momentum of Proposition 13 in California, concluded a strategy meeting here today by giving rousing approval to an informal declaration borrowed from the movie Network": We're mad as hell and we're not going to take it any more.

title: Carol Anne Lichtenberger, Teacher, Bride Of Rev. Jeffrey Fishwick in Massachusetts
description: The Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Westfield, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Anne Lichtenberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Lichtenberger of Westfield, to the Rev. Jeffrey Palmer Fishwick, son of Mrs. William Ryan of Madison, Wis., and Dr. Marshall W. Fishwick of Blacksburg, Va.

title: Stabbed Doctor Listed In Critical Condition; 2 Other Victims Fair
description: Dr. Friedrich Friedmann, a 62-year-old physician who was stabbed Friday morning at his office in the Jackson Heights section of Queens, was reported in critical condition yesterday at Elmhurst General Hospital.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING Carriage Houses: Rare and Prized
description: The exterior, living room and detail from door of Jack and Crime Ram's carriage house in Mamaroneck.

title: Foreclosure at Candlewood Lake
description: FORECLOSURE proceedings have been started by Hartford Federal Savings and Loan against the Suburban Action Institute, owners of a 256acre parcel of land on Candlewood Lake. The bank holds over $3 million worth of mortgage loans on the property.

title: Small Classes Do Not Always Lead To Better Education, a Study Finds
description: Smaller classes do not necessarily lead to better education, according to a new Educational Research Service study that contradicts a widespread assumption among parents, teachers and administrators.

title: Melville Would Know the Faces
description: New Bedford, Mass., is a city whose men still go to the sea, from docks at the bottom of town. In the middle of the last century, when as many as 5,000 seamen worked out of this port and sea captains built Federal houses for their daughters wedding gifts, the fortunes of the community rode on the rolling backs of whales. Today, New Bedford hauls much of its life from the fishing and scalloping banks worked by New England's largest fishing fleet, which has been flourishing since the United States gave itself a 200mile limit.

title: Diane E. Devoll, a Student, Married to P.J. Vandermeer
description: The marriage of Diane Elizabeth Devon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willys Devoll of St. Louis, formerly of Smoke Rise, N.J., to Peter Joseph Vandermeer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ray Vandermeer of Grand Rapids, Mich., took place yesterday in St. Peter's Episco- pal Church in St. Louis. The Rev. Edward Johnston of Kinnelon, N.J., performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. George Plattenburg of St. Louis.

title: Mongo Queen Triumphs In Sorority Stakes Upset
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 29George Raboski's lightly regarded Mongo Queen today scored a surprise victory over nine rivals in the $120,945 Sorority Stakes at Monmouth Park.

title: Design
description: Anyone walking into the Manhattan apartment of Daniel Friedman, a freelance graphic designer, is immediately required to rethink his understanding of the natural order of things at least in terms of interior design. Is a rock tied with pink ribbon still a rock, or is it a sculpture, or a piece of conceptual art? Are those heapedup incometax forms domestic detritus or are they carefully considered element of the room? And what about the visitor's own coat? Slung over the arm of a chair which has been covered with many-colored rectangles of fabric all lashed together with nylon rope, it rapidly recedes from any ownership and becomes incorporated into the landscape of the extraordinary living room.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Outdoor art shows may be a summer staple, but that's not stopping Islip from adding a few new wrinkles. For its Fifth Annual Art and Cultural Festival, being held today from 10 A.M. to P.M. on the Brookwood Hall ballfield in East Islip, the town will make browsing (and perhaps buying) easier with continuous puppet show for children, concert by Clem DeRosa and His Orchestra from 2 to 4 P.M. and occasional art demonstrations. Meanwhile, indoors, the Islip Town Art Gallery, at 50 Irish Lane, will have its Summer Showcase, a mixedmedia exhibition by local artists, on display through Sept. 3. The gallery is open from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Wednesdaysthrough Saturdays, from 2 to 5 P.M. ,Sundays and from 8 to 10 P.M. Wednesdays and Thursdays.

title: Building Steam for a. Tax Rollback
description: THE realproperty tax, that inescapable problem for which there appears to be no easy solution, has drawn greater attention on the Island than usual since Proposition 13 in California greatly lowered the property tax in that state.

title: IngJohn
description: Anne Jackson

title: GARDENING Flowering Stones Peculiar Succulents
description: THE early Hottentot people gave the name karroo to the vast stretch of country that lies northeast of Cape Town in South Africa. Although karroo means barren, great numbers of strange, succulent plants grow in that area.

title: The Way It Was: Even Ruth Was Subject to Discipline
description: These recent days have belonged to three wild men  Billy Martin, Reggie Jackson and George Steinbrenner. Their childish ego antics have dominated the sports news. Only Pete Rose with his hitting streak has been able to gain much attention amidst the bellicose bedlam raised by Martin, Jackson and Steinbrenner.

title: Mets Take Day Off After Difficult Loss
description: HOUSTON, July 29  Having been beaten last night as a result of a whirlwind finish by the Astros, the New York Mets found themselves with a day off today  a rarity for a Saturday. The Mets were defeated, 43, in the 10th inning last night, on a line drive to shallow right field that Elliott Maddox lost in the lights. The hit sent Terry Puhl home from third on a play officially scored as a sacrifice fly, although the New York right fielder never caught the ball.

title: LETTERS
description: A Liberal View?

title: BOOK ENDS
description: PUBLISHED in conjunction with the recent retrospective exhibition of the work of Saul Steinberg at the Whitney Museum of American Art was a handsome catalogue that traced the course of the artist's work from his early drawings to his efforts in the 1970's. It contained some 274 illustrations, 69 in color, and a lengthy introduction to the man and his work by the late art historian Harold Rosenberg. Issued jointly by the Whitney and Alfred A. Knopf, it is one catalogue that seems destined to have a successful life of its own as a book. Two book clubs have already taken it as a full selection, and another as an ternate selection.

title: It Was Just a Little Dinner. Party at Versailles
description: PARIS, July 27.  The charity party story is the same everywhere. You buy a table at my event and I'll support yours.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: $uccess without hype. In 1975, the paperback rights for E. L. Doctorow's novel Ragtime were sold for $1,850,000. In 1976, Colleen McCullough's The Thorn Birds went for $1,900,000. This June, Mario Puzo's yet-to-be-published Fools Die, along with reprint rights to The Godfather, brought $2,550,000. Such events are blazoned in publications that usually pay little attention to the world of books.

title: Karpov, as White, Draws Again In Sixth Game of Baguio Match
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 29 The sixth game of the world-championship chess match here ended today in yet another draw, after the champion, Anatoly Karpov of the. Soviet Union, changed his opening strategy under continuing pressure from the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi.

title: Huck Finn Rides Again in Deep River
description: ESSEX

title: Tnki Grace, Finch Alumna, Is Wed to Victor M. Hall Jr.
description: Toki Lee Grace, daughter of Mrs. Melvin E. Grace of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Grace, was married yesterday afternoon to Victor M. Hall Jr., son of Mrs. Herbert Mooney, also of Mount Vernon, and the late Mr. .Hall. The Rev. Paul Jaquith, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the nave of Riverside Church.

title: Author's Query
description: With the authorization of the Bernard Shaw and Frank Harris Estates, I am editing a volume which will contain both sides of that correspondence. Some letters for which I have a record of auction sale, or which are referred to in the correspondence, have not yet surfaced. I would appreciate hearing from owners of such letters or readers who have seen them.

title: POSTAL PACT VOTE DELAYED BY UNION
description: The American Postal Workers Union, facing a lawsuit by a union leader in Pittsburgh who opposes the tentative wage settlement with the United States Postal Service, has postponed this week's scheduled ratification vote.

title: Expert on Bird Dogs Sets 3Ddy Seminar
description: Delmar Smith, fivetime winner of both the National open and United States open Brittany championships, travels all over the United States and to Canada Conducting field-trial seminars. On Aug. 1113 Smith will be imparting his proven techniques at the Delmar Smith birddog seminar at the English Setter Club of America's 340acresite on Route 541 in Medford, N.J.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON U.S. Aid Increases
description: IT sounds like a tidy sum  a Federal distribution of funds amounting to $1,530 a year for every man, woman and child in New Jersey, a gain of one third in such Federal payments in just two years.

title: Flamingos Outwitted By 6 Dummies at Zoo
description: Sr. LOUIS, July 29 (UPI)  Two previous attempts to breed Caribbean flamingos at the St. Louis Zoo failed, so when six more eggs were laid early this summer officials resorted to trickery. They placed the eggs in an incubator and gave the mothers dummy eggs to sit on.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MARIE Citterberg and Betty Sposato were on their way to work one recent morning, walking down the alley that leads from the parking lot to the front of one of Huntington's oldest taverns, Finnegan's Restaurant, established in 1913.

title: Melissa McRoberts Is Wed
description: Melissa Jane McRoberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McRoberts of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Harry Boit Freeman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Jr. of New York.

title: Hunting Witches at the Border Again
description: Two unfortunate pieces of legislation came closer to becoming unfortunate laws last week. The Senate, in a latenight vote, adopted a bill that would reinstate barriers to visits to the United States by Communists. In the House, a bill barring the entry and requiring the deportation of any person who participated in the persecution of another emerged from the Judiciary Committee. Both affront human rights.

title: Elizabeth A. Santos Bride of a Professor
description: Elizabeth Anne Santos was married to Dr. William Stefan Wurzer yesterday in St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Sparta, N.J., by the Rev. Harold Schaeffer, rector of the church.

title: COMPETENCY TESTS OF TEACHERS ASKED
description: ALBANY, July 28  The vice chancellor of the State Board of Regents recommended today that minimum-competency standards be developed for teachers to insure that they were doing proper job in the classroom.

title: Shipping Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 3a VOLENDAM (HollandAmerica). Lett Bermuda July 28; due 8 A.M. at W 55th Street.

title: Dracula Is a Bourgeois Nightmare, Says Herzog
description: The picturepretty Dutch town of Delft eliminated rodents from its cobbled streets and narrow canals 10 years ago.

title: Correction
description: Because of a copy editor's error in Ted Morgan's review of The Last Adventurer (July 9) the Organisation de l'Armee Secrete was incorrectly stated to be the Organization of African States.

title: Top F.B.I. Aide Rebuked for Public Criticism of Civil Service Reform
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has prompted a lobbying campaign by supporters of the bureau but has been rebuked by William H. Webster, the bureau's Director, because of a recent letter in which the official warned that President Carter's proposed Civil Service reform bill could be the end of the F.B.I. as we know it.

title: A Jointly Published Reader On Cozzens's 75th Birthday
description: James Gould Cozzens, one of the living giants of American fiction, will be 75 years old on Aug. 19. The occasion will be marked by .a rare publishing venture  a book issued jointly by university press and a regular trade house.

title: The World
description: The United Nations, largely ineffectual in achieving majority rule in Rhodesia or an end to apartheid in South Africa, took considerable satisfaction last week in approving a plan to transform SouthWest Africa into blackruled Namibia. But self-congratulation may have been premature.

title: William McCue to Marry Julia Brooke Churchman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael S.B. Churchman of Richmond and Aspen, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Brooke Churchman, to William Allen McCue, son of Mr.and Mrs. Allen Lord McCue of Yarmouth and Southwest Harbor. Me.

title: Two Share Lead at 199 By Stroke
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., July 29 (AP)  Howard Twitty fired a fiveunderpar 66 today for a 54hole total of 199 and tied Phil Hancock for a onestroke lead after three rounds of the $210,000 Greater Hartford open.

title: Miss Brennan, W.A. Hastings Have Nuptials
description: Patricia Eileen Brennan and William Abbot Hastings. who are with the Chase Manhattan Bank in London, were married .yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Waterbury, Conn.

title: An Incentive Plan Faces Attacks From All Sides
description: WASHINGTON  Five years ago, a 22member group called the President's Export Council was created to advise the Administration on the ways and means of increasing American exports. The task was considered vital to the nation's wellbeing, and the council met regularly and issued advisory reports as the United States trade balance seesawed between surplus and deficit.

title: `Boot Camp
description: Photographs by Peter Schaaf

title: African Rally Hopes U.S. Joins the Safari
description: Imagine, if you can, a road rally in which the competitors cover 3,000 miles in three days and three nights. They go from sea level to a 9,000foot elevation. That includes running through rain and mud in the low areas, through a desert and up and down mountains.

title: Sally Elizabeth Homer Wed
description: Sally Elizabeth Homer, who is with the First National Bank of Boston, and David Sumner Hansel, who is with Solar Solutions in Sudbury, Mass., were married yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me., where the Rev. Laman Bruner performed the ceremony in St. Ann's by the Sea Episcopal Church. The couple, alumni of Bowdoin College, are the children of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Earl Homer Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. John Parker Hansel of Harrisville, N.H.

title: Fashion What They're Wearing
description: Some of the freshest trends in fashion can be seen right now on bigcity streets, both in America and in Europe. Here are the

title: Belmont Closing Day Marred by Violence
description: New York's thoroughbred racing clan packed its vacation bags and closed the store at Belmont Park yesterday, but not before three horseplayers were injured in a closingday brawl.

title: Gordon Young Will Marry Ellen L. Craver
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Everett Craver Jr. of Charleston, S.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Lloyd Craver, to Gordon Douglas Young, son of Mr. and Mrs William Holton Young of Ancaster, Ontario. A Nov. 4 wedding is planned in Charleston.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: CIGARETTE smoking is under attack from a new source in New Jersey. The State Board of Education, reacting to what called an alarming increase smokingrelated diseases, is trying to discourage smoking among the state's 1.9 million publicschool pupils.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 29  The New York Yacht Club cruise, an event that dates back 138 years, began its annual summer sojourn in Rhode Island Sound today with half a dozen trophies at stake for 66 yachts. The yachts were of varying sizes and age but included two America's Cup 12Meters, France I and Intrepid, which dressed up an already distinguished fleet.

title: The Nation
description: ATLANTA  For the first time in a decade, that tired old warhorse of racism, the Ku Klux Klan, is undergoing modest growth and, for an organization of hooded terrorists that once called itself the. Invisible Empire, becoming increasingly visible. Its new leaders Nicker, stumbling over each other to get their faces, hooded and unhooded, before the public. The message of racial hatred is the same; the

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: As an attorney who has been engaged for many years in the representation of home buyers and sellers, I was particularly interested in the July 9 article concerning inspections by prospective home buyers.

title: Second Quarter Brings Joy to Many a Boardroom
description: With longlanguishing steel companies leading the parade, major corporations showed a generally upbeat record for the second quarter. There were some laggards, but the figures announced last week sounded an optimistic note for the nation's economy.

title: He Mixes Casinos, Ecology
description: TRENTON

title: Danbury Begins to Reduce Services as Voters Reject New Tax Rate
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 29  Mayor Donald W. Boughton has begun dealing with what he termed the winds from California, a decisive voter rejection of a new realestate tax rate that has plunged this city into fiscal turmoil.

title: Standing Before the Bar, Bearing Gifts
description: The American Bar Association, a century old this week, will celebrate in New York City. It should not expect many presents. Lawyers are not popular these days.

title: EGYPT RESISTING U.S. ON NEW PEACE TALK
description: CAIRO, July 29  The United States special envoy for the Middle East, Alfred L. Atherton Jr., was unabld to persuade the Egyptians today that there was anything new in Israel's peace position that would warrant another round of face-toface talks.

title: Susan Beth Greenberg Wed To James Albert Stewart Jr.
description: Susan Beth Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Greenberg of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to James Albert Stewart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart of Westport, Conn. State Supreme Court Justice Lewis Grossman performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel.

title: HOME CLINIC The Art of Replacing That Broken Sash Cord
description: ALTHOUGH modern doublehung windows use spring balances or special types of weatherstripping to hold the movable sash in the partly opened position by friction, many older houses still have doublehung windows that use sash cords and weights to counterbalance the sliding sash frames and keep them from crashing down when raised.

description: CANTERBURY, England, July 29Bishop Musa Kahurananga presides over the 100,000.squaremile Diocese of Western Tanganyika in Tanzania, and, like many of his fellow Anglican bishops in Africa, he faces a shortage of priests in a period of rapid church growth.

description: Ask NeW Yorkers to treeassociate with the Erie Canal and many will mumble about fifthgrade history and mule named Sal. Few realize that the canal is a living waterway, as panoramic as the Rhine, as intricate as the canals of Amsterdam and as strewn with ruins as Rome.

description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 26 Gambling to me is a comic relief, said Daniel I. Engel, a Long Island businessman who flew down to Atlantic City this afternoon to play blackjack in the casino there.that in the near future Cosmopolitan would also begin scheduling flights from La Guardia Airport to the New Jersey gaihbling resort.

title: Council Against Red Aggression Honors General Forced to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who was forced to retire after twice criticizing President Carter, was named today to receive an award from the Council Against Communist Aggression.

title: The Worst Bedfellow
description: By the surprisingly close vote of 59 to 92, the United States has just escaped forced identification with the Interim Government of Ian Smith in Rhodesia. That's the margin by which the Senate defeated an amendment by Senator Danforth of Missouri that would have lifted economic sanctions against Rhodesia for the last three months of 1978.

title: A BlueFlower Mystery Solved Successfully
description: When I saw bugloss for the first time on a neglected country road several summers ago, I didn't even know its name. The wild flower stood proud and erect, its bellshaped blossoms a bold deep blue with protruding --violet-red stamens. I was so amazed by its beauty that I determined to learn more about this majestic wildflower and, if possible, to transplant it to my own garden.

title: Judge Rejects Government Rule On Compensation Over Flu Shots
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Judge Gerhard Gesell of Federal District Court here rejected today as totally inadequate the Justice Department's stipulation on which cases of injury from swineflu vaccine are eligible for Government compensation.

description: LTHOUGH modern doublehung windows use spring balances or special types of weatherstripping to hold the movable sash in the partly opened position by friction, many older houses still have doublehung windows that use sash cords and weights to counterbalance the sliding sash frames and keep them from crashing down when raised.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I'm a younger Grandma Moses, 59-year-old Belva Plain said with a laugh the other day, as she sat in Sardi's lunching on mako shark. What she was talking about was that she, too, had made her first big splash rather late in life, waiting until she had raised three children and become a grandmother three times before she sat down and wrote her first novel, the bestselling Evergreen.

title: Votes in Congress

title: A Decade of Prevention Is Beginning to Pay Off
description: WASHINGTON  Recently, the National Institute for Dental Research here, a division of the National Institutes of Health, recommended that children in areas without fluoridated water have a weekly oneminute fluoride mouthwash to cut down on tooth decay. The advice stems from a threeyear nationwide testing program of some 75,000 children which showed a 35 percent average reduction in cavities with the use of the once-a-week rinse.

title: Headliners
description: Long ago, before the Trojan War, Jason, a Greek shipowner from a prosperous family, married Medea, an enchantress living in what is now the Soviet Union. It did not work out. Last week, Christina Onassis, daughter of megatanker magnate Aristotle Onassis, said she would marry, as her third husband, Sergei Kauzov, a Soviet citizen cloaked in mystery. A shipping official, he is alleged to be about 90 and to lack one eye, but few claim ever to have seen him. Miss Onassis is said to be acting against the advice of friends, who perhaps have read Euripides Medea. Will legend repeat itself? If so, as tragedy or farce?

title: MainBreak's Victims Assail City
description: Angry residents of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn denounced several city agencies yesterday for insensitivity and needless bureaucratic red tape in repairing damages caused by a watermain break that sent millions of gallons of water coursing intostreets and homes in the area last Thursday morning.

title: .Josephine Anne Curran Wed to J.H. Wiesenberg
description: Josephine Anne Curran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Curran of Wellesley, Mass., was married yesterday to James H. Wiesenberg, son of Mrs. Marion B. Wiesenberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Herbert Wiesenberg of West Palm Beach, Fla. The ecumen- ical ceremony was performed in the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass., by Msgr. Joseph T. Tinnelly, a Roman Catholic priest.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29The Iraqi regime of President Ahmed Hassan al- , Bakr marked the 10th anniversary of its accession to power last week by making a strong effort to project a moderate image.

Unknown thousands of others  estimates range as high as 25,000 and 500,000 fled the country.

description: VIENNA, July 29  Chinese diplomats here are expressing concern that the Soviet Union may attempt to win Albania back as an ally, exploiting the ideological rift between the Chinese and the Albanians.

title: Two Sparkling Performances Light Up the West End
description: LONDON arely are a play and a performance so intricately meshed that we wonder where the character ends and the actor begins. This season London theatergoem have an opportunity to experience two such examples of theatrical harmony, each coming not from one of the respected knights and dames of the English theater but from impressively talented younger players  Tom Conti in Brian Clark's Whose Life Is It Anyway? and Kate Nelligan in David Hare's Plenty. The evenings are made doubly significant by the quality of the playwriting. Underneath a comic veneer, each play has something pertinent to say about contemporary sodety.

description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Carter Administration is considering the sale to Iran of 31 advanced fighters fitted with sophisticated electronicwarfare equipment.

title: Bluegrass Days at Seaport Feature Music, Crafts Fair

The sixth annual New York City Bluegrass and OldTime Country Music Band Contest and Crafts Fair will be held at the South Street Seaport at Fulton Street and the East River on Aug. 12 and 13.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: I HAVE been under attack for six months and I began to get bit tired of it, Keith Drake said, explaining his resignation as head of the Westchester=Putnam Manpower consortium. The bitterness perhaps explained why the 52-year-old official did not attend the press conference at which County Executive Alfred B. DelBello announced Mr. Drake's departure and a reorganization of the office supervising the $35 million in federally funded jobs programs uzler Deputy Social Services Cominissioner Eugene Aronowitz.

title: Bishop in U.S. Last Week
description: JOHANNESBURG  Perhaps the most disappointed spectator in the gallery of the United States Senate last week as that body voted to uphold sanctions against Rhodesia was Bishop Abel Muzorewa. For the bishop, it was only the latest frustration since he and two other black nationalist leaders joined the Government of Ian D. Smith in March in return for a pledge of majority rule by the end of the year

title: Around the Nation

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 28 (AP) Representative Bobby Hill, chairman of the Georgia Legislature's Black Caucus, was arrested yesterday on charges of public drunkenness and suspicion of violating Alabama's controlled substances act.

title: The. Saudi Boom's Paradox
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The attire of power has become a triad: To the businessman's suit and the officer's uniform we now must add the Arabiah galabiyya - the newest symbol of worldly success. The Arab world has entered what has become known as the Saudi Era. While other Arabs are in shambles, the Peninsula is lucky again, a major center of financial power.

title: World News Briefs
description: PLYMOUTH, England, July 29 (AP) Two exhausted Britons, pursuing one of the last air records left in the space age, a balloon crossing of the Atlantic, were blown off their course today. They radioed at one point that they might give up their flight to France and ditch their craft in the ocean.

title: Ethiopia Defends Cuba's Right to Give Military Aid
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 (Reuters)  Ethiopia's Foreign Minister, Feleke Gedle Giorgis, speaking today at the nonaligned conference here, defended Cuba for its military help to Ethiopia in Ethiopia's conflict with Somalia. He accused the Somalis of aggression.

title: Opulent Rosenkavalier
description: SALZBURG, Austria, July 28  The Salzburg Festival opened yesterday with a new production of Richard Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier that in the critics view epitomized the festival itself safe, solid and sumptuous.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, after setting a National League record by hitting in his 38th consecutive game: I'll stop hitting when I go 0 for 4 some night. I got 3,000 hits in 15 years, one month and one week, and that's the fastest anybody ever got so many hits. And I'm not over the hill at 37. I've never been a fast runner or good thrower, but my legs and arms are my strongest things. I'm strange.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSINGSluggish Market for HigherPriced Homes
description: THE summer doldrums have swept over the expensive end of the realestate market in Fairfield County  with a vengeance. A dramatic slowdown in activity has caused some asking prices, especially those above $100,000, to be cut sharply.

title: U.S.O.C. to Aid L.A. Olympic Bid
description: The United States Olympic Committee has offered to assume financial responsibility for the 1984 Games, virtually assuring Los Angeles will be the site. Details, Section 1.

title: Beverly Canzater
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Canzater of Hollis, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Beverly Faye Canzater, to Gregory Alexander Jacobs, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Solomon N. Jacobs of Hillcrest Heights, Md. The wedding is planned for next fall in the Corona (Queens) Congregational Church.

title: Canadian National Ballet Gives Premiere of Party
description: When the National Ballet of Canada comes to town, it tends to comes in with a fair sampling of 19th- and 20th,centory masterpieces. One of these will be Marius Petipa's Kingdom of the Shades scene from La Bayadere, to be performed today and tomorrow, and another is Sir Frederick Ashton's living poem  his 1960 ballet, La Fille Mal Gardee, given for the first time this season Friday night at the State Theater.

title: Girl Who Fell 5 Floors Shows Gain in Hospital
description: An 8-year-old girl was listed in stable condition yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital Center after she and her 9-year-old sister, who had been bouncing on a bed in a Manhattan apartment house, crashed through a window and fell five stories to the pavement. The 9-year-old was killed.

title: Janet Oppenheimer Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Oppenheimer of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Oppenheimer, to Kenneth H. LaJoie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. LaJoie of Worcester, Mass. The couple are recent graduates of Syracuse University.

title: ART VIEW
description: One of the masterworks of Western civilization is the English country house. Along with poetry, drama, music and the novel it is way up near the top of the list of exalted pleasures that we should not care to be without.

title: Manilow Returns to New York After Year Recording, Touring
description: Barry Manilow played the first of two soldout shows at the Forest Hills tennis stadium Friday night, and although he insisted that everything was going wrong  spotlights wandering, earphones malfunctioning  everything seemed to be going just fine. It may be that Mr. Manilow was nervous about returning to the New York stage after a year spent recording and touring, for as he kept reminding the audience, New York is his home. But then, Mr. Manilow's stage presence is always nervous and manic, sometimes, one suspects, calculatingly so.

Tomabene of White Plains, and Garry Pottenger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Pottenger of Indianapolis were married yesterday in Bloomington, Ind. The ceremony was performed in the Beck Chapel at Indiana University by the Rev. Robert Shores, pastor of the Indianapolis Christian Church.

title: Return of Billy the Kid
description: Joe DiMaggio was standing in the dugout at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon waiting to take his annual curtaincall when the blockbuster was dropped.

title: Man, Pulled From Lake, Dies
description: MUSKEGON, Mich., July 28 (AP) New Jersey man died today almost 20 hours after he was pulled from the bottom of a lake at Sch-Nepp-A-Ho Camp. ground. Officials at Muskegon General Hospital said that Mark Macellaro, 22 years old, of Bellmawr died at 1 P.M. without regaining consciousness. The police said that he was on the lake bottom five to seven minutes.

title: TEXAS TRASH STRIKE SEEMS NEAR ITS END
description: SAN ANTONIO, July 29  A weeklong strike by municipal garbage collectors appeared near its end today as dismissed workers began to ask for their jobs back. Refuse collection returned to nearly normal levels as replacements for the strikers were hired.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In the last decade, increasing numbers of American corporations have been introduced by the Government and the courts to the world of social responsibility. Increasingly, these corporations are being forced to bend on such issues as energy and consumer needs, labor and racial problems.

title: The Fighting Last Week Reflected a Further Shift of Alliances
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  When Syrian troops and Christian militiamen again began battering each other last week, Lebanon's Moslems, the majority the population, stayed cautiously on the sidelines. There was no need for them to act since the Syrians were opposing their enemies for them.

title: 14 Memorials to Holocaust Are Created by Dallas Jew
description: DALLAS, July 29  When President Carter told Prime Minister Menachem Begin in Washington that the United States was planning its first monument to the six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust, he was apparently unaware that 14 such memorials already exist in this country, one of them of five blocks from the White House.

title: TRIAL SET ON ROLE OF TV IN SEX CRIME
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29  A trial will begin here on Monday in a case that could determine whether television broadcasters can be held liable for the effects of the violence they portray on the screen.

title: CRIME
description: Irwin Maurice Fletcher, better known as Fletch, made his first appearance more than three years ago and promptly won a Mystery Writers Award for his author, Gregory McDonald. Fletch was the book. The following year his adventures could be followed in Confess, Fletch. Last year Mr. McDonald dropped Fletch for the Boston cop Flynn, who had been the investigator in Confess, Fletch. Now Fletch, as irreverent and smart as ever, is back in FLETCH'S FORTUNE (Avon, paper, $1.95).

title: E.P.A. Study Finds That Houston Can Grow and Still Curb Pollution
description: HOUSTON, July 29  Houston can bring its serious airpollution problem under adequate, control by 1987 and still Maintain the rapid expansion that has made it the nation's fastestgrowing big city, the Environmental Protection Agency says.

title: Artists and Craftsmen Find A Home of Their Own in Avon
description: AVON

title: Health
description: Keeping fit is probably today's leading national pastime. Luckily, there's not just one royal road to getting- and then keeping  one's body in good shape. O. J. Simpson and James Coburn, two Americans who are in extragood shape, arrive at fitness from two totally different directions. Mr. Simp- son, famous as a professional athlete, and now a rookie actor, takes his fitness cues from a lifelong physical awareness of every muscle in his body. Mr. Coburn's view  and training  of his body is more tied in with mental, almost mystical, processes. He's also interested in the effects of the stress that is an inevitable part of being a wellknown actor in the frenetic American movie industry.

title: Stalemate After 124th Move Ends Fifth Chess Game
description: BAGUIO, The Philippines, July 30The fifth game of the worldchampionship chess match here finally ended in yet another draw today, after two adjourned sessions last week and a completed sixth game yesterday.

title: Topics Plain Language
description: Some statistics came to light the other day of the kind invariably described as compelling; anyway, they compelled us to groan. It seems Mat almost three million parking ticketsabout a third of those handed out last year by the police and other agencies  might as well have been written on the wind. All those tickets, representing $49 million which will never be collected, could not be handled by the computer because they were illegible or full of wrong information or lacked information altogether.

title: Lemon's Job Now: A Pennant
description: At the'age of 57, as a veteran of 40 years in baseball, Bob Lemon could not be considered an innocent. He has taken a few drinks, smoked some cigarettes and seen his share of women hanging hopefully around the players favorite bars. He also can read, so he knew about most of the crises that have bedeviled the Yankees season.

title: Crime in Coal Industry Investigated By Federal Grand Juries and States
description: ATLANTA, July 30  Federal and state authorities in the South and elsewhere in the nation are joining in a wide investigation into allegations of fiaud, corruption, bribery, tax evasion and related crimes centering in the coal industry.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (AP)  Charles Leslie Dennis, who headed the nation's largest railroad union for 13 years, died yesterday at Augustan Hospital. He was 70 years old.

description: Tax Credit Gives Industry a Boost

title: Waltrip Victor at Pocono
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 30  Darrell Waltrip and David Pearson produced twoman show today that illustrated how theatrical stockcar racing can be. After 500 miles of racing, sometimes side by side and sometimes nose to tail, Waltrip beat Pearson by half a second. As Waltrip put it: It's fun to play games with David. We did it all day.

title: Rose Hits in 43d as Reds Win
description: Pete Rose singled to left in the fifth inning against Larry Christenson of the Philadelphia Phillies in Cincinnati yesterday to extend his hitting streak to 43 games, driving him past Bill Dahlen of the Chicago Cubs, who hit in 42 straight itames in 1894. Only Wee Willie Keel- er's 1897 streak of 44 games remains for the National League mark. After that there is only Joe DiMaggio's 56game major league record with the 1941 New York Yankees.

title: Chicago Merc Seat at Record
description: A seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was sold last Friday for $210,000, the highest ever paid for membership on a commodity futures exchange.

title: Quake in Guatemala Kills 3
description: GUATEMALA CITY, July 30 (AP) An earthquake that struck the city of Patzu yesterday killed three persons and injured many others, the police reported today. They said the quake shook central and western Guatemala and that there were aftershocks today. Many residents of Patzu, 50 miles west of Guatemala City, fled in panic from their homes and spent the night in the open.

title: The New York Times/Joyce Dopkeen
description: A LITTLE MISS ON BIG DAY: As group of young girls marched along Broad Street in Newark at Puerto Rican Day Parade, one scrambled for lost baton.

title: F.T.C. Official Warns On Protein Supplements
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  Protein supplements, which are generally sold as health foods, actually provide no important health benefits and for some people can be hazardous, a Federal official concluded today after long hearings on the matter.

title: AntiKlan Protest Leads to Melee
description: OXNARD, Calif., July 30 (AP)  About 300 shouting demonstrators, some of them carrying iron pipes and two-byfours, scuffled with police outside a community center today while Ku Klux Klansmen watched a screening of the classic D.W. Griffith film Birth of a Nation, the police said.

Galgay of the Federal Bankruptcy Court has ordered initial payments of $161 million to 114 bank creditors in a potential 50 percent settlement and more than $70 million to another group of creditors in a potential 42 to 50 percent settlement.

title: A FEW SLIP THROUGH EAST GRMANY'S NET
description: WEST BERLIN, July 30  The daring escape of three East German students who scaled the wall to West Berlin on dark night not long ago served as a -reminder that despite formidable obstacles the CommUnistbuilt border fortification has remained essentially vulnerable and is still a challenge to human ingenuity.

title: How to Do It
description: Primary requirements for an outboard cruise are the appropriate National Ocean Survey charts; a guidebook to marinas, such as the Waterway Guide; the Marine Atlas Series, for preplotted courses, and Eldridge, for tides and currents. These publica- tions can be found at good marine supply houses and map stores. Hammond's, at 12 East 41st Street, Manhattan, is a favorite.

title: Building Activity Off
description: A large drop in new electrical plant projects brought about a 14 percent drop in overall construction activity for June, compared with yearearlier totals, according to the F. W. Dodge Division of McGraw Hill. The value of new construction contracts last month totaled $14.2 billion.

title: BLIND TRUSTS
description: Public officials increasing use of trusts  devices designed to minimize the potential for conflicts of interest by putting barriers between the officials and their financial interests  has created public confusion and some suspicion, according to Congressional testimony.

description: STONINGTON, Conn.  They're quiet but fearful minority. Pending legislation is designed to rob them of their security and haunt their futures, yet they do not dare to speak up in their own defense.

description: Outgoing

title: A Gymnast With World Goals
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 30 can happen anywhere, anytime. Kurt Thomas suddenly will decide to stretch his legs, even while driving a car. One foot will go to the roof while the other foot remains on the gas pedal.

title: Tax Cut, Crime Bills and Politics Mark 201st Legislature in Albany
description: The New York State Legislature began its 201st session with one of the largest and broadest tax cuts in the state's history and closed the major part of it with one of the toughest revisions to the state's criminal laws in recent years. In the sevenmonth interim, it sent Governor Carey only 798 bills, the fewest since 1930, amid some of the most unusual political wrangling in recent memory.

title: Dissidents in Teamsters Union Meet to Plan Contract Strategy

description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 30 (Reuters)  African athletes were cheered into the Commonwealth Games village when they arrived from Algiers last night, bringing an apparent end to the threat of a mass boycott similar to the one at the 1976 Montreal Olympics.

Glover was appointed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's planning and inspection division Saturday, becoming the first black to reach the rank of F.B.I. inspector. Mr. Glover, 39 years old, has been an agent with the bureau for 11 years, most recently in the Newark, N.J., office.

title: Dance: Solos by Tand_y Beal
description: THE everenterprising Dance Theater Workshop is holding an Out-of-Towners dance series through Aug. 20 at its American Theater Laboratory, with programs by four choreographers and small dance companies from as far away as California and as near as Washington. On Saturday, the workshop's first visitor, Tandy Beal, presentee an flour and a half of solos that proved her to be a deft performer, a choreographer of taste and intelligence, and a somewhat misguided producer.

title: Tax Cut, Crime Bills and Politics Mark 201st Legislature in Albany
description: The New York State Legislature began its 201st session with one of the largest and broadest tax cuts in the state's history and closed the major part of it with one of the toughest revisions to the state's criminal laws in recent years. In the sevenmonth interim, it sent Governor Carey only 748 bills, the fewest since 1930, amid some of the most unusual political wrangling in recent memory.

title: Birth Rate Optimism at Gerber

Such optimism springs from the company's demographers who are predicting that the number of births might approach postwar levels of 4 million a year by the mid1980's. he said.

title: Genesis, Maturing Rock Band
description: ONLY three of the musicians who contributed to the success of the English progressive rock barid Genesis in the mid70's remain. Peter Gabriel, who was the group's lead vocalist, departed in 1975 to start a solo career, and last year, Steve Hackett, the band's innovative guitarist, followed him. But the group's fans have remained loyal, and  their numbers have grown. Genesis filled Madison Square Garden on Saturday night and kept the crowd entranced with a program that consisted of newer material for the most part, despite the fact that the older numbers drew the most fervent applause.

title: Cleaning Up After Dirty Words
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission spoke words of reassurance the other day to broadcasters with dirty words on their minds. His subject was a recent Supreme Court decision that upheld the commission's reprimand of Pacifica Radio Station WBAI in New York City for broadcasting monologue entitled, Filthy Words. It consisted of the repetition of colloquial uses of words you couldn't say on the public airwaves. The Court's decision, though very narrowly drawn, made broadcasters uneasy.

description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell $7 billion of notes and bonds tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday, and dealers in Government securities find the financing more difficult than usual to assess. The credit markets rallied strongly late last week, sharpening their differences in the current debate over the outlook for interest rates.

title: A Call to Broaden The News
description: TUNISCalling for a new world order is no easy task, especially when it means facing the hostile reaction of the developed countries and the big international news agencies. We, the nonaligned countries, see in their attitude clear evidence of a lack of understanding of our aims. For, we merely intend to establish a more balanced exchange of news and thus to promote international friendship through reciprocal knowledge of the world's peoples. We are anxious to create a pool of nonaligned news agencies that would add to the transnational agencies already positive coverage of matters concerning our countries.

title: Clare Meeker Is Married
description: The marriage of Clare Hodgson Meeker to Daniel S. Grausz took place yesterday at, the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Amherst Wight Meeker, in Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I. Roger Hawk, Associate Justice of the Peace of Lloyd Harbor, officiated. Mr. Grausz, a lawyer with the New York firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Grausz of Utica, N.Y. The bride is a law student at Hofstra University.

title: Rafshoon Says Carter Should Go on the Road
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Gerald Rafshoon, the advertising man advising President Carter on his public image, says he wants Mr. Carter to hold more outoftown news conferences because Washington reporters hog the camera and cramp the subject matter.

At first the trend seemed to be mere nostalgia, but soon a number of artists in their 20's began to tackle the 40's seriously, some harmonically  Steely Dan, for example  and some, like Bette Midler and Phoebe Snow, in terms of arrangements and vocal style.

title: Philippine Volcano Active Again
description: MANILA, July 30 (Reuters)  The Bulosan volcano in the central Philippines has begun throwing ash and steam 500 feet into the air after being dormant for 56 years, the Government said today. Officials said a threemile area around the volcano, 240 miles southeast of here, had been declared a danger zone. The activity in 5,140foot volcano, which last erupted in 1922, comes two months after the nearby Mayon volcano erupted.

And, every once in a while, doing something special like learning to fish.

description: The volume of sales in June at 33 of the nation's leading retail chains increased by an average of 16.7 percent over June 1977, according to a compilation by Chain Store Age, a trade publication. The gain is the largest monthly advance of the year.

title: South Yemen to Hold Election
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, July 30 (Reuters)  The first general election in Marxist Southern Yemen since independence from Britain in 1967 will be held sometime in November, it was announced today. The announcement, which said a parliament would replace the 101member council appointed by the ruling National Front in 1971, came less than five weeks after the overthrow and execution of President Salem Robaye Ali for an alleged plot to usurp all power.

description: The cases against six youths accused of assaulting and seriously injuring six men in the Central Park Ramble this month may be in jeopardy because of the way confessions were taken from four of them and the fact that only two of them have been identified by eyewitnesses.

description: TAOS PUEBLO, N.M., July 30 (AP) Juan de Jesus Romero, the spiritual leader of Taos Pueblo, died here today and, in accordance with tribal custom, was buried the same day. He was 103 years old.

title: Residents of Pennsauken Area to Join in U.S. Testing of Electric Cars

They will be part of a Governmentsponsored test to determine whether electricpowered autos are a practical alternative to gasolineconsuming, air-polluting conventional cars.

title: The Lingering Effects of Swine Flu
description: The House of Representatives displayed a bad case of swine flu backlash last week when it voted against spending $15 million for a limited program of immunization against oldfashioned flu this fall. The legislators were reacting against the illfated 1976 swine flu campaign, which resulted in deaths and injuries from sideeffects.

title: Woman, 69, an Apparent Suicide, Found in Queens With $800,000
description: An elderly woman was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning Friday night in a car inside her garage in the Kew Gardens section of Queens. About $800,000 in cash and an undetermined amount ,in stocks and bonds was found hidden in her house, the police reported.

description: New York State's tough new crime legislation will increase the state's prison population by more than 30 percent over the next fiVe years, according to three top penal experts who are planning for a proposed state takeover of New York City's Rikers Island orison complex.

description: BETHESDA, Md., July 30  The first worldwide survey of a rare virus disease that causes mental deterioration and death shows that the infection has been found in at least 41 countries and that there have been unexplained clusters of. cases in some geographical areas, population groups and families.

description: MAZARA DEL VALLO, Sicily, July 30 (Reuters) Two Sicilian fishermen were forced to board a submarine that intercepted their trawler in the Mediterranean Sea. the police said today.

title: MachineTool Orders Up
description: Orders for machine tools, one of the key barometers of capital spending by American business, rose 54 percent in June from the yearearlier figure, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Motorcyclists, Helmeted or Not, Fight Restriction
description: DEFIANCE, Ohio, July 29  Paul Bailey says he would not be around to talk about motorcycle helmets now if he had not been wearing one the day the elderly woman suddenly pulled out in front of his speeding bike.

title: Ireland's Industrial MiniBoom
description: Incentives Spur Expansion of Foreign Plants

title: WEEKEND CAMPAIGNING: Governor Carey waving to Harlem residentsduring tour of brownstones being renovated by Harlem Interfaith Counsel.
description: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 31, 1978

title: StockMonitor Design Sought
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that it has awarded to MonchikWeber Associates Inc. lf New York a $379,380 contract to design a comprehensive market surveillance system.

title: Associated Press and United Press International
description: BALLOONISTS DITCH SHORT OF GOAL: The Zanussi, piloted by Maj. Christopher Davey and Donald Cameron, about to ditch in the Atlantic yesterday after adverse winds almost blew them back out to sea. Above, Belgium Express picks up balloon. Pilots in gondola were picked up by another ship.

title: Chinaglia Sets Mark in Cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 30 Giorgio Chinaglia set a North American Soccer League record for goals scored in a season tonight, collecting his 31st and 32d of the year, as the Cosmos defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 21.

title: Paintings Worth About $750,000 Stolen From Hamburg Museum
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, July 30 (AP)  Thieves stole paintings worth an estimated $750,000, including a Degas and a Renoir, from the art museum here last night, the police reported.

title: A tomary of theActions.TakenTh This Year by the New York State Legislature
description: ALBANY- Following are some of the major actions taken by the New York State Legislature during the first two parts of its 1978 session. The Legislature is expected to return next week to complete action on a limited number of additional matters.

title: Exodus Continuing Of Rainess Partners
description: The exodus of partners from the accounting firm of Clarence Rainess & Company continues, with the announcement that nine of the New York office partners were joining the firm of Brout & Company. They included two of the Rainess firm's senior audit partners and two of its senior tax partners,

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 30  Two top. ranked squads and several New York stars found themselves on the sidelines when the quarterfinal stage of the Spingold knockout team championship began here this afternoon. And there were several littleknown names among the survivors of the previous round.

title: 376 Americans Are Safe After Irish Plane Mishap
description: SHANNON, Ireland, July 30 (Reuters)  A group of 376 IrishAmericans escaped injury today when their plane, bound for Philadelphia, skidded off the runway on landing at this west Ireland airport.

title: Susan Singer, an Editor, Is Married to Leslie Bart
description: Susan Singer of Chevy Chase, Md., an editor with the Transportation Research Board of the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, was married yesterday to Leslie Bart, tournament bridge player. Rabbi Samuel Berman performed the ceremony at the Manor in West Orange. N.J.

title: NONALIGNED NATIONS END DIVISIVE TALKS; PLAN CUBA MEETING
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30Foreign ministers of the world's nonaligned nations wound up a divisive conference here today, agreeing at the end on a series of compromise declarations that avoided taking stands on major political and economic problems.

title: Associated Press
description: A BAD DAY FOR DRIVING: Two people were injured when bus overturned yesterday in Tamagusuku, Okinawa. Accident was one of 56 reported on the island on the first day that traffic switched from driving on the right to the left, to conform to traffic laws on the main Japanese islands.

title: Krupsak Bandwagon Rolling Against the Odds
description: It is lunchtime in lower Manhattan. Like workers around a queen bee, a crowd of reporters, photographers and curious citizens swarms east on Nassau Street, all but obscuring the object of their interest.

title: Chylak Sidelined By Mild Stroke
description: BOSTON, July 30 (AP)  Nestor Chylak, the dean of American League umpires, is recuperating from a mild stroke suffered in Toronto on Friday. Dick Butler, the league's supervisor of umpires, said today that Chylak was hospitalized briefly in Toronto but now is up and walking around at his home in Dunmore. Pa.

title: Municipals
description: Instead of slowing down as it frequently does in August, the taxexempt bond market this week faces an unusually active schedule of financing, with more than $1.2 billion of new bonds expected to be sold over the next five days. Half this total is a $600 million bond issue Massachusetts will sell Friday.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Sailing Surfboard

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day; As I said before, the moves from the Israeli side are negative and backward.  President Anwar elSadat, of Egypt.[A1:3.]; Harmon CoveSecaucus Rail Depot Not Attracting Enough Commuters
description: SECAUCUS, July 30  The monthold Harmon CoveSecaucus railroad station, hailed by officials as a model of cooperation betWeen government and private enterprise for the improvement of mass transportation, appears to have failed to attract enough daily passengers to make it worthwhile.

title: Volleyball, Power Style, Is No Picnic In the Park
description: To most New Yorkers, volleyball is something you play with either a slice of watermelon or a cold beer in one hand at the annual office picnic. It's more popular than the threelegged race but not nearly so popular as the touch football  game. Kids play volleyball at summer camp, but only after all the canoes have been signed out, or as punishment when they haven't cleaned their cabins properly. In a camper poll, volleyball would probably rank somewhere above crafts but below archery.

title: Cauthen's Agent Back in Business
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30  Steve Cauthen's agent had some encouraging news today for bettors who have been losing money lately on horses ridden by his famous 18yearold client.

title: Commodities
description: Coffee Price Stability Near?

title: Armed Visitors Help 2 Murderers Flee From Arizona State Prison
description: FLORENCE, Ariz., July 30 (AP) Three brothers who showed up for visiting day today with sawedoff shotguns hidden in an ice chest freed their father and another convicted murderer from Arizona State Prison, corrections officials said.

title: Washington Watch
description: BudgetCutting By Shortfall

title: Public Relations
description: PETE Rose is a line drive, and Ron Guidry is a snapping slider. But the manager, any manager, is words. They fool you sometimes, the clever ones, and Billy Martin is a very clever one. They rage and charm and bluster until you think the managers win and lose. But what they do is talk. Chatter is a manaeer's occupation.

title: Cattlemen ;Gather in Idaho To Eat, Holler and Grouse
description: SILVER CITY, Idaho, July 30 Along with 2,000 other highspirited visitors, Rodney Hawes; the publisher of The Owyhee Nugget, a weekly newspaper in Marsing, Idaho, ended an ecstatic weekend today in'this southwest Idaho town.

title: 18's Title to Mayotte
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., July 30 (AP)Tim Mayotte of Springfield, Mass., defeated Ray Disco, 75, 62, yesterday and won. the boys 18yearsoldandunder national junior clay courts tennis tournament. Neither Mayotte nor Disco, of Forest Hills, Queens,. was seeded in the tournament.

title: No Time for Hide-and-Seek Missiles
description: One of the ironies of recent history is that the United States invented most of the weapons that, Soviet hands, now frighten it the most. The multiplewarhead (MIRV) missile that once promised great advantage now looms as the most menacing weapon against our underground missile force. And to meet that menace, we are drifting toward a new invention that could have the same boomerang effect.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 31, 1978

title: Pilobolus at American Dance Festival
description: DURRAII, N.C. THE American Dance Festival brought its first season in its new home to a joyous conclusion Saturday night with a performance by the Pilobolus Dance Theater at Duke University's Page Auditorium. Pilobolus is a genuine curiosity. It is a choreographic collective whose members create works communally. And the works themselves are unusual because of the way they transform gymnastic tricks into dancing.

title: DOCTORS FIND FIRS IN CITY FIRE FORCE
description: A special medical team, while crediting New York City's firemen with a significantly better record on sickleave absences than the city's other uniformed services, has recommended to Mayor Koch that sweeping reforms be introduced in the Fire Department's medical nractices.
